HEADLINE: FED CUTS KEY RATE TO BOLSTER FIGHT AGAINST RECESSION

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Acknowledging in effect that the American economy is in recession, the Federal Reserve sent a clear signal yesterday that reversing the decline -- rather than fighting inflation -- is now its top concern.
The signal came in the form of a reduction in the discount rate to 6 1/2 percent, from 7 percent. This is the rate the central bank charges for loans to commercial banks, but since banks rarely borrow from the Federal Reserve -- unless they are in trouble -- the discount rate has become largely a signpost for policy decisions. 
 The signal this time was a strong one, coming as it did as the Fed's top policy makers concluded one of their periodic reviews of the economy. The Fed had taken a few tentative steps recently to push down rates and thus encourage consumers and business people to borrow money to spend and invest, stimulating the economy. But the action yesterday -- the first change in the discount rate in 22 months -- was seen as an unequivocal statement that policy has changed.
 
'The Debate Is Over'
 "The debate is over within the Federal Reserve," said Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers. "Their action is a clarion call that they want rates down and they want people to borrow and spend."
The announcement at 3:25 P.M. listed "weakness in the economy" as the main reason for the discount rate cut. Further evidence of that weakness came yesterday morning as the Labor Department reported that the Consumer Price Index had risen a mild three-tenths of 1 percent in November. [Page D4.]
Wall Street in general exulted, and so did Congress and the Bush Administration. The White House has been pressing for lower rates to avert a recession.
Within seconds of the Fed's announcement, the Dow Jones industrial average shot up 28 points, and it ended the day 33.41 higher, at 2,626.73. [Page D8.] Interest rates on Treasury securities fell, in anticipation of further steps by the central bank, perhaps as early as today, to bring down the rates that more directly affect consumer and business loans. [Page D15.]
At their meeting yesterday, the Fed policy makers, known as the Federal Open Market Committee, had before them recent data showing that unemployment was on the rise, industrial production had plunged, Christmas retail sales were weak and inflation had declined at last.
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said the cut in the discount rate "demonstrates the intention of the Fed to assist in reinvigorating economic growth through lower interest rates." Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, issued a similar statement, endorsing the Fed's action.
For weeks, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and most of the other policy makers had resisted using their power to reduce interest rates, largely out of concern that the higher oil prices resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis would raise the nation's inflation rate. The small rise in the Consumer Price Index apparently helped to convince Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues that recession had become more of a danger than the inflationary impact of the Gulf crisis.
As recently as late November, Mr. Greenspan had been reluctant in public testimony to call the nation's economic slowdown a recession, describing it instead as a "meaningful downturn." Although he apparently acknowledges the recession now, he has indicated that he expects it to be a short, mild one.
 
Other Reductions Expected
 Many analysts predicted that the discount rate cut, which is effective today, would be followed by a reduction in the Federal funds rate and a reduction in the prime rate -- the basis for rates on bank loans to favored corporate customers. Many adjustable-rate consumer loans, like mortgages and home equity loans, are also pegged to the prime, which has been at 10 percent since January.
The Federal funds rate, currently about 7 1/4 percent, is what banks and other financial institutions charge each other for loans. Since banks borrow frequently from each other, this rate is of crucial importance in determining their cost of funds. And it is a rate directly controlled by the Federal Reserve.
When the Fed allows the Federal funds rate to decline, the banks gain the leeway to reduce their prime rate and other loan rates.
Some economists contend that the Fed has waited too long to recognize the recession and take steps to fight it. The greatest concern is that even with lower interest rates, many consumers and businesses will be reluctant to borrow during a downturn that shrinks profits and endangers jobs.
 
Additional Easing Suggested
 Recognizing this problem, Henry Kaufman, an economic consultant, said, "In this case a lot of additional easing will be needed."
Fearing inflation, the Federal Reserve had held the Federal funds rate at 8 1/4 percent from last December until July 13, when it was lowered to 8 percent. Of the four quarter-point reductions this year, one was in response to the agreement to cut the budget deficit and another was aimed at offsetting the credit crunch -- the tendency of many banks, hurt by mounting losses from real estate loans, to restrict credit even to companies planning potentially profitable projects.
Many economists had thought the Fed would reduce the Federal funds rate more over the summer and fall, but Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 once again made inflation the top issue for Mr. Greenspan and for most other policy makers -- the five governors and the 12 presidents of the Fed's regional banks.
But as the economy weakened, so did the inflation rate. Except for oil prices, the Consumer Price Index rose by a mild 4 percent, at an annual rate, from September through November. Recognizing that the slowdown and credit crunch were becoming increasingly more severe -- even threatening the solvency of some banks -- the Fed reduced the Federal funds rate early this month to 7 1/4 percent and also took the unusual step of reducing the level of cash reserves that banks had to hold in non-interest-bearing accounts to make loans. But over the last two decades, the Fed has come to use changes in the discount rate as its clearest policy signal, and its failure to change the rate left doubts, until now, about just how concerned it might be about the economic slowdown.
Some economists had said a discount rate cut was imminent, because the Federal Reserve rarely lets the Federal funds rate fall below the discount rate. Indeed, the announcement yesterday said that the discount rate was being cut, in part, to realign it with market interest rates. Technically, however, this is not strictly necessary, since banks have refrained from borrowing at the discount window, lest it be seen as evidence that they are in trouble and cannot borrow easily in the marketplace.
The Federal Reserve last changed the discount rate on Feb. 24, 1989, pushing it to 7 percent, from 6 1/2 percent. At that time, the big worry was inflation. The central bank was pushing up other rates as well then, trying to discourage consumers and businesses from the robust spending that drives up prices.
The Federal Reserve's governors vote on discount rate changes, acting on the requests of the regional banks, which actually lend the money. Yesterday's announcement said a rate cut had been requested by the directors of nine of the regional banks -- in Boston, New York, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Kansas City and Dallas. The three others, in Philadelphia, Cleveland and San Francisco, later in the afternoon endorsed the rate cut.
Besides weakness in the economy and the constraints banks have placed on lending, the Fed's announcement yesterday also listed "slow growth in the monetary aggregates" as a reason for cutting the discount rate. The aggregates, also known as the nation's money supply, had been growing below the Fed's target levels. A primary reason for the slow growth is that the money supply is affected, in part, by lending levels, which have declined in a weak economy.

HEADLINE: Is a Dream Museum Dead or Progressing?Officials Disagree

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
Depending on who's talking, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, the $46 million dream museum that is envisioned as the world's largest showcase for postwar art, is going under, or going forward.
On Monday, Joseph R. Barresi, the Massachusetts Inspector General, wrote a letter to L. Edward Lashman, Secretary of Administration and Finance, saying that the museum was not a "cost-effective economic development project" and that its sponsors had failed to demonstrate its feasibility. He added that "as a practical matter," adverse findings by John I. Carlson Jr., deputy commissioner for capital and planning operations for the state, "close the book" on the project, known as Mass Moca.
But Mary Sullivan, a spokesman for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who is an advocate of the project, said yesterday, "Mass Moca is not dead by a long shot." She pointed out that in a letter to Mr. Lashman on Friday, Mr. Carlson had said Mass Moca did not meet three of the five requirements for state certification but recommended that the state draft a new grant agreement. The new agreement, Mr. Carlson said, should set forth "very specific conditions that Mass Moca must meet in order to obtain further state funding."
 
Financing in Question
 The museum was proposed five years ago by Thomas Krens, now director of the Guggenheim Museum in New York City, to occupy a vast, abandoned factory complex in the industrial town of North Adams in northwest Massachusetts. It would focus on large-scale art of the 1960's, 70's and 80's, and Mr. Krens said he had pledges of long-term loans of major holdings from the Italian collector Giuseppe Panza di Buomo of Milan, the New York art dealers Ileana and Michael Sonnabend, and the German Architectural Museum in Frankfurt. Now the Guggenheim, in response to a request from Mass Moca's development commission for a collaborator in the project, is seeking to become Mass Moca's operator.
A $35 million grant for the museum's planning, design and construction was approved more than two years ago by the State Legislature. More than $2 million of the grant has been spent on a feasibility study required by the state. Mr. Carlson's review of the much-revised study singles out five "critical areas" of feasibility for the project and says that two of them, the physical program and schematic plans for the museum building, meet requirements for certification.
But the feasibility study did not satisfy him in three other areas: "the amounts, sources and timing of the private capital funding" needed to pay the 30 percent of the museum's costs not covered by the state; the "post-opening management and operations plans for the facility," and the availability of artworks and money for installation. Before the state could give out more of the $35 million, Mr. Carlson said, the new grant agreement should be drafted with the Mass Moca Cultural Development Commission, which oversees the project.
Yesterday Steve Cotton, first assistant inspector general for the state, said: "Mr. Carlson's findings do not preclude the commission from limping ahead on its own. They can still do what has always been open to them, raise $12 million to $14 million in order to call forth the rest of the state grant. But they have failed to raise money for the last year, and nothing suggests a capacity to produce cash in the foreseeable future."
But Joseph Thompson, director of the museum's executive planning group, said yesterday, "The project is still very much alive, and we're continuing the work required to launch it.
Mr. Krens resigned from Mass Moca's commission last week to conform to a legal opinion by the Mass Moca Development Commission's chief counsel that it would be a conflict of interest for the Guggenheim actively to pursue an operating agreement while he was still a member of the commission.

HEADLINE: Sales Down, Christie's Announces Layoffs

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Christie's , the first of the major auction houses to issue its international sales totals for the year, said yesterday that its fall and year-end totals were substantially less than last year's, which has forced it to cut its staff by 10 percent.
Sales since September totaled $651 million, down from $1.06 billion in fall sales a year ago, a decline of 39 percent. Sales for the year totaled $1.96 billion, down from $2.14 billion in 1989, a drop of 8.5 percent. 
 Christie's chairman, Lord Carrington, attributed the reversal to the economic declines worldwide and the threat of war in the Middle East.
 
With Salaries Frozen
 "The United Kingdom, Japan and the United States are in the grip of economic uncertainty, which has been intensified by the situation in the Gulf," he said. "We have therefore decided to take prompt action to reduce our cost base significantly enough to weather the current climate."
As part of that action, Christie's announced it would freeze the salaries of senior level staff and board members and substantially trim its worldwide staff of 1,477.
"We are reducing our head count by just about 10 percent, which takes us back to the head count of the end of 1988, the beginning of 1989," the managing director of Christie's International, Christopher Davidge, said yesterday by telephone from London. Of the 144 employees affected, he said, the largest reductions would be made in London, with 65 layoffs and in New York with 60 layoffs.
While Christie's figures had decreased in Impressionist, modern and contemporary art sales, jewelry did better than usual. Its sale of gems in October brought a total of $31 million, the highest for a jewelry sale at Christie's, Mr. Davidge said.
Sotheby's , which last week announced a worldwide cut of 80 to 100 employees from its staff of 1,400, said it would issue its international sales figures this week.

HEADLINE: National League Narrows Expansion Entries to 6

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Three Florida candidates and three other cities -- Buffalo, Denver and Washington -- were named yesterday as the finalists for the National League's two expansion teams.
The expansion committee, some baseball officials said, is virtually certain to select at least one of the Florida entries -- Miami, Orlando or St. Petersburg-Tampa -- when it awards the franchises by the end of next season. Washington is considered the least likely of the six short-list cities to gain a team unless the financial picture of the prospective owners there improves. 
 The four-man committee compiled the list from 16 presentations it heard during the summer. Losing out were Charlotte, N.C.; Phoenix, Nashville, Sacramento, Calif., two groups each from Miami and St. Petersburg-Tampa, one from Washington and a Florida man who proposed a team that would play in four of the cities vying for a franchise.
 
Softened Statement?
 The Rich family of Buffalo, owner of the highly successful International League team there, survived a near-fatal statement made last Saturday. Robert Rich Jr., head of Buffalo's effort to get a franchise, said that the economics involved in securing and operating a team could make it too costly, adding that "we do not believe in baseball at any cost." He referred to the $95 million cost of an expansion franchise and the cost of signing free agents.
One baseball official familiar with the expansion committee's work said that Rich retracted or softened the statement before the committee met on Monday. The committee consists of Bill White, the league president, and three owners: Douglas Danforth of Pittsburgh, John McMullen of Houston and Fred Wilpon of the Mets.
Danforth, the committee chairman, said in a statement that the cities on the list were the "best in terms of market size, government commitment to support baseball and stadium facilities in place or planned."
"All prospective ownership groups on the short list," he added, "are the most qualified in terms of financial stability, significant community identification and long-term commitment to a baseball club and their community."
Probably the most heatedly contested efforts were made by groups in Miami and in the St. Petersburg-Tampa area. H. Wayne Huizenga, chairman of the Blockbuster video outlets and half owner of Joe Robbie Stadium, was designated as the prospective owner in Miami, which is viewed by some people in baseball as the No. 1 candidate in Florida and maybe over all.
Huizenga, who would spend approximately $10 million to alter his stadium so it could fit a baseball field, beat out a group headed by Abel Holtz, a Miami banker, who proposed playing in a baseball-only stadium to be built, and another group that included Mike Schmidt, the former player.
 
Long Battle Ends
 The designation of Sunshine State Baseball Associates as the prospective owner of a St. Petersburg-Tampa franchise ends the longest area competition. The two cities began jockeying for position in a race for an expansion franchise years ago, and merged their efforts only after St. Petersburg gambled and built a domed stadium.
The winning ownership group includes S. Joel Schur and Stephen Porter, part owners of St. Petersburg's minor league team; Sidney Kohl, a Palm Beach, Fla., developer, and Allen Kohl, a California developer.
The winning Washington group is headed by John Akridge 3d, a real estate developer. The losing group had proposed playing eventually in northern Virginia.
The two new franchises are expected to be awarded no later than next Sept. 30. Their minor league teams would begin play in 1992, and the new major league teams would join the National League in 1993 after an allocation draft in November 1992.
A potentially explosive side issue involves the desire by American League clubs to share in the $190 million the National League will receive from the new teams. In previous expansions, the leagues that added the new teams received all of the money, but American League owners say those sums were meager compared with the current franchise price.

HEADLINE: Is Uncle Sam Getting Stiffed?

BYLINE: By Jim Sasser; Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Early next year, the Pentagon will ask Congress for at least $20 billion in additional funds for Operation Desert Shield. That's just to keep the peace. A full-scale shooting war could cost the U.S. from $1 billion to $2 billion per day. At that rate, all of the $41 billion in deficit reductions we achieved in the budget agreement would be wiped out in a single month.
Though economic issues are clearly of lesser moment when weighed against the lives of thousands of young Americans, the economic consequences of war demand attention. 
 There is a heavy dose of irony in the specter of America mobilizing for a war to protect our economic self-determination and then sinking into economic quicksand beneath the cost of the operation itself.
All of which poses a fundamental question: Where are the financial contributions of our key allies, especially those who have more to lose than we do from a disruption of Persian Gulf oil?
Overall, the Bush Administration, preoccupied with forging international support for the use of American force in the gulf, has given scant attention to the question of who will pay. It has shown little interest in alerting the public to this issue and has exerted minimal pressure on our allies to pay up.
Japan relies on the Persian Gulf for some 70 percent of the oil it uses to sustain its $3 trillion-a-year economy. Its leaders reluctantly pledged $4 billion to the gulf effort -- $2 billion in military assistance and $2 billion in foreign assistance.
As of Nov. 30, the Pentagon reported that its Major Foreign Contributors' Responsibility Sharing Program had received from Japan only $374 million, 40,000 Sony Walkmen and a few Toyotas.
Unified Germany arguably has more to gain from stable oil prices and a reliable new world order than any other industrialized nation. Nonetheless, Bonn has offered just $800 million, and, to date, we have received only $330 million of that sum.
A more glaring case still is Saudi Arabia, whose royal family asked the U.S. to protect that nation's immense oil reserves. A safe Saudi Arabia has been able to increase oil production in a tight market and realize a windfall profit of some $150 million a day. That's at a time when Americans are paying $80 million more per day for our gulf oil imports than we did prior to the August invasion of Kuwait.
The Saudis originally promised $3 to $5 billion in cash and in-kind contributions. So far, they have contributed only $987 million in cash and materiel -- about 6.5 days' worth of their windfall oil profits.
Clearly, something is out of joint. America's share of the cost simply doesn't match our share of the international risk.
The Administration announced this week that it will seek $5 billion in additional foreign aid support from the allies to help Turkey, Jordan and Egypt offset the economic losses they have suffered since the crisis began. That seems a fair and generous course. In the meantime, Secretary of State James Baker should press the delinquent allies to pay their debts to the Desert Shield fund and not to accept "the check's in the mail" as an answer.
Every nation with a definable interest in the Persian Gulf should make a contribution that is commensurate with its interest. With our NATO allies and, especially with Japan, we should make this question a centerpiece for any future trade discussions. Moreover, we now have sufficient leverage in Saudi Arabia to simply demand a greater contribution from that country.
If we don't insist on that, our orchestra of nations against Saddam Hussein is virtually a one-man band.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Who's In Charge?

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Who, if anyone, is minding the store at the White House? What kind of Administration is it that could allow the minority-scholarship flap, without even a high-level review, to flare into fiasco?
 Such ineptitude has not been seen at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue since Donald Regan, then chief of staff to the Great Communicator, described Ronald Reagan's staff as being "like a shovel brigade that follows a parade down Main Street cleaning up." True enough, but infelicitous; and for that and other offenses against the First Family, Mr. Regan soon thereafter got the gate.
 
 This time the victim may prove to be President Bush himself. It's his Administration, after all; and the political climate he fostered led a second-level bureaucrat in the Department of Education to proclaim a major policy decision that embarrassed Mr. Bush and may have destroyed any lingering hope for a bigger Republican share of the black vote.
 In extricating itself, or something, from this dilemma, the Administration not only floundered between conflicting courses, giving new evidence of its inability to guide itself, let alone the country; it further alienated the Republican right wing, which already was holding its nose. That could be disastrous for a Republican President seeking re-election.
 This unwanted and unnecessary rumble came along just when other developments had made Mr. Bush look like the Incredible Shrinking Man: the budget flip-floppery that tumbled him out of the approval-rating stratosphere; his inability to make clear the vital national interest that requires 400,000 U.S. troops on the Saudi border; such unseemly intramural bouts as Richard Darman vs. Newt Gingrich and John Sununu vs. Ed Rollins, all topped by William Bennett's on-again, off-again, gone-again Finnegan performance in re the chairmanship of the G.O.P.
 Now, in recognition of the larger political realities, the President again has had to give the back of his hand to conservative theology. He repudiated the belief, which his Administration had seemed to foster, that no deviation can be allowed from the strictest color-blindness, even in a good cause or to correct obvious evils.
 It need not have happened. No one was agitating for an end to scholarships for minorities; the charge that "affirmative action" sometimes disadvantages some whites -- which might occasionally be true of college admissions policies -- almost never applies to minority scholarships. Nor should any competent Administration permit a policy of such profound social and political implications to be decided anywhere but at the top.
But if the Administration is looking weak, and if the Republican right threatens an insurgency against Mr. Bush in 1992, where is the Democrat to take advantage of the situation? Testimony from Iowa and New Hampshire, where would-be nominees usually are a dime a dozen, suggests that this time around no one aspires to fill the shoes of Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis.
Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, who leads the speculation, did make a campaign-sounding speech to a campaign-like forum, the National Press Club in Washington. He accused Mr. Bush of being more worried about Kuwait than the U.S. economy, which could be a potential campaign theme; but Mr. Cuomo is not confessing to Presidential ambitions and has nasty budget problems of his own.
In view of the President's mounting troubles, no doubt Iowa and New Hampshire soon will receive visits from some of the usual Democratic suspects -- Senators Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Al Gore of Tennessee, for example, and certainly Jesse Jackson. Mr. Cuomo and Senator Sam Nunn are much "mentioned," as is a newcomer from a state not known for Presidential timber -- Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, an honored Vietnam veteran.
The first signs can be seen, however, of the internal warfare that characterizes the Democrats. An unnamed spokesman for the Democratic Leadership Conference -- the organization led by Senator Charles Robb of Virginia, Senator Nunn of Georgia, and other "moderates" -- said the conference hoped to be able to counter the "money and publicity" the Northeastern liberal Mr. Cuomo would receive if he became a candidate.
With the economy in decline, the Administration in disarray, the right-wing conservatives in high dudgeon and the Middle East situation in doubt, Republican prospects for 1992 might seem dubious at best. But with the Democrats in their usual muddle, the oldest rule of politics may nevertheless apply: You can't beat a horse with no horse.

HEADLINE: Banking and Securities Businesses Don't Mix

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Regulate Banks: Less, and More" (editorial, Dec. 10) disturbs me greatly. Over the last 40 years I have been an investment banker, securities salesman and, for a brief period, an employee of a bank. My experience tells me that your recommendations on the proposed deregulation for commercial banks is a terrible mistake.
Banks traditionally have been unable to operate successfully any business other than the banking business. The banking business does not include underwriting securities and trading securities. These activities are absolutely different from the typical cautious investments and loans that banks are in business to make, to monitor and to collect, and thereby make a profit.
If banks are permitted to enter the securities business 5 or 10 years from now, there will be additional losses of a substantial magnitude.
The very essence of the securities business involves risk in trading and in underwriting, which is the kind of risk that bankers should not be permitted to undertake with depositor money. Your statement that "Economists have shown this can be done without endangering the taxpayer" is absolutely untrue.
There are banking businesses, and there are securities businesses. They don't mix, and they don't complement each other. I trust that the Treasury Department will hold against the lobbying of the banking industry to allow banks to enter a business about which they know very little and in which they will not be successful.
In support of my position, you only have to look at the trading positions and losses of any of the major banks in the United States over the last 25 years from their Government bond departments.
 
ELLIS P. EISENSTEIN
New York, Dec. 10, 1990

HEADLINE: Banking and Securities Businesses Don't Mix;
Harsh Medicine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Dec. 10 editorial on bank deregulation addresses a major problem: the diminishing competitiveness of United States banks because of an outmoded regulatory framework. Additional powers, coupled with closer monitoring, will determine whether or not the largest United States banks can safely and successfully compete in the world.
In the meantime, however, hundreds, if not thousands, of medium-size and smaller institutions have a more immediate problem: how to reach a way of living with bank regulators that will reinforce sound banking practice without causing grave injury to banks, their borrowers and the regional economy.
Is there a credit crunch? After small-group meetings with more than 90 of our members, I can confirm that the answer is yes. Have regulatory standards changed? Perhaps not the standards, but the rigor of their application has changed, dramatically.
Requirements for large increases in the allowance for possible future loan losses based on "worst case" assumptions, along with pressure to sell sound earning assets to meet new capital requirements (more difficult to achieve because of the write-downs) are part of the problem.
Equally important, bankers have pulled back from loans that involve even traditional levels of risk, after having experienced (firsthand or secondhand) an inflexible, uncompromising, "white glove" examination procedure that they have never known before.
The result of this fear of making mistakes -- by both regulators and bankers -- is the onset of the kind of economic damage regulation was designed to avert. In short, we are in a downward spiral where values continue to fall, partly because the credit resources that would help stabilize those values have dried up.
By all means, argue for greater freedom and more timely monitoring for financial institutions, but in the crucial short term, excessively harsh regulatory medicine threatens to cripple both banks and their borrowers.
 
RICHARD D. DRISCOLL
President
Massachusetts Bankers Association
Boston, Dec. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: SOCIAL SECURITY IS SHORT OF MONEY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Commissioner of Social Security said today that she would ask the White House and Congress for additional funds because the money provided in the recent budget agreement was not enough to operate the agency through the remaining nine months of the current fiscal year.
The Commissioner, Gwendolyn S. King, said she would ask the White House to release a "contingency reserve" of $146.4 million and was preparing a separate request to Congress for supplemental appropriations. 
 Her plans came to light as the Federal budget director, Richard G. Darman, notified more than 100 Government agencies of his preliminary decisions on their budget requests for the next fiscal year. In most cases, he allowed less than had been requested.
Cabinet officers and other agency administrators have until the end of this week to challenge those decisions. President Bush will send his 1992 budget to Congress in early February, eight months before the start of the fiscal year 1992.
 
Benefits Are Not Jeopardized
 Congress earmarked $4.2 billion to cover the administrative costs of Social Security in the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. But Mrs. King and other Social Security officials said the amount was not enough.
The shortage could adversely affect services to Social Security beneficiaries, but does not in any way jeopardize the benefits of people who are legally entitled to them. Benefit payments are not subject to the statutory limit on administrative expenses.
In a memorandum analyzing the problem, Janice L. Warden, Acting Deputy Commissioner of Social Security, said the spending limits set by Congress "will cause severe cutbacks to public service" provided by Social Security field offices.
"We project that field offices, teleservice centers and program service centers will run out of supplies by the middle of the fiscal year," she wrote.
 
Effect on Training Cited
 Ms. Warden warned the agency's central records office, which makes a permanent record of earnings for millions of American workers, "will run out of both office and computer supplies during the second quarter" of the fiscal year, from January through March 1991.
In addition, she said that as a result of budget constraints, "we will not be able to provide sufficient training to the technicians we will hire this year."
Even low-paid Social Security employees are now expected to work with computers, Ms. Warden said, adding, "We gain little advantage in hiring new staff if we cannot give them adequate training."
Peter C. Toland, manager of the Boston office of the Social Security Administration, said he shared Ms. Warden's concerns.
"From October through early December of this year we have not been able to order supplies like computer paper and forms for the filing of claims, except in real emergencies," said Mr. Toland, who is president of a national group representing Social Security field office managers.
 
Agency's Staff Cut by 21%
 The problems are exacerbated by the fact that the staff of the Social Security Administration has been cut by 21 percent, or 17,000 people, over the last six years, even as the number of beneficiaries was increasing.
Officials in the Bush Administration contend that Social Security employees, working with new computers, are more productive. But Mr. Toland said the personnel cuts "have resulted in reduced service to the public."
Mrs. King said the Administration would ask Congress for extra money to review claims filed by hundreds of thousands of poor children with severe physical and mental disabilities. The Supreme Court ruled in February that the Government had improperly denied benefits to such children, using eligibility criteria far stricter than those established by law.
"Readjudication of the children's disability cases will require a tremendous amount of additional resources," Mrs. King said. She did not specify the cost.
 
Claims for Jobless Benefits
 The Labor Department is also drafting plans for a supplemental budget request to cover administrative costs of the unemployment insurance program. Those costs have soared with the increase in claims for jobless benefits across the country.
Congress provided nearly $2 billion to operate unemployment insurance offices in the current fiscal year. Cheryl A. Templeman, a spokeswoman for the Interstate Conference of Employment Security Agencies, said at least $150 million more was needed to keep up with the increase in claims. The conference is composed of state officials who administer unemployment insurance laws.
Other Federal agencies are also considering supplemental budget requests. For example, Medicare officials said they did not have enough money to pay contractors who review claims filed by Medicare beneficiaries, doctors and hospitals.
Donald R. Cohodes, administrator of Federal programs at the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said the 1991 budget for contractors was inadequate, in part because Medicare officials had underestimated the number of claims.
Without additional funds, he said, those who provide health care "will not be paid promptly for their Medicaid services" and "improper payments will inadvertently be made" from Medicare trust funds.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 20, 1990, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A caption yesterday with an article about the Social Security Administration's budget misstated the setting and age of for the picture of Gwendolyn S. King. The picture was made during Mrs. King's testimony before the Senate Finance Committee last Feb. 6; that testimony was unrelated to the article yesterday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Profit Squeeze In TV Retailing

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
THE "mall in the living room," as some people call in-home shopping by television, has had success attracting customers who like to avoid real stores. But the industry's giant, Home Shopping Network Inc., like other retailers in this laggard Christmas selling season, has found that its customers want bargains, so profits are under pressure from price-cutting and are drifting downward.
Home Shopping is actually a holding company with various direct-marketing activities, like catalogue and mail-order sales. But its main business is selling discounted merchandise -- everything from clothes to can openers -- on cable television systems and on 11 broadcast stations it owns in New York, Miami, Dallas, Chicago and other cities.
 
 And while sales are brisk -- up almost 14 percent for the season and the year -- profits from Home Shopping's television-shopping operations are down about five-tenths of 1 percent so far this year, and they are not particularly promising for the rest of the Christmas season. The company earned a record $38.8 million in its last fiscal year, which ended Aug. 31, on a 30 percent rise in sales, to slightly more than $1 billion.
Investors do not seem sure how to react to the recent earnings slide. The stock closed at $4.125 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up 12.5 cents. The shares' 52-week high is $8.50, and the low is $2.875.
Nonetheless, some analysts suggest that HomeShopping Network -- with half the industry's sales -- will continue to dominate despite the recent merger of two competitors, QVC Network Inc. and the CVM Companies.
"In an industry which could generate $2 billion in calendar 1990, versus less than $100 million as recently as 1985, the company appears to be a stride closer to tracking $1 billion in annual volume," said Robert M. Lilly, an analyst for J. W. Charles Securities, in Boca Raton, Fla. "QVC Network is having a difficult time integrating the acquisition, servicing its additional debt load and realizing a profit."
Mr. Lilly sees 1990 as a transitional year for Home Shopping.
"H.S.N. has quickly grown," he said, "but its execution isn't perfect. It broadcasts to two-thirds of the viewing population but only sells 5 percent. Also, it has succeeded in selling jewelry and clothes, but has not done well with financial services or upscale electronics."
He also said that Home Shopping had a high rate of merchandise returns, about 18 to 20 percent of sales.
Roy M. Speer, chairman and chief executive of Home Shopping, in a telephone interview from company headquarters in St. Petersburg, Fla., conceded that profits were softening. He said that merchandising profits before expenses in November were 34.6 percent of sales, compared with 36.2 percent of sales in October and 36 percent of salesin September. He said merchandising profits were down five-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter, compared with the quarter last fiscal year.
During the holiday season, Home Shopping's best sellers are costume jewelry and gold jewelry sold by weight. Women's apparel has also been popular, with dresses priced from $25 to $80 selling best. Although they are not held during the current season, "Barganthons" in most months help clear leftover merchandise, with discounts of 50 percent to 60 percent off traditional store levels.
Asked if there was a performance measure for television shopping -- as for store retailing, where sales of $200 a square foot in department stores and $400 in specialty stores are viewed as above average -- Mr. Speer said: "It's a spanking new industry, and there's no real format to go by. I guess we are judged by the amount of sales we get in a specified time span. We like to get a yield of $1,000 a minute, but I'm afraid it does vary greatly."
Although shopping by television does not offer the range of goods of stores and does not allow its customers to feel the merchandise, Mr. Speer thinks Home Shopping has some strategic advantages.
Using sophisticated technology to process orders, Mr. Speer said, Home Shopping can be sensitive to shifts in customer preferences and to service lapses. He said first-time buyers become members of the Home Shopping Club, which allows the company to track demographics. He said the club had five million members.
And unlike regular retailing, where the current recession has stunted normal sales growth, at-home shopping "does better in recessions than the normal retailers because we are perceived by our customers as bargain-oriented," Mr. Speer said. He even sees rising gasoline prices as a boon.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 29, 1990, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The Market Place column in Business Day on Dec. 19 misstated the financial condition of QVC Network Inc., a home-shopping service. The company says that it has made all interest and principal payments so far this year without difficulty and that it will be able to make payments due later this year.

HEADLINE: Seoul Voices Trade Doubts

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Faced with the threat of an unfair trade complaint from the United States, South Korea said today that it was reviewing its tight controls on imported food but added that a liberalized trade policy was unlikely.
A top South Korean official, in Washington trying to patch up worsening trade relations, said, "Economic reasoning has little persuasive power in the deliberation about agricultural issues; it is mostly dominated by politics."
Cho Soon, a special envoy of President Roe Tae Woo, said, "The Korean Government is under extreme political constraints, so I don't know to what extent can it liberalize agricultural imports."
Mr. Cho said the austerity program was designed to "arrest fast-growing consumption," but he acknowledged that it had the "smack of an anti-import campaign."
The campaign is seen by some United States officials as a backslide on South Korea's pledge to open markets.
The United States has said it is ready to file an unfair trade complaint against South Korea for its closed rice market.
South Korean and United States trade officials are to meet in Seoul in mid-January.

HEADLINE: MAJOR TO BE IN U.S. FOR TOP MEETINGS

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Prime Minister John Major will fly to Washington on Thursday on a mission aimed mostly at establishing his identity in a country where his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, was universally recognized, aides at 10 Downing Street say.
By the time he heads back to London on Saturday morning, the 47-year-old Mr. Major will have appeared on all the Friday network television breakfast programs, met with Vice President Dan Quayle, had lunch with Republican and Democratic lawmakers on Capitol Hill and spent the night conferring with President Bush at Camp David. 
 He will tell them all a lot of things they already know. Britain stands just as squarely behind American-led demands for Iraq to pull all its forces out of Kuwait as Mrs. Thatcher did, he will say, and he thinks both Americans and Europeans will have to compromise in their positions on agricultural subsidies if a new global trade agreement is to be reached next month, as he and other European Community leaders decided in Rome last weekend.
 
Looks to Success
 Mr. Major hopes to have as much success in Washington as he did in Rome, where he convinced most fellow Europeans that after 11 1/2 years of excited debate with Mrs. Thatcher, here was a quiet man they could work with.
On the Persian Gulf, where Mr. Major will be visiting the 34,000 British troops early next month, British officials say that there is not an iota of difference between Britain's position and that of the United States. But they do worry about the opinions of the American public and of Congress.
"It is very important we try to convince them of the need to stand firm, and convince them of our position," one adviser said. In particular, the Prime Minister will align himself with President Bush's view that Iraq should not be let off the hook for a partial withdrawal from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for a complete pullout, British officials say.
Both in America and here at home, Mr. Major, who was elected Prime Minister by the Conservative Party on Nov. 27, is trying to move out from under his predecessor's shadow.
 
Relationship Stressed
 The Prime Minister comes from a lower-middle-class background and never went to college, takes easily to being called by his first name, and doesn't flinch at the working breakfasts so deeply disliked by members of the upper classes, this adviser said.
"The important thing is to establish relations with the President at the personal level, to establish a presence with the American public, and to make it clear the special relationship will continue," he said.
If the emphasis in America is on the similarities between Mrs. Thatcher and her successor, here at home, where she had become deeply unpopular, it is more on the differences.
Though Mr. Major stands for all the same policies Mrs. Thatcher did, one aide who knows them both said: "Things will be lower key. Life will not be one long crusade."
 
Changing the New Tax
 The most dramatic sign of this willingness to concede error was Mr. Major's decision to review Mrs. Thatcher's unpopular "poll tax," a new per capita charge for local government services. He put Michael Heseltine, whose challenge to Mrs. Thatcher's leadership last month led to Mr. Major's selection as Prime Minister, in charge of coming up with a better system, and ruled nothing out -- not even abolishing the charge and going back to property taxes instead.
Another sign of this less ideological approach to Conservative policy, in the eyes of an influential party figure, was the replacement of Prof. Brian Griffiths by Sarah Hogg, a former journalist, as head of the Prime Minister's policy unit. Professor Griffiths, a devoted admirer of Mrs. Thatcher's policies, was described as "the keeper of the Holy Grail" by one high party official who saw the change as another welcome indication of flexibility.
Mr. Major's low-key performance in Rome last weekend, highlighting not British objections to greater European political and economic union but British suggestions for improving the way the community did things, bolstered his image as quite a different leader.
But, a key policy-making official said, "his whole instinct will be to concentrate on domestic affairs." To hold onto his job in the next election, which has to be held by July 1992, Mr. Major will have to restore the British economy to good health.
 
Economy in Recession
 Now, with inflation at 9.7 percent and basic lending rates at 14 percent to try to get it under control, the economy has slid into recession, with the total value of goods and services generated by the British economy in the third quarter of this year falling by 1.2 percent, according to statistics released today, and unemployment is rising for the first time since the early 1980's.
Mr. Major, a banker, spent most of his Government career under Mrs. Thatcher dealing with financial and economic problems, most recently as her Chancellor of the Exchequer. In that job, he pegged the pound closely to the German mark, at a central exchange rate of 2.95 marks, and aides say he will not contemplate devaluing in future, though Britain's high inflation will create pressures to do so.
In Washington, he will also be concentrating on financial affairs, meeting with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank, and Nicholas Brady, the Secretary of the Treasury, on Friday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances in U.S. After Being Mixed Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher in domestic trading yesterday after putting in a mixed performance overseas.
Analysts said the dollar remained particularly resilient in United States dealings in the face of the Federal Reserve's move late Tuesday to trim a key lending rate. The Fed said it would lower the discount rate, the interest charged on loans to member banks, to 6 1/2 percent from 7 percent. 
 Lower rates are usually harmful for the dollar as they erode the value of fixed-income securities. But the dollar gained some support from continuing worries about the Mideast crisis.
"Concerns about the Persian Gulf are discouraging dollar bears from selling," said Marc Chandler, an analyst at IDEA.
The dollar also drew support from rumors that the Bank of Japan was preparing to follow the Fed's lead and lower interest rates. Lower Japanese rates would be helpful to the dollar as well as United States bonds by widening the rate differential between Japan and the United States.
"The yen was very weak," Mr. Chandler said, noting that investors bought the European currencies and sold off their yen.
Activity was very quiet, and traders predict the coming week will continue to be slow unless tensions intensify in the Middle East, said Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.24 yen to close at 133.27 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 134.05 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 134.05 yen, up from 132.72 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound slid to $1.9316, from $1.9350 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.9310 to buy one pound, cheaper than Tuesday's $1.9430.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Silver Prices Rise After Rate Cut by the Fed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The decision by the Federal Reserve Board to reduce its discount rate helped lift the price of gold and silver yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
The lowering of the discount rate on Tuesday, which was seen by analysts as an attempt to stimulate the economy, particularly helped silver and platinum futures, which had been in a free fall because of concerns about the economy. 
 "Silver and platinum depend solely on economic conditions," said Peter Cardillo, director of commodities research at Jesup, Josephthal & Company. "If the economy can be lifted, then obviously both metals will do better because of lower interest rates."
 
Renewed Fears of War
 Gold traded higher on renewed fears of war in the Persian Gulf. Those fears were rekindled by Iraqi rhetoric following the European Community's refusal to meet with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz.
Also contributing to tensions were reports that Iraq is adding to its forces in Kuwait, as well as word of a planned meeting of Saudi Arabian officials with the United States Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, and Gen. Colin Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Gold settled $9.50 to $10.10 higher, with the active contract for delivery in February at $388 an ounce; the near-month December contract settled at $386. Silver was 13.2 to 14.1 cents higher, with December at $4.095 an ounce. Platinum was 50 cents to $7.70 higher, with December at $416.40 an ounce.
Grain and soybean futures were lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as export trade continued to lag behind expectations.
Helping to push prices lower was news that United States and Soviet officials failed on Tuesday to agree on terms of the $500 million to $1 billion export credit offer made by the United States. Moscow reportedly wants the credit offer to include the cost of shipping farm products to the Soviet Union, a condition the United States is reluctant to agree to.
Analysts said that if the cost of shipping was included, it would leave the Soviets with less money to purchase grain.
 
Word of Deal for Soybean Meal
 Soybean futures were under heavy pressure as a result of word of a major purchase of South American soybean meal by the Soviet Union.
"So much attention is being paid the lack of business from the Soviet Union that people are ignoring the fact that sales to our traditional customers -- Taiwan, South Korea and Japan -- are down," said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, adding that those countries are buying from China, which had a record crop.
"They don't feel the pressure to buy U.S. grains as they have in the past," Mr. Karlin said.
Wheat was 1/4 cent to 4 cents lower, with December at $2.47 3/4 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 3 1/2 cents lower, with December at $2.24 a bushel; oats were 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents lower, with December at $1.05 1/4 a bushel; soybeans were 5 1/4 to 7 3/4 cents lower, with January at $5.76 1/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Funds' Yields Still Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the fourth consecutive week, ended yesterday.
Money fund managers have already noted some downward activity in short interest rates, following the Federal Reserve Board's lowering of the discount rate to 6 1/2 percent, from 7 percent, on Tuesday.
Certain investors, money fund managers said, like to invest in money market funds when interest rates begin falling because fund yields do not change quickly. Thus, they can continue to receive a high return for a longer period of time.
 
Average Period at 56 Days
 In tax-exempt money funds, the average number of days that securities are held in portfolios was increased by one, to 56 days. Assets declined $37.8 million, to $85.6 billion, but analysts at Donoghue's said the change was minimal.
The average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield, up for the third consecutive week, rose 5 basis points, to 5.55 percent, while the 30-day compounded average yield increased 8 points, to 5.43 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The rise in tax-exempt yields continues to be attributed to the large supply of municipal debt securities as communities increase their borrowing before the end of the year.
The current seven-day tax-exempt yield is equivalent to 7.70 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 8.28 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund produced the best return for the second consecutive week, with a return on investment of 6.62 percent. The fund is managed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc., Milwaukee.
 
Taxable-Fund Assets Up
 Assets on taxable funds rose by $1.37 billion, to $420.3 billion, with institutional funds up $1 billion, to $96.2 billion, and consumer funds up by $370 million, to $324.1 billion. Money continued to flow into United States Treasury and government agency security funds this week to the tune of about $437 million, despite the widening yield spread between non-government and government securities, which has made non-government yields attractive enought to forgo safety.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 6 basis points, to 7.42 percent, while the 30-day fell by a similar amount, to 5.49 percent.

HEADLINE: German Link To U.S. Rates

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
German unification could raise interest rates in the United States by at least a percentage point after 1992, a Congressional study released today said.
The Congressional Joint Economic Committee, which requested the study, said in a statement that "if Germany finances higher Government spending with higher borrowing, real short-term interest rates are estimated to be a full percentage point higher in the 1990's" in the United States.
The study, by the Congressional Budget Office, projected that the rate increase in the United States could be six-tenths of 1 percent next year, nine-tenths of 1 percent by 1992, 1 percent by 1993 and 1.1 percent by 1994.
The committee said that much of the money the United States borrows comes from the savings of German people. That money helps to cover the Federal budget deficit and to pay for imports. If the German Government borrows more of those savings for its own purposes, interest rates could rise in both countries.

HEADLINE: In First Gift to the Neediest, a Foundation Donates $125,000

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
A $125,000 gift to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund -- money that could send 100 disabled youngsters to summer camp -- was received on Monday from the Willard T. C. Johnson Foundation in Manhattan.
In an uncertain climate for charitable donations, the check put the fund, for the first time, ahead of where it was at the same time last year. Twenty-five days into the campaign, the fund is $73,587.93 ahead of where it was in 1989. 
 This year's campaign started out last month with $222,034.21 less than the 1989 effort did. Gifts and bequests made during the year are counted in the pre-campaign totals, which gave the 1989 count a big head start.
Officials at different charities said that they were nervous and uncertain about their abiility to improve on previous fund-raising drives, and they cited various concerns -- government cutbacks, hard economic times and more homeless people -- that may mean more people in need of assistance and fewer who can pay for it.
Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, sounded a cautious note in assessing his group's fund-raising efforts this year: "We're kind of holding our own, but we're beginning to see signs that people who feel poorer are reaching deeper into their pockets."
 
More People Need Help
 The Children's Aid Society has raised about the same amount as last year, Mr. Coltoff said, but had hoped to improve on last year's performance because more people need help.
Henry Goldstein, president and chief executive of the Oram Group Inc., a national consulting organization for charities like CARE and the Big Brothers/ Big Sisters of New York City, said that most of his clients have not seen a fall-off in contributions.
Similarly, the Neediest Cases has not seen a drop in donations. Many of its traditional donors continue to send in contributions, and new ones, like the gift from the Johnson Foundation, are arriving for the first time.
The foundation had never donated to the Neediest Cases before, and it came as a surprise to officials of the fund, who had not solicited the gift. The donation is the second largest that the fund has received this year -- the first was a gift of $150,000 from the Starr Foundation of Manhattan.
A Johnson Foundation spokesman said that it normally is an "unobtrusive, quiet giver" and that it prefers to avoid public recognition. Established in the 1970's by an heir of a founder of Johnson & Johnson, the foundation has supported a variety of groups involved in cultural and social service activities.
In a statement released yesterday, the Johnson Foundation said: "The officers of the foundation recognized that it is a very difficult year in New York, particularly for the charities. The foundation believes that everyone should respond by giving to people who are less fortunate. The Times Neediest Cases Fund is one of the most effective ways of doing that.
Yesterday, there was also a $35,000 contribution from a donor who wished to remain anonymous.

HEADLINE: 5th Avenue Merchants Want a Ban on Vendors

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Officials of some of New York's most prestigious Fifth Avenue stores -- Tiffany's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Bergdorf Goodman -- told a legislative hearing yesterday that street peddlers had turned the avenue into a flea market of haggling, hustling and counterfeit goods.
The merchants said the problem was especially bad this Christmas, as peddlers compete with stores for bargain-hunting shoppers. They said the peddlers clog pedesterian traffic around their stores, litter and try to engage prospective shoppers in illegal card games. 
 "New York needs the image of a healthy, glamorous Fifth Avenue," said Ira Neimark, chairman of Bergdorf Goodman. He read state legislators a letter from a customer who had complained that the world-famous shopping district had become "a sleazy main drag."
The hearing by the New York State Senate Committee on Investigations, Taxation and Government Operations was about New York City street vendors. In particular, the committee solicited information about the impact of state-licensed peddlers who are disabled veterans. They are exempt from municipal regulations on peddling.
 
Open-Air Markets
 In April, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan upheld an 1894 state law that gives special consideration to peddlers who are disabled veterans. The court ruled that the state law took precedence over a 1979 city ordinance that outlawed street peddlers from 30th Street to 65th Street between Second and Ninth Avenues, except on Sundays.
As the area's economy continues to slump, more vendors are on the streets throughout the city. The peddlers have turned some parts of Canal and 14th Streets into open-air markets, and on 125th Street in Harlem the battle continues betweeen growing numbers of vendors and shopkeepers.
"Conditions right now are the worst they've ever been in midtown," said Lieut. Robert Louttit, head of the Police Department's peddlers task force. Lieutenant Louttit said many of the veteran peddlers were improperly licensed or not really disabled.
The city has 1,150 licensed vendors, 560 of whom are veterans.
 
'Great Retailing Center'
 "No one wants to deprive disabled veterans, many of whom have joined the tragic ranks of the homeless, from a chance to earn a legitimate living," said Senator Roy M. Goodman, the committee chairman. "But while that right is being protected, our society must insure that it is not destroying a great retailing center which provides employment to tens of thousands of New Yorkers and a shopping mecca for millions of customers."
Mr. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican, said that while the peddlers were a problem throughout the city it is a particular problem for the Fifth Avenue stores because of the area's reputation. He said an informal survey by the investigations committee staff showed 166 street vendors on Fifth Avenue between 49th and 59th Streets one Sunday, selling everything from balloons to fake Cartier watches.
Joseph Kaswan, a 72-year-old disabled World War II veteran who sought the ruling on disabled peddlers, said yesterday that they had been been unfairly blamed. He said he had personally appealed to the peddlers not to sell counterfeit goods and to carry proper papers.
"I am very disturbed when I hear people equating the elegance of Fifth Avenue with the blood of the men shed defending this country," Mr. Kaswan said.
Senator Goodman said he hoped to amend the state law to restrict business times and places for the disabled vendors while taking into account their need for jobs. New York City Councilwoman Carol Greitzer, Democrat of Manhattan, has called for the State Legisature to amend the law so that all veterans are subject to regulations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A street peddler selling counterfeit designer sweatshirts in front of Tiffany's. State legislaters heard testimony yesterday from Fifth Avenue merchants that the peddlers are ruining the street's glamorous image. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Haitian Victor Reported Ready to Soften Stands

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Haiti's President-elect, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has privately told American officials that he is ready to work with the Haitian Army he has long opposed and moderate much of his leftist platform, Administration officials said today.
The officials pledged cautious support for Father Aristide, saying that their main concern now was to help assure that the army and supporters of the old Duvalier dictatorship refrain from disrupting or even preventing his scheduled Feb. 7 inauguration. 
 "Anything can happen in Haiti, but we believe he can take office and then we'll face the next hurdles," a ranking Administration official said. "This guy may not be our cup of tea, but we are going into this relationship with an open mind."
The Administration has concluded that the army's protection of the election and Father Aristide's conciliatory words toward his longtime enemies in the officer corps give Haiti the best chance it has had in years to work out an orderly political system. Officials also said that diminished concerns about Soviet interference in the Caribbean region had eased American fears about political figures like Father Aristide who openly criticize the United States and favor a socialist economic system.
 
'Off to a Good Start'
 Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said the Administration's relationship with the new Haitian leader "got off to a good start" when he, Ambassador Alvin P. Adams Jr., and other American election observers met with the President-elect on Monday. Mr. Aronson requested the meeting to signal to the army that Washington supported the electoral process even though Father Aristide won.
"It was important to send a signal to the Duvialierists and the army that there was no wink and a nod" for them to undercut Father Aristide, a senior State Department official said.
At the meeting, Father Aristide thanked the United States for its support of the election process, recognized the contribution of the army in guaranteeing the balloting, and said he was willing to cooperate with military officers, private business and opposition political parties to unite the country. He also invited President Bush to attend his inauguration. A White House spokesman said Mr. Bush "welcomes the invitation but hasn't decided whether he can accept or not."
Officials quoted Father Aristide as saying during the meeting that "I want to make it clear to foreign investors that they are welcome in Haiti."
Father Aristide's comments came in sharp contrast to many of his previous public statements, in which he called for a social revolution and attributed much of Haiti's problems to the United States' support for a series of past dictatorships.
 
Further Aid Weighed
 Since Monday's meeting, officials in the State and Defense Departments have begun to study ways to increase aid to Haiti, which now stands at about $50 million a year. After three years of granting virtually no military aid, the Pentagon is considering sending the Haitian military medical supplies and perhaps even beginning a civic action program for road and bridge building.
Robert Pastor, a former National Security Council staff member who accompanied former President Jimmy Carter as an observer of the election, said, "Aristide begins with a mind-set that will inevitably cause some problems with Washington." But he said he and Mr. Carter were left hopeful after discussions with Father Aristide in which he gave the impression that he might appoint Marc L. Bazin, the leading conservative presidential candidate, as his Prime Minister. Mr. Pastor said Mr. Bazin also expressed interest in the idea.
Robert I. Rotberg, president of Lafayette College and an expert in Haitian affairs, said, "I've been a pessimist for many years, but now I am an optimist." He said he based his assessment on the fact that the army "secured the election," something that has won the military the kind of domestic and international praise that it has long desired.
Mr. Rotberg said Father Aristide could face serious problems, however, if he moves swiftly against the cocaine traffickers said to hold senior positions in the military. "Then he may confront a counterattack," he said.

HEADLINE: STUDY DISCOURAGES CASH FOR SOVIETS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
A report by four Western economic organizations to be made public Friday concludes that the Soviet Union faces more obstacles to economic health than most third-world countries and that its current disarray is such that a large amount of direct aid would be wasted.
Assessing the economy of the Soviet Union in much the same way they have the economies of Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Nigeria and other troubled economies of the third world, the organizations' analysis is "very much in line" with the Administration's thinking, said a senior Bush Administration economic official, who asked not to be identified. 
 The study was commissioned at the economic summit meeting of seven industrial nations in Houston in July and chiefly drafted by the International Monetary Fund, with help from the World Bank, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which is based in Paris, and the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, based in London.
The study recommends an extensive infusion of technical assistance to help carry out a series of economic revisions. Later, to cushion the impact of suggested changes on Soviet citizens, who for example would pay higher rents once subsidies were cut, the Soviet Union could be made a member of the I.M.F. and World Bank and become eligible for loans to build a social security safety net for the poor and jobless.
 
Access to Global Lenders
 Last week President Bush, in what could be the first step toward that process, proposed a "special association" of the Soviet Union with the I.M.F. and the World Bank that would give Moscow access to the technical expertise of the lending organizations, which have assets of nearly $400 billion.
Administration officials had worried that the report would call for large-scale Western aid far beyond the food credits recently granted by the United States and its industrial partners.
"The conclusion comports with the President's position that direct financial help should not be used" before there is a coherent reform process, the Administration official said.
The report, which has gone through several drafts and was still being revised last weekend, is to be submitted to the heads of the seven nations this week. Those who have seen it say it urges that the Soviets lower the growth of the money supply, cut subsidies, curb wages, lift price controls, overhaul taxes, privatize Government enterprises and make the ruble's value more realistic.
 
An Economic Clean Break
 Still, such changes cannot be achieved as easily in the Soviet Union as in many third-world countries. In contrast to much of the third world, Moscow does not have in place an active private sector or the institutions, like a central bank and a commercial banking system, needed to ease market-oriented changes.
Nevertheless, the study calls on Moscow to make a clean break with its seven-decades-old command economy and speed the efforts President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has already started toward a market economy.
Otherwise, according to a draft obtained in Moscow by The Financial Times, the report warns, of "growing macroeconomic imbalances, increasingly severe shortages, and rising black-market prices."
The I.M.F. role proposed by Mr. Bush "appears to be a way for the U.S. Government to acquiesce in a program of real medium- and long-term aid to the Soviet Union without having to legislate in Congress," said Richard F. Kaufman, general counsel to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
 
Freeing the Ruble
 The report urges that as the keystone to economic change, Moscow establish a realistic value of the ruble, similar to what the Poles did with the zloty a year ago. The exchange rate of the ruble, like that of the zloty until it was freed, is governed by strict rules and controlled by the Government.
Warsaw increased interest rates on holdings denominated in zlotys, making the rate more attractive than it was for holdings in dollars.
The zloty has maintained its value. Under the Polish revisions, prices were completely freed while strong restraints remained on wages, which lowered purchasing power of workers.
Today stores in Poland are well stocked, but most people can not afford to buy what is in them. Because the political situation is more explosive in the Soviet Union, the report, while calling for similar currency changes, does not urge the same degree of control over wages.
Creating a currency with credible value would tend to end the hoarding of goods that is widespread in the Soviet Union and draw more scarce food and other goods backto store shelves, experts say.
"One of the reasons the system is not working is that they don't have a viable currency," says Dr. John P. Hardt, associate director of the Library of Congress and a scholar on Soviet affairs.
The report calls for a three-to-five-year program that would phase in the currency revisions and the privatization of industry and housing. It also urges better legal protection for private enterprise and greater security for foreign investment.
Initial reaction in Moscow has been noncommittal. A spokesman for President Gorbachev, Vitaly Ignatenko, told reporters Tuesday that the report was being studied by appropriate Soviet organizations and that certain conclusions would be drawn from it.

HEADLINE: Dow Ends Unchanged in Robust Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
With only eight business days left until the end of the year, investors moved into the market with a frenzy yesterday, pushing trading to a robust 180.4 million shares, the heaviest level in a week and up from 176.5 million the day before.
But after twice bounding 6 points ahead and twice retreating 13, the Dow Jones industrial average ended precisely where it began -- at 2,626.73. 
 The last time the Dow closed unchanged was when it hit its all-time high of 2,999.75 on July 17. By yesterday it was 373 points lower.
Advances narrowly outpaced declines, 854 to 712. But while 40 stocks fell to new 52-week lows, an impressive 30 rose to new highs.
Showing that stocks were treading water in what was still a bear market, the broader S.&P. 500 index, practically unchanged, rose less than a point. Moreover, program trading played only a minor role in price movements. Birinyi Associates said that one buying spurt just before 4 P.M. lifted the Dow 4 points, meaning that if not for the activity yesterday, stocks would have ended lower.
Crude oil weighed only slightly on the market with prices rising just a penny a barrel, to $26.93, near its low for the day.
 
Lack of Movement by Close
 Explaining the lack of movement by the close, traders said that institutional buyers trying to make their holdings look as attractive as possible and sellers eager to take their profits and get out were both active in the market.
After the 33-point rise on Tuesday in response to the Fed cutting the discount rate, Traders returned to worrying about the growing signs of war in the gulf, dividend woes of the big banking companies, fourth-quarter earnings disappointments, the sluggish economy and crude oil prices that seem to rise and fall with every mood change in Washington and the Middle East.
One of Wall Street's widely followed market services, the Bullish Consensus of Pasadena, Calif., reported that its weekly survey of futures traders showed that only 40 percent -- the lowest this year -- were bullish on stocks.
Richard A. Ishida, vice president of research, said that "90 percent of the people who see the number use it as a contrary indicator," but that "a contrary opinion only works at market extremes," that is, when the market is either near a high or low point.
Noting that the market had rallied sharply from its low in October, he said that rather than signaling a market upturn, the number "means that if you own blue-chip stocks, you're getting an early Christmas present and should get out at current price levels."
Even so, traders said, index funds, which mirror market averages like the S.&P. 500, were actively in the market yesterday and are expected to continue buying for the rest of the year. As explained by one trader, if they buy more stocks in the index, the stocks rise and the index rises, making their performance look more favorable.
Banking and other interest-sensitive stocks looked particularly good yesterday after the Fed cut the discount rate. Although Citicorp, the Big Board's most active stock, fell 7/8, to 13 1/4, after slashing the dividend and 4,400 jobs, Manufacturers Hanover, which kept its dividend unchanged, rose 1 5/8, to 22 1/2, and BankAmerica rose 1 5/8, to 26 5/8.
Freddie Mac rose 2, to 51 1/4; Norwest 1, to 20 3/8; First Wachovia 1 5/8, to 42 1/2; NBD Bankcorp 1 3/4, to 32 1/2; National City 1 5/8, to 29 5/8; MBIA 1, to 28 3/4, and AIG 1 5/8, to 78 3/4.
With gold prices up, gold stocks also advanced. American Barrick rose 1, to 20 3/8; Homestake 1 1/8, to 17 1/2; Newmont Mining 2 1/4, to 36 3/8; Newmont Gold 2 3/8, to 37 1/8, and ASA 1 7/8, to 42 1/2.
Penn Central, which plans to buy up to 5 million shares at $21, rose 1 1/4, to 20 1/8.
Disney fell 2 5/8, to 100 3/4, in what appeared to be profit taking.
 
STOCKS RETREAT IN TOKYO
 TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Japanese stocks fell today after two days of gains. The Nikkei index lost 351.84 points, or 1.41 percent, to close at 24,524.94. In the last two days, the Nikkei had risen 788.87, putting it close to the 25,000 mark.
