HEADLINE: New York's Shaky Bridges Facing New Cuts

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
At a time when engineers are warning that New York City's bridges are in such deteriorated condition that dozens may be closed for repairs next year, city officials are planning further cuts in bridge maintenance and rebuilding, city engineers disclosed yesterday.
The engineers said city transportation officials notified them this week that the capital budget for bridge reconstruction would be cut by $22 million over the next five years. That would be in addition to $252 million in cuts ordered in November and would reduce spending on bridge projects to $930 million from the original figure of $1.2 billion. 
 The new cuts would mean that scores of deteriorating bridges due for rehabilitation over the next five years would not be repaired until sometime after 1995. Many bridges where repair work is being deferred would suffer major structural damage during the delay and might have to be closed temporarily, the engineers said.
 
Many Decks Corroding
 The decks of many of the bridges are corroding and if left unrepaired will develop large holes that could force engineers to close the bridges. Also, the concrete in many bridges is shearing away from reinforcing steel, which corrodes rapidly when exposed to water and pollution.
The engineers said pains would be taken to make sure the cuts would not affect the busiest city bridges, like the ones over the East River. Instead plans are to slow repair work on scores of smaller bridges, ramps and highway and street overpasses.
The city is also considering cutting $2 million more from the preventive maintenance budget, which already has been cut 38 percent -- to $5.8 million from $9.4 million -- for 1991. The $2 million cut would eliminate a program to remove loose concrete from the underdecks of bridges. The program was started in 1989 after a man was killed on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive when his car was hit by a slab of concrete that fell from the deck above.
The engineers, who spoke on condition that their names not be used, said that deferring maintenance and repairs would eventually cost the city hundreds of millions of dollars in emergency repairs and in major reconstruction that would result from the delay in rebuilding the bridges.
Transportation Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio acknowledged yesterday that cuts in bridge repairs would have severe consequences in several years.
 
A Future Crisis Predicted
 "In the short term we are on track, but as we look to the future years, we will be facing a crisis if we are not able to maintain the current level of rebuilding," he said.
A spokesman for the Transportation Department, Joseph DePlasco, said that the agency was still negotiating its capital budget with the city's Office of Management and Budget and that the city would announce the cuts in the capital budget tomorrow.
However, people at the Transportation Department who are familiar with the agency's capital budget confirmed yesterday that the budget figures supplied by the city engineers were correct.
And independent engineers and former transportation officials who have studied New York City's bridges agreed with the city engineers that the cuts would have devastating impact on the bridges.
 
'A Traffic Nightmare' Feared
 "These new cuts mean that the city will be spending far less than is needed to maintain the bridge system," said Ross Sandler, who was Transportation Commissioner under Mayor Edward I. Koch. "The result of this will be bridges in poorer condition, more closings of bridges and dislocation of traffic, and greater cost to eventually repair the bridges."
Louis G. Albano, a licensed engineer who is president of the Civil Service Technical Guild, which represents 7,000 city workers, including engineers and project coordinators for the city's bridge program, said cuts would slow the response to emergencies and result in more bridge closings and billions of dollars in additional future reconstruction costs.
"It will be a traffic nightmare," he said. "Are we forgetting the lessons of the 1970's and 80's, when the city even skimped on rust-proofing paint?"
 
Examples of Work Affected
 One of the bridges that was scheduled for repairs in the current capital program but that will not receive them if the budget cuts are made is the East 189th Street Bridge, at Fordham Plaza in the Bronx. It has large holes in its deck, and concrete is shearing from steel beams and falling onto the Metro-North Railroad tracks below. The bridge was scheduled for $11 million in repairs in 1992, but the work would be delayed until 1993. Engineers said they could be forced to close the bridge and reroute train service underneath.
Also facing delays in repairs is a ramp from North Conduit Boulevard over South Conduit Boulevard, at 84th Street in Queens, which has major corrosion in its deck and abutment and can no longer carry the loads for which it was designed. The ramp, a major thoroughfare, was scheduled to be repaired in 1993 at a cost of $1 million, but the budget cuts will delay the repairs until 1999, the engineers said. The ramp is likely to be closed during this time or to receive costly temporary repairs.
 
Hazardous Conditions Rising
 The city's Bureau of Bridges is scrambling to cope with a sharp increase in hazardous conditions that state inspectors have found in the last two months on city bridges, especially four over the East River. The inspectors have listed 355 hazardous conditions, or so-called red flags, on the Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges.
The number of red flags is growing so quickly that city engineers say they cannot possibly fix them within the six weeks required by the state. Making matters worse are the growing cuts in the capital and maintenance budgets, the engineers said.
Under the latest cuts in the capital program, repairs will be delayed for at least one year on 85 bridges, the engineers said. About 70 of these bridges will receive no rehabilitation work until sometime after 1995.
Leland T. Jones, a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said yesterday that city was still negotiating its capital budget with the various agencies and that "none of these rumored cuts are cast in concrete."
"Everything is on the table now," he said, "but we must keep in mind that we are in a fiscal crisis and we have to scale back. If you devote more money for bridges, it will have to come from education, child abuse, AIDS care or other programs."

HEADLINE: Peru-I.M.F. Loan Accord

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Peru and the International Monetary Fund have agreed on guidelines for economic reforms, clearing the way for new loans, Peru's Finance Minister said today.
"We have reached an understanding on all points" of Peruvian President Alberto Kenyo Fujimori's austerity package, the Finance Minister, Juan Carlos Hurtado Miller, said. 
 The I.M.F., the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank have expressed "broad agreement" with Mr. Fujimori's plans to turn Peru's economy around, Government officials said.
Peru is now hoping that the United States, Japan and some European and Latin American countries will provide about $2.5 billion in low-interest loans and grants next year to cover a gap in its balance of payments and to clear interest that piled up during the administration of President Alan Garcia.
The fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, will be asking a group of countries to provide loans to Peru.
Mr. Fujimori's economic program includes new taxes, the sale of state-owned companies, a cut in the number of Government workers and a reduction in tariffs.

HEADLINE: Oil Price Is Little Changed; Heating Fuels Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Weather, not war fears, had the biggest impact on a generally sluggish oil market yesterday, with unseasonable warmth in the Northeast depressing natural gas even as a chilly forecast lifted heating oil.
Amid lackluster trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil settled at $26.93 a barrel, up a cent, on contracts for delivery in February. 
 Brokers have said the market will probably stay quiet through the holidays, barring major developments in the Persian Gulf.
 
Fears of a Price Plunge
 Although many oil traders have recently decided that war in the gulf region seems more likely than peace, they have not gone on a buying spree. Oil supplies are adequate, and there is a lingering perception that last-minute diplomacy could defuse the crisis, sending prices plunging.
Prices for a barrel of crude oil have, therefore, shown no inclination to move out of the area around the mid-$20's.
"On fundamentals, it would probably go to $20 a barrel or below," said Stephen Smith, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. "If there was war, it would probably go to $40. It's sitting halfway in between, not knowing where to turn."
Without any rumblings of war or peace stirring the market, the weather seemed to take control on some futures contracts.
Home heating oil showed the greatest strength yesterday, rising 2.17 cents, to 77.84 cents a gallon, on contracts for delivery in January.
 
Forecast of Cold
 "There's been a forecast of Arctic temperatures heading our way," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. "It kept prices up."
The fall has been unseasonably warm, keeping demand down for heating oil and natural gas.
Natural gas contracts have plummeted in recent weeks, and the cold weather hitting much of the nation this week was not enough to lift them. Natural gas for February delivery fell 6.4 cents yesterday, to $1.897 for 1,000 cubic feet.
"Inventory for natural gas is simply brimming," Mr. Smith said.
Unleaded gasoline showed little change, rising 0.70 cent, to 67.42 cents a gallon, on contracts for January delivery.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Allies Leave Jordan 'Out of the Loop'

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Jordan's growing isolation is perhaps best reflected in a small notice that appeared today in The Jordan Times: the German airline Lufthansa has announced that it will stop all flights to and from Amman by the end of January.
Lufthansa was the fifth airline to suspend flights to what only a year ago was a major Mideast hub, joining British Airways, Swissair, Alitalia and KLM. Of the major international carriers, only Air France still flies here, but businessmen say it, too, will soon suspend service. 
 Jordan's physical isolation mirrors the country's growing political isolation. Jordanian officials insist that their position on the Persian Gulf crisis -- opposition both to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and to the deployment of American and other foreign forces on Saudi soil -- has not changed.
But recent statements by King Hussein have angered members of the American-led alliance and enhanced the perception outside Jordan that he has sided with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
 
Speeches By King Hussein
 After King Hussein delivered a speech at the opening of Parliament last month implying that Washington's real motive for coming to Saudi Arabia's defense was safeguarding its oil, President Bush canceled a planned meeting with him in Paris. "That speech did not contain a single criticism of Saddam Hussein," an official in Washington noted.
Another speech on Dec. 9 by King Hussein, which he wrote himself, infuriated Saudi Arabia and Egypt. Arab officials noted that the speech never mentioned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, referring instead to the Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait as "the Iraq-Kuwait dispute" and "the disagreement between two sister countries."
The King also endorsed "the principle of compromise" to bring about "an outcome acceptable to both parties." And he linked the need to resolve the gulf crisis with the Palestinian situation, Saddam Hussein's demand, which has been rejected by the United States, Egypt and Saudi Arabia.
A senior Arab official said the King's remarks led Saudi Arabia to conclude that since King Hussein had recently returned from Baghdad, the speech reflected not only a more distinct tilt by Jordan toward Iraq, but also Saddam Hussein's conclusion that he should "hang tough" because Washington would ultimately decide against a military confrontation.
 
'Now Out of the Loop'
 The Saudis have sent signals to insure that Iraq understood that Saudi Arabia would not accept King Hussein's proposed "compromise." The Algerian President, Chadli Benjedid, had planned to visit Amman and Riyadh, but the Saudis told the Algerians that there was no point in his visiting Riyadh without an Iraqi commitment in principle to withdraw from Kuwait. The Algerian press agency said Tuesday that Mr. Benjedid would soon visit Saudi Arabia. But the Saudi message rejecting a territorial compromise on Kuwait was clear.
"The King is now out of the loop," one diplomat here said. "He doesn't seem to understand how angry his traditional friends are at him. Only Syria seems willing to receive him." The Jordanian Prime Minister, Mudar Badran, visited Damascus on Tuesday to discuss the region's water crisis and "events in the gulf."
Jordanian officials say they have no new initiatives to resolve the crisis peacefully. But, they add, King Hussein has no intention of abandoning either hope or his stand against the acquisition of territory by force and the presence of foreign forces in Saudi Arabia.
 
Envoy Quietly Returns
 The officials also say Jordan is not as isolated as it may appear. Officials said that Jordan's Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, Nasir Batayneh, quietly returned to Saudi Arabia this week, and the Saudi envoy is expected back in Amman soon. The ambassadors were recalled several weeks ago as relations deteriorated over the gulf crisis.
Many Jordanian businessmen and intellectuals, however, are increasingly concerned about their country's economic and political plight. "Even if there is no war, Jordan is in trouble," said a longtime friend of the King's. "We have alienated the West, which supported us politically. And we have alienated the east -- Saudi Arabia and the gulf -- which helped sustain us financially. Jordan cannot survive with neither of them."
But most Jordanians, like the King himself, seem defiant. They say they must prepare for the war they hope will not come. At the Al Mahata Civil Defense Center, Brig. Gen. Omar Dandis, a 26-year-veteran of Jordan's civil defense agency, said that by the end of the year some 30,000 Jordanians -- 60 percent of them women -- will have been trained in voluntary civil defense classes that began in mid-August.
"We fear a battle is coming to our area," said Hani Haddadini, 50 years old, a doctor who spent the morning lifting colleagues on stretchers in a first-aid training session. "Our enemy is Israel, first and last," agreed Osama Mreish, 39, a pharmacist and fellow volunteer. "I don't want a war, but we must be ready if it comes."
Like many Jordanians, they are proud of Jordan's stance. And while diplomats in Riyadh and Washington express dismay and bewilderment at King Hussein's policy, diplomats here agree that he has never been been as popular at home.

HEADLINE: JAPANESE TO HEAD U.N. REFUGEE UNIT

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 19

 BODY:
A Japanese professor of international relations and expert on human rights was nominated today to take charge of the world's 15 million refugees, at a time when the relief agency she is to head faces a severe financial crisis.
The United Nations Secretary General named Sadako Ogata, who teaches at Sophia University in Tokyo, to be the next United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, replacing Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway. 
 Mr. Stoltenberg resigned in October after 10 months to become Foreign Minister in the new Norwegian Government of Prime Minister Gro Harlem Bruntland.
Diplomats say Japan had indicated it would try to increase its contribution to the refugee agency if Mrs. Ogata was chosen against rivals from Norway, Italy, Canada and elsewhere.
Although the world's refugees have doubled in number over the last decade, the agency's budget has remained frozen at around $500 million a year after adjustment for inflation. As a result the aid it gives to individual refugees has fallen by half.
Last year Japan was the second largest contributor to the agency, after the United States. The agency is financed entirely by voluntary contributions.
The choice of Mrs. Ogata, who is 63 years old, appears to be popular with the aid-giving countries that finance the agency as well as with the mainly developing countries that are host to most of the world's refugees. The General Assembly is expected to unanimously approve her nomination on Friday.
Mrs. Ogata holds degrees from George Washington University and the University of California at Berkeley. Her selection brings to an end a difficult search that was marred by a quarrel between the United States and the Secretary General over the latter's attempt to give the post to his Indian chief of staff, Virendra Dayal. That ended with Mr. Dayal's withdrawal.
Mrs. Ogata served as a senior member of Japan's delegation to the United Nations from 1976 to 1979. She has also been chairwoman of the United Nations Children's Fund Executive Board and has served as Japan's representative on the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva, which this year sent her to investigate human-rights abuses in Myanmar, formerly Burma.

HEADLINE: Long-Term Treasuries Fall, Reversing Tuesday's Gains

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Waves of sell orders swept the market in long-term Treasury debt issues yesterday, more than erasing the gains on Tuesday that were sparked by the Federal Reserve's first cut in its discount rate in four years, to 6.5 percent from 7 percent.
The selling came in spite of the downward revision in the third-quarter gross national product by the Commerce Department, to an annual growth rate of 1.4 percent from a previous estimate of 1.7 percent. 
 Normally, any negative economic news is considered bullish for the fixed-income market because it reduces the likelihood of inflation and higher yields on newer issues.
In yesterday's bearish market, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent bonds maturing in August 2020, were offered late in the session at 106 12/32, down 1 5/32 on the day, for a yield of 8.17 percent. The day before, the long bond rose 1 1/32, for a yield of 8.08 percent.
"It seems that everyone was waiting for an opportunity to bail out of the bond market and put some black ink on the books," said Andrew J. Schnydrig, money market trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. "When the bond market took off Tuesday after the Fed cut its discount rate, that was the opportunity the longs were waiting for to take profits and run."
In Chicago, the spot December futures contract on Treasury bonds expired at 96.26, down 10/32 on the day. The contract's high, 99.24, was set on Dec. 20, 1989, and the low, 79.30, was posted on July 13, 1988.
Meanwhile, the Treasury's long notes, the 8.5 percent notes maturing in November 2000, dropped 26/32, to 103 14/32, to yield 7.98 percent.
Some selling was also prompted when the Tokyo and London markets showed no response to the Fed's discount rate cut.
Several dealers said the overseas markets would have been more impressed if the discount rate cut had been followed by reductions in banks' prime lending rates. But such reductions are considered unlikely in the near future in view of the poor profit outlook at many of the big banks.
 
Holiday Sluggishness
 Later, when the New York Treasury bond market opened on a weak note, there were relatively few buyers aside from some with short positions who were seeking to cover those positions. But this buying was not enough to stanch the flood of selling, Mr. Schnydrig noted.
Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu, attributed the dearth of buyers largely to the holiday season.
"No one wants to hold inventory, especially at current carrying costs, until the end of the year," he said. "With the Fed not expected to do anything until after New Year's Day, if then, most market participants are busy closing their books on 1990."
The Fed did inject $1.5 billion of reserves yesterday, which usually is seen as a signal for a lower Federal funds rate, but it was not a clear statement yesterday, Mr. Fabbri said, because it came at the end of the two-week bank statement period, a time when many banks scramble for funds to meet reserve and other requirements. Thus the Fed's move could have been aimed at helping banks meet their needs.
"But the fact that the funds traded down to 7 percent, from 7 1/16 percent, after the Fed's move led some to briefly conclude that 7 percent is the Fed's new target for the funds," Mr. Fabbri said. However, the funds traded back up to 7 1/16 percent at the close.
The Federal funds rate is considered the bedrock cost of credit because that is what banks charge each other for temporary loans. Last Friday, the funds traded at 7.25 percent, which was then viewed as the Fed's target.
 
Early Auction Scheduled
 The discount rates on Treasury bills, meanwhile, held firm. The 90-day bills, usually the most immediately influenced by changes in the funds rate, dipped a basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, to 6.60 percent; six-month bills rose a basis point, at 6.60 percent, and the one-year bills rose 3 basis points, to 6.47 percent.
Because trading in Government securities will end at 2 P.M. next Monday, Christmas Eve, the Treasury will hold its next weekly auctions of three- and six-month bills tomorrow.
The Treasury also announced that it would auction a record $12.5 billion of two-year notes on Dec. 26, up from $12.3 billion at the last sale of this maturity a month ago.
On Dec. 27, the Treasury said, it plans to hold its last auction of four-year notes. Starting in January, the Treasury will be regularly offering larger amounts of five-year notes. The final four-year note sale will consist of a record $8.5 billion, up from the $8.25 billion sold at what has been a quarterly auction of this maturity.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Wave of Gloom Over War Peril Covers Baghdad

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 19

 BODY:
A wave of national gloom is settling over the Iraqi capital at the prospect that this nation may be sliding toward a destructive military confrontation with the United States and its allies.
With diplomacy deadlocked, food prices soaring under the pressure of United Nations trade sanctions, medicines in short supply and a whole generation of young men going back into uniform after eight years of brutal combat against Iran, many of those Iraqis who answered a Westerner's questions, in more than a week of interviews, said they were living day to day, hoarding money and searching for mental distraction from the harsh realities of life. 
 Nightly television programming has been taken over by instructional films on evacuation plans, first aid, bomb shelter making and air-raid procedures. The civil defense authorities have announced that they will run an evacuation drill on Friday in Saddam City, the sprawling and impoverished neighborhood northeast of downtown, home to a million Iraqis.
 
Loath to Criticize Policies
 In the police-state atmosphere here, Iraqis are loath to criticize the policies of President Saddam Hussein. But in family discussions and among trusted friends, Mr. Hussein's invasion and annexation of Kuwait have been the subject of intense debate and are widely regarded as unpopular moves, according to dozens of Iraqis, Arabs and Westerners interviewed here in recent days.
Political jokes about Mr. Hussein and his Government, seldom heard outside the home because they could lead to arrest, torture or imprisonment, can now be heard with greater frequency, Western diplomats report. This week, many Baghdad residents have greeted with scorn reports that the Government has distributed gas masks and protective clothing to members of the governing Arab Baath Socialist Party, but not to the population as a whole.
The Government has tried to lessen the burden of the economic sanctions by funneling into the open market tons of luxury items, specialty foods and supplies looted from Kuwait, but there are few buyers. Meat has remained in relatively plentiful supply and prices have gone up only modestly.
New Mercedes buses taken from Kuwait are running the downtown Baghdad routes, but tires for passenger cars are in such short supply that the price has risen from 35 dinars for a pair to nearly 500 dinars.
Iraqis are buying little more than what is needed to survive. "Go to the shops," a young Iraqi professional said. "No one has sold anything in four months."
 
Price Increases of 700%
 One Iraqi businesswoman said, "People will not spend their money when there is this much uncertainty about the future."
Government-subsidized bread and other basic foods remain the staples that feed the nation, but most families must supplement Government rations by buying on the open market, where prices have risen as much as 700 percent.
A 100-pound bag of flour that sold for 3.5 dinars in the summer is selling for 200 dinars this winter. A hundred pounds of rice cost 10 dinars in the summer, but costs 200 dinars today. Sugar has undergone a similar price explosion.
As an Eastern European diplomat noted, the value of the Iraqi dinar has slipped beneath the lowest level it reached during the Iran-Iraq war.
 
Military Registration
 On Thursday morning, all healthy male 33-year-old Iraqis must report to military registration centers, where they will be given a date and time to report to various military bases. The call-up of all men born in 1957 followed a broader call-up on Nov. 23 to muster 250,000 other troops to defend Kuwait and Iraq from attack, according to an announcement by Mr. Hussein. In the first call-up, men born between 1958 and 1960 were ordered to report for duty.
Western diplomats said there were more frequent reports of desertions by young men.
The Iraqi businesswoman said many young men were hiding inside the country, moving from hideaway to hideaway to avoid the military police, who are authorized to execute deserters.
A young Iraqi, Samir, the oldest child in a family of six, got the news of his call-up this week while listening to the radio in his car.
"I served 9 1/2 years in the Army," said the young man, his forehead pressed against the steering wheel. "I have no wife, no profession. I have forgotten my English and accounting and so many things I learned in school because of the army. Where is my life? The best years are gone."
 
Aging Speeded in Captivity
 The young man showed a visitor a photograph of a family reunion at his home recently in which the family welcomed a cousin who had spent eight years in an Iranian prisoner-of-war camp.
The cousin, Samir said, is 35 years old, but his aging was accelerated by life on a half piece of bread a day and two cigarettes a week.
An Iraqi merchant who has tried to employ several returning prisoners of war said they were suffering severe psychological problems.
Another army reservist, who has not yet been called up, lives in dread that he will soon hear a similar radio bulletin. He said most Iraqis would return to the military without question. They will fight to defend Mr. Hussein's adventure in Kuwait because they have no choice, he said.
Under Mr. Hussein, that reservist said, resistance and opposition are snuffed out immediately and brutally.
As a result, the reservist said, "it's a kind of fatalism" that drives Iraqis as they prepare to go back into battle. "People already are dying emotionally and psychologically -- so it is not such a threat for them to die physically," he said.
 
Civil Defense Programs
 That attitude can be found in various forms throughout the country, Western embassies report.
Reacting to the blitz of civil-defense programs on state-controlled television, a Western diplomat said, "I suppose they've got to do it, but it just makes people more and more depressed."
In Saddam City this week, a visitor stopped in a tea house and was invited to play a game of dominoes with a middle-aged man, Qathem Abu Juwad, who said he had lost one son as a pilot in the war against Iran and has a second son serving as an Army captain in the south of Iraq. There is one small son left at home, he said.
Mr. Abu Juwad, in the crowded tea house where many ears were trained on his conversation with a foreign journalist, recited the national rote response when asked whether he was concerned that war was coming.
 
'Practiced in War'
 "We are practiced in war," he said. "We know war and we are not afraid of war."
But as he talked about his youngest son, the one who had not yet seen war, Mr. Abu Juwad amended his comments. "We don't need war because it will destroy everything," he said.
But there is another common expression in Iraq this holiday season, that of hope, which the Iraqi businesswoman said was another common refuge of people who have no control over their lives.
She said many Iraqis become wildly optimistic at the slightest hint of diplomatic progress in broadcasts into Iraq by British and American shortwave radio programs.

HEADLINE: U.S. Adopts New Policy for Hearings On Political Asylum for Some Aliens

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The Government agreed today to stop detaining and deporting most illegal aliens from El Salvador and Guatemala and to adopt new procedures for their applications for political asylum.
The actions, in a settlement of a lawsuit filed five years ago in Federal District Court here, mean new hearings for 150,000 illegal aliens from El Salvador and Guatemala who have been denied political asylum or are awaiting decisions on their applications. 
 Also qualifying for hearings are about 350,000 other illegal aliens who have never sought asylum because the previous system was so weighted against them, said Marc Van Der Hout, a lawyer with the San Francisco chapter of the National Lawyers Guild and the lead lawyer for the plaintiffs in the class-action suit,
At the heart of the suit was the assertion that the Government had not decided on the granting of political asylum in a neutral, non-political manner, as required by law.
 
An Embarrassing Choice
 Such applications have long presented the Government with an embarrassing choice. The United States supports the Governments of El Salvador and Guatemala, and at the same time it is asked by asylum applicants to find that they have a "well-founded fear of persecution" if they are returned home. Every approval of an application for political asylum thus amounts to an admission that the United States is aiding governments that violate the civil rights of their own citizens.
Since 1980 the Government has denied 97 percent of applications for political asylum by El Salvadorans and 99 percent of those by Guatemalans. During the same time, applications for political asylum by Eastern Europeans, Nicaraguans and residents of other countries have a high percentage of approval. For example, 76 percent of applications by residents of the Soviet Union were approved, as were 64 percent of those by residents of China.
In pre-trial rulings in the suit, Judge Robert F. Peckham of Federal District Court held that the low percentage of approval of asylum applications from El Salvadorans and Guatemalans made it futile for those aliens to continue to pursue the usual administrative process for legal residence in the United States.
Under the settlement, the Immigration and Naturalization Service agreed to no longer defer to the State Department regarding grants of political asylum.
 
Praise for the Agreement
 "We hope that 10 years of bias and hostility are finally over," said Lucas Guttentag, director of the Immigrants' Rights Project of American Civil Liberties Union and a lawyer in the suit. "For the first time, Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees will have a meaningful opportunity to secure political asylum under United States law."
Joseph C. Krovisky, the spokesman for the Justice Department in the matter, said today, "The Government believes it is a fair agreement. At this point we have no further comment."
The settlement means that all cases heard since 1980 will be reheard under regulations for asylum processing that were enacted this fall in conformity with the Refugee Act of 1980. Mr. Van Der Hout said these include the establishment of a corps of asylum officers who will no longer report to local immigration service officials, but will rather work at a Central Office for Refugees, Asylum and Parole in Washington.
In addition, the new asylum officers and immigration judges will receive training in international human rights issues. The churches and alien-rights groups that originally brought the suit will designate representatives to help conduct the training.
 
A Humanitarian Gesture
 The settlement also applies to all El Salvadoran illegal aliens who plan to register next year under a law guaranteeing them 18 months of "temporary protected status." The measure, which President Bush signed into law last month, is meant as a humanitarian gesture to those fleeing war in their homeland; El Salvadorans who are living in the United States illegally and who come forward and register obtain the right to live and work here temporarily.
Under the settlement, Mr. Van Der Hout said, those aliens can apply for political asylum at the end of the 18 months rather than face deportation. All those who have begun the asylum process may legally work in the United States.
The settlement averts a trial on the Government's immigration policies. Judge Peckham had ruled last year that such a trial could proceed on the aliens' claims of discriminatory denial of asylum in violation of their constitutional rights to free speech, equal protection and due process.
The judge has signed the preliminary settlement agreement and scheduled a final hearing for Jan. 31. In anticipation of the settlement, lawyers for the aliens said, the immigration service issued a memorandum last week halting the scheduled deportations of El Salvadorans and Guatemalans. It began taking applications for release from border detention centers today.
"This settlement is a major victory for all Salvadorans and Guatemalans in this country whose claims for political asylum were being summarily denied for purely foreign policy reasons," Mr. Van Der Hout said. "The tragedy, however, is that it took 10 years for the Government to reverse its policy of putting support for the military governments of El Salvador and Guatemala over its human rights oblications to grant asylum to legitimate refugees."
 
Campaign to Find Aliens
 The Government has agreed to allocate $200,000 to work with churches, refugee social service centers and advocacy groups to locate illegal aliens who are affected by the settlement. The campaign will concentrate on the eight cities with the largest numbers of El Salvadoran and Guatemalan aliens: San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York, Washington, Miami, Houston, Dallas and Chicago.
In response to arguments that the immigration service repeatedly deferred to State Department wishes in ruling on asylum applications, the Government specified that certain factors would no longer be proper for consideration in determining eligibility for political asylum. They are American foreign policy, border control and an applicant's coming from a country supported politically by the United States.
The lawsuit was filed in May 1985, a time when religious leaders and lay workers were offering sanctuary to El Salvadorans and others fleeing fighting in Central America and when the Government was charging sanctuary workers with violations of Federal law by assisting illegal aliens.
The suit originally sought to bar the Justice Department from prosecuting sanctuary workers, who claimed a constitutional right under the First Amendment's clause on free exercise of religion to protect people they viewed as refugees. It also charged discriminatory treatment in asylum and deportation of Central Americans who claimed to be refugees.
 
Redrafting the Lawsuit
 In a series of rulings, Judge Peckham dismissed the sanctuary workers' claims but allowed the suit to go forward on behalf of the illegal aliens. It was redrafted as a class-action case on behalf of all El Salvadoran and Guatemalan immigrants.
The Rev. Gustav H. Schultz, president of the National Sanctuary Defense Fund, called the settlement announced today "a vindication of the hundreds of people in the sanctuary movement who put life and liberty on the line to assist Central American refugees who were fleeing for their lives."
The Government has consistently argued that illegal aliens from Central America are not political refugees, but are economic refugees who come to the United States looking for jobs.
 
Reason Is 'Obvious'
 But one of the plaintiffs in the lawsuit, Reginaldo Velasquez, who first fled El Salvador in 1980, said in an interview, "It is obvious that the war is what brings us up here. The reason why we come is political."
Mr. Velasquez, 28 years old, said he was a student in Uluazapa when he organized a local chapter of the Green Cross, an organization of relief workers that helps civilians and fighters on both sides of El Salvador's civil war. When several co-workers either disappeared or were killed, he fled to Mexico in 1980. He was caught and deported, but in 1984 he fled again. This time he was arrested in Texas just after crossing the Rio Grande.
Mr. Velasquez applied for asylum, and it was denied. He has been working as a cook in a San Francisco restaurant while waiting for a ruling from the Board of Immigration Appeals.
He said that he would like to return to Uluazapa, but that relatives have told him that soldiers still come to the house looking for him.
"Nothing has changed," Mr. Velasquez said. "The military people are still there, and they know me. Many people have died like this, and it could happen to me."
His hope is to gain political asylum in the United States.
"I always have doubts, but I think it's a very good chance," he said of today's settlement. "Perhaps this time things will be seen with a more human view."

Like about 97 percent of all applications for political asylum from El Salvadorans, his was denied. It is under appeal. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate Is Cut to 1.4% In Revision for 3d Quarter

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The economy was even weaker than previously feared in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported today. It said the gross national product grew during the period at an anemic 1.4 percent rate, compared with its previous estimate of 1.7 percent.
Today's report was the second and final revision for the G.N.P., the central figure used to determine whether the economy is growing. 
 Many economists say the G.N.P. began to shrink this quarter and will continue to do so through the first quarter of next year, meeting the traditional definition of recession, which is two successive quarters in which growth shows a decline.
 
Focus on Credit Policy
 Alan Levenson, director of financial services at the WEFA Group, said that cheaper credit was needed to prod the economy back to life.
Indeed, the economy's weakness has led the Federal Reserve's policy makers, who had focused their efforts on fighting inflation, to reverse course and fight recession instead, by easing credit.
The central bank pumped money into the banking system today in a move that analysts said was intended to push down the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other on overnight loans. The action followed the Fed's decision late Tuesday to cut the discount rate, which is what it charges on loans to member banks.
The moves send a strong signal to major banks to start cutting their prime lending rates, now at 10 percent. Cheaper credit might encourage borrowing and spending.
Weaker consumer spending accounted for much of the decline in G.N.P.. That component grew by only $18 billion, down from last month's estimate of $20.9 billion, the Commerce Department said. Consumer spending is critical to growth because it accounts for about two-thirds of economic activity.
 
Exports Falter
 Export sales provided no lift. They fell $1.9 billion, a revision from the previous estimate of a drop of $500 million.
"With exports not roaring and the consumer pulling back, that takes out the twin engines of growth that were keeping things moving," said Jean Sundrla of Evans Economics Inc.
Financial markets shrugged off the G.N.P. figures, with stocks little changed.
Robert McGee, economist at Tokai Bank Ltd., termed the data "ancient history," saying, "It is clear from fourth-quarter statistics so far that growth has turned negative."

HEADLINE: Manhattan Man Held In Slaying of Nephew

 BODY:
A 22-year-old Manhattan man was arrested last night and charged with beating his 15-month-old nephew to death to stop the child from crying, the police said.
The suspect, William Vega, of 70 West 115th Street, called 911 just after 9 P.M. on Tuesday for medical help for the child, a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Mary Wrensen, said.
The child, Antoine Grady, was taken to St. Luke's Hospital, where he was pronounced dead on arrival.
The boy's injuries indicated that he had been beaten and kicked, Sergeant Wrensen said. Mr. Vega, who is unemployed, was charged with second-degree murder and endangering the welfare of a minor, she said.
The police said the child's mother, who was not identified, brought him from North Carolina just before Thanksgiving and had recently returned there, leaving the boy in Mr. Vega's care.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Drops Plan to Require Waste Incinerators to Recycle

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Bowing to strong objections from a White House panel, the Environmental Protection Agency reluctantly agreed today to drop a planned requirement that incinerators recycle a quarter of their incoming garbage.
The recycling proposal met stiff resistance earlier in the day at a meeting of the President's Council on Competitiveness. Among those attending the White House meeting was the environmental agency's Administrator, William K. Reilly, who said afterward that the provision would be deleted from a regulation on incinerators that his agency is to adopt on Dec. 31. 
 Mr. Reilly said he decided during the meeting that the regulation was not the "appropriate vehicle for a major mandatory program with significant potential to disrupt local government plans" for incineration programs that could generate electricity and thus reduce the demand for new power plants.
 
Plight of Cities
 The regulation, issued in draft form a year ago, will set stricter air pollution standards for trash burning at a time when an increasing number of communities see incineration as a means of dealing with a growing shortage of landfill space, especially in the East.
Environmentalists had campaigned vigorously to include a recycling provision in the regulation, arguing that the requirement would reduce the amount of wastes burned and, therefore, air pollution.
"This is a major environmental retreat," said David Doniger, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council. "The Administration is retreating on its own commitment for recycling."
The waste disposal industry had opposed the recycling provision. Allen Moore, president of the National Solid Waste Management Association, recently said in a letter to Mr. Reilly: "Waste combustion is now seen as a cost-effective and environmentally sound means of solid waste management for many communities. This could change if burdensome, and perhaps costly, recycling requirements are a condition."
 
Stiff Opposition
 Administration officials knowledgeable about the White House discussions today said that Mr. Reilly had argued in favor of the recycling provision but had found stiff opposition from members of the Council on Competitiveness, a regulatory review panel that is headed by Vice President Dan Quayle.
Among those reported to have argued against the provision were Deputy Energy Secretary Henson W. Moore; Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
 Mr. Reilly could have appealed the matter to President Bush, but he declined to do so.
Critics of the provision maintained that the costs of recycling a quarter of the garbage destined for incineration outweighed the benefits and could hinder development of waste-to-energy programs in some communities. They argued that the issue of recycling should be dealt with separately next year.

HEADLINE: Struggle at White House;
Mishandling of Scholarships for Minorities Reflects Search for a Civil Rights Agenda

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The White House's tortured handling of scholarships for minorities reflects both the disarray in President Bush's domestic policy management and a fierce struggle for the civil rights agenda in the top levels of the Administration.
 That struggle resumed with a new intensity from the moment Mr. Bush woke up on the morning of Dec. 12 to news reports of the Education Department's decision to prohibit federally subsidized institutions from designating scholarships for specific minority groups. 
 Surprised and reportedly disturbed, the President ordered his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, to find a way to retreat from the ruling, which was not only politically damaging but also challenged Mr. Bush's commitment to minority scholarship programs.
 
Trying to Please Both Sides
 Panicked White House officials clashed over policy and tactics in a series of contentious meetings that concluded, as has happened so often in Mr. Bush's tenure, with the White House trying to please both sides and, in the view of critics and supporters alike, pleasing virtually nobody, including the President himself.
Mr. Bush expressed concern that there would be a court challenge of the new ruling, which allowed use of private money specifically designated for minorities but not money from a college's general operating funds. And some Administration officials worried that the split-the-difference approach would not only undercut the President's position opposing racial quotas, but would also leave the White House grappling for months with an issue that should have been laid to rest.
Under the revised proposal announced Tuesday by Michael L. Williams, the Assistant Secretary of Education for civil rights, there will be a four-year transition period during which "the Administration will not pursue a broad compliance review," thereby giving the Administration some leeway.
 
A Lack of Direction
 "It's the central impulse of the Bush Administration -- why can't everyone be satisfied?" said an adviser to the White House, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Administration officials and Republican strategists said the fact that no senior White House official knew the change in policy was even being contemplated reflected a lack of direction and a lack of an "ideological compass" on domestic issues.
"If it were a different kind of Administration you could argue that someone would have known about the shift or that Bush's policy would have been so clear that Williams wouldn't have done it in the first place," one official said.
He added: "If it were a different kind of Administration, it wouldn't have been so hard to react. People didn't immediately fall into their grooves and say, 'This is what we have to do,' because people don't necessarily know where their grooves are."
 
'Constant Tension and Pressure'
 Stuart E. Eizenstat, who was President Jimmy Carter's domestic policy adviser, said the scholarships issue was part of a much broader problem.
"Bush has had to make common cause on issues from the budget to clean air and civil rights with a majority of Democrats in Congress who are to his left," Mr. Eizenstat said. "He is postured within his own party in the middle, while the interest groups, the outside advocates and the Young Turks on the Hill who are the most vocal are to his right. So you get constant tension and pressure, and the domestic policy of the Administration is Janus-like."
But the uproar over the scholarship issue was a case study more specifically in why it is so difficult for the Bush Administration to deal with civil rights issues as it tries to mollify conservative Republicans, woo Democrats who once voted for Ronald Reagan and mend fences with minority groups.
In part this is a reflection of one of the most fundamental battles in Republican politics, between movement conservatives who oppose all forms of racial quotas and establishment, government-oriented Republicans like Mr. Bush who operate largely according to pragmatism and support affirmative action.
 
Another Political Dimension
 Some officials, like C. Boyden Gray, the counsel to the President, and William Kristol, Vice President Dan Quayle's chief of staff, see the issue of job quotas in the workplace as a strictly legal and ideological issue and as a golden opportunity to appeal to Reagan Democrats. They have been working to capture that issue for the 1992 elections, but have had to proceed slowly to avoid alienating black voters entirely.
Other officials, including Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Roger P. Porter, the White House domestic policy adviser, and his aide, James Pinkerton, have been pressing for the Administration to be more open to minorities and to espouse affirmative action and other carefully modulated civil rights as a way of overcoming the Republicans' problems with minority voters.
"The Education Department thing threw the cat among the pigeons, forcing a confrontation between those two desires," said Stuart Butler, director of domestic policy studies for the Heritage Foundation, a conservative, Washington-based research group. "They were trying to make a case for a civil rights policy that requires moving slowly and methodically, and the last thing you want is something that forces you to take sides."
Mr. Eizenstat said: "Bush and the Republican Party are torn. There are his own predilections to be fair and accomodating, and the political imperative to chip away the last remaining loyal bloc of Democratic voters, minorities. But there is also a need to give the Reagan Democrats red meat at a time when the economy is going into the tank, and they see civil rights and quotas as a wedge issue."
For months, the first group seemed to be winning this battle for Mr. Bush's soul, including an equally highly wrought fight over whether the President should veto the Civil Rights Act of 1990 in October. In that case, Mr. Bush came down on the side of those who argued that the bill would create job quotas, and he vetoed the bill.
 
Ambivalence on Civil Rights
 But the ban on the practice of designating scholarships for minority students thoroughly confused the picture, since it struck at the President's own ambivalence on civil rights.
The pragmatic Republican in Mr. Bush was able to embrace the purist, no-quotas position despite the political hazards of vetoing the civil rights legislation. The scholarship issue touched the noblesse oblige side of Mr. Bush, who has long supported affirmative action and has contributed to causes like the United Negro College Fund.
"It's one thing to tell blue-collar workers you're protecting their jobs against racial quotas," said a Republican strategist. "It's quite another to take a college scholarship away from an 18-year-old black kid."
Some Republicans said they worried that the new position on scholarships would undermine the foundation of Mr. Bush's stand on the civil rights bill -- that special treatment for any minority group, is not acceptable even if it is intended to help an underclass.
"Bush was on the record with that position on the Hill and it was something that Republicans and conservative Democrats could use to explain why they supported Bush's veto," said a Republican strategist. "Now all of a sudden, here comes Bush saying it is O.K. to treat some groups differently."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK PHONE WINS AN INCREASE IN RATES OF 4.8%

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the New York Telephone Company to raise the price of local phone service by about 7 percent for residential customers and 2 percent for business customers.
But the actual increases will be much larger for customers in both categories who make only a few calls within their community, and smaller for those who make many calls to nearby communities, for which they are billed separately. 
 The rate increase, totaling $250 million, for an overall rise of 4.8 percent, was a fraction of the $832 million increase that New York Telephone had sought last spring after the Public Service Commission narrowly rejected a $445 million increase jointly proposed by New York Telephone and the commision's staff.
 
Criticized by Company
 The commission's rejection prompted the phone company to file a formal rate increase petition, which ended in yesterday's decision. The new rates are to take effect on Jan. 1.
New York Telephone officials immediately criticized the $250 million figure as inadequate and said the ruling would leave it with some of the lowest profits per telephone line of any company in the United States.
"We need reasonable earnings if we are to continue to modernize New York's telecommunications network," the company said in a statement.
 
'A Christmas Present'
 Richard M. Kessel, the executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, was also unhappy about the ruling. "The P.S.C. has decided to give New York Telephone a Christmas present with our money," Mr. Kessel said, adding that the board would consider filing a lawsuit seeking to overturn the commission's decision.
The main effect of the commission's ruling will be to raise the basic fee residential users pay for having a phone line and making some local calls. The current rate is $3.75 to $7.55 a month, depending on the number of free calls included in the billing plan, plus a fee for additional calls.
This fee will change to about $7 a month, and there will be no free calls. Each local call will cost from about 4 to 10.2 cents.
For example, a resident who subscribes to New York Telephone's basic budget service and made one daytime call to a nearby friend every day last month was charged about $6.25 for that basic local service. Long-distance calls, Federal taxes and fees, and charges for other services, like call waiting and touch-tone dialing, are additional.
Under the state commission's ruling yesterday, the same customer will owe as much as $9 or $10 for the basic service. The precise amount is unclear because the commission's staff must recalculate many of its rates based on specific instructions from the commissioners.
Both New York Telephone and the Public Service Commission declined to comment about how much specific rates might rise, citing the need for new calculations. For example, the commission ordered the price of touch-tone telephone service to be reduced by a third, instead of by a half as expected.
 
Special Rates for the Poor
 The decision will affect New York Telephone's 6.3 million residential and 2.8 million business phone lines throughout the state, including 2.9 million residential and 1.6 million business lines in New York City. Forty other small phone companies serve a total of nearly a million lines in the state.
Dr. Gail Garfield-Schwartz, an economist who is the commission's deputy chairwoman, said raising the phone bills of residential customers more than those of businesses was appropriate. Businesses have long subsidized residential customers by payingmore to the phone company than the company spends on serving them. Yesterday's decision, which also maintains special low phone rates for the poor, will reduce that subsidy slightly and insure that more people pay for phone service based on how much they value it, Dr. Garfield-Schwartz said.
The commission also ordered its staff to study whether New York Telephone should continue its policy of charging needy customers and disabled veterans $1 a month for local phone service, plus the usual charge for each outgoing call.
For more than a year, the rate case has been overshadowed by accusations that the New York Telephone Company overpaid affiliated but unregulated companies for goods and services, like the hiring of temporary employees and the removal of outdated equipment. The commission's study of New York Telephone's $832 million rate increase petition uncovered evidence last spring that a dozen employees of one of those affiliated companies, the Nynex Materiel Enterprises Company in Manhattan, attended lewd parties in Florida that may have been subsidized by vendors.
 
A Separate Inquiry
 The commission recently began a separate inquiry into those allegations, and did not consider them yesterday. It did set aside $32 million of its $250 million increase, pending the outcome of the inquiry.
New York Telephone and the affiliated companies are all subsidiaries of the Nynex Corporation, one of the seven regional Bell companies created when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company divested itself of its local telephone operations in 1984.
Richard Stannard, the director of the commission's communications division, said that all but $20 million of the $250 million increase will go toward compensating New York Telephone for the cost of outdated equipment. The phone company will keep the remaining $20 million as increased profit.
 
A Major Issue
 New York Telephone earned $497 million last year on sales of $7.45 billion.
A major issue in the rate case was whether New York Telephone is earning enough money to modernize its network quickly enough.
The State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, a strong critic of the company's management, said the $250 million increase was preferable to the $445 million originally sought. But he criticized the commission for not specifically requiring the company to invest part of the increase it received to improve its local telephone network.
The company does not plan to replace its last electromechanical central-office switches with electronic switches until 1998. Electronic switches allow customers to connect to any long-distance carrier without having to dial extra numbers and make possible other services like call forwarding and call waiting. Coincidentally, the regional Bell company for the Southeast, which serves a more rural market, announced yesterday that it had replaced its last electromechanical switch.
The New York Public Service Commission yesterday considered increasing telephone rates by $195 million, and then added an extra $55 million to allow New York Telephone to write off some of its electromechanical switches more quickly.
Mr. Kessel of the Consumer Protection Board pointed out that three of the commission's administrative law judges who reviewed the same material as the commissioners had recommended that the company be awarded a rate increase of only $23 million.

HEADLINE: In Blacks' Homes, the Christmas and Kwanzaa Spirits Meet

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
TWO holidays will be celebrated at Dr. Cheryl Doyle's house in Brooklyn next week: Christmas, for her Christian roots, and Kwanzaa, a nonreligious cultural observance, to pay tribute to her African-American heritage.
Dr. Doyle, a pediatrician, said the Kwanzaa celebration was meant mostly for her and her husband, William Hilton, a psychologist. Christmas, she said is for their 5-year-old son, Glenn, who is not yet prepared to forsake traditions like Santa Claus bringing gifts to good little boys and little girls. 
 For years, black Americans have sought to reconcile what W. E. B. Du Bois called "two thoughts, two unrecognizable strivings, two warring ideals in one dark body." But a growing number of black Americans have found ways to merge the holidays, affirming their identities as Africans and Americans.
Kwanzaa began as an African-American alternative to Christmas observed primarily by black nationalists and it has gradually evolved into a holiday enjoyed in various degrees by about 13 million blacks.
Kwanzaa, Swahili for "first fruits," was initiated in 1966 by a civil-rights leader, Maulana Karenga, who is now a visiting lecturer at the University of California at Riverside. He is also the author of "The African-American Holiday of Kwanzaa: A Celebration of Family, Community and Culture" ( University of Sankore Press , 1989).
"The idea was for blacks to come together to celebrate their history and their culture and focus on values that would be beneficial in their development," said Subira Kifano, a spokeswoman for Dr. Karenga, who is traveling and unavailable for comment.
"There is no conflict in celebrating both Kwanzaa and Christmas," said Mrs. Kifano, vice chairwoman of the Us organization, which Dr. Karenga began in 1965 to provide cultural and educational services to blacks.
The holiday is a seven-day observance, Dec. 26 through Jan. 1, with feasts and the giving of simple gifts. Each day the celebrants light a red, black or green candle in a holder called the Kinara and interpret one of the Nguzo Saba, Kwanzaa's seven principles.
They include such values as collective work and responsibility (Ujima), creativity (Kuumba), faith (Imani) and unity (Umoja), as well as principles like self-determination (Kujichagulia), purpose (Nia) and cooperative economics (Ujamma), including the support of black-owned businesses.
In Celeste Morris's home in Brooklyn, Kwanzaa has shared a special place alongside Christmas for 12 years. Guests find a Christmas tree next to the Kinara and mantles and doorways adorned with red, black and green -- incorporating the colors of African nationalism and Christmas.
"We definitely had to come to terms with Kwanzaa," said Ms. Morris, the mother of a 21-year-old son and 16-year-old daughter. "It was easier when the kids were younger because they didn't really grasp the full meaning of the holidays. As they got older, they wanted Christmas. Kwanzaa was good food; Christmas was toys."
 For years, many blacks felt that the only way they could be true to the spirit and principles of Kwanzaa was by abandoning all the trappings and traditions of Christmas. Those with children often gave up on the idea of observing Kwanzaa, convinced that it could not compete with Christmas and Santa Claus.
Still other blacks wanted to embrace a more Afrocentric way of life but were bothered by the holiday's militant beginnings and connotation.
"Kwanzaa had what I referred to as a 'culture club' connotation, that if you were not carrying a spear or had a bone through your nose, you weren't down," said Cedric McClester, author of "Kwanzaa: Everything You Always Wanted to Know but Didn't Know Where to Ask" ( Gumbs & Thomas Publishers, 1990). "A lot of blacks didn't want to get involved because they thought we were asking them to give up Christmas to celebrate some pagan African holiday."
Seven years ago, Mr. McClester, the spokesman for the New York Urban Coalition, began what became an annual series of Kwanzaa activities co-sponsored by his nonprofit service organization and the American Museum of Natural History. The observance, at the museum at 81st Street and Central Park West, attracted 85,000 people last December.
This year's program, scheduled for Dec. 27 and 28, includes music, other arts and a lecture exploring the significance of Kwanzaa.
Elsewhere, several urban agencies, schools, churches and community centers in various parts of the nation are holding Kwanzaa services.
The growing acceptance of Kwanzaa by individuals and institutions has made it more palatable to blacks of all ages and backgrounds. Indeed, more blacks are celebrating Kwanzaa at home with family and friends. Among new celebrants this year are G. Douglas Pugh, chairman of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board, and his wife, Dr. Clementine Pugh, a retired college professor.
"I don't have any kind of confusion or ambivalence about it," Mr. Pugh said. "Our kids are grown and out of the way now. This will be our first Kwanzaa celebration and we're going to do it to death."
Mr. Pugh asked Paul deCroon, a jewelry designer, to make a special wreath, using Afrocentric materials, for the Pughs' Kwanzaa celebration at home in Riverdale, The Bronx.
The broad appeal of Kwanzaa is evident in other ways. Kwanzaa cards are now sold at major stationery stores. Catalogues carry the Kwanzaa symbols, from the Kinara to the Kikombe Cha Umoja, the communal unity cup, which is passed among celebrants to honor ancestors and promote the spirit of oneness. Coloring books, games, buttons and cards marking the holiday are sold at museums' gift shops -- the museum of natural history, the Smithsonian Institution in Washington and the Studio Museum in Harlem.
Instead of reading "A Visit From St. Nicholas," a parent might choose Edward and Harriet Cox Robinson's " 'Twas the Night Before Kwanzaa." The poem, in rap style, was dedicated to the Robinsons' grandchildren. It reads, in part:
 
'Twas the night before Kwanzaa
 And all through the street
 "Happy Kwanzaa" rang out
 When folk chanced to meet
"I'm creating a character that will bridge the gap between Christmas and Kwanzaa," Mr. McClester said. Nia Umoja, his new character, is described as an ancient African storyteller whose spirit appears at harvest time. exhibiting traits similar to those of Santa Claus. He is kind and fond of children, and smiles favorably upon youngsters who adhere to the Kwanzaa principles. Such efforts are attracting more and more children to the celebration.
But with dual celebrations growing in popularity, long-time celebrants of Kwanzaa express concern that merging the holidays distorts the meaning of Kwanzaa.
"In the same way that Christmas can be overcommercialized, I believe Kwanzaa can be commercialized," said Martia Goodson, an instructor at Baruch College who has held a Kwanzaa celebration with her two children for seven seasons.
"Everybody's being black now and doing Kwanzaa," said her daughter, Jaime Goodson, a 15-year-old student at the Horace Mann School. "There will be those who will commercialize it and turn it into a fad. Once something becomes popular, everybody wants to cash in on it."
Jaime recalled a time when she and her brother, Malik, now 13, were "uncomfortable about losing Christmas." They say they are beyond that now. They have shed the ghosts of Christmas past: decorating the tree, hanging the stockings, staying up all night to see their gifts. In their dreams, they said, the spirits of Christmas future show a vision in which not only African-Americans but people of African descent throughout the world celebrate Kwanzaa.

HEADLINE: A Paycheck Gone, A Family in Crisis

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
FOUR in the afternoon to seven in the evening is the roughest part of the day for Bob, the time when he gets lowest during this week before Christmas.
Laid off more than a year ago from his job as a health-care manager in the Boston area, the 48-year-old father, who requested his last name not be used, spends his days caring for his two young girls. His wife, a hospital nurse, is now the sole breadwinner. 
 "I can't control the crying of the 2-year-old," he said. "There's a lot of unraveling, and I do a lot of yelling, and I shake her a lot, but no one has gotten hurt yet. I'm not a macho man, but I'd rather dig ditches with a spoon than watch kids."
At a time when the two-paycheck household has become a mainstay of American life, unemployment or the threat of it is placing enormous financial and emotional stress on families.
"This generation of working men and women doesn't have models to fall back on in times of economic hardship," said Bradley Googins, director of the Center on Work and Family at Boston University. "Today's middle-class families, even with two incomes, may be one or two paychecks away from dire straits if one of those jobs is lost."
Relationships between working spouses, already strained by child care, care of the elderly and other demands on time and money, are now being tested by layoffs, vanishing savings, mounting debt and pessimism about the future. More than three dozen men and women in the New York region and in New England, where the economic downturn has been under way longer, were interviewed recently on the effects of unemployment. Nearly all seemed more dazed than embittered about events that have rapidly drained success from their lives and upended finely balanced family arrangements. "Financial anxiety can produce as much stress as a death in a family," said Dr. Martin V. Cohen, a Manhattan psychotherapist. "You see all the symptoms: sexual problems, depression, substance abuse -- more alcohol this time around than cocaine."
"If you take away the money and the distractions and people have to sit at home on a Saturday night and talk to each other, it might be the end of the marriage," Dr. Cohen said.
Many who find themselves in that position discover they cannot even afford a divorce, Dr. Cohen added, "so they are pushed to make peace, even if they are sexually and emotionally separated."
For professional couples, the loss of one job can undermine a relationship built on unstated terms. Chippa Martin, a psychologist with Aradia Counseling for Women in Boston, tells of a couple in their late 40's whose marriage broke up after the husband lost his job: "The wife, who was very egocentric, became very resentful that she was moving ahead in her career while he was not and practically accused him of sabotaging her life style because he had been making more money than she had."
Unemployment tends to bring out the best or worst in relationships, said Bruce Davidson, a clinical psychologist who administers an employee-assistance program for the Digital Equipment Corporation, a computer company in the high-technology belt north of Boston that has been hit hard by layoffs.
"Those with good coping and communication skills tend to weather a job crisis," he said. "Those without them tend to become dysfunctional."
It has been documented that prolonged unemployment increases physical, sexual and child abuse within affected families.
"Isolation is an important predictor of abuse," said Faye J. Crosby, a psychology professor at Smith College who is the author of "Spouse, Parent, Worker" (Yale University Press, 1990). "He may feel psychologically battered by losing his job and feels like crawling under a rock and staying there. He wishes he was working, and perhaps his wife wishes she didn't have to. Tempers are frayed."
Unemployed women are often surprised to find they do not get the consolation extended to unemployed men. "Women may become depressed when spouses, family and friends tell them they were lucky to be out of work so they could catch up with their housework and children," said Paula Raymond, a professor at Wellesley College's Center for Research on Women. Women, she added, often internalize their depression and develop eating disorders, distorting their sense of self-esteem.
Unemployment among women has not alarmed American society as much as unemployment among men, said Barbara Gutek, a professor at the University of Arizona School of Business who has studied women in the workplace. But, she said, "it's going to be devastating for modern women if they feel they've made many sacrifices to get where they are, only to have the rug pulled out."
The coping skills used to build a successful two-career life in times of plenty are not always enough to buffer families against a financial shock.
"It took us 11 very carefully planned years to put this life style together where we made enough money, lived in the right town, and I could raise our children, and it's all crumbled in a matter of months, and we're not emotionally prepared for it," said Christine Mann, a 34-year-old manager at a computer software firm in Cambridge, Mass.
After Ms. Mann gave birth to her second child last year, she cut her work schedule in half to devote time to raising her two girls. Meanwhile, her husband, a self-employed contractor, saw his business dry up.
 Even those who can fall back on parents for financial help find the experience painful.
"My parents have been so good to me and given me such a good education that it's very distressing that I may have to borrow money from them to fill up my heating oil tank this winter or meet any unexpected big bill," said Kae Koger, 34, an assistant professor at the University of Massachusetts with a doctorate in theater.
Her husband, David Pasto, 36, who also has a Ph.D. in theater, has not been able to find a teaching job since 1987, when he left a professorship in Ohio to allow his wife to accept the Massachusetts post. He said hiring freezes had forced him to take part-time jobs far beneath his training.
He said he was considering taking a job at Burger King as a cook, work usually done by teen-agers. "It's depressing to think about what to write down on the application card in the space on education level," he said.
The kitchen of Robin and Robert Sargent of Manchester, Conn., a suburb of Hartford, is a chilly 65 degrees. The Sargents are turning the thermostat down even further at night to put off the hour, any day now, when their 275-gallon heating oil tank hits empty.
Married four years, they are perplexed by how they stumbled into debt. When Mrs. Sargent quit her job as a trainer for an insurance company to give birth to twin girls in 1988, they felt comfortable that his $30,000 income as a service manager for a vending-machine company could support the family and its $1,100 monthly house payments.
But the New England economy turned down dramatically in 1989, and Mr. Sargent's company froze pay increases and overtime. To try to prop up the family budget, she went to real-estate school and was licensed as an agent, but then housing prices began to tumble and sales dried up. She tried to get back her former job, but the insurance industry was also laying off thousands of workers.
Now the family lives from paycheck to paycheck, and their bank balance has dropped as low as $5.
Her father and his parents have been asked to give their grandchildren, Lauren and Kristin, clothing and shoes for Christmas gifts instead of toys. Baby dolls "that do anything" cost at least $25, she noted, and with twins, it is twice the cost.
The couple borrowed from their families to help buy their house and are reluctant to ask for more help, Mrs. Sargent said. The Sargents feel the financial strain tearing away at their marriage.
"I go into a frenzy when I see the pile of bills," said Mr. Sargent, 28.
"It takes a lot of work when you're constantly worried about the future," Mrs. Sargent said, "to maintain the quality of the relationship that brought you together in the first place. It's a constant internal battle."
