HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Glorious, Squalid Broadway's Lore and Lure

BYLINE: By JOHN TAURANAC; John Tauranac is the author of "Elegant New York."

 BODY:
On Broadway
A Journey Uptown Over Time
By David W. Dunlap
Illustrated. 327 pages. Rizzoli International Publications. $65. 
 Broadway. Depending on your point of view, it is the best of streets, it is the worst of streets. But on one thing everyone seems to agree: Broadway is the city. And David W. Dunlap, who now reports on real estate for The New York Times, has done a wonderful thing for Broadway, no doubt about it.
In his marvelously illustrated book "On Broadway," Mr. Dunlap has catalogued every building on the street from the southern tip of Manhattan to the Harlem River, telling the salient information about each building that is standing there now, as well as cataloguing important buildings that stood there in earlier incarnations.
This chronicle, which in itself makes "On Broadway" a major contribution to New York's architectural history, is only the skeletal framework of "On Broadway." Fleshing out this framework is a narrative history of the street, with neighborhoods acting as the logical groupings for chapters. Mr. Dunlap describes the ebb and flow of neighborhoods, how economic and social forces might create a neighborhood that is upper middle class one generation, commercial the next, perhaps then becoming a backwater only to rise phoenixlike and metamorphose into something entirely different.
The illustrations in the book, which include historical prints and photographs as well as contemporary photographs by the author, contribute mightily to the understanding of Broadway. Good architectural photographers manage to capture the essence of a building, its very personality, and Mr. Dunlap is a very good architectural photographer indeed. He might purge all the dross to show the classic simplicity of a building, or show how buildings can become ravaged by thoughtless changes to their fabric and how messy the cityscape can become. "The entire disregard of unity" that was observed in 1873 is manifested in Mr. Dunlap's photographs of today's urban scene.
One of the most remarkable historical photographs links 18th-century New York with the 20th-century city. The view shows the Vanden Heuvel mansion, which stood on the west side of Broadway between 78th and 79th Streets from the early 1790's until it was torn down to clear the land for the Apthorp Apartments in 1906. Standing in the foreground of the photograph is the great harbinger of change on the Upper West Side, a kiosk leading to the IRT subway.
A vintage photograph of the Colonnade Building, which occupied the block between 57th and 58th Streets in 1923, has the building looking familiar, as if you saw it only yesterday. And you very well might have. But somehow it's wrong: something is missing, and what is missing is the rest of it. Twenty-three stories were added in 1928, making the former Colonnade Building the plinth for today's 1775 Broadway.
Perhaps the book's most telling series of pictures is the threesome showing the changing faces of the Times Tower. The photographs show the same perspective, first in 1907 when the Times Tower, that apparition of Giotto's Gothic campanile, had been standing two years; second, after the original skin had been stripped off and the tower was clad as the banal Allied Chemical Building in 1979; and then, looking even more forlorn, the same building in 1987.
Broadway, always a catholic street, has happily accommodated saints and sinners. It has been home to some of the city's "best" churches, including Trinity and Grace, and, although never the site for a cathedral, several buildings along Broadway have been nicknamed "The Cathedral" of something. The most famous is the Woolworth Building, which a cleric described as the "Cathedral of Commerce," a sobriquet that has stuck since the consecration-of-the-house dinner. You will also find Toffinetti's, the "Cathedral of All Restaurants," as well as Rector's Restaurant, the "American cathedral of froth and frivolity."
Cathedral laurels were claimed for a plan in 1923 for the Broadway Temple Methodist Church in Washington Heights. The scheme called for a 725-foot-high "cathedral-like apartment house and church topped with a cross visible for 100 miles by aeroplane." Only 2 12-story wings of the complex were built, and they appear unrelated to each other, much less to any grander scheme. But the layout puts them in perfect perspective, putting a photograph of the wings next to a rendering of the grand plan, and the ordinarily disparate parts suddenly fit together like a puzzle.
Perhaps the religious edifice most indicative of Broadway was squirreled away within the American Circle Building, which William Randolph Hearst built where the tower long known as the Gulf and Western Building stands at Columbus Circle. "Within it," relates Mr. Dunlap, "was a mysterious chamber that did not come to light until the building's demolition in 1966: a 'cameo Gothic cathedral,' with vaulted ceilings, pointed arches, delicate stonework and opulent chandeliers. There was speculation that Hearst built it as a private chapel for his mistress, the actress Marian Davies."
There are some cavils concerning editorial and art-directorial judgments. This book is a gold mine, and although there are indices to illustrations and architects et al., there is no general index, so there is no way to extract the precious information. Photographs are often far removed from their primary entries and the captions do not provide addresses, so the buildings cannot easily be tracked down. And then there are the maps that lead off each chapter, which are City Planning maps with tape over the germane swath of Broadway, so the street is completely obliterated. A street atlas would have been informative and helpful.
Beyond all this, there is an unstated moral to the book, and that is the health of the city. New York is not preserved in brick and mortar, much less in aspic; it is a healthy, changing, vibrant place. And that is a message to architects, city planners and developers: No plan is likely to remain pristine for the ages, as seen in a bewildering remembrance of something past, a marble arch that was originally the grand entrance to the Seaman-Drake estate at 215th Street but that is now home to an auto parts business. Seeing desecrations like that often leads to the desire for a benevolent despot in City Hall whose first act would be the appointment of his own Baron Haussmann to bring some order to the streetscape. Of course, if we had an ordered city we would not have a Broadway, where the raffish meets the elegant, and that would be a pity. Nor would we have more books like "On Broadway," which would be more the pity. Once you taste of the fruit, you want more.

GRAPHIC: Photo of street sign at Broadway and 45th St. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Living Together, Divided by Money

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In Stephen Jeffreys's "Valued Friends," four young working-class Londoners renting an unfashionable basement flat suddenly find themselves surrounded by gentrification. By holding fast to their tenancy, they become increasingly wealthy, at least on paper. The play (at the Long Wharf Theater) opens up into a study of the effect of real estate on individuals, of property values on friendship. At the root is a question of colonization: people living together in pursuit of a common goal but divided by self-interest.
The play, which was first presented at the Hampstead Theater in London, is trenchant in its exploration of the group living arrangements, especially in matters of economics. Mr. Jeffreys is somewhat less revealing about the original connection of the characters. One has to accept on faith that these disparate people are such close friends (two are on-again, off-again lovers). 
 Individually the characters are scrutinized with empathy and humor. There is something to be said about each point of view, from the most altruistic to the most egocentric. The latter position is represented by a pert, would-be alternative comedian (Jill Tasker), always in need of cash and lightheaded in all matters of responsibility.
When the first offer for a buy out comes from the landlord, Ms. Tasker is quick to suggest that the quartet take the money. Her flat-mates want to proceed cautiously, knowing that a collaborative hesitation would provoke a higher offer. Finally when three of them agree to buy the flat at an insider's price, they buy Ms. Tasker's share and she flies around the world, a spree that is bound to leave her penniless and in need of lodging.
In various ways the others are each self-sustaining: Liann Pattison as an executive on the rise, Bill Camp as a scholar and John Benjamin Hickey as the play's principal character, a rock critic who gradually finds himself caught up in his new role as homesteader.
Forsaking his work as well as his romance with Ms. Pattison, Mr. Hickey immerses himself in renovation. It becomes his compulsive preoccupation, as he undertakes painting, carpentry and plumbing, and finds that he enjoys it. When Ms. Pattison decides the new kitchen should be built by an outside professional, Mr. Hickey is crestfallen. Such is the credibility of the play and the performances that one feels the weight of his disappointment.
It might be said that the play is of specialized interest. A similar charge might have been raised against Michael Frayn's "Benefactors" or Margaret Drabble's novel "The Ice Age," both related in their concern with urban redevelopment. On the other hand, it should appeal to all those who are either tenants or landlords; in other words, almost everyone trying to live in a city.
Important issues are at stake, such as survival in a sinkable economy and how to get the most for one's money. There is an amusing second-act cameo performed by Ian Trigger as a disk jockey turned construction worker, who pitches in to help Mr. Hickey. Together they do the backbreaking manual labor as well as the architectural planning, because it is Mr. Trigger's conclusion that "the whole building trade is an enormous rip-off."
Although there is not an excess of plot, there is conflict as the tenants ally themselves against Mark Vietor as the increasingly frustrated landlord and as each tries to maximize the return on his investment. The play is more than just a group case history. It becomes a highly informative slice of contemporary life and an object lesson for prospective householders.
"Valued Friends" is firmly situated in London but achieves a more widespread relevance. One could find similar stories in New York. To make its point, the play has to have a localized foundation. Robin Lefevre, who directed the London production of the play, leads an expert American cast (Mr. Trigger is one English exception) into Anglicized waters. Accents, attitudes and characteriztions are exacting.
The authenticity extends to the scenic design. Sue Plummer, the play's original designer, turns the Long Wharf stage into a run-down Victorian flat. Between scenes, the apartment is converted into a stylish lair, a before-and-after transformation that could earn a spread in House and Garden. In fact, the final setting looks as cool and contained as Ms. Pattison's character is supposed to be, as she waits alone to entertain her guests. Enter Ms. Tasker with an aerosol can of reverse intention. With it, she gives the place a natural cooking smell -- to restore life into an environment that is now as antiseptic as it is fashionable.
 
VALUED FRIENDS
 
By Stephen Jeffreys; directed by Robin Lefevre; set and costumes by Sue Plummer; lighting by Marc B. Weiss; production stage manager, Tammy Taylor. Presented by Long Wharf Theater, Arvin Brown, artistic director; M. Edgar Rosenblum, executive director. At New Haven.

HEADLINE: Painful but Fair Tuition Hikes

 BODY:
New York's revised budget contains a jolt for students at the state's public universities: a proposed tuition increase of $300 a year. That's burdensome for struggling students. But it's reasonable and long overdue.
For full-time undergraduates, tuition at the State University is $1,350; at City University, it's $1,250. The price has not been raised since 1983, making public higher education in New York a real bargain. By contrast, California and Texas, which have university systems comparable to New York's, have raised their tuition for state residents 24 and 48 percent respectively in the past four years. 
 Last year SUNY and CUNY proposed a $200 annual raise to make up for a $40 million shortfall between what the Legislature allocated and what administrators insisted they needed. The proposed increase was generally accepted by State University students. But some at City University staged demonstrations at several campuses, protesting that the raise was unfair to poor students. Gov. Mario Cuomo, who had long opposed tuition hikes, vetoed the proposed increase.
This year, with the state and city under severe economic strain, Mr. Cuomo, the Legislature and the SUNY and CUNY Boards of Trustees accepted a raise as inevitable.
Hard-pressed students can thank the CUNY board for taking steps that will soften the blow. Even before the Legislature acted, CUNY authorized a $200 annual tuition increase. It did so, however, on the condition that the state ease restrictions on an $11 million program to aid part-time students.
The Legislature went along. As a result, the proposed tuition raise will be covered by state aid for the poorest part-time students, while less affluent full-time students will be covered by the state's Tuition Assistance Program or Federal Pell grants.
New York has long been committed to providing quality public higher education to as many students as possible. The modest tuition increase does not diminish that commitment.

HEADLINE: In Moscow, the Forces for Force

 BODY:
A controlled revolution may be a contradiction in terms. Ask Mikhail Gorbachev. He's caught between radicals anxious to keep reform from stalling and reactionaries who think it is rapidly turning into chaos. Unlike China's leaders, who tried to hold back the tide of change with armed force, the Soviet President now seems determined to restore order so as to impose reform.
While it's easy to sympathize with his plight, he has much to lose, at home and abroad, by cracking down with force. Washington is right to remind him of that, as Secretary of State Baker reportedly did in his meeting with Foreign Minister Shevardnadze in Houston last week. 
 Pressure from below has forced the pace of change in the Soviet Union. Without it, Mr. Gorbachev could not have moved as far as he has against hard-line resistance in the bureaucracy, the party and the regional military leadership. And without initiative from below, neither democracy nor markets can work.
Having ridden the reformist wave to power, he cannot turn on it now. Nor can he afford to alienate or undercut reformers by allying himself with the forces of order.
But pressures to restore order are mounting. Yesterday a wide array of the old guard made its resistance unmistakably public in the Kremlin by circulating an open letter urging Mr. Gorbachev to "put an end to the chaos, to prevent disintegration of the state by all means of power and authority remaining at your disposal." Even dedicated radicals like Mayor Gavriil Popov of Moscow favor a harder line, out of fear that public unrest could unseat Mr. Gorbachev and jeopardize the reforms they want.
The radicals' agenda has given Mr. Gorbachev pause, especially since late summer when reformers from the republics convened at his invitation to work out plans for a 500-day transition to markets. Their draft posed a dilemma for him -- how to decentralize control without eliminating the center. The dilemma endures:
He wants to institute the rule of law, but how can he force elected parliaments to revoke the laws they passed and submit instead to his decrees?
He wants to encourage formation of groups independent of the state, but many of the most powerful groups are ardent nationalists. Can he curb any of them without inflaming the rest?
He wants to devolve power from a rigid central bureaucracy, but some nationalists want to shatter the union altogether. Can he rein them in without reviving the dead hand of bureaucracy?
He wants to shift from a command economy to competitive markets, which means, among other things, stopping black markets and thievery. Yet in many cases today's profiteers are tomorrow's marketeers. Can he arrest them without also strangling markets?
Given his predicament, Mr. Gorbachev may take up the rhetoric of reaction -- without actually attempting to reimpose control by force. Washington is right to raise these troubling questions and quietly urge him to stay his hand.

HEADLINE: The Fed: Room to Move, and It Does

 BODY:
Critics have accused the Federal Reserve Board of rigidly pursuing an anti-inflationary policy even as the economy was sinking into recession. On Tuesday, the Reserve Board signaled a welcome change. It cut the discount rate -- the interest rate banks pay when they borrow money directly from the central bank -- by one-half percentage point, which paves the way for lower interest rates across the board. That will give a desperately needed boost to spending and help revive a sluggish economy.
November figures on output and prices convinced the Fed it was time to shift gears. Unemployment jumped from 5.2 percent to 5.9, and industrial production slumped. And the latest figures on consumer prices show that inflation had dropped to less than 4 percent annually. With inflation in check, the Fed is free to fight slumping production. Lower interest rates will stimulate corporate borrowing and spending, help revive a dormant real estate market and boost consumer spending. 
 What Tuesday's decision does not mean is that the Fed has abandoned its anti-inflation policy. To control inflation, it sets a target range for the growth rate of the money supply. For the past year, and especially during the past six months, it has kept the supply at or below the bottom of this range. That means it can now step up the money supply, thereby driving down interest rates, without overstepping its money-supply targets.
At a time when unemployment is rising and inflation is falling, there is little excuse for keeping interest rates high. The Fed's decision to stimulate spending without accelerating inflation is an unambiguous victory for the economy.

HEADLINE: Peace With Iraq Now Isn't Path to War Later

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Those who advocate attacking and destroying Saddam Hussein now argue that a negotiated settlement would allow him to attack again by 1995, armed with nuclear and chemical weapons, and the means to deliver them. This reason for initiating what could be a bloody and disastrous war is spurious.
Iraq would emerge from a negotiated settlement with a greatly weakened economy because of its mobilization, the United Nations embargo and the loss of thousands of trained foreign workers for its weapons plants. President Saddam Hussein would not be able to complete his plans to produce nuclear and chemical weapons and delivery systems if the United States, Germany, France, Britain, Italy, Japan, the Soviet Union and the smaller industrial nations blocked provision of equipment, materials and technicians. Moreover, if the Soviet Union, France and other suppliers of tanks, planes and other conventional weapons refused to resume delivery of replacement parts, as well as new weapons, his military machine would steadily decline.
If a reasonable settlement is possible, we will be able to bring our men and women home with the knowledge that we can then act to insure an erosion -- not an increase -- in Saddam Hussein's military power in future years.
 
BENJAMIN SOLOMON
Evanston, Ill., Dec. 2, 1990

HEADLINE: New Medicare Schedule Will Hurt the Elderly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Federal Government plan to restructure the pricing of medical services under Medicare has failed to consider critical issues.
Pricing medical services at or below the cost of delivering them (as has been done in New York City and other high-overhead urban centers) will reduce access to and quality of medical care for the Medicare population. Also, complex and severe medical problems, especially in tertiary consultative services, are extremely time consuming to evaluate and to explain fully to the patient and family. The training required to provide such expertise is also lengthy and economically burdensome.
Despite Government lip service to these two issues, the resultant schedule will fix prices far below the current realistic market pricing. Physicians will have to choose between avoiding patients who are covered by Medicare or short-changing them by devoting less time to explaining procedures, evaluating problems and care. Those not in financial need will save some money, but at the cost of greatly reduced access to health care and a reduction in quality of care.
Furthermore, unrealistic reductions in reimbursement under Medicare will disrupt the means by which medical services for the uninsured or underinsured are delivered. Traditionally, this has been achieved by the voluntary, pro-bono gift of physician time. Similarly, the cost of medical education (not only at the medical school level, but also at the residency and fellowship level) has been subsidized by the nonremunerated attending physician's gift of time and effort.
These two systems have, in effect, been subsidized by patient-care dollars from economically sound recipients of medical care. The new unrealistic price schedule for Medicare will force physicians to abandon unpaid, but time-consuming, activities in these two areas and lead to disruptions. Access to and quality of care will be reduced for the seriously ill.
New funds and additional taxes to support medical education and the care of the indigent will be needed. Furthermore, all the costs of medical care, both direct (medical fee increases) and indirect (medical insurance rates), will rise. This burden will fall upon the working population and not upon those members of the 65 and older population who are able, but unwilling to pay any out-of-pocket expenses toward medical care. No consideration of these matters has been factored into the new mandated pricing scheme.
There is no reason for the economically capable not to bear their share of the cost for medical services and for the physician's time and effort that the public has come to expect as its due. An analysis of the consequences of the proposed fee schedule is overdue.
 
RALPH S. BLUME, M.D.
Clinical Professor of Medicine
Columbia University College
of Physicians and Surgeons
New York, Dec. 10, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (93%);

HEADLINE: The World's Farmers Reject Trade Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is far more behind the failure of the Brussels conference on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade than you recognize in "Europeans Sabotage Trade" (editorial, Dec. 8). Your headline refers to the refusal of Germany and France to end all farm price supports affecting 10 million of their farmers.
It is a fair assumption that both governments are aware that if they left the farmers of their countries at the mercy of the world price levels for farm commodities, mass bankruptcy would ensue.
In contrast to what you term "sabotage," the United States Department of Agriculture supports the rapid cutting back of all farm price supports. The rejected GATT proposal would have required our Federal and state governments to cut back supports by 75 percent and eventually to wipe them out entirely. Government-sponsored credit would also be cut by 75 percent, and without credit, most commercial farmers cannot produce.
Even without enactment of the GATT proposal, the Department of Agriculture is announcing cuts. This outlook is being met by vociferous protests from the farm belt.
The North Dakota Farmers Union induced Gov. George Sinner to declare Nov. 12-17 Farm Income and Rural Crisis Awareness Week. That week, the Farmers Union in several cities sold 1 1/2 pound loaves of bread for 5 cents, explaining this was the share wheat growers receive from a $1.50 loaf! The Governor announced that some 6,000 North Dakota farmers had been forced out of business by low prices in recent years.
It would not be surprising if some American farmers sent a letter of thanks to President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
Farm opposition to the GATT proposals from northern countries has been supported by the foreign ministers of a series of developing southern countries. These are led by the Group of 15, whose members include Argentina, Brazil, Egypt, Indonesia, India, Mexico and Venezuela. These countries also protest that their raw products bring ruinously low prices on world markets.
Venezuela's Foreign Minister, Reinaldo Figueredo, at a gathering of these foreign ministers at Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, termed the GATT proposals the "recolonialization of the third world by economic means." Carlos Andres Perez, the President of Venezuela, added that the Malaysia meeting had served as a launching pad for new approaches to the woes that have faced southern countries for years.
There appears to be emerging a common view from the world's producers of farm products, shared in Senegal, Indonesia, Dakota and Iowa: Holding farm prices far below actual costs of production is a bonanza for agribusiness and ruinous for the producers.
 
LEMENT HARRIS
Norwalk, Conn., Dec. 9, 1990

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
A Credit Expert Who Rates High At Budget Time

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Ten days ago, Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman made a pilgrimage to 25 Broadway. For 90 minutes, over coffee and cookies in a windowless 22d-floor conference room, they pleaded New York's case before Hyman C. Grossman, whose verdicts can cost the city tens of millions of dollars and more.
"When Hy Grossman speaks, we listen," said Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director. 
 "He makes a big difference -- whether we get our bridges fixed and our schools built," said Ms. Holtzman, who paid a courtesy call on Mr. Grossman last year even before she was inaugurated.
Who elected Hy Grossman? Voters in Marlboro, N.J., did a decade ago, as president of their Township Council. He holds no public office in New York but can wield considerable influence as the Standard & Poor's managing director whose committee determines New York's credit rating and consequently its ability to borrow money. That rating can profoundly affect how much interest the city pays.
The rating represents a collective assessment of trends and of an intangible "comfort level" that local officials instill. But Mr. Grossman, who is 55 years old and has been monitoring New York for Standard & Poor's since 1963, has emerged as a mythic figure in municipal finance -- much like a counter part once had at Moody's Investors Service, a rating agency that city officials describe as equally influential.
 In 1975, Standard & Poor's suspended New York City's rating because, Mr. Grossman recalled, city officials seemed incapable of grasping even the dimensions of the fiscal crisis then. Subsequent tax code changes drove commercial banks, widely regarded as heavies who forced city government onto an austerity diet, to invest elsewhere. Rating agencies remained "a franchise virtually created by law, but which is unregulated," as former City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, put it, though one that has grown more vigilant.
Because they work in New York, rating analysts may be susceptible to giving their city government the benefit of any doubts. (City officials wooed Mr. Grossman and others with a helicopter tour of economic-development projects last month). Analysts are also personally exposed, though, to social problems that may shape their prognosis.
"Sure it affects us, but not to the detriment of a collective judgment," Mr. Grossman said. "If a person might be sideswiped by something they see coming into the Port Authority bus terminal, our process doesn't allow that one person to make a ratings judgment. And my answer would be, 'Los Angeles doesn't even have a bus terminal -- does that mean it doesn't have any problems?' "
Standard & Poor's rates New York City general-obligation securities A-, in the third highest of four major investment-grade categories. Two months ago, the Dinkins administration's conflicting fiscal signals prompted Mr. Grossman's committee to impose a temporary "credit watch" for the city.
"We scratched our heads and said, 'Does the city have its act together?' " said Mr. Grossman, who likens his role to that of a theater critic.
"We don't say, 'You better raise revenue or cut expenses,' " said Vickie Tillman, Standard & Poor's executive managing director for municipal finance. "We say: 'You have a fiscal imbalance. How are you going to deal with it?' "
Last week, Mr. Dinkins convincingly argued against reducing the rating. Mr. Grossman, who grew up on the Lower East Side and is fond of informally surveying everyone from sales clerks to city officials, was comforted by the fact that the city has balanced its budgets for 10 years, that safeguards imposed since 1975 remain largely intact and that the mid-1990's hold the promise of an "economic rejuvenation."
A rating reduction would have dealt an enduring psychological and financial blow. As it was, the city sold bonds last week at a premium in a glutted and skittish market disoriented by a government in "transition," as Standard & Poor's annual review described New York after last year's election. The next review, Mr. Grossman said, might be entitled "City Meeting Challenges," if indeed it does so.
"So far, Mayor Dinkins's fiscal policy has met the test," he said. "He's said that fiscal stability is his No. 1 priority. He may just be repeating things someone told him to say, but the lesson of the 70's is clear: without financial stability you can't get anything else done."
Affixed to Mr. Grossman's office door is a small plaque quoting Eleanor Roosevelt: "No one can make you feel inferior without your consent." Conversely, Mr. Grossman says he is willing to give credit where credit is due.

HEADLINE: Murdoch's Time of Reckoning

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Michael Milken is headed for jail. Alan Bond and Robert Campeau no longer run the sprawling businesses they built through daring acquisitions. Donald Trump is living on an allowance from his bankers. Compared with these other entrepreneurs, who also gambled that the robust business climate of the 1980's would endure, Rupert Murdoch is faring well.
Nevertheless, Mr. Murdoch is facing a time of reckoning for his strategy of loading up on short-term debt to finance the astonishing growth of the News Corporation, his global media enterprise. In recent months, even as Mr. Murdoch spent endless hours negotiating to reschedule billions of dollars of debt, he has cut back dramatically on his spending -- most notably by merging Sky Television, his British satellite broadcasting venture, with its major competitor. Bankers in turn have temporarily extended loans that have come due. 
 Both sides have said they hope to agree by Christmas on what Mr. Murdoch will pay the lenders for the backing he needs to prevent the dismemberment of the television, newspaper, publishing and entertainment empire he laboriously assembled. But a number of small banks are refusing to go along, raising fears that a settlement could be weeks or months away.
"No one is being asked to forgive anything," said one banker close to the talks, which involve about 150 banks and insurance companies in the United States, Europe, Australia and the Far East. "They are being asked to extend maturities and would be compensated for it." Like others involved in the continuing negotiations, the banker declined to be named.
In addition to higher interest rates, Mr. Murdoch is likely to face covenants that will restrict his ability to acquire new properties and force him to move more conservatively in investing to upgrade existing ones, according to analysts following the negotiations.
Mr. Murdoch was unavailable for interviews during the last two weeks. But Stanley Shuman, the executive vice president at the investment firm of Allen & Company, who has been a longtime adviser and member of the News Corporation's board of directors, said that Mr. Murdoch would be more comfortable with the covenants than outsiders might assume.
"Anyone who has been as successful as he has would be frustrated by not having a completely free hand, but from a strategic point of view, he has already created a good deal of the mix he wanted, particularly in broadcast," Mr. Shuman said.
The restructuring would cover about $6.5 billion in bank debt due by June 1993, including a number of loans that have recently come due and been extended on the condition that a restructuring be completed in the next few months. Such short-term debts represent most of the $8.1 billion in total debt the News Corporation took on during a period of heavy investment in recent years to upgrade Australian and British newspapers, start up satellite television operations in Britain and develop the Fox television network.
The debts also reflected the costs of acquiring 20th Century Fox; the book publishers Harper & Row and William Collins & Sons; the magazine company that publishes TV Guide, and a string of television stations in the United States.
 
Substantial Fees Expected
 Without a debt restructuring or the sale of some of its major assets, the News Corporation would hit a financial wall by the end of its fiscal year next June 30, when $2.4 billion is due. Another $1.2 billion is due by June 30, 1992, and about $3 billion by June 30, 1993. The lenders negotiating the restructuring own all but $300 million of the debt, which is publicly held.
Senior officials at the News Corporation said that the restructuring proposal would include a $600 million bridge loan, which would be repaid along with $600 million of the current debt in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1992. The company would make semi-annual payments totaling $800 million in its next fiscal year, ending June 30, 1993. The rest of the debts would presumably be rolled over into a new long-term package by 1994.
In return, the banks expect substantial fees for the restructuring, a 1 percent increase in interest rates and a commitment from the company to sell a reported $1 billion of assets over the next three years.
Mr. Murdoch has said that he plans no major acquisitions for the time being, but the covenants may not stop him if he changes his mind. Instead of using cash, the News Corporation could make a major deal through a stock swap. But Mr. Murdoch has been determined not to sacrifice his control of the company, which results from the ownership of 45 percent of the voting stock by his family.
 
Threat to Leave Australia
 He will gain more flexibility to make a stock purchase, as well as shore up the company's balance sheet, if he is successful in his current drive to create a nonvoting class of News Corporation shares. Such nonvoting shares are currently forbidden in Australia, where the News Corporation is based. Mr. Murdoch has threatened to move the company to an American or European exchange unless the rules are changed.
Bankers certainly are sympathetic to Mr. Murdoch's determination to keep control. They praise his record for spinning profits out of media companies and are eager to leave him considerable management freedom as long as he reduces his debt load.
Analysts say three major developments undermined Mr. Murdoch's growth strategy. First, cash flow was hurt when advertising revenues quickly collapsed with the sagging economies in Australia -- where the News Corporation owns 9 magazines and more than 100 newspapers -- and in Britain, where it publishes 8 magazines and 5 newspapers, including The Times and The Sun.
The company also experienced heavier-than-expected costs to support Sky Television satellite broadcasting system in its competition with British Satellite Broadcasting.
 
Citibank Organized Talks
 Last, and certainly not least, bankers, under pressure from regulators to improve their own balance sheets, began to view any company with heavy debts as suspect.
The talks, which have been organized by Citibank and Britain's Midland Bank, started with an inner circle of eight banks with the largest loans to the News Corporation, then expanded their focus to another 15 or so middle-tier lenders and have recently included the rest of the banks and institutional lenders.
Mr. Murdoch and his fellow executives have done more than issue soothing explanations. Among his cost-cutting measures was the decision to kill The Melbourne Herald, the evening paper that had been the mainstay of the family's business during the heyday of his father, Sir Keith Murdoch, by merging it into The Daily Telegraph.
But the most striking move was Sky Television's merger last month with British Satellite in a deal that will leave the News Corporation with just 20 percent of future losses but 80 percent of the first 400 million in profits once the venture breaks into the black and 50 percent of profits over the long run.
Analysts say that the satellite venture should become hugely profitable by the mid-1990's. In the meantime, the News Corporation should add more than $200 million to its cash flow this year by limiting its losses.
Investors are still nervous. Since Aug. 1, the News Corporation has sold about 12 million shares of Reuters P.L.C. to satisfy the demands for cash by investors holding bonds backed by its Reuters holdings. On Tuesday Mr. Murdoch resigned as a Reuters director.
But stockholders in the News Corporation seem to believe that the worst is over. American depository receipts representing shares in the company closed at $8.375 in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, down sharply from the year's high of more than $23 in January, but comfortably above the low of $6.625 on Nov. 1.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE KREMLIN;
West European Policy Makers Are Perplexed and Worried by Shevardnadze's Move

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The resignation of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in protest against "dictatorship" in his country threw Western European security policy into confusion today.
For the last year, Western European nations have based their policies on the assumption that support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would also help insure the success of his plans to turn the Soviet Union into a political democracy with a free-market economy. 
 The implication of Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation seemed to be that Mr. Gorbachev could fail and be replaced by more authoritarian rulers, or that he could himself abandon a commitment to greater democracy and freedom.
Either way, Western European governments would be left without a coherent framework for their post-cold-war security policy, and their shocked and perplexed reactions today reflected their dismay at the prospect.
 
Clinging to Faint Hope
 Some were clinging with faint hope that Mr. Shevardnadze did not really mean it, or that his dramatic speech in the Soviet Parliament today was some kind of political maneuver.
But the overwhelming reaction today was one of worry. "If there is a crackdown in the Soviet Union," a NATO diplomat in Brussels said, "pressure will grow in the United States to react to it with a hardening of policy, and the Germans will want to resist. What will be weakened is the cohesion of the alliance."
The German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who forged a close friendship with Mr. Shevardnadze in the 16 meetings this year in which they hammered out agreement on German unity, said in Berlin today, "We must do whatever we can from our side in Western Europe to support the forces of reform in the Soviet Union."
The French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, also said Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation should not lead the West to suspend plans to send food aid to the Soviet Union.
 
Europeans Pledged Aid
 In Rome last weekend, European Community leaders sent out a strong signal of support for Mr. Gorbachev's policies of economic reform, a process Mr. Shevardnadze said today that he continued to support even as he resigned.
As an indication of their support, they also pledged about $1 billion in emergency food aid and technical support to the Soviet Union, much as the United States had done a few days earlier. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany warned then that "old hard-liners" could do Mr. Gorbachev in if they did not help him, German officials said.
"I hope that this cry of alarm made by Mr. Shevardnadze will be heard," Mr. Dumas said in Paris today, saluting the Soviet Foreign Minister's "very courageous" position of support condemning Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.
"He never hid his concern about the rise of dictatorship in the Soviet Union if perestroika did not succeed," Mr. Dumas said. "This is the first time that he has done so publicly."
 
Perplexity in Germany
 The sense of perplexity was greatest in Germany, where the sense of debt to Mr. Shevardnadze was greatest.
"We cannot be thankful enough that we managed to achieve unity in the period of time that lies just behind us," said Rita Sussmuth, Speaker of the newly elected all-German Parliament, which held its first session in Berlin today.
Mr. Genscher, who aides said was astonished at the news of Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation, said it "should prick up the ears of the world."
Chancellor Kohl, looking grim during a break in a session of Parliament, said: "I regret this very much. We cannot really judge from here whether this is grounds for alarm."
About Mr. Gorbachev, he added: "We hope, we must hope, and I do, that he will pull through. We can only hope that the reforms are carried out. They are good for the Soviet Union, and they are good for the relationship between our people and for developments in Europe."
 
A Key to Reunification
 Without Mr. Gorbachev, German unification would not have taken place this summer. In consenting to it, the Soviet leader also agreed to pull his 380,000 troops out of the eastern part of Germany by 1994.
But the Soviet Parliament has not yet ratified the treaty by which the U.S.S.R., along with the United States, Britain and France, returned the rights of sovereignty they reserved for themselves after defeating Nazi Germany in 1945.
Mr. Kohl and Mr. Genscher expressed no concern today that Moscow might change its mind about unification or about its support for the resistance to Iraq's aggression in the Persian Gulf.
But German officials have become increasingly concerned about the possibility that as economic chaos grows worse in the Soviet Union, the Soviet forces in their country could become a source of instability. They also fear that Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia could soon be confronted by millions of economic refugees.
Gerhard Stoltenberg, the German Defense Minister, said in Berlin today that Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation was an "alarm signal" that Mr. Gorbachev might turn to the secret police and the army for support.
"Our main concern is that Gorbachev was much too slow with economic reform, which he could not get out of the cradle, and that his constitutional reform came too late," Mr. Stoltenberg said. "He could have found a resolution to the nationalities problem three years ago, but our fear is that now it may be too late."
 
Quitting Seen as Pressure
 Prof. Heinrich Vogel, an analyst at the Institute of Eastern Economic and International Studies in Cologne, said he thought that Mr. Shevardnadze had resigned in an attempt to make Mr. Gorbachev face down the conservative forces of reaction in the Soviet Union.
"If he accepts the resignation, then he makes himself a prisoner of the military-industrial complex and of the K.G.B.," he said, adding that hard-liners in the Soviet military and intelligence network viewed Mr. Shevardnadze as "the most-hated man in the Gorbachev platoon."
In Brussels, officials of both the European Community and the NATO alliance expressed concern. "I hope that the development toward full democracy, freedom and human rights will not be put at risk by the current events in the Soviet Union," said NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner.
In London, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said of Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation: "On political grounds, I think we all have to feel some concern at the reasons which he gave, the explanation which he offered for this step. It's too early to draw any definite conclusions. Obviously, we hope that the policies of reform which he supported and which President Gorbachev over the years has introduced, will be continued."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Has the Fed Eased Enough?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Federal Reserve's cut in the discount rate to 6 1/2 percent from 7 percent this week was hailed in the financial markets as a welcome policy shift toward fighting recession rather than inflation. The Fed itself did not explain its move so simply. Rather, it said the discount rate cut was due to "weakness in the economy, constraints on credit, and slow growth in the monetary aggregates." The Fed added that the cut "in part realigns the discount rate with market interest rates," implying that the Fed was following the market, not pushing rates down.
Such an explanation does not require the Fed to concede that it has really changed its policy, but that it is only making a slight midcourse correction, to keep various measures of the money supply growing within the range already set for this year. But outside the walls of the temple -- not only in the marketplace but also at the White House -- critics are saying the Fed is still too hesitant about shifting to a more stimulative policy. 
 The critics insist that despite the effect of the Persian Gulf crisis inflationary pressures have abated. In November, consumer prices increased by only three-tenths of 1 percent. And some economists believe that the real threat is that of deflation, not inflation.
Kurt Richebaecher, a German economic consultant and former chief economist of Dresdner Bank, says the downward pressure on the American economy stems from two sources: "an unsustainable, credit-inflated expansion in consumption" and "a depletion of savings and investments which undermines productivity and income growth." The second influence, he says, "makes a debt and banking crisis a virtual inevitability, as collapsing real-estate collateral values and mushrooming problemloans force the banks to tighten their lending standards."
The banks are struggling to cut costs. This week Citicorp, the nation's largest, announced an increase in layoffs to 8,000 and a sharp dividend cut. The commercial bankers are blaming the regulators for raising capital standards at the wrong time. But the broad fall in bank stock prices is a reflection of how private investors and private rating agencies, not just the Johnny-come-lately public regulators, regard the condition of the banks.
Nevertheless, although capital ratios must be raised, the Fed wants the banks to keep lending, lest a worsening credit squeeze weaken the economy further, and it has cautiously moved toward that goal.
But the Fed faces another problem in sustaining the economy: the slackening flow of foreign capital to the United States, in response to higher real interest rates abroad as well as to stronger economic growth and rising currency values, as the dollar depreciates. Some of the decline in foreign investment here results from developments abroad.
In Japan, for instance, as Kenneth S. Courtis, chief economist of the Deutsche Bank in Tokyo, observed, capital outflow is inhibited by three crucial areas of "unfinished business" at home: the slumping real estate market, the strained financial system and the evaporation of corporate liquidity.
The Japanese banks are under strain not only from falling stock prices and real estate values but also from regulators, who have forced some retrenchment in loans and investments.
Germany, too, has less capital to invest abroad. Reunification with the East will absorb an estimated $50 billion annually for the next several years. The efforts to rebuild Eastern Europe and rescue the Soviet Union from starvation and economic collapse, with all the political dangers that would breed, will further restrict capital flows to the United States.
The United States has carried the heaviest burden of sustaining world economic growth during most of the postwar period, but it will have to rely increasingly on Europe and Japan to hold the world economy together in this post-cold war era, with the Soviet economy collapsing and the United States and the other Anglo-Saxon countries, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand, falling into recession.
Indeed, there is danger that the recession may become worldwide. The collapse of the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations in Brussels was an ominous event that needs to be repaired, to avoid a crackup in the longest period of economic growth the world economy has ever experienced.
The Fed faces difficult problems in trying to sustain the United States economy without driving interest rates and the dollar down so low as to stanch the flow of capital to this country. Yet so serious are the threats of an American and global slump that neither fear of inflation nor of a lower dollar should deter the Fed from aggressively easing money.
The most serious threat to capital investment, whether from foreign or domestic sources, would be a plunge in the American economy.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Drops Plan to Require Waste Incinerators to Recycle

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Bowing to strong objections from a White House panel, the Environmental Protection Agency reluctantly agreed on Wednesday to drop a planned requirement that incinerators recycle a quarter of their incoming garbage.
The recycling proposal had met stiff resistance earlier in the day at a meeting of the President's Council on Competitiveness, a regulatory review panel headed by Vice President Dan Quayle. Among those attending the White House meeting was the E.P.A.'s Administrator, William K. Reilly, who said afterward that the provision would be deleted from a regulation on incinerators that his agency is to adopt on Dec. 31. 
 Mr. Reilly said he decided during the meeting that the regulation was not the "appropriate vehicle for a major mandatory program with significant potential to disrupt local government plans" for incineration programs that could generate electricity and thus reduce the demand for new power plants.
The regulation, issued in draft form a year ago, will set stricter air pollution standards for trash burning at a time when an increasing number of communities see incineration as a means of dealing with a growing shortage of landfill space, especially in the East.
 
Drive for Recycling Provision
 Environmentalists had campaigned vigorously to include a recycling provision in the regulation, arguing that the requirement would reduce the amount of wastes burned and, therefore, air pollution.
"This is a major environmental retreat," David Doniger, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said of the new development. "The Administration is retreating on its own commitment for recycling."
The waste disposal industry had opposed the recycling provision. Allen Moore, president of the National Solid Waste Management Association, recently said in a letter to Mr. Reilly: "Waste combustion is now seen as a cost-effective and environmentally sound means of solid waste management for many communities. This could change if burdensome, and perhaps costly, recycling requirements are a condition."
 
Stiff Opposition
 Administration officials knowledgeable about the White House discussions said Mr. Reilly had argued in favor of the recycling provision but had found stiff opposition from members of the Council on Competitiveness, whose task is to determine what impact proposed Federal regulations would have on American business and local governments.
 Mr. Reilly could have appealed the matter to President Bush but declined to do so.
Among those reported to have argued against the provision were Deputy Energy Secretary Henson W. Moore; Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Japan to Share More of U.S. Troop Cost

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Responding to pressure in Washington, Japan said today that it would increase its share of the cost of maintaining 50,000 United States troops here even though overall Japanese military outlays are being trimmed.
After long negotiations with American officials, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Government said Japan would raise its subsidy of American troop expenses by about $600 million over the next five years, increasing Japan's contribution for American forces here from 40 percent to 50 percent. 
 American officials said the specific figures still had to be worked out in light of fluctuating exchange rates, but as of last year, Japan was paying about $3 billion out of the $7.6 billion expenses to maintain the troops on its soil.
The Japanese move was praised by American officials, although it fell short of a Congressional demand in a joint resolution this year that Japan pick up 100 percent of the cost of American troops or face the prospect of a gradual withdrawal.
 
Irritation Over Gulf
 The resolution was passed at the height of irritation in Congress over a feeling that Tokyo was stalling in putting up money to help support the military buildup against Iraq. Afterward, Japan announced its package of $4 billion in economic and military aid for the Persian Gulf.
In recent days, a new round of criticism has been heard in Washington that Japan and other nations had not fulfillled their earlier pledges on aid, and Tokyo has responded by saying it is disbursing the money as fast as it receives specific requests from the United States or from Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, which have suffered economic stress because of the gulf crisis.
It was unclear how much the Japanese step would placate Congressional unhappiness with Tokyo. But an American official said the Japanese action announced today was "a very good arrangement" that was unprecedented in basing arrangements with other allies around the world.
"This is a very important step in strengthening our security relationship and the importance that Japan attaches to it," the official said. He added that the demand for a 100 percent subsidy was impractical because that would involve Japanese payments for fuel for planes and ships, as well as salaries for Americans.
 
No 'Inappropriate' Subsidies
 "There are some things it would be inappropriate to have subsidized by another country," the official said. "The United States is a sovereign country, and it should supply its own fuel for its aircraft and ships. Its soldiers cannot be mercenaries or hired guns paid by others."
The agreement announced today by Japan calls for Tokyo to subsidize many of the costs paid in yen at American bases in Japan, including the full costs of water, heat and lighting, as well as the salaries of Japanese employes at the bases. Japan declined to pay for waste disposal and telephone services.
Japan has traditionally paid for part of the salaries of Japanese employes, as well as for improvements at installations, rents of certain property and compensation to local communities.
The Japanese step was seen as significant because it came in the context of an overall cutback in earlier projections of military spending growth. The cuts were described as a response to the diminished security threat posed by the Soviet Union and the post-cold war global environment.
 
Increasing 2.7 Percent a Year
 According to the budget outlines adopted by Mr. Kaifu's Cabinet today, Japan will increase its military outlays by about 2.7 percent a year over the next five years, about half the previous projection of an annual increase of 5.4 percent.
Japan has been increasing its military outlays since the early 1980's in response to requests by the United States that it pick up added responsibility for the security of the region, particularly patrolling and guarding sea lanes extending 1,000 miles outside the Japanese archipelago.
"This is the first time that frontline defenses will be cut back on a contract bases," said Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who discussed the changes after the Cabinet meeting. "I think we have come up with figures that convincingly take recent global changes into consideration."
Government officials said that the military budget was still increasing overall and that there would be room for some upgrading of weapons, including the acquisition of Awacs air reconaissance planes and multiple-launch rocket systems.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Predicts U.S. Downturn in '91

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The United States economy will worsen next year, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said today, but the group's economists said that thanks to robust growth in Germany and Japan, America's troubles would not drag the world into recession.
Economists for the Paris-based organization predicted the American economy would show no growth in the second half of this year and would decline in the first half of 1991. A month ago, the organization forecast that the American economy would grow by six-tenths of 1 percent in the first half of next year. 
 David Henderson, the O.E.C.D.'s chief economist said he thought the American economy would start to grow again sometime in 1991, with overall growth for the year falling under 1 percent, which would mean two consecutive years of growth under a slim 1 percent.
The organization's economists projected that unemployment in the United States would rise to 6.4 percent next year and 6.7 percent in 1992, from 5.9 percent at present.
The jump in oil prices was said to be an important factor in the slowing of the world economy since early 1989, but the organization added that the United States and many other nations were already slowing before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.
The O.E.C.D. consists of 24 wealthy industrial nations. It works to promote economic growth and cooperation. In its semiannual outlook, the O.E.C.D. forecast that the industrial world's economy would grow faster than the American economy, with the industrial nations registering 1.8 percent growth in the second half of 1990, 2.8 percent for all of 1990, and 2 percent next year.
 
No Pneumonia
 "It's popularly supposed that when the United States sneezes the rest of the world catches pneumonia," said Stephen Potter, a senior O.E.C.D economist. "We don't believe that is going on at the moment."
Nonetheless, Britain, Sweden and Finland are expected to join the United States in experiencing recessions, although for different reasons.
Mr. Potter said that continued strength in Germany's and Japan's economy "puts some kind of floor under" the world economy. According to the O.E.C.D., Japan's economy will grow at a robust 3.7 percent next year, after bounding ahead at a 6.1 percent rate this year. The O.E.C.D. said that thanks in part to German reunification, economic growth in western Germany would be 4.2 percent this year, its strongest since 1973, and 3 percent next year.
The organization also said that inflation in Germany and Japan was lower than that in the United States. American inflation was expected to reached 4.2 percent this year and 4.9 percent next year, while Japanese inflation was projected to be 1.5 percent this year and 2.2 percent next year. In Germany, inflation is expected to rise from 3.4 percent this year to 4.3 percent next year.
The report, entitled O.E.C.D. Economic Outlook No. 48, is available from the organization's Washington office.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Shevardnadze Move Bolsters Bills

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Money poured into short-term Treasury bills yesterday after the sudden resignation of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Meanwhile, the year-end cashing in continued in the Treasury bond market, where prices fell and yields rose for the second straight session.
The threat to Soviet political stability from Mr. Shevardnadze's departure rattled European financial markets early in the day, and pushed German, French and British interest rates up sharply. The news also generated a strong rally in the dollar, particularly against the German mark. Analysts said at least some of the money that fled into dollars was invested in Treasury bills. 
 "If you want safety, you buy Treasury bills," said Joseph Liro, senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "The strong performance in the bill sector was related to Shevardnadze and the message he conveyed in announcing his resignation."
By late in the day, three-month Treasury bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.53 percent, down 4 basis points, or hundreths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 5 basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.53 percent.
 
Bond Sell-Off
 Dealers continued to sell Treasury bonds yesterday, though there was no news that prompted the price drop.
"There are a lot of people who have generated a lot of paper profits over the past few weeks," one Government bond trader said. "That makes it very tempting to square positions and realize those gains before the end of the year."
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 105 3/4, down 5/8 point, to yield 8.22 percent, compared with a yield of 8.17 percent late Wednesday.
Since Tuesday, when the bond market rallied after the Federal Reserve announced that it had lowered the discount rate, yields on the benchmark 30-year issue have risen by 15 basis points.
Yesterday's decision by the First National Bank of Chicago to lower its prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent, had no impact in the credit markets. First Chicago is the largest bank thus far to cut its prime rate, but analysts expect many others to follow soon.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at a price of 103 3/32, down 13/32, to yield 8.03 percent. And the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, down 2/32, to yield 7.23 percent.
Analysts suggested the price movements of the last two days have pushed yields on shorter-term notes to very attractive levels.
"With the two-year yielding more than 7.20 percent and the Federal funds rate at 7 percent and on the way lower, once people come back from the holidays, they will like what they see," Mr. Liro said.
In other developments, participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues dipped by a modest 1/8 point in fairly light trading.
Trading was also light in the tax-exempt municipal bond market. Prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to down about 1/8 point, according to market participants.
Elsewhere, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Dec. 12. The report had no impact on prices in the fixed-income markets.

HEADLINE: First Chicago Cuts Its Prime Rate to 9 1/2%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The First National Bank of Chicago cut its prime lending rate to 9 1/2 percent yesterday, becoming the largest bank to lower the closely watched rate since the Federal Reserve began pushing other interest rates lower six weeks ago. The First Chicago Corporation, which owns the bank, is the nation's 12th-largest banking company.
Despite the Fed's lead, large banks have been slow to reduce their prime rates. The only other banking companies among the 30 largest in the country that have lowered rates are the First Fidelity Bancorporation of Lawrenceville, N.J., which cut its rate to 9 3/4 percent on Monday and the Norwest Bancorporation, Minneapolis, which adopted a 9 3/4 percent rate on Tuesday. 
 Although large corporations negotiate rates on their bank loans, the prime rate is still a closely watched barometer of interest rates because rates charged to smaller businesses and many consumer loans are pegged to it. Small businesses generally pay interest rates a few percentage points above prime. Many home equity loans and credit card loans carry interest rates that are adjusted according to changes in the prime.
The scattered reductions in the prime rate have come after the Federal Reserve had made credit so available in the banking system that the cost of overnight loans between banks had fallen to about 7 percent, from 8 percent in early November. On Tuesday, the Fed signaled to the financial markets that additional rate declines were likely, reducing the discount rate it charges on loans to banks and other financial institutions to 6 1/2 percent, from 7 percent.
"The Fed has been aggressive in pushing rates down, but the cost of our funds declined more slowly," said James E. Annable, senior vice president at First Chicago. He said that First Chicago lowered its rate as soon as the move was justified by a decline in the interest rates it pays for deposits and that it was not influenced by other large banks' lack of action.
"A videotape of our meeting this morning would show that we think banks have an important role in helping the economy recover and a responsibility to lower rates when it is justified," Mr. Annable said. "Nobody will benefit from a deep recession, certainly not the banks."
He noted that investors in large certificates of deposit -- $1 million and more -- had become nervous enough about large banks' financial strength to demand higher-than-normal interest rates on new certificates.
Also in recent weeks, he noted, efforts by Japanese and other banks to borrow all the money they need before the last days of the year had put upward pressure on short-term rates in the Eurodollar market.
First Chicago's share price was unchanged yesterday, at $18.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Lower Rates Slow to Spread
 Lower rates have been slow to spread to various kinds of consumer accounts offered by banks. According to The Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla., the national average for bank money market accounts was 5.95 percent in the week ended Wednesday, down only sightly from 6.02 percent in the week ended Nov. 7. The national average for three-month certificates of deposit fell to 7.32 percent from 7.48 percent in the same period.
Kurt T. Peters, editor of Credit Card News, a Chicago publication, said that credit cards with interest rates pegged to the prime "are a fairly common offering, but as a percent of all credit card loans they probably account for no more than 15 percent of the business."
One of the most prominent companies offering such credit cards is the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which entered the business in March and has issued about six million cards. The rate on A.T.&T.'s cards is adjusted every three months, at 8.9 percentage points above the prime rate.
 
Benefits to the Economy
 When consumers and businesses pay lower interest rates on loans, there are many kinds of benefits to the economy. There is more money available for other kinds of spending, and there is less chance that businesses will default on loan payments.
The other side of the coin, as President Bush told bankers attending a meeting of the Association of Bank Holding Companies earlier this month, is that banking companies must earn profits if they are to remain strong enough to make the loans necessary for a healthy economy. And Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, was quoted by Reuters yesterday as having said, "These things take time -- they have to work through the system."
But bankers have felt growing pressure from their customers for lower rates.
James R. Campbell, president of the Norwest Bank Minnesota, the largest bank subsidiary of the Norwest Corporation, which cut its prime to 9 3/4 percent from 10 percent, said, "We had a lot of customers asking when rates would move down, and I just came from a lunch with some customers where I could tell the bank benefited from moving."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE KREMLIN;
Conference by Baker On News From Soviets

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Ladies and gentlemen, I have a brief statement on the resignation of Foreign Minister Shevardnadze, and then I'll be glad to respond to your questions.
Minister Shevardnadze's resignation and warning I think has to be taken seriously. In my experience, Minister Shevardnadze has always worked as a professional who served his country's interests. He was in the forefront of the new thinking in foreign policy and democratization at home, and I think that he has earned the respect of leaders all around the world.
We are pleased that President Gorbachev has said that there will be no change in Soviet foreign policy. Since the United States-Soviet partnership serves the interest of peace internationally, and the process of reform domestically, we of course expect that to be the case, and we will be watching events closely in the weeks ahead.
As the President has often stated, our new relationship with the Soviet Union depends upon its continuing commitment to democratization and to reform. On a personal note, let me say that I've known Eduard Shevardnadze to be a man of his word, a man of courage, conviction, and principle.
I am convinced that he is committed to peaceful reform, political and economic, in the Soviet Union. And I'm also convinced that the dramatic moves toward democratization and freedom in Central and Eastern Europe, and the new thinking in Soviet foreign policy, would never have happened without his and President Gorbachev's courageous leadership.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
 
Soviet Foreign Policy
 Q. You and he appear to have quite a close personal rapport. With the disappearance of that personal relationship, do you think there will be any impact on the progress of arms control negotiations?
A. Well, we hope not, and we frankly do not think so. President Gorbachev has said there will be no change as a consequence of this resignation in Soviet foreign policy, and if there is no change, then we would expect that the agreement with respect to Start would move forward to the end that President Gorbachev and President Bush could sign it at their February summit.
Q. Could I just follow that up? Do you think the difficulties that he mentioned this morning in his resignation speech may explain some of the hiccups and false starts in the recent negotiations?
A. I just don't know, Jim. That's not something I really can speculate on.
 
U.S. Policy on Gulf
 Q. Mr. Secretary, various Sovietologists have already speculated that this is not good news for U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf, particularly is someone more inclined toward the gulf view comes in to take that job over. Do you foresee any problem, any change there?
A. No, I don't, and the reason I don't is, again, that President Gorbachev has said that Soviet foreign policy will not change. President Gorbachev himself has assured President Bush on several occasions that the Soviets do not intend to diverge from the United Nations position on this issue.
 
Ties With Eastern Europe
 Q. Mr. Secretary, is there a possibility that this will open a window of opportunity to those forces within the Soviet Union that are not precisely enthusiastic about what has been happening in Eastern Europe, and the rapprochement with the West?
A. Well, we don't know, and we certainly hope not. As I said Monday in Brussels, we have seen some worrying signs for a period of time now, and, as I said in my statement, we would obviously be foolish, I think, not to take the warning in Minister Shevardnadze's resignation statement seriously.
But following up on that, we have made it very clear over the 23 months that we have been dealing with the Soviet Union and its efforts at reform that legitimacy depends on further democratization, and not on a return to authoritarian rule, and I said, as recently as two or three days ago that we certainly hope that there's nothing done to snuff out these rudimentary markets that are beginning to develop in the Soviet Union on the economic side.
 
Soviet Unraveling
 Q. Does this indicate that the ball of string is now beginning to unravel in the Soviet Union? Is this seen by the Bush Administration, when you look at the level of the turmoil now within Gorbachev's administration, that really profound difficulties now lie ahead beyond the scope that you were ----
A. I don't think that we would put it that way, John. We have said, for some time, that there are significant difficulties that they are facing, political -- in their efforts to reform politically and economically. Certainly this, I think, points up that there are differences of view and differences of opinion. It's not something that we haven't seen before in public debate coming out of the Supreme Soviet. It's not something we haven't seen before, and something we haven't spoken to before.
 
Military Resurgence
 Q. Isn't it obvious that Soviet foreign policy has changed and is changing here beyond this resignation, and that the military is sort of resurgent in Soviet foreign policy?
A. No, I think it's obvious that there has been for some time an internal debate within the Soviet Union, but this is not surprising and it is something that we have spoken to, as I said before, on a number of occasions.
I think that debate continues. We have no reason whatsoever to doubt President Gorbachev's statement that Soviet foreign policy will not change.
 
A Personal Relationship
 Q. I wondered if you'd talk about -- what difference do you feel that that personal relationship made?
A. Well, I made a -- I spoke, in my opening remarks, to the fact that he was a professional who I think was totally focused on representing his country and its interests as he saw them. I certainly think that's what's motivated me in my relationship with the Soviet Union. Having said that, however, I am proud to call this man a friend. I think that we achieved some significant things during the 23 months that we were able to work together, and it's -- on a purely personal note, I would have to tell you that I'm going to miss him.
 
A Mutual Approach
 Q. Mr. Secretary, what if anything more should the United States do to keep this policy that Minister Shevardnadze exemplified going?
A. I think we should continue to make the case to our interlocutors in the Soviet Union that our policy approach of searching for mutual advantage is a good approach. It is one that has paid off in the manner that I've just outlined to you externally, for both the Soviet Union and the United States. I think it has the potential of paying off in terms of internal reform -- democratization and economic reform within the Soviet Union. And it's a policy approach that we should both continue. And that's why we are heartened when we hear President Gorbachev say there will be no change in foreign policy.
 
A Soviet Crackdown
 Q. You spoke to the foreign minister in Houston about the possibility of a step back toward a possible repression. We are told you again stated very strongly the U.S. position on this. Did he give you any indication that there might be a move in this direction or some kind of crackdown? And what is your own assessment of the prospects for moving away from democratization in the Soviet Union?
A. Well, I just said, Owen, a minute ago that we certainly hope that that will not be the case. We really are not in a position today, I don't think, to stand up here and absolutely guarantee that it won't be the case, just as we haven't been in a position to do that over the course of the past 23 months, and just as we were not in a position to guarantee that force would not be used to hold Central and Eastern Europe.
Again, I think it's important that we understand -- that we all understand what we mean when we start using terms like "crackdown" and we must I think appreciate the desire to employ measured force to protect citizens against interethnic violence, armed militias, and things like that, versus using that force to suppress or stifle peaceful dissent or peaceful expression of opinion.
Q. Can you tell us what his assessment was when you raised it with him recently?
A. I simply said that we were concerned about reports that there would be some resort to force that might be legitimate in the first instance but would get out of hand. We were concerned that it might spill over and get out of hand. And they have -- I think it's fair to say that they are committed to reform, "they" being the president and the foreign minister, and they would not want to see that happen either. That's what he indicated.
Q. Do you agree with Mr. Shevardnadze's comment that a dictatorship is coming in the Soviet Union?
A. Well, we hope it isn't. That's what I mean, though, when I said I think that the warning that is embodied in this resignation needs to be taken seriously.
