HEADLINE: 3 Big Banks Reporting Loan Woes

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
With falling real estate prices and uncollectible loans chipping away at their stability, two more leading banks said yesterday that they had been forced to write off tens of millions of dollars in bad loans in the fourth quarter. A third bank cut the dividend it pays on its stock.
Such hardship announcements are becoming ever more frequent and appear to be part of a process that is spreading, creating the worst banking crisis since the mid-1970's recession, economists say. Two large banks -- the Franklin National Bank on Long Island and the Herstadt Bank in West Germany -- failed during that crisis.
 
Obstacle to New Lending
 No major bank has failed in the current crisis, but hundreds are writing off bad real estate loans, and each write-off, in effect, becomes an obstacle to new lending -- adding to the crisis. A real estate developer, for example, who is deeply in debt cannot get a fresh loan to carry him through hard times. So he, too, defaults, and another loan has to be written off, further hurting bank profits and increasing the possibility of failures. 
 "There is a contradiction here that is weakening the economy," said Albert Wojnilower, a senior adviser at the First Boston Corporation. "Bank managers, to raise capital, to keep their jobs, to comply with Federal regulations, are engaging in behavior that is destructive to their banks and destructive for the system."
 
Most Blame on Real Estate
 The three big banks that made announcements yesterday attributed their problems mainly to real estate. So did Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, which announced on Monday that it was cutting its stock dividend, with the money saved to be used to offset loan losses.
The NCNB Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., which operates banks in the Southeast and in Texas, said yesterday that 1990 profits would shrink because the bank had set aside $55 million to $65 million for bad loans in the fourth quarter. Most of those loans are not paying interest or are uncollectible. Bad loans will reduce net income this year to about $360 million from $447 million last year, the company said.
The Bank of Boston said it would report a substantial loss in the fourth quarter, although not as big a loss as the $255 million deficit in the third quarter. The bank lost $209 million in the first nine months of the year.
"The prolonged deterioration in the commercial real estate market and the ongoing downturn in the regional economy continue to adversely affect our operating results," said Ira Stepanian, chairman and chief executive. Beginning-of-the-year salary increases for 5,000 bank officers will also be deferred, he said.
The UJB Financial Corporation, which has headquarters in Princeton, N.J. and has bank offices throughout the state and in eastern Pennsylvania, said it would cut its quarterly dividend to 15 cents from 29 cents, effective Feb. 1. Again the announcement referred to the "weak real estate market and the economic slowdown." Because of them, UJB Financial will "break even or report a modest loss for all of 1990," the company said.
 
A Need to Save Cash
 Similarly on Wednesday, the Midlantic Corporation of Edison, N.J., said it was eliminating stock dividends to conserve cash. And the C&S/ Sovran Corporation, a banking company based in Atlanta, said the fourth quarter would be profitless because more than $225 million was being set aside to cover future loan losses.
The problem spreading through the banking industry stems mostly from the real estate boom of the 1980's, particularly along the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts. By mid-1990 bank loans for commercial real estate alone -- mostly office buildings -- totaled $285 billion, or 13.7 percent of the $2.08 trillion in total outstanding bank loans. Defaults on loans to corporations for leveraged buyouts are also creating difficulties, but this lending from the banking system totaled only $80 billion as of last June.
Across the country, the prices of the best commercial real estate are down 5 to 10 percent and still falling, says David Shulman, a managing director at Salomon Brothers and an expert on commercial real estate. With prices falling and 20 percent of all office space vacant today, according to the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill, building owners have found themselves unable to keep up payments or sell their buildings for large enough amounts to repay their loans.
 
Tightening Standards
 As a result there has been a rising number of loan losses -- in effect, depositors' money has been lent out and now will not be repaid. To cover these losses, the banks have drawn funds from their capital, just when Federal regulators are tightening standards. Most important, they are requiring banks to increase their capital as a percent of loans and other assets outstanding.
With capital shrinking, the banks are meeting the requirements by not making new loans and even selling off or calling in loans already on the books. As the cutback in lending spreads from real estate to other industries, many companies are having difficulty financing their operations, and they are cutting back, deepening the recession that most economists say is now under way.
"Real estate has become the key to understanding this recession," said John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Shevardnadze Resignation Cited as the Dollar Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished broadly higher yesterday as traders apparently sought a safe haven in the wake of the uncertainties created by the resignation of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
Gold prices rose in Europe but retreated slightly in United States trading. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $385.90 a troy ounce, off 10 cents from Wednesday. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $383.35 an ounce, down 55 cents. 
 The dollar gained ground in European trading and continued its climb when dealings shifted to domestic markets. In New York trading, it jumped more than 3 pfennigs against the German mark and, against the Japanese currency, it rose nearly 2 yen.
Although traders were buying dollars, much of the day's activity centered on selling the German mark on the theory that Germany is more widely exposed to the economic and political climate in the Soviet Union than other nations.
"Germany has large loans outstanding" to the Soviet Union, said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago. "And because of German monetary union, there was great expectation that they would find a huge export market within the Soviet Union."
John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, characterized trading as "a flight out of Germany rather than a flight to quality." He predicted that "we will have to see more disintegration in the Soviet Union before there is any real permanent effect" on dollar trading.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose in New York to 1.5125 marks, up from 1.4783.
Still, Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation was dramatic enough to distract attention from the weakening United States economy and declining interest rates. Lower interest rates generally hurt the dollar because they erode the value of fixed-income securities.
The move "brings the market focus to the economic fundamentals of Europe and takes some of the focus off the economic concerns in the U.S.," Mr. Malpede said.
Trading was active but typically thin ahead of the Christmas holiday, which accentuated the dollar's advance.
In New York, the dollar rose to 135.85 Japanese yen, up from 134.05 yen on Wednesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 134.58 yen, up from 133.27 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it rose further to 134.75 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9080, from $1.9316 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.8930 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9310.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.2995 Swiss francs, up from 1.2675; 5.1425 French francs, up from 5.0425; 1,139.20 Italian lire, up from 1,117.75, and 1.1593 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1588.

HEADLINE: Donations to the Neediest Giving the Homeless a Fresh Start

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
When George Horton, director of New York's Catholic Charities programs for the homeless and the hungry, interrupted a meeting among four of his homeless clients and a visitor on Tuesday night, he was politely but firmly told to return in five minutes.
For Mr. Horton, the rebuff, while annoying, was a symbolic victory. 
 "They're much more assertive and confident now," he said. "They wouldn't have done that in September."
The four people -- two men and two women -- had just completed 12 weeks in the Education Outreach Program, jointly sponsored by the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York and the Interfaith Assembly on Homelessness and Housing. The program is a mix of leadership training, finishing school and group therapy for people who are trying to battle back after losing their homes.
Supplies for the program were bought with money provided by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund began its 79th annual appeal last month, and the proceeds will be distributed to the New York Catholic Charities and six other charities. The New York Times pays for the overhead of the campaign, so all donations are used to assist the sick and poor of New York.
 
Graduates' Progress
 Of the 30 people who have completed the Education Outreach Program, more than half have found work, several others are in school and at least six have moved out of shelters into their own apartments. Some have become advocates for the homeless, visiting churches and synagogues to talk about the problems that they and others in similar situations have faced.
But Sister Ann Murray, the program's coordinator, said those accomplishments were secondary to another objective, more difficult to measure precisely. "We help people develop the groundwork -- the self-esteem -- that's needed to live independently," she said. "They don't necessarily have it when they finish, but they're a lot closer."
On Tuesday evening, the four participants said that they now felt comfortable going out into the community, while before it was difficult to look people in the eye and to follow a daily routine. They were dressed like young professionals -- the women wore makeup and jewelry, the men, slacks and new button-down shirts. And they said they saw it as their mission to dispel popular conceptions that the homeless are misfits who panhandle on street corners and wear tattered clothes.
"There are a million and one reasons for being homeless, and it could happen to anyone," said Cheryl Ann DeMoss, 34. And while the four people in the room shared a common experience, each had come to be homeless for different reasons.
 
Array of Problems
 Russell L. Bland, who spent many years in and out of jail, said that for him homelessness occurred in the early 1970's, after his mother and brother died, and he stopped caring about his own life.
One word -- crack -- summed up the cause of Phillip T. Clayton's unemployment and lost apartment.
For Patricia A. Ward, homelessness -- along with battering and sexual abuse -- had plagued her since childhood.
Ms. DeMoss said that her homelessness followed a severe depression, an overdose of pills and a stay in the hospital that left her with no place to go.
Now Mr. Bland and Ms. Ward are working, Ms. DeMoss is in the job market and Mr. Clayton is about to start nursing school.
The program did not work miracles, its staff members said. Participants are carefully screened and already on the road to recovery. They have completed drug rehabilitation programs and found transitional housing arrangements that offer support services.
But Ms. DeMoss said the program had helped her and the others begin to plan their lives. In meetings every Tuesday and Wednesday, they are forced to improve communication skills by talking to each other.

HEADLINE: Making Bad Risks Good Business

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
Recently, an executive at State Farm said he could not make money selling auto insurance to speeders, hit-and-run drivers, drunken drivers and other menaces.
"We love attitudes like that," said Bruce Marlow, chief operating officer of the Progressive Corporation. "Prejudices like that allow us to succeed." 
 Progressive, the nation's 38th-largest property and casualty insurer, has earned an enviable living by committing what seems to be heresy: It specializes in covering drivers whose coverage has been rejected or canceled by other insurers.
These pariahs not only include drivers with blemished records but also people rejected as too old or too young, because they own a fast car like a Maserati or Lamborghini or because they do not speak English. In the process, Progressive has become not only one of the largest issuers of "nonstandard" auto policies in the United States but also one of the most profitable auto insurers of any type.
Indeed, most insurers no longer hope to make money on auto insurance. They look to other lines of insurance or to investment income for profit. But since 1980, Progressive has consistently made money from its offbeat auto insurance business, producing an average annual return on investment of 23.6 percent companywide.
Under the 25-year stewardship of Peter B. Lewis, Progressive's 57-year-old president and chief executive, the company has grown to $1.3 billion in revenues and 6,000 employees from $6 million in revenues and 100 employees.
"Progressive pretty much provides an example of how to run a successful insurance company," said Richard Haverland, executive vice president of the Great American Holding Corporation, a Cincinnati-based insurance group.
More than that, Progressive's success is a standing reproach to the conventional wisdom of the insurance business, which is under attack on many fronts.
Most broadly, Progressive's strong financial performance validates the view that even bad risks can be insured profitably, provided the premiums are high enough.
An unmarried man in his 30's in Chicago who drives a late-model midsized American car and who has one drunken driving conviction would pay more than $2,500 a year for complete coverage through Progressive. A comparable motorist with a clean driving record could pay about half that amount or less through another company.
Further, the fact that Progressive will issue an auto policy to just about anyone tends to rebut the view that soon no insurers will take on motorists with blemished driving records. Allstate, State Farm and other giant auto-policy writers have increasingly moved toward insuring only drivers with nearly perfect records. The only drivers Progressive rejects are recidivist drunken drivers, motorists who have lied on insurance applications and people who have staged accidents to collect claims.
 
A Model System
 Perhaps most importantly, Progressive may provide a model for how successful auto insurance companies will operate in the future. Progressive can insure high-risk drivers profitably because of its talent for measuring risks and setting premiums.
Progressive still applies the basic insurance principle of grouping drivers into large broad-brush categories, but it has many more categories than the typical insurer, and, correspondingly, many more premium levels. At the heart of its success is a data base that includes statistics on accident rates and driving histories of various kinds of drivers and repair costs of various cars -- a data base that is unusually large and detailed for a company its size.
Using this data, Progressive separates drivers into far more risk categories than do competitors and sets a wide variety of prices. That enables Progressive to be profitable on more customers than is an insurer that averages risk to come up with a smaller number of catch-all prices.
 
Motorcycle Coverage
 For instance, many insurers consider all motorcyclists to be big risks and charge them similar prices because of the serious injuries they suffer in accidents. Progressive studied the history of motorcycle accidents and found that big-engine touring motorcycles were not all that risky if they were driven by an older, married driver. So, beginning in 1980, Progressive began charging older, married motorcyclists lower premiums than younger cyclists. Today, Progressive claims to have the largest market share among companies that sell motorcycle insurance through independent agents.
Similarly, many insurers divide drivers into only two age groups -- below and above age 25. Progressive concluded that a 45-year-old driver was, on average, safer than a 35-year-old driver, who in turn was a better bet than a 25-year-old. Progressive has 11 age categories.
Traffic tickets provide another example of how Progressive segments the market. Many insurers consider all tickets to be black marks, regardless of when they were received. Progressive considers the age of a ticket, giving breaks to policyholders whose citations were issued a while ago.
"The thing that is astonishing about all this is that it is such common sense yet hardly anyone else does it," said Joyce Culbert, vice president of the Firemark Group, an insurance-research firm in Parsippany, N.J.
Insurance experts add that at a time when profit margins throughout the auto insurance business are thin and are expected to shrink further because of tighter rate regulation, Progressive's knack for accurately pricing risks may provide a model.
 
700,000 Customers
 About 15 percent of American drivers do not qualify for regular automobile insurance. Among companies that specialize in issuing such policies, Progressive is by far the biggest, with 9 percent of the market. Its 700,000 policyholders drive 1.4 million cars. While many of Progressive's policyholders are genuinely bad drivers who could not obtain insurance elsewhere, many of the policyholders have no marks on their records.
For example, many insurers prefer not to insure drivers older than 65, drivers who do not speak English, and young, first-time drivers with no insurance history. Like the motorists with bad records, these drivers come to Progressive because no other companies will insure them. They prefer Progressive over state-run assigned-risk insurance pools because its rates -- while well above standard rates -- are 5 percent to 10 percent below premiums at the state-run insurance systems..
To be sure, Progressive's record has not been unblemished. A number of years ago, the company began selling extended-warranty programs for new cars. Claims ran so high that Progressive quickly found itself having to abandon the business.
A few years later, Progressive began issuing collision and liability policies to truckers but again suffered big losses because of unexpectedly large claims and low premium levels. Progressive has since made the business profitable by raising prices and not renewing the coverage of trucking companies whose policies proved particularly costly.
If Progressive's foray into truck insurance was handled hastily, part of the blame must go to Mr. Lewis. A son of a founder of the company, Mr. Lewis is known as a unusually demanding manager who prefers to make quick decisions to enter and leave a business. He delights in saying that Progressive has "fired more Harvard Business School graduates than most other insurance companies have hired." Indeed, in the last decade, no fewer than 15 top officers of Progressive have left the company after locking horns with Mr. Lewis.
"I get off on helping people be all they can be, and I do get frustrated when people decline to risk, stretch, learn and grow," Mr. Lewis said in a recent interview at his office in Mayfield Heights, Ohio, near Cleveland.
But there is no denying that Mr. Lewis has produced enviable results. Over the last 10 years, Progressive's premium revenue has grown 23.7 percent annually on a compound basis, compared with 8.6 percent for the industry. And while profits fell last year because of to a special provision for auto-insurance rate rollbacks in California, the overall trend has been positive. From 1980 to 1988, Progressive's net income increased to $108.1 million from $22.6 million.
Over the last year, Progressive's stock has traded at of low of $32.975 a share in April and at a high of $56.375 in September. Yesterday, the stock closed unchanged at $49.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Growth Is Predicted
 With the nonstandard auto insurance market growing because of the increasing insistence of the giant auto insurers to cover only above-average drivers, Progressive's nonstandard business will grow, analysts say. It has been growing at nearly double-digit rates, and many analysts say that pace could continue.
Auto insurers that have chosen to steer clear of bad risks contend that no company can make money over the long run by insuring bad drivers. But if comments by business scholars are any guide, Progressive may continue to fare well.
"Progressive does unconventional things in ways that make perfect intellectual sense," said George G. C. Parker, who teaches a course in financial institutions at the Stanford Business School. "Their behavior is consistent with an economist's view of how markets can operate when left to work."

HEADLINE: HEALTH SPENDING IS FOUND TO SOAR

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Consumers, private insurers and state and Federal programs spent more than $604 billion on health care last year, the Government said today.
The total amounted to roughly $2,400 for everyone in the country, and, as in every other year since 1986, the rate of growth in health-care spending accelerated. 
 "The ability of society to meet other needs is affected by the growing share of economic resources claimed by health expenditures," Gail R. Wilensky, chief of the Health Care Financing Administration, said in issuing the data.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, called the growth in health costs alarming, saying that it cut some people off from medical care and put a heavy financial burden on many of those who are able to get care.
Dr. Sullivan is leading a review that the Domestic Policy Council has undertaken on the nation's health care system; he is to present his recommendations next year. Dr. Sullivan has already rejected Government-financed national health insurance as a solution, saying he favors continuation of a public-private system.
The latest data showed that health spending last year accounted for 11.6 percent of the gross national product, the total of all goods and services produced, and that it was 11.1 percent higher than in 1988. The gross national product rose 6.7 percent over the same period.
The total spent as well as the share of the gross national product that it represented set records, the Government said.
Federal spending on health programs in 1989 amounted to 14.7 percent of the total Federal budget of about $1.1 trillion; this was up from 14.1 percent the previous year.
Of the total spent on health care last year, 33 percent was paid by private insurance, 21 percent by consumers, 17 percent by Medicare and 10 percent by Federal and state Medicaid programs. Other government programs were said to contribute 15 percent and other private sources, 4 percent.
The Federal agency also said that 39 cents of every dollar went to hospitals, 19 cents to doctors and 8 cents to nursing homes. It said that 22 cents was spent on dental and other professional services, home health care and drugs and vision products, and that the remaining 12 cents paid for administration, research and construction.
Nearly $50 billion was reported spent on nursing home care. Of that, 44 percent was paid directly by patients. Most of it, 41 percent of the total, came out of Social Security income. Medicaid and Medicare paid 51 percent of the bill, and private insurance paid 1 percent.

HEADLINE: New York Area Being Hit Hard By Loss of Jobs

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

DATELINE: NEW YORK, NY

 BODY:
Enduring its bleakest year in more than a decade, the New York metropolitan region lost an estimated 100,000 jobs in private industry in 1990, according to a Federal report released yesterday.
New York City accounted for half the jobs lost. But the weakness that began on Wall Street three years ago with the stock market's plunge has spread to northeastern New Jersey, which the report showed has lost 22,000 jobs this year; the northern New York suburbs, which lost 10,000 jobs, and Long Island, which lost 14,000 jobs, its biggest drop in nearly 40 years of Government record-keeping. 
 In a gloomy briefing that seemed reminiscent of the 1970's, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, used more than 40 charts and tables to illustrate how a part of the country that was booming only a few years ago had stalled, reversed course and was now suffering a steepening decline.
 
The Latest Is the Worst
 "The most recent months have been the worst," Mr. Ehrenhalt said at the briefing at the bureau's Manhattan office on the report's projected figures for the year.
Asked what that meant for the coming year, he said, "I don't think it's run its course."
A few hours after Mr. Ehrenhalt's briefing, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman told the City Council that New York City lost 45,000 jobs -- about 1.5 percent of its total employment -- in the 12 months beginning in October 1989. She also projected a loss of 90,000 public and private sector jobs for 1991.
"That represents an acceleration of job losses that we expect to continue through the beginning of 1991, and then maybe moderate a bit," said Stephen Kagann, her chief economist.
Sylvia Ashrafiuon, director of New York services for the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting service in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said Mr. Ehrenhalt's figures might prove "pretty conservative," especially for New York City, "when the year is finished and all the bodies are counted."
 
Final Projection
 The final projection of a loss of 100,000 jobs brought the region's private-sector employment to 6.8 million, a level it last reached in 1987.
The loss was the first significant one suffered by New York City since 1982, when it lost 12,000 jobs. The decline brought the city's private-sector employment to about 3 million.
From 1970 to 1978, a time when the city's economy collapsed and its municipal government narrowly escaped bankruptcy, the city lost an average of 77,000 jobs a year.
In his report, Mr. Ehrenhalt found that some sectors of the economy that were among the strongest during the region's boom were now deteriorating the most rapidly.
 
A Loss for Construction
 Construction, for example, which added an average of 16,200 jobs a year from 1979 to 1987, lost 36,000 jobs this year, he said. The commercial and retail sales sector, which had been gaining 32,500 jobs a year, has lost 41,000 jobs. And the finance, insurance and real-estate industries, which added 27,800 jobs annually through most of the 1980's, had a loss of 23,600 jobs, many with high salaries.
Services are still growing, though more slowly. And more of the new jobs are relatively low-paying positions in health and social services; the gain in more lucrative fields like law and accounting has dropped from an annual average of 43,600 jobs during the boom to 19,500 this year.
The long decline in manufacturing accelerated sharply this year, Mr. Ehrenhalt reported. The region, which lost just over 30,000 factory jobs annually from 1979 to 1989, has lost 49,000 such jobs this year, he said.
Ms. Ashrafiuon attributed the decline in Nassau and Suffolk Counties to the weakness of defense-related and high-tech manufacturing.
 
Municipal Cutbacks
 Government employment grew by 16,700, but that trend seems certain to slacken or even be reversed in 1991 as New York City contemplates reducing its work force by thousands of positions through attrition and layoffs to close a widening budget gap.
Mr. Ehrenhalt estimated that the city would lose about 15,000 more jobs than the city itself projected when it modified its budget just last month. In a telephone interview after the briefing yesterday, a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, Leland T. Jones, said, "As we move through time, the data change and our projections change."
The unemployment rate in the region, which comprises 23 counties in New York and northeastern New Jersey, is still lower than the national average, 5.3 percent against 5.4 percent.
Eight counties in the region averaged jobless rates below 4 percent during the year: Hunterdon, Somerset, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Nassau, Morris and Bergen. Seven areas averaged rates higher than 7 percent: Queens, Staten Island, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Hudson, Passaic and Essex Counties.
 
'Significant Silver Lining'
 Mr. Ehrenhalt called the unemployment rate a "small but significant silver lining." But he said it was largely the result of slow work-force growth due partly to discouraged job hunters and partly to lower birth rates beginning in the 1960's, which have reduced the number of young workers.
Employment, rather than unemployment, is considered the most important measure of the health of a local economy. Mr. Ehrenhalt based his analysis on seasonally adjusted data from joint Federal and state surveys from January through October. He used that data to estimate job loses for November and December, then adjusted upward the final figures -- including a loss of 92,000 jobs in the region -- to account for a pending revision of the numbers.
"It kind of accelerated during the course of the year," he said of the employment losses. "There was a clear deterioration."

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Visions of a Tax Cut From Republican Right

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
A con servative organiz er-around-town says he knows how to beat George Bush in the 1992 New Hampshire primary: "We'll run his 1988 New Hampshire ads against him."
Those were the ads in which Mr. Bush stopped Senator Bob Dole dead in his political tracks by accusing him of flip-flopping on taxes. 
 Now it is Mr. Bush who has a tax problem. "No new taxes" was not a sound bite to right-wing Republicans. It was a governing philosophy, and one that Mr. Bush, in their view, shed like so much bunting and ribbon after he moved into the White House.
The President has tried to soothe the the rage on the right with the explanation that the tax increase he agreed to this fall was a one-time ransom to get Democrats to agree to a budget deal vital to the economy. Now, says the White House, when the President says no more new taxes, he means it.
The conservatives, to put it politely, are skeptical -- a mood heightened by Mr. Bush's comment this week that a cut in the capital gains tax seems politically out of reach. Some are talking about challenging Mr. Bush in the primaries. A group in New Hampshire thinks Gordon J. Humphrey, who is retiring from the Senate this year, might run in his home state primary to make the point. And the columnist Patrick J. Buchanan is thinking about a campaign, too.
The organizer-around-town, with those visions of New Hampshire ads dancing in his head, has another horse. He is Pete S. du Pont, the former Governor of Delaware, who was one of Mr. Bush's opponents for the Republican nomination in 1988.
It happens that Mr. du Pont is organizing a new political committee with a simple avowed goal: to fight tax increases and press for tax cuts. "Mr. Darman, Mr. Brady and the President have taken the Republican economic philosophy and thrown it over the side and adopted the Democratic philosophy," he said. "I hope we can persuade them to come back to the girl they brought to the dance."
Mr. du Pont believes this would be good politics and good economics. With the fall of communism, he said, a commitment to low taxes is the single most important issue differentiating Republicans from Democrats, and the way out of recession is to cut taxes and spur growth.
This may strike some historical- minded people as the simple wisdom that led to the current massive deficits. But Mr. du Pont, his blue-blood pedigree notwithstanding, has a blue-collar suggestion: cut Social Security taxes. This aligns him with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, and that is not the first time Mr. du Pont has shared the dias with an iconoclastic Democrat. (He and Bruce Babbitt were strange bedfellows more than once in 1988.)
Mr. du Pont insists his new group is not a Presidential exploratory committee. His proof is that he has recruited a fairly wide range of Republicans with differing Presidential loyalities, including another 1988 candidate, the Rev. Pat Robertson, the religious broadcaster. Mr. du Pont says his purpose is not to challenge Mr. Bush but to help him.
"I kind of hope that if we can give him a little of this kind of help he would make a speech that said: 'You know, we made a terrible mistake. We put through a bill that raised spending, that raised taxes, that hasn't helped with the deficit. Here's an economic growth package that will do a much better job,' and put that before Congress. That would unite the Republican Party again."
 But what if Mr. Bush never gives that speech? Some Republicans loyal to Mr. Bush suggest that Mr. Du Pont is trying to carve out a political base on the right to turn to in 1996.
Everywhere Mr. du Pont has gone in recent weeks he has left conservatives with the impression that he might run if the President has not patched up his relations with the right. The conservative-around-town thinks Mr. du Pont could, at the least, win a few states in 1992.
Mr. du Pont says that talk of a challenge, by anyone, rests on the notion that Mr. Bush will ignore the cries from within his own party.
"I fervently hope it's all going to come back together again," he said. "You don't challenge sitting Presidents very often, and never successfully. Hardly ever successfully."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Et Tu, Eduard

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation recalls us to our sense of proportion in world affairs. It makes us realize that while we have been preoccupied with the Persian Gulf, life and politics in the Soviet Union have been deteriorating to what is now a point of menace.
Mr. Shevardnadze was Mikhail Gorbachev's closest ally in the opening up of Soviet society. According to Mr. Gorbachev, the whole idea of glasnost and perestroika -- opening and restructuring -- arose from a conversation between the two men as they walked on a Black Sea beach. 
 The resignation was a thunderclap not only because of who he was but because of how he went. Mr. Shevardnadze gave as his reason that the Soviet Union was moving in the direction of "dictatorship."
It was as if James Baker had told a Congressional committee that he was resigning as his friend George Bush's Secretary of State because the American political system was headed for disaster.
Why did Mr. Shevardnadze resign? An immediate cause was that he was tired of being hounded by conservative critics. In recent months he has been savagely attacked for allowing the reunification of Germany on Western terms and "begging" for American food aid.
That criticism reflected a division in Russian thought going back a century and more, between those who favor Westernization and Slavophiles who want the country to look inward to a mystic Slavic tradition. Mr. Shevardnadze is a Westernizer through and through.
The anti-Western tradition is joined now by Communist Party bureaucrats opposed to the loss of their privileges. And lately a third powerful element has joined the resistance to change: those who call for a forceful restoration of order in the Soviet Union as the answer to economic and political strains.
The day before Mr. Shevardnadze's announcement, a coalition of military, religious and literary figures called for direct rule by the Kremlin in turbulent areas of the country. The 53 signers of an open letter included the Chief of the Armed Forces General Staff, Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev.
The letter called on President Gorbachev to "put an end to the chaos" and suggested "instituting a state of emergency and presidential rule in zones of major conflicts."
Mr. Gorbachev said he was ready to do that where there was "a serious threat to the state."
Against the background of such talk, Mr. Shevardnadze's warning of dictatorship looks extremely serious. Is it possible that Mikhail Gorbachev, the man who so courageously moved the Soviet Union out of its paralyzing fear, is now prepared to go backward? It is certainly true that he is relying increasingly on the military and the K.G.B. in internal affairs.
A leading Soviet expert here, Prof. Marshall Goldman of Wellesley College and Harvard, said the Soviet President had been asking for more and more legal powers.
"With what he has he finds he can do nothing," Professor Goldman said. "So maybe he thinks, 'If I get just this one more, I can make it work.' It's really backwards. When he gets another power and can do nothing, he loses more credibility. But he's driven -- he can't think of anything else to do.
"This was a golden era. But maybe it's over."
For us in the West to write off Mikhail Gorbachev would be both unfair and foolish. He has done more than anyone would have thought possible to introduce democracy. If he is faltering now, it may not be for lack of desire to continue on the reform path but simply because the difficulties are so great.
But whatever we wish, the fact is that Mr. Gorbachev has lost credibility with his people -- the legitimacy that enables leaders to govern democratically. And that has worrying consequences.
How is the new world order that President Bush wants to build through the United Nations going to work with a Soviet leadership under internal nationalist pressure? Can Mr. Bush continue to count on Soviet support in the Persian Gulf crisis? Will the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty go forward without Mr. Shevardnadze?
The other day Mr. Gorbachev was surrounded by reporters in the lobby of the Congress of People's Deputies. He said:
"Unfortunately our society is not ready for the procedures of a law-based state. We don't have that level of political culture, those traditions. All that will come in the future, but the important thing in the meantime is not to smash each other's bones."

HEADLINE: How Do We Know Port Authority Isn't Being Mismanaged?;
Look at Oakland

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your rationale for the Port Authority's proposed $1 increase for four bridges and two tunnels in "For Whom the Tolls Toll" (Topics of The Times, Dec. 4) eludes me. From relatives in the San Francisco Bay area we have heard about the destruction and rebuilding of the Oakland Bay Bridge Tunnel. The toll before last year's earthquake was $1; it remains at $1. What is California doing that New Jersey and New York can't do?
Most of us commuters would love to work close to home rather than brave the George Washington Bridge every day. It is up to the Port Authority, with the legislatures of New Jersey and New York to come up with a more equitable and appropriate solution -- especially since the costs to operate the PATH are included. The task is politically and economically difficult, but bridge and tunnel commuters cannot be asked to shoulder everyone's burden.
 
TOBY GLICK
L. WENDY POST
Teaneck, N.J., Dec. 7, 1990

HEADLINE: Texan Convicted of S.& L. Fraud

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Don R. Dixon, who had been one of the most audacious savings and loan operators in Texas, was convicted by a Federal jury today on 23 counts of fraud involving his mishandling of $41 million in loans for his personal benefit and other violations.
The verdict raised the prospect of a long prison term, as well as fines that could total more than $500,000, for Mr. Dixon for his conduct as the owner of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association in Dallas from 1982 to 1987. 
 Once a sleepy institution specializing in home loans, Vernon was transformed by Mr. Dixon into a high-risk lender on land and speculative properties. Mr. Dixon was ousted by Federal regulators in 1987 and Vernon was seized by the Government a few months later, with 96 percent of its loans nonperforming.
 
$1.3 Billion Cost
 The institution's giant losses are expected to cost taxpayers an estimated $1.3 billion.
Mr. Dixon is the 71st person convicted of fraud under investigations completed by the Dallas Bank Fraud Task Force, an agency created by the Justice Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Government savings regulators to pursue financial fraud in Texas. The task force has brought indictments against 93 people since it was organized in 1987.
Most of the other convictions, however, have been of owners, executives or borrowers of institutions whose losses have paled against those of Vernon.
"This is obviously the first major owner of an S.& L. here in Texas that has been convicted," said Robert Hauberg, the lead United States attorney, who argued the case against Mr. Dixon.
Mr. Dixon attended a bail hearing after his conviction and was taken from there in handcuffs to the Dallas County Jail, where he is being held until his sentencing. Judge A. Joe Fish of the Federal Distict Court in North Texas said he would sentence Mr. Dixon at a hearing on Feb. 19.
In completing 10 days of deliberation following a 6-week trial, the jury found that Mr. Dixon diverted $577,000 in Vernon loans made to a borrower to cover rental payments on a lavish beach house north of San Diego, in Solana Beach, Calif. The borrower obtained the money by falsifying statements, the jury said.
Mr. Dixon, who is 51 years old, also was convicted of using Vernon's money to pay women who accompanied senior Vernon officers and directors to a party in California in 1985. The jury said he also used Vernon's aircraft and money to promote interstate prostitution in taking the female companions from Dallas to California.
The jury concluded, however, that Mr. Dixon was not guilty on 15 counts of improper attempts to influence political candidates and to defraud the Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas. Mr. Dixon was also found not guilty of making payments to women who accompanied him and a former Texas savings commissioner on a trip to San Francisco in 1985 and to Kansas in 1986.
 
Ties to Politicians
 The Federal indictment, issued last June, had accused Mr. Dixon of contributing more than $3,000 to 13 political candidates and political committees. The candidates were unaware that the payments might have been illegal, the Government has said. The candidates included Jim Wright, the former House Speaker; Tony Coelho, the former House majority leader, and Senators Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, and Alan D. Cranston, the California Democrat.
Mr. Dixon was part of a group of savings executives in North Texas who enlisted House Speaker Wright's support in 1986 to oppose an effort by Federal regulators to seize insolvent Texas savings institutions and oust the owners and directors.
Analysts and economists have said the cost of the savings-industry bailout was increased by billions of dollars because Mr. Wright and members of Congress were successful in blocking regulators from closing dozens of troubled institutions.
 
Undecided on an Appeal
 Mr. Dixon told reporters after the verdict was announced today that he had not decided if he would appeal. He faces a maximum prison term of 120 years and fines of $560,000.
In addition to the criminal action against Mr. Dixon, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been seeking $530 million from him and other former Vernon officers under a civil lawsuit it filed against the group in March 1987. But it is unlikely that much of the money will be recovered. Mr. Dixon, for one, filed for personal bankruptcy in 1987.
In a statement, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the guilty verdicts against Mr. Dixon vindicated the Government's strategy in several Vernon cases. That strategy involved seeking convictions among lower-ranking officials as Government investigators and lawyers sought to build strong cases against senior officials and Mr. Dixon.
"His excessive life style and illegal management practices stood as a symbol of the wrongdoing in our national thrift industry," Mr. Thornburgh said.
Seven former high-ranking Vernon officers have been convicted in the last two years. Vernon's former chairman and chief executive, Woody F. Lemons, is serving the first year of a 30-year prison term that he received from a Federal judge in April. Former Vernon employees and executives testified against Mr. Dixon during his trial.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Don R. Dixon leaving Federal District Court in Dallas yesterday with his wife, Dana, after he was convicted on 23 counts of fraud. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In Haiti, a Political Cockfight

BYLINE: By Amy Wilentz; Amy Wilentz is author of "The Rainy Season: Haiti Since Duvalier."

 BODY:
As anyone knows who has ever seen one, a Caribbean cockfight is an iffy thing. The beautiful birds claw and peck at each other's eyeballs, and the overheated crowd throws money at the caller and shouts encouragement. In the middle of the fight, the bird you thought was winning can suddenly sink like a stone, and all that you've invested in him -- the hope and excitement, as well as the money -- sinks with him. Haitian politics is like that, too.
In last weekend's elections, the ballot symbol for Haiti's new president, Father Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was a fighting cock -- in Haitian creole, kok kalite. And even before the polls closed Sunday night, the supporters of Father Aristide were crowing in the streets of Port-au-Prince, the capital, celebrating his unofficial victory. They were rejoicing in a virtually violence-free election (the first in recent memory) and, more important, the triumph of a man who will stand up for the average Haitian. 
 But the fight is just starting, and if he is not himself to sink like a stone, Father Aristide will need a lot of help. In Haiti, as in most other third world countries with traditions of corruption and exploitation, the arrival of a freely elected government is just as likely to signal the start of chaos and unrest as it is a final victory for democracy.
Between now and his inauguration on Feb. 7 (the anniversary of the 1986 downfall of the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier), Father Aristide will face two major hurdles. First, he will have to insure that the army and the Tontons Macoute, the violent, paramilitary supporters of the Duvalier family, do not conspire to steal his presidency. These forces were held at bay during the election by U.S. pressure, which must be sustained.
Recently, for example, Roger Lafontant, a former leader of the Tontons Macoute, vowed before the foreign press that he would never allow Father Aristide to become president. Mr. Lafontant was not talking about his political clout; outside his headquarters after the election, scores of his supporters brandished automatic weapons.
Although a warrant for Mr. Lafontant's arrest was issued this summer, the military has neglected to act upon it. If the Duvalierists continue to behave as outlaws, Father Aristide -- who has escaped at least three assassination attempts since 1986 -- cannot consider himself safe.
Second, Father Aristide will have to forge a consensus government that can surmount enormous obstacles to change. Since his coalition, the National Front for Democracy and Change, did not field enough legislative candidates to gain a majority in the parliament, he will be forced to choose a prime minister from the opposition. A rivalry between the president and prime minister could lead to stalemate, instability and, eventually, a military takeover.
One of the first orders of business for Father Aristide -- and one that will set his administration off from its corrupt predecessors -- will be dealing with the public clamor for punishment of abusive officials of past regimes. Since 1986, less than a handful of criminals from the Duvalier era have been tried, although thousands of Haitians have lost relatives and friends to the Tontons Macoute.
As a priest, Father Aristide constantly called for such prosecutions. To initiate them, however, he must have the cooperation of the army -- the same men who have refused so far to arrest Mr. Lafontant.
Faced with Father Aristide's enormous popular mandate -- and following its own uncharacteristically good behavior in the elections -- the army may well stand by and allow the new president to take over the government. Whether the generals will tolerate the investigations and trials merited by the crimes of the old regime -- which would implicate many in the army -- is an open question.
To accomplish all of this, Father Aristide will need U.S. economic aid and political support. Yet, in the past, his liberation theology and occasional anti-Yankee rhetoric did not endear him to Washington.
Lately, however, he seems to have realized who will be buttering his presidential bread in days to come. He has said he wants a relationship with the U.S. that is based on "dignity," a decent enough goal and one designed not to raise hackles on either side.
For his part, Ambassador Alvin Adams, a Bush appointee, maintained an exemplary neutral stance on Father Aristide's candidacy. He has promised to work with the man the Haitian people elected -- no matter their past ideological differences.
"Ti pay pa ti pay," runs a famous Haitian proverb encouraging caution and determination, "zwazo fe nich-li." Straw by straw, the bird makes his nest. During his campaign, the formerly impetuous Father Aristide seemed to adhere to that wise maxim. Now, given the time and support, he may change things in Haiti -- little by little, for real.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Prices Fall Sharply; Gold and Platinum Also Off

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York in a wave of profit taking that erased most of this week's earlier gains. Gold and platinum futures also retreated.
Silver futures ended 17.4 cents to 19 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in December down 17.4 cents at $4.025 an ounce. 
 On the Commodity Exchange, gold for December delivery settled at $382.50 an ounce, down $3.40. Platinum was $11.50 to $11.70 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with January at $407.20 an ounce.
Traders who bought metals contracts earlier in the week took profits in a market made thin and volatile by the absence of many people who were getting an early start on Christmas, said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
Spot silver prices had soared nearly 24 cents in the two previous trading sessions after the Federal Reserve Board moved to lower interest rates on Wednesday. Silver has many industrial applications, and its price surged amid hopes that lower rates would stimulate the economy.
But "it moved up too fast, it was overbought," Ms. Raptopoulos said. When a few traders started selling into yesterday's thin market, others followed suit and prices plunged, she said.
The New York commodities markets will not reopen until Wednesday. In Chicago, the Board of Trade and the Mercantile Exchange will hold abbreviated trading sessions Monday.
Soybean futures plunged on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting frustration over the slack pace of export sales and fears that a political shake-up is brewing in the Soviet Union that could bring a halt to American sales of soybean meal to the Soviets.
Wheat futures settled 1/4 cent to 1 1/2 cents higher, with March at $2.615 a bushel; corn was 1/2 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher, with March at $2.34 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 3/4 cent lower, with March at $1.1125 a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 8 1/2 cents lower, with January at $5.6275 a bushel.
Orange juice futures for January delivery fell sharply amid profit taking on the New York Cotton Exchange. The drop came after several days of strong gains tied to what weather forecasters had said was a slim chance of freezing weather in Florida during the Christmas weekend.
Orange juice contracts for other months, which are limited to daily moves of 5 cents a pound, rose moderately to catch up with January. There is no price limit now on the January contract, and it had jumped a total of 16 cents in the three previous sessions.
Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 3.6 cents lower to 1.85 cents higher yesterday, with January at $1.164 a pound.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports Rise, to $604 Billion, In Health Care Spending in 1989

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Consumers, private insurers and state and Federal programs spent a record total of more than $604 billion on health care last year, the Government reported Thursday.
The total amounted to roughly $2,400 for each person in the country, and, as in every other year since 1986, the rate of growth in health-care spending accelerated. 
 "The ability of society to meet other needs is affected by the growing share of economic resources claimed by health expenditures," Gail R. Wilensky, chief of the Health Care Financing Administration, said in issuing the data.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, called the growth in health costs alarming, saying that it cut some people off from medical care and put a heavy financial burden on many of those who were able to get care.
Dr. Sullivan is leading a review that the Domestic Policy Council has undertaken on the nation's health care system. He is to present his recommendations next year, but he has already rejected Government-financed national health insurance as a solution, saying he favors continuation of a public-private system.
The latest data showed that health spending last year equaled 11.6 percent of the gross national product, the total of all goods and services produced, and that it was 11.1 percent higher than in 1988. The gross national product rose 6.7 percent over the same period.
Federal spending on health programs amounted to 14.7 percent of the total Federal budget of about $1.1 trillion; this was up from 14.1 percent the previous year.
Of the total spent on health care last year, 33 percent was paid by private insurance, 21 percent by consumers, 17 percent by Medicare and 10 percent by Medicaid. Other government programs contributed 15 percent, and other private sources 4 percent.
The data also show that 39 cents of every health-care dollar went to hospitals, 19 cents to doctors and 8 cents to nursing homes. Twenty-two was spent on dental and other professional services, home health care and drugs and vision products, and the remaining 12 cents paid for administration, research and construction.

HEADLINE: New England Bank Offered Swap for Debt

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Bondholders of the Bank of New England Corporation proposed a debt-for-equity swap yesterday that could provide the troubled bank with needed cash. The bank also settled accusations of fraudulent accounting practices with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The proposed swap, which is subject to approval by the bank's directors, would give bondholders 92 percent of the company's common stock in exchange for $705 million in debentures. The deal is intended to reduce the bank's interest payments and provide financial flexibilty. It is currently considered to be insolvent. 
 "This is clearly a positive sign that gives the bank more life," said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day in Portland, Me. "But it is not the key issue that will permit the bank to survive. Management is performing a heroic effort in attempting to turn the bank around. But the deck is stacked against it with the New England environment."
 
 Like Cod Liver Oil
 Mr. Cassidy added that the bondholders' arrangement was "not a slam-dunk done deal." He said that approval was also needed from all bondholders and existing common shareholders. "It's in the best interest of everyone to approve it, but it's like cod liver oil," he added. "It doesn't taste good when it goes down, but the bank is sick and it needs it."
Under the plan, existing shareholders would find their stake severely diluted as 92 percent of the bank's ownership would be almost evenly divided between holders of the $181 million senior debt and $525 million in subordinated debt. Bondholders would also receive an additional $100 million in newly issued debt that would not pay interest, but would be redeemable in five years.
James Dorsey, a spokesman for the bank, declined to comment on the bondholders' proposal. "We will review it carefully and discuss it with the board of directors," he said.
In the S.E.C. settlement, the bank neither admitted nor denied that it had falsified its 1989 third-quarter earnings. But it agreed to restate those earnings and to allow independent accountants to continue a review of its internal accounting procedures, as well as its quarterly financial statements for two years.
"We're pleased to have been able to arrive at a satisfactory settlement with the S.E.C. to put this matter behind us," Mr. Dorsey said. "This settlement has no effect on our current operations and will not interfere in any way with our ongoing affairs."
 
 Plight of Former Officers
 The S.E.C. settlement, however, could have a significant impact on the bank's former officers, many of whom are being sued by disgruntled shareholders. With the agreement to restate the earnings, "the former officers of the company are going to have a tough time proving their innocence," Mr. Cassidy said. "The S.E.C. is essentially saying that the management did not tell the truth," he added.
The swap would not only eliminate $60 million a year in interest payments, but it would also raise the bank's capital from a 1.1 percent of total assets to the mandated 3 percent.
Still, this does not secure the bank's future, even if approved. Mr. Cassidy noted that over 6 to 12 months, the bank would have to reduce its $2.8 billion nonperforming loan portfolio, as well as begin to grow out of its problems with new loans. Yet this effort could be thwarted by the depressed New England economy, particularly the real estate sector. Most of the bank's troubled loans are commercial real estate loans.
Any strategy to improve the bank's fortunes is "directly correlated to the health of the New England economy, which has been in a downslide since spring of 1989 and is continuing that downslide," Mr. Cassidy said.

HEADLINE: Minutes From Fed Meeting Show Backdrop of Rate Cuts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve set the stage for its recent interest rate reductions at a mid-November meeting of its monetary policy committee, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
The central bank has permitted four reductions of its Federal funds rate since October and on Wednesday it dropped the discount rate from 7 percent to 6 1/2 percent, the first decline in four years. 
 The decline in the Federal funds rate on Oct. 29, to 7 3/4 percent, from 8 percent, was in response to the Federal budget-cutting agreement between the Bush Administration and Congress.
But the Federal Open Market Committee noted weakening economic activity at its Nov. 13 meeting and agreed to another "slight reduction."
The move, the minutes said, was intended to "provide some insurance against a deep and prolonged recession without incurring a substantial risk in current circumstances of fostering intensified inflationary pressures."
And, the minutes said, the committee agreed to give weight "to potential developments that might require some slight further easing" until the next meeting. That meeting was held Tuesday and was followed by the cut in the discount rate. The Federal funds rate is also closer now to 7 percent.
Between the meetings, the Federal funds rate fell to 7 1/2 percent on Nov. 16 and to 7 1/4 percent on Dec. 7. The rate is the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans. The discount rate is the interest the Fed charges on loans to banks and other financial institutions.
The minutes show that the committee members were concerned about "the growing signs of a softening economy, the related vulnerability of many business and financial firms to added financial strains and the increased reluctance of institutional lenders to accommodate less-than-prime business borrowers."

HEADLINE: In Hard Times, More Gifts For the Neediest Cases Fund

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
As strange as it might sound, the worsening economy may actually be spurring donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Businesses, law firms and medical practices that have contributed to the fund in years past have continued to give to the Neediest Cases, often increasing their donations. And they have been joined by many others who never donated before but were moved to give this year by the growing poverty that surrounds them. 
 The 79th annual appeal for the Neediest Cases began last month, and already $2,197,153.23 has been collected. The proceeds are given to seven charities to be used to aid the sick and the poor. The New York Times pays all the overhead costs of the campaign.
More than 4,500 people and organizations have sent money to this year's drive, and many write that they consider it an annual tradition.
 
In Honor of Friends
 For the third straight year, the law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan sent $15,000. Another donor, the financial public relations agency Kekst and Company, gave $2,500 in honor of friends and clients -- their fifth consecutive annual donation.
One business, which wished to remain anonymous and has contributed to the Neediest Cases for years, increased its gift by several thousand dollars to $25,000. Asked about their largesse, an executive responded yesterday, "You only have to walk about the streets of New York to see why."
Along with these companies that have given in previous years are new donors.
Noel Hecht and Steve Wettan, who share an oral surgery practice in Brooklyn and Queens, have abandoned the ritual of sending baskets of fruit or bottles of liquor to the dentists that refer patients to them.
 
No More Presents for Clients
 "They're more fortunate than most, and they can afford their own gifts," Dr. Hecht said in a recent telephone interview. Instead, the two men notified their colleagues that they were giving money to charities, including $100 to the Neediest Cases.
Like the two oral surgeons, the Weave Corporation in Hackensack, N.J., a manufacturer of upholstery, apparel and drapery fabrics, also decided to stop sending umbrellas, coffee mugs and desk sets to their clients this year. Instead, for the first time, they donated $5,000 to the Neediest Cases.
While the gifts were an effective way to keep the company's name in front of its customers, the executives felt "increasingly uneasy" about spending money on such items, wrote Roger L. Berkley, the company's president. "It became increasingly clear," he wrote, "that at this point in the history of both our company and our society, it was more important to put our name on a check that will help people who can't fend for themselves."
Mitelman & Associates Ltd., an advertising agency in Tarrytown, N.Y. was another first-time donor to the Neediest this year.
Bonnie Mitelman, the company's vice president, wrote that they were concerned about the "$400 million budget gap that the area will be facing" and that in lieu of gifts to their clients, the company was sending $200 to the Neediest Cases.
Ms. Mitelman wrote: "We would use that money to do what we could to make the metropolitan area a better place for all of us. We're giving the money to your fund to give to people who can really use it."

HEADLINE: Energy Policy Options Are Submitted to Bush

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Senior Bush Administration officials gave the President a list of options today from which to fashion a comprehensive national energy strategy.
The 60-plus options, which involve everything from car mileage standards to hydroelectric dams, are the product of nearly 18 months of interagency work coordinated by the Energy Department and supervised by the President's Economic Policy Council. They options also represent perhaps the most ambitious energy study ever conducted by the Government. 
 But critics say the decision to offer the President a menu of options rather than overall strategy recommendations constitutes a significant retreat from the goal Mr. Bush seemed to have in July 1989, when he ordered the study.
 
Framework for Legislation
 Mr. Bush declared then that the United States could not and would not wait for another energy crisis to find a solution to the nation's growing dependence on foreign oil. The study was supposed to provide a framework for energy legislation that the President would submit to Congress in early 1991.
While that is still the idea, energy experts on Capitol Hill fear that unless clear objectives and coordinated solutions quickly appear, it will be difficult to build Congressional support.
The decision to take a more piecemeal approach apparently came at the insistence of the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, an engineer and a candidate for Energy Secretary 10 years ago, who did not like the path the early thinking was taking and decided the White House would put together its own strategy.
 
 Little Urgency Seen
 But by all accounts, including drafts of the study that have circulated throughout the energy and environmental community, President Bush heard little that is new in the ideas for promoting energy supplies and reducing demand. And he does not seem to have injected the project with much urgency, even though nearly 400,000 American troops are deployed in the Persian Gulf, which holds about two-thirds of the world's oil reserves.
Some of the most bitter feuding within the Administration has occurred over efforts by the Office of Management and Budget to pre-empt decisions in matters like subsidies for rural electrification and rates charged by Federal power agencies, by putting economic considerations ahead of energy concerns. Mr. Sununu and Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, are also said to be at odds with senior officials in the Energy Department, including Energy Secretary James D. Watkins.
In an interview this week, the Deputy Energy Secretary, W. Henson Moore, acknowledged the friction, calling it a useful part of the process. "It's healthy that you have a debate like that," he said.
 
 Options Aren't Ranked
 In fact, Mr. Moore added, the 60-odd options were not ranked for the President but were grouped according to the degree of endorsement.
One group of options consists of those approved in all quarters; it is believed to include a recommendation that regulatory impediments be removed to the use of more natural gas. A second group consists of options supported by some Bush operatives and opposed by others; this is thought to include the idea of opening up various offshore and wilderness areas to oil and gas drilling.
A final set of options will be presented as those recommended by none of the officials taking part, Mr. Moore said. Among these, no doubt, is a 50-cent-a-gallon tax on motor fuels mentioned in at least one draft.
 
 Environmentalists Disturbed
 In recent weeks, critics and skeptics have assailed the priorities that seem to be emerging from the process, with environmentalists and those who favor greater reliance on alternative fuels voicing the strongest concern.
Public Citizen, an advocacy group founded by Ralph Nader, this week called the options "a politically expedient response to the Persian Gulf crisis that lacks any long-term vision and will result in continued energy waste and environmental destruction." The group said it deplored any options that would seek to revive nuclear power and further entrench fossil fuels like oil, natural gas and coal.
Whatever Mr. Bush decides to order from the options is not expected to become known for several weeks. A decision may emerge either piecemeal or full blown in budget proposals and the State of the Union Message in late January.
At the moment, however, many fear that while the Administration has briefed Congress on the list, it has done little else to smooth the way for passage of an energy bill.

HEADLINE: Crisis in the Kremlin;
Reading Tea Leaves of Soviet Fate: U.S. Experts Look Ahead

BYLINE: By James H. Billington; Librarian of Congress; expert on Russian history.

 BODY:
Gorbachev classically tries to balance the right and the left in exercising domestic control within the U.S.S.R. But there are times when one must choose a path for the future. His indecision and his drift for most of this year into alliance with reactionary forces are very disquieting and may move him on the path toward becoming a Russian Jaruzelski. Jaruzelski thought of himself as a patriot restoring order and avoiding bloodshed. But objectively speaking, what he did was to repress the grass-roots reformist element represented in the Solidarity movement and to set democratization back a decade.
One would have expected that Gorbachev, as a pragmatic politician who unleashed glasnost and the reform impulse, would have found opportunities to work more boldly with reform-minded officials who received popular electoral mandates in the past year -- or at least to adopt the economic measures his own economists have been recommending. The reform movements in the dominant Russian republic have been generally nonviolent and have shown tremendous vitality this year and opened up a real possibility for relegitimizing civil authority from the bottom up. 
 However, there is a very real risk that unless Gorbachev changes now at the 11th hour, he would set back a reform movement that he made possible. That's a paradox. It's a further paradox that the man who refused to use weapons against peaceful change in Eastern Europe may abet the process whereby weapons come to be used against his own people.
There has been a strong tendency, from a variety of powerful officials, the police and the military, in favor of a crackdown and restoration of social discipline within the Soviet Union. Equally important is the proven reluctance of Gorbachev to embrace a whole series of possibilities for collaboration with the elements seeking to provide long-term stability by overhauling and relegitimizing political authority.

HEADLINE: Loan Company Is Sued Over Check in the Mail

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Dec. 21

 BODY:
New York State officials today sued Beneficial New York, a financing company, accusing it of misleading consumers into accepting loans.
The suit stems from checks of up to $1,500 Beneficial mailed to people across the state. An accompanying letter urged them to cash the checks immediately. 
 While the company noted that cashing the check amounted to agreeing to repay the loan, Attorney General Robert Abrams said that Beneficial misled consumers by calling the monthly repayments "low."
Mr. Abrams said the interest rate on the loans were 25 percent, which is the maximum permitted by New York law and about double most conventional bank loans. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court, says that Beneficial's letter promoting the loan informs the potential borrower of the size of each monthly payment but it does not disclose the number of payments and the total amount to be repaid.
Officials at Beneficial, based in Peapack, N.J., denied any wrongdoing. "We're sure we're within New York guidelines," said a Beneficial spokesman, Robert Wade.
The lawsuit asks the court to suspend repayment of those loans and force Beneficial to drop its marketing campaign. The suit also asks that the company be forced to notify everybody who received the checks to destroy them.

HEADLINE: Democrats to Hold Off on Surtax on High Incomes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders no longer plan to propose a surtax on incomes above $1 million a year as the first order of business when Congress convenes next month, although the proposal may resurface later, aides to the leadership said today.
Instead, the Democrats are focusing on piecing together a larger package aimed at promoting "economic growth and tax fairness," as an aide to a top Democratic Congressman put it. They hope to have the legislation ready by the time President Bush presents his State of the Union address on Jan. 29, the aide said. 
 "Don't focus too much on whether it's H.R. 1 or not," said the aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
That is the designation given the first bill introduced in the House at the beginning of a session of Congress. The 102d Congress convenes Jan. 3, when lawmakers are likely to introduce their first bills.
The aide said Democratic leaders had still not decided what would be in the economic growth package, but he would not rule out a surtax on incomes above $1 million.
Until now, Democratic leaders had spoken of making the session's first bill a tax increase on the rich. The issue was a big political winner for Democrats during this year's budget battle with the White House. They used the proposal and Republican opposition to it to characterize the Republicans as the party of the wealthy. The proposal was ultimately defeated.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, told Mr. Bush this week that he would not immediately pursue the surtax, an aide to Mr. Rostenkowski said today.
That move came after Mr. Bush told Mr. Rostenkowski on Tuesday that the President would not include in the budget for the 1992 fiscal year his plan to cut capital gains tax rates. The budget will go to Congress on Feb. 4.
Democrats argue that a reduction in the capital gains tax would mainly help the rich and would reduce Government revenue.
