HEADLINE: Crisis in the Kremlin;
Soviet Economic Output Off Sharply

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Output of the Soviet economy fell 4 percent this year and is likely to drop 5 percent more in 1991, increasing unemployment and adding new urgency to the task of revamping the country's economy, four leading Western economic institutions said today.
Their long-awaited report, the closest and most comprehensive look yet by any Western agencies at the Soviet economy, was made public today. In line with predictions of its contents, the report calls for a speedier transformation to market operations than presently contemplated by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 
 "The imperative is to make sufficient progress at the beginning so that reform is seen as an irreversible break with the past and the process gains unstoppable momentum," the study concluded.
It was conducted by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, both based in Washington; the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, based in Paris, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, based in London, a new institution seeking to encourage reconstruction of both the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
 
Declines in Output Severe
 Commissioned last July by the leaders of seven industrial countries meeting in Houston, the report used words like "breakdown," "collapse" and "unraveling" to describe current conditions. It said that few goods are found in state stores, barter is becoming more common, and black markets and the use of dollars instead of rubles to pay for goods are spreading rapidly.
Declines in output of the magnitudes seen in the study are unprecedented for any major nations in the postwar period but are akin to the experience of many countries during the Great Depression of the 1930's.
In postwar recessions in the United States and Western Europe, it has been unusual for output to fall by 1 to 2 percent. In the deepest postwar American recession, 1981-82, output dropped 2.5 percent.
Output of the economy, as measured in the report, is the sum total of production of goods; the figure does not include services.
 
Employment Declining
 For the first time in postwar history, the report found overall employment declining. Although unemployment is not yet an officially accepted Soviet concept, the report placed current joblessness at 1.5 percent of the work force, which by next year could increase to 4 percent, or 6 million workers.
The report, which was prepared by teams of about 80 economists from the four organizations with the cooperation of the Soviet authorities, cautioned that the West should hold back financial aid, other than credits for food, until a comprehensive reform program is in place.
"Without such a reform, additional financial resources would be of little or no lasting value," it stressed.
Bush Administration officials said the conclusions are "fully consistent" with their thinking. The European Community came to similar findings in a study published today in Brussels.
The Washington report is expected to serve as the basis for talks between Moscow and the I.M.F., which was the major contributor to the study.
 
A Boost for Reformers
 It also could strengthen the hand of economic policy reformers in Moscow, who are struggling with forces basically distrustful of the market and who want to push the economy back to old ways of central planning.
The Soviet Government has already indicated that it wants to join the I.M.F. Membership could open up important new financial support, which would cushion some of the more painful adjustments to market operations, like restrictions on consumer subsidies for food and housing. But to get the money, Moscow would have to follow the I.M.F.'s policy advice.
The fund's endorsement is the seal of approval required by the World Bank and other international lenders. Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and scores of other developing countries have tapped extensive lines of credit over the years once that approval was won.
Acknowledging that the Soviet Union does not now qualify for fund membership, President Bush last week proposed a special associate status under which Moscow would get technical advice to help anchor its reforms and prepare the ground for full membership.
 
New Data on Economy
 The report provides extensive new data on the Soviet economy. Overall indebtedness was placed at $54 billion at the end of 1989, which as a percentage of exports of goods and services is less than the percentage in Bulgaria, Hungary and Poland.
Because many banks have been increasingly unwilling to grant loans to the Soviet Union, indebtedness at the end of this year was projected at $52 billion, while the country's hard currency reserves were placed at $5 billion, which is equivalent to less than two months of hard currency imports.
The Soviet Government helps balance its accounts by selling gold in Zurich and London. Gold sales were projected to reach $4 billion this year and about $3.5 billion next year.
Although the Soviet authorities generally cooperated in providing data, they refused to disclose total gold reserves, a long-held Soviet secret.
 
Gold Seen as Strategic Resource
 Soviet specialists explained that gold mines have long been considered a strategic resource in the Soviet Union and are operated by the Defense Ministry. If the Soviets eventually join the I.M.F., they would have to provide such gold reserve data.
Although the Soviet budget for 1990 shows miltary spending equivalent to 7 percent of domestic output, the report notes that if spending on internal security and all budgeted research and development are added to military expenditures, the figure would rise to 9 percent.
But since prices of many military goods are kept low under the command economy, the report suggested that the total military burden might be twice as high, approaching 20 percent. In the United States military spending is about 5 percent of the gross national product.
The report suggested possible remedies for the distribution bottlenecks that are behind food and other shortages.

HEADLINE: When Will Slump End? Pick a Year, Pick an Economist

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Relying on sophisticated computer models, an understanding of the vagaries of New York and experience in charting its ups and downs, economists believe they know when the city should hit bottom and start to turn around: 1991. Or 1992. Or 1993. Or maybe 1994? Or even 1995.
Forecasting has proven perilous in New York, which 10 years ago was beginning one of its most prosperous decades just when everyone was expecting its demise. But businesses and government, which must at least to try to anticipate economic trends, have no choice but to rely on such predictions. And whatever their accuracy, forecasts can reveal much about the forces atwork in, and on, the city. 
 In any case, in a year in which New York City has lost an estimated 50,000 jobs -- and its region, 100,000 -- talk of a turnaround, no matter how far off, is reassuring.
Among the gloomier forecasts is one from Rae D. Rosen, senior economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, who said she believed it could be three to five years before growth resumes. In the meantime, she expects more pain.
 
'I Don't See Any Relief'
 "We look for another, possibly 30,000-job, loss in 1991," she said. "Every single sector with the exception of services is likely to show a decline."
The construction industry, she said, is stillfinishing projects begun in better times and will lay off workers when they are done. Telecommunications will be flat at best. Several major retailers are floundering and shoppers are hardly feeling flush. The finance sector appears close to an end of layoffs, but banks are overstaffed. Manufacturing will continue to lose jobs. And local government, which added 10,000 positions so far this year, will shed at least 7,000.
And in 1992, Ms. Rosen said, "The best we can hope for is some sort of stagnation."
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission and a professor at Columbia Business School, said he, too, believed a recovery would not begin until 1993 or later. But, he added, "there are some people who think we are in a Detroit situation. Idon't believe that at all. The decline will be a little sharper and longer than a lot of people think, but of greater certainty is that there will be a strong recovery, beginning in the mid-1990's."
By then, the city will most likely have benefited from a stronger national economy as well as a wringing out of its own notoriously high costs, especially for rent and labor. Stores that once could not afford leases in the city will be able to open. Companies that have reduced payrolls may begin to expand.
Elinor B. Bachrach, the Deputy State Comptroller for New York City, agreed with this reasoning, but predicted an earlier re bound, in the second quarter of 1992. In 1991, though, she expects a loss of 40,000 more jobs. "We really think next year is going to be quite bleak," she said.
After the stock market's fall three years ago, Matthew P. Drennan, an economics professor at New York University's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service, was a pessimist, predicting that 60,000 jobs would be lost by the end of 1988. It took longer to reach that figure than he thought.
 
Hard to Duplicate
 Now, he has turned into an optimist, at least compared to some colleagues. He believes the city will hit bottom in late 1991 or early 1992, and that the demand for its abundance of lawyers, accountants, engineers, advertising and media executives will be a major factor in its rebound.
"If New York unraveled," he said, "it would have to be invented somewhere else, which would be very expensive."
Sylvia Ashrafiuon, director of New York services for the WEFA Group, a forecasting service in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., looks for the decline to continue into the first half of 1991, to be followed by stabilization and, finally, a change of direction at the end of 1991 or the beginning of 1992.
"What is going to get us out of this is the consumer," she said. "Income growth picks up again, because of the national economy. The oil price shock is over. There will be some kind of recovery in construction. And the end of employment losses. Hopefully, some of that consumer confidence will come back."
 
Waiting for a Reason
 Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was even more optimistic. She said she believed a recovery could come "anytime after the middle of next year."
"But," she added, "there has to be a reason for it."
Ms. Scanlon said the region had been basically holding its own until the national economy weakened at mid-year, credit tightened and Iraq invaded Kuwait, which pushed up energy prices and further worried already anxious consumers. Should calm prevail in the Mideast, energy prices would recede and interest rates could fall, stimulating both the national and local economies. Increased trade with Europe could provide New York with another boost.
One economist who avoids forecasting is Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. He said New York City is too complicated, pieces of data are missing and that right now important sectors are being restructured, with uncertain results.
"There are a lot of variables," he said, "and that makes things difficult."
To make his point, at a briefing earlier in the year, Mr. Ehrenhalt handed out a copy of a newspaper article with the headline, "Economic 'Seer' Predicts Loss of 97,000 Jobs in City."
The article was from 1980, written as the city's economic boom was already unfolding.

HEADLINE: Arts Endowment Takes and Then Gives Away

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
A final determination of how the National Endowment for the Arts will cut $12 million from its direct grants to artists and arts organizations and add the same amount to its contributions to state arts councils was approved yesterday by John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the endowment, a spokesman for the agency said.
The decision immediately drew expressions of praise and concern from arts administrators around the country. 
 Randolph McAusland, deputy chairman for programs of the arts endowment, said the agency's $125.8 million budget for programs would be reduced by an average of about 10 percent in each of 16 areas, ranging from $1.9 million subtracted from music programs to $465,000 from design programs.
"We will likely trim the dollar amount of grants in order to avoid cutting the number of grantees," Mr. McAusland said, "and we want to retain the flexibility to recognize new artists and organizations. Several whole grant subcategories are being suspended, and we will be forced to eliminate some grantees in each discipline."
 
'New Purchase Plan'
 Among the subcategories to be suspended are the "new purchase plan," which assists museums in acquiring works of art, and the "special artistic initiative plan," which helps museums in a variety of ways.
Direct support to states will increase to $37.7 million from $26.1 million.
"Coming at a time when the economic climate is causing a pulling back of state, corporate and individual contributions," said Richard Oldenburg, director of the Museum of Modern Art, "we're very worried about cuts at the Federal level."
Bennett Tarleton, executive director of the Tennessee Arts Commission, took a contrasting view. "The general impact will be to spread and deepen and widen support for the arts," he said.
The arts endowment's shift in support from direct grants to increased contributions to states was required under the Federal legislation that extended the life of the agency this fall. A provision in the law requires an increase of about $12 million in the amount of money the endowment contributes to the states in the present fiscal year.
By 1993, assuming that the arts endowment's overall budget remains constant, states would receive nearly $45 million out of the $125.8 million program budget.
 
Complicated Formula
 The states are awarded block grants according to a complicated formula. California, the largest recipient, gets about $650,000, and a small state like Delaware gets about $340,000. In fiscal 1991 each state will receive at least an additional $90,000.
There is no pattern in the way state arts councils plan to use the new money. New York expects to spend it to avoid laying off employees in folk arts programs and to replace state cuts in the agency's travel budget; Tennessee says it will use the extra money to increase the size of grants for general operating expenses to medium and large cultural institutions; Nebraska plans to use it for local government challenge grants, artists' fellowships and touring programs; Mississippi expects to use it for training programs to help local arts groups be better able to compete for Federal and corporate grants; and Idaho plans to direct the money chiefly to the 45 local arts councils throughout the state, which will use it for presenting local and national arts groups.
Representative E. Thomas Coleman, the Missouri Republican who was one of the chief sponsors of the provision to increase Federal support of state arts councils, said he was pleased to hear that there has been a variety of reactions from the states.
"That diversity was the driving reason behind the legislation," he said. "We thought the different states would know how to use these funds in ways best suited to their individual needs."
 
Smaller Companies May Benefit

 <>
Spokesmen for many state arts councils expressed enthusiasm for their increased appropriations. "This change will support local arts groups in a way that the National Endowment for the Arts never could," said Margot Knight, executive director of the Idaho Commission on the Arts. "The N.E.A. never had the travel money to come out here and see what we were doing. Consequently, their money goes to well-established organizations rather than to an excellent local group like the Idaho Theater for Youth, a children's theater. Smaller companies like that stand to benefit."
Mr. Tarleton, executive director of the Tennessee Arts Commission, said: "We make several hundred grants every year, whereas in a good year the National Endowment for the Arts makes only a dozen grants in Tennessee. Most of the groups we support -- like the Carpetbag Theater, a minority-owned and -operated theater in Knoxville -- have never received a Federal grant. Now, through us, they will have a chance to get some Federal dollars."
"The economic impact will be mixed," said Holly Sidford, executive director of the New England Foundation for the Arts. "In a state like Connecticut, which gets about $2.5 million and is about to be cut approximately 10 percent, the loss of $250,000 won't be compensated for by a grant of $90,000. On the other hand, a northern state that's getting only $500,000 and is cut 10 percent gets a big boost from that $90,000 increase."
Jonathan Katz, executive director of the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies, said that a very important provision of the new legislation is one that requires setting aside 5 percent of the Federal agency's program budget to give to states for the purpose of assisting rural, inner-city and other communities that are "underserved artistically."
"The state arts councils," Mr. Katz said, "are uniquely able to nurture these kinds of groups, and to help them foster excellence."
 
Not 'a Real Boon'
 One concern about the shift of endowment support voiced at a recent meeting of the National Council on the Arts, the Presidentially appointed body that advises the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, is that state legislatures around the country will cut contributions to their state arts councils with the expectation that these councils are about to benefit from a windfall from the Federal Government.
"I doubt that state legislators will look at a $90,000 increase as a real boon," Mr. Tarleton said. "If it were $900,000, that might be something, but nobody here is going to say we got rich all of a sudden because we got an extra $90,000. That's only enough for maybe three of our medium-sized grants."
Ms. Knight of Idaho agreed. "If the states cut their arts budgets," she said, "they will do so in response to internal pressures, not because they think their arts councils can get a free ride on the Federal Government."
Mary Hays, executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, said: "There are economic and political forces -- such as that the state is facing a $4 billion problem -- that make the arts endowment's action almost irrelevant."
 
'Maintenance of Effort'
 Representative Colemen took the matter more seriously. "The original legislation included what we called a 'maintenance of effort' provision to prohibit states from decreasing their funding," he said, "but that was not included in the compromise measure that passed. However, if we see states reneging, we will certainly consider bringing up the 'maintenance of effort' provision again."
Mr. Tarleton said: "To some extent, we're taking money from Peter to pay Paul. I wish there were enough money so we could help both the states and the arts endowment's program budget. Maybe we'll see that happen in a better economic climate."
The cuts in program budgets to be made by the National Endowment for the Arts are as follows:
 
Dance -- 10.5 percent ($1,005,000)
 Design -- 11.2 percent ($465,000)
 Inner-city, rural and tribal arts -- 9 percent ($585,000)
 Folk arts -- 15.2 percent ($500,000)
 Interdisciplinary arts -- 13 percent ($580,000)
 Literature -- 11.3 percent ($565,000)
 Media arts -- 12.8 percent ($1,730,000)
 Museums -- 13.7 percent ($1,764,000)
 Music -- 12 percent ($1,938,000)
 Opera and musical theater -- 11 percent ($745,000)
 Theater -- 11.1 percent ($1,200,000)
 Visual arts -- 12.7 percent ($775,000)
 Teaching art in public schools -- 1.5 percent ($100,000)
 Local arts councils -- 11.5 percent ($300,000)
 Developmental assistance -- 4.6 percent ($168,000)
 Challenge grants -- 0.8 percent ($129,000)

HEADLINE: Coping/With an Ailing Old Car

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
That old car made it through the fall, but with winter here, it clearly needs an expensive overhaul. Is it worth it?
Facing major repairs, motorists commonly weigh the cost against the car's market value -- what it would fetch if it was sold or traded for a car of similar age. Plausible as that may seem, various specialists call this approach a big mistake. 
 At a time of economic and household retrenchment, minimizing transportation costs -- equal to food as a percentage of the typical American budget -- has particular appeal.
A Maryland man's 1982 Toyota Celica GT needed a new engine, a job that he reliably determined would cost about $2,500. He knew that after investing this sum he would have a car worth little more than $2,500. But newspaper ads offered '82 Celicas at $2,200 to $3,000. He quite naturally hesitated. "That's more than the thing is worth," he said, expressing the concern of those who face heavy repair bills for cars of a certain age.
In fact, the Toyota unrepaired appeared worth nothing. That calculation was so dismaying that it inspired further investigation.
The Marylander decided not only to invest the $2,500 in his eight-year-old Toyota, but within six months he spent another $350 on a new clutch for his 1981 Mercury station wagon. Even before it broke down, he had believed the Mercury worth no more than $500. He came to realize that the main question he had been considering was the wrong one.
 "It has nothing to do with the market value of the car," said James F. Smith, a professor of finance at the University of North Carolina. "The relevant questions are how much you like it and whether the money you spend to fix it up will significantly extend its life."
Of course some people insist on driving only the latest models and will pay heavily for them. New cars can lose about 25 percent of their value as they are driven from the showroom and will lose 40 percent by the time they are three years old.
Many consumers fail to get the most for their money because they underestimate the advantages of repair. If a car, particularly the body, is in decent shape, "the majority of the time you're going to be better off fixing" it, said C. Michael Johnson, president of the Wealth Planning Corporation, Cincinnati financial planners. Too often, he said, people panic: "A car needs $300 worth of work and they trade it in."
Louis Stanasolovich, a financial adviser in Pittsburgh, said that while fixing a car frequently might be a bother, "most of the time you'll find an older used car will probably be cheapest in terms of cost per mile to drive."
Mechanics are fond of advising the dubious to consider a bill for repairing an older car an investment in thrifty transportation, not an expenditure. In most cases, the the expenditure is a month's installment on a new-car loan.
There are advantages to repairing an old car beyond immediate dollars and cents. Probably the most important one is that the consumer knows what he has. The Maryland man knows, for example, not just that his Toyota has a new engine. but also -- in contrast to what he might face if he replaced it with a used car -- that he has not abused his transmission or bought third-quality tires, and the battery may last another two years.
Such information provides some of the peace of mind sought by many who buy only new cars.
There are some things the zealous motorist must do. One is to maintain the car so that it does not leave the owner stranded in bad weather or in a high-crime area or at the mercy of unknown mechanics.
Another is to make sure the garage is not enticing you with a low estimate that will be wildly exceeded. Many dealers subscribe to a Eastern Seaboard service offered by the Hayes-Ligon Corporation, based in the Washington area: It allows dealers, by referring to customized manuals for cars up to 10 years old, to quote a price virtually to the penny.
An ardent repair fan, not surprisingly, is Donald A. Randall, a Washington lawyer who represents the Automotive Service Association, the industry's biggest trade group.
"As the economy tightens," he said, "we see a lot of people debating this issue," of whether to repair or trade a car in. He said there had been an increase in the number of motorists who chose to fix their old cars.
Mr. Randall has become quite attached to his own "nice and heavy" 1985 Ford LTD. He is about to spend $4,600 for a premium repair, or "restoration." He figures that he will drive his dream machine, which has already traveled 87,000 miles, for at least another four years.

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Seeing Green in Draft

 BODY:
If Dan McGwire is chosen as the No. 1 player in the National Football League draft next spring, the price tag on the 6-foot-8-inch quarterback will exceed $15 million, his agent, Leigh Steinberg, said yesterday.
"Dan has the opportunity to be the first player drafted," said Steinberg, who was announced yesterday as McGwire's agent at a news conference at San Diego State University. "Even if he was not, and he was simply a first-round quarterback, those economics are very strong. Jeff George was worth $15 million for six years, with a $3.5 million signing bonus. Those are the parameters: Jeff George plus inflation."
McGwire finished his college career at San Diego State with 528 completions and 7,484 yards gained, and set a National Collegiate Athletic Association season mark with a 1.56 percent interception rate (7 in 449 pass attempts).

HEADLINE: Panama: A Poor Report Card

 BODY:
A year ago, the United States invaded Panama. The immediate justification was Gen. Manuel Noriega's provocations against U.S. military personnel. President Bush also said he was acting to defend the Panama Canal treaties, combat drug trafficking and defend democracy.
Panama's drug trafficking is now less brazen and General Noriega sits in a U.S. jail. The treaties are still in force. But Panama remains a shattered country, its war damage unrepaired and its sovereignty not yet reclaimed. It is no longer a lawless dictatorship. But neither has it become the democracy Mr. Bush claimed to defend. 
 Guillermo Endara was the apparent winner of a May 1989 election abruptly halted by General Noriega. That made Mr. Endara the obvious choice to head a provisional regime, and he was sworn in at a U.S. military base. But by declining to seek a democratic renewal of his mandate, Mr. Endara has left his own legitimacy tainted.
As Panamanian disillusionment over unresolved problems has grown, his popularity has tumbled. Public order remains shaky. Sanctions, invasion damage and looting shrank Panama's economy by 30 percent. Even now, unemployment exceeds 25 percent. A recent coup attempt was suppressed only with U.S. help. American troops still patrol Panama's streets, exceeding their treaty role of protecting the canal.
After the invasion, President Bush pledged a billion-dollar aid package. "You've got to do what's right," he declared. "You have to try to help repair the wounds, repair the damage." Nearly half the package consisted of restored trade privileges and credits, not really new money. Congress cut the other half by 15 percent and red tape has held up all but $120 million. Neither damage nor wounds has been decently repaired.
Mr. Bush's decision to use force in Panama was justifiable because of the apparent danger to U.S. troops lawfully stationed there. The President had properly explored, and exhausted, less drastic policy instruments without result. Sanctions and diplomacy had not resolved official collaboration with drug syndicates. An internationally monitored election and subsequent efforts by the Organization of American States failed to win respect for basic rights.
Justifiable. But has the invasion of Panama been justified by its results to date? This year's disappointments provide an object lesson in the messiness of war as a solution to political problems.

HEADLINE: Nothing Gained in Tibbett Gardens

 BODY:
The sad tale of Tibbett Gardens demonstrates again how adept New Yorkers have become at stopping anything that offends anyone. Tibbett Gardens was to have been a badly needed complex of middle-income housing, part of a creative experiment some leading developers proposed five years ago. They agreed to waive profits. The Koch administration agreed to help. And a plan to transform eight weed-choked acres into 1,000 condominium apartments was on its way.
Except it really wasn't. Even as city officials approved the plan, critics with two sharply different perspectives rose up to kill it. On one side were people who lived near the site, an abandoned lot in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. They contended that Tibbett Gardens would overcrowd the community. But that claim masked a less admirable fear -- that the complex would attract blacks and Hispanics. 
 On the other side were purists who believed that all city-aided housing should go to the poor, not the middle class -- which the Government defines as households with incomes of $33,000 to $53,000. Over the last four and a half years, the city has rehabilitated thousands of apartments for the poor. Tibbett Gardens was deliberately aimed at providing housing for the middle class, which has also suffered from the housing crunch.
Neighborhood opponents filed a lawsuit that delayed the project for almost two years. Then the economy started to slide, the real estate market softened, costs rose and the banks became skittish. The 1,000 apartments became 750, then 400. Finally, this week, the Dinkins administration reluctantly killed the project.
What a curious victory for the critics. The money meant for Tibbett will not go into low-income housing, because that money no longer exists. The desolate lot in Kingsbridge remains a desolate lot. And the people who so badly needed those apartments have to do without. Once again, narrow fears and cramped dogma prevailed.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Should Sit Down With the Unions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For many years, organized labor has supported Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his agenda for New York State. We've worked side by side with the Governor on many projects and programs, and our help has been critical to many of his successes.
It is, therefore, with great sadness that I feel compelled to speak out against the Governor's actions on the state budget in the last few weeks. By refusing to negotiate with our affiliate the New York Public Employee Federation and other state employee unions, he has undermined collective bargaining for all workers.
By attempting to go around the unions and to take his message of fear and loathing directly to the members, he has shown great disrespect for many fine union leaders and thousands of public employees. And by attempting unilaterally to implement proposals abrogating union contracts, he's given aid and comfort to the enemies of organized labor.
We acknowledge that New York is in economic distress. A rational approach, built on consensus and negotiations with the unions and other constituent groups, could have achieved decent, mutually acceptable, rational solutions to deficit reduction.
As a native New Yorker, I've seen what labor-management cooperation like that can do toward solving huge problems. On behalf of the 250,000 Service Employees Union members in New York State and the nearly one million members across the country, I call on Governor Cuomo to sit down now with the state employee unions and solve his problems in the New York State tradition of collective bargaining.
The thousands of members of public employee unions who insure that ours is a civilized and morally responsible state surely deserve no less.
 
JOHN J. SWEENEY
Intl. President, Service Employees, Intl. Union, A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Washington, Dec. 13, 1990

HEADLINE: Investor in Chrysler: Seldom Passive Before

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Executives of the Chrysler Corporation are preaching calm in the face of Kirk Kerkorian's unsolicited and unwanted 9.8 percent investment in the auto maker. But their actions suggest concern, and analysts say Chrysler may have cause for worry, judging from Mr. Kerkorian's record.
The Los Angeles financier has a 20-year history of making life miserable for the managements of companies in which he invests, including the now-defunct Western Airlines and Columbia Pictures, both of which ultimately paid him a high premium to go away. Mr. Kerkorian contends that his investment is passive, but analysts and some Chrysler executives say there are reasons to believe that his new investment could eventually follow the pattern he has set in the past.
 
 Different From Buffett
 "This is a lot different than if Warren Buffett comes to you and says he wants to buy your stock as a long-term investment," said one Chrysler executive who refused to be identified, referring to the Omaha investor who is known for his long-term investment strategy. 
 Last week, after public disclosure of Mr. Kerkorian's stake, Chrysler took the precaution of strengthening its "poison pill" protection against hostile investors.
Mr. Kerkorian, now Chrysler's largest single shareholder, is publicity-shy and rarely talks to the press. But Terry Christensen, his lawyer, said the change in Chrysler's poison pill was an "overreaction" to Mr. Kerkorian's refusal to refrain from further stock purchases. He is required to notify the Federal Trade Commission if he plans to increase his stake to more than 10 percent.
Until it becomes clear whether he will hold his stake to less than 10 percent, Mr. Kerkorian holds an investment that could provide a nice return, even without a rebound in the economy or the sluggish automobile business. The dividends on his stock represent a pretax return of roughly 10 percent; since the shares were bought through the Tracinda Corporation, which he owns, 70 percent of the dividends would be sheltered from tax. Dividends received by corporations are partly tax-exempt.
But because of Chrysler's weak financial condition, many analysts think the company will be forced to cut its dividend next year -- a move that Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, has vowed not to take, "short of nuclear war." Analysts say Mr. Kerkorian would likely object to such a cut or suggest an alternative, which could test his relations with Chrysler management.
For now, Chrysler executives are publicly using conciliatory rhetoric to prevent a public dispute. As Robert Lutz, the president of Chrysler, said at a holiday gathering for the press at the Detroit Press Club on Tuesday night: "I believe that he's totally sincere that he wants to be a passive investor. He's a 73-year-old entrepreneur who really respects Lee Iacocca, and he looks at Chrysler's stock and he looks at what we're doing, and he's got a lot of faith in Lee."
At least Chrysler need not worry that its new investor will interfere in the car business. In the past, Mr. Kerkorian has avoided day-to-day management. Also, he has no experience in the automobile industry.
 
 A Dizzying Pace
 But he does like to buy, sell and rearrange assets, sometimes at a dizzying pace. Few people in the entertainment industry can recall the number of times during the 1980's that he bought and sold various pieces of the MGM/UA Communications Corporation, which he controlled through the 1970's and 1980's before finally selling what was left this year to Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications Corporation for $1.3 billion.
Mr. Kerkorian's earlier investments in Western Airlines and Columbia Pictures, in which he owned minority stakes, are more analagous to his current minority position. Those investments provoked much rancor and litigation, and Mr. Kerkorian walked away from his stakes after the companies elected to buy back his shares at a premium over market value rather than fight with him.
While selling stock back to management at a premium price, known as "greenmail," has become a practice of some corporate raiders, Mr. Kerkorian's friends and associates say that is not his way of operating. One friend, who insisted on anonymity, said: "He isn't a greenmailer. He hates greenmail."
Mr. Kerkorian is secretive about his investment strategy. His investments usually stem from intuition rather than hard research, his lawyer and other associates say. His investment bankers and friends say he keeps his own counsel and rarely asks for their investment advice or orders research on a company in which he is interested.
The nation's No. 3 auto maker is clearly in a poor position for tussling with unwanted investors. For the last two years Chrysler has been selling assets and cutting costs to amass enough money to develop new vehicles and weather the soft United States automotive market.
Unlike the General Motors Corporation, which spent $700 million in 1986 to buy back the stake held by H. Ross Perot, the billionaire founder of Electronic Data Systems -- ending what had become an enormous corporate distraction -- Chrysler has a thin financial cushion and little management depth. Chrysler has lost several leading executives in the last year and Mr. Iacocca has been saying he is eager to get the company in shape so he can retire.
To beleaguered Chrysler stockholders, who have watched the price of their shares plummet to a bit more than $9 earlier this year, from a peak of $48 in 1987, Mr. Kerkorian's arrival must seem welcome. The stock has since climbed more than 40 percent, closing at $13.25 today, down 50 cents for the day.
Automotive analysts have often expressed concern about Chrysler's short-term prospects, given the weakening economy and competition from stronger rivals like G.M., the Ford Motor Company, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company.
 
 Too Big to Fall
 But for the long term, Wall Street regards Chrysler as an important manufacturing giant, which one way or another will rebound and reward investors like Mr. Kerkorian who have bought its stock at recent prices. In their view, Chrysler, like Continental Illinois and other companies that have received Federal bailouts, is still considered too big to fail.
If Chrysler does make a comeback, it would not be the first time Mr. Kerkorian has demonstrated shrewd investment sense. The son of Armenian immigrants, Mr. Kerkorian got his start in aviation, buying and selling cargo planes and running a charter service. He sold his Trans International Airlines in 1962 to Studebaker, bought it back, took it public, then sold it again in 1968, this time to the Transamerica Corporation in a stock transaction.
He used his Transamerica stock as financial backing for a tender offer for a sizable stake in Western Airlines in 1968.
Western's management publicly opposed his investment, but failed to deter him. Eight years later, after a period in which the airline prospered, Mr. Kerkorian was able to sell his stake back to Western at a premium over the market price because airline managers feared he would sell the shares to a competitor, threatening the company's independence and spoiling Western's applications for new air routes.
In the meantime, Mr. Kerkorian had begun investing in Las Vegas casinos and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., which was making fewer movies but was building the MGM Grand Hotel. In 1978 he made a cash tender offer for 20 percent of Columbia Pictures, creating tension with Columbia's executives and other big shareholders. Columbia executives finally agreed not to oppose him on condition that he not interfere in the business or increase his stake.
The agreement proved short-lived. By 1980, Mr. Kerkorian and Columbia were suing each other in several courts over whether he could raise his stake. Fay Vincent, who was then Columbia's president and is now the baseball commissioner, called his attempt to buy more shares "an outrageous assault."
A year later, in February 1981, as legal bills grew and executive attention increasingly was occupied by litigation, Columbia agreed to buy back Mr. Kerkorian's stock at a sizable premium over the market value. Once again, he had tangled with management and walked away a wealthier man.

Table: "Highlights of Kirk Kerkorian's Career"
 
1947: Starts a charter service that becomes Trans International Airlines.
 
1962 to 1968: Sells and rebuys the airline. Then sells it to Transamerica for stock. Purchases a large stake in Western Airlines. (He sold the last of it in 1976 for $30.6 million.)
 
1969: Makes a tender offer for 17 percent of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Later raises stake to 37 percent.
 
1974: With his stake at 50.1 percnet, tries to take MGM private. The company had cut back on movie production and shut a distribution subsidiary to focus on the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas.
 
1978: Begins a tender offer for 20 percent of Columbia Pictures and later agrees to limit his stake to 25.5 percent.
 
1979: Wins a suit against the Justice Department, which, citing antitrust considerations, sought to block him from holding a large stake in Columbia while controlling MGM. Eventually drops an attempted takeover of Columbia after a bitter legal struggle with management.
 
1981: Loses to Marvin Davis in a bid to acquire 20th Century Fox. MGM subsequently buys United Artists for $380 million. The next year, the company sells part of its film library to Warner Communications for $95 million.
 
1983: Tries to take MGM/UA Entertainment private, offering $375 million for the 49.9 percent of the company he does not own, but later drops the offer.
 
1988 to 1990: Seeks a buyer for the restructured MGM/UA Communications Co. Considers several offers but strikes no deal.
 
1990: Sells MGM/UA to Pathe Communications for $1.3 billion. Buys 9.8 percent of Chrysler stock, becoming the company's largest stockholder.

HEADLINE: Real Underground Fiction

BYLINE: By Roy Hoffman; Roy Hoffman is an essayist and author of the novel "Almost Family."

 BODY:
Twenty minutes to nine, Tuesday morning. The F train grinds to a halt at the Smith-Bergen stop. I squeeze into the packed car, my shoulder against a youth's leather jacket, my face inches from a lady's orange-scented swirl of hair. Twisting about, I manage to reach in to my satchel and pull out my sanctuary.
Instantly, I am standing on Willa Cather's Nebraska plain, the sky immense, the talk engaging. I glance up only once to see a young woman across from me steeped in Russian snows, another in Southern magnolias. The subway grinds around a curve, takes on more passengers at Boro Hall. I eagerly turn the page, delighted to have five stops ahead -- enough to get me to the next chapter. 
 There seems to be a great deal of serious reading going on in New York subways these days. Emile Zola, William Faulkner, Gabriel Garcia Marquez -- over the last few months I have seen their books lovingly clasped by riders otherwise annoyed at being packed together beneath the Dial-900 and foot consultation ads.
In some quirky footnote to literary history, it may be that the atmosphere of the F train is especially bookish. Sweeping as it does from far-off Brooklyn, through Greenwich Village and on toward the West Side before bending back to Queens, it picks up a wide range of readers: Hasidic Jews intent over their religious commentaries, students working their way through Dickens, mid-town managers trying to keep up with the bestseller list.
This morning alone, I have noted the serious (Robert Graves's "Claudius the God,"), the popular (Carrie Fisher's "Postcards from the Edge,") and the avant-garde (Jim Carroll's "Basketball Diaries"). While clinging to poles and leaning against railings, riders pore over these books with edgy intensity.
In its noise and crush, a train inspires a fierceness of concentration. The subway car is a reading room turned inside out, the pure inversion of a library. Whereas whispers distract in a library's hallowed quiet, neither bawling babes nor howling singers can disturb the subway reader. The car gives us every excuse to wrap ourselves in good prose and drift far away.
Not that reading on the subway is escapist. The tight quarters of a car push uncomfortably near all the ambitions and letdowns known to man: the idle gaze of a person traveling to the unemployment line set against the briskness of a company manager anxious to hurry the train along. A novelist, in his pages, could dream to capture so much.
Should other riders be allowed to preach the gospel, beg money, play lousy guitar or hawk newspapers? Why not? For those who love to read on the subways, freedom of speech -- the eloquence of which is in the books at hand -- gets us through our morning ride. Besides, the more racket the better; I have been meaning to read "War and Peace."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Reform Never Works

BYLINE: By Alan Tonelson; Alan Tonelson is the research director of the Economic Strategy Institute, a policy research center in Washington.

 BODY:

THE DEMOCRATIC WISH
Popular Participation and
the Limits of American Government.
By James A. Morone.
402 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95. 
 IF the conventional wisdom in Washington is finally right about something, the United States is in for a wave of populist reform generated by public anger over everything from the savings and loan debacle to Japanese purchases of American companies, cabinet officers and trade negotiators. If James A. Morone, an associate professor of political science at Brown University, is correct in his new interpretive study of American politics, "The Democratic Wish," this reform wave will produce exactly the opposite of what was intended: additional layers of ineffective, unresponsive government. Even more depressing, Mr. Morone suggests that reform efforts are doomed because, after more than 200 years of self-government, Americans still lack a sensible, coherent view of what government can and should be expected to do.
At first glance, this argument may seem absurd. Americans, after all, have given the world some of its greatest political thinkers and ideas, and arguably the most brilliant constitution ever written. But Mr. Mo rone covers so much ground so skillfully that none can simply dismiss his principal conclusion: we Americans will never solve our collective problems as long as we instinctively fear any meaningful exercise of public power as a threat to liberty.
According to Mr. Morone, American politics went wrong almost from the beginning, its dread of European-style state power producing fragmented governments practically impossible to mobilize for public purposes (except, perhaps, in periods of national emergency such as the Great Depression and World War II). Public purposes, however, plainly have to be served. Just as plainly, the United States Government has grown dramatically in size and authority.
Yet Mr. Morone argues that this growth has always been guided in the worst way possible -- by a desire to restore power to the people. Mesmerized by the myth of a citizenry that was not only virtuous but fully in accord on "the common good" and capable of coherent action, American reformers have time and again responded to crises and turmoil with a dodge. Instead of authorizing the state to attack these problems directly, they have sought to sidestep it altogether and rely on new institutions designed to promote direct democracy.
From the popular assemblies of the 1770's to the community action agencies of Lyndon Johnson's War on Poverty, Mr. Morone argues, the determination to cure the ailments of democracy with more democracy (as John Dewey advised) has only produced new bureaucracies that take on lives of their own. In the process, they wind up reinforcing the status quo. Momentous confrontations over equality or race or class turn into sterile dickering over representation. Even radical forces accept the belief that, say, enough seats on the community school board will solve the dropout problem. Losing sight of the substantive forest for the procedural trees, newly legitimized groups themselves become roadblocks to more sweeping changes.
Further, Mr. Morone says, such disappointments are inevitable. For the root assumptions of the democratic wish -- that overwhelming popular consensus exists on key issues and that problems can be solved simply through the unfettered clash of private interests -- were problematic enough in a country of yeoman farmers and small towns. Today they are completely groundless. Indeed, in today's more complicated political environment, the uncoordinated American way of government is a guarantee of paralysis.
Finding faults in big-idea books like this is always easy -- in fact, too easy. For example, Mr. Morone seems to neglect one major strand of the American political heritage entirely comfortable with using state power: the tradition that has flowed out of the ideas of Alexander Hamilton. Since the Federalist period, this tradition has spearheaded the construction of roads, bridges, dams and the like, while nurturing the development of new technologies from the telegraph to the integrated circuit. At the same time, as Mr. Morone shows, these ideas clearly have not been extended from the economic sphere to cover social and political questions.
Some inconsistencies pop up as well. For example, like many contemporary observers, Mr. Morone finds touching but pathetic the faith of the early 20th-century Progressives in ideal, nonpolitical solutions devised by disinterested technocrats for complex social ills. Yet he seems attached to some himself, suggesting, in one instance, that "massive job creation, a crash program designed to end illiteracy [and] a substantial redistribution of income" could have been enough to alleviate black poverty in the 1960's.
More important, Mr. Morone seems to overlook some rather understandable reasons for our political obsession with form over substance. It is only natural that the citizens of a democracy balk at giving their bureaucrats or even elected leaders a blank check to take steps with potentially far-reaching consequences -- even if we can always vote them out of office. In addition, we as a nation simply are not yet convinced that state power is the key to curing our ills in many areas, and in many cases skepticism may be justified.
As Mr. Morone concludes, the trick is to figure out how Americans can marry "democratic wishes to contemporary institutions." He suggests that by jettisoning "the checks and balances of multiple, competing authority," the nation can construct a state that is not only more competent but more accountable. He hasn't the faintest idea how to do this. But "The Democratic Wish" merits the highest compliments one can accord a public policy book. It spotlights a problem that can no longer be evaded. And it makes you think.

HEADLINE: Little Engines That Couldn't

BYLINE: By Craig R. Whitney; Craig R. Whitney, the London bureau chief of The New York Times, became a rail fan during the last days of steam on the Boston & Albany.

 BODY:

AMERICAN NARROW GAUGE RAILROADS
By George W. Hilton.
Illustrated. 580 pp. Stanford, Calif.:
Stanford University Press. $49.95; $60 after Dec. 31. 
 ANYONE who has ever wondered how it came to be that the rails on almost all American railroads are 4 feet 8 1/2 inches apart will want this account of the nonconforming railroads that flourished for a while, mostly for a couple of decades in the 19th century, running on gauges as narrow as two feet. Intended by George W. Hilton, a professor of economics at the University of California, Los Angeles, as both a state-by-state catalogue and an economic history of one of the dead ends in the story of American rails, "American Narrow Gauge Railroads" is also a treat to browse through, with 382 historic black-and-white photos and drawings and 56 maps. An authoritative documentation of a long-gone era, the book brings back to life ancient steam locomotives, railroads and rolling stock that have mostly disappeared without trace.
A few operating relics of the narrow-gauge movement survive as tourist attractions. The best known and most popular (and heavily booked) is the three-foot-gauge former Denver & Rio Grande Railway branch in Colorado that now operates as the Durango & Silverton. The Edaville Railroad in South Carver, Mass., still hauls tourists in the summer and cranberries in the fall on two-foot-gauge equipment that came mostly from the old Sandy River & Rangeley Lakes Railroad, which went out of business in Maine in 1935.
But these are curiosities begging the questions Mr. Hilton seeks to answer: why narrow-gauge roads were built in the first place, and why most of them failed. The 4-foot-8 1/2-inch gauge standard in Britain, where railroads had been born, quickly became standard in the United States and nearly everywhere else as well.
But given the American tendency to think short-term and build cheap, it's a wonder there weren't more narrow-gauge lines. For the biggest argument in favor of narrow gauge in its boom years, the 1870's and early 80's, was that it cost less to build and run a narrow-gauge line than a standard-gauge one. The locomotives and cars weighed less, so the bridges didn't have to be as sturdy; the trains could go around sharper curves, reducing the need for expensive cuts and fills; and they could run on lighter rails. Narrow-gauge locomotives also burned less fuel, and the ratio of payload to dead weight was higher than was possible with 4-foot-8 1/2-inch lines, the backers argued.
Isolated communities far from the main lines listened, seeing in narrow-gauge short lines the quickest way to make freight connections -- not necessarily with other railroads but with the nearest canal, river or seaport (everybody assumed in those days that canals and sea lanes would forever be the most economical means of long-distance bulk transportation).
And so miles and miles of narrow gauge were built -- 2,627 miles in 1882 alone -- until the peak in 1885, when there were 11,699 miles in all, according to an illuminating table in Mr. Hilton's book that also shows the precipitous decline that followed almost immediately. In 1887 alone, 1,345 miles of narrow gauge were converted to standard gauge, and by 1903 there were only 5,761 miles of narrow-gauge track left in the whole country. Today there are fewer than 50 miles. So the exhaustive state-by-state listing of narrow-gauge roads in the second half of this book, covering Alaska and Hawaii as well as the continental United States, is a historical archive, not a contemporary catalog.
In the early 1870's there were plans for a transcontinental three-foot-gauge line from Washington to Denver, but it was never built, as people began discovering the downside of building small and cheap. Lilliputian narrow-gauge locomotives and cars could not run on standard-gauge track, except piggyback on flatcars. When narrow-gauge lines tried hauling standard-gauge cars mounted on wheels to fit their track, the heavier, wider equipment became unstable and derailed on the poorly ballasted track. So they converted to the wider gauge, though not without cost: flimsily built narrow-gauge lines made for inefficient, twisting, expensive-to-maintain standard-gauge ones, as the Nickel Plate Road, the Norfolk & Western and others quickly found out.
So, except for a few historical dinosaurs surviving here and there, we ended up with the familiar 4 feet 8 1/2 inches, from the IRT subway in New York and Amtrak's Northeast corridor to the Santa Fe. So did most European countries -- except notably Spain, Russia, and Finland, which, like most of the American South in the 1860's, had opted for a still wider gauge instead. Unlike the South, these countries kept it.
The magic 4 feet 8 1/2 inches, as Mr. Hilton explains it, was about the width of cart tracks in Roman times and represented the most efficient width of a loaded vehicle that could be pulled by a horse. It suited the iron horse best, as well.

HEADLINE: Up From Invisibility

BYLINE: By James Forbes; The Rev. James Forbes is senior minister of the Riverside Church in New York City.

 BODY:

THE BLACK CHURCH IN THE AFRICAN AMERICAN EXPERIENCE
By C. Eric Lincoln and
Lawrence H. Mamiya.
519 pp. Durham, N.C.:
Duke University Press.
Cloth, $47.50. Paper, $18.95. 
 When I was a child in North Carolina, I used to travel with my father as he made the circuit of several small churches he served. I can remember passing large, beautiful churches where the white people worshiped. I used to wonder what those churches looked like on the inside, what kind of music they sang. I wondered what the pastors preached about: did they talk about how to get along with black people, or did they tell their children not to play with us? And I wondered whether they were curious about what went on in our churches, and whether they were all that different.
In their important study, "The Black Church in the African-American Experience," C. Eric Lincoln and Lawrence H. Mamiya provide a long-needed look at what was once called "the invisible institution." The black church still is invisible to many whites; no matter what other changes may have taken place, most whites and blacks in this country still pray separately. But black churches are more than places to pray; they are the hub of traditional black life. For more than two centuries, the black church has been our most important agency for the development of citizens and the training of leaders; it has fostered our solidarity as a community and fueled our drive toward political empowerment.
Blacks were exposed to Christianity in the early days of slavery by plantation owners who hoped to create obedient and docile workers. But enslaved black people transformed this sponsored religious activity into an experience that supported their eventual liberation. The gospel of Jesus Christ, with its themes of suffering and redemption, spoke to the slaves in a far more powerful voice than slaveowners had intended. By the mid-1700's, compelled by genuine faith, blacks on small plantations (George Liele, founder of the Silver Bluff Baptist Church in South Carolina, is regarded as one of the first) began to meet for private, independent worship, since the idea of authentic worship with whites was impossible.
By the late 18th century, according to Mr. Lincoln and Mr. Mamiya, black churches had embarked on what would become their dual missions of spiritual and political revival. In 1787, for example, Richard Allen, Absalom Jones and other former slaves withdrew in protest from St. George's Methodist Episcopal Church in Philadelphia after being pulled from their knees during prayer in a gallery closed to blacks. "All went out of the church in a body, and they were no more plagued with [us] in that church," Allen wrote. He and some of his colleagues became founders of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, one of the seven historically black denominations discussed in this book. The continued existence of the black church indicates that no matter how compelling the ideal of one church for all people, the notion of unity without equality remains for black people an unacceptable and spiritually empty alternative.
The public's knowledge about the black church is typically limited to the familiar movie image of black worshipers overcome by emotion, given to outbreaks of shouting and estatic praise, their funeral-parlor fans fluttering frantically to prevent exhaustion. In fact, no single image could ever do justice to the richness of the African-American religious tradition. In "The Black Church in the African American Experience," the authors have given us a portrait of black churches that reflects their complexity and variety. This excellent book documents much of the religious experience of the African-American people through the use of social science techniques, translating general impressions into solid data; it lifts these institutions into the mainstream of scholarly reflection and analysis.
Mr. Lincoln, who is a professor of religion and culture at Duke University, and Mr. Mamiya, an associate professor of religion and African studies at Vassar College, challenge what they say is "the uncritical assumption that the black experience in religion is but the replication of the white experience." Because 80 percent of all black Christians are members of seven major black denominations, the authors decided to use these Baptist, Methodist and Pentecostal communities as the subjects for a series of field interviews. More than 1,800 black clergy participated in this 10-year study -- both male and female, formally trained and self-taught; those interviewed served congregations in both urban and rural areas.
The book does more than clarify and articulate an appropriate methodology for studying the black church. Mr. Lincoln and Mr. Mamiya have compiled an enormous store of information. Most helpful are the historical overviews of the three streams of traditionally black demominations; members of these groups will find themselves revising some of their own assumptions as they regard their churches in the light of these new data. Smaller religious communities not included in the study will sharpen their focus on their own denominational objectives, problems and possibilities.
Some of the information expands on widely held beliefs about black church communities. For example, the quality of preaching is clearly central to successful leadership in black congregations. Yet the authors found that the role of music in the services ran a close second in importance. The kinds of music used in services were split along urban-rural lines, with urban churches more willing to experiment with the inclusion of secular music such as blues and jazz. Rural churches were more conservative, relying on the traditional, rhythmically accentuated gospel songs. Most of the churches studied had at least two choirs, and music is especially important to younger members.
The role of women within the black church community is contradictory, the authors found: "Both historical and contemporary evidence underscore the fact that black churches could scarcely have survived without the active support of black women, but in spite of their importance in the life of the church, the offices of preacher and pastor . . . remain a male preserve." (Only 3.7 percent of those ministers studied were women, and the authors estimate the total proportion of female ministers in the black church at about 5 percent.)
The Church of God in Christ is perhaps the most resistant of all historically black denominations to the notion of women in the pulpit, though some signs of breakthrough are beginning to appear. Even among those denominations where women are accepted as missionaries and evangelists, the pulpits of the larger or more prestigious churches may not be open to women. This state of affairs mirrors many of the same contradictions to be found in white denominations. Yet the authors also discuss "the mothers of the church," the oldest female members of a congregation or the wife of the founding pastor. These women hold extraordinary, if unofficial, power within a congregation and are often consulted before major church decisions are implemented. "The phenomenon of the 'church mother' has no parallel in white churches," the authors write. "It is derived from the kinship network found within black churches and black communities."
One surprise can be found in the numbers of black clergy who must work full time at other jobs to support themselves and their families: nearly half, according to Mr. Lincoln and Mr. Mamiya. This is a cruel paradox in light of the important economic role black churches have always played in the lives of African-Americans. In the early 20th century, black banks and credit unions, insurance companies and building and loan companies -- many of which still exist -- all had their roots in black church communities. And at the time of the study, the authors found that black churches received more than 75 percent of all charitable donations made by black people and benefited from 35 percent of blacks' volunteer time. The authors suggest that the black church is only beginning to comprehend its collective economic power, a power that might be put to significant use in helping the black community move toward full equality.
Another surprise was found in the research on black churches and the civil rights movement. The movement would have been impossible without the central role played by black churches. Yet in spite of overwhelming general support for political activism, the authors found considerable ambivalence, particularly within more evangelical strains of the black church. Some churches are reluctant to embrace the concept of black empowerment; a church with a strong emphasis on love and a commitment to reconciliation, for example, might be reluctant to take a confrontational stand.
Perhaps the most promising of all the information contained in this study is the evidence of a growing interest among black church leaders in ecumenical options that can empower the black church to pursue its mission in ways that would be impossible for individual churches. The Congress of National Black Churches -- a confederation of the leadership of the seven major denominations, founded in 1978 -- has embarked on several efforts in this regard, including economic development projects, national training programs for pastors, antidrug efforts and family support programs.

THE authors end their book with an examination of the challenges that face the black church in a changing African-American culture. The rise of Pentecostal sects within the black church offers what many feel is a deeper sense of spirituality than more mainstream black denominations provide. The growth of Islamic religion, particularly among young black males, is sure to bring changes in the black church's influence. And the growing numbers of middle-class blacks in church communities raises questions of whether black churches will split along class lines and abandon their longstanding commitment to the poor.
"The Black Church in the African American Experience" has been published at an opportune moment. The strength of the black church has always been as a vehicle for social, political and spiritual transformation. At a time when America seeks ways to restore its national identity, to rehabilitate the spirits of alienated masses, to open the doors of opportunity for millions who feel locked out, black churches stand out as institutions with a proven record in such transformation. They have demonstrated their capability for empowerment, emancipating black people from the ravages of generations of slavery and equipping them to recover a sense of identity, to forge ties of communal loyalty, to help themselves and others and to create cultural expressions that embody their hopes and aspirations.
Thanks to the patient work of Mr. Lincoln and Mr. Mamiya, the whole nation now has at its disposal much information that black communities have always taken for granted. Theological seminaries and universities may discover or reaffirm the value of researching the black church; liberation and womanist (black feminist) theologians may enter a second phase of engagement and dialogue. The private and public sectors may explore ways to make optimal use of the black church network, its varied facilities and the deployment of volunteers from its congregations in the service of the wider community; new leaders will be identified, both sacred and secular. Together with leaders of other churches and social agencies, America may discover at last that the black church is not a sideshow for the down and out, but a hidden treasure to be shared by all who pray for the health of our nation.

HEADLINE: Are We Cracking Under the Strain?

BYLINE: By Arthur C. Danto; Arthur C. Danto is the Johnsonian Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University. His most recent books are "Connections to the World" and "Encounters and Reflections: Art in the Historical Present."

 BODY:

MODERNITY ON ENDLESS TRIAL
By Leszek Kolakowski.
261 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $24.95. 
 Toward the end of the last century, and at a particularly dark moment in his life, Paul Gauguin painted what many regard as his masterpiece, in which he inscribed what were doubtless intended as eternal questions but which in truth exemplified to perfection the fin de siecle spirit the painting itself expresses: "Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?" Hegel supposed that the shape and meaning of an era become visible only when it is over with, but our century ends with the same set of questions as to the meaning of our history and where we stand and what we have to look forward to. Leszek Kolakowski's collection of essays is in this sense very much a fin de siecle book. Few people can be better equipped through philosophical discipline, personal experience, moral sensibility, historical learning and a lifetime spent confronting the events and ideas of his times to provide a degree of orientation in the historical present. If Mr. Kolakowski has no answers to Gauguin's questions, neither, one feels, can anyone have.
But the cumulative tone of the 23 essays (not counting the epilogue) is that, even more than in the last fin de siecle, historical change is out of control, and beliefs and practices, the institutional armatures of social and moral life, are cracking under the strain of innovation, revision and disillusionment. Mr. Kolakowski's is a vision of people clawing at truths that give way under their fingers. In the title essay he writes: "Whatever area of life we reflect upon, our natural instinct is to ask, What is wrong with it? And indeed we keep asking, What is wrong with God? With democracy? With socialism? With art? With sex? With the family? With economic growth? It seems as though we live with the feeling of an all-encompassing crisis without being able, however, to identify its causes clearly, unless we escape into easy, one-word pseudosolutions."
In fact, the pseudosolutions have just been enumerated: God, democracy, socialism, art, sex, the family, economic growth. The solutions, in fact, are the problems. Whatever answer we give to Gauguin's first question, it will do us no great good, since the answer to the third question is that the world is already so different from what it only recently was that there are no useful lessons to be drawn from the past -- except that lesson. It is as though fin de siecle has become a permanent condition of being. "Modernity on Endless Trial" is a very pessimistic book, the burden of which is perhaps that we have to learn to live without solutions and make do instead with a few human values and some tentative norms.
Mr. Kolakowski is a research fellow at All Souls College, Oxford, and a member of the Committee on Social Thought at the University of Chicago. In 1968 he was expelled for political reasons from Poland, where he had been chairman of the department of the history of philosophy at the University of Warsaw. His exile, and in some measure the respect and admiration he has received in the West, are acknowledgments of his personal integrity in a world that demanded orthodoxy, and of his subtle and courageous criticisms of Marxism as a philosophy and an ideology. The abrupt irrelevance of these criticisms in a world in which Marxism has become marginal as a political force, and largely antiquated as an intellectual agenda, must reinforce the resigned irony with which Mr. Kolakowski perceives the world.
Although he is the author of some 30 books in several languages, one feels it is the essay that best expresses his complex intellectual personality, since it gives opportunity for nuance and reservation, qualified assertion, personal aside, the balanced consideration of opposing views, the guarded conclusion -- as if the form were the man himself. As a form it is opposed to manifestoes and proclamations just as Mr. Kolakowski, as a person, would be opposed to those whose natural expression these forms would be. Small wonder he was perceived as a danger in a dogmatic culture, where insisting upon the gray-in-gray of philosophical fastidiousness was a form of heroism.
But the essay is as well the form par excellence for addressing a reality that resists simple, clear answers to Gauguin-style questions. An essay is a trial effort, a tentative exploration, a feeling round the contours of shapes that may never become wholly visible, a report of qualified findings. It is perhaps the literary counterpart to a form of life in which we are obliged to live tentatively and cautiously.
To those for whom the solutions have not as yet become problems, who live under clear moral skies, who are fortunate enough not to live in their own times, the essay in its essential incertitude can have little point. But for those who have confronted or been confronted by the issues with which these essays deal -- moral relativism, cultural difference, Eurocentrism, the role of the intellectual, the value of the intellectual life, the grounding of human rights and humane values, the crisis of Christianity, the price and promise of revolution, the appeal and limits of conservatism or liberalism or socialism, and the conflicting claims of religion, science, reason and philosophy -- Mr. Kolakowski's essays are exemplary. They represent perhaps the best we can come up with if we are as scrupulous as their author in resisting the easy solution that we know in advance will shortly become its own problem. The essays, in effect, embody the condition they address.
Some of them aspire to a certain playfulness that does not, I think, come naturally to this thinker. His essays on the Devil lack the lightness of touch the Devil demands in those who invoke his name, and "The General Theory of Not-Gardening" and "Emperor Kennedy Legend: A New Anthropological Debate" are heavy gambols in scholarly jocularity. Far closer to Mr. Kolakowski's temper are utterances like these: "There never have been and never will be improvements that are not paid for with deteriorations and evils." "There is no happy ending in human history." "We would do well to expect the worst." For Mr. Kolakowski, the greatest danger of modernism is "the disappearance of taboos": "It is perhaps better to believe in the validity of even apparently silly taboos than to let them all vanish." But he also knows that we cannot preserve them by an act of social will. And in any case, the idea that by erasing taboos or changing the institutional framework of human life we can build hope for a better life is "a reliable blueprint for despotism." This is the voice, bitter at times and at best sardonic, of someone who has witnessed the horrendous human costs of enacting an idealism with insufficient sensitivity to the value of what was being sacrificed in its cause.
Mr. Kolakowski retains a sort of faith in a basis of values that does not depend upon us, and indeed, he feels that our civilization will vanish if this faith is not shared. Yet he is painfully aware that there are a great many who share his belief that "the distinction between good and evil, between the prohibited and the mandatory, does not depend on our respective decisions," but whose contempt for the things he cherishes, like human rights and political freedom, is flagrant. Grounding good and evil in an external moral authority has not always, in fact has rarely, contributed to the enhancement of freedom and a respect for human dignity. Mr. Kolakowski is also aware that his faith will not especially help in making political decisions. There are always moral costs. So we must, in effect, make moral decisions the way we write essays -- we must live essayistically and diffidently.
SOME of these essays end disappointingly if we do not recall the spirit in which they were composed. "Politics and the Devil" concludes with what the author admits is, after all, a trivial truth -- we are not passive observers but participants in the struggle between God and the Devil -- even if this is mitigated by his claim that it is, "as many trivial truths, worth repeating." "Irrationality in Politics" recognizes that it has but offered "three meager and philosophically less than stimulating conclusions." "The Idolatry of Politics" concludes with the concession, "An objection might be raised that what I have said could well borrow its title from the famous treatise of Abelard: Sic et non [Yes and no]." Well, yes, he says, but "Sic et non is a suitable title for most of the stuff our minds are made of."
It is certainly the stuff of which most of these essays are made, and I think it should be celebrated. Somewhere in Mr. Kolakowski's soul is the sic of a knight of faith, but his intellect is filled with nons of qualification, extenuation and exception. The feeling of the book is that of a tension between a simple sic and a thousand inhibiting nons. That is what I call civilization, and probably the best by way of an answer civilized people can live with in an age that shrieks for the security of orthodoxy.
