SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1530 words

HEADLINE: Life's Goofy Splendors

BYLINE: By David Kirby; David Kirby is the author of "Saving the Young Men of Vienna," a volume of poems, and "Mark Strand and the Poet's Place in Contemporary Culture."

 BODY:

THE BOOK OF GODS AND DEVILS
By Charles Simic.
70 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.
Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95.
 
BODY TRAFFIC
By Stephen Dobyns.
137 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.
 
WESTWARD
By Amy Clampitt.
107 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.
Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $9.95. 
 CURRENTLY there is a schism in American letters between the presence of humor in poetry and the failure of reviewers to comment on that presence. It is hard to think of a poet today who does not sample in some way the widely varying comic tones, from subtle to raucous, that are first heard in the poems of Walt Whitman and Emily Dickinson and then echoed by writers as different as William Carlos Williams, Marianne Moore and Allen Ginsberg. Yet, while reviewers argue theme and technique in great detail, when it comes to humor they seem to have a collective tin ear. If humor is noticed at all, it is often dismissed as simply slick or clever.
Lately, this schism seems all the more remarkable, given the eagerness of a new generation of reviewers, fresh from graduate seminars, to buttress their arguments with references to Jacques Derrida, Mikhail Bakhtin and other formidable European intellects. Has none of them remarked the witty mischief in Derrida's deconstructive strategies or Bakhtin's assertion, in his book on Rabelais, that laughter has "a deep philosophical meaning"?
Three splendid books illustrate some of the ways in which humor functions not as a mere stylistic quality but as a mode of perception. Typically, a Charles Simic poem starts with a sentence fragment, an ungainly image crash-landing at the feet of a speaker who was expecting something else entirely. Thus the characters in his poems are often like the protagonists of fairy tales -- farmers or fishermen who in the course of their labors come across a talking fox or a lamp with a genie inside. These characters begin as rather ordinary types and end as heroes, their bemusement turning to amusement as they regain control over their interrupted lives.
Mr. Simic was born in Yugoslavia in 1938, and his family moved to Chicago in 1954; perhaps there is a Central European sensibility at work in his poems. His colors are fairy-tale colors: where his world is not sooty, it is splashed with reds and whites. And in many of his poems, a simple, lighthearted fellow succeeds against a harsh world. It is as though Thumbling found himself on State Street rather than his father's farm.
Fairy tales tell us that things will work out, that little people like ourselves are capable of great heroism. In "The Book of Gods and Devils" the speaker of "Windy Evening," in which this cheap stage set of an earth seems to be falling to pieces, can say, with confidence: "Better grab hold of that tree, Lucille. . . . / I'll hold the barn." In Mr. Simic's world, action is everything.
Besides, thinking is too hard -- "I get sad when I think," confides the speaker of "A Letter." Thought is sad because it simply leads to more thought, whereas action is the royal road to life's goofy splendors. In "Evening Talk," the speaker tells a friend he shouldn't have wasted his time worrying about someone who didn't show up. Instead,
 
 You should have crossed the street
 And followed that obviously demented woman
 With the long streak of blood-red hair
 Which the sky took up like a distant cry.
 Fortunately, most of Mr. Simic's hero-next-door types are more resolute. They speak to every fox, rub every magic lamp. And they are the ones who are invited, as it says in "Heights of Folly,"

 To breakfast on slices of watermelon
 In the company of naked gods and goddesses
 On a patch of last night's snow.
In Stephen Dobyns's poem "Careers," a young poet who is fascinated with Ulysses and other purposeful fellows thinks, "How simple it seemed / to pick a life and have that life make sense." But when he goes to a hospital to visit a friend, he sees a group of senile nuns caressing and singing to dolls they mistake for their own children. That's when he realizes his life might end up crazy or just dull, like that of the man in "Toting It Up" who discovers his has been merely a "twelve car life," a "two wife life," a "four kids life" and so on.
For Mr. Dobyns's characters, like Mr. Simic's, thought is rare; not because action is better, however, but because life is too crowded and busy for thought. In "The Body's Journey," the first poem in "Body Traffic," our earthly tumult is described in terms positively Dantesque:

 one woman dragging herself up by the long
 black tresses of another, an old man slamming
 his cudgel against another old man's
 bald spot, thousands scrambling to the top.
In his way, Mr. Dobyns is as fascinated with the body as St. Augustine. Unlike the church fathers, though, Mr. Dobyns adores the body and enumerates its separate parts, devoting individual poems to the nose, the nails, the feet. The laughter in his poetry derives in part from the writer's sense of the silly body heading for its next inevitable pratfall, but also from a sunny awareness of the body's unflappable optimism: at the moment of death, as he observes in "The Body's Strength," the body keeps plodding dumbly ahead, ignoring the exhausted mind's pleas to give in. And in his paean called simply "Feet," the feet are depicted as cheerful cowards ready to whisk us away when death calls. (That's why the feet love to dance, incidentally -- it's how they stay in shape for that ultimate getaway.)
Life can be pretty grisly in Mr. Dobyns's poems. But life isn't a tragedy in which we are fatally mired. Instead, it is a farce we view from a certain remove -- not much of one, but it is as though we were watching life on a movie screen. As Mr. Dobyns says, "We are lackluster virgins which the mustachioed world / ties to the train tracks of tomorrow's locomotive." Because of that slight distance between our real selves and the ones on the tracks, there is still time to do something, even if it's just to let out a rueful guffaw. After all, the train isn't here yet.
There is a ceaseless current of laughter in Amy Clampitt's poetry, a chuckling appreciation of the incongruity inherent in everything -- an incongruity, the poet seems to suggest, that she just might be able to overcome. Her poems are brightly lighted and joyous; often there is a rising delirium to them, as in a saint's description of her ecstasies. One can't help wondering if this is how Emily Dickinson might have written had she had more encouragement -- if someone had just said, "Come on, Emily, you can do it."
Ms. Clampitt's speakers don't seem to be able to contain themselves; as a consequence, one thing always leads to another. If the humor in Mr. Simic's and Mr. Dobyns's work often derives from people who think too little, in Ms. Clampitt's it stems from those who can't stop thinking. In "The Field Pansy," one of the poems in "Westward," a violet recalls asters, then Johnny-jump-ups, then, in a parody of academic description, "the bi- or tri-colored native field pansy of Europe" that is the true subject of the poem, a subject as much avoided as it is approached. One is reminded of Jim Blaine's story of his grandfather's old ram in Mark Twain's "Roughing It," a story that never gets told because each character reminds the teller of another until he himself falls asleep, so that, as Twain says, "the mention of the ram in the first sentence was as far as any man had ever heard him get."
Ms. Clampitt creates another level of humor in "The Field Pansy" by means of a teasing commentary on this tendency to ramble:

 I know I'm leaving something out
 when I write of this omnipresence of something like eagerness,
 
 this gushing insouciance that appears at the same time capable
 of an all but infinite particularity: sedulous, patient, though
 in the end (so far as anyone can see) without consequence.
 What is consequence?

And unlike Jim Blaine's story, "The Field Pansy" does end -- not with anything like a ram or even a flower but with the understanding that "consequence" lies in our ability to connect with ourselves and others.
Characteristically, Ms. Clampitt's speakers introduce a rather ordinary subject, forget it, recall it and mix it in memory with a second subject, often a tragic one. Thus in "The Beach Pea," a plant is associated with a dying neighbor. The speaker, traveling in England, sees another plant, laburnum, which is "kin of broom and gorse, of / the acacia, the beach pea . . . / The beach pea!" And she remembers the dying woman. With remarkable economy, Ms. Clampitt has her speaker simultaneously lamenting a death and chuckling at her own supercharged powers of association, which somehow manage to combine the charm of absent-mindedness with the fury of total recall. Sooner or later, everything gets connected in Ms. Clampitt's poems, so that, at the heart of each of them, there is a well-earned smile of proud wonder.
If one were to judge from reviews alone, contemporary American poetry would seem a rather dour undertaking. But these poets, three of our best, say otherwise.

HEADLINE: Five Babes in Toyland

BYLINE: By Joe Queenan; Joe Queenan writes about business and is the father of two children, one of whom falls in the Quints target market.

 BODY:
Not long ago, a relatively small toy company called Playmates stormed into stores with a quartet of radioactive mutant turtles fighting for truth and justice throughout Manhattan's sewer system. The toys have made millions. Hoping that five cuddly baby dolls can enjoy some similar measure of success, Tyco Toys this year introduced a set of tiny, reasonably priced, not-at-all-mutant quintuplet dolls called the Quints. Apparently, the theory is that there is safety in numbers, and so far the numbers -- a projected $20 million in wholesale revenues this year alone -- are very encouraging. Tyco claims it has a hit, and is now making every effort to turn that hit into an institution.
Every year, between 5,000 and 6,000 toys are introduced in the $13.4 billion United States toy business, and every year about 95 percent of the new products vanish without a trace. The Quints won't be one -- or five -- of them. The new line of quintuplet baby dolls is a very hot item, and if Tyco projections are correct, the Quints could be good news in what many expect to be a down year for the toy industry. The industry has been hurt by the recession as well as by deep discounting of toys in pre-Christmas sales, partly stemming from the desperate financial straits of Child World (the No. 2 retailer after Toys "R" Us), which suspended payments to its suppliers early this month. 
 The $20 million in Quints sales is relatively impressive, considering that the sets of five two-inch plastic dolls with innumerable matching accessories will have been on the market only 10 months. Tyco expects sales to reach $35 million in 1991, when the Quints line is significantly expanded from the three sets of five now available to a total of 11 varieties of Quints. Industry observers like Sean McGowan, a toy-industry analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, a New York securities brokerage firm, agree that this is a reasonable expectation. But McGowan also notes that Hasbro's My Little Pony, by comparison, jumped from $20 million its first year to $65 million in its second.
Next year's Quints will include the Sunny Time Quints with red hair and magic freckles, Rainy Day Quints with magic rosy cheeks, Drink and Wet Quints and Playful Quints, which shake their heads, wave their arms and suck their thumbs. In 1992, Tyco plans to add relatives -- twin brothers, triplet cousins, quadruplet aunts?
Whatever they might represent to children, the Quints are a housekeeping nightmare. Each set of Quints consists of the dolls -- three girls, two boys -- dressed in numbered diapers and ensconced in a strip of quilted bunting that sleeps five. The set, which costs $10, also includes five numbered baby bottles attached in a row on a long plastic strip, suggesting an oar for infant galley slaves. The color-coded numbers also appear on the dolls' accessories, all of which come in multiples of five, usually bonded to each other. These cost between $8 and $30 and include everything from a rocking horse for five to a five-room house.
Introduced last spring to by-no-means-overwhelming praise from buyers in the toy trade, the Quints rapidly took over second place in the small-doll segment of the doll market, behind My Little Pony. The four-inch Classic Pony, which cantered into toy stores in 1983, costs just under $5 and did $90 million of business in 1985, its peak year. The catalogue for this year offers some 60 Classic Ponies, with different-colored bodies, tails and manes and names like Rainbow Curl and Glittery Sweetheart Sister. (Later pony lines include the Petite and Dream Beauties.) Their distinguishing characteristics, largely imperceptible to the adult eye, are so fraught with delicate nuance that some little girls demand dozens of specimens from their parents. "A serious collector has 80 or 90 ponies," reports Mike Hirtle, vice president of research and development at Tyco Toys.
"The appeal is in the ownership," says Maurene Souza, Tyco's vice president of marketing for girls' toys and activities, who built her reputation through her work with My Little Pony before joining Tyco in December 1989. "It's important to say you have a lot of them." And, indeed, Wayne Charness, a Hasbro spokesman, says that one little girl somewhere in America owns 364.
With the $10 Quints, Tyco is basically operating on the razor-blade principle: sell the original product cheap and make the real money off the refills or, in this case, the accessories. These include, or will soon include, the rocking chair for five, the vanity table for five, the crib, highchair, carriage, rocking horse, wagon, wading pool and the Special-for-Five-Playground. Within this diminutive pentagonal universe there are further subsets of five; the playground, for example, includes a slide for five, a sandbox for five, a seesaw for five, etc., etc., etc., etc., etc.
Right now, according to Jim Alley, Tyco's senior vice president of marketing, most people buy around $30 worth of Quintiana; buying one starter set of Quints and the entire line of accessories would cost $120, a number that could soon double. Or triple. Or even, one day, quintuple.
The priciest item in Quintdom is the Special-for-Five-House, which has a playroom, bathroom, kitchen, nursery and a patio. Unfortunately for the consumer, it comes unfurnished, though available accessories include sinks for five, potties for five, watering cans for five, changing tables for five and playpens for five. Presumably, should the Quints ever take a sinister turn, there will be holding tanks for five, balls and chains for five and perhaps even a five-person legal defense team. But that's down the road. For the time being, Tyco will content itself with churning out a steady new supply of Quints each year, with new facial expressions, new hair styles, new ethnic groups and new furniture.
"We give them different reasons why they want more Quints," Souza says of the targeted consumers, 4- to 8-year-old girls. Tyco hopes those reasons may soon include a Saturday morning television show, the toy industry's principal instrument of coercion in dealing with children.

IT WAS BERNARD Loomis, something of a legend in the toy business, who brought the Quints concept to Tyco, in March 1989. Loomis is the president of Bernard Loomis Inc., which also employs his daughter Merry. Before that, he held top executive positions at Mattel Toys, Kenner Products Company -- where he was president and chief executive officer between 1971 and 1978 -- and General Mills Toy Group. At Mattel, he was involved with the Barbie line, but he won his stripes by bringing the tremendously successful Hot Wheels action cars to market. At Kenner, he cooked up the idea of selling consumers what amounted to "toy futures" -- the right to buy not-yet-available Star Wars toys as soon as they rolled off the assembly line. While at General Mills, he was responsible for both Strawberry Shortcake and Care Bears, maddeningly cuddly toys that, under his direction, quickly transmogrified into maddeningly inane television shows and feature films. These programs are for all intents and purposes nonstop commercials; the characters in the shows are all available as toys. Loomis, whose marketing exploits were immortalized in the title essay of David Owen's 1988 book "The Man Who Invented Saturday Morning" has long been a force in Toyland, so when he came to Tyco with the Quints, months of in-house development of a new toy line called Pussy Willow People got put on the back burner. (Which, Alley says, is no big deal in the business.)
Alley estimates that at Tyco 70 percent of new toy ideas come from independent idea people like Loomis. "Toy design people tend to be undisciplined," Alley says. "They need to be in an undisciplined environment." Tyco quickly saw the potential: "Our team totally embraced the concept."
As with many great inventions -- handwriting, the microcomputer, season-ticket plans that force hockey fans to attend three preseason games at full price -- it is sometimes difficult to assign credit to the right person. When queried about the precise circumstances surrounding the birth of the Quints, the folks at Tyco are fuzzy. They know Loomis brought up the idea in the spring of 1989, but can't recall exactly where he got it. Loomis himself initially reported that it came from either his daughter or Christina Ericson, whose own design company, Advanced Concepts, works hand in hand with Loomis's.
Merry Loomis unhesitatingly gives the credit to Ericson. "It was the classic 'What if?,' " says Ericson, a cheerful but slightly less bouncy sort than the highly animated Loomises. "I always thought a little girl would rather have five pennies than a nickel. Well, we were having a blue-sky session one day early in 1989 and. . . ."
"It exploded right here," says Merry Loomis, who is sitting in the East Side apartment her father uses as an office on his visits to New York from his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.
Bernie Loomis, wresting himself free from the grasp of a grandson who has careened into the room, now becomes turbo-charged. "As soon as I heard the idea, I knew we could come up with some interesting economics. When you design for five, you're not doing five separate products. Making five dolls is not five times as expensive as making one. The accessories are what brought it to life. I am only interested in things that have longevity and multiplicity."
Convinced that the Quints had the capacity to be big, perhaps super-big, and at the very least bigger than Inhumanoids and Stage II -- less successful Loomis inventions of recent years -- the group spent a few months developing models of the Quints and some basic accessories, including the rocking horse. In March, Loomis took them to Tyco, with whom he has a creative-development arrangement. "Tyco has no right of first refusal," Loomis says, "but Dick Grey is my best friend in the toy business."
Richard E. Grey is president and chief executive officer of Tyco.
Loomis wanted Tyco to reach a decision quickly, and agreed to one -- and only one -- child-testing session. The toys were tested on 30 girls between the ages of 4 and 8 in a research center in Teaneck, N.J. "The response was very enthusiastic," he recalls. "The kids immediately identified the central concept; they focused on the fiveness as a continuous dramatic theme."
Although Tyco officials always shared Loomis's enthusiasm for the project, they had one concern: price. Ten dollars was twice what Hasbro was getting for My Little Pony, and it was My Little Pony that the Quints would be competing against. Part of the appeal of both the Quints and My Little Pony is that the toys constitute what Sean McGowan calls "a negotiation." In other words, the toy is cheap enough that a parent can escape from the toy store relatively unscathed. A toy like Tyco's My Pretty Ballerina can set a parent back $40.
Still, $10 was a stretch. "So we all said, 'How about triplets?' " Alley says.
And?
"Triplets didn't seem that unusual," Alley says. As for quads, well, frankly, "Quads sounds like an automobile term."
Marketing director Nancy Feinberg, herself a twin, says, "One of the reasons we decided to do quints was that it would pre-empt any knockoff products, because triplets aren't as good as quints, and quads aren't as good as quints." Thus far, the Quints have inspired at least one knockoff, a set of triplets that sells for $14.99, but nobody at Tyco seems concerned.
Heather McComb, Tyco's director of product development, felt that the dolls had to be an odd number for the sake of visual intrigue. "Quads aren't as cute," she says before launching into a gentle critique of such humdrum, predictable, four-sided objects as rectangles and squares. "Five is a nicer balance. When you're arranging flowers, you would never put four in a vase, you'd put five."
How similar to the Quints on the store shelves today are the models that Loomis brought in? "It's extremely close to the original concept," Grey says, although, as McComb points out, "the body, which way it moved, the hair, the sculpt, that was all redeveloped here."
"Tyco's ability to adhere to the designer's wishes, and to do so quickly, had a lot to do with getting the product out to market," says Grey.
The research-and-development department had to move quickly because the folks upstairs wanted to take the product to Hong Kong right away to see if they could get a realistic vendor price -- toyese for the cost to the manufacturer to produce the toy. Tyco headquarters in Mount Laurel, N.J., occupy a scant three floors; most of the manufacturing is done in the Orient. Once the company was confident it could deliver a quality product for a $10 retail price, the official designing of the toy began. Heads. Hair. Clothes. Package. Bunting.
Should the Quints be all girls, or four girls, or three girls? Should their major accessories be a single, bonded unit or five separate items? At no point did the company feel that the sheer novelty of multiplicity was going to make the Quints a success. They also had to be cute. "If the little girl can't fall in love with the face on one of them, she's not going to fall in love with the face on five of them," says Alley.
Nancy Feinberg says the key moment for Quints occurred when Tyco tested the rocking horse with the 30 little girls. At the time, the horse for five was five separate horses, meaning that a child could play with each mounted Quint individually. The girls found this idea unbelievably foolish, recoiling at any suggestion that the Quints should be paired off into smaller, more manageable units. "Right then and there, we knew we should go gangbusters with the idea of fiveness," says Feinberg.
In the fall of 1989, Tyco showed the Quints, along with its other products, to major retailers like Toys "R" Us, Child World, and K Mart.
"The reaction was, 'O.K., we'll stock it, but no big deal.' " Feinberg says.
Still, Tyco felt it had a potential hit, based on its child testing. "You have to market it to the ultimate consumer, not to the trade," Souza says. "The industry is kid-driven."
At that initial showing, the accessories were packaged in a closed cardboard box. The retailers suggested Tyco open up the packaging, putting in a see-through blister window. This change added about 80 cents to the manufacturing cost of each item, but Tyco decided not to pass the increase on to the consumer.
The reaction to the Quints' official unveiling, at the toy industry's American International Toy Fair in February, was mildly enthusiastic. But buyers' attention was directed at big-ticket items, like Tyco's Baby Shivers and My Pretty Ballerina and Hasbro's Baby Uh-Oh and Go-Go, My Walking Pup.
Still, Alley, dead certain that the kids knew more than the trade, wanted to move quickly. In order to get the Quints into the stores by Easter 1990, he had the dolls flown in, rather than shipped, from Hong Kong, at the same time launching an advertising blitz on television. "We brought in enough to get a little bit of product everywhere in the country," Alley says. "It cost more to bring it in than the profit we made on the product. But sales kept climbing after Easter" -- a time when they ordinarily drop -- "and I knew we had a winner." The toys were stocked in big retail and discount outlets across the country. They sold well in all.
Confident that the Quints were a hit, Tyco went to work on line extensions, again with Loomis's intimate involvement. The research-and-development department fooled around with punk Quints and rocker Quints, and even made prototypes, though Tyco claims it wasn't serious. But most of the ideas were standard stuff. For the 1991 line, Tyco made 300 Quint prototypes (from which eight final sets were developed) with 600 different pairs of eyes. All of them crying out for affection, Tyco hopes.
"It's the ultimate nurturing toy," Souza says. For a girl's toy to be successful, "it has to have some sort of vulnerability. With Oopsie Daisy, the doll falls and they scoop it up. With Baby Shivers, when they take her gown off, the baby shivers. In their world, these are the only things that are weaker than they are." (Souza, Alley, Grey and Loomis were all asked if feminist groups might not take exception to such sexual typecasting. None of them seemed concerned. "We haven't had a single comment," Grey says.)
Vulnerability may not be enough. Tyco would like to think of the Quints as a hermetically sealed universe. But this reporter's own extremely limited research found that children seem to find the Quints a somewhat static toy and quickly bring other dolls, such as Barbie, into the play environment to act as mothers or baby sitters.

WHY DOES A TOY like Quints lend itself so readily to endless expansion, licensing, television shows, etc., while other creatures, including popular characters on successful TV shows, do not?
"A lot of these characters aren't really toyetic," Alley answers.
Along with the 11 sets of Quints that will be available in 1991 will come quintuple sets of bunnies, pacifiers, rain ponchos, sun dresses and bonnets. Not to mention the supplementary outfits for five -- visors, toothbrushes, sand shovels, party clothes, earmuffs. And that's just the beginning.
"The Quints can go up in age," Alley points out. "They can have cars and airplanes, anything they like. . . ."
Loomis, who is already thinking about 1993's product mix, refuses to be pinned down on how the line will be extended, but he hints that efforts have been taken to "protect every kind of multiple possible."
Though Loomis has income from royalties on other toys and highly lucrative consulting arrangements all over the place, the Quints make for a big payday. For Loomis and his group, the Quints figure to be worth $1 million this year alone.
In the coming months, there will be more revenues, from the licensing of lunch boxes, children's clothing, sheets, the works. Ericson now spends about 40 percent of her time on the Quints, much of it handling the burgeoning licensing business.
"We are also talking entertainment," says Loomis. Speaking of the possibility of a Quints television program or special, he rhapsodizes: "We might have a TV special where the kids speak a language that adults wouldn't understand. It's not that different from the 'Look Who's Talking' concept, where Bruce Willis plays a baby boy."
Couldn't the Quints simply fade away overnight? Loomis says this rarely happens in the toy business. (But Sean McGowan, the toy-industry analyst, recommends caution in projecting Quints sales as far ahead as 1993.) "If you ask anyone in the business about My Little Pony right now, people would says it's dead," says Loomis. "Yet My Little Pony is still No. 1 among small dolls."
Then, discussing Mattel's absolute refusal to ever pull the plug on Barbie, Loomis declares: "For a product like this, you need a commitment on the part of the company to the idea that the death of the Quints is just not acceptable."
Even if they could be driven to a mausoleum-for-five in a hearse-for-five with five sets of color-coded funeral accessories?

PERSON: QUEENAN, JOE

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4422 words

HEADLINE: DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub, the author of "Too Good to Be True: The Outlandish Story of Wedtech," has been a Giants fan for 30 years.

 BODY:
There came a moment, midway through the second quarter of the New York Giants' game with the San Francisco 49ers earlier this month, that illuminated the extraordinary character of the Giants' defense this year. The score stood at Giants 3, 49ers 0. The 49ers had the ball in their own territory, on second down with 10 yards to go. Quarterback Joe Montana dropped back to pass, and began to retreat almost immediately under pressure from the linebacker Lawrence Taylor and from the blitzing safety Greg Jackson.
Montana, who is famous for his ability to take in the whole of a field like some bird of prey, looked and looked -- and found nothing. The Giants' zone defense had blanketed his receivers, as it would all day. Montana backpedaled, his protection collapsing, and at last, in a gesture of despair, tossed the ball 15 yards from the nearest receiver. It was the third time that Montana had thrown into dead space. He looked rattled. He would stay rattled all game. 
It was not a particularly noticeable play. Lawrence Taylor didn't tear Montana's head off. It was just an incomplete pass. But it was an incomplete pass produced by perfect defense. The Giants finally lost the game, 7-3; but in the course of losing, the defense proved that it was a mechanism every bit as powerful, as precise and as coordinated as the 49ers' offense -- the standard by which offensive squads have been measured for much of the last decade. The Giants' defense may not have the sheer destructive power that it had in the 1986 season, when Taylor and the gang bullied their way to the Super Bowl. This is a different team; but it may be just as good. Through the Giants' victory against Minnesota two Sundays ago that clinched the division title, the defense had given up fewer yards and fewer points than any other team in the National Football League.
"There are a lot of teams that are physical," says John Madden, the CBS television analyst and former head coach, "but the difference with the Giants is that their efficiency level is so high. They play the zone so well, they guard the run so well. I don't think there's any weakness." In regard to teamwork, says Madden, "They're better at it than anyone else I've ever seen."

FOOTBALL THEORY DICTATES THAT TEAMS located in cold, windy regions, where Arctic blasts make the forward pass perilous, concentrate on the ground game and defense. The Giants have honored this principle for so many years that it has the status of a sacred tradition and a spiritual principle. From 1931 to 1960, the team had but two coaches, Steve Owen and Jim Lee Howell, and both compiled tremendous records by playing fundamental football. Owen, in fact, is credited by some football scholars with inventing the 4-3 defense in 1950. (The 4-3 alignment -- with four linemen crouched in a three-point stance, and three linebackers behind them -- then became the standard N.F.L. defense for nearly three decades.) Only, in fact, when the Giants tried to play flashy football, starting in the 1960's, did the team lose its way and wander in the wilderness for 15 years of humiliating incompetence.
After the 1978 season, Wellington and Tim Mara, the club's owners, hired George Young as the general manager. Young had imbibed his football wisdom from a potent source: Don Shula, a certified football genius with whom Young worked first with the Baltimore Colts in the late 60's and early 70's, and then with the Miami Dolphins in the 70's. It was Shula, still the Dolphins' head coach, who more or less invented the 3-4 defense, designed to combat offenses built around the passing game.
In the years prior to Young's arrival, the Giants had lavished first-round draft picks on such football forgettables as Rocky Thompson, Eldridge Small and Francis Peay. Young's first three top selections were Phil Simms, still the Giant quarterback; Mark Haynes, a cornerback who played six seasons for the Giants and became an All-Pro, and Lawrence Taylor, the linebacker generally cited as the most dominating defensive player the game has ever seen. In 1984, Young was criticized for devoting his top pick to another linebacker, Carl Banks, when that was one of the few positions where the team already had gifted players. Banks became an All-Pro, and a prototype of the new breed of outside linebacker necessary to the 3-4 defense -- powerful enough to dominate blockers on running plays, fast enough to stay with pass receivers.
Young, a man of ample girth and owlish mien, is at pains to explain that he has assembled the Giants along sound theoretical lines. One of the core Young principles is, "More Spartanlike teams tend to win championships." Another of his military dictums is, "Mercenaries don't necessarily make the best soldiers." And so it's not by accident that, no matter what their record, the Giants have emphasized defense, toughness, team play and continuity.
Perhaps the most important choice Young made was to hire Bill Parcells as his defensive coordinator in 1981 and to promote him to head coach two years later. Parcells, like Young, is a man of substantial proportions, as well as a tough-minded pragmatist. One of his favorite sayings, often used as a riposte to inquiries from the press, is, "Guys, this is not a complicated game." Actually, it is a complicated game, but Parcells's intensity of focus tends to make everything seem elemental. He does not care to appear complicated, or creative, or even pleasant. "I'll tell you what Bill Parcells is," says Joe Theismann, the former Washington Redskins quarterback. "He's a guy. He's a regular kind of guy. And all he wants to do is win football games."
Parcells is a violent enemy of complacency. A few days before the team was due to play the far weaker Detroit Lions, Parcells was ripping into his defense after a shoddy practice. Didn't they know that the Lions' great running back, Barry Sanders, could score from anywhere on the field? Didn't they recall, he said, reaching for an obscure, if ominous, statistic, that in last year's game the Lions had gained 18 yards for every minute their offense had held the ball? Thus forewarned, the Giants went out and beat the Lions, 20-0.
Parcells's indifference to public opinion sometimes shades into outright hostility, particularly to the press, whose function, as he sees it, is to destroy the sense of team spirit he so carefully nurtures. This can make him difficult to talk to. He did, however, show up one morning in the red-white-and-blue cinder-block bunker that serves as the press room in Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., to talk to me about the Giants' defense. "I don't think it's all that good," he said. "The team's fairly mature. Most of them know what they have to do to win. But I'm not convinced of anything." He was, he conceded, pleased at the way the inside linebacker Pepper Johnson had been playing. But he said that he was looking for "more dominance, more consistency, more turnovers."
Trying to dislodge Parcells from his rapt focus on the next game is generally a vain pursuit. "My job," he said, "is to give the players good designs, and try to get 'em to play. That's my job. It's the only job I have. Their job is to pay attention, and to condition themselves to play on Sunday. That's their job."
Parcells, in short, is a Spartan. He believes that defense is more important than offense because -- well, he just believes it. Indeed, the Giants' head coach has defense in his bones. A former linebacker himself at Wichita State University, he spent 15 years bouncing around the college ranks as a defensive coach. In the two years he spent as the Giants' defensive co-ordinator, Parcells was virtually a member of the defensive squad, hanging out with the players in the off-season. "It was like we had a close-knit, impenetrable clan," recalls George Martin, the longtime defensive end who retired in 1988.
"There are times when we're in a tight game," says Carl Banks, "and Bill will come in at halftime and he'll turn to the offense and say: 'Offense, we've got to move the ball. Offense, we've got to execute a little better.' And then he starts with the defense, and it's almost like a change of personality. 'Defense, we need two turnovers. We need one for a touchdown. We need to get a sack. We got to make them punt into the wind.' And then he'll send us out there. I don't know if a lot of players on other teams would keep in mind what he says. But he has us in such a trance that when we walk out on the field, we'll get one turnover and come over to the sidelines and say, 'O.K., the next one's got to be for a touchdown.' "

If, on the level of character and culture, the Giants' defense has its Spartan spirit, on the level of strategy and deployment, it has a proficiency that comes with slow, patient growth. Young, Parcells and Bill Belichick, the current defensive coordinator, have now had a full decade together -- an amazing span, in football terms -- to adapt the personnel and the system to one another. "The whole thing has to be integrated from top to bottom or it's a mess." says Belichick. "If you get guys who can't play your system, then you can either play the system even though they're not very good at it, or you change the system to fit the players." In either case you've got a mess.
The Giants like to say that they play "plain vanilla" defense, as opposed to what the linebacker coach, Al Groh, calls "the tricks and gimmicks philosophy." But that's just the way Spartans talk. The defense isn't simple; it's rational.
Begin with the linebackers. The 3-4 alignment, now played by the majority of N.F.L. teams, places the linebackers at the fulcrum of the defense, and the Giants' current starters -- Taylor and Banks, Pepper Johnson and either Gary Reasons or Steve DeOssie -- are arguably the finest corps in the game. Linebackers on the Giants have to be big enough to take on the block of an offensive guard but also fast enough, at least if they play on the outside, to stay with a receiver. The Giants will not recruit a small, swift outside linebacker, though they have made a place for Steve DeOssie on the inside. DeOssie, a former Dallas Cowboy, was considered too slow to play middle linebacker in the Cowboys' 4-3 alignment, but in the Giants' 3-4 he plays against the run; on passing downs, he goes out in favor of the more agile Reasons. DeOssie is a perfect instance of the Giants' flair for filling round holes with round pegs.
Taylor, as a linebacker, has virtually mutuated into a stand-up defensive end, a role now played by the most versatile linebackers on all teams that employ a 3-4 defense. With his combination of speed, strength and ferocity, he is able to overwhelm pass blockers; from his standing position he also reads the development of a play and pursues it as no down lineman can. Last year, the Giants found that Pepper Johnson had some of the same talents; Johnson now sometimes rushes the passer from the weak side (away from the opponents' tight end) while Taylor charges from the strong side, an instance of the scheme of adapting to a player.
The Giants' down linemen, like the linebackers, are purpose-built. George Martin, who played defensive end at about 240 pounds, would no longer fit on the defensive line. In the Giants' "two gap" defense, in which the three down linemen are positioned nose to nose with the offensive center and two tackles, with responsibility for the gaps on either side, the linemen are expected to stand up their opponents on running plays -- clogging up the running lanes and occupying blockers so that the linebackers are free to make tackles. It is a job that requires size on an alpine scale. The starting linemen -- Eric Dorsey, Erik Howard and John Washington -- average 6 feet 4 inches, 275 pounds, and their mighty exertions have held opposing teams to an average of 85 yards a game on the ground. The pass rush has produced relatively few quarterback sacks, but wise heads in the N.F.L. insist that hurrying the passer matters almost as much as sacking him. In three notable cases -- against Dan Marino of the Dolphins, Jim Everett of the Rams and Joe Montana -- the line hurried a gifted quarterback into a gamelong state of near futility.
The Giants' pass rush may be a trifle less ferocious than it was in 1986, when, as the defensive end Leonard Marshall (who replaces John Washington in passing situations) says with a contented smile, "We put quite a few quarterbacks out," but the secondary has made up the difference. Last year, Myron Guyton, then the rookie strong safety, led the team in tackles. This year, Guyton says he has finally mastered the Giants' zone coverage, and he and the second-year safety Greg Jackson have gained an intuitive sense of one another's whereabouts.
During the off-season, the Giants acquired Dave Duerson, an experienced safety formerly with the Chicago Bears, and Everson Walls, a veteran cornerback. Walls is another round peg. Released by the Cowboys, he was, at 30, thought to be growing a bit old and slow for man-to-man coverage. In the zone, however, where a player covers a certain area of the field rather than a player, sheer speed matters less than the ability to sense a play's unfolding. Walls, who intercepted 44 passes with the Cowboys, clearly has this gift. When I asked him how he knows where a pass pattern is heading, Walls said, "You just sort of float into the play." (As the linebacker coach Al Groh points out, players with "football intelligence" are often better at perceiving than explaining.) Walls now leads the Giants in interceptions.
Like the Chicago Bears and the Philadelphia Eagles, the Giants are known as a hard-hitting team with a hard-hitting secondary, but unlike those teams they don't often use the straight man-to-man pass coverage that is associated with in-your-face football. The Giants play a zone, which for all the talk about plain vanilla, is a complex piece of clockwork. Sometimes the Giants will play a zone deep and man-to-man underneath, or a zone on one half of the field and man-to-man on the other. In these variations, the defensive backs often line up as if they were playing a basic zone -- with two safeties deep and the cornerbacks underneath -- thus misleading the opposing quarterback. Carl Banks says he delights in the fact that he learns a few new wrinkles every year, as the coaches conclude that the players' abilities have grown.
As a whole, this is a defense that makes so few mistakes that the miscues can be counted. Until Game 11, when the Philadelphia Eagles made the defense look mortal for the first time in a 31-13 trouncing, the Giants had yielded no gain longer than 34 yards. On two separate occasions, the Eagles' quarterback, Randall Cunningham, found Keith Byars, a receiver, all by himself along the sidelines; Byars gained 54 yards the first time, and 20 the next. Cunningham also completed a 49-yard touchdown pass. But when I spoke to Bill Belichick several days after the game, he was clearly more upset about the open man than the long pass, which he viewed simply as the law of averages catching up with his club.
Belichick is an intensely studious man with a degree in economics; still, asked what went wrong, he took the hallowed route of inarticulateness. "We had a breakdown," he mumbled.
Belichick's own fascination with football diagnostics, however, got the better of him, and by and by he was scribbling hieroglyphics in my notebook. His point, so far as I could grasp it, was that on both plays the Giants had gone to man-to-man coverage. Even in man-to-man, Belichick explained, two defenders will take either of two receivers depending on the routes the receivers run. In each case, someone had made the wrong choice about which receiver to follow, though Belichick declined to point the finger at the guilty party.
Belichick also wished me to understand that just because the machine had coughed, it didn't mean it was broken. Whatever changes would be made for the 49ers' game would have to do with the 49ers, not the Eagles.
The Giants lost to the 49ers, of course, but the defense won the battle. The inside linebackers and Erik Howard, the nose tackle, bottled up the middle against the run. The secondary took away the long and even intermediate pass, and almost shut out the great receiver Jerry Rice, who caught only one pass for 13 yards. Joe Montana managed one perfect pass, to a sliding receiver, John Taylor, inches beyond the reach of a diving cornerback, Mark Collins, and that was the touchdown that won the game.

ON THE WEDNESDAY before the Sunday game against the Detroit Lions, I found Bill Belichick pedaling away furiously on an exercycle in a darkened room. I asked Belichick, a trim, lantern-jawed, weathered-looking veteran of 38, if he always performed his regimen under cover of night. "No," he said, "I was watching films of last year's game." After I promised the coach that I would not reveal troop movements prior to battle, he slapped the cassette back in the recorder.
The Lions play a formation called the run-and-shoot, a wide-open offensive strategy that has gained a certain vogue in the N.F.L. On virtually every play they use four wide receivers, no tight end and only one running back. It's a little bit like playground football -- the spiritual opposite of how the Giants play -- but the Lions have run up points and yards, if not victories. In the game Belichick was watching on film, Detroit had gained more than 400 yards while losing to the Giants, 24-14. The Giants hadn't seen a run-and-shoot team during the regular season since then, and during practice that day the offense had had trouble simulating the alignment, and the defense had had trouble guarding against it.
On the screen Belichick ran a series of plays in which the four Lions' wide receivers outraced the Giants' linebackers to make receptions in front of the secondary. The receivers, said Belichick, had been faster than the Giants had anticipated. The logical response would be to insert a fifth defensive back in place of a linebacker, known as a nickel formation, or even a sixth, which the Giants call a dime. But the danger of overloading the defense to protect against the pass is that the Lions will then hand the ball off to Barry Sanders.
Underneath these tactical matters was a psychological consideration that the Giants take very seriously. "You might want to say, 'Look, here's our base defense, we can play it against anything. You're not going to chase us out of something we've been practicing since the first day of the season,' " Belichick says. On the other hand, he continues, you can't be stubborn. "It's going to depend on how the game is going. We've got to be prepared to go both ways."
Giving good designs, as Bill Parcells calls it, is a large part of pro football. So much time falls between games that coaches and players can prepare for every eventuality. What is an opponent likely to do in this formation? With this player in motion? On this down, on this part of the field? By Sunday a player must be ready to react instinctively. The coaches must decide what alignment they want to open with and what adjustments they must be ready to make. They have to decide, as Belichick said, how much they are willing to let the opponent dictate their strategy. Last year the Giants had come out in their base defense, the 3-4, and then had shifted to the nickel package after getting burned on short passes. This time around, Belichick decided to prepare the defense to play the 3-4, the nickel and the dime. (Box, page 24.)

GAME DAY, NOV. 18, WAS Giants' weather -- 41 degrees, wind at 22 miles per hour. I recalled another George Young maxim: Teams that play in domed stadiums, like Detroit, have trouble playing outside. I also recalled one of Bill Parcells's rare aphorisms: "Defense travels." Translation: Offense suffers from weather, crowd noise, and other contingencies; defense does not.
By the time the Lions got their hands on the ball, the Giants had driven 76 yards for a touchdown, lending support to a contention heard around the league: The Giants' defense has gotten better because the offense is putting the other guy behind the eight ball. The Giants came out in their nickel defense. Erik Howard, a nose tackle, and Leonard Marshall, a pass-rush specialist, were joined on the line by Taylor and Lawrence McGrew, who was filling in for the injured Banks. Parcells and Belichick had decided, in effect, to go with their third-down defense on first down. After making a first down, the Lions went to third-and-5. At this point the Giants shifted to the dime, sending Duerson in for McGrew. Bob Gagliano, the quarterback, completed a pass, but Duerson made the tackle short of a first down.
The pattern stayed the same. By the time the Lions saw the ball again it was four minutes into the second quarter, and the Giants were winning, 10-0. Gagliano threw to his wide receivers, completing four in a row, though none of them for long yardage. After the fourth pass, on third-and-1, Belichick, expecting the run, brought in the 3-4 for the first time. In came the defensive ends Eric Dorsey and John Washington, the inside linebackers Steve DeOssie and Johnie Cooks. Sanders ran left, and Dorsey threw him for a one-yard loss.
On the Lions next possession, the Giants came out in the dime, with Duerson in place of McGrew, Belichick having concluded that the Lions would have to pass, and for much of the rest of the game he would stay with this 2-3-6 alignment. On the first play of the drive, Sanders ran up the middle for 15 yards, a perfect instance of what the run-and-shoot can do if the defense overcompensates. But when the Lions tried the same play again, the Giants plugged up the middle and Sanders was dropped for a loss. Two plays later, the Lions punted, and two plays after that Phil Simms found the wide receiver Mark Ingram for a 57-yard touchdown. The game was effectively over after three possessions. When the gun sounded, the Giants had their first shutout of the season.
After the game the Giants were not exactly jubilant; they were very pleased. The players stood in front of their lockers -- dressed, by the way -- and savored a professional performance. Pepper Johnson, a very sunny young wrecking ball, said the coach had apologized to the defensive players for abusing them earlier in the week.
"We studied well," said Everson Walls, when someone asked him why the Giants won so handily.
Several times I wandered over to Gary Reasons's locker. The aptly named Reasons is one of the Giants' most reflective players, and when I first walked over he was talking about how the Giants hadn't had "enough history" on the Lions last year to know how to react; this time around, he said, there had been no indecision. The zone had been tight because they secondary had matched up with the receivers at the line of scrimmage rather than waiting for a route to cross their zone. It had been interesting, he said. "When you play against an offense like this that's very different, it lightens the atmosphere, so to speak; it's a challenge," he said.
Later on, as the locker room was emptying of both players and the press, I paid another visit to Reasons, who was still sitting and expounding. What did Parcells say at half time? I asked.
" 'We got 30 more minutes! Anything can happen! This team is explosive!' " Reason mimicked in a near falsetto. "Really," added Reasons, "he just said: 'Stay focused. You know what to do.' "
The defense, I said, had looked flawless. Reasons pondered the compliment for a moment.
"I wouldn't say that," he replied. "There's always something that can be improved."
 
 
 
WHAT THE DEFENSE SEES
 The Giants' basic defense, the 3-4 (Diagram A), is an alignment that employs three "down" linemen - John Washington, Erik Howard and Eric Dorsey - stationed opposite the offensive center and the offensive tackles; two inside linebackers - Steve DeOssie or Gary Reasons and Pepper Johnson - who fill the gaps between linemen on running plays and play zone coverage against the short pass; two outside linebackers - Lawrence Taylor and Carl Banks - who not only play the run and the pass, but also blitz the quarterback; and a secondary comprising two cornerbacks - Everson Walls and Mark Collins - and two safeties - Myron Guyton and Greg Jackson - whose prime responsibility is pass coverage, though they must also be able to "read" and stop a running play.
Of course, defenses are now so flexible that a team on the field may look very different from the way it does on the blackboard. In the Giants' case, Taylor, and occasionally Johnson, may station themselves on the line of scrimmage, giving them the option to rush the passer.
The secondary is lined up in a "two deep" formation, which the Giants use more than any other team. The advantage of going with two, rather than three, players in the deep zone is that it frees one cornerback to fill the area that is vacated when a linebacker rushes the passer. The two-deep zone, in effect, provides insurance for Taylor's ferocious blitzes. It also means, however, that the Giants must often do with single coverage on long pass routes.
Diagram B shows the offense in a run-and-shoot formation, with four wide receivers, and the Giants in a "nickel" defense, with a fifth defensive back. In obvious pass situations like this, the Giants often replace Washington with Leonard Marshall, a better pass rusher; they also sometimes remove the other defensive end, Dorsey, and place two outside linebackers - Taylor and Johnson - on the line of scrimmage. This makes the defense more vulnerable to a power running attack, but more effective against a deceptive maneuver like the screen pass; a linebacker is not only faster than a lineman, but playing in a stand-up position gives him a better chance of seeing the blocking pattern for the screen develop than a lineman.
The nickel defense is designed to put more speed on the field to cover the passing zones. A linebacker steps into the position normally occupied by a defensive end, and a fifth defensive back, generally the cornerback Perry Williams, occupies the linebacker's spot. (In the "dime," an inside linebacker is replaced by a sixth defensive back, normally Dave Duerson.) In both of the "sub" defenses and the basic 3-4, the Giants may resort to a three-deep secondary. -- JAMES TRAUB

SECTION: Section 6; Page 27; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Food;
Out of Africa

BYLINE: BY ERIC V. COPAGE; Eric V. Copage is an editor of this magazine.

 BODY:
I was never a holiday kind of guy. Perhaps it was because I grew up in the seasonless sprawl of Los Angeles, or because my family was not particularly religious. Perhaps it was that we observed few holiday rituals. Although we put up a Christmas tree every year (an aluminum one for several seasons, I'm embarrassed to say), there was no ceremony to it -- no drinking of eggnog or listening to Christmas carols while hanging the ornaments. To me the tree seemed more or less like another piece of furniture. Over the past two years, however, the holiday season has taken on a new meaning as my family sits at the dinner table the week following Christmas to celebrate Kwanzaa.
Kwanzaa, created 24 years ago by Maulana (Ron) Karenga, chairman of black studies at California State University in Long Beach, is a cultural observance for black Americans and others of African descent. The name means "first fruits of the harvest" in Swahili. There is no festival of that name in any African society, but, to emphasize that black Americans come from many parts of Africa, Karenga synthesized elements from many African harvest festivals to create a unique, American celebration. 
 When I first told my wife I was thinking about observing the holiday, she barricaded the closet door and said she'd never chuck our Christmas tree lights and antique ornaments. I told her that wouldn't be necessary. Kwanzaa, which runs from Dec. 26 to New Year's Day, does not replace Christmas and is not a religious holiday. It is a time to focus on Africa and African-inspired culture.
I came to Kwanzaa by accident. Late December a few years back, I was visiting the American Museum of Natural History when I heard the sibilant sound of African rattles. It came from a dance performance that was part of the Kwanzaa celebration that has been held at the museum since 1978. The holiday didn't make much of an impression on me then, but I turned to it after the birth of my son, Evan, three and a half years ago. I wanted him to have a joyous, nonoppressive sense of his black heritage; I wanted him to have a celebratory African-American holiday with memories he'd be able to savor as an adult.
When my family lights the black, red and green Kwanzaa candles this week, we will do so with more than five million black Americans around the nation who celebrate Kwanzaa to varying degrees. Some adhere strictly to the program as Karenga conceived it. Their observances incorporate the seven Kwanzaa symbols. Fruits and vegetables, for instance, stand for the product of unified effort, a straw place mat for reverence for tradition and an ear of corn symbolizes each child in the family. The other symbols are simple gifts; a communal cup for the libation (I like to look at this latter bit as a kind of homage to past, present and future black Americans); a seven-branched candleholder and the seven candles.
Each candle symbolizes the seven principles black Americans should live by. A family member lights a candle on each day of Kwanzaa, then discusses one of those seven principles: unity, self-determination, collective work and responsibility, cooperative economics, purpose, creativity and faith. The idea is that during Kwanzaa, families share simple dinners and exchange gifts with a black theme -- an album of South African music, for example, or a book by Toni Morrison. The last day of the holiday is marked by a lavish feast, which, in keeping with the theme of black unity, may draw on the cuisines of the Caribbean, Africa, South America . . . wherever Africans were taken.
My family, along with many others, takes an a la carte approach to the holiday. I paraphrase excerpts from biographies of black men and women or black folk tales, myths and historical events that illustrate the seven principles. We omit the communal cup and the candleholder on the dinner table, preferring to use free-standing candles instead.
And then there is the dinner. Since my wife does the heavy Christmas cooking, the challenge of orchestrating the Kwanzaa meal is in my hands.
This is not easy stuff. When I was growing up, meals in our household tended to be haphazard affairs, and the holiday season was no exception. We'd either improvise meals for ourselves -- baked chicken or a steak would be as likely as anything -- or leapfrog to the homes of friends and relatives for more traditional turkey and cranberry sauce. My father, brother and I would politely compliment our host, but the real reason for the visit was the bonhomie, independent of the food.
In adapting Kwanzaa into our life, I decided we'd have one Kwanzaa meal in the middle of the weeklong holiday. The first meal comprised dishes that brought forth sweet memories of my youth. I remembered helping my grandmother make collard greens, especially the arduous task of washing dirt from the leaves (and getting bawled out if someone got a gritty mouthful during dinner), and I remembered sorting and discarding the bad black-eyed peas for the Hoppin' John she cooked. I remembered visiting West Africa when I was 18 years old and tasting the spicy tingle of peanut soup for the first time. And, of course, there was a lifetime of cornbread.
This year, I decided to ask for help. Dee Watts-Jones, a clinical psychologist, has cooked groundnut stew for the 16 years she has celebrated Kwanzaa. The stew, made with chicken, peanut butter and tomato paste, inspired me to search for a new recipe for the dish's first cousin, peanut soup. The latter was my initiation to African food, and was so highly spiced in that first encounter that when I tried it I broke into a sweat.
Since then, I have tried several peanut soup recipes, one of which includes ribs as well as the usual chicken, and another from a 1953 cookbook that calls for "a cigarette tin" of roasted peanuts. The recipe I have included here doesn't employ such arcane measuring devices, and is just spicy enough without searing the palate.
A Brazilian dish of red snapper, green peppers and onions came to me from Avis Johnson-Piper, owner of Army & Lou's Restaurant in Chicago. "I picked up this recipe when I was traveling in Bahia, the most African part of Brazil," Johnson-Piper says. Callie Crossley, a producer at the television news program "20/20," gave me the holiday punch recipe of her mother, Mattie. And Norma Jean and Carole Darden, caterers and the authors of "Spoonbread and Strawberry Wine," offered what I ultimately decided would be the main dish for this year's Kwanzaa meal. They call it Babatunde's African Stew, after a Nigerian friend who gave them the recipe, which makes a delicious, subtly spicy stew of chicken, onions, carrots, spinach and green pepper. I had eaten a similar dish years ago in Liberia, the difference being that in the remote village where I was staying, I had to catch my own chicken.
Anyway, after deciding on the stew as a main dish, I decided to give it a preholiday trial run one Saturday last month. By six that evening, my house was fragrant with the scent of the meal. As I put the stew before Evan, I was full not only of cultural pride, but also of the feeling of accomplishment of having cooked the dish without having burned it. However, before even taking a bite, Evan poured a puddle of ketchup on his plate, pulled the chicken from the spinach and immersed the bird in the puddle. So much for fundamentalist Afro-centrism. I guess he's not yet ready for the hard-core, traditional fare. Maybe next year.
 
AVIS JOHNSON-PIPER'S RED FISH
 
 6 yams, unpeeled and quartered
 2 to 3 tablespoons brown sugar
 7 large carrots, peeled and sliced
 1 tablespoon peanut oil
 1 medium onion, sliced thin
 2 large green peppers, seeded, deveined and sliced into 1/4-inch strips
 1 1/2 to 2 pounds red snapper filets (see note)
 1 1/2 teaspoons chopped fresh dill
 1/2 cup thinly sliced white onion
 1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper
 1 clove garlic, minced
 1 1/2 teaspoons hot paprika
 4 large Boston lettuce leaves, washed and patted dry
 4 tomatoes, quartered.
 1. Using a steamer and a large saucepan, steam the yams over simmering water for 15 to 20 minutes, or until just soft. Remove and sprinkle with brown sugar. Set aside in a warm place. Meanwhile, steam the carrots in another saucepan for about 12 minutes or until just soft. Remove and set aside in a warm place.
2. In a large skillet, heat the peanut oil. Saute the onion and sliced green pepper for 2 to 3 minutes, until the onion is just soft and the pepper is bright green but still crisp. Set aside in a warm place.
3. Meanwhile, rinse the fish under cold running water and gently pat dry. Fill a large pan with water to a depth of 1 inch. Place the fish on a steaming rack, place in the pan and sprinkle with the fresh dill. Strew the 1/2 cup sliced onion around the fish, and sprinkle with theground pepper, garlic and paprika. Steam the fish over simmering water for 12 to 14 minutes, or until the fish is opaque and cooked through.
4. Line a serving platter with the lettuce leaves. When the snapper is done, remove to the serving platter. Surround with the cooked vegetables and garnish with the tomatoes.
Yield: Four to six servings.
Note: Avis Johnson-Piper's recipe calls for a whole red snapper, which has definite visual appeal. However, I've substituted red snapper filets, which I find easier to eat.
 
GROUNDNUT SOUP
 
(From "The African Cook Book" by Bea Sandler, Harvest House)
 
1 5 1/2 to 6 pound chicken, cut into eigths
 2 tablespoons salt, or to taste
 1 teaspoon pepper
 2 medium yellow onions, trimmed and peeled
 2 carrots, trimmed and peeled
 1 6-ounce can tomato paste
 8 ounces peanut butter
 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper
 1 teaspoon crushed red pepper
 2 tablespoons dry white wine.
1. Place the chicken in a large stock pot and cover with 2 quarts of water. Add the salt, pepper, onions and carrots. Simmer over medium heat for 45 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through. Remove the chicken, onion and carrot and reserve for other purposes.
2. Add the tomato paste, peanut butter (blended with a bit of the stock before you return it to the pot), cayenne and red pepper to the pot. Heat gently over low heat for 10 minutes, or until the oil rises to the top of the stock. Skim off the oil and cool to room temperature. Stir in the white wine. Chill thoroughly before serving.
Yield: About 10 cups.
 
BABATUNDE'S AFRICAN STEW
 
(From Norma Jean and Carole Darden)
 
2 chickens (about 3 1/2 pounds each) cut up
 Salt to taste
 1 large onion, chopped
 1 green pepper, seeded and chopped
 6 carrots, peeled and sliced
 Crushed red pepper to taste
 Freshly ground black pepper to taste
 2 8 ounce cans tomato sauce
 2 10-ounce packages frozen spinach, partially thawed.
 1. Wash the chicken and place it in an empty stock pot. Add salt to taste. Place over medium-low heat and cook for 10 minutes, covered (the chicken will make its own juice), stirring occassionally.
2. Add the onion, green pepper, carrot, crushed red pepper and black pepper. Cover and cook for an additional 10 minutes, or until the onion begins to wilt. Raise the heat to medium, add the tomato sauce and bring the mixture to a boil. Add the spinach. Bring to a boil again; cover and simmer over low heat, stirring occassionally, for about 1 hour, or until the meat is done and falling off the bone. Serve over rice.
Yield: Six servings.
 
SWEET POTATO SPOON CUSTARD
 
(From "Spoonbread and Strawberry Wine" by Norma Jean and Carole Darden, Fawcett)
 
1 cup mashed, cooked sweet potatoes (about 2 whole sweet potatoes)
 2 small bananas, mashed
 1 cup milk
 2 tablespoons brown sugar
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 2 egg yolks, beaten
 3 tablespoons seedless raisins
 1 teaspoon butter for the pan.
1. Preheat the oven to 300 degrees.
2. In a large bowl, combine the sweet potatoes and bananas. Add the milk and blend until smooth. Add the brown sugar, salt, egg yolks and raisins. Mix well and pour into a well-greased 1-quart casserole.
3. Place the casserole in a large baking pan. Add boiling water until it reaches halfway up the side of the casserole. Bake for 45 minutes, or until the custard is firm and golden brown.
Yield: Six to eight servings.
 
MATTIE CROSSLEY'S HOLIDAY PUNCH
 
4 cups boiling water
 4 bags cinnamon tea
 6 whole cloves
 4 cinnamon sticks
 1 teaspoon allspice
 4 cups cranberry juice
 4 cups apple cider
 4 cups ginger ale
 1/2 cup lemon juice
 1/2 cup brown sugar, or to taste.
Steep the tea bags in the boiling water for 5 minutes. Discard the bags and add the spices. Add the cranberry juice, cider, ginger ale, lemon juice and brown sugar.
Yield: Sixteen cups.

HEADLINE: Wine;
Brut Force

BYLINE: BY FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
JACK AND JAMIE Davies run Schramsberg Vineyards in the Napa Valley. They may make the best sparkling wine in California; they may be the prototypical let's-kick-this-affluent-but-empty-L. A.-life couple, and they may have their own little niche in history thanks to Zhou Enlai. But let James Conaway describe them in his book "Napa":
"He of the quizzical smile, she of the pale green, catlike eyes." And again: "Jamie, 30, wore her blond hair short. The breadth of her smile left people with the impression that they were talking to a taller person." 
 Conaway fell in love with the Davieses. They provide the opening leitmotif for his book because they were among the first of a new breed of wine makers in America. They were not farmers. Jack was a businessman educated at Harvard and Stanford; Jamie was a painter who'd grown up in affluent Pasadena. It was 1965, and the Davieses had embarked on the quintessential American 1960's quest for relevance, for challenge, for commitment. They found what they sought in a battered old winery. It came with a house (even more battered), some tired old vineyards and a few imposing caves that had once been used to keep aging wine cool. Backed by a group of partners, the Davieses crossed their fingers and bought the place.
The property had once been owned by a barber from San Francisco, named Jacob Schramm, who gave up his scissors to become a vintner. He built the old house and hired Chinese laborers to dig his caves. He called the place Schramsberg and, in the correct German style, called the wine Schramsberger. (Once he entertained Robert Louis Stevenson, who wrote admiringly about the place and the wine.)
But Jack Davies didn't want to make ordinary wine; he wanted to make Champagne. Sparkling wine was not new in Napa Valley, but sparkling wine made using the traditional painstaking techniques of the Champagne district in France was. And that's what the Davieses proposed to do.
Using the methode champenoise would mean handling each bottle individually -- adding sugar and yeast to still wine to induce a second fermentation, aging it, then removing the dead yeast cells before laying the bottles away for further aging. It would be all handwork at first, expensive and time-consuming, and some older hands in the valley advised against it. But Robert Mondavi, then still with his family at the Charles Krug Winery, was encouraging. He even sold Jack 500 gallons of chardonnay to make the first run of Schramsberg sparkling wine, the 1965 Blanc de Blancs.
The wine was good from the start, and soon had a solid, if limited, reputation. That changed in 1972, when Richard Nixon brought 13 cases of Schramsberg with him on his epochal journey to China and used it to toast Prime Minister Zhou Enlai. There must be 75 wineries producing methode champenoise sparkling wine in California now, but none, even the huge subsidiaries of the French Champagne houses, has ever dimmed Schramsberg's reputation.
Shramsberg makes five sparkling wines, all but one finished as brut. Brut is actually a technical term meaning extremely dry -- in other words, no sweetness at all. The four are Blanc de Blancs, made almost entirely from chardonnay grapes with a touch of pinot blanc; Blanc de Noirs, made mostly from pinot noir with some chardonnay; Reserve, which is also mostly pinot noir and is aged four years in the bottle, and Cuvee de Pinot, which is a rose made from pinot noir with a touch of gamay. The fifth wine is Cremant, a slightly sweeter, gentler wine with about half the natural effervescence of the others. It is made from the Flora grape, a variety developed at the University of California at Davis from, of all things, gewurztraminer and semillon grapes.
California wine makers thrive on challenge. Once, they were told they would never produce a good chardonnay. They did it. They were told they could never make a first-rate pinot noir. They did it. And they were told they could never match Champagne. Most producers still do not and probably never will, but a handful regularly do, and Schramsberg is one of them.
Stylistically, Schramsberg wines are fuller and richer than some of its serious competitors, inviting comparison with Champagne makers like Bollinger and Krug in France. For Bob Thompson, a wine writer, "Schramsberg is the wine for winter, when the fireplace is lighted and a hearty meal is coming, and the weather invites sober reflection on what might be in the glass to warm one's soul."
Slowly but surely, California wine makers have weaned themselves from the old European names. They no longer feel obliged to call a jug wine made from grenache and carignane "burgundy." In the same vein, most top sparkling wine producers avoid the use of the name Champagne -- but not the Davieses. They interpret Champagne as a generic term, and they use it freely on all their bottles.
Well, not quite all. They are actively seeking customers in Europe now, and European Economic Community rules say Champagne, upper case "C," is a wine that can be made only in Champagne. If it's not, then it's champagne, lower case "c."
Does it really matter? Probably not. As Bob Thompson once put it, "Can only a Cuban make a Cuban heel?"
