HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Operating in the Gap Between Art and Not Art

BYLINE: By Roberta Smith

 BODY:
The art world has no shortage of heated debates these days, and one whose temperature is rising concerns the definition of American art.
 Last summer's "Decade" exhibition, organized by three New York City museums, broadened the vision of American art of the 1980's to include high percentages of art by women, Hispanic and black artists. 
 From another direction there is an effort to bring folk art, long one of the most vital strains of American visual culture, more concretely into the mainstream. An exhibition planned for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 1992, with the working title "Parallel Visions: Modern Artists and Outsider Art" will tackle this subject by examining the way 20th-century artists in both America and Europe have been affected by the work of untrained artists.
 At the moment, the National Museum of American Art, in Washington, is jumping feet first into this debate with its exhibition "Made With Passion: The Hemphill Collection in the National Museum of American Art" (through Jan. 21). The exhibition, organized by Lynda Roscoe Hartigan, an associate curator at the museum, fills the enormous third-floor gallery with a cacophonous, pulsating melange of form, material and artistic expression -- folk art in every possible medium and at every level of refinement, from every period and every region.
 The show's 199 objects start with early 19th-century portraits and mourning pictures and sweep through American culture, right into the present. They cut across all ethnic and economic lines, and include work by American Indians and Eskimos, Hispanics, Southern blacks and whites, Midwestern eccentrics, residents of mental institutions. Included in its broad reach are paintings and drawings, shop signs and handmade gates, carved canes and painted furniture, larger-than-life tin figures and an unusually impressive pair of carved wood cigar-store Indians. Twenty-one of the artists represented are still alive.
The objects on view are among the 427 works that the National Museum has acquired, partly as a gift, partly as a purchase, from Herbert Wade Hemphill Jr. Mr. Hemp hill, 61, has been collecting for more than 30 years, and is perhaps the most influential postwar collector of American folk art.
 The National Museum is no stranger to folk art; it owns some 200 pre-Hemphill-Collection objects, including James Hampton's aluminum-foil, chapel-sized altar, "Throne of the Third Heaven of the Nations Millennium General Assembly," acquired nearly 20 years ago and on permanent display near the main entrance. Nor does the addition of the Hemphill Collection make much of a numerical dent in the museum's larger total of 35,000 objects.
 But the Hemphill addition symbolizes an important change of direction that should not be underestimated and that few other museums of American art have yet been willing to make. (The one exception is the Milwaukee Art Museum, which last spring acquired the 273-piece collection of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Hall, close friends of Mr. Hemphill's, which it will exhibit sometime in 1993.)
Simply comparing the catalogue for the Hemphill show with the 1985 catalogue of selections from the museum's permanent collection vividly illustrates the difference between American art as it has traditionally been defined and as it may come to be defined. The 1985 catalogue is dominated by skillfully rendered landscapes and portraits by such names as Cole, Catlin and Bierstadt. The Hemphill catalogue is full of energetic, awkwardly made work, mostly by artists whose names are unknown.
 Elizabeth Broun, director of the National Museum, thinks it is time for general-purpose museums, not only specialized museums of folk art, to "take into account the huge number of people who have had the urge toward visual expression and more or less made up the way they did it." She sees the Hemphill show and collection as the beginning of a concerted program to give the history of American art a completely new outline by treating the work of indigenous, untrained artists just as seriously as the work of artists trained according to largely European standards, in terms of acquisition, display, research and education programs.
 "Made with passion" may describe the show's best objects, but the phrase also sums up the formation of the collection itself. Possessed of an ecumenical and rather daring taste, Mr. Hemphill has collected folk art with something like a vengeance since 1956. The collector's Manhattan brownstone, crammed wall to wall and floor to ceiling with objects, has for years been a major mecca for folk art aficionados. Mr. Hemphill is often regarded as a visionary collector of visionary art, a man whom a friend described as having a "360-degree eye."
 His unusual accumulation, which still numbers more than 2,000 objects and continues to grow, has been praised for broadening the definition of folk art, moving beyond the tendency to see it primarily as a proto-modern phenomenon that presaged or influenced "regular" artists or, even more purely, to limit folk art to objects made mostly in New England before 1900. But the Hemphill Collection has also been criticized for its unwieldy, almost senseless breadth and unevenness of quality. Walking into this exhibition, it is entirely possible to understand both points of view.
 The historical revision that this exhibition marks is hardly seamlessly smooth or wholly successful, nor is it even easy to look at. In its sheer overcrowding the installation communicates some of the urgency that often motivates folk art. It also captures the tone of the teeming interiors and exteriors that many folk artists create for themselves. But it doesn't necessarily foster the best viewing conditions, or make the best case for folk art's historical importance.
 The boundlessness of Mr. Hemp hill's vision, his disregard for any kind of definition or hierarchy is everywhere apparent and at times a little bewildering. The show includes many traditional folk art items, like the stiffly dignified portrait of a woman named Huldy Martin painted in 1826 by a New England limner named Frederick Mayhew, and examples of mourning pictures (the small idyllic graveside images made to commemorate the death of a loved one), along with quilts and decoys. These objects, often tenderly made, can spring out at the visitor like familiar anchors in a storm.
 And, indeed, the eye is often buffeted from one unexpected and unsettling thing to another. Among the most garish items are several related to the circus, including a waxworks-like head of an Indian in a box and a carnival banner featuring a tattooed lady who looks like Jane Russell. Many of the most recent works, dating from the 1970's and 80's, do not always convince the viewer that folk art can extend infinitely into the future. In addition, Mr. Hemphill's eye for three-dimensional objects -- especially toys, whirligigs and other carved or constructed figures -- seems noticeably stronger than his eye for painting.
 Not everything on view deserves to be in a museum; at times the show has the feeling of an anthropological display or what museum professionals call a study collection, rather than a carefully culled group of works of the best possible quality. As Ms. Broun willingly acknowledges, the show raises many more questions than it answers.
 "We have a long way to go before we really understand the basis on which we make distinctions between fine and folk art," she says. "I think there may be a distinction, but it's not clear to us yet how we are separating the two." But within the show's extraordinary range are some powerful objects, and their interactions pinpoint many timely issues.
 In a sense this exhibition is an esthetic battlefield in which the various qualities attributed to folk art and, by extension, all art are vociferously argued. High art versus low art, or kitsch, or craft? Major versus minor? Skillful finish or mastery of form versus intuitively slapped-together crudeness? Every point of view finds a voice here.
 On the issue of refinement, for example, consider several intricately carved canes that are among the show's high points, especially one covered with figures and animals and on which each little stub, instead of being whittled smooth, has been carved into an animal's head.
For so-called crudeness at its best, turn to "Man on a Hog," part of a mechanical tableau built by a Connecticut farmer named Clark Coe for his grandchildren in the 1890's. Carved and carpentered from several pieces of wood and dabbed with paint, it is one of several figures in the exhibition whose initial awkwardness gradually yields rewarding subtleties of both form and spirit.
A similar change occurs with Harold Garrison's "Water Gate or Government Machine No. 3" from 1974. Perhaps best described as a tableau on a stick, this amalgam of carved figures and written commentary recount the details of the Watergate saga.
 Some paintings and sculptures speak of autonomous, fully developed visions that seem original or major by any standards -- for example, the drifting, floating Madonna with a Statue of Liberty crown made in the late 1950's by Martin Ramirez, an uneducated Mexican laborer who spent most of his life in a California state mental hospital. While Ramirez left a large body of work -- some 200 drawings were preserved by one of his doctors and discovered in Sacramento in 1970 by the Chicago Imagist painter Jim Nutt -- many artists are less fortunate.
 The only known surviving work by Alice Eugenia Ligon is a muslin hospital gown densely embroidered with images and messages, made as a Christmas present for her children while she was a patient at a Missouri mental institution. It is one of several works on view that vigorously transcend the line between art and craft.
 It is no wonder that a 1978 portrait of Herbert Wade Hemphill by the Rev. Howard Finster identifies him as the "man who preserves the lone and forgotten." To walk through this exhibition is to grasp with full force both the resilience of the human impulse to create, however eccentrically or sporadically, and the frailty of these creations -- how easily they can be lost, passed over by time, and erased. Finally, in its astounding and sometimes confusing diversity, the Hemphill Collection challenges its visitors to embrace a freedom similar to that taken by the artists themselves, and that is the independent, unrestricted exercise of their individual tastes and preferences.

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
You Can't Make Book On Movies

BYLINE: By Janet Maslin

 BODY:
We have the good luck now to be inundated with films adapted from serious works of fiction (a big improvement over those that originate as two-sentence story ideas very late at night). However, this luck has its limits. Not every lean, minor noir novel becomes a diamond-hard classic on the order of "The Grifters." Not every tragedy of manners takes on the verve and delicacy of "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge." Some books, most notably Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities," can fall prey to the directorial equivalent of hit-and-run driving.
Brian De Palma's enthusiastic mauling of Mr. Wolfe's keenly observed book is only the latest reminder, although quite a pungent one, of how far afield a film adaptation can go. With a screenplay by Michael Cristofer, who blithely gutted and rearranged John Updike's "Witches of Eastwick" with similar abandon, this "Bonfire of the Vanities" unabashedly jettisons much of Mr. Wolfe's story and just about all of his style. "You are cheap and rotten and a liar, and you are dripping on my Aubusson carpet!" cries the irate wife of Mr. Wolfe's hero, thus offering some measure of the film's flair for social satire. 
 Indeed, by the standards of anyone who imagines that a film adaptation owes at least some small debt to it source material, this "Bonfire of the Vanities" could serve as a dictionary definition of "author's nightmare." (Mr. Wolfe has somehow managed to remain mum about this. But if he ever feels inclined to look at movie making with the same sharp eye he cast upon Sherman McCoy, this novel's Park Avenue paragon, he will doubtless have a lot to work with.) Mr. De Palma's film is as coarse, broad and casually irreverent as its narrator, the drunken tabloid journalist Peter Fallow (Bruce Willis), who grabs and throws a handful of salmon in his opening scene.
When a book is as freely mangled as this one has been, even the elements that are left unchanged take on different import. Mr. Wolfe's abundant thoughts on the social, cultural and racial differences separating New York City's many strata have necessarily been narrowed down, but so has everything else about this story; as a result, the slurs and ster eotypes are much more glaring here than they were on the page. Scatological gags, of which Mr. De Palma seems especially fond, also leap out with disproportionate emphasis.
And the cynicism of this story, in which a wealthy white bond trader (surprisingly well played by Tom Hanks, though he seemed from afar to have been grievously miscast) strays into the South Bronx in his Mercedes and becomes involved in a hit-and-run accident that injures a young black man, has been made to seem much greater. In part, this is a result of the film makers' own sloppiness. No pious speech about decency and racial harmony, like the regrettable one foisted upon Morgan Freeman (playing a judge) in the film's closing courtroom scene, can make up for the film's carelessness. It never quite remembers to tell its audience whether the accident victim lives or dies.
If these sound like fatal flaws, they may well be for anyone expecting to see Mr. Wolfe's book gracefully transferred to the screen. However, Mr. De Palma's brazenly comedic approach does deserve a little credit. As with the equally hair-raising "Witches of Eastwick," this is a literary adaptation tailored to the tastes of a sub-literate audience, a version that aims low but does sometimes hit its mark. At least, in reducing a novel of nearly 700 pages, the film makers have distilled something that vaguely coheres on its own obnoxious terms, and that isn't hopelessly fragmented or dull. Many a loftier literary adaptation has failed to achieve the crude, lively impact of this one.
In fact, in its way this "Bonfire of the Vanities" makes a shade more sense than "The Russia House," directed edgily by Fred Schepisi and based on the novel by John le Carre. No original screenplay, no matter how quick-witted or abbreviated, would ever attempt to compress as much minor data as Tom Stoppard crams so confusingly into his adaptation. Nor would an original screenwriter concentrate so heavily on aphorisms and clever rejoinders at the expense of simple background information or transitional material, too much of which Mr. Stoppard has pared away.
Mr. le Carre's many readers are apt to find this economy gratifying at times. But it will be possible for viewers unfamiliar with his novel to watch the entire film without being sure what its title means, or where certain scenes are taking place or even precisely what is at stake. This adaptation's excessive density violates the most basic precept of bringing works of fiction to the screen: they must be freestanding. No audience should have to do its homework in order to watch a work of popular entertainment.
As the James Ivory-Ismail Merchant-Ivory-Ruth Prawer Jhabvala "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge" makes clear, a film can greatly abbreviate or alter the work upon which it is based without truly losing ground. This exceptionally skillful adaptation blends Evan S. Connell's two novels, softens their viewpoint and even changes a crucial aspect of its story's ending without violating the spirit of its material. Mr. Connell is at times more openly critical of his characters' small-mindedness, but the film prefers to make its point more gently. Helped tremendously by the sad and humanizing performances of Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward in the title roles, the film adopts a rueful, lulling tone and makes it work.
If "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge" remains slightly superior to its characters, and if its decorous good looks are at times overwhelming, these attitudes at least have a purpose in relation to the material. They never leap out to announce the literariness or detachment of the endeavor, as does the presence of Paul Bowles in Bernardo Bertolucci's mesmerizing version of Mr. Bowles's "Sheltering Sky." Seated watchfully in a North African cafe, asking a cosmic question of his story's heroine, Mr. Bowles serves as a reminder of the film's origins -- and quite an extraneous reminder, given the film's unmistakably literary voice.
For all its visual beauty and its skill in expressing emotion in visual terms, "The Sheltering Sky" could never be confused with a work imagined solely for the screen. Too much is missing; too much is ineffable; too much sends a viewer back to the page. Only Mr. Bowles's writing supplies the real essence of his characters' anomie; what Mr. Bertolucci dwells on instead is the world-weary glamour that accompanies such a hauntingly desolate spirit.
 In the universe of the novel, no detail is trivial; even the smoking of a cigarette can become a metaphor for the human condition. ("The first few puffs it tastes wonderful, and you don't even think of its ever being used up," says the book's nihilistic hero. "Then you begin taking it for granted. Suddenly you realize it's nearly burned down to the end. And then's when you're conscious of the bitter taste.") There is, of course, a visual equivalent to such brooding scrutiny, but the film is often too arch and scenic to achieve it.
By comparison, Stephen Frears's "Grifters" grasps and distills its characters' attitudes so sharply that it seems a bigger work than Mr. Bertolucci's eye-filling epic. Although "The Grifters" has been faithfully adapted by Donald Westlake, the toughness of Jim Thompson's brief, hard-boiled novel is given a much greater complexity on the screen. The smallest strokes here, particularly in the ways that the three principal roles are acted, can make great differences in how these characters are ultimately perceived.
This film's stunningly cruel ending, with Anjelica Huston at the crest of an unforgettable performance, is hugely enhanced by one tiny adjustment in Mr. Thompson's dialogue. It's a change that turns an inhuman monster into a pitiablyreal one. And it's a change that underscores how far beyond the written word a genuinely inspired screen adaptation can go.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Coalition Sees Unfair Edge by Nonprofit Groups

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
A COALITION of businesses, hurt by the recession, is battling to prohibit nonprofit organizations from selling travel, among other things, in competition with the private sector.
The coalition argument, which is being directed at state legislators nationwide, is that nonprofit organizations have a built-in competitive advantage over tour operators and travel agents because they receive tax exemptions, use volunteer labor and pay less postage. 
 In addition, the coalition cites a "halo effect" that allows nonprofit organizations like churches, universities and museums to trade on "public assumption of a lofty purpose." Examples might be a church-sponsored tour of the Holy Land or a museum-led tour of art in Italy.
Theresa Stanion, the director of the group, the Business Coalition for Fair Competition, in Washington, said in an interview, "The truth is that many of our members, small businesses, have been put out of business by nonprofits' competition."
Thomas R. Frenkel, vice president of Presley Tours in Makanda, Ill., said, "A church in my town operates tours that look like my tours." He added that the tours can be offered for 20 percent less because of the church's nonprofit advantage. Mr. Frenkel is the new president of the National Tour Association, a founder and moving force in the coalition, made up of three dozen trade associations ranging from the United States Chamber of Commerce and the American Society of Travel Agents to the National Association of Retail Druggists and the American Association of Nurserymen.
At the high end of the price spectrum, tours offered by large museums and universities, which may have special features, can cost a lot more than the same tour sold by a travel agent or tour company.
For example, the Center for the Study of Southern Culture at the University of Mississippi is offering a seven-night cruise in April on the Delta Queen, going from Memphis to New Orleans. The historians Alex Haley and Shelby Foote and the jazz musicians Mose Allison and B. B. King will be on board to speak and perform. Land tours are included as is a stay at the Peabody Hotel in Memphis the first night. The charge for one person in a two-person cabin on D Deck is $2,850. The regular seven-night trip in such a cabin is $1,790, including meals and entertainment but not shore excursions or celebrity speakers, according to Patti Young of the Delta Queen management. P.V.A. Travel Planning and Management, the commercial organization that put together the sold-out trip, said the cruise would yield a little over $11,000 for the cultural center, which also has overhead.
Model Bill Drafted
The Business Coalition for Fair Competition moved its campaign to the states after it failed to persuade Congress and the Treasury Department to take action. Neither Ms. Stanion nor Mr. Frenkel could offer a dollar estimate of how much business their members were losing to nonprofit agencies. Everyone agrees that the offering of tours by nonprofit groups has been on the rise, sharply so in the last five years.
The coalition is now offering a model bill for the states. The bill's stated intent is "to provide additional economic opportunities to private industry and to regulate competition by government agencies and public institutions of higher education."
It would do so by requiring that "if government agencies and public institutions of higher education engage in sales of goods or services at retail, such sales shall not be for less than the costs that would be borne by persons making similar sales in the private sector."
If passed by the states, consumers would find a reduction in tour choices or price increases in nonprofit agencies' tours.
The coalition's hopes were high for Michigan to adopt the measure, but earlier this month the state Attorney General ruled that the bill might violate the state constitution's provision for independence of state universities. The coalition, now waiting for legislatures to reconvene, said that a bill had been prefiled in Wyoming.
The likelihood of passage in any state is difficult to assess. The coalition is optimistic. In a recent mailing to members, it said, "Well-organized plans exist in at least a dozen states," including Arizona, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Ohio, New York, Texas and Washington.
A Question of Equal Footing
Spokesmen for the tour association, with 600 bus tour operators and travel agency members, say they seek a level playing field with nonprofit organizations. In addition to legislative action, one way they want the field leveled is through firmer application of a Federal tax that parallels the corporate income tax. This tax, the Unrelated-Business Income Tax, applies to nonprofit groups' gains from selling goods or services unrelated to the group's primary mission.
In this category, the coalition cites sales of computers by universities, sales of hearing aids by hospitals or operation of health clubs by Y organizations. They also point to trips sold by alumni groups and museums.
The former president of the National Tour Association, George Guenther, who is president of Talmage Tours of Philadelphia, said that the campaign was spurring collection of taxes from the nonprofits. "In 1985," he said, "before we started beating the drums on this, 2,500 companies filed the Unrelated-Business Income Tax form, and they paid a tax of $30 million. In 1987, 7,000 companies reported unrelated-business income and they paid $137 million."
The question of whether the travel is tied to the mission of the nonprofit group is crucial. A big tour operator that puts together packages for such clients as the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the Harvard alumni, the Yale alumni and the Art Institute of Chicago says the organizations' travel programs always tie into their overall mission. "We never go to the beach," said Miki Adams, assistant director of marketing for the agency Academic Travel Abroad in Washington. "We would go to Leningrad and study art and architecture there or a topic directly related to the mission of the organization."
Ms. Adams said alumni tours were accompanied by a faculty member who would give lectures. William Ferris, director of the Center for the Study of Southern Culture, said that the Delta Queen cruise was another step in his group's effort to take education outside academic walls and made the study of Southern culture accessible.
In its statement of purpose, the business coalition says, "Unfair competition results when a tax-exempt organization -- a nonprofit group or government-subsidized agency -- sells goods and services, on a frequent and ongoing basis, using its special privileges. The organization does not use for-profit intermediaries to market its goods and services; rather it sells similar products to compete directly with private, for-profit businesses."
Elaborating on this, John Hawkes, a spokesman for the tour association, said that the target was not groups like the National Trust that use for-profit tour packagers. "If they can expand the total field of tourism, we have no problem with them," he said. Rather, he said, it is small-town senior citizen groups, youth agencies, churches and the like that put together tours themselves and offer them to the public -- not just their members.
But Mr. Guenther, the former president of the tour operators, is not so easily placated because he is concerned not just with the process of assembling the tour, but with its selling. In this, he says, the nonprofit groups compete with retail travel agents; 60 percent of the tour group's members are also travel agents. He referred to the tours offered by the 92d Street Y, which BatiaPlotch of the Y said were run by profit-making tour operators. "She is an unfair competitor as a travel agent," Mr. Guenther said.
Several representatives of big nonprofit groups said that they doubted that their use of commercial tour operators would deflect an attack by the coalition. One officer who preferred not to be named said that it was probably easier politically to set up a big, visible target like the Smithsonian than to say the target was the local senior citizens center.
Bryan DeLeo, director of study tours for the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a nonprofit agency that offers tours, said, "It is ironic that members of the coalition would prefer to criticize institutions that offer high-quality educational travel programs rather than endeavor to provide tours of comparable quality themselves."

HEADLINE: Two Classic Resorts Face the Future

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD; ROBERT REINHOLD is head of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
ON the Mexican Riviera, this is a season of transition and renewal, a winter of uncertainty in paradise. In Puerto Vallarta, the once sleepy fishing village that first gained fame and Hollywood stars when Tennessee Williams's tale of decadence, "Night of the Iguana," was filmed nearby nearly 30 years ago, the talk among the American expatriates is whether the time-share industry will be the ruin of their tropical hideaway. A favorite hangout, the bar at the old Oceano Hotel, is gone now, turned into apartments and shops. Elizabeth Taylor has finally sold her dilapidated house in Gringo Gulch. It is to be converted into a bed-and-breakfast. Three weeks ago, Ava Gardner's aged beachboy lover, who played a skin diver in the movie, died.
Four hundred miles to the southeast, frenetic Acapulco, the now-faded grande dame of Mexican beach resorts, finally realized it was driving away tourists and responded by banishing peddlers and time-share salespeople from the beaches and streets. It has been cleaning up its polluted waters and filthy beaches and streets and sending out a squad of earnest young bilingual helpers to protect visitors against dishonest taxi drivers and restaurateurs. A mammoth new resort area is under construction on Diamond Point, just east of Acapulco Bay, and already the most fashionable restaurants and discotheques are moving toward it. And soon a new superhighway from Mexico City will open, bringing a much needed boost from affluent Mexican visitors. 
 These are difficult times for Acapulco, and even for Puerto Vallarta, the two classic winter resorts that pioneered the concept of the fleshy tropical beach getaway a generation ago. Now they find themselves hard-pressed to compete in a world of planned mega-resorts like Cancun and Ixtapa, not to mention Hawaii and the Caribbean. Both have suffered drastic drops in the number of visitors in the last few years, shocking local authorities and hoteliers into action to repair the effects of years of excessive unplanned growth and urban neglect.
It may be that time has irrevocably passed them by as vacationers seek the next new destination. But their bayside settings are as magnificent as ever, the climate nearly perfect, and unlike sterile remote Cancun, Acapulco and Puerto Vallarta -- each in its own very different way -- offer a close-up look at the reality of Mexican life and its warm-hearted people. Not least in this day of $250 hotel rooms, both are bargains. It is possible to find a pleasant room on or near the beach for $75 or even less, for two people to eat well for $35, including a bottle of excellent Mexican wine, and to taxi from one end of town to the other for $3.
 Acapulco's crescent-shaped bay lined with fine sand beaches first began to attract the rich and famous after World War II when European travel was difficult. It later became a premier jet-set winter resort, with its huge throbbing discos, all-night dancing, beautiful people, hustlers and fashionable boutiques. Some locals say the jet-set crowd still comes to Acapulco, but they mostly stay to themselves now in rented villas in the Las Brisas area on the hill just east of town. The old Acapulco along the Costera Miguel Aleman, the strip, has been largely turned over to the package tour vistors, Kentucky Fried Chicken, Pizza Hut and Big Boy. The shrinking number of visitors is still 70 percent American, along with budget travelers from Canada, Germany, France and, increasingly, Japan.
The decline was a paradoxical product of Acapulco's success. With little agriculture or industry, the Mexican state of Guerrero depends on tourism for 70 percent of its income, mainly from Acapulco. So a huge unplanned and chaotic city of 2 million has grown up behind the hotel zones to service, and sometimes prey on, the visitors. "We became a city instead of only a resort," said Eduardo F. Saenz Viesca, the Minister of Tourism Development for the State of Guerrero. "A big city with all the problems of a big city."
Uncontrolled development overwhelmed water-treatment facilities and hotels began dumping their raw sewage directly into the bay. Every heavy rain brought a cascade of trash and dead rats from the mountains above the beaches into the waters. Beggars and peddlers selling everything from serapes to fraudulent time-share deals descended on the beach daily in such numbers that it was impossible to nap without being woken up every five minutes. Many tourists retreated to the safety of hotel pools.
But this year, a $300 million government program to rejuvenate Acapulco has begun to take effect. New sewage collection and treatment systems have reduced contamination of the bay and, according to Mr. Saenz, the waters are "absolutely safe" for swimming, and this recent visitor swam in the sea without apparent ill effect.
 But many a resident and tourist remains skeptical, and with good reason, according to Jorge Gonzalez Torres, president of the Ecological Alliance in Mexico City. "The sea is still very polluted," he said. "The whole shoreline of Acapulco Bay is polluted. Yes, they've built a sewage treatment center and collectors, but 50 percent of the time they're not working. They just aren't capable of doing the job. There is still drainage from hotels and buildings directly into the ocean and many small rivers that discharge into the bay, bringing filthy water and sewage down from the mountains where the poor people live. I would recommend that no one enter the water anywhere in Acapulco. There are many cases of skin and ear infections."
Nearly all 2,500 peddlers have been removed from the Costera and the beaches under a new law and either relocated to one of three government-constructed flea markets or given jobs or job-training. For now, at least, visitors can walk or sun on the beaches almost unharassed.
A private consortium of hotel, restaurant and disco owners has bought hundreds of yellow-painted dumpsters, as well as street sweepers, trucks and vacuums; a squad of nearly 60 sanitation workers patrols the hotel zone. Traps have been placed over drainage ditches to keep trash off the beach. Once ugly concrete walls along the Costera have been painted in striped pastels, and new walkways providing access to beaches, have been opened, along with public showers and toilets. A government agency has taken over the rental of all the chairs and umbrellas on the beaches and plans this winter to illuminate all the beaches at night.
In addition, the state Government's tourist assistance bureau has been beefed up. Bilingual assistants patrol the hotel zone, beaches and other tourist spots, and they are authorized to intervene on behalf of visitors in case of disputes with taxi drivers, merchants or restaurateurs.
 For all these improvements, Acapulco is literally fleeing itself, moving east. The new resort area called Punta Diamante, or Diamond Point, now being built occupies a 30-square-mile peninsula just southeast of old Acapulco. It is meant to be Acapulco's answer to Cancun, a lavish masterplanned community. In all, there will be about 5,200 hotel rooms and 1,000 condominium apartments, plus golf courses, tennis courts and other amenities, the first opening early next year. The idea is to create a so-called destination resort like the splendid 1,000-room Acapulco Princess Hotel nearby on Revolcadero Beach.
 More adventurous visitors who walk from the Costera hotel zone through the serene Papagayo Park, with its ponds and aviary, arrive downtown and plunge into the wonders and horrors of everyday Mexican life, lived mostly on the chaotic streets. Trucks and buses roar by as Indian women sell every type of nut and fruit; two cheerful street urchins with a bathroom scale offer your weight for 17 cents; an American woman shrieks as a thief on the trot snaps off her necklace and darts down an alley.
 In the main square, the zocalo, where local people socialize under shade trees, stands the city's main church, Nuestra Senora de la Soledad, an imposing whitewashed building with colorful bulbous spires. In nearby side streets, the small restaurants serve such local specialties as iguana soup. There are many fine old buildings and there is some talk in government circles of creating an artists' enclave here with studios and exhibitions. "Regardless of what humans have done to it," said Jose Ruiz, a Mexico City civil engineer who advises the Guerrero state government, "there are great values associated with Old Acapulco."
In Puerto Vallarta, where a sprawling town has grown around the old fishing village, the perennial question on the Bahia de Banderas, with its cobblestoned streets and whitewashed buildings, is this: "Is Puerto Vallarta becoming another Acapulco?" The short answer is no, but it is trying hard. The number of hotel rooms has tripled to 13,000 since 1975. On the road north of town, toward the airport, there is now a Domino's Pizza and a Pizza Hut; in the big new shopping mall at the nearby marina, a Denny's, Woolworth's and a McDonald's.
Despite all that, Puerto Vallarta retains much of the charm and color that have drawn thousands of expatriates over the years, including such Hollywood celebrities as John Huston, Richard Burton and Ms. Taylor and Ms. Gardner. Most of the new resort and hotel development has occurred either north or south of town, or just across the Nayarit state line in Nuevo Vallarta, leaving the old village itself, which hugs jungle-clad mountains, with less of Acapulco's gross commercial excesses.
 Puerto Vallarta is much smaller and quieter, and less assertive. While vendors are still permitted on the beach, they are neither very numerous nor overly aggressive. Taxi drivers rarely try to cheat their clients, and a tourist can walk virtually unnoticed along the malecon (seawall) and through the town's narrow streets, except for the time-share salesmen. They operate from tiny booths carved out of building facades, usually pretending to offer free tourist advice or jeep rentals at an impossibly low $5 a day.
Long-time residents like Maria Alexander, a Texan, and Bill Chappell, an advertising art director from Los Angeles, recall Puerto Vallarta in 1962 when it was little more than a village of 6,000 with two taxis, open sewers, no phones and no access by road. In less than three decades it has grown into a bustling town of 150,000, swollen by 30,000 visitors on any given day during the high season. The movie stars still come, ensconcing themselves in lavish rented villas in the fashionable Conchas Chinas residential area just south of town. But Puerto Vallarta today is a destination for holidaymakers with varied budgets. They seem to come principally from California, the West and Midwest, but there are growing contingents of Europeans and Japanese. A new superhighway under construction from Guadalajara will make it more accessible to Mexicans who, hoteliers say, are already beginning to replace some of the lost American visitors. For the most part, visitors seem to seek a quieter, more romantic and Mexican experience than those who go to Acapulco, though Puerto Vallarta offers plenty of opportunity to dance till dawn.
 Puerto Vallarta has begun to ask if it is being spoiled, as Acapulco was. High rise hotels and condominiums with a vaguely Moroccan look have sprung up along the beaches downtown, far outpacing sewer capacity, and contamination of the bay has become an urgent concern.
The local director of the Jalisco and Federal tourist office, Gabriel Igartua Sanchez, maintained that the pollution problem has now been "controlled" by the opening of a new sewage treatment plant; two more are to open by next March. He added that the bay, unlike Acapulco Bay, is very large and therefore "flushes itself." Tourists "can be very confident the water is good to swim in," Mr. Igartua said, issuing a verdict not entirely accepted by visitors or local people.
 Mr. Gonzalez of the Ecological Alliance advised caution. "They still have a serious problem with pollution but it's not as bad as Acapulco," he said. "I'd say the water in the Puerto Vallarta bay is contaminated 30 to 40 percent of the time. The treatment plants are not big enough and are also broken down half the time. Hotels still have drainage into the bay. I'd say there are places in Puerto Vallarta where you could go swimming with little risk, maybe up around Nuevo Vallarta."
 But certainly the larger threat to Puerto Vallarta is the scourge of the time share. Forbidden to solicit prospects on the street, operators of these buildings are now willing to pay $500 a month rent to post their salespeople in cubicles facing the busy tourist streets, from which they shout to passers-by. The rents have driven out restaurants and shops , and already the cubicles have obliterated much of President Diaz Ordaz Street.
"We have to do something to guarantee people the right to walk the streets freely," Mr. Igartua said, adding that the authorities were considering imposing heavy fines for harassing visitors. Time- share operators have also taken to providing attractive young "hostesses" to restaurants for free. After she seats you and befriends you with cheerful banter comes the pitch. One restaurant has a sign out front: "Open -- No Time Share." The assistance bureau on the ground floor of City Hall gets more complaints about time-share deceptions than anything else.
Still, Puerto Vallarta remains an attractive destination, with its narrow cobbled streets, lined with interesting and off-beat shops, and bars and restaurants from which to watch a rich red sun set over the Pacific Ocean.
 
WHAT IT COSTS TO LODGE AND DINE IN TWO RESORTS
 
Acapulco
All prices are in United States dollars, but with the slow devaluation (80 centavos a day) of the Mexican peso and inflation they could fluctuate a bit. Hotel rates are for high season, generally Dec. 20 through April 20; after that they drop by about 30 percent.
While some hotels have toll-free 800 numbers in the United States, it is often worth calling direct to get a better rate.
HOTELS. Las Brisas, on a hill overlooking the bay, boasts 250 swimming pools. Each of the bungalows has a small one. Room with shared pool is $200, plus $20 service charge in lieu of tips; with private pool, $285. 5255 Carretera Escenica; telephone (748) 415-80 or (800) 228-3000 in the United States.
The Villa Vera provides seclusion in the hills hectic Acapulco, with 80 villas and rooms, swim- up bar surrounded by palm trees and a jacuzzi that holds 40 people. The daily room rate is $120. 35 Lomas del Mar; (748) 4-03-33 or (800) 223-6510.
The Acapulco Plaza, with more than 1,000 mostly cramped rooms right on the Costera, is convenient to all the shops and action if a bit noisy; $155 until Jan. 3, then $125 until March 31. 123 Costera Miguel Aleman; (748) 5-9050 or (800) 465-4329.
The Copacabana in the Pink Zone, a high rise, is $100 until Jan. 1, then $75 through March 30. 2 Tabachines; (748) 4-31-55 or (800) 562-0197.
La Palapa, rising 30 stories on the beach, is $86. 210 Fragata Yucatan; (748) 4-53-63.
RESTAURANTS. The Kookaburra is the newest local favorite, with an immaculate whitewashed terrace high on a hill and views of the bay and city. It offers steaks and seafood, like filet of sole in nuts and pecan cream sauce. Dinner for two, including wine and a tip for flawless service, was $62.35. Carretera Escenica near Las Brisas Hotel; (748) 4-44-18, dinner only.
Madeiras, an old standby nearby, is warmly lit and spread out over terraces overlooking the crescent-shaped bay. The four-course, fixed price menu is $24.40 a person. Bill for two including a fine cabernet sauvignon from Baja California came to $76 with tip. Carretera Escenica; (748) 4-4378, dinner only.
El Zorrito is the place for a more authentically Mexican dining experience favored by local people and Mexican vacationers. It is a big casual open-air cafe on the Costera. Recommended are a bowl of pozole, a traditional soupy stew of hominy with chicken and vegetables ($2.45), or the usual enchiladas and fish dishes. The check for two, including service and wine, was $16. Costera Miguel Aleman near the Acapulco Dorado bus stop.
El Amigo Miguel is another favorite of local people. There are two branches on either side of Calle Benito Juarez two blocks west of the zocalo. A lunch of broiled red snapper and broiled shrimp in garlic sauce came to $21.30, including Negra Modelo dark beer and a Yoli soft drink.
Or drive about 20 miles south along the coast to the village of Barra Vieja, where about half a dozen beachside restaurants serve food that belies the crude surroundings of picnic tables in the sand under palapas. The specialty here is huachinango a la talla, or grilled red snapper marinated in a red chile sauce. No menus, so establish the price in advance. We let down our guard and paid too much.
ASSISTANCE. It's worth beginning your visit to Acapulco by stopping by the Tourist Assistance Bureau, which operates from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. daily from an office on the Costera in front of the Convention Center (telephone 44416 or 44583). The staff dispenses cheerful advice on local customs to protect visitors from being cheated.
 
 Puerto Vallarta
HOTELS. Garza Blanca, 4.5 miles south of town, is a pleasant elegant retreat on a hillside by the beach. Beachfront suites are $225, less for other locations. Carretera a Barra de Navidad; (322) 2-10-23 or (800) 331-0908.
Buganvilias Sheraton is a spacious well-run resort complex within walking distance of downtown, and it has two large pools; $135. 999 Carretera Aeropuerto; (322) 2-30-00 or (800) 325-3535.
The Quinta Maria Cortez may suit those looking for the offbeat. This is a guesthouse on the beach with just six large suites designed by the Texan host, Maria Alexander, Silver to friends, and eclectically decorated. Rates are $65 to $130 plus service. Playa Conchas Chinas; (322) 2-11-84 or 2-1317.
The Buenaventura is a bargain on the beach at the edge of downtown. There are 210 rooms and 4 suites. Rates are $68, including tax. 1302 Avenida Mexico; (322) 2-37-37 or (800) 878-4484 or (800) 223-6764.
Hotel Molino de Agua, in the heart of downtown, is a shaded compound of bungalows in a coconut grove beside the Rio Cuale, at $40. Corner of Ignacio Vallarta and Aquiles Serdan Streets; (322) 2-19-57 or (800) 826-9408.
Hotel Playa Conchas Chinas is 1.5 miles south of town, with 40 suites facing the ocean. Rates are $63, tax included. Carretera a Barra de Navidad; (322) 2-01056.
RESTAURANTS. Le Bistro is probably the most beautiful restaurant in Puerto Vallarta, with tables under banana trees and palms on a deck over the gurgling Rio Cuale, but the setting is better than the food. A forgettable meal for two came to $66.75 with tip and wine. 16A Isla Rio Cuale; (322) 2-02-83.
Santos is a new restaurant near Los Muertos Beach where the owner, Santos Atzin, presides over four tables under coconut palms on the street and a pleasant white dining room inside. A fish filet Veracruzana was $7.50. Total tab for two with drinks and tip was $32.60. 136 Francisca Rodriguez; no phone, dinner only.
Archie's Wok, next door, is where John Huston's former chef serves passable Asian food, like Thai coconut fish at $8.55 and barbecue ribs at $7.15. 130 Francisca Rodriguez; (322) 204-11.
The Chef Roger restaurant has a Swiss chef who attempts innovations with fresh Mexican ingredients in a pleasant courtyard setting. A salad with warm shrimp was $8.55 at lunch. 267 Agustin Rodriguez; (322) 2-06-04.
Franzi Cafe, a nice place for breakfast, has a pleasant outdoor setting on the river, where scrambled eggs with ground beef, spinach, mushrooms, cheeses and spices was $4.50. On the Isla Rio Cuale, at bottom of steps at new bridge; no phone.
DISTRACTIONS. The two hottest discos these days are Christine (2-69-90), in the Krystal Vallarta Hotel, and Cactus (2-60-77), at 399 Ignacio Vallarta Street.
The resort has developed a healthy art scene, with galleries selling both contemporary Mexican artists like Alejandro Colunga and Sergio Bustamante and indigenous masks and other objects by the Nahua and Huichol Indians. For contemporary art, the leading galleries are Fitzpatrick de Gooyer (2-19-82) at 589 Morelos, Galeria Pacifico (2-67-68), 519 Juarez, and Galeria Sergio Bustamante (2-11-29), 275 Juarez. Best shops for indigenous art are across the river. -- R. R.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: MEXICO (95%); UNITED STATES (79%); CARIBBEAN ISLANDS (79%); 

STATE: HAWAII, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory

Alpine Resorts Revel in Snow, For a Change
The snowstorms that brought havoc to Europe's highways this month have had at least one happy side effect: after four consecutive warm winters, the storms have dumped heaps of snow on ski slopes in the Alps. Early in December, almost simultaneously with reports of 100-car pile-ups on superhighways because of ice and fog, heavy snow blanketed the mountains of Germany, Austria and Italy. Then France and Switzerland also reported enough snow to open the season early and to insure a good Christmas for skiers. After a series of indifferent winters, Alpine resorts are looking forward to a busy one.
The Suddeutscher Zeitung, published in Munich, reported in mid-December that almost all the Alpine ski areas had snow depths of 25 inches or more on slopes a mile high and between 15 and 25 inches on runs down into the valleys. Ski towns and hotels said that reservations were pouring in and many places were quickly sold out for Christmas. But a survey of some resorts turned up available rooms through the month of January and good chances of finding space in February and March.
Responding to inquiries, a skiing instructor in Lech, Austria, said, "12 to 38 inches and snowing heavily." In Corvara in Badia, Italy: "We have enough to last until Easter" (12 to 48 inches), and in Zermatt, Switzerland: "30 inches on top and more snow predicted today."
In the French Alps -- where many ski resorts were obliged to offer tennis, bicycling, hiking and other summer activities to winter vacationers last season -- snow started coming down in November and held to the slopes. Then came heavy snowfalls the second week of December that forced the temporary closure of some passes leading to resort areas and of the Mont Blanc Tunnel to Italy. High-altitude resorts like Val d'Isere and Tignes opened their slopes in November, earlier than scheduled, and places lower down, like Les Contamines, opened on weekends. Chamonix, at medium elevation, reported 45 inches of snow on its slopes. Most French resorts open officially this weekend.
 
Rome Gallery In First Show
An art gallery that opened this month in Rome's Palazzo Ruspoli, once a bank, is presenting an exhibition entitled "Expressionism: Masterpieces from the Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection from van Gogh to Klee." The exhibition, organized by the Memmo Foundation, part owner of the palace, contains 47 paintings representative of early 20th-century movements preceding Expressionism and associated with van Gogh, Chagall, Kirchner, Kandinsky and Schiele. It is the first of three exhibitions planned within a year at the Palazzo Ruspoli Art Gallery, which includes a conference room, cafeteria and gift shop.
The palace, about 100 yards from the Spanish Steps, is an attraction in itself. Built in the 16th century for the Florentine merchant and patron of the arts Orazio Rucellai, it houses frescoes by Jacopo Zucchi, a pupil of the Renaissance master Vasari.
The address is 418 Via del Corso (telephone, 6832177 or 6832179). The exhibition continues through the end of February; hours are 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. every day (until 11 P.M. on Saturdays). Admission is about $9.

As the European Community moves toward integration as a single domestic market in 1992, work has begun on expansion projects designed to more than double the capacity of the Brussels National Airport
 
Hotel Discounts In Three Cities
New York hotels and bargains may sound contradictory, but a discount service called Express Hotel Reservations says that on average it obtains rooms at 20 to 25 percent off regular rates at certain hotels in Manhattan as well as in Los Angeles and San Francisco. It says its leverage comes from volume and that its clients include many business travelers whose companies don't get corporate rates. Travelers are not charged for the service, and they do not have to join a club.
Express Hotel Reservations says it books about 50,000 rooms a year. Among the hotels are, in Manhattan, the Doral Court (39th Street and Lexington Avenue), the Warwick (54th Street and Avenue of the Americas) and New York Penta (32d Street and Seventh Avenue). In Los Angeles, they include the Midtown Hilton, the Ma Maison Sofitel and the Mondrian; in San Francisco, the Diva, Kensington Park and Parc Fifty-Five. The agency can be reached at (800) 356-1123 Monday to Friday from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. Eastern standard time.
Travelers bound for Disney World and other attractions in Florida at busy periods -- and that can be any time other than May and September to November -- can ask the Central Reservation Service to find them rooms. The service, a member of Orlando-Orange County Convention and Visitors Bureau, operates around the clock and does not charge a fee. "Orlando fills up every holiday," said Carlos Giraldo, the manager. "Demand outpaces supply, and travelers go through an ordeal trying to find a room. We can help." The phone number is (800) 950-0232.
 
Economy Class Gets New Name
 Starting Jan. 15, British Airways won't have an economy class anymore. Instead, the section will have a new name -- two in fact. Economy will be called world traveler on long-haul routes, including trans-Atlantic, and Euro traveler on short-haul routes in Europe.
The change, the airline said, is the result of three years of market research resulting in improved catering, more comfortable seats, free newspapers and improved in-flight movies for the 13 million passengers who travel economy with British Airways every year.
In the cabin, world travelers will be greeted by a new blue and white decoration, designed to give a feeling of greater space, but the width and pitch of the seats will remain the same. Euro travelers will have improved service with free beverages.
 
Tours: Horses, Wildlife, Food
A crossing of the Andes on horseback is offered by Southern Cross Expeditions. The trip is scheduled to begin from Mendoza, Argentina, on Feb. 9. Participants will ride across the Andes into Chile and back, making a 13-day loop amid glaciers, forests and Aconcagua, the highest peak of the Western Hemisphere. The price of $2,440 a person covers horses, tents, meals, guides and a two-night hotel stay in Buenos Aires but no air fares. (Southern Cross Expeditions, Post Office Box 1228, Bowling Green Station, New York, N.Y. 10274-1228; [800] 359-0193.)
Changes in wildlife and plant and marine life that may have occurred in the Galapagos Islands as a result of the "greenhouse" global warning and the unusually strong El Nino current of 1983 will be studied on a 19-day trip next summer. In 1983, the El Nino current deluged the Galapagos with 103 inches of rain instead of the usual 3 inches. The tour will be led by Richard Hilton, an instructor in natural sciences at Sierra College, Rocklin, Calif. Participants will travel aboard a motor yacht with private cabins. The trip, scheduled for June 22 to July 10, costs $2,990, including accommodations and all meals on the yacht, lectures and a three-night hotel stay in Quito. Air fares to Ecuador and the islands are extra. (Nature Expeditions International, Post Office Box 11496, Eugene, Ore. 97440; [800] 869-0639 or [503] 484-6529.)
The cookbook author Eileen Yin-Fei Lo will escort a tour to Hong Kong for the colony's Food Festival. The eight-day tour starting March 11 costs $2,750 a person, including round-trip air fare from the West Coast ($200 more from the East Coast), rooms at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel and most meals. Another tour leaving the same day offers one cooking class and provides rooms at the Kowloon Shangri-La Hotel. It is $2,495. (Orient Flexi-Pax Tours, 630 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; [212] 692-9550 or [800] 545-5540 outside New York State.)
 
VIEWING AREA IN HAWAII
 The observation point at the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific, Hawaii's most popular tourist attraction, has reopened following a two-year renovation. The area, which offers a panoramic view of Honolulu, was redesigned to reduce traffic congestion and to provide a more tranquil setting.
Nearly 36,000 members of the military who died in World War II and the wars in Korea and Vietnam are buried in the cemetery.
The $2 million renovation, organized by the Veterans Administration, which maintains the cemetery, includes new parking areas for buses and cars, restrooms and enlarged viewing areas.
Memorial plaques donated by veterans groups will be placed along what was called Observation Drive but has been renamed Memorial Walk, now closed to traffic. The changes mean that passengers on buses have to walk up Memorial Walk from a new parking area, adding about 15 minutes to their visit.
In the year before the renovation began, more than 5.6 million people visited the cemetery. But even after the renovation, the area is still congested with traffic, especially tour buses. About 85 to 100 buses arrive each day along with stretch limousines and cars.
Officials of the cemetery and representatives of tour companies are engaged in discussions on easing congestion.
The cemetery is in the crater -- known as the Punchbowl -- of an extinct volcano.

HEADLINE: BETTING THE PLANET

 BODY:
The market price of food, fresh water, minerals, metals and fuel has never been related to the finite quantity of those resources. Rather, it has has been determined by current micro- and macroeconomics, which, in turn, are affected by hourly wage rates, subsidies, politics, current supply and demand.
To date, the market pricing of natural resources has not included the other direct and indirect costs resulting from overpopulation and the consumption of these resources: the costs of pollution, waste disposal, climatic changes, ecological deterioration, species destruction.
Ehrlich's bet with Simon is meaningless. Instead of obfuscating the real problems, these gentlemen should be working on methods to adjust the market pricing of resources to reflect their real costs -- which involves a lot more than their current degree of "scarcity." The problem is urgent and complicated.
 
JACK FREIDIN
Weston, Conn.

HEADLINE: A Changing Climate for Co-op Sublets

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
THE weakened co-op market throughout the city is putting the feet of many board members to the fire as more shareholders who need to move seek permission to take tenants rather than accept an unfavorable price in a sale.
The subletting issue, some board members say, has forced them into a balancing act, trying to extend relief to apartment owners facing financial hardship, but at the same time addressing the concerns of other shareholders about rental occupancies. For some of them, subletting is opening a door to trouble. 
 "It is an issue that is very important now," said Steven Vamos, president of a co-op at 222 East 80th Street between Second and Third Avenues, "and I can tell you that it can be very emotional, even bloody. Dealing with subletting problems is taking more and more of our time."
Arguments against subletting range from its potential for compromise in a building's security to the difficulty of removing a tenant who turns out to be noisy or disruptive. Some shareholders argue that too many tenants -- even if they are neighborly and helpful -- can give a building an unwanted transient characteristic.
"Every board has heard the horror stories," said Lee Miller, a lawyer whose firm, Miller Friedman & Eisenman, represents co-ops on the Upper East and West Sides of Manhattan. "Tenants who have all-night parties or who sneak in roommates or don't pay their rents. Subletting can be an enormous burden to a building if it is not monitored."
Owners of co-op apartments hold shares in a corporation rather than real property and hold proprietary leases that give them the right to occupy their space under the terms of their lease. When they rent out their apartments the new occupants are sublessees.
In condominiums, in which owners hold real property as opposed to corporation shares, owners normally have an easier task when they seek out renters. Condominium managements cannot deny permission to rent, although they may review the owner's tenant choice and charge fees to the owner for rental occupancies.
The rental option for the condominium owner who wants to move but not sell has in fact been one of the selling points in condominium promotions in recent years, as condominiums have become the prevalent form in newly built multifamily residences in New York City. But in the face of falling prices, some co-op boards have eased their policies on subleasing.
"It's no longer a matter of limiting the profits of the seller, as it used to be when the market was stronger," said Jesse Morris, vice president of the directors at 375 Riverside Drive at 110th Street. "It is now how much of a loss the owner might have to take if a sublet is not approved."
Mr. Morris said that until last year the board approved subletting only for shareholders who left the city temporarily for professional reasons and who returned to their apartments. But in the last several months it has heard the pleas of shareholders being dragged down by falling co-op prices.
"The subletting requests were not coming from people who were taking sabbaticals or temporary out-of-town assignments," he said. "In an increasing number of cases people wanted to leave the city for good or needed to move to a larger apartment. And in these cases they had tried to sell but could not even recover their original investment." Not all co-ops have bowed to pressure to relax subletting policies.
Lester Lazarus, president of the board at 36 Sutton Place South, said that after years of virtually no discussions on the matter, in recent months the board has heard the pleas of three shareholders who could not sell and wanted to rent their apartments. One bought two units with plans to sell one. When he could not, he asked the board to let him sublet.
Another, who said he had to move to Florida for his health, asked permission to sublease because he could not find a buyer.
A third shareholder told the board that a bankrupt business had made it hard for him to meet financial obligations on his apartment.
All were turned down, Mr. Lazarus said.
"Unfortunately," he said, "we have not been lenient when it comes to sublets. I can see how the board's position in these cases could make us seem rather heartless. I am personally troubled by these situations. But I must say that I believe that we were responding to the feelings of the majority of shareholders, who still do not like the idea of subletting."
A particularly nettlesome aspect of subletting discussions, Mr. Lazarus said, is that of setting a precedent that would make it difficult for the board to turn down requests.
"We don't want to be put in the position of being a judge on the degree of hardship people are experiencing," he said. "If you give permission to one, how can you justify turning down the next person or the next, each of whom might have legitimate reasons for wanting to rent?"
Despite the continued resistance to subletting in a few co-ops, real estate lawyers and managers and board members themselves say that many boards have liberalized their polices in the last six months or so.
"I don't think we have any buildings in the portfolio of co-op properties that we manage that have absolutely refused to even consider some hardship cases," said Kenneth Cohn, executive vice president of Century Operating Corporation, which manages buildings throughout Manhattan, including co-ops and condominiums on the Upper East Side. "The boards don't want the apartments to be enterprises and they are looking to us for guidance in making policy that can allow them to be humane without letting down their guard."
In buildings where boards will allow subletting, the privilege usually carries restrictions designed to keep tenancy to a minimum, give the co-op control over who their nonshareholding neighbors will be and defray the costs of such arrangements.
Many boards limit subletting to one or two years. Some boards allow shareholders to sublet only once during their ownership. Others put a ceiling on the total number of sublets allowed at one time and still others insist that owners show that an effort has been made to sell an apartment before a sublet is discussed.
Nearly all boards reserve the right to approve any tenants and charge subletting fees, which can be high. Mr. Vamos, for example, said his co-op charges each shareholder a $750 fee for subletting, no matter what the size of the apartment. In addition, a monthly surcharge ranging from $50 for studios to $200 for two-bedroom apartments is added to the maintenance bills of shareholders who sublet.
Mr. Morris said that when he and his fellow board members are reviewing a potential subtenant they look at references and personal finances and demand that the shareholder put two months' maintenance payments in escrow. "We have the full right to evict," he said, "and we hold the shareholder responsible for the conduct of the subtenant."
About 5 percent of the building's 100 apartments are being sublet by their owners.
LAWYERS and property managers reject the notion that co-ops that are holdouts against subletting are the long-established co-ops in buildings on Park and Fifth Avenue and on Sutton Place in Manhattan.
"Cooperatives have personalities," said Frank Karelsen, a partner in Kurzman, Karelsen & Frank, a law firm that represents co-ops. "Some are conservative, some liberal. So, often whether residents do or do not want to allow tenants has less to do with a building's location or whether or not the owners are wealthy than it does with how owners want their home to be."
No one knows that better than Nancy Frey. After failing to sell her apartment in Howard Beach, Queens, she approached the board of directors for permission to sublet. Since August, when she inherited the apartment after her father's death, she has been turned down twice in bids to sublet.
"This is not a fancy apartment building," said Ms. Frey. "But the people who live here are a very close group, most of them from the neighborhood."
Ms. Frey, who has never lived in the two-bedroom apartment she inherited, said she would have moved into it except that she already owns a vacation home and the Stuyvesant Town, where she rents an apartment in Manhattan, does not allow subletting either.
"My father did not leave me with the resources to make the payments," she said. "So for the time being the maintenance is coming out of my own pocket. At $517 a month it has become a burden."
Ms. Frey said that she does not believe the board's inflexibility is tied to her never having been a resident of the building.
"My father had a lot of friends in the building," she said. "The board members I have dealt with knew my father and were sympathetic to my situation. I just think that the shareholders there just don't want anyone who is not an owner to live in the building."
After the second rejection, Ms. Frey investigated the possibility of taking legal action against the co-op. But she, like other frustrated co-op owners who have met rejection in their bid to take tenants, found that the law sides with the board. New York State Business Corporation law gives co-op corporations the absolute right to forbid subletting or formulate subletting policy any way they see fit. Most proprietary leases say the bona fide tenant is the shareholder and members of the immediate family.
Court cases have strengthened those rights.
Shareholders who sublet without permission from their boards risk losing their own right to occupy the apartment. A board can terminate proprietary leases. The only recourse is a recall of the co-op board members or a change in the corporation's bylaws, which in most co-ops requires approval by two-thirds of the shareholders.
Ms. Frey was preparing to go back to the board a third time when she recently accepted a bid of $65,000 on the apartment. She says that is $25,000 less than the selling price for a similar apartment in the building.
Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said that complete inflexibility on subletting can come back to haunt a co-op.
"Some shareholders," she said, "are beginning to see that when their neighbors can't sublet and must sell at a substantial loss, it affects the value of other apartments in the building."
Mrs. Rothman also said it is possible that if the economic climate worsens some shareholders could stop paying maintenance or, in extreme situations, be forced to default.
"There comes a point at which a co-op must decide if it is smarter to allow subletting with restrictions," she said, "or maintain rules against it and run the risk of losing the maintenance of shareholders who can not meet their financial obligations."
Inflexibility on subletting is emerging as a negative for buyers, too.
"BUYERS are starting to ask about subletting rights," said Rose Edwards, a principal in Walscott Real Estate, a brokerage company in Manhattan. "I have not lost a sale because the buyer didn't want to go into a co-op where subletting was hard, but it is something that buyers are more aware of than they used to be. The down market has made them think about their vulnerability and flexibility in the future."
A lenient subletting policy, some board members say, is no protection against subletting headaches.
Mr. Vamos, president of the board at 222 East 80th Street, said that the board is currently chasing five shareholders who it believes have illegal subletting arrangements.
"They are trying to get out of paying the fee," he said "or they want to take in people who they are afraid would not be acceptable to us."
When it comes to justifying their offenses, Mr. Vamos said, the creativity of shareholders is remarkable. One shareholder, Mr. Vamos said, said that the man who would be staying in his apartment was not a tenant but a workman who would be there so he could paint the apartment.
"But when this guy tried to move in," said Mr. Vamos, "he showed up with a truckload of furniture instead of the stuff you'd think a painter would need."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Christmas Decor;
Scrooge Banished as Businesses Get Into the Spirit

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
AS TOUGH as things are, you would need a caliper, a yardstick and a good memory to discern much difference in the holiday ornamentations undertaken by New York City's commercial interests this year.
There have been some cutbacks, to be sure. The West Side Chamber of Commerce reduced the number of its trees along upper Broadway. And the Park Avenue Malls Holiday Lighting Project and Avenue Association, faced with a drop in contributions, invested in smaller trees, although they did not lessen the scope of the effort -- nearly 140 trees, from 54th to 96th Street. 
 As a rule, it seems, businesses have maintained seasonal decor. Fifteen-foot nutracker soldiers are still arrayed smartly at the Paine Webber Building on the Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52d Streets. Seven giant "candy canes" made of boxwood -- 17 feet high and 700 pounds each -- still hang from the parapet at 9 West 57th Street. More than 200 fir trees from Nova Scotia still fill the pools at the Seagram Building on Park Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets. Cartier, at Fifth Avenue and 52d Street, is still wrapped in a vast red ribbon.
And an enormous snowflake still hangs at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, although community antagonism, on esthetic grounds, has prompted a redesign for next year.
By that time, private concerns will be expected to play even more of a role in decorating. Absent any outside help, for example, the city may have to cut out holiday trees altogether. In 1986, the Parks Department bought 44 trees for installation around New York; this year, the city bought only 14. "Next year," said Parks Commissioner Betsy Gotbaum, "the trees will have to be funded with private money."
The Parks Department had to depend on corporate largesse to maintain the tradition of filling the Pulitzer Fountain at Manhattan's Grand Army Plaza with 100 trees. In years past, the city picked up half the $20,000 cost, but this year could afford nothing.
The shortfall was made up by a group of donors led by Richard R. Wilhelm, vice president and general manager of the Plaza Hotel, that included the Pierre and Sherry Netherland Hotels. Real-estate interests that chipped in included Corporate Property Investors, managers and soon-to-be owners of the General Motors Building, across from the Plaza; LaSalle Partners, managers of 745 Fifth Avenue, next door, and the Solow Building Company, owner of 9 West 57th Street.
Although landlords would rather talk of their seasonal efforts in terms of giving a gift to the city or fulfilling corporate responsibility, it is also true that decorations draw attention to their properties and add a certain luster that carries over to the rent rolls.
PERHAPS no other owner does so much as the Rockefeller Group. This year, in fact, the tree-lighting ceremony at Rockefeller Center was held once and then restaged four days later. It turned out that the children from the Northside Center for Child Development in Harlem, who came down to push the button that lights the tree, had inadvertently been kept off stage the first time around.
Rockefeller Center officials will not discuss the cost of installing the 75-foot Norway spruce and its 20,000 lights, nor how much has been spent over the years on the sculptured wire angels that fill the Channel Gardens, the 16-foot garlands that ornament the Fifth Avenue facades and the 13 1/2-foot fiberglass cadets that surround the Lower Plaza.
But they are sure it is money well spent. "From the business sense, it's what distinguishes Rockefeller Center from its competition," said James V. Reed, the director of marketing communications. "From the selling of space and the marketing standpoint, being distinguished from the competition is something that's important to us and we do a lot of things to see to it that that happens."
The Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, based in Manhattan, spends something like $100,000 to ornament the plaza of the Seagram Building, placing 224 fir trees (with 50,000 lights) in the pools that flank Mies van der Rohe's landmark.
"It recognizes the community element of that property," said Philip R. DiGennaro, managing director of the insurance company. "That's part of the allure, part of the quality of the building. Independent of that, I think we would recognize the holiday season with prudent, cost-effective, decorative displays that reflect our pride in the product. Maybe it's a bit of preening on the part of the owners, but keeping marble polished isn't a wasteful expenditure. It goes to the quality of the product."
"I like to think of it as a continuity of investment through good and bad cycles," he said. "It's fun to do, it enhances the building and adds to the enjoyment of the tenancy."
Tenant enjoyment was also a consideration for Equitable Real Estate, a subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. It functions as the landlord at the Paine Webber Building, which was formerly Equitable's headquarters. In 1988, Drew Masters, the vice president of asset management, was looking for a way to distinguish the tower during the holidays. "We wanted something significant and prominent for the property, yet sophisticated," he said. He found a nutcracker at a gift shop in Wilton, Conn., and that was reproduced on an enormous scale by Arnold Migliaccio & Sons of the Bronx.
"It's a nice gift to the people in the building, as well as people in the city," said Jerry I. Speyer of Tishman Speyer Properties, managers of the Paine Webber Building.
More oversized soldiers can be found at Cartier, which may be the most ornamented commercial property, inch for inch. "We've heard about this so-called recession," said Ralph Destino, the chairman of Cartier, "but have chosen not to participate."
"EVEN with aspects of gloom and doom lurking around us," he went on, "I think the spirit of Christmas -- and all that it implies -- happily remains unbowed and undaunted. I haven't seen any evidence of people saying, 'Let's save money and cut out Christmas trees.' The hardest of hard-nosed financial guys would recognize that this is not the place to cut back."
That may be true on Fifth Avenue, but the West Side Chamber of Commerce has sponsored only one holiday tree, at Broadway and 72d Street, instead of the usual four, saving some $12,000. "People are having difficulties," said Andrew Albert, the chamber's executive director, "and it's tough to get those contributions."
Across town, Margaret Ternes, executive director of the Park Avenue malls project, said: "As far as funding is concerned, it is down. All the real-estate people on the avenue have donated as always. They're very, very supportive. But some of the off-Park Avenue owners have not contributed this year. I see that as a way of saying, 'Business is down, rentals are down and it's something we don't really have to do. We'd like to, but this may not be the year to do it.' "
This is apparently the last year for the illuminated snowflake at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street that was created by the Douglas Leigh Organization and unveiled in 1984. Its appeal tends to diminish the closer one gets, when its wires and structural elements stand out and its massiveness becomes apparent.
"It's intrusive and it's not esthetically pleasing and it's not fun," said Bobbie Handman, vice president of People for the American Way and a member of Community Board 5. "It hangs, almost like a sword, over what I consider to be one of the most jovial corners of New York at Christmastime."
In October, the board unanimously approved the reinstallation of the snowflake this year but noted in an amendment from Ms. Handman that it "anticipated a new design with the next application."
"I'm redesigning it as we speak," said Dennis Dady, vice president of the Leigh Organization. "I'm making it more appealing for the up-close public."
