HEADLINE: Disputes Threaten Plan to Control Flooding

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: MAMARONECK

 BODY:
RESIDENTS in the village of Mamaroneck say they often feel caught between the devil and the deep blue sea, especially when the two rivers that flow through this coastal community, the Mamaroneck and the Sheldrake, overflow their banks.
The village is at the lowest geographical point of the Mamaroneck-Sheldrake watershed, which drains areas of Westchester as far inland as Harrison. The two rivers converge in Columbus Park in the village, sometimes with such force that parts of the adjacent railroad station parking lot have been turned into an inland sea. 
 The last serious flood in the village occurred more than a decade ago, but it nearly paralyzed the downtown business district and caused damage estimated in the millions of dollars. While flood-control experts said there was no way to predict when the next serious flooding would occur, they said it was inevitable and that as new development upstream increased the runoff, the flooding was certain to become more devastating.
 
U.S. Reviews a Proposal
 The Federal Government has agreed with those experts, and a $72 million flood-control plan is receiving its final review in Washington. This comes 12 years after the Army Corps of Engineers began investigating the problem, proposed corrective steps and completed a $3.1 million design for a solution, which includes widening the Marmaroneck River to accommodate additional water volume.
The project had been on hold for eight years, when Congress passed the Water Resources Development Act of 1986. This allowed projects nationwide to proceed, but at an additional cost because of inflation during the delay.
Final Federal approval of the project could come early next year, but two long-dormant local conflicts now threaten to delay the plan again.
 
A Town-Village Dispute
 Village officials are locked in a dispute with town officials over the responsibility for five stone bridges over the Marmaroneck River that would have to be widened to accommodate an enlarged river channel.
At the same time, the state and the village cannot agree on how to share responsibility for the $18 million part of the project's cost that will not be picked up by the Federal Government. Federal law stipulates that 25 percent of such projects must be paid for locally, but the state has not established a formula to govern how local costs are to be divided in such projects.
Widening the bridges will cost an additional $12 million, Federal and state engineers estimate, a financial burden that village and town officials hesitate to shoulder. Although the town concedes that it owns the bridges, officials there insist that village money must be used to expand or replace them because the village has maintained them for 50 years.
Village maintenance crews have repaved the surfaces of the bridges, posted weight limits and even closed a bridge, town officials said. The village of Mamaroneck does not dispute that. But Mayor Paul J. Noto said: "We are not in the bridge business. The law is very clear: bridges and cemeteries are the exclusive responsibility of towns, not villages."
 
The Mayor Draws an Analogy
 Although the village has conducted some "minor patchwork" on the bridges, Mr. Noto said, "that action by no means constitutes a change in ownership."
"If we plow Route 1, that doesn't mean we own Route 1," he said, referring to the state-owned thoroughfare through the village. So far, a rule of convenience has operated to say who does what chore.
Each municipality has appointed a committee to negotiate with the other, a move that Stephen V. Altieri, the town administrator, said had led to some progress. The biggest question, he said, is determining the interests of town taxpayers, many of whom do not live in the village's flood zone.
Part of the village of Mamaroneck is in the town of Mamaroneck, which also includes all of the village of Larchmont and part of the village of Rye Brook. The rest of the village of Mamaroneck is in Rye. Town officials provide all municipal services to the unincorporated areas of the town, but only limited services, like recreation programs and certain election services, to the villages.
 
But What Role for the State?
 Even if village and town leaders can resolve their financial responsibility for the bridges, the state's financial role must be addressed for the flood-control project to proceed. "Our portion could be considerable," Mayor Noto said. "We are extremely concerned, and we are asking ourselves if we can afford to participate at all."
Village residents complain that without a set formula, a local government like the village of Mamaroneck could be responsible for most of the $18 million local share.
"It's a very difficult situation," said Richard L. Kensella, chief of flood-control projects for the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. "The village wants to know why the state isn't helping more. Until a formula is specified in law, how can we?"
During the last two sessions in Albany, legislation has been introduced to set up a formula, but the measure has been bottled up in the Assembly. A similar bill will be introduced at the next legislative session, said a spokesman for Ronald C. Tocci, the Assemblyman who represent the village. Mr. Tocci's bill would divide local costs equally between the state and the county, a proposition that county lobbyists in the state have opposed.
 
A Local Alternative Is Rejected
 Mayor Noto and the Village Engineer, Les Zakarin, have considered a locally designed and financed alternative, but Mr. Noto said any flood program the village could afford would not be comprehensive enough to solve the problem. In addition, a local program could jeapordize continuing involvement by the Federal Government, he said.
"It isn't just the people whose homes and businesses are wiped out by flooding who are hurt," said Mr. Kensella of the D.E.C. "The entire region and its whole transportation network will be disrupted."
He warned that "the da'nger gets greater and greater" as development continues in the upbasin above the village. "But although the problem is getting worse," he said, "it's getting less close to a solution."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: San Francisco State;
An Unusual Class Puts Students On the Street

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Passing Beverly Ovrebo's course on homelessness takes fortitude, compassion and a warm jacket, say many of her students at San Francisco State University.
For one of her class projects, the associate professor of health education asks students to empty their pockets of money and to become homeless for a day. Considering the subject matter, she says, the streets are just as appropriate a place to study as her classroom. 
 Professor Ovrebo began teaching what she says is the nation's first undergraduate seminar on homelessness three years ago. She said that separating the homeless from their condition brings them "a step closer" to getting them off the streets.
"Experiencing homelessness," she said, "is necessary to getting a handle on that situation."
 
 'It's Really Degrading'
 Linda Kocher, a 20-year-old sophomore from Santa Cruz, Calif., majoring in social sciences and Spanish, chose a warm November to fulfill the class requirement. She said she slept in her clothes "to get a feel for what it was like to be homeless."
"It's really degrading," she said. "You're ignored by everyone. I learned that homeless people are human, too. Now, when I see them, I talk to them, and if I have money, I give them some."
When Grace Olshansky became a street person for a day in October, she said her tattered jeans and old sweatshirt drew some "real looks" from residents as she wandered down the streets and alleyways of the city's tenderloin district.
"I was surprised at how easy it was to identify with the homeless people," said the 26-year-old junior from San Francisco, majoring in pre-med. "I think there was some real camaradarie that developed after being there for only a few hours."
 
Sleeping on a Park Bench
 Another student, 24-year-old Stephen Williams, a junior from Eugene, Ore., majoring in English literature, said he forgot his coat when he spent an evening outdoors for the class. "I realized how vulnerable I was," he said.
Not all of Professor Ovrebo's students spend the night outside. Some choose to be homeless during the day, while others spend an afternoon or evening outdoors. A few have slept on a park bench or under a bridge at night.
In the three years she has taught about homelessness, none of her students have been robbed or hurt. To protect her students, Professor Ovrebo encourages them to take a friend. "I tell them not to put themselves in any jeopardy," she said.
She has helped to begin two classes on homelessness since 1988: a one-semester course examining homelessness and public policy and a five-week seminar called "Outta Control," which introduces students to issues and attitudes about homelessness.
 
Seminars on Homelessness
 In both classes, students participate in a series of exercises, including asking a passer-by for a quarter, keeping a journal of their experiences and applying for unemployment benefits.
Professor Ovrebo also helped organize the Bay Area Homelessness Program, a coalition linking 10 colleges with social service and government agencies. The group tackles issues of the homeless in quarterly seminars.
Homelessness is increasing in the San Francisco Bay area, officials say. In a market so expensive that only 10 percent of San Franciscans can afford to buy a home, 230,000 people are homeless, Professor Ovrebo said.
"There are still a lot of misconceptions -- that people choose to be homeless or that they are the undeserving poor," said Professor Ovrebo. Those misconceptions "can be turned around."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In an effort to help students understand the problems of the homeless, Prof. Beverly Ovrebo of San Francisco State University began teaching undergraduate courses on homelessness three years ago.Sherrie Walsh, left, and Michael Ezton, who are students in the course, delivering blankets they donated to the Hamilton Family Center, a homeless shelter. With them was Lauren Alden, the center's manager. (Fred Mertz/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Diary/December 16-21

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
THE ECONOMY
 
The Federal Reserve, at Long Last, Steps Forward
 
First the economists worried about a recession. Then the retailers and industry executives. Then the President. Finally, the only one besides Saddam Hussein who can actually do something to stimulate the economy acted. For the first time since he became chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in 1987, Alan Greenspan agreed on Tuesday to cut the discount rate, by half a point to 6.5 percent. The Government has few other anti-recessionary medicines in its cabinet. President Bush and Congress are trying to reduce the yawning deficit by cutting spending and raising taxes, a Hooveresque combination. Economists doubt the Fed's new course will immediately cause businesses and consumers to spend, borrow and rejoice. Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover, called last week's action "the first in a series of steps the Fed has to take to curb a recession." The next cut, he said, could come as soon as next month.
 
Consumer Prices Rise Modestly
 
The Fed's rate cut followed the comforting news that consumer prices rose only three-tenths of 1 percent in November. The core rate, without food and energy, rose by the same percentage. Economists pointed to stabilizing energy prices and an economy too weak to allow producers to pass along their own higher costs, up five-tenths of 1 percent the same month. Lower corporate profits are likely to result.
 
Trade Deficit Widens
 
Foreign trade, one of the few recent sources of economic strength, is turning against the United States. The nation's trade deficit widened to $11.6 billion in October, the worst monthly showing in two and a half years. A weak dollar raised exports to a record. But higher car imports and expensive oil raised total imports a great deal more.
 
Should Weak Banks Pay More?
 
L. William Seidman's hospital for sick banks may turn out to be more like a hospice. Mr. Seidman has proposed that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which he heads, charge higher premiums to weaker banks. The new scale would discourage risk-taking and speculation, analysts say, but also force many banks to combine. He also suggested to Congress last week that his agency's dwindling insurance fund -- likely to lose $5 billion and approach insolvency next year, he said -- could be bolstered by increasing premiums across the board and charging a one-time assessment of $25 billion, or $1 for every $100 in deposits. Some analysts said that such a heavy charge -- about equal to the entire industry's peak annual profits, in 1988 -- would be easier to impose over about five years.
 
K.K.R.'s Patient Money
 
Nothing like an economic downturn and a sour "junk-bond" market to turn Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company into a patient investor. The firm said last week that it plans to ask holders of $752 million in RJR Nabisco Inc. junk bonds to accept cash and stock, valued at $5 a share, in return. In effect, Kohlberg, Kravis is letting the public invest in its RJR leveraged buyout, the largest ever, at the same price the firm paid for stock in 1988, and $1.25 less than it paid for shares earlier this year. One Kohlberg, Kravis partner said his firm might need five to seven years to take its profits from the deal, more than twice the time it took a few years ago.
 
America's Edge on Digital TV
 
American companies have taken the lead in developing digital, high-definition television systems that can broadcast over ordinary, local channels. Japanese and European systems have to transmit by satellites instead. Last week, Zenith Electronics and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company became the third American group to announce plans for developing digital television.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Soviet Ship Off Course
 
It was during a quiet vacation stroll on the beach in the Crimea, during the dangerous Brezhnev years, that Eduard A. Schevardnadze broached to Mikhail S. Gorbachev the need for thorough economic reform. Last Thursday, Mr. Schevardnadze angrily quit as Foreign Minister, warning of a national march toward dictatorship. "He was one of the good guys," said Ed A. Hewett of the Brookings Institution. "It sends a signal that one of the most prominent founders of perestroika had decided that the whole ship is off course." As party secretary in Georgia, Mr. Schevardnadze took opinion polls, allowed plants to elect managers, uprooted the party's corrupt minions and introduced profit-sharing. As Foreign Minister, he became a sort of Soviet James Baker -- a confidante on matters far beyond his portfolio. Mr. Hewett said that Mr. Gorbachev might be able to bring Mr. Schevardnadze back into his Government, but only after "four or five months of enormous chaos."
 
China's Little Board
 
In China, they might call it "the little board." A new securities exchange opened in Shanghai on Wednesday with prices displayed on a small electronic screen. Most trading will be in bonds, primarily Governments, because many officials put more faith in the state.
 
 
 
COMPANIES


Citicorp's Quarter of Discontent
 
The examiners examined, and Citicorp executives executed a sharp dividend cut and a moderate increase in reserves for bad loans. The biggest United States banking company plans to lay off 4,400 more workers, cut its quarterly payout from 44.5 cents to 25 cents a share and take a fourth-quarter loss of $300 million to $400 million. Analysts had feared that the bank examiners, who finished their annual look at Citicorp last week, would demand much higher reserves, resulting in deeper losses. Now many analysts say that Citicorp has not set aside nearly enough. But Frank R. DeSantis Jr., an analyst at PaineWebber, said the company faces no crisis. "Citicorp is more right than analysts give them credit for, and more wrong than they think they are," he said. "It will be a muddle-through strategy rather than capitulation."
 
More Banks With Losses
 
Other banks buffeted by problem loans: The NCNB Corporation said earnings will fall from $447 million to $360 million this year, with an especially weak fourth quarter. The Bank of Boston, having lost $255 million in the third quarter, expects another, though smaller, loss in the fourth, and the C&S/Sovran Corporation expects to at best break even in the quarter. And bondholders asked the Bank of New England to swap 92 percent of the company's common stock for a $605 million reduction in debt.
 
Problems With Going Public
 
Alex. Brown & Sons, the venerable Baltimore brokerage, has had a strong record of taking fledgling technology companies public. Then it tried financing other industries, becoming Wall Street's leading underwriter of initial public offerings, raising more than $2 billion this year. But several issues, especially in retailing, have flopped. Silk Greenhouse Inc. sells artificial flowers, and Alex. Brown sold its stock last year at 17 1/4 a share. The retailer has since filed for bankruptcy protection and its stock has wilted to a few cents a share. Last week, the executive who made the brokerage a leading underwriter stepped down. Donald B. Hebb Jr. resigned as president of Alex. Brown Inc., the parent company, for reasons that a spokesman called "totally unrelated" to issues like Silk Greenhouse. The company lost $3.1 million in the third quarter, though it expects a profit for the year.
 
Pan Am Accepts T.W.A.'s Offer
 
Pan Am World Airways conditionally agreed on Friday to combine with Trans World Airlines, its historical rival in travel overseas. But Pan Am, nearly broke, asked the T.W.A. chairman, Carl C. Icahn, for a loan to keep it flying until regulators and shareholders approve the deal. Mr. Icahn offered $375 million for Pan Am earlier in the week. He said he first wants Pan Am to file for bankruptcy protection, guaranteeing him priority repayment for any subsequent loan. Mr. Icahn hopes to weld two weak airlines into one strong one. T.W.A. and Pan Am both lack the domestic networks to feed their international flights. Both airlines have agreed to sell their prized London routes, Pan Am to United Airlines last month, and T.W.A. to American Airlines last week. American would pay $445 million to T.W.A., which Mr. Icahn needs both to buy Pan Am and to pay down his airline's debts. "It was a great deal," said Helane Becker of Shearson Lehman Brothers. "The routes are far more valuable to American than to T.W.A." British authorities are less enthusiastic, saying they will allow American and United to use London's Heathrow Airport only in return for major United States concessions.
 
Savings and Loan Chiefs Guilty
 
Final exam, Accounting 201: As the owner of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association of Dallas, you want to impress board members and clients. But where on your operating statements can you safely list payments for the California beach house and the prostitutes? Don R. Dixon, Vernon's owner, is likely to have many years behind bars to figure out the answers after his conviction Thursday on 23 counts of fraud. For benefiting from his own mishandling of loans worth $41 million, he faces as much as 120 years in prison and fines of $560,000. Prosecutors and Justice Department officials thumped their chests and issued the usual statements about the vindication of their strategies. But the Government is unlikely to recover more than a sliver of the estimated $1.3 billion that Vernon's failure will cost the taxpayers.
 
Another Dallas savings and loan executive agreed to plead guilty on Friday in a failure that was even more costly. Edwin T. McBirney 3d, the former owner of the Sunbelt Savings Association, faces a maximum prison term of 15 years and fines of $8.5 million on charges including fraud and tax evasion. The Government is spending an estimated $3 billion to cover Sunbelt's losses.

LENGTH: 3095 words

HEADLINE: Drinking Salt in the Dawn

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
If there has been a theme to Seiji Tsutsumi's remarkably varied career, it has been finding opportunity in alienation.
As an angry young student at prestigious Tokyo University, Mr. Tsutsumi rebelled against his autocratic father, a top conservative politician, by joining the Communist Party. But instead of suffering permanent social ostracism for this affront, he used the experience as the basis for a popular autobiographical novel, one of whose climactic moments has the protagonist shouting during an anti-Korean War rally: "Get your hands off, Imperialists! We will never be Truman's mercenaries!" 
 Later, when the department store his father ordered him to open in Los Angeles flopped, his response to the humiliation was also characteristic: "I wrote a poem," recalled the impish, 63-year-old Mr. Tsutsumi, an unassuming man in a three-piece blue suit and his trademark shy smile. "I called the city the farthest spot on earth from civilization." And he eventually won a top literary honor for doing so.
But his greatest feat of alchemy was in the pioneering business empire he created from his bitter inheritance. Left with just a third-rate department store -- the rest of his father's railroad, hotel and real estate holdings went to a half-brother, Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, the son of one of the old man's many mistresses -- Mr. Tsutsumi slowly built it into one of Japan's most innovative retailers, Seibu Department Stores.
With a combination of marketing gumption and avant-garde advertising -- one television ad for Parco, a retailer Mr. Tsutsumi created, simply showed Faye Dunaway eating a hard-boiled egg -- the stores have succeeded by peddling a product rare in Japan: individuality. But Mr. Tsutsumi did not stop there. Seibu is now just the core of what is called the Saison Group, a sprawling and largely private retail, travel, financial and property development conglomerate.
 
'Season of Wandering'
 In the process, Mr. Tsutsumi (pronounced tsoo-TSOO-mee) has put together a billion-dollar fortune and an impressive body of writing, under the pen name Takashi Tsujii, with titles that aptly express the sense of alienation he has come to represent, like "In the Season of Wandering," "The Circumference of Unrest" and "Poetry, Poison, Roaming." He is probably the only person in Japan, or any other country, taken so seriously as a writer and a business magnate.
The tale of a great fortune built partly out of the ruined estates of former Japanese nobility, intra-family rivalries, trysts with geisha and forlorn poets seems like the stuff of a racy novel. In fact, this real-life drama speaks volumes about Japan's quiet but powerful transformation over the past decade into a services-based economy, and the new personalities bubbling to the surface in the ferment of this consumer boom.
The boom is in large part a product of a five-year-old Government policy to turn domestic consumption, rather than exports, into the engine of economic growth. Encouraging people to enjoy more leisure activities by reducing the work week to five days is among the initiatives taken to get workers to save less and consume more.
In the services realm, where the sizzle is often more important than the substance of what is sold, vivid characters like Mr. Tsutsumi are transforming themselves into effective marketing symbols.
"The fact that we have behaved differently from others has been the main force behind the Saison Group to date," Mr. Tsutsumi commented, sitting amid the contemporary art in his spacious and sparsely decorated white-on-white office, 48 floors above the northern Tokyo neighborhood of Ikebukuro, where his original store is located.
That formula and the group's spectacularly rapid growth have also bred an almost un-Japanese level of confidence. Many of the group's executives clearly feel they have far exceeded their one-time mentor -- Sears, Roebuck & Company. Executives from Mr. Tsutsumi's retailing companies used to go to Sears's headquarters in Chicago for training. And Mr. Tsutsumi said he was spurred to undertake his frantic diversification by Sears's moves nearly a decade ago into securities and real estate. But, said one of Saison's executives, "We surpassed the teacher in many ways."
 
A Mountain of Debt
 Even so, it is becoming apparent that Mr. Tsutsumi has been better at creating than managing. His expansionary zeal has been aided by a genius for intuiting fads and a willingness to use his own artistic image as a marketing tool. But it has also been marked by a hard-driving style that sometimes leaves his executives terrified and by a virtual mania for delving into new businesses. And that has left him with a mountain of debt. With interest rates having doubled in the past 18 months, the pressure is on.
"This is a very fast plane flying very low to the ground on very little fuel," said Mike Allen, the retailing analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, stockbrokers.
The Saison Group, with 124,000 employees, had net sales in the fiscal year that ended last March 31 of $31.8 billion. It declines to release earnings numbers, nor will it disclose its total debt. But a look at some of the major components gives an indication of the debt's magnitude. Seiyu, the group's supermarket chain, had consolidated bank borrowings of $6.9 billion as of February, nearly 10 times its shareholders' equity of $725 million. Figures were recently leaked to a magazine here showing that the private Seibu chain, Japan's largest department store operator, had another $2.5 billion in debt, which was supported by operating profits of just $28.8 million in the last fiscal year.
Because of these pressures -- and the fact that Mr. Tsutsumi has said he is slowly withdrawing from active management -- the Saison Group is now at a crossroads. It can no longer afford to simply add to the unusual conglomerate that Mr. Tsutsumi created, analysts say. Instead, it must focus on making the parts work together.
Indeed, behind the torrid growth rate and its attendant risks is Mr. Tsutsumi's still unproven belief that the more than 100 businesses he controls will naturally weld themselves into a complex "information network" that will enhance the value of the whole. Information garnered through the group's credit card and retailing operations, for instance, is supposed to help determine a customer's travel and housing needs.
That was the theory behind Mr. Tsutsumi's boldest acquisition, the purchase of Inter-Continental Hotels two years ago for $2.2 billion, much of which had to be borrowed.
"It was typical of Seiji that he was willing to throw the company into something new, even though the price was more than we could really justify by the returns alone," said Yuji Tsutsumi, Seiji's younger half-brother, who left Yoshiaki's Prince Hotel chain after a dispute and became chairman of Seiji's Inter-Continental operation. "We didn't just get assets; we bought into a business network. Without taking advantage of all the synergies, this is not a good deal."
 The Saison Group also has a number of joint ventures, ranging from Sears, in insurance, to Thomas Cook, the British travel company, and France's Club Mediterranee. Last April, Saison and Hermes, the French fashion house, formed a venture which controls Jean-Louis Scherrer, another French couture house.
One key problem facing Saison is Mr. Tsutsumi's habit of forging loose links between group members; some companies are less than 25 percent owned by Mr. Tsutsumi or his entities. The ties involve strategic coordination and the pull of his personality.
"It's true that the existence of the group owes a lot to the personality of Mr. Tsutsumi," said Seiichi Mizuno, the recently named president of Seibu. "But gradually, it is hoped that the members of the group will function more individually and with cohesion as an organic entity, even without Mr. Tsutsumi. This is not a conglomerate, but an organic entity, like a living thing."
The 44-year-old Mr. Mizuno, a thoughtful man with a salt-and-pepper mop of hair, is rumored to be heir apparent.
He proved his mettle helping launch Seed and Loft, two new stores that, with hip graphics and trendy merchandise, deepened the group's image as being in touch with fashion-conscious Japanese youth. And Mr. Mizuno also happens to be Mr. Tsutsumi's brother-in-law. Even that tale is unusual.
More than a decade ago, Mr. Tsutsumi sought to marry a former geisha, now Asako Tsutsumi, after divorcing his first wife, Motoko. The union would have been socially unacceptable, so he corrected the problem in a time-honored fashion, arranging for a prominent friend to adopt her. That gave her the legitimacy needed for the marriage.
The maneuver was a throwback to an era of delicate samurai etiquette. The friend was Shigeo Mizuno, also a former Communist, who put in place the pieces of what later came to be called Fujisankei, a major media group. Mr. Mizuno is Seiichi's father.
 
Dizzying Array
 Part of the Saison Group's current difficulty is that it takes something of a poet's mind to fathom the links between the dizzying array of companies Mr. Tsutsumi has assembled. They make tofu, steel and fertilizer, build and run resorts, operate supermarkets, build homes, run one of the country's largest credit card operations, import Chryslers and Head sporting gear, trade oil products and run restaurants.
"If you examine them closely, you can see that he really runs a big venture capital business," explained Takayuki Suzuki, who was an executive at the group for 20 years and now is a retailing analyst at Merrill Lynch Japan. "They use their assets to borrow money and then use that to finance a broad range of new businesses."
One effect of the current transition is that more members of the group are likely to go public to boost their finances. One candidate: Inter-Continental Hotels.
"That would be an exciting opportunity that we would consider seriously," said Yuji Tsutsumi. Saison has already sold a 40 percent interest in the hotel operation to Scandinavian Air Systems for $500 million, but is still trying to ease the debt burden. "For the time being, more help is needed in financing what it has to do," Yuji conceded.
In the meantime, the hotel operation is undergoing a rethinking in which it will expand in Eastern Europe through its Forum chain, and move some of its other hotels slightly down-market to appeal to a younger Japanese clientele, Yuji explained. It is also spending heavily to refurbish some of the older hotels.
"I don't know if you can manage a group like that, in the end," said Barclays's Mr. Allen of a strategy that would make some parts of the business public and others not. Added Merrill Lynch's Mr. Suzuki, "What they really need to do is make the parts work together finally."
If Saison can pull that off, say some observers, the payoff would be enormous. "They are now getting to a point where they can begin harvesting the seeds they have sown," said Segio Sugioka, a noted retailing expert who said he had long been a skeptic about the group because of its weak bottom line, low wages and haste in expanding.
"In the short term," he added, "the group will probably be in the red because of their debt, but over time, the accumulation of capital will be gigantic. These are mostly high cash-flow businesses, and they are in areas where the Japanese economy is growing fastest."
That area is consumer services. The service sector now accounts for more than 60 percent of gross national product, nearly equal to the level in the United States.
Saison, in fact, has helped define a new generation of restless consumers searching, with their wallets full of yen, for the image of soulfulness and individuality that Mr. Tsutsumi has projected onto his companies.
"The largest benefit for us in being part of the group is what happened to our corporate image, which came from just being associated with the name," said Masato Suzuki, president of I&S, an advertising agency that joined the group a few years ago when Mr. Tsutsumi acquired a large minority stake.
That is a sign of the times here. Young consumers have emerged from Japan's headlong rush toward economic dominance with a growing appetite for the one thing most Japanese companies are ill-equipped to provide -- meaning. Mr. Tsutsumi has made an art of satisfying their urge to feel they are more than cogs in Japan Inc.
 
Spicy Tidbits
 It does not hurt, of course, that tales of his longstanding rivalry with his brother Yoshiaki -- one of the wealthiest people in the world, with a fortune estimated at $7 billion -- fill the press here, including spicy tidbits about the notorious womanizing of their father, Yasujiro, who was known as Pistol for his willfulness and quick temper.
Pistol Tsutsumi built his fortune in railroads and property before World War II, then expanded it significantly afterward, in part by snapping up the holdings of financially ruined members of the nobility. His Tokyo Prince Hotel rests atop what had been the cemetery of the Tokugawas, the family that ruled Japan for 270 years as military dictators, or shoguns.
Seiji Tsutsumi's soft-edged public image is set off by Yoshiaki's reputation as a dictatorial manager. While Yoshiaki is often seen counseling leaders of the conservative ruling political party, Seiji's advertising company, I&S, produced an innovative and amusing campaign for the opposition Socialist Party in the last election, despite his professed distance from politics now.
Mr. Tsutsumi admitted in an interview that some reports of the brothers' feuding are slightly exaggerated, but serve the purpose of keeping them in the news. "When it comes to magazines, peace doesn't make articles," he said.
Some who work for Mr. Tsutsumi say his benevolent public image does not quite square with reality either. "He is a very cynical person and can be brutal in his criticism," said one long-time executive. "The image he projects to the outside and the image he projects to the inside are quite different."
A widespread complaint is that he sometimes resides in his own world and can be difficult to understand. "Even being his brother, it's sometimes hard to know what he's getting at," said Yuji Tsutsumi, who nonetheless credited Seiji with having a keen sense for marketing.
All the same, he has been a remarkable phenomenon. His presence at Saison will be hard to replicate for a new generation grappling with an uncertain future.
"We all see the centrifugal forces at work, so we need a center," said Mr. Mizuno. "Up to now, we have been able to maintain the group because of Mr. Tsutsumi's character. His strong presence acts as the centripetal force holding it all together. You might get the impression that he's a kind of czar, but that's not the case. Rather than holding it together with power, he holds it together by allowing people freedom to give play to their individual abilities. I think that's a very important part of the group that we must preserve somehow."
 
 
A FEW WORDS ON LOS ANGELES
 Seiji Tsutsumi has spent his life building a literary career as well as a business empire. Under the pen name Takashi Tsujii, he published the following poem, "Letter From America," in 1964, shortly after returning from several months in Los Angeles, where he failed in trying to establish a Seibu department store. The poem, which first appeared in a book called "Letter With No Address," was translated by Hisao Kanaseki and Timothy Harris.
 
Steel sheets flow out in long belts
 Keeping a quiet rhythm.
 The evening glow paints the sky a flaming red.
 People line up who have forgotten they were once created by people
 and flow like magnetic sands on a magnet.
 There, on the continent that was proclaimed to be new,
 love is no more than a crudely fashioned machine.
 I, like you, am alone
 and drink salt in the dawn.
 
 People seek solace in far fields,
 leaving the cities at a hundred miles an hour.
 They eat exactly the same food,
 importing chopsticks from the Orient,
 cooked raspberries from Alaska,
 creating fads which denounce fads,
 only faintly remembering that they,
 as embryos,
 looked like fish, turtles, bulls.
 Tropical rhythms beat out
 from speakers built into walls, coating the glittering steel.
 I am alone.
 You are alone.
 In the conference room
 the gavel shrieks of everlasting prosperity.
 
Reprinted by permission of the author.
 
 
 
GOING AFTER THE NATION'S YOUTH
 A GOOD place to see the Saison Group's heady stew of marketing, retailing and property development in action is Tsukashin, a shopping center it developed in Osaka.
With studied care, the outdoor shopping center groups numerous stores in a casual pattern to create the organic feeling of a village, with a large Seibu department store acting as an anchor. But the most important element is a church.
That is an odd sight in this Buddhist and Shinto country. And no matter that it is used mostly for weddings. Seibu's planners recognized that in the popular mind, a church conjures up an appealing image of quaint American or English towns. It lends an unthreatening foreign touch that Japanese consumers generally find irresistible.
Seibu's transformation of Shibuya, a central Tokyo neighborhood, is another example of the group's style.
Several decades ago, the area was well known for its massage parlors, peep shows and dark bars. Seibu first built a large department store there, and then added several of its newer retailing offshoots: Parco, which houses a jumble of fashion boutiques in a single building; Loft, which sells housewares, sporting goods and gifts; Seed, a fashion shop laid out in a trendy "dramatic space," and Wave, a pulsating music store.
Over time, the combination of stores transformed the area into a magnet for younger Japanese. Marked by the Seibu chain's avant-garde buildings and bright graphics, all in Roman letters, Shibuya has become a major shopping district.
Shibuya now provides a type of controlled chaos that allows young Japanese to feel they are expressing themselves, but in a tame way that weds their restlessness with the habit of consuming.
"Nowadays, youth would like to rebel against their fathers, or any fatherly figure," said Seiji Tsutsumi, Seibu's chairman. "They want to say, 'I'm different,' but not fight or overcome or pull their fathers down, as in the days when fathers were real barbarians, real dictators."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Old St. Alan's Gift: A 30-Minute Trading Spree

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
It was almost Christmas, and so the time was right for a present from the Federal Reserve. Even more nicely, it came with a little candy cane for traders who could act quickly.
The Fed's decision last week to cut the discount rate, at which it lends to banks, was announced half an hour before the markets closed. That gave quick traders time to buy before the slower ones could react, and thus to make a little money. The Fed used to made such announcements when markets were closed, but this time it evidently wanted to stimulate a quick reaction. 
 It succeeded. Prices of stocks and bonds zoomed within minutes, but by the next day it was back to dull markets, and the Dow Jones industrial average ended the week up 39.85, to 2,633.66, a four-month high but not far above the level reached minutes after the Fed acted.
One explanation for the short-lived nature of the rally was that President Bush took time out from the minority scholarship mess to proclaim that he would not soon fight for lower capital gains taxes. Who'd have thought it? The President plays Scrooge, while the Fed chairman puts on the Santa Claus suit.
There is not, to put it mildly, a lot of holiday cheer in the financial district. The banks and the brokers, who used to be eager to invade each other's turf, now seem to be competing to see who can lay off more workers, and there is a widespread belief that a lot of pink slips are being delayed until after the holidays.
It was that glum atmosphere that the Fed set out to cheer, and it was appropriate that it threw in a little something extra for the traders. For this was a year in which almost everything went down.
The important question, of course, is what impact the Fed's easing will have on the economy. The banks should be helped, as lower interest rates are passed on more rapidly to depositors than to borrowers. And maybe lower rates will help some borrowers to survive.
But those lower rates for depositors will also mean falling incomes for a lot of Americans, notably retirees. And it is unlikely that borrowing will soon pick up, A.T.& T.'s $6 billion line of credit notwithstanding. "The banks have nobody to lend to," says Chuck Clough, Merrill Lynch's chief investment strategist. Or, to be more precise, nobody who is sure to pay them back. Mr. Clough thinks short-term rates will fall sharply.
This recession has hit the hardest at financial services, but there are signs that all service industries are in trouble -- McDonald's is experimenting with discounted hamburgers. "The inventories of service industries are people," notes Mr. Clough, who foresees many more layoffs.
Still, there are reasons for hope, even if they are hard to see on Wall Street. The manufacturing sector has not caved in, and exports are rising nicely. Inflation is under control despite Saddam Hussein and the Fed evidently is serious about trying to get business moving. Its actions may not help much very soon, but in the current depressed environment, any piece of good news ought to be treasured.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
A Paper Company That Loves Itself

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
In the interest of full disclosure, the author of this column is a biblioholic whose favorite possessions are all catalogued in the Library of Congress and whose patron saint is Elbert Hubbard. Mr. Hubbard, writing almost a century ago in The Philistine magazine, warned that "this will never be a civilized country until we expend more money for books than we do for chewing gum." His disciples see a bookstore purchase as a contribution to the advancement of civilization.
The odds are that those purchases, seasonal and otherwise, also contribute indirectly to the coffers of the P.H. Glatfelter Company, an utterly endearing corporation based in Spring Grove, Pa. The Glatfelter people, in business for more than 125 years, make the paper that makes the books that fill the shelves and shopping bags of America. 
 But while the rest of us have been buying books, the Glatfelters have been shopping, too -- for their own shares, traded on the American Stock Exchange. The company apparently thinks its stock is a fine long-term investment. And some savvy Wall Street investors agree.
 While paper and forest product stocks have recently begun to outperform a sluggish market, paper manufacturers generally are not a popular choice when recession is at the door because they are seen as incurably cyclical, zigging and zagging with each spasm in the economy.
However, P.H. Glatfelter is not really in the same boat as, say, the Weyerhaeuser Company or Georgia-Pacific. Its specialty is uncoated publishing papers of all sizes, with a growing sideline in recycled printing stock. Jean M. Auel's latest best-seller, "The Plains of Passage," is printed on Glatfelter's recycled paper, for example, and the company has supplied the stock for countless Book-of-the-Month Club editions, including Anne Rice's "The Witching Hour" and Steven King's "Four Past Midnight." Indeed, about 30 of every 100 pages bound between hard covers these days are made by Glatfelter.
While this niche business is less cyclical than the market for commodity grades of paper, no one in Spring Grove, or on Wall Street, would suggest that the Glatfelter company is immune to hard times. (It is not unfamiliar with them either; surviving the Great Depression with one's business more or less intact probably puts today's economic downturn into perspective.) Although the company managed to generate strong sales in the first nine months of this year, earnings were lower than in the same period last year, as higher labor costs and lower product prices have squeezed profit margins. The current quarter looks strong, said M. Alanson (Jake) Johnson 2d, the company's chief financial officer, "but obviously, we don't know how tough it will be going forward."
Nor is the Glatfelter company untouched by the increasing concern about the environment. Long careful with its production processes, it plans to spend about $125 million over the next few years to make its Spring Grove pulp mill more nature-friendly. Even for a company with 1989 sales of more than $600 million, that is real money.
But there is one current problem this old-fashioned company does not worry about: the credit crunch. It seems to view debt the way an intelligent teetotaler views alcohol -- a substance with some rare medicinal uses, but one that should never be employed on a habitual basis. The company borrowed $179 million in May 1987 to buy the Ecusta Corporation, which makes the wispy-thin paper sold to cigarette manufacturers. The therapeutic purpose was to expand the company's business into a more recession-resistant line. And by September 1989, the loan was fully paid off.
At the same time, the company has sustained a pace of growth in its sales and earnings that would be the envy of many heavily leveraged companies. Analysts for Mabon, Nugent & Company note that Glatfelter's average annual return on equity and return on assets over the past decade "are the highest in our paper universe, outpacing the group averages by 50 percent and 90 percent respectively." They expect Glatfelter to generate a 20.7 percent return on shareholder equity this year, dipping to a still-respectable 17 percent next year.
But Joseph V. Battipaglia, director of research for the Gruntal Company and an early Glatfelter fan, says the most intriguing thing about the company is how it chooses to use its spare cash. It buys back its own shares -- by the millions.
By 1985, after numerous stock splits, Glatfelter had about 25.8 million shares outstanding, adjusted for subsequent splits. Today, it has just 22.6 million shares outstanding. And last Wednesday, its board authorized the repurchase of another 1 million shares through open-market and private transactions over the coming year.
 In October, Mr. Battipaglia noticed that Glatfelter had purchased 800,000 shares from Ruane, Cunniff & Company, the Wall Street investment firm whose nose for investment values is nearly legendary. (He sees no bearishness in this sale, by the way; Ruane, Cunniff still owns about 2.5 million of the company's shares, making it one of Glatfelter's largest stakeholders after the heirs of the founding family.) The transaction, done a bit below the market price of about $33.50, cost nearly $27 million. "They paid cash," Mr. Battipaglia said. "They just cut a check. And they're still debt-free."
It would be hard to argue with the past wisdom of investing in Glatfelter. Adjusted for splits, the shares climbed almost nine-fold during the past decade, and closed on Friday at $41.25. Prior to 1985, the company, wanting to improve the liquidity of its shares, had avoided buybacks. "By then, though, that wasn't as big a concern," Mr. Johnson said. "And we had been running around like chickens with our heads cut off trying to find good acquisitions, and none of them measured up to the value of our own company. Finally we said, 'Here's a good company right here.' So we started buying."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A Last-Minute Gift List

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Looking for a cheap last-minute Christmas gift? Joel Tillinghast has some ideas. Mr. Tillinghast manages the $80 million Fidelity Low-Priced Stock Fund, a grab bag stuffed with stocks that sell for less than $15.
While small stocks have taken a real beating this fall, his quirky picks have enabled his fund to take less of a hit than its peers. The fund, which celebrates its first birthday this week, was down 3.1 percent at the end of November. That compared to an 8.9 percent drop for the 77 small-company stock funds tracked by Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants, and to a 21.8 percent drop in the NASDAQ index. 
 One reason is that the 32-year-old Mr. Tillinghast runs a defensive portfolio. When the market sours, most small-company funds fall through the floor. But Mr. Tillinghast's fund, despite its focus, "is a legitimate value-oriented fund, not an aggressive, bouncy type," said Eric M. Kobren, publisher of Fidelity Insight, an independent investment newsletter based in Wellesley, Mass. "Over the long term, he'll do well."
There is certainly a market for low-priced stocks. Curious investors support 20 or so newsletters about them, proving that these stocks have a built-in constituency.
Fidelity's has a $15 cutoff for purchases. And low stock prices give a boost to the fund's philosophy: Buy low (very low); sell high. Its small-company turf is a natural segue from Mr. Tillinghast's apprenticeship with Morris Smith, who was running Fidelity's Over-the-Counter Fund when the two worked together in the late 1980's. (Mr. Smith, of course, now runs Magellan). Both Mr. Smith and Mr. Tillinghast look for growth companies at value prices; Mr. Tillinghast gets an extra bang because of his bargain-basement prices, "like the people who bought Chrysler for $4 in the early 80's," he said.
Clearly, he can sniff out value. Stocks in the fund sell at eight times earnings, compared to a marketwide price/earnings ratio of 12. The median market capitalization of companies in the portfolio is less than $50 million.
 The fund's biggest bet is a basket of British utilities; 18 percent of the fund's assets are wrapped up in four British water companies privitized by the Thatcher government about a year ago: Northumbrian Water (current price, roughly $5.55), Welsh Water ($5.35), Southwest Water ($5.10) and Severn Trent Water ($4.60). Mr. Tillinghast says the companies have strong balance sheets, sell at only five times earnings and yield about 7 percent. Unlike American utilities, these have a chance to soar: After five years of heavy spending by the utilities to upgrade the mediocre British water, the Government is allowing them to jack up water prices.
One of the fund's first holdings was Frederick's of Hollywood, the Beverly Hills-based retailer that sells mainly lingerie. When Mr. Tillinghast bought the stock last winter, the price had sunk to $8 because of problems with its retail stores: "They had too many sex toys, which kept the average customer away," he said. Management has since refocused sales on lingerie and given the stores a "better-lit, more romantic atmosphere," said Mr. Tillinghast, who sold his shares for $10.
 He also has invested in Thomas Nelson Publishers ($10.375), a bible and religious-gift company based in Nashville. "This seems to be a counter-cyclical business -- when the economy gets tough and people are depressed and troubled, they turn to religion. So business is very good right now." He expects earnings to grow about 20 percent over the next two or three years.
 Ryan's Family Steak House ($5.625), a Greer, S.C.-based restaurant chain, has "the highest ratio of food cost to revenue in the country," Mr. Tillinghast says. For customers, that means getting a big meal for the average $6 dinner ticket. The company is almost debt-free and internally finances expansion of new restaurants at rate of 15 percent annually, Mr. Tillinghast says. He expects earnings and sales to rise 19 percent a year over the next five years.
His smallest holding is Bingo King ($2.625), based in Littleton, Colo., a company that manufactures Bingo equipment, has a market capitalization of $7.5 million and sells at five times earnings.
 In financial services, Mr. Tillinghast likes the United Federal Bank Corporation ($8.875) in State College, Pa., which sticks to the local market, an economically stable college town, and does "little wild real estate speculation," he said. It has a ratio of 18 percent equity-to-assets, triple what is needed for a savings and loan to be called well capitalized, and less than 1 percent of its assets are in non-performing loans, he said.
The Grant Street National Bank ($0.41) in Pittsburgh, is a spinoff of the Mellon Bank designed to get all of Mellon's bad assets off its books. It has paid off nearly all of its debt in the past two years, and management gives quarterly estimates of the liquidation value after all sales are completed. The latest: 90 cents a share, or more than double the share price.
 Can't decide what to buy? Buy a piece of the fund itself ($9.35); there is no sales charge, but the minimum investment is $2,500.

 
 
INCOME FUNDS OUT OF SYNC
 For the first half of 1990, the total returns for domestic and world income funds moved in tandem. But that reversed sharply in the third quarter, largely because the value of the American dollar plunged against foreign currencies. There is an unmistakable nervousness among investors about the strength of the domestic economy and the risks down the road.
What comes next? After the dollar falls far enough, American exports become cheaper and the economy picks up steam. At some point, the dollar will stabilize and the funds' performance should move into approximate alignment again.
No one knows when that will happen, of course; investors must make their own bets about which way the dollar is headed. But you can remove some risk from the equation by staying with short-term funds, which are less subject to price fluctuations than the long-term ones.

HEADLINE: Four Formulas for Avoiding the Mess in Banking

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Like a container of rotten food that makes an entire refrigerator smell bad, the problems of troubled banks are casting a pall over the industry.
But only about 1,000 of the nation's 12,400 banks are in serious enough trouble to be labeled by regulators as "problems," although their troubles are great enough to threaten the solvency of the Government-run deposit insurance fund. Their problems also obscure the fact that nearly 90 percent of the country's banks are still earning profits. Many banks are even managing to increase profits despite the weakening economy and problems with commercial real estate loans. 
 Four good examples of this are First Wachovia Corporation in Winston-Salem, N.C.; State Street Boston Corporation in Boston; Banc One Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, and BankAmerica Corporation in San Francisco. There are other successful banks, but these four illustrate how careful management and a focus on specific lines of business have helped companies avoid banking's current problems and left them poised for additional growth and profits.
The successful formulas in banking, many of which these four banks have skillfully adopted, are not deep secrets. Banking executives often cite four elements: The most important is the ability to avoid making bad loans, which seems obvious in an industry where just a 5 percent default rate is a sign of serious trouble, but is nevertheless at the root of problems at many banks.
Another is the presence of a strong consumer business that provides a stable source of deposits on which low interest rates are paid to depositors while offering opportunities to make high-interest loans. The third is development of fee-producing businesses, like corporate cash management accounts or credit card service systems.
Finally, many successful banks have learned the importance of the diversification of business by geography and product.
These successful strategies may not necessarily endure into the 1990's. A change in Federal law to allow banks to be owned by other kinds of businesses has been widely discussed in Washington. It would probably attract new investors with different ideas about making money in banking.
"If bankers do not keep up with changes, even their good busineses could become the dinasaurs of the 1990's," said James McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm.

 
 
FIRST WACHOVIA
A Strategy Of Moderation
 When bankers talk about First Wachovia Corporation, the conversation invariably turns to the company's exemplary record of avoiding bad loans.
Based in Winston-Salem, N.C., First Wachovia eschewed the rapid growth in commercial real estate lending and financing of corporate takeovers in the late 80's. In 1987 and 1988, for example, when other banks rapidly expanded their commercial real estate lending because they saw no other way to generate profits, Wachovia pulled in the reins. "I was a little unpopular with some of my colleagues by saying it was time to slow down on real estate," said John Medlin, Wachovia's chairman.
But now, with defaults mounting on commercial real estate loans across the country, Wachovia is reaping the rewards of a lending system that relies on the separation of powers -- and competition between -- lending officers whose bonuses are based in part on how many loans they can issue and loan administration officers whose job is to make sure bad loans are not issued. In the last year, the company has been charging off as a loss less than half of 1 percent of its loans, a significantly lower rate than other large banks in its region.
To supplement its lending business, Wachovia has invested heavily in corporate cash management products -- such services as helping companies conserve cash by paying bills at the last possible moment -- and became a leader in this area. As a result, the bank can open doors at large corporations that might not otherwise consider doing business with a bank that ranks only 29th in the country.
Mr. Medlin said the stable, predictable flow of fee-producing businesses, like servicing student loans and credit card fees, which provided about a third of the company's total revenues of nearly $1.2 billion in 1989, "helps take some pressure off lending and gives us the luxury of not having to be aggressive at times when credit and pricing terms are deteriorating."
The years of successful lending have strengthened Wachovia's balance sheet to the point where it has more than twice as much shareholder capital as the minimum set by Federal regulators.
But Wachovia is more than just a skilled lender. Its diversified business includes a network of 363 branches, giving it more than a 20 percent share of North Carolina deposits and a 14 percent share in Georgia, where it bought a large bank in the mid-80's.
Bank officials like to say they bring a "high tech and high touch" philosophy to consumer banking. For example, Wachovia provides branch officers with a computer system that allows them to call up the file on every customer account. Each customer in North Carolina also has a personal banker who is qualified to handle every kind of consumer product a customer might want. Bank officials say such an approach and the bank's reputation for financial strength helps account for the 13.3 percent gain in consumer deposits over the last year.
 
Against the Grain Into the Global Market
State Street Boston Corporation has set two remarkable records this year. It managed to increase profits in the first nine months of the year despite the severe economic downturn in New England; and it has greatly expanded its foreign operations with four new offices, at a time when other banks are closing foreign offices and laying off staff.
As the nation's largest custodian and trustee for mutual funds and pension funds, State Street has long been a familiar name in the investment world. It is custodian for about 40 percent of the over $1 trillion of securities held by American mutual funds, and is the largest custodian and trustee for corporate pension funds.
The handling of securities and related record-keeping jobs in recent years produced a steady stream of profits that kept the company so occupied it was not tempted to plunge deeply into the lending business. Fiduciary fees, which now account for slghtly more than two-thirds of total revenues in 1989 of $676 million, grew 28 per cent annually in 1984 through 1989, and are up another 14 percent to $280 million in the first nine months of this year.
Although fees could decline as securities prices fall, State Street has been countering that possibility by developing a broad array of products related to its bread and butter record-keeping and safe-keeping businesses. State Street's executives believe the same companies that use it to keep track of pension fund investments might also need a cash management service, require foreign exchange trading, or need to hire State Street's trust department, the eighth largest in the country, to make investment decisions.
State Street is already the largest American bank that invests clients' funds abroad so that they equal the performance of foreign stock and bond markets. William S. Edgerly, the bank's chairman, said the bank's top priority is increasing its share in the global custody business of providing pension funds and others with the information they need about foreign exchange and securities markets to coordinate investment activities around the globe.
Although many larger banks are also pushing for the global custodian service business, State Street said it has kept pace. "Our focus on this business is better than some other very large banks that have fully diversified product lines," Mr. Edgerly said.
Like other New England Banks, State Street has been hit by a rash of loan defaults as the New England economy turned down. But the relatively small amount of lending, now $2.6 billion, or only about 18 percent of assets, compared with 60 percent at other banks, has kept the problem manageable. Losses from writing off bad loans nearly doubled to $32 million in the first nine months compared with a year ago, but the company still reported a 13 percent increase in profits, to $86 million from $76 million.
According to Mr. Edgerly, about 90 percent of State Street business lending is to New England middle-market businesses, an activity that he says will continue, despite recent setbacks. The company is almost completely out of the consumer loan business. It does not make home mortage or installment loans and recently agreed to sell its $425 million of credit card loans to the Household Corporation, a transaction that generated a profit of $60 million.
 
BANK ONE
Geographic Diversity In the Middle of the Road
 Ten years ago, Banc One Corporation was hardly known outside Columbus, Ohio. Today, after acquiring dozens of large and small banks, it is the nation's 24th largest banking company and a leader in the Ohio, Indiana, Wisconsin and Texas markets.
The geographic diversity of its business -- something that many larger banks have yet to achieve -- is complemented by self-imposed restrictions that limit its lending to local consumers and small- and medium-sized businesses. "When you limit yourself to consumer and small business loans, it's a lot harder to get into trouble," said John B. McCoy, Banc One's chairman. "If a $50 million loan goes bad, you feel it. But it takes an awful lot of small bad loans to equal one of those big losses."
All the banks operate with identical accounting structures and must make monthly reports of results and projections. This allows early identification of problems and promotes what company executives see as a healthy competition among the banks.
After a decade of acquisitons and rising profits, Banc One has accumulated enough capital so that it now holds $9.20 of shareholders capital for every $100 of assets, after adjusting for risk of the assets. This is more than twice the minimum Federal regulators have said they will require beginning in 1992, placing Banc One near the top of the industry.
Banc One's executives believe a key part of the success has been the development of technology to help the bank provide better service to customers and operate fee-producing businesses that further diversify the company's sources of income. In 1989, for example, its credit card business and record keeping and processing it does for others had revenues of $81.1 million. Other businesses, like its new system allowing members of the National Tire Dealers Association to run a quick credit check while a new customer's tires are being mounted, produced fees of $136.1 million, not counting fees on deposit accounts.
To replace its old accounting system, Banc One has joined Electronic Data Services, a subsidiary of General Motors, in a $100 million project to develop a new generation of computer software for record keeping.
"We want a system that tells us more about our customers than just their account file," said John Russell, the company's senior vice president. With more information, the bank could, for example, adjust the prices of various products depending on the customer.
 
Building Business On Consumer Service
 BankAmerica Corporation, with 850 branches in California and a rapidly growing network in nearby states, epitomizes the benefits of a well-honed system for collecting consumer deposits and making consumer loans.
The stable base of consumer deposits was vital to the company in the dark days of 1985-1987, when it lost more than $1.8 billion and was struggling with more than its share of bad loans and a costly overexpansion into foreign markets. Having survived that crisis and cut its foreign presence to 40 countries from 76, BankAmerica is focusing again on its local market, where its branch system and the strength of the California economy produced more than $1.1 billion in profits in 1989.
Much of the improvement came from changes in managing the branch system. "We moved a lot of people and operations out of the branches and into specialized regional centers," said Frank Newman, chief financial officer. "It's not a brilliant new idea, but we did it very intensively."
Routine accounting tasks like reconciling customer accounts have been shifted to 20 regional centers where economies of scale are greater. The same system has been applied to the lending business. The bank has five centers for processing home mortgage applications, four centers for other consumer loans and eight centers for business loans. Branches still help consumers fill out loan applications, but the evaluation of the applicant and the decision on the loan are done in the processing centers.
The result of these back-office changes has been the reduction of noninterest expenses as a percentage of interest and fee revenues to 61.9 percent in the third quarter of 1990, from 83.6 percent in the second quarter of 1987. A median level for the country's 50 largest banks is 65 per cent.
BankAmerica remains one of the nation's most active lenders to large corporations and is benefiting now from an ability to collect higher interest rates and fees as more banks abandon that business. Within California, it has reorganized its lending to small and midsized companies by keeping commercial loan officers only in 50 strategically placed branches. By eliminating loan officers in areas where opportunities are not great, it no longer has lenders who are tempted to justify their existence by making loans that eventually turn sour.
Flush with the profits of its California business and of the Seafirst Bank in Washington, which it bought in the mid-80's, BankAmerica is pushing to diversify the geographic base of its consumer business. In the last year it has spent more than $400 million to buy eight savings and loans or savings banks, adding 127 branches in Arizona and 66 in Oregon, two states where it had been active but did not have a branch.
Richard Rosenberg, an alumnus of Wells Fargo & Company who became chairman of BankAmerica earlier this year, talks of the day when laws are changed to allow nationwide banking and BankAmerica can take full advantage of an intangible asset -- its name. "Don't forget," he likes to say, "This is the Bank of America."
