HEADLINE: A Hot Market Emerges for the Third World's Bad Loans

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Behind the third world debt crisis, a market is bubbling.
The trading of the debt -- the swapping of often steeply discounted loans for cash, other loans or equities -- has grown in less than a decade into a $70 billion-a-year global market. While that is not big by the standards of foreign exchange, bond or stock trading, it is not bad either for a lot of paper that until this year was declining in value. 
 But this year, trading prices for the loans of most of the biggest debtors have been rising with a vengeance. The debt market has even been strong enough to rebound from the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis, a feat unmatched by the world's bond and stock markets and the dollar. Mexican debt is now trading at 45.625 cents per dollar of face value, up 30 percent for the year, and Argentina's debt, long one of the poorest performers, is up 70 percent, to 20 cents on the dollar. Of the major debtors, only Brazil has seen a decline.
"If you threw darts at the beginning of the year, you could not have lost money," said Giacomo de Filippis, one of the originators of debt trading while working for an Argentine bank and now head of his own firm in New York, Giadefi Inc.
Giving the market its lift are a number of ongoing economic restructurings that seem to augur a turning point for much of Latin America, which holds about 29 percent of the $1.3 trillion in third world debt.
The market has also gotten a boost from the debt-relief program initiated by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Under the Brady plan, several countries have had their debt burden reduced and have converted old loans into new bonds that are more attractive to investors because they are backed by international guarantees. As a sign of the growing acceptance of the debt-trading market, Mexico's so-called Brady bonds last week got their first rating from Moody's Investors Service Inc.
Besides causing debt prices to rise, the economic restructurings are altering the market's character and scope, offering new opportunities not only for some of the debtor countries but also for the big Western lenders who wrote off billions of dollars of loans in recent years when it became clear they would never be repaid.
Until recently, the debt has largely been the medium for a traditional trading market, a place in which Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover Trust, Morgan Guaranty, Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan, Bank of America and hundreds of other banks could try to improve the value of their bulging debt portfolios or just shed them. These trading operations, along with those at some investment banks, have also been used to speculate on the movement in debt prices, producing enough income so that some institutions, like Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, have highlighted the profits in their earnings reports.
Now, because of the economic turnabouts that have begun in Chile, Mexico and Venezuela, commercial and investment bankers are opening up a traditional corporate finance business in a debtor's setting, a move that could well spread to Eastern Europe. Two venerable investment banks, Morgan Stanley Group and Goldman, Sachs & Company, have been lured into the business this year.
IN some cases, the bankers are packaging the debt held by a number of lenders -- including themselves, at times -- and swapping it for shares in state-owned companies being sold to the public, like Entel, the telephone company in Argentina. As part of the deal, the new owners often infuse the privatized company with cash to modernize or expand.
In other cases, the bankers capitalize on their ties to the third world to be hired as traditional advisers in raising new capital. MG-First Boston Asset Trading acted in this capacity when Mexico's state-owned development bank went to the Eurobond market this year to raise $100 million.
While privatizations have buoyed the debt market in the past, they have never been conducted on such a scale or with such commercial appeal. In the last two years, privatizations and traditional corporate finance deals have brought $18.4 billion to the five major debtors in Latin America, according to Salomon Brothers's John F. H. Purcell.
"This is the transition year," said Peter R. Geraghty, senior vice president in New York of NMB Postbank Groep N.V., a Dutch bank that is one of the major debt traders. "The market evolves. The trading market is not the be-all and the end-all. It is now M.& A. and corporate finance."
The move away from trading for trading's sake and toward corporate finance is a logical one, banking experts say. The deals provide attractive fees for the bankers. They are also less risky than playing the debt market and, for the large debt holders, provide another avenue for getting rid of debt.
"If Mexico and Brazil and other countries turn around, then this market becomes the old, traditional, humdrum capital-raising business," said Peter Woika, a managing director at J. P. Morgan & Company, the parent of Morgan Guaranty.
The success of the business depends, of course, on the success of the economic restructurings that are going on. As long as the programs, like those in Mexico and Venezuela, move ahead, there will be a market for raising cash or doing privatizations.
But if they are set back -- and Brazil is having new problems less than a year after the start of its austerity program -- then the business could dry up.
DEBT trading is a product of the debt crisis that began in 1982, when it became obvious that many third world countries would not be able to pay back the huge loans that Western banks had made to the governments.
At first, the trading took the form of simple swaps. A bank would consolidate its debt portfolio, trading off debt from Chile, for example, for that of Mexico, a country in which it had more confidence. Some banks, especially smaller ones, then decided to get rid of the risk entirely, and sold debt for a portion of its face value.
Some privatization deals in Brazil, Chile and Mexico helped give the market another rationale in the mid-80's, but these debt-for-equity deals came and went.
The biggest boost for the market came in May 1987, when Citibank bowed to reality and became the first big bank to set aside reserves for anticipated losses from third world loans. Other banks followed, making the trading of debt at less than face value much easier.
By the end of the 80's it was obvious that banks were unwilling to lend new money to the debtors. It was also obvious that some reduction of the existing debt level would have to be accepted as part of a solution to the crisis. To this end, the Bush Administration in March 1989 announced the Brady plan, which offered debt reduction to countries that were restructuring their economies to reduce inflation and lift trade barriers.
In July of that year, Mexico reached an initial agreement on a proposal for a 35 percent reduction in its debt and the exchanging of the old loans for the Brady bonds. This deal was finalized last March, at the same time that Venezuela reached its own debt reduction agreement. Other deals have been reached with the Philippines, Costa Rica and Morocco.
Dealers in third world debt are hoping that the Brady bonds will make the market attractive to larger numbers of investors, even retail customers. The bonds come with guarantees on interest and principal and can be repackaged into a number of financial products with broad appeal.
New bond and debt funds, like the Latin American Investment Fund Inc. at Salomon Brothers, are trying to attract such business but most dealers think the wider appeal of this still-risky market will take more time to develop.
DEBT traders have many of the accouterments found in big-league trading rooms. There are computers on their desks and prices on the computers. They have the toys that traders collect, like the baseball bat and hand weights on Stephen W. Dizard's desk at Salomon Brothers and the joke doll stuck to the window of the trading room at Bankers Trust Company. Last week, they even formed their own trading association, a sure sign of arrival.
The market is maturing in other ways, too. Prices for buying or selling debt are getting easier to obtain.
But the market still does not have the pace or the size of its bigger cousins that deal in equities and bonds. When Henry Ansbacher & Company, a merchant banker involved in debt trading, had its Christmas party this year in London, the market there ground to a halt. And debt trading is far from a 24-hour game, even though traders are based around the world.
Indeed, debt trading is far from a full-fledged market. Prices may be easier to obtain, but there are no guarantees a quote will be available when a trader needs one. And traders must be prepared to negotiate even when they see a broker's quote on a computer screen, because those prices are not firm, as they are in the stock and bond markets.
Traders must also be aware of potential conflicts of interest since some of the big banks that trade debt also are involved in negotiating debt reductions under the Brady plan.
"A market has wide distribution of assets and information and a complete network of market makers and brokers," said Nicolas Rohatyn, a managing director of J. P. Morgan and head of the firm's loan transaction unit. "None of that exists here."
But now that the action in third world debt is turning more toward corporate finance, those shortcomings may be less glaring.
"You're looking at finite issues to finite people: one-of-a-kind deals," Mr. Rohatyn said. "This is more of a business than a market."
 
 
 
NEW MARKET, NEW ABUSES?
 Every financial market has the potential for abuse and the growing debt-trading market is no exception.
One of the most hotly debated aspects of the market concerns banks that trade the debt of a given country at the same time that they negotiate a debt reduction agreement with that country. Critics see an inherent conflict of interest in this practice, one that could allow the banks to profit from inside information.
Bank executives strongly deny the potential for abuse, contending that they keep their trading and negotiating operations separate. As evidence, one banking company, J. P. Morgan, says its traders took a major loss in 1989 when Morgan announced an increase in its reserves to reflect the worsening condition of its debt portfolio. The traders were holding large positions of the debt, whose prices tumbled.
Allegations of another type of potential abuse are the subject of an ongoing Federal grand jury investigation looking into the possible diversion of funds at the debt-trading operation of the Los Angeles-based Security Pacific Bank.
The investigation was prompted by a report given to bank executives early last year by several traders at Security Pacific in which they described a pattern of transactions involving a fellow trader, Antonio M. Angotti. Mr. Angotti, they said, sold debt at below-market prices to friends at other institutions, who then sold the debt at the market price.
Earlier this month, the Swiss Bank Corporation and NMB Postbank Groep N.V., a Dutch company, confirmed that they had been subpoenaed in connection with the investigation. Both companies said they are not targets of the probe.
Security Pacific, which conducted its own investigation of the allegations, closed down the New York-based debt-trading operation in April 1989. The bank says its investigation revealed nothing "requiring further action."
Rita E. Hauser, a lawyer for Mr. Angotti, denies that her client did anything wrong. She added that the Security Pacific investigation cleared Mr. Angotti, who left the bank after the trading operation closed to become a White House fellow.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Dow and a Decade of Discount Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
The conventional wisdom is that the Federal Reserve Board delivered a giant Christmas gift to Wall Street last week by cutting the discount rate a half-point, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. And figures collected by the archivists at Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in New York, show how such assumptions arose.
Not counting this recent action, the Fed has cut the discount rate by a half-point or more on 25 occasions during the past decade. The Birinyi folks checked to see where the Dow Jones industrial average stood three months after a major discount rate cut. And, in 18 of the 25 cases, the Dow was higher. Pretty reassuring, huh?
But before you uncork the champagne, look carefully at the record during the brief economic downturn in the first half of 1980 and the much deeper recession that began in July 1981 and continued through November 1982. Despite a lot of pushing and shoving from the Fed, the market didn't start to rebound until the recession was nearly over. Aspirin, anyone?

HEADLINE: All About/Smelling Good;
Two Crucial Days In Scent Peddling

BYLINE: By JOSH KURTZ

 BODY:
EVERY holiday season, the fragrance industry gets nervous. With more than 50 percent of annual sales taking place in the weeks before Christmas -- most in the last two days -- fragrance companies are like children wondering how bountiful their holiday will be.
 With more than 800 fragrances on the United States market and a notoriously fickle public, the companies seldom experience the blissful state their products are meant to induce. The industry always seems hyperactive, introducing an average of 60 new products a year. And in the past 18 months, many industry giants have found themselves with new owners or altered fortunes. This holiday season is the first in more than 25 years that Avon Products Inc., the perennial leader in women's fragrances, has not been No. 1. 
 Marketing is the key. Industry executives say that in a $25, four-ounce bottle of scent, the fluid and bottle cost the maker about $3.75. Add on marketing and some profit, and it goes to the retailer as about $15, where another marketing/profit chunk is added.
 
The Players
Unilever Outstrips Avon and Revlon
 The new ruler of both the men's and women's fragrance markets is Unilever N.V.-P.L.C., the Anglo-Dutch consumer products and chemicals conglomerate. Unilever built its lead the 1980's way: by taking over other companies. It stormed into the fragrance business in 1987, and in 1989 alone, spent more than $2 billion to acquire companies including Faberge Inc., Elizabeth Arden Inc. and Calvin Klein Cosmetics, the maker of Obsession and Eternity perfumes. Analysts expect more acquisitions to come, as Unilever seeks to preserve or extend its lead.
In the still-fragmented $1.83 billion-a-year women's fragrance market, Unilever, with a 12.6 percent market share, now seems secure. But its closest competitors, Avon and Revlon, are not far behind.
At Avon, some investors have been making a stink about the stock's fall from $41 a share in mid-1989 to about $27 recently. On Dec. 3, Chartwell Associates, an alliance of dissatisfied Avon shareholders, urged the company to repurchase $500 million of its common or preferred shares. Chartwell, which holds 26.2 percent of Avon's outstanding common stock and 19.8 percent of the voting shares, has hired Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. for advice. Avon's chairman, James E. Preston, said he would not respond until his committee on ways to enhance shareholder value releases its report in January.
Third-place Revlon, meanwhile, introduced a major new fragrance this year. It's Unforgettable, considered revlon's most ambitious start-up since Charlie, launched 16 years ago. It comes in a skinny bottle that looks like an Art Deco skyscraper and at a price of $23 for a 1.6-ounce bottle, higher than most other Revlon fragrances.
Revlon officials said the product was launched to capitalize on the company's "Unforgettable Women" advertising campaign, which has featured actresses Melanie Griffith and Susan Lucci, and Barbara Sinatra with her well-known husband.
The company -- led by Ronald Perelman, the master of leveraged buyouts -- has come under criticism for its stodginess, its reliance on low-priced fragrances and the steep discounting of its "junk bonds." With Unforgettable, "they finally decided to do something after 17 years," said Andrew Shore, a fragrance industry analyst at Prudential-Bache.
The smaller men's market, which includes aftershaves, has gone through some reformulation as well. In July, the Procter & Gamble Company bought the toiletries and fragrance division of the Shulton Group -- makers of Old Spice, the leading men's fragrance -- from the American Cyanimid Company for $370 million.
Under American Cyanamid, Old Spice and other Shulton products had stagnated because the company hesitated to spend on the necessary marketing, analysts say. Cyanamid's profits from the Shulton Group dropped from $52 million in 1988 to $18 million a year later.
Both the Shulton sale and the Avon shareholders' dispute are likely to help these companies in the long run, analysts say, by sharpening their focus and adding energy.
 
The Battlefields
From Glitzy Aisles To the Drugstore
 Like many fragrances today, Unforgettable can be bought in huge department stores like Macy's, in elegant boutiques and in discount drugstores like Duane Reade, an aisle or two away from mouthwash and dental floss. Some industry executives question whether a product loses its luster when it is so readily available. Not so, says Annette Green, executive director of the Fragrance Foundation, a trade group.
"Every industry is going to have to go where the customers are, not where they want to be," she said. "You can't just be in the Bergdorf Goodmans."
The biggest sales battles are fought on department store floors. Major retailers depend on cosmetics, toiletries and fragrances for about 9 percent of their sales, said Joseph Siegel, director of the National Retail Association's merchandising division. "That's why impulse items, like fragrances, are generally on the main floor," he said. "People go out of their way to buy furniture. They don't go out of their way to buy a tube of lipstick.
The fragrance companies are so intent on securing prime space for their products that they often pay retailers for prominent displays, and supply their own sales help. Retailers often have to referee squabbles among fragrance companies for the best positions.
"A lot of it is based on the expected volume level," said Michelle Williams, group fragrance manager for Bloomingdale's in New York. "We want to present to the customers what we think they're looking for."
Counter position, fancy bottling and ambitious marketing may mean nothing in an economic downturn. Consumers who until recently boughe different fragrances -- for work, recreation and romance -- are scaling back, buying just one. "In good times, you're willing to experiment with two or three scents," said Mr. Shore. "But not now."
Ms. Green is less pessimistic. "Everybody cries the blues in December until the last 48 hours before Christmas," she said. "We're probably on firmer ground than a lot of product categories. It's a gift that doesn't break the bank. And it's always easy for men to buy, because you don't have to get a size or a color."
 
The Tinkering
Trying to Please Fickle Consumers
 Since the late 1960's, fragrance buyers have become notoriously disloyal, adopting and abandoning new products as fast as the companies could turn them out. This year, along with a less-robust economy, the fragrance industry has suffered from an apparent shift in consumer tastes. Just as the new decade has brought an end to many excesses and indulgences, women's tastes in fragrances have become moderate and simpler.
"The passions and poisons and obsessions of the world have given in to the florals," Mr. Shore said. "We have definitely seen a return to the classics." Some of the beneficiaries of these trends, he said, are two long-popular Chanel products, No. 5 and CoCo, and another old reliable, Shalimar, from the French cosmetics company, Guerlain.
This hasn't stopped the industry from tinkering. International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., the nation's leading developer of scents, did $870 million of business in 1989 and works on hundreds of different products at a time, sometimes for competitors. Launching a new fragrance is no easy proposition; it can cost manufacturers $5 million to $30 million, depending on the amount of marketing.
The next olfactory fad, analysts say, will be "behavioral fragrances" -- mintier products that will be marketed to suggest that they make people more alert or give them a spiritual lift. Sarah Friend, director for fragrance evaluation at International Flavors, doubts that they will truly have such miraculous powers. But they might make people feel good. "You don't need a Ph.D to tell me that putting orange flowers in your tub is going to make you relax," she said. "You wear fragrance to give yourself a lift."
Lift, it would appear, lies in variety. "There are so many fragrances on the market today," observed Ms. Green, "it's nose-boggling."
 
 
 
IN GROWTH, IT'S A MAN'S WORLD
 Insects and animals have their own mating scents, and some humans do, too, at least those of the male variety. In a recent Gallup Organization survey of 808 men for the Fragrance Foundation, 21 percent identified what the foundation called a "killer cologne" as their choice to wear when trying to attract members of the opposite sex.
In the United States, women's fragrances still far outsell men's, by $1.83 billion to $860 million last year. But the men's total represented a 7.5 percent gain from 1988, compared with 5.2 percent for women. "Men are recognizing that vanity is not a terrible thing," said Andrew Shore, a fragrance industry analyst for Prudential-Bache. In the Gallup survey, 89 percent of the men said they had used aftershave or cologne in the previous six months, and half said they used it five times or more in the week before they were interviewed.
Indeed, the men's market appears to have the greatest potential for growth, a factor behind the Procter & Gamble Company's first major foray into the fragrance business, which took place this year. P.& G. bought up the toiletries and fragrance division of the Shulton Group, the maker of the venerable Old Spice aftershave and cologne, which is the perennial fragrance leader among men.
Procter & Gamble, with marketers reknowned for making the best of a good thing, is determined to increase Old Spice's market share. P.& G. has already launched a vigorous advertising campaign, reviving the popular Old Spice "Mariner Man," who last stepped ashore on television eight years ago.
When the company announced its Shulton purchase earlier this year, P.&.G. chairman and chief executive Edwin L. Artzt hinted that further acquisitions are in store. "The male toiletries and fragrances markets have great growth potential," he said, "and Old Spice represents an outstanding first entry for us."
P.& G.'s main competition comes from Unilever N.V.-P.L.C., the Anglo-Dutch consumer products group. With an old standby, Brut, and newer, higher-priced products like Calvin Klein and Obsession for Men, Unilever enjoys the largest market share, although a by no means dominant one.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
An Ominous Warning

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker; Anna Quindlen is on vacation. 

 BODY:
No one can imagine a Soviet foreign minister surprising Josef Stalin by the sudden announcement: "I quit." Thus, the startling resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze demonstrates that a considerable degree of freedom and democracy has been achieved in the Soviet Union -- a point not to be denigrated.
That makes it all the more ominous, and poignant, that Mr. Shevardnadze specifically said he was resigning to "protest against the onset of dictatorship" -- which he characterized as "approaching." 
 Secretary of State James Baker promptly responded that Washington viewed the resignation as a "warning . . . to be taken seriously," and obviously that's what it was. But as a warning against what? Those who might replace Mikhail Gorbachev? Or Mr. Gorbachev himself? Or a warning to him?
There's no doubt that the Gorbachev Government has been slow and uncertain in moving from the old, discredited Communist dictatorship toward democracy and a market economy. As a result, severe tensions have been generated in Soviet society, on the part of those who want faster movement toward reform as well as those who cling to old ways and old positions. Mr. Gorbachev is under sharp criticism from both groups.
More economic deprivation than Soviet citizens have been accustomed to also has resulted from his failure to organize a new system in time to replace the old -- or at least to establish rudimentary new economic functions. The resulting discontent has been made worse by the long-festering resentments -- which, ironically, now can be politically expressed -- of the various nationalities forcibly included, years ago, in the Soviet Union.
Nor are hard-line elements, including some military leaders, necessarily pleased by the remarkable external achievements of the Gorbachev regime -- which has relinquished the old puppet states of Eastern Europe, allowed the peaceful reunification of Germany and accepted greater military limits and more cooperation in its agreements with the U.S.
In his warning against dictatorship, Mr. Shevardnadze undoubtedly meant that some or all of these unhappy elements might combine to impose a new authoritarian regime, no doubt justifying themselves by claiming to "restore order" or "end chaos." These have been the slogans of dictators everywhere.
He did not make clear whether he feared that such a combination might overthrow Mr. Gorbachev and seize power, or if he interpreted recent events to mean that Mr. Gorbachev might try to call upon such elements to support increased power for his own Government. A close reading of The New York Times text of Mr. Shevardnadze's speech seems to me to disclose, however, a warning to Mr. Gorbachev that an effort to impose democracy forcefully could destroy democratic reform and turn into renewed dictatorship.
The resignation itself supports that interpretation. If Mr. Gorbachev's closest associate feared his overthrow, he would hardly abandon the battle before it really began. Mr. Shevardnadze, moreover, after declaring his devotion to Mr. Gorbachev and to his policies, and recalling that together they had done "great work in international affairs," added a pointed word: "but." In this context, his deliberate "but" almost certainly had the meaning of "yet" or "despite that."
"But I think that it is my duty [to resign] . . . I cannot reconcile myself with what is happening in my country and to the trials which await our people."
The phrase "what is happening" again seems to suggest that Mr. Gorbachev's reform plans are coming too close for Eduard Shevardnadze's comfort to an authoritarian effort that might suppress rather than achieve democracy.
On the other hand, Mr. Shevardnadze said that if his fears came true, "No one knows what this dictatorship will be like, what kind of dictator will come to power and what order will be established." Or perhaps that, too, was a warning to Mr. Gorbachev that he might not be able to control any reactionary forces he might attempt to harness to his own support.
This apocalyptic warning, as James Baker said, has to be taken seriously by the U.S. No doubt some Americans will urge a return to a hard-line anti-Soviet policy; but that would only encourage Soviet hard-liners to take their own action. For the moment, Washington has little choice but to support Mr. Gorbachev any way it can -- while hoping that he also takes seriously Mr. Shevardnadze's warning to him, if that's what it was.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 6, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of a transmission error, an article on Dec. 23 about the resignation of Eduard A. Shevardnadze as Soviet Foreign Minister rendered a quotation from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev incorrectly. According to Izvestia, Mr. Gorbachev said, "And even after everything I said, I don't want us to decide now that Shevardnadze is 'written off' and, so to speak, goes off into history." The use of a partial quotation, "Shevardnadze is written off," distorted its meaning.

HEADLINE: Sanctions Just May Avert War With Iraq

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Economic sanctions and the supporting blockade in effect against Iraq are dull stuff, and they suffer for it. Sanctions fail to engage the emotions. There is nothing that Americans can see and no distinct daily events to give us a sense of progress or failing. Dan Rather visits the troops in the desert and on the deck of naval ships, but how is he to visit sanctions? There is nothing to show on the television screen: no glamour or heroics. Just dull talk about Iran's declining gross national product and the drying up of its trade with the rest of the world.
Small wonder that many people grow impatient with sanctions and doubt their effectiveness, and that President Bush is "tired of the status quo" (front page, Nov. 24). Impatience lies beneath the debate about the risks and costs of sanctions, whether or not they will achieve our objectives, and how long they should be relied on to pressure Iraq into leaving Kuwait. I suggest America's experience with recent wars offers a useful and contrasting context for thinking about these questions.
When the Korean and Vietnam wars began, there was no certainty about the outcome. We knew the human and economic costs would be high, but not whether military action would achieve any or all of America's political objectives. Nevertheless, the political leadership throughout the country, and much of the public, supported these military efforts with a commitment that was strong and persistent for a long time. I can still hear past Presidents resolving to stay the course, bear any burden and hunker down -- for the long haul if necessary. Korea took three years and Vietnam twice that. Stay the course we did, even past the point when stalemate and compromise had become obvious and inevitable.
Sanctions just may prevent a war with Iraq. The uncertainties and risks that go along with sanctions are certainly no greater than those that go along with war. Yet Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney tells the Senate that he cannot "guarantee that sanctions will work" and that "we cannot wait indefinitely" for them to work. Far better if this country's political leadership supported sanctions for the long haul if necessary, and with the same resolve and persistence that they would ask of all of us if the country were now at war.
"Real men" may prefer strong action, but wise men know the value of patience.
 
BRINTON WHITALL
Princeton, N.J., Dec. 9, 1990

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Relaxing Its Ban on Oil Imports From Iran

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has quietly authorized American oil companies to import limited amounts of crude oil from Iran, partly relaxing a ban on all Iranian goods imposed in 1987 near the end of the Iran-Iraq war.
The action, approved by the President in early November, allows the companies to apply on a case-by-case basis for permission to import Iranian crude, with the provision that their payments be channeled into an escrow account that finances American claims against Iran dating to the 1979 overthrow of the Shah. 
 Companies will still be barred from sending money to Iran, the Treasury declared in confirming the action, which was first reported in Platt's Week, an industry newsletter.
The main motivation for the decision, a State Department official said, was to ease the payments awarded by the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal, an organization set up in The Hague in early 1981 to arbitrate disputes involving broken contracts and expropriated property.
But the move was also seen, the official acknowledged, as providing another oil-supply option should war break out in the Middle East and shortages develop.
The Government contended that allowing Iranian oil to be imported under the specific license, envisioned in regulations putting the 1987 ban into effect, "is not a concession" to Iran and that the action had no connection with the multinational sanctions against Iraq to which Iran is committed.
"It is our interests to do this since we wish to see the Security Account replenished," the official stated. "We want to encourage the settlement of claims."
But Iran badly needs to bolster its hard currency reserves, and to the extent that deposits are made to the escrow account from other sources, Iran's reserves are not depleted
The Security Account, the vehicle for paying tribunal awards, has been replenished by Iran on numerous occasions over the years, in many cases by reinvesting interest. But the balance has now fallen to $269 million, well below the required $500 million minimum, an official said.
 
Arco Settles a Claim
 This week, Arco, the Los Angeles-based oil company, settled under tribunal auspices a claim that is to yield it $9 million, but an Arco spokesman said he had no information about when it was expected to be paid or whether the company, largely a domestic operator, expected to buy Iranian crude.
Treasury officials said that no company has yet applied for an import license under the new program, although some have made inquiries since being privately informed that licenses were available.
The State Department stated: "Last month we decided to license the import of Iranian oil into the United States on a case-by-case basis where the proceeds of the transaction are to be deposited in the Security Account. If such transactions occur, this will help insure that there are adequate funds available to pay Tribunal awards to U.S. claimants. To date, over $2 billion has been transferred from the Security Account in satisfaction of Tribunal awards to U.S. claimants."
The United States imposed strict trade sanctions against Iran in late 1979, but these were lifted in January 1981 as part of the Algiers accord under which American hostages werealso released.
Partly reflecting the stigma that persisted, American companies tended to buy relatively little Iranian oil even after the Government signed a 1982 deal to buy bargain-priced Iranian crude for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve. By the mid-1980's, however, Iran was supplying substantial quantities to the United States.
In October 1987 President Reagan imposed a ban on all Iranian imports and tightened restrictions on what could be exported to that country. This was in response to what he called "increasingly bellicose behavior" by Iran, including attacks on American forces and American-flagged Kuwaiti ships in the Persian Gulf.

HEADLINE: Greenwich Welcomes Homeless From Stamford

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 21

 BODY:
A coalition of church and civic groups, with the consent of local officials, has welcomed homeless people into this wealthy Fairfield County town.
It is a limited welcome: each evening at 10, up to 14 homeless men are bused here from a shelter in neighboring Stamford. They spend the night on cots in local churches or a Y.M.C.A., and each morning after breakfast they board a bus to return to Stamford for the day. 
 But in a state where home rule is paramount and regional solutions to social problems are few, experts on homelessness say Greenwich's gesture is an unusual example of two towns voluntarily addressing a problem that does not affect them equally.
 
'A People Issue'
 "It's not a Stamford issue or a Greenwich issue, it's a people issue," said Barbara T. McKelvey, a former director of a homeless shelter in Stamford and now executive director of the American Red Cross chapter in Greenwich. "And that is what people are responding to."
Stamford, with 110,000 people, is largely suburban, with many wealthy neighborhoods, but it also has a large downtown area bordered by poor neighborhoods. Unlike the towns around it, it operates homeless shelters.
The arrangement with Greenwich, which is believed to exist in only a few other suburbs in the nation, was conceived this fall when Stamford social services officials feared that they might not have enough beds for their homeless population this winter.
Last winter, Stamford operated a 100-bed shelter for men in the classrooms at a former elementary school. But the school is being demolished, and the current shelter, a renovated factory called the Pacific House, has only 67 beds. In an emergency, like a night of near-zero temperatures, the building can accommodate up to 90 people.
 
Call Leads to Cooperation
 "The Coalition for the Homeless in Stamford gave Barbara a call and asked if the Red Cross could encourage Greenwich to respond because of the overflow problem in winter," said the Rev. Leonard A. Schneider, who operates Pacific House, Stamford's only homeless shelter for men. A shelter for homeless women and children is operated at St. Luke's Church in Stamford.
"Last winter, we had as many as 96 in a night," Mr. Schneider added. "This winter, we are at about 80 to 85 now, but it is not January or February yet."
The call to Ms. McKelvey led to meetings among the Council of Churches and Synagogues of Lower Fairfield County, the Greenwich United Way, the Greenwich Police Department, the Greenwich Department of Health, the Greenwich Y.M.C.A. and Y.W.C.A. and several Greenwich churches.
The outcome was that the Y.M.C.A., the Y.W.C.A. and three Greenwich churches -- Christ Church, First Presbyterian Church and First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich -- agreed to house, on rotating two-week shifts, up to 14 of Stamford's homeless men until Feb. 24.
 
'Pretty Nice in Greenwich'
 "I came from 28 years of working in shelters in New York, and this is a rare experience for me," said Mr. Schneider, who came to Pacific House a year ago after directing the shelter at 69 St. Marks Place on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. "Up here, interagency coordination is a big thing."
This week the first group of homeless men slept on cots in the basement of the Greenwich Y.M.C.A., and their reactions were mostly positive. "It's pretty nice in Greenwich," said Domingo Arroyo Jr., 34 years old, a Bridgeport native who is a recovering alcoholic and became homeless while he was drinking. "I like the view."
Besides sleeping in quieter, more spacious quarters than Pacific House, the homeless men taken to Greenwich have also awakened each morning to a freshly cooked breakfast served by teen-age girls wearing plaid kilts who are students at the Greenwich Academy, a local private school.
"I was skeptical," said Arthur Nelson, 26, a Stamford native and an unemployed construction worker. "When I was a kid, we would walk through Greenwich, and because we were black we would always get stopped by the police for doing nothing."
"But they seem to be getting it together now," he added. "Whether it is from the heart or not, I don't know."
 
History of Social Involvement
 Mr. Schneider said the arrangement is in addition to the money Greenwich already pays for the small number of its own homeless who are housed in Stamford shelters. He said Greenwich, which has a population of about 60,000 but does not have a permanent shelter, already provides Pacific House with $16,000 for the homeless. The United Way of Greenwich also contributes $50,000.
He added that the town government and the United Way chapters in Darien and New Canaan, two other wealthy suburban communities that border Stamford, also contribute to Pacific House's $800,000 annual budget, the bulk of which comes from the State of Connecticut. Stamford contributes $150,000. The Stamford United Way contributes $114,000.
"They are all paying more than their fair share," Mr. Schneider said, noting that there are too few homeless people in Greenwich, Darien and New Canaan to warrant permanent shelters in those towns. During the last year, Stamford has had about 600 homeless people seeking overnight shelter; Greenwich probably has less than a dozen.
Ms. McKelvey noted that Greenwich has a history of social involvement, particularly among its churches. "It has been absolutely overwhelming," she said. "We have 80 volunteers from one church."
Morgan Flatley, 16, a junior at the Greenwich Academy who was one of three young women serving breakfast to the homeless men last week, said: "I feel fulfilled in doing this, and once a week is not a problem for me. It is easy to get locked into this community and forget that not everyone is like you and has your life style."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE KREMLIN;
Bush Concerned Over Shevardnadze

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was concerned about Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's warnings of the threat of dictatorship in the Soviet Union and said he hoped that any political change in the Kremlin would be peaceful.
In his first comment on Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation, Mr. Bush tried to make the best of the upheaval in Moscow, saying that "life goes on" and that he expected that Soviet foreign policy would not change, especially in the Persian Gulf. 
 The President appeared at a news conference in Camp David, his Maryland mountain retreat, with Prime Minister John Major of Britain, who arrived on Friday evening for his first meeting with Mr. Bush since he succeeded Margaret Thatcher last month.
Both leaders took the opportunity to project an image of collegiality and reaffirm both the "special relationship" between Washington and London and solidarity on the Persian Gulf.
 
No Talk With Gorbachev
 Mr. Bush said he had not spoken with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev since Mr. Shevardnadze resigned, stunning the Soviet leader and the rest of the world.
"I am convinced, from what we have received so far from the Soviet Union, that the policy on the gulf will continue," Mr. Bush said.
He said he and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had a "very close relationship" with Mr. Shevardnadze.
"But life goes on," he said, "and we will pursue the policies in the gulf, confident that the Soviet Union will continue on its path, and I will continue to work with this new and very encouraging bilateral relationship, work to enhance that in every way possible."
Mr. Bush said: "Obviously, people are concerned about, are wondering about the concerns raised and expressed by Mr. Shevardnadze. But we will, we will continue to deal with them in the future, here, as we have in the past, and hope that the changes that are taking place will be done in a very peaceful way."
 
Reaction to K.G.B. Chief
 Mr. Bush blanched when asked about a speech in the Soviet Parliament today by Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, head of the K.G.B. Mr. Kryuchkov told the Soviet Parliament, "Warnings are sounded that if we take decisive measures today to restore order, this will mean we wittingly agree to spill blood." He continued, "But respected comrade deputies, isn't blood already being spilled?"
In response, Mr. Bush said today: "We hope, very much, not. What, clearly, one wants to see is the reform program continuing. It's gone a long way in a short period of time, but it has a long way still to go. We hope it can travel that long road and do so without bloodshed and peacably."
He shrugged off an American military commander's suggestion that ground forces in Saudi Arabia would not be ready for war by Jan. 15, the United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.
He said he would be discussing the military situation on Monday with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. "But let me put it this way," he added. "If there was some clear provocation 10 minutes from now, the allied forces are ready to respond vigorously."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Major said they were, as Mr. Major put it, "of one mind" on their determination to enforce United Nations resolutions demanding that President Saddam Hussein withdraw from Kuwait.
 
Difficulties Complicated
 But Mr. Bush's remarks also carried the air of a President grappling with a difficult situation that has been made increasingly complex by Lieut. Gen. Calvin A. H. Waller's comments about American readiness for combat, by the Administration's concern that Congress will return in January to debate gulf policy and send an irresolute signal to Baghdad, and by Mr. Shevardnadze's resignation.
Seeking to send Iraq a signal that the alliance against Baghdad is still strong, Mr. Major made it clear that he intended to follow his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, in supporting American policy. But he avoided Mrs. Thatcher's overt talk of war.
Referring to Mr. Hussein, Mr. Major said: "I hope he takes seriously the fact that the Security Council resolutions will be enforced. If he moves out, there won't be a conflict. If he doesn't, well, he knows what the consequences may be."
 
No Estimate of Prospects
 Both leaders declined to say how likely they thought a war was, or whether they expected Iraq and the United States to overcome a stalemate over when to hold the direct talks that Mr. Bush proposed on Nov. 30.
Asked whether he would be seeking a new endorsement of his gulf policy from Congress or a resolution explicitly supporting the use of force against Iraq, Mr. Bush said, "I want Congress fully on board."
"I'd love to see Congress say this minute that we fully endorse the United Nations resolutions and the President should fully implement them," he said. "Because I'm determined to do that and it would be very nice to send that solid signal out to Saddam Hussein. I think it would help him get the message as to what he's up against."
An Administration official said the White House was discussing the possibility of Congressional action on the gulf, but was not specifically asking for a resolution. The new Congress is sworn in on Jan. 3 and is not scheduled to begin work until Jan. 23. Congressional leaders are considering a pro forma session during that recess.
 
'Wrong Signal' Feared
 "If they want to come in and pass a resolution endorsing the President's policy, fine," the official said. "But what we don't want is for them to come back just to debate the gulf situation. That would send the wrong signal to Saddam Hussein."
On Friday, Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, broke with many members of his party by explicitly endorsing the use of force in the gulf, if necessary.
"I believe that the interests we have at stake in the Persian Gulf are vital," Mr. Aspin said in a speech. "If all else fails, they are worth going to war for."
But Mr. Aspin, who said he believed that economic sanctions were not enough to force Iraq out of Kuwait, added that there was still a chance for diplomacy to bring about a peaceful solution.

HEADLINE: 21 States Imposing Drug Tax And Then Fining the Evaders

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
A day after the police raided a jewelry store in St. Paul last month and charged its owner with cocaine possession, an agent of the Minnesota Department of Revenue went into the store and left with a bag of jewels. On Dec. 8 and 9, the jewels were auctioned off for $160,000, and the money went into the state treasury.
Reminiscent of a system used to combat bootlegging in Prohibition, more and more states are using the tax codes to go after drug traffickers and tap some of the vast proceeds gained from drug sales. 
 Under the approach, 21 states have imposed taxes on illegal drugs. On Jan. 1, Nebraska will become the 22d state to impose the tax. The states do not expect the dealers to pay the tax. Rather, the idea is to fine them much greater amounts for not paying the taxes if they are ever caught possessing or selling drugs.
 
Some Early Challenges
 The fines can be imposed and collected within hours of an arrest and are usually kept by the state even if the suspect is cleared of criminal charges. That person can appeal the confiscation of property through the state tax courts, but few do because the battle is so difficult.
When the laws went into effect, some of those arrested challenged the confiscation of their property, citing their Fifth Amendment rights against compelled self-incrimination. But the highest courts in several states have rejected those claims. In only one state has the highest court overturned the law, and that state, South Dakota, repealed its law. Since then, other states have modified their laws to take into account the South Dakota Supreme Court's objections.
"The drug tax is one of the best pieces of anti-narcotics legislation to have come along in years," said Robert D. Ebel, an official of the United States Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.
The key to the tax's effectiveness lies in the difference between criminal and civil penalties. Under criminal law, the prosecution must establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, and assets may be seized only after a court is satisfied that the defendant's constitutional rights have been observed.
 
Burden on the Accused
 But under civil codes like the tax laws, the obligation shifts to the accused to establish that a penalty is unfounded or unfair. In a tax audit, for example, the burden is on the taxpayer to justify deductions, not on the tax collector to prove they do not exist.
In the same way, people arrested with drugs in their possession could be fined for a civil violation of the tax code if the state could show they had not paid any tax on the drugs. Even if they escaped criminal prosecution on grounds like having been illegally searched, under civil law they would have to prove to the tax-collecting agency that they were unaware of the drug.
"All we need to establish is knowledge and control," said Ken Kincade, a collection officer for the Minnesota Department of Revenue. "While the police have to establish ownership, we go after anyone who knows about the drugs and could do something to them."
The wife of a suspected drug dealer was taxed and then fined, Mr. Kincade said, because she had access to a room where the drugs were kept. A man who had sold his house and helped the new owner move his posessions, including some marijuana plants, was taxed and fined. (So was the owner of the plants, who also faced criminal charges.)
 
Strike at the Dealers
 While such laws have had little effect in some states, Minnesota and several others consider the approach to be an increasingly effective way of striking financially at drug dealers. Mr. Ebel and others say the measure is a workable way for the states to tap into the illegal and untaxed multibillion-dollar drug economy.
Harley T. Duncan, executive director of the Federation of Tax Administrators, an association of state tax departments in Washington, called the tax "a pretty effective tool."
"It can immediately tie up a dealer's assets," Mr. Duncan said. "It can be used in plea-bargain deals, and it permits a far broader range of property forfeiture than under criminal statutes where a direct link has to be shown between the drugs and the property."
Some of the early critics of the measure maintained that by taxing drugs, the states gave the impression its use was legitimate. They said the imposition of a tax whose primary aim was not to collect money but to establish penalties was a cynical way to make up for ineffective criminal prosecutions.
Several years ago, Allan Green, a director in the Office of Legislative Research in the Connecticut General Assembly, expressed concern that the "expedited procedures" provided in the Minnesota law could jeopardize a defendant's right to due process.
But most of the early doubts about the constitutional issues appear to have been resolved, although doubts remain about the measure's effectiveness.
 
A 'Gimmick,' a Critic Says
 Richard D. Tulisano, chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly, which is now considering such a law, said the drug tax is a "silly" measure that substitutes a "gimmick" for preventive measures. "If we can't collect regular taxes, we can't assume we'll collect on illegal things," he said.
Supporters argue that the United States Supreme Court has repeatedly upheld the taxation of illegal gains, including a ruling in 1961 in a case involving embezzled money, James v. United States. In that case, the Court held that there "has been a widespread and settled administrative and judicial recognition of the taxability of unlawful gains of many kinds." So far there has been no challenge in the Federal courts of the drug tax.
The tax on illegal drugs is considerable. In Minnesota, for example, it is $1,590 a pound for marijuana and $90,800 a pound for cocaine. If dealers are caught without having paid the tax, they are subject to the tax plus a fine equal to 100 percent of the tax.
Dealers are supposed to buy tax stamps, which must be attached to the drugs just as tax stamps are attached to bottles of liquor and packages of cigarettes. They are not asked for their names or any other information when they buy the stamps, but just a handful of marijuana dealers have bought the stamps.
In the four years that its law has been in effect, Minnesota has fined suspected dealers $33 million for nonpayment of taxes and has collected $1.7 million. That program is expected to gain strength: Dorothy McClung, a lawyer for the state who was largely responsible for framing the law, is to become the Minnesota Commissioner of Revenue on Jan. 4.
In almost seven years, Arizona has assessed $3.6 million and collected $210,174. Nevada has assessed $900 million but collected only $66,000 in three years. Experts say some states collect more money than others because of varying degrees of cooperation between the police and the tax authorities.
Taxation of illegal drugs is not new in this country. Aside from Prohibition, and the revenue raids on moonshine stills that are Southern legend, the nation had a Federal Marijuana Tax Act from 1937 to 1970. It was repealed in 1970 partly because of what the courts saw as inherent violations of the Fifth Amendment right against compelled self-incrimination. If dealers paid the tax, the police could be tipped off and gather evidence that the dealers were violating criminal laws.
It was such an objection that led the South Dakota Supreme Court to overturn that state's drug tax four years ago on the ground that compelling a person to register illegal activity with the tax authorities violated the Fifth Amendment.
 
Economically Fitting, Some Say
 Since then, Alabama, Arizona, Colorado, Idaho, Illinois, Kansas, Florida, Maine, Minnesota, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Rhode Island, Texas and Utah have passed similar measures, but with some modifications to deal with the South Dakota Supreme Court's objections. This year, Georgia, Iowa, Oklahoma and Wisconsin followed suit.
Minnesota is often cited by the Federal authorities as having a model drug tax law for what is considered its ironclad protection against Fifth Amendment challenges, since dealers can buy tax stamps in anonymity. It was also the first state, in 1988, to have its law sustained through the state courts.
To supporters, such laws are not only constitutionally sound but also economically fitting. "The illegal drug trade can and should be taxed as a business or economic activity," said Lorne H. Seidman, a professor of legal studies at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas and a supporter of Nevada's enactment of the tax in 1987.
And Mr. Ebel of the Federal Commission on Intergovernmental Relations said: "Drug dealers may be odious characters, but they are also entrepreneurs who must buy, sell and turn a profit to stay in business. This basic commercial aspect of the business creates a weak spot in the dealers' defenses against the law.
"There is absolutely no justification to giving drug dealers tax breaks just because their business is illegal."

HEADLINE: 2% OF G.N.P. SPENT BY U.S. ON CLEANUP

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
The United States devotes 2 percent of the total value of its annual output of goods and services to control pollution and to clean up the environment, an analysis by the Environmental Protection Agency has found. That is about the same as the most environmentally concerned European countries spend, agency officials said.
The nation spends nearly half as much to control pollution as it does to clothe itself and roughly a third of what it allocates to the military, according to the study, which the agency said was the first attempt to calculate the cost of pollution-control measures. The study was prepared for Congress and is now circulating within the Government in draft form. 
 It said the cleanup and containment cost would rise to as much as 2.8 percent of the total value of its goods and services, or gross national product, by the end of this decade. As a result, the study concluded, the pollution-control burden on municipalities will "increase dramatically," causing some smaller communities to face "severe difficulties" in financing control measures through increases in fees and taxes.
Agency officials say that except for the Netherlands, no other country is likely to devote a bigger share of wealth to clean up the environment in the foreseeable future. The Netherlands has declared its intention to spend 4 percent of its gross national product on pollution control.
 
Questions About Priorities
 The report also raises serious questions about whether some pollution-control activities are commanding more than their appropriate share of national wealth, William K. Reilly, the E.P.A. Administrator, said in an interview last week. "What it says to me," Mr. Reilly said of the report, "is that at this level of expenditure, there's a very large obligation to get it right."
Future programs to control and dispose of waste, particularly hazardous waste, "loom disproportionately large," given the wide array of other environmental problems that must be confronted, Mr. Reilly said. The waste programs, according to the E.P.A. analysis, are expected to cost $46 billion in 2000, as against $19 billion in 1987. Both figures are in constant 1986 dollars.
Expenditures related to controlling waste are expected to grow much faster than those to control air pollution, water pollution and the control of pesticides and toxic substances, the report said. Expenditures on waste control will increase to a third of the total by 2000 from a quarter currently, the report said, adding that most of the increase will be accounted for by efforts to deal with hazardous wastes under Federal laws enacted in the 1980's.
"That's a very disturbing admission of failure in past practice," Mr. Reilly said. While the money being spent to control hazardous wastes "do not represent an indictment of current effort and do not cause us to pull back from current effort," he said, "they are sobering."
 
Federal Help Limited
 Of the report's finding that municipalities' pollution-control costs will sharply rise and pose problems for some small communities, Mr. Reilly said: "It's true. I think we have proceeded to layer obligations on the local-government sector without any sense of the aggregate impacts."
But he said the Federal Government "is not in a mode to be able to help them much," although it provides some grants and technical assistance.
The study analyzed the total costs of Federally mandated pollution-control and cleanup programs that have been incurred and are expected to be by all levels of government and private business up to the year 2000. It did not include environmental activities that do not deal with pollution control, like wildlife conservation programs.
The study found that total costs rose to $100 billion in 1990 from $85 billion in 1987 and $26 billion in 1972 in constant 1986 dollars. By 2000, according to the analysis, the cost could rise to anywhere from $148 billion to $160 billion.
 
Big Emission Reductions
 The agency did not assess the benefits of pollution control in detail. That is to be the subject of a future analysis. But the report did estimate that emissions of sulfur dioxide into the air are less than 60 percent of what they would have been without pollution controls; that airborne particles are 30 percent of what they would have been otherwise; nitrogen oxides, 72 percent; carbon monoxide, 43 percent, and lead, 3 percent.
In 1987, private business paid 63 percent of the pollution-control bill, the Federal Government 11 percent, local governments 22.5 percent and state governments 3.5 percent. Because of large anticipated increases in the cost of cleaning up wastes from the military arms and the energy programs, the Federal share is expected to grow to about 15 percent in 2000 with the private share dropping to 60 percent, the local share to 22 percent and the state share to 3 percent. While the local share of total cost will decline, the actual costs will increase dramatically.
Expenditures for the control of air pollution were projected to grow to $44 billion in 2000 from $26.7 billion in 1987, in 1986 dollars. Outlays for the control of radiation were projected to grow to $896 million from $327 million in the same period; for control of water pollution to $57.6 billion from $34.4 billion, and for pure drinking water to $6.6 billion from $3.1 billion.
The cost of solid waste management was projected to grow to $22.3 billion from $16.7 billion.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Majors Look East for More Riches

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
During a recent tour of Japan by major league all-stars, both management and union executives went along eagerly looking for ways to expand baseball's business horizons to the Far East.
 But if trade winds of the times blow as consistently as they have in other industries, the Japanese can be expected to seek new baseball outlets not only on their own soil, but also right in the lap of the American pastime as well. 
 Rumors of Japanese interest in major league clubs surfaced last year, when the Seattle Mariners reportedly attracted some interest when they were on the open market. This summer, two limited partners of George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, were reportedly exploring the possibility of selling their minority shares to Daiei, one of Japan's largest supermarket chains.
 The reality of global markets and the buying power of both the dollar and the yen have not been lost on officials on either side of the Pacific. How such issues will be handled was a popular topic of conversation during the major leaguers' eight-game tour.
 "It is a more complicated question than just baseball," Commissioner Fay Vincent said. "We're part of a larger organization and we have legal restraints. It is not the policy of the United States, nor is it in its best interest, to inhibit economic activity with Japan. So baseball has to fit its own activities within those standards. I don't know if the Government standards really limit us, but we are not going to impose artificial restrictions on Japanese capital coming into this country."
 Vincent pointed out, however, that adherence to major league baseball's relatively new local ownership regulations made it all but impossible for majority interest in any club to be assumed by absentee owners, be they out of state or out of country.
 There are no rules barring minority interests or minor league ownership. And Suntory, the giant Japanese entertainment and food conglomerate, became part-owner of the Birmingham Barons, a Class AA Southern League team reportedly purchased for $2.5 million to $4 million before the 1990 season.
 The president, chief executive and managing partner of Birmingham is Marty Kuehnert, an American who first proposed buying the team along with a former Stanford University schoolmate. That friend, Gary Shaii, happens to be the son of Suntory's chairman.
 Kuehnert, who has business interests in Japan, resents inferences that it is somehow wrong to sell to the Japanese at all, pointing to negative publicity that invariably follows sales like those of Rockefeller Center, MCA and Columbia Pictures. Now, said Kuehnert: "There's this concern about Japanese business buying America's pastime. But what people don't know is that American brokers, American owners come to Japanese companies all the time and ask them to please buy this, please buy that. Then the Japanese take the flak. Look, everyone knows that Japan is a very wealthy country. And when people need money for investment, they see an economic opportunity and they come and ask for it."
 Vincent, who found himself denying unsubstantiated rumors that he had toured Japan to cultivate buyers, is also concerned about the potential for ill will. Acknowledging concerns on both sides, Vincent has appointed an ownership committee to deal with the so-called Japanese question.
 "I wanted a systematic way to think through any and all questions that might arise," Vincent said. "Such as, do we have strong position on minority interest? The Japanese are starting endeavors in the Dominican Republic. If they are going to do that, does it mean we're going to have to compete for kids?"
 Citing an increasing Japanese presence at winter meetings, Vincent also said: "The Japanese are there to compete for players and talk about signings. Do we have any policy on that?"
 Vincent said these were not exclusively "Japanese" questions, but rather questions that would apply to any foreign baseball entity. "But," he said, "at the moment the Japanese currency is so strong and the baseball ties are so strong, it's the only system that is powerful enough that it can and does take away players who could play at our level."
 Players, of course, see absolutely nothing wrong with that. "The best of all possible worlds is to have opportunities for players, no matter where they originate from, worldwide, the way it is in other sports," said Donald Fehr, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association. Fehr added, "The clubs have agreed that Japanese efforts to sign free agents is appropriate."
 Are such policies reciprocal? Japanese players impressed the major leaguers by winning the all-star series. But if they wanted to play here, it's doubtful they could. "Japanese players are indentured servants," Kuehnert said. "They are still pre-Curt-Flood-type of players. Their contracts have reserve clauses and they have no freedom."
 As for Japanese teams, Vincent said: "I once asked the Japanese commissioner a hypothetical question. 'What if I owned Coca-Cola and I wanted to buy a Japanese baseball team?' He said, 'No!' "
 The fact that Americans may not be able to buy Japanese teams has not deterred interest in buying into that burgeoning market in other ways. While other countries are just starting out in baseball, the Japanese are already there. Not only do they have the economy, but a longstanding love for the game, a combination viewed as too valuable to pass up by major league executives, who market hats, jackets and other equipment, and the union, which markets trading cards, posters and other items.

HEADLINE: SPORT OF THE TIMES;
The Lords Must Be Crazy

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
THE SHORTENING of daylight at this time of year must do something to the brains of baseball operators. How else to explain the sacking of Ernie Harwell, a national treasure of a broadcaster, by the pizza-and-football experts who run the Detroit Tigers?
Harwell had committed the crime of approaching the age of 73, still erudite after all these years, but instead of being given a holiday goose-with-trimmings for his excellence, he was turned into a lame duck. Charming. 
 The lords of baseball have also been wreaking havoc on a much broader scale in recent weeks. Their shopping frenzy has caused people in Buffalo to worry if they would be able to afford the grand national game if and when it arrives.
Only last Monday, Buffalo was selected as one of six finalists for the National League expansion of two more teams in 1993. Unfortunately, this will give the National League an imbalanced, rivalry-destroying schedule that has dragged the American League down since 1977. But nobody's perfect, and surely not these people.
The other expansion finalists are: Washington, D.C., which has lost two teams already; St. Petersburg-Tampa, Fla., a lovely region stuck with yet another sterile dome; Orlando, out in the middle of Florida, not near much except amusement parks; Miami, an important international city but whose Joe Robbie Stadium is neither configured for baseball nor logistically convenient; and Denver, which has been waiting a long time, and who really knows?
Buffalo is the best of the six. It has a perfect stadium, better weather than people think, a baseball-wise population belt in New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Ontario, and a savvy ownership already in place.
How savvy is the ownership? Well, Robert E. Rich Jr. heard rumblings that people in his town were concerned that baseball prices have, as he put it, "gone through the roof." (A figurative roof; Rich, bless him, has built an old-fashioned ball park with real grass and real sky.)
These people in Buffalo are not fools. They have seen industry come and go. They have seen prices rise for heating homes. Yet they have also supported Class AAA baseball to the tune of one million fans in each of the last three seasons, a record for the minor leagues.
They have also seen the current teams recently spending $3 million per season on players who look suspiciously like potential expansion draft choices.
These current prices are courtesy of a local character known as Crazy Neal (His Prices Are In-SANE), who gave away tons of money so that CBS could have the rights to the post-season, plus a few odd regular-season games. Those daffy baseball operators liked Crazy Neal's style, just tossing dollars on street corners, so they imitated him. Wouldn't you know it? Along came agents and players to scoop up those bills.
Now the baseball operators probably don't have any more money. But baseball has a plan to make more money. It is called expansion.
Wait a minute, the people of Buffalo began to ask, who is going to pay that $95 million entry fee and those $3 million contracts for journeymen?
I am, Robert Rich said, in effect. And to further assure them, he issued a statement more than a week ago that said, in part, "While we remain committed to bringing major league baseball to Buffalo, we have said that we do not believe in baseball at any cost."
After his statement was interpreted in several ways, Rich said, one version led to an unfortunate headline that said, "Bowing Out in Buffalo." Not true. Bob Rich and Buffalo are not bowing out, he insisted in an interview late last week.
"People are saying, 'Geez, I bring my family to one game a week,' " Rich said. "Does this mean I can only bring one friend a month?' We are saying it's got to have the same feeling, the same ambience, that baseball in Buffalo has now. We want to allay their fears."
Rich said that Buffalo would be one of the smaller markets in the major leagues, but big enough to support a team. He added, "The proposed expansion draft is generous, and you can win with a developmental approach."
And while ticket prices would surely rise from the current $3-7 minor league scale, Rich said they would be consistent with major league baseball prices(roughly $4-10.25 last season) "and not what people pay at Madison Square Garden, or for the Buffalo Bills." He also recognized that people would not appreciate huge increases in cable television, concessions and parking.
"We are committed to baseball in Buffalo," Rich said, "but you have to look at the whole cost. I don't think we're pessimistic. We're keeping an eye on all these trends. People say, are you going to be a voice? I hope this is not just an auction. We plan to speak out."
Baseball had better wonder who is going to pay for these ludicrous salaries. It is welcome news that the owners and the players are forming a joint economic committee, only a decade after Larry O'Brien, David Stern and Larry Fleisher salvaged professional basketball with labor peace.
Baseball's dollar-flinging will be difficult to stop. The Ernie Harwell foolishness is easy. Rich should hire Harwell immediately to truly usher Buffalo into the major leagues. Think the pizza-and-football experts would enjoy the Detroit region beaming its antennas toward Buffalo? Serve 'em right.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Social History From Berkow

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
Ira Berkow's moving column ("A Black Star Long, Long Ago," The Times, Nov. 24) on George Gregory, the first black basketball all-American, constitutes an important piece of social history. For example, it documents virulent racism in Northern universities, such as Columbia and Rutgers, in the 1920's and 1930's. The disgraceful treatment accorded George Gregory and Paul Robeson by contemporary student athletes is a reliable barometer of deeply held racial attitudes by the society at large during much of this century.
One point which we can extrapolate from the experiences of Gregory, Robeson and Jackie Robinson is that the long-term effects of racism throughout American society have been cumulative. Most black Americans, athletes included, pay a price for our nation's unresolved racial dilemma each and every day.
Some sports have (begrudgingly) given the very best black athletes a shot at the golden ring. Other sports -- golf is the most visible today -- continue to reflect society's historical bigotry. It may seem unfair to single out golf (or tennis or swimming) when these sports merely mirror the attitudes of the majority in our nation. The fact is, however, that each breakthrough moves a few more white Americans in the direction of justice and equality, while also opening up economic opportunities to a few more minority men and women.
Even more convincing are the occasional elevations of black athletes to leadership positions -- a head football coach in the N.F.L., two major league baseball managers, and a growing number of N.B.A. head coaches. These visible advances help to demonstrate that intellect is as widely shared among all segments of the human race as athletic ability. Ultimately, we may well break the circle of cumulative deprivation resulting from our racial legacy.
Progress in sports plays a part in promoting progress in our society.GILBERT JONAS
New York

The writer is resource and program development director of the N.A.A.C.P. Special Contribution Fund.
