HEADLINE: The World;
Euphoria Gives Way to Fractured Feelings of Gloom

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
THE gesture did not make the front pages and it probably won't influence policy much. Nonetheless, when the Friends of the Earth, the environmentalist organization, wrote to Secretary of State James A. Baker last week warning that war against Iraq would be an ecological disaster, it seemed to be a small sign of the tenor of these last few days of a strangely ambiguous year.
It is true, of course, that nothing could be more environmentally unsound than waging war -- and Friends of the Earth also alluded to the great loss of human life that a Persian Gulf military conflict would entail. 
 Still, the letter seemed to reflect how complicated the world has become, how burdened with special-interest pleadings -- how everyone seems still to be craving something at the end of a year that began on such an optimistic note, virtually promising that everybody would get something. Everybody now seems to be wondering what, if anything, they got.
Friends of the Earth wants desert plants to be protected from tanks, shorebirds from chemical warheads. The bank regulators want more insurance. The Government wants more taxes but doesn't want to tell the people who will have to pay them. Everybody wants more money and, certainly, more personal security. Contrary to popular myth, The New Republic announced last week, the Christmas season is always a "blue" time, marked by "environmental degradation, hazardous products and travel, and -- perhaps most important -- inefficient uses of key resources."
This Christmas season seems undisguisedly blue, especially when compared with the general merriment that prevailed when 1990 began, promising a new, easier and simpler era. The hoped-for peace dividend seems already to have fallen through some hole in the national pocket. The economy, far from celebrating the miracle of German unification, chose just this moment to bring seven years of expansion to an end. Recession looms. Banks fail. And there is the prospect of war.
Is the year-end malaise just a passing mood or does it stem from something deep and permanent? Does the sourness suggest that the country might even be in the great decline envisaged by Paul Kennedy, the Yale University historian whose 1988 book, "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers," held that the United States was following the unfortunate pattern of the great empires of history? Mr. Kennedy wrote that economic power leads to "imperial overstretch," which in turn produces economic exhaustion and a loss of power -- in short, permanent decline.
Is that our fate? A new group, led by Joseph Nye of the Harvard Center for International Affairs, emerged this year to challenge both the fact and the inevitability of decline. Mr. Nye, in a book called "Bound to Lead," argued that the United States was still the global number one and would remain so for a long time.
The biggest crisis of the moment, the looming war in the gulf, could be used to support both the declinists' and the revivalists' arguments.
"The gulf will be a defining point," Mr. Nye said. "If we end up with a success -- meaning that Iraq withdraws either after negotiations or as a result of a short war with few American casualties -- then the American people will say to themselves, this is where we can and should be leaders. If it's a failure -- and by failure I mean either a falling apart of the coalition or a war involving large American losses -- then they will say that we can't lead."
For most people, those simply trying to make ends meet, the great historical abstractions may have curiosity value, but the real issue is getting by at a time when so many people are losing their jobs. In the first 11 months of the year, 55,000 companies declared bankruptcy. The polls do not show despair, not yet, but they do show something pessimistic in the country's mood. In November, Gallup indicated that 64 percent of Americans were dissatisfied with the way things were going in the United States, the highest figure since 1979, the year of the Iran hostage crisis, when the figure went up to 84 percent.
"We're experiencing the end of the illusions of the 1980's," said John Guare, the playwright whose "Six Degrees of Separation" is sold out through March at Lincoln Center in New York City. Mr. Guare, speaking for a large group that always found something false about the upbeat nature of the Reagan years, meant that problems ignored, forgotten, pushed under the rug for the better part of a decade are now coming back to haunt the country, demanding attention.
"The decade of auto-hypnosis seems to be over and people want to know what's happening and who's to blame," he said.
Does that mean that the 1990's, following the decade of happy greed, will be the decade of sad despair? Maybe not. The Gallup poll that showed people dissatisfied with the state of the country said 85 percent of them were satisfied with the way things were going in their personal lives.
"It doesn't astonish me that there's a mood of dissatisfaction about the country, but it does that people think things are going well in their personal lives," said the economist Robert Heilbroner. He cites the things that are conspicuously going wrong as reasons for the national discontent -- the homelessness, the poverty, the physical deterioration that many people see around them every day. And yet, he says, "there doesn't seem to be a grass-roots desire, a yearning for a new New Deal, an effort just to clean things up."
It seems likely that, after what looked like clarity early in the year, the fogs have gotten so thick that many people have simply retreated into the domains of private life, essentially giving up on public problems.
Many single-interest groups are demanding satisfaction, but few are addressing the large fact regarding the common welfare, which is that after the optimism of a few months ago, most of the hard work waits to be done.

HEADLINE: Headliners;
Who's Afraid of the Big, Bad Recession?

BYLINE: By CARLYLE C. DOUGLAS

 BODY:
THE numbers, the experts and the politicians were all in general agreement last week that the wolf is at America's door. The only debate was over how big it might be, how long it might stay and, among storekeepers, how many holiday shoppers it might scare away.
Acknowledging that there was a "weakness in the economy" that demanded attention, the Federal Reserve Board moved to spur borrowing and spending by lowering the rate it charges banks to borrow to 6.5 percent from 7 percent. The change in the discount rate, the first in nearly two years, got a wag of the tail from Wall Street -- the market rose more than 30 points and held the gain all week -- and one major bank responded by dropping its prime rate, the rate banks charge their most credit-worthy business customers, from 10 percent to 9.5 percent. 
 In the meantime, however, three other major banks announced they would be reporting huge fourth-quarter losses. The nation's largest bank, Citicorp, said it was looking at perhaps $400 million in quarterly losses and would cut its payroll by 4,400 workers in addition to the 3,600 it laid off earlier this year.
And when banks are troubled, so is the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. William L. Seidman, the F.D.I.C. chairman, said the agency might lose as much as $5 billion next year as 170 to 200 banks fail. Such a loss piled on top of the $4 billion lost this year from a like number of failures, Mr. Seidman said, would bring the agency uncomfortably close to insolvency.
There was other bad economic news as well. The Commerce Department reported last week that if huge farm subsidy payments were not counted, personal income actually fell in November, mainly because of cutbacks in manufacturing. The agency also reported that consumer spending last month, which included the start of the Christmas shopping season, rose only 0.1 percent.
Though government forecasters tended to emphasize the possibility that a downward spiral in interest rates might boost consumer spending enough to keep the recession brief, some private economists were more pessimistic. "It will be a long and moderately severe recession," said David Jones of Aubrey G. Langston & Co.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady noted on "Meet the Press" that the nature of business is, after all, cyclical. "I don't think it's the end of the world even if we have a recession," he said. "We'll pull back out of it again. No big deal."

HEADLINE: The World;
New Leader Of Haitians Offers U.S. a Wary Hand

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
ALONGSIDE his pledges to uplift the poor and provide justice for victims of the Duvalier dictatorship, another deeply resonant theme loomed large in the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide's sweeping victory last week in Haiti's first democratic elections. Like no other major Haitian political figure of recent times, Father Aristide gained in popularity by challenging what many Haitians see as the overbearing influence of their powerful American neighbor to the north.
While Father Aristide's chief rival, Marc L. Bazin, a conservative former finance minister and World Bank official, campaigned as the man best able to attract American help to jump-start the economy, the leftist priest shunned aid-centered solutions and dared Haitians to regain their dignity by taking their fate into their own hands. His suspicions of United States policies have been reflected in such statements as criticisms of food-aid programs as destructive agents that maintain the country in a state of dependency. 
 These statements strongly echo the feelings of many Haitians, who, citing a history that includes 19 years of military occupation early this century and three decades of American support or acceptance of repressive dictatorships, harbor strong doubts of Washington's good will.
No sooner had Father Aristide's victory become apparent than supporters, from his closest aides to many in the huge crowds that coursed through the streets in celebration, began to question whether their choice of a frankly leftist leader would be accepted by the United States or subverted by the invisible American hand that many Haitians instinctively blame for whatever goes awry here.
Partly to put such fears to rest, Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, rushed to put his imprimatur on the election results. He promised that the United States would respect the Haitian people's choice of a leader and would quickly extend political and financial support to the new Government when it takes office on Feb. 7.
President-elect Aristide's surprised entourage, newly conscious of the vastly different demands of campaigning and governing, accepted the olive branch and extended one of its own; it invited President Bush to the inauguration and made its clearest statement yet that foreign investment would continue to be welcome.
Despite such moves, officials and political analysts in both countries say that a smoothly functioning relationship between Haiti and the United States will only emerge after a testy period of frank discussions and confidence-building measures.
"For us the United States has always been the country that has bothered, controlled, done and undone whatever it wanted to in Haiti," said Louis Roy, author of the Constitution adopted after the Duvalier dynasty fell nearly five years ago. He is also president of the Council of State, which has shared power with the provisional President, Ertha Pascal-Trouillot.
 
Bitter Memories
 "You supported Francois Duvalier despite all of his abuses, and when he died, instead of allowing the dictatorship to melt away, the United States stepped in to help consolidate his son's power," Dr. Roy said, bitterly dismissing as inadequate the periodic American efforts to isolate the Duvalier regime. "Today every Haitian regards any American interference with a suspicious eye. We don't want the United States to drop their relations with Haiti, but when the people have finally made their own choice, we don't want you to bring it down."
On the American side, while officials say that the demise of the perceived threat of Soviet expansionism makes it easier to work with a presidential entourage top-heavy with past and present Communists and leftist academicians, there is strong skepticism about the effectiveness of the protectionist and collectivist strategies advocated by many in Father Aristide's camp.
After the glow of initial good-will gestures has passed, tensions could result if the United States and the multilateral donor institutions in which its voice is strong balk at assistance programs that go against the grain of free-market policies. "Their ability to function and equip themselves depends on their ability to attract outside assistance," said a United States official, who added that while American commitment to respecting the result of the election was irrevocable, significant development assistance would depend on "macro-economic policies that are sound."
Some supporters of Father Aristide, while awaiting further indications from their new leader of his intended policies, expressed cautious optimism that a serious ideological rift with Washington can be avoided.
"There are questions we cannot resolve without international aid, like fighting contraband and drugs, and improving education and health care," said a supporter who asked not be identified. "We will follow a formula of the left, not of Communism, which has failed all over the world, and we are hopeful the United States will not see us through its old prism."

HEADLINE: Chill Factors;
For Bush, a Season Of Bad Tidings And Poor Timing

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH lighted the National Christmas Tree the other night, a custom dating back to Calvin Coolidge. The capital is awash in Christmas cards and gifts, since politicians and lobbyists are in the business of friendship, and the holiday parties have built to a low, alcoholic roar.
But there is a tremor to the times, an anxiety at the edges of the seasonal cheer. Rarely have peace and prosperity looked so fragile. Never has the Bush Administration looked so besieged by problems at home and abroad -- many of which are of its own making. 
 In his first 18 months as President, Mr. Bush seemed fortune's child, rolling along at extraordinary heights in the public opinion polls, buoyed by a still-solid economy and a world that seemed bent on democracy. He was the happy beneficiary of the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, the tumbling wall in Berlin and the lurching toward perestroika in the Soviet Union.
But the international scene has turned far more perilous in recent months; that much was summed up in the resignation last week of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
Mr. Shevardnadze was a known and trusted quantity in the treacherous world of Soviet politics, a man with a special relationship to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and a valuable ally in the standoff against Iraq.
His loss alone was troubling to the Bush Administration, but even more troubling, perhaps, were Mr. Shevardnadze's reasons for leaving: his warning that the Soviet Union was heading toward some form of dictatorship.
Mr. Bush had more worries in the Persian Gulf as well. For weeks the United States has tried to apply steady, unremitting pressure on Saddam Hussein to withdraw Iraqi forces from Kuwait by Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations. But that careful diplomacy, built on the threat of imminent military conflict if the deadline is not met, seemed undercut last week when Lieut. Gen. Calvin A. H. Waller, the deputy commander of American forces in the gulf, told reporters that American-led forces would not be ready to attack by Jan. 15.
 
The Education Debacle
 Still, the Administration's foreign policy seemed a model of discipline and coherence compared with its handling of domestic issues. Last week the White House was consumed with a furor over minority scholarships, a furor that was fanned by its own sloppiness.
It began with the announcement of what was widely seen as a Scrooge-like ruling by the Education Department: that colleges and universities receiving Federal funds could not grant scholarships exclusively designated for minority students.
It ended with a complicated revision of the policy that allowed the use of private money specifically designated for minorities, but not money from a college's general operating funds. The administration also established a four-year transition for the new rules. Along the way, the episode highlighted the deep divisions within the White House and the Republican Party over such fundamental issues as civil rights, and specifically over the point at which an affirmative action remedy turns into an unfair racial preference.
The White House's attempt at a compromise also gave new ammunition to Mr. Bush's critics, who charge that this President has only passing interest, and few core beliefs, on many issues of domestic policy.
 
Democratic Detractors
 "I think the real failings are on the domestic front," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Majority Leader, who is widely seen as a potential Presidential contender in 1992. "I don't think there's a sense of direction about where we need to go.
"There's this preoccupation with ideology, new paradigms, philosophical umbrellas, rather than trying to see where the country needs to go and doing something about it. I think we're falling behind economically in almost every respect."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, another potential contender, sounded similar alarms when he came to Washington last week. "There is a long-term national economic crisis as dangerous to this country as Saddam Hussein," Governor Cuomo said. "But so far, there is little evidence that Washington is prepared to deal with it."
This is not just another chorus from the gloom-and-doom Democrats. The economic news has been unrelentingly grim in recent days: industrial output fell 1.7 percent in November, while the economy lost more than a quarter of a million jobs. The Federal Reserve acknowledged the obvious last week and cut the interest rate it charges commercial banks, signaling that recession is now a greater concern than inflation.
Perhaps the only reason Mr. Bush is not getting even more criticism over domestic affairs is the anxiety over the international scene, as if the nation were so consumed with its heart palpitations that it cannot focus on the pain in its belly.
"The pent-up demand to come home and deal with our own problems will surface as soon as the gulf situation is resolved," said Thomas E. Mann, director of government studies at the Brookings Institution.
Mr. Mann added, "The uncertainty about the direction of domestic policy is very embarrassing for this Administration, and makes them even more vulnerable than they would be given the economic downturn that's occurring."
This is an old problem for Mr. Bush, one often described as the vision thing, which he was able to finesse in a Presidential campaign that revolved more around symbols and tactics than the problems of the day. It was the stuff of good-natured joking during more placid times; now, the continuing search for a domestic vision has turned out to be deeply unsettling to his party.
"Beginning with the State of the Union, I believe we're going to see a significant shift," said Representative Jerry Lewis of California, chairman of the House Republican Conference, referring to the President's address to Congress in late January. "I really do think the President will shift gears to begin to share with the public where he thinks we ought to be heading on a broad range of domestic concerns."
Others, however, were less sanguine as they watched the internal struggles in the White House, reflecting the broader struggles in a party trying to redefine itself for the post-Reagan era.
Some conservatives were talking of "new paradigms" for governing, fundamentally restructuring social welfare programs to reflect more individual choice through measures like encouraging tenant management of public housing projects. Some were preaching the old supply-side gospel of tax cuts, arguing that the recession now demands a return to Reaganomics. Others insisted that the Administration will have to abide by its budget agreement with the Democrats and forswear major tax cuts. The President, who so often seeks to please all sides, will soon have to choose.
This is more than the bureaucratic squabbling that is customary in the weeks leading up to the State of the Union address. Passions are very high in the Republican Party. Conservatives have not forgotten the fight over the budget and the Administration's embrace of higher taxes, which was simple heresy to the party's right wing. The old Reagan coalition of movement conservatives, Republican regulars and so-called "Reagan Democrats" is under extraordinary strain, which will only intensify in the 1992 election cycle as the party begins to debate once more such bitterly divisive issues as abortion. Mr. Bush's job is not made easier by the White House political operation, overseen by John H. Sununu, who has shown an uncanny ability to alienate Washington politicos.
So it goes in the shadow of the 35-foot-tall Colorado blue spruce now glittering on the Ellipse, just next to the White House, as George Bush celebrates his second Christmas as President.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Oil Shock or No, Shoreham Is Still Heading for Oblivion

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
ONE reason given for building the Shoreham nuclear plant was to reduce Long Island's dependence on expensive, unreliable foreign oil. Last summer, as the plant waited to be dismantled, the invasion of Kuwait doubled the price of oil on the world market, raising for a moment the possibility that the Iraqi dragon could be the savior of the distressed damsel of nuclear power.
But Shoreham is as doomed as ever. On Friday the Long Island Power Authority voted to submit a decommissioning plan to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
The reasons that Iraq finally did not make a difference will loom large in the nation's energy situation for years to come. 
 The first is that nuclear plants do not replace the whole barrel of oil, only the part that is typically used in big power plants. That is the heavy end, what is left over after refineries have removed the molecules used for more valuable products, like gasoline, jet fuel and heating oil. And heavy oil is plentiful.
When traders thought supplies were short, they quickly bid up the price of the light products far more than the heavy. The light, low-sulfur crude oil traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange, for example, went from under $20 at the beginning of July, before Iraq's saber rattling, to a peak of over $41 in October. But the price shift in the oil bought by Lilco was much smaller: from $16 before the crisis to about $26 at the peak.
Morris J. Greenberg, vice president of the WEFA Group, a consulting firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said that heavy oil "is one of the easiest of all petroleum products to find substitutes for, particularly natural gas."
"There are surplus supplies of gas still available, and more coming onto the market," he said. During the Persian Gulf crisis, the price of gas has risen only modestly above the normal seasonal fluctuation.
And more gas is coming to Long Island. As the oil markets were rising, the Iroquois pipeline, which would carry gas from the Trans Canada Pipeline across Long Island Sound, was collecting key approvals; most experts think its construction is a certainty now.
 
More Megawatts
 In addition, over the last five years Lilco, despairing of ever running Shoreham, has added far more capacity than the 800 megawatts the plant would have provided. It reactivated its Far Rockaway generating station, adding 100 megawatts. It increased the output of other plants by 95 megawatts. It developed a way to keep its plants on line 90 percent to 95 percent of the time, above the national average, effectively adding 300 megawatts. It built three small combustion turbines in Brookhaven, giving another 240 megawatts. And by installing high-efficiency equipment on customers' premises and radio-controlled shut-off switches on pool pumps and home air conditioners, Lilco cut peak load by 188 megawatts.
It was not only improved efficiency that helped lower demand; recession contributed, too.
"It would have been good business to have Shoreham," said Richard J. Rudden, an energy consultant based in Hauppauge and a former Con Ed executive. But now, he said, "the capacity is not required."
This does not mean that the price increase was without costs for Long Island. Joseph W. McDonnell, a Lilco vice president, said that fuel comes to about 30 percent of utility costs, so the 60 percent increase in oil paid by the company would have resulted in an 18 percent rise for customers without mitigating factors.
But Lilco cut oil use bybuying power made from coal or other sources from other utilities and by burning more natural gas in its own plants. Oil produced 59 percent of the company's power in July but only 46 percent in November.
Also holding down the price increase was Lilco's annual switch to winter rates. So the total increase for customers was about 3.7 percent.
Dr. McDonnell, asked what difference Shoreham would have made, said that if it ran as well as the average American nuclear plant, it would have produced about 25 percent of the power that Lilco needs, cutting oil consumption by more than half. But he turned down an opportunity to say that this was a good idea.
When the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approves Lilco's application to demote Shoreham from its status as an operable reactor, the plant can be sold to the Long Island Power Authority; in the meantime, the plant cost ratepayers $150 million in 1990.
Operators still practice startup and shutdown procedures in a computerized simulator so they can pass their annual licensing exams, but many of those who would be required to run the plant are long gone. Of the 1,100 Lilco and contractor employees who were there in May 1989, when the agreement for abandonment was reached with New York State, nearly half have left, including "a number of people who felt their career path was in the nuclear area," Dr. McDonnell said.
The prospects for the nuclear industry as a whole do not seem to have improved much from the third oil shock, either. It would take prices approaching $100 to make some of the plants finished in the 1980's, after multibillion-dollar overruns, look like good investments. Building new nuclear plants at prices now prevailing would be like conserving dog food by substituting sirloin.
Said Mr. Greenberg: "Even if relative fuel prices appeared to justify new nuclear plants, it would be very difficult for private utilities to go ahead and finance a power plant right now. Investors are not going to be excited about it."

HEADLINE: The World;
China Keeps Door Closed On Dissent

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
A FEW days ago, as Chinese officials were impassively listening to the highest American human-rights official urge the release of political prisoners, the Beijing Intermediate Court was conducting hearings several blocks away in preparation for sentencing two young democracy activists.
The visit last week of Richard Schifter, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, came at an opportune moment: just in time to open a dialogue on human rights before dissidents jailed after the Tiananmen Square crackdown of June 4, 1989, are expected to go on trial and be sentenced to long prison terms. 
 Still, the lesson of the week seemed to be that while China had become willing to listen to American officials talk about human rights -- a step forward -- it remained unwilling to pay any heed. "To exchange views on human rights is one thing and to interfere in internal affairs under the pretext of human rights is another," Li Zhaoxing, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said after Mr. Schifter left. He said China would agree to continue the dialogue but had no plans to free the jailed intellectuals.
For more than a year, China seemed to freeze the legal status of its June 4 dissidents, keeping them behind bars without formally arresting them. But in November, relatives of several dissidents received notices of the arrests that said the prisoners were accused of "counter-revolutionary incitement and propaganda." At least two were accused of sedition, a capital offense.
Beyond these notices, the families have been told nothing, which fans their fears and frustrations. They also face difficulty finding lawyers, only one of whom has dared risk his career to advise dissidents, according to a Chinese citizen who knows the lawyer.
Mr. Schifter was told trials had not begun. But an official of the Beijing Intermediate Court confirmed on Thursday that court hearings had begun in the case of two prominent democracy activists, Zhang Ming and Zheng Xuguang, who are being prosecuted together for their role in the Tiananmen Square demonstrations.
"They have not gotten more liberal in what they consider offenses against the socialist system," said Timothy A. Gelatt, a New York University law professor whose specialty is China. "From an ideological point of view, don't expect better treatment for these people. The law remains harsh. The ideology remains harsh."
 
A Shift of Attention
 One reason China may be going ahead with the trials now is that it believes that the international outrage over the killings in Tiananmen Square has simmered down. A Chinese official says he has seen confidential documents in which Chinese leaders point out the benefits that the Persian Gulf crisis has brought this country, notably a diversion of attention from human rights issues here.
"While the United States is watching out for the possibility of war, China can settle its domestic situation quietly," the official said. "Before, the whole world was watching China, and so it didn't move at all."
In addition, China's permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council has proven a source of leverage over the United States during the crisis.
Indeed, China's international stature, both politically and economically, seems to have suffered few long-term setbacks. While World Bank loans are not fully restored, trade with the West has surged. In the first 10 months of this year, China had an overall trade surplus of $6.2 billion, compared to a deficit of $6.6 billion during the same period last year. Moreover, it achieved a record trade surplus of $1.2 billion with the United States in October, making it likely that the year-end surplus in American-Chinese trade will be a record $10 billion or so.
Another reason that trials may be taking place only now is that China's own attention was previously focused elsewhere. Until September, when China began hosting the Asian Games, it was preoccupied with elaborate preparations for those games, which were intended to dispel the shadow of the June 4 crackdown. "Before the Asian Games there was more a nebulous sense that 'We can't do this now, it's going to hurt us,' " said a Beijing-based Western diplomat. "Now it's not so much that the international climate is better, but that they feel more in control."
But some Chinese say that even after such recent international successes as the opening of relations with Saudi Arabia, Singapore and Indonesia, they believe the Chinese leaders will take care to prevent another international backlash. One Chinese student who spent many months in prison after the crackdown said he thought that there would probably be no executions and that jail sentences would be relatively light -- five years or less. That compares to sentences of 15 years meted out to dissidents in past democracy movements.
"They are very insecure," said a middle-aged Beijing scholar. "On the outside, everything looks wonderful, but on the inside, they are still controlling us very tightly, even more so than before."

HEADLINE: Blunt Regulator Thrives in the Banking Crisis

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Six months ago the White House was trying very publicly to push L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator, out the door, exasperated by his self-confidence, independence and tart tongue.
But those qualities are now seen as assets, and the Bush Administration is happy to have him stay on as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which regulates 12,399 banks, and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is overseeing the bailout of the savings and loan industry. 
 Mr. Seidman (pronounced SEED-man) accomplished this turnabout by making himself Mr. Indispensable. As the White House and Congress prepare to battle over reorganization of the nation's banking and financial services industries, he has emerged as the White House's vehicle for delivering the stream of bad news about the banking system that other Government officials have been reluctant to convey.
 
Value of Bad News
 The Administration believes some bad news, though not too much, is essential to motivate Congress to undertake a sweeping reorganization of the industry.
Mr. Seidman's good relations with Congress and the press help give him the leverage to push his own agenda. Happily for the White House and for him, his agenda is largely in sync with what the Administration wants.
On the other hand, he provides political cover for President Bush and the Republicans if problems among the nation's banks and savings associations become much worse.
"He will be the scapegoat if things fall apart," said a friend of his in the banking industry.
Since the attempt to remove him in May, the drumbeat of bad news for savings institutions and banks has grown steadily louder as Mr. Seidman's relationship with the Administration has mended. The banking industry is reeling from declining earnings, while the fund that insures bank deposits is expected to post record losses as it makes good on deposits at the growing number of failing institutions.
 
Experience Required
 "We are in a reasonably difficult period," a senior regulator said. "His experience is necessary now."
Mr. Seidman, a 69-year-old native of East Grand Rapids, Mich., has been at the F.D.I.C. since 1985, and his six-year term expires in October. For the last few weeks he has been coy about his plans. He has said for months that he would step down before then, but he has yet to set a date. He also insists that he does not want to be reappointed.
In an interview on Wednesday in his spacious sixth-floor office suite overlooking the Washington Monument and the Old Executive Office Building, he sidestepped the issue of his future, saying he hoped to figure out what to do while spending the holidays with his family at his 15,000-acre ranch in New Mexico. His hobbies there include raising expensive Corriente cattle and riding and raising horses.
"I haven't had a lot of chance to focus on it, between getting my skeleton back together and handling the daily emergencies around here," he said, referring to surgery on his hip last month and the mounting problems of banks and the Federal program that protects depositors.
 
'An Old Man's' Choices
 He is torn, he said, between what he called "my duty to the institution and financial institutions," and "a very long list of wonderful things for an old man" to do, including television commentary, the presidency of a university and the resumption of an active corporate career.
He also gets conflicting advice from his six children, most of whom have suggested he move on, and from his wife.
"She feels that I'm essential to save the financial system, poor misguided lady, so she wants me to do my duty," he said.
Mr. Seidman, who was trained as a lawyer and an accountant, was a managing partner of Seidman & Seidman, his family's accounting firm, when in 1974 he became one of President Gerald R. Ford's top advisers on the economy and the New York City fiscal crisis. In the 1960's he was an adviser to Gov. George Romney of Michigan and helped run his unsuccessful 1968 campaign for President.
 
A Corporate Officer
 Returning to private business in 1977, he spent five years as vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the copper producer. He returned to Washington in 1983, as the co-chairman of the White House Conference on Productivity, and then was chosen to head the F.D.I.C. Last year, when Congress created the Resolution Trust Corporation, he added that chairmanship to his portfolio.
One important factor in his decision over how long to stay on, he says, is "who I want to work with, and who wants to work with me." The Bush Administration's leading official on the banking overhaul is Under Secretary of the Treasury Robert R. Glauber. Both men say they are getting along fine.
The attitude at the Treasury Department represents a sharp retreat from the stance taken six months ago. At that time, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, pressed for Mr. Seidman's departure after several disagreements that had lingered for more than a year.
 
A Cool Relationship
 Foremost among them was Mr. Seidman's opposition to a proposal to fold the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation into the Treasury. When the savings and loan bailout legislation was being prepared last year, relations between Treasury officials and Mr. Seidman were so cool that he did not learn of the Administration's plans for his agency until he was told by a Congressional aide.
His sharp tongue and unpredictable nature also did little to endear him to the Administration.
He ridiculed an idea that bank depositors pay a premium for insurance based on the size of their accounts in a change from the current system in which banks pay the fees. To the irritation of some senior White House officials, he repeatedly and publicly referred to the proposal as the "reverse toaster theory," referring to the incentives banks often give to new customers.
The remark infuriated Mr. Sununu, and the fight with the White House chief of staff became so widely known that Mr. Seidman recalls that friends subsequently sent three toasters to him.
 
Contrast to Brady
 He remains a studied contrast to Mr. Brady, who has maintained a lower public profile on financial issues and instead wields his influence by being the President's chief counselor on economic issues.
While the Treasury Secretary steadfastly rebuffed urgent requests to appear before Congress recently to explain how much is needed to bail out the nation's crippled savings and loans, Mr. Seidman did not decline a single invitation from Capitol Hill. Rather, he used the witness table brilliantly, offering a steady stream of brutally pessimistic projections to disarm those critics who have accused him of understating the problems facing the deposit insurance program and the savings and loan industry.
If he stays on much longer, Mr. Seidman would be facing the political test of his life. Republican strategists have warned that more problems with the savings and loan bailout and the banks could spell disaster for President Bush in 1992. There is a growing perception that with more trouble for banks on the horizon, Mr. Seidman could be an easy fall guy if things get much worse.
Asked about this concern, Mr. Seidman said: "That's a good insight into Beltway thinking. I'm not going from here to run for President or dog catcher or anything else."

HEADLINE: College Basketball;
Freshman With a Mission

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

DATELINE: PROVO, Utah

 BODY:
SOME time long before letters from dozens of colleges began to arrive, long before the jammed gymnasium at Emery High School, the two Utah state championships, the national all-star games and the beginning of his freshman season at Brigham Young University, and long before Shawn Bradley grew to 7 feet, 6 inches, there was a trip to an amusement park and a realization that remains as vivid as if it occurred yesterday.
"There was this bumper car ride," Bradley remembered. "All my friends were all excited about these bumper cars, and I was excited, too. And the lady goes, 'I'm sorry, you can't go on this ride.' 'Well, why?' She said, 'You have to stand over here.' 
 "So I went over in the corner and started crying, and I asked my Mom, 'Why won't she let me ride?' I was above the height limit for the little kids. I was a little kid. I was one of the youngest ones there. My Mom finally went over and told her, 'This kid is one of them. They're friends. He's always been that way. You can't treat him like that.' She wasn't quite that nice. She gave her a piece of her mind.
"They finally let me go on. But it has always sat in the back of my mind: Why didn't she let me go? I know because there were rules. But at the time I thought, hey, I'm a little bit different. That was the first time I realized I was a little bit different."
That difference has helped Bradley excel at a game that can become a career that can provide an athlete with a lifetime of financial security. But unlike many of those chosen few on the fast track from high school all-America status to the riches the professional game can bring, Bradley has also shown a rare ability to place his game in perspective.
His style, so surprisingly fluid for a 78-inch, 210-pound college freshman, inspired comparisons and speculation and wonder long before Bradley became a high school graduate: How big? How good? How high? How much? He has quickly established himself as a player capable of changing opponent's shots, if not the game itself.
Heading into the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden this week, where Brigham Young will face South Carolina, Bradley leads the Cougars with averages of 18.3 points and 9.2 rebounds. And he is averaging 6.3 blocks a game, which led the nation last week. Six games into his college career, he blocked 14 shots to tie a National Collegiate Athletic Association record.
Even among the biggest players at the most competitive level, there is a difference. "The thing about Shawn that separates him from a lot of big guys is his desire to play the game," said Roger Reid, the Brigham Young coach who gained 11 inches at the center position, from 6-7 Steve Schreiner to the most highly recruited athlete in the history of the Cougar program.
"With a lot of big guys, somewhere along, someone said, 'Well, you're big, so you ought to be a basketball player,' Reid said. "And they're really not sure they want to be this basketball player. But that's what they do because somebody said they're supposed to.
"Shawn has his own self-motivated desire to be a basketball player," Reid said. "That's half the battle. I've been around big guys, 6-10 guys, 6-11 guys, that don't have the desire. Shawn really wants to be very good."
The freshman's voice is as deep as his arms are long. "If I was 6-6 or 5-6, I'd play the game," Bradley said. "I just have an innate love for basketball. I love it. It's a sport where you're running, you're cardiovascularly in condition. Your muscles have to be in condition. You're thinking. Everything is going on. It's a sport that involves almost everything. It's just so much fun to play."
The time has already come for Reid to point out that Bradley's game has moved closer to a business. That time came less than three weeks ago, not long after the return from an enjoyable, educational, but unproductive trip to Philadelphia, where foul trouble limited Bradley to just 15 minutes of play in a loss to La Salle.
That was the trip when Shawn Bradley, perhaps for the first time as an adult, found himself standing face-to-face with someone who forced him to stretch his frame as high as it could go. Bradley usually stands with self-assurance, his shoulders erect. But the day he met Manute Bol of the Philadelphia 76ers was unlike anything he had experienced.
"It's not every day you meet someone 7-6," Bradley said. "And it's not every day someone 7-6 meets someone 7-7.
"We were measuring up, standing there, trying to get the extra little bit."
As he remembered the happy confrontation, Bradley's chin inched outward and upward. His nose reached higher. His eyebrows arched.
"And someone said, 'I don't know, Manute. I don't know. It's awful close,' " Bradley recalled. "And he said, 'No, man. I'm still the king. I'm still the king.' That was sweet."
There was just one problem. Between the meeting with Manute, and the pregame interviews, and the tour of historic Philadelphia, and the autographs he signed for people behind the bench, Bradley had not been able to find any time to stop and consider what had to be done in the game.
So after the Cougars arrived back home, Reid thought it was time to talk. "I said all the people want to talk to him only because of what he does on the floor," said Reid. "That same attention can turn sour if you're not successful. So I had to tell him, 'You can talk to all these people if you want, but you better be businesslike when it's time to be businesslike. You better know how to adjust to all that attention.' "
Two days after their talk, in a game against Eastern Kentucky, Bradley's 14 blocked shots tied David Robinson's N.C.A.A. record and established an imposing personal standard. "If he's able to get 14 blocked shots, I expect that," Reid said. "I expect him to be in that neighborhood."
The coach expects that Bradley's commitment to improvement will guarantee it. "Just by adding one pound and any kind of strength, every day he's in the weight room, every day he picks up any kind of weight, he just gets better," Reid said.
"The best way people try to defend him is physically manhandling him. Holding. Pushing. Don't let him go where he wants to go. With added strength, that will never happen."
Bradley said he does not have an idea of how accomplished he can become. What some people would define as potential, Bradley sees as a potential barrier.
"If any player put a limitation on how good he or she could be," he said, "then they wouldn't be as good as they could have been."
Aside from an injury, there is just one factor that could disrupt Bradley's progress towards becoming a dominant player at Brigham Young for the foreseeable future. His devotion to the game, and to his daily improvement, is matched only by a devotion that will soon take him away from the game.
Bradley has decided that after his 19th birthday, next March, he will acknowledge the wishes of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and leave for two years on a mission. He will receive an assignment to spread the word of his faith anywhere from a domestic site to a hostile, primitive area on another continent. Wherever he is sent, the strict regulations of the mission would leave little, if any, time for basketball.
It is a voluntary commitment that many outstanding Brigham Young athletes, including Jim McMahon, Steve Young and Danny Ainge, have chosen not to accept. The length and restrictions of the missions complicate any effort to achieve continuity in a basketball program that has played in 7 of the last 12 N.C.A.A. tournaments. Two of the six basketball players currently away on missions would have provided a badly needed balance in the backcourt.
"We love it and we deal with it," Reid said. "We endorse it 100 percent."
The father in Reid understands the importance of the missions; his son, Randy, is one of the six departed players serving the church from Kentucky to New Jersey to Argentina. But the coach within Reid would rather not have to wait until the 1993-94 season for Bradley's sophomore year; that is, if there is a sophomore year at Brigham Young.
If Bradley should serve on his mission and then leave for the National Basketball Association -- a scenario Bradley holds as an option -- it is possible that the greatest player Roger Reid will ever coach will be gone forever after one season.
"I don't know if there are many people in the country that would like to really try that," Reid said. "Take a Bobby Knight or a Dean Smith. I'm not sure they'd like to work with that too much."
In an era that has seen elite athletes coddled from the time they are in elementary school, pushed through an educational system without adequate reading skills, offered tens of thousands of dollars in illegal inducements and then tempted by N.B.A. dollars to leave school, it seems unthinkable that someone as young and gifted as Bradley could see beyond the trappings and volunteer to serve at a time in his life with such stunning economic potential.
"I hear it now," Bradley said. "'Why are you going to give it up? Why are you going to put off all that money? What if you lose your touch?'
"But it really doesn't bother me," he said. "It's something that the church officials and the Lord have asked us to do. We don't have to. It's not mandatory. We're not going to get kicked out of the church if we don't. But it's something they strongly suggest you do. And it's something I've always wanted to do.
"It's something that I think is mandatory for me, that I need. It's something that I want very much.
"I have often compared my excitement to go on the mission to the excitement I have coming here to play basketball. They're parallel."
Sometimes, when he is alone, Bradley wonders why all these things have happened to him. The world of an 18-year-old Utah farm boy is expanding from coast to coast, and soon may stretch beyond an ocean. His dream, the N.B.A., is coming closer to his reach. He has made friends that he can see becoming friends for life.
"When you're little," Bradley said, "you always remember a big-time change in your life. You remember big-time events. And this is a big-time event right now in my life, going from high school to college, playing basketball for the first year, making all these friends. This is a big-time event."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Shawn Bradley, Brigham Young's 7-6 freshman center, towering over the competition (Don Grayston for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
A Way to Help, With a Penny And a Thought

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
"The barrier between me and the homeless has grown higher over the years," Theodore Faro Gross wrote recently. "With it has come a feeling of powerlessness, combined with an uneasy mixture of guilt and anger.
"But walking down Broadway did not become an acutely uncomfortable experience until my daughter started putting to me questions I couldn't bring myself to answer. Like this one, posed as she pointed to a man crouching against the back of a newsstand: 'That man is cold. Why don't we bring him home?' " 
 Mr. Gross, a 41-year-old playwright and author of children's books, lives with his wife, a children's neurologist, and their 4-year-old daughter on Manhattan's Upper West Side. One day last year, when he fetched his daughter at the apartment next door, his neighbor retrieved Mr. Gross's keys from a porcelain jar jammed with unopened penny wrappers. Why, the neighbor's husband demanded, had he gone to a bank to get the wrappers if nobody bothered to use them?
"I said, 'You two have the same arguments we have,' " Mr. Gross recalled. "I was working on a children's story at the time with a character, a young bear, and something in the story had to do with a collection of pennies. I remember thinking, is this a story or is this something else?"
Mr. Gross's vision turned out to be something else. It evolved into grist for a story, this one.
"I canvassed my floor," he said, "and asked two questions: Do you have any pennies in your apartment? And how would you feel about giving them to the homeless? One neighbor showed me goldfish jars filled with pennies. Another neighbor's son had a cookie jar filled with pennies."
Encouraged by fellow congregants and officials at the West End Synagogue, guided by advisers from the Community Resource Exchange and by students from Columbia University's nonprofit law clinic, and supported by executives at Chemi cal Bank, where his wife's cousin works, and by a coin-count ing company, Mr. Gross organized Common Cents.
 Volunteers "har vest" coins, mostly pennies, from their neighbors. The entire proceeds -- without anything deducted for overhead -- are donated to the Coali tion for the Homeless. Mr. Gross got to know the Coalition six years ago when, through Artists in Action, he registered voters who had no permanent address. The contributions help pay for meals for homeless people from Grand Central Terminal and City Hall Park, rent subsidies to prevent homelessness, temporary housing for AIDS patients, and summer camp for children from welfare hotels and shelters.
Mr. Gross said he raised about $1,000 in his own apartment building last year and that volunteers harvested $1,000 in coins from two smaller buildings. This holiday season, he said, 47 buildings have been or are being harvested by volunteers ranging from 12 to 82 years old; residents of 25 more buildings are poised to join in.
About 12 billion pennies have been minted this year. The Government figures that 129 billion are in what is loosely described as circulation. Actually, some are being hoarded while many others, devalued as a nearly obsolete inconvenience, have been forgotten in pockets, containers and drawers. From each household that contributes, Mr. Gross estimates that Common Cents collects an average of $13 in coins.
As an emerging Vaclav Havel of West Side civic affairs, Teddy Gross regards volunteering to canvass for Common Cents as an entry-level job in grass-roots social activism. But, he said, "there's a limit to how much can be done run out of my kitchen," as he works at being a playwright (his latest is "a post-Contragate interpretation of the Trojan War") and a father. Piled in a corner of his apartment are canvas money bags awaiting delivery to the bank. Mr. Gross, using the Yiddish word for a container with which alms are solicited, calls the bags "post-inflation pushkes."
He has applied for a modest grant to cover administrative costs, including the Common Cents telephone (212 PENNIES). He is also exploring whether utility customers and merchants can be convinced to round off their bills and receipts, respectively, and to donate the difference.
The Coalition for the Homeless, meanwhile, hopes to persuade commercial tenants and managing agents to cooperate in mounting efforts like Common Cents in office buildings.
Mr. Gross has no illusions about solving homelessness. But, he said, "I realized that pennies and the homeless were the same: wasted capital, scorned and ignored." Sometimes, a big difference can begin with what seems like small change.

HEADLINE: Japanese Brokers Accused

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Japan's Finance Ministry has begun an investigation into whether Japanese brokerage houses intimidated two Japanese companies into canceling an agreement to issue new bonds through Salomon Brothers, an American brokerage with offices in Tokyo.
The ministry's confirmation that the investigation is taking place out of the public eye appears to be a tacit acknowledgement of a discriminatory practice that the ministry has long said does not exist. 
 The case has potentially broader implications, both for American efforts to obtain fairer competition in the Japanese financial markets and for the Finance Ministry's battle to keep other Japanese regulators out of its territory.
 
 Criticism by Treasury
 Two weeks ago, a report by the United States Treasury Department criticized the Japanese Government for continuing to provide unfair advantages to Japanese banks and securities companies.
The report acknowledged progress toward the opening of Japan's financial markets but noted that many remaining barriers were informal, involving exclusionary practices rather than explicit rules. One area singled out was the underwriting of securities for Japanese companies. It has been rare for a foreign securities firm to act as a lead underwriter.
Makoto Utsumi, the ministry's Vice Minister for International Affairs, said the report was inaccurate. "We have nothing to be ashamed of," he said in defending the ministry's record of deregulation.
 
 Inquiry Opened Quietly
 About the same time that the Treasury's report was released, the Japanese press reported that the two Japanese companies had canceled their deal with Salomon Brothers, a unit of Salomon Inc. Within days of those reports, the Finance Ministry quietly opened its investigation.
Another regulatory agency, the Fair Trade Commission, while generally regarded as toothless, has in recent months investigated and put a stop to some cartel-like practices in the financial industry, including meetings at which commercial bankers agree upon interest rates.
Those recent cases suggest the Finance Ministry has tolerated such anti-competitive practices, lending support to assertions by some experts that it may be using its enormous regulatory powers to benefit Japanese banks and securities companies to the disadvantage of consumers and foreign concerns.
The Salomon case involves two companies, the Oji Paper Company and the Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company, that canceled offerings of yen-denominated bonds of which Salomon was to be the lead manager. The bonds were to be convertible later into stock.
It was the second time Salomon had tried to crack the lucrative underwriting business here; last winter it managed an offering of dollar-denominated bonds for Mitsui Toatsu Chemicals Inc.
Salomon had won the latest deals by offering the companies extremely low interest rates on the bonds. It was able to do so by using a sophisticated technique that involved swapping the bonds into dollars, adding an option and then privately placing them with American investors, mostly insurance companies.
 
 Unusually Harsh Language
 Days later, Japan's biggest broker, the Nomura Securities Company, publicly protested Salomon's plans in unusually harsh language. "It's like exporting AIDS from Wall Street," Tadashi Takubo, an executive managing director of Nomura, was quoted as saying in the Japan Economic Journal.
Nomura later said that neither Mr. Takubo nor any other official would comment further. Fujisawa Pharmaceutical and Oji Paper have been unwilling to comment on the matter.
But Salomon executives insisted that Japan's Big Four securities houses, Nomura, the Daiwa Securities Company, the Nikko Securities Company and the Yamaichi Securities Company, had intimidated the companies into backing away from using an American lead underwriter.
 
 Accused of Making Threats
 These executives contend that the Japanese firms accomplished this by making veiled threats that their legions of stockbrokers would not encourage clients to buy the companies' shares, or would perhaps even encourage investors to sell the shares.
Tadashi Uemura, an official in the Finance Ministry's securities bureau, confirmed that the hearings were taking place. He said the Japanese firms had denied some descriptions of what had taken place. "We have not yet decided how we will respond to this matter," he added. But commonly such hearings are themselves the remedy, since the point is to send a warning to Japanese firms not to create such embarrassing episodes.
Another senior ministry official added that there was some concern about how Salomon was able to offer the two companies such good terms on the bonds. "The main point is we need to make clear that we do not have a policy of excluding foreign firms from the Euroyen market," he said.
 
ACTION ON ILLEGAL CARTELS

TOKYO, Dec. 23 (REUTERS) -- Japan plans to raise sharply the surcharges on companies involved in illegal cartels in response to a United States request for tougher penalties against violations of anti-monopoly laws, officials of Japan's Fair Trade Commission said on Friday.
Unlike fines, surcharges are administrative penalties used in Europe and Japan on companies that form cartels. The surcharges are imposed on sales in the period the company is found to have joined a cartel.
The commission plans to impose surcharges of up to 6 percent on a company's sales, for a period of up to three years, an official said. It now imposes surcharges of 2 percent on manufacturers, 1 percent on retailers, five-tenths of 1 percent for wholesalers and 1.5 percent on other companies. The charges average 1.5 percent of sales.
A United States Assistant Attorney General, James Rill, said last month that Japan should impose surcharges on illegal cartels amounting to 10 percent of sales.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 25; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1472 words

HEADLINE: Casinos Falter, but Atlantic City's Fortunes May Be Rising

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
From his office on the seventh floor of City Hall, Mayor James Whelan has a panoramic view of the city: the glittering towers where gamblers play out their dreams and the mean, gritty slums where dreams are about all anybody can afford.
Both parts of town are changing dramatically. But for the first time since voters made casino betting legal, the casinos are looking down, while the city is looking up. 
 Mayor Whelan gestures toward the skyline carved along the boardwalk by DonaldJ. Trump's huge Taj Mahal and the other pleasure palaces, which even in a time of economic distress are money machines of awesome power -- and which now are producing resources for the city even as their owners face problems.
 
Shifting Fortunes
 The change in fortunes is visible. "For the first time since 1976, for the first time, you look out the window and you don't see any construction cranes," said Mr. Whelan, a native of Atlantic City who was a swimming coach and City Councilman until he became mayor five months ago.
But while there is no construction in thecasino area of the city, at least one crane is at work: in the Northeast Inlet, a devastated area just beyond the casinos that is sometimes compared with the South Bronx or war-torn Beirut.
The crane recently topped off a new housing development, plucking up the second floor and setting it atop the first as a kind of crown amid a seedy filigree of vacant lots, boarded-up homes and abandoned warehouses. The development of 130 new homes, financed by Harrah's casino, is not merely an oasis in the squalor. After nearly a decade and a half of unfulfilled promises, it is the most visible project to be completed in the city with casino money. There have been four other housing projects built under the aegis of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, an agency established to transform some of the revenue from legalized gambling into urban renewal for this troubled city. But the two largest ones were high-rises set on less than an acre apiece, and they did little to announce their presence.
These new low-rise units in the Northeast Inlet, part of a development called Harbour Pointe, cover two city blocks. And they are only the first phase of an ambitious project that will eventually cost $600 million and aims to turn the devastated area into a thriving middle-class neighborhood.
The new units are to be quickly followed by 200 more apartments built by K. Hovnanian, New Jersey's largest residential developer, and subsidized by the development authority.
Many people here believe the completion of the first phase is the start of Atlantic City's long-awaited renaissance.
After years of excuses, neglect and buck-passing, the casinos have been forced by the state to set aside a percentage of their gross win -- the total revenue from the gaming tables -- to help rehabilitate the city. The development program, authorized in 1984 and started in 1986, mandates that the casinos reinvest 1.25 percent of their gross revenues in projects that benefit the city, or, in some cases, other parts of the state.
Paradoxically, the signs of the city's revival come at a time when the gambling industry itself is in trouble after a dozen years of spectacular growth.
The city now has 12 casinos, and their gross gaming revenues last month totaled $240 million, about $8 million a day.
 
Trouble at the Casinos
 Although that was up from November 1989, when the gamblers left $214 million at the tables, the industry is in difficulty, brought on by junk-bond financing, large promotional expenses, a flattening market and overexpansion typified by Mr. Trump's Taj Mahal, which alone soaked up $30 million of the total November gaming revenue.
The Atlantis closed its doors 18 months ago, Merv Griffin's Resorts International went into and out of bankruptcy and Mr. Trump has said the Taj Mahal will probably enter bankruptcy. Whether or not it will come out is an open question.
But even if some casinos founder, total gambling revenues -- and thus the casino contribution to the city's development -- are not likely to drop sharply.
By the time legal gambling was adopted in 1976 in an attempt to save the city, all the elegant old hotels had been torn down, the boardwalk was all but deserted, and the city's population was declining sharply and becoming increasingly poor.
The casinos flourished, but the city continued to spiral downward. Its population today is about 38,000, half what it was in its heyday.
 
Lack of Housing
 The casino industry employs some 40,000 people, but almost all of them live outside the city. One reason is lack of good housing. The redevelopment program is changing that, as well as undertaking projects to revive the sagging business district.
Other changes also offer the city signs of hope.
The new Casino Control Commission chairman, Steven P. Perskie, who left Trenton as Gov. Jim Florio's chief of staff, sees his job not only as policing the gaming industry and putting it back on sound financial footing, but also as point man for the city's renewal. Mr. Perskie, like Mayor Whelan, is a Democrat.
The former Mayor, Jim Usry, a Republican, has been indicted on corruption charges, like two of his recent predecessors. Some previous mayors have also been known more for hostility toward Trenton than cooperation.
"For the first time in political history," Mr. Perskie said, "we have a Mayor who is part of the solution rather than part of the problem." Mr. Perskie grew up in the Atlantic City area and, as a member of the Legislature in the 1970's, wrote the bill legalizing casino gambling.
 
Coordinating Efforts
 Governor Florio also appointed him, Mayor Whelan and other key players to a new agency, the New Jersey-Atlantic City Coodinating Council, to cut through a chaotic array of agencies and authorities often characterized by infighting and rivalry.
One example: For a decade, traffic planners have urged that traffic lights on major thoroughfares be timed to speed traffic. When the state offered $500,000 through a transportation authority last year for a study, city officials turned it down for fear of "losing control" on the issue. Only public criticism changed their minds.
Racial divisions in the city -- which has about an equal number of black and white residents, and a growing number of Hispanics -- remain severe. But Mayor Whelan was elected by a landslide -- by a vote of 61 percent to 39 percent -- on a racial unity theme; Mr. Usry, who was the city's first black mayor, based his campaign on a racial appeal to the city's blacks, aligning himself with the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader, and refusing to campaign in white neighborhoods.
Meanwhile, the huge injection of casino capital means that the redevelopment authority can undertake projects that would otherwise be financially imprudent in a town as depressed as Atlantic City. The Harrah's development, Harbour Pointe, for example, cost $28 million and was heavily subsidized by the authority. Units that will sell for $69,000 actually cost over $200,000.
 
Commercial Development
 Over the next 25 years, the authority plans to spend $1.4 billion of casino money, the greatest part of it in Atlantic City.
The agency also recently enlarged its scope, planning redevelopment of two other large neighborhoods, Chelsea and Westside, as well as focusing on two economic development areas, the entrance corridor to the city and the downtown central business district along Atlantic Avenue. Besides extensive housing rehabilitation, projects include a commercial office building and a new 234-room hotel.
Plenty of problems remain, however.
While the city has firmly decided to sell the city airport and leave its proposed expansion to the state, neither the sale nor the establishment of an authority to run it has come to pass. Nor has any major air carrier stepped forward to provide the expanded service that many say is necessary to expand the market reach of the casinos.
And despite Mr. Whelan's electoral mandate, former Mayor Usry continues to act as a political rival. When Mr. Whelan hired a new city business administrator and increased salaries of other department heads, the former Mayor personally gathered signatures on an ultimately unsuccessful petition to block the moves.
Even the most optimistic people here concede that the problems are enormous. The 130 units of new housing built by Harrah's are complete, for example, but new sidewalks and gutters are six months away.
While the logjam on timing the city's traffic lights to expedite traffic has at last been broken, even Mayor Whelan, who is already replacing the city engineer, said he did not know when the job would be done.
"All this is much harder than it would seem," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER, 24, 1990

 BODY:

The Economy
The Defense Department has been paying high prices to charter vessels and book space aboard freighters to support the military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Ship brokers, freight agents and shipping executives agree that higher prices have meant more profits for shipowners. But they defend the surge in rates, saying that the deployment has sharply increased worldwide demand for shipping and that the Pentagon has made special demands. [Page 1.]
 
 International
Japan's Finance Ministry has begun an investigation into whether Japanese brokerage houses intimidated two companies into canceling an agreement to issue bonds through Salomon Brothers. Confirmation of the investigation appears to be an acknowledgement of a discriminatory practice that the ministry has long said does not exist. [29.]
The economy of Alsace is booming, a transformation of France's smallest region that is startling compared with the plight of its neighbor, Lorraine, which remains a classic rust belt. [34.]
 
 Companies
Some Drexel employees are still receiving more than $1 million a year, even as Wall Street salaries continue to collapse. The firm, which declared bankruptcy on May 29, now has a skeletal work force of 292. Of those, 29 executives are each receiving more than $250,000 a year, and two traders are each receiving $1.45 million a year, according to internal documents. [29.]
If T.W.A. and Pan Am can reach a deal to merge, airline industry executives and analysts say the resulting company will have enviable routes but will face formidable problems. [29.]
Next Inc.'s highly automated California factory is a model for improving American competitiveness, many experts say. But the ambitious manufacturing experiment may be wasted unless Next's second generation of computers gains wider acceptance. [29.]
 
 The Media Business
For almost the entire television industry, 1990 was the worst year ever, marked by loss of momentum, loss of market share and loss of money. Bill Carter: Television. [29.]
In a further sign of the pessimism of advertising executives, WPP Group said it would not pay a previously announced interim dividend to shareholders. The reaction of investors was sharp and negative. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [29.]
Sol Stein is making a remarkable comeback as a publisher three years after Stein & Day went into bankruptcy. Now he is publishing not books but computer software programs. [32.]
American Photographer is now American Photo, a general-interest photography magazine loosely modeled on Photo, a French magazine that is also part of the Hachette family. [32.]
The BBC's decision to stop publishing The Listener, its 61-year-old weekly television, radio and literary journal, demonstrates the corporation's increasing attention to the bottom line. [32.]
MTM Entertainment may soon be sold by TVS, British newspaper reports said. MTM, which was responsible for hits like "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and "Hill Street Blues," has had trouble creating successful new shows. [33.]
 
 Today's Columns
The S.E.C. is preparing an overhaul of regulations and laws governing mutual funds. The move has set the industry against bankers, pension funds and insurance companies, who all fear a regulatory overhaul. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [30.]
It is the Wall Street bears who are now buying corporate jets. The success of short-sellers has not gone unnoticed by money managers, who have turned from their bullish ways and started short-selling funds to cash in on a stream of bad news. Market Place. [31.]
Credit market participants are beginning to express rising unease about the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union. After the relative serenity of December, the first two weeks of January will probably test the nerves of traders and investors. Credit Markets. [31.]
