SECTION: Section 1; Page 10; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1567 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
2 Top Republicans Keep on Feuding, and Talking

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
This is a city of shifting alliances, strange partners, feuds folding into rapprochement, the constant clash of ego and expedience. But not many can figure out the relationship between Newt Gingrich, conservative bomb thrower, and Richard G. Darman, Machiavellian budget maker.
Over the last month the two men have engaged in a public duel that included speeches, philosophical debate, subtle and not so subtle digs, even an ultimatum. At the same time, privately, they keep talking -- and talking and talking, 10 to 12 hours in a variety of settings over the past three weeks, said one Republican close to Mr. Gingrich. 
 Burton Pines, a senior official at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative study group, struggled to explain the two men in a recent interview and then sighed, saying it was, perhaps, a task better suited to his wife, a psychotherapist. But there is more at work here than id and ego, although there is probably plenty of that.
"I think it's partly about real issues, it's partly psychodrama, and it's partly posturing," said one senior Administration official.
Like many great political spats, it all began with a speech. This one was delivered by Mr. Darman, the White House budget director, and grandly titled, "Neo-Neo-Ism: Reflections on Hubble-ism, Rationalism and the Pursuit of Excellence (After the Fiscal Follies)."
Some say the talk was intended to be lighthearted, a whimsical trip through domestic policy and the fads that often sweep it. But there is little room for whimsy among Republicans these days, riven as they are between right and left, old imperatives and new paradigms. Mr. Darman's speech, to the Council for Excellence in Government, a nonpartisan organization of former senior Government officials, was taken very seriously by some conservatives, a slap by the dark prince of establishment Republicanism at their search for new ideas.
The most obvious target was Jim Pinkerton, the young White House aide who has been promoting a "new paradigm" for domestic policy, emphasizing values like empowering the poor. But Newt Gingrich quickly made the fight his own.
 
One More Fight
 Mr. Gingrich, the House Republican whip, was coming off a harrowing autumn, having broken bitterly with the White House over the budget negotiations and having endured a humiliatingly close re-election race in his district in the Atlanta suburbs. But being Newt Gingrich, a man whose political passions are in a permanent state of arousal, he had room for another fight left in him.
Mr. Gingrich said his initial reaction was that the Darman speech was sad, an exercise in "preppy humor" and -- most insulting of all in Washington policy circles -- "not very important in and of itself." But in the days that followed, the Georgia Republican decided that Mr. Darman was trying to take on the conservatives and their search for a new domestic policy.
So Mr. Gingrich delivered a public ultimatum to the budget director: Recant or resign. Mr. Darman, to whom the word arrogant is assigned as often as hothead is to Mr. Gingrich, did neither, and Washington braced itself for the mighty clash of two formidable egos.
Instead, the two men began to talk.
Mr. Gingrich says they are seeking to air their differences, to try to debate the shape of domestic policy as the White House prepares its next budget and State of the Union message. Mr. Darman refuses to be interviewed about it.
 
Battle for the Party's Soul
 The Darman-Gingrich tension is just part of the broader battle for the soul of the Republican Party. The struggle over the budget last fall reflected these passions: Many Republicans found the Administration's acceptance of higher taxes a stunning repudiation of not only the economic orthodoxy of the party but also of a successful political formula, a victory for the accommodationist wing of the party.
Mr. Gingrich broke with the White House over the budget and became a leader of the opposition. He scoffs at the notion that, after 10 years of Reaganomics and growing deficits, it was simply an act of good government to raise some taxes and reach a budget deal with the Democrats.
"In Washington, governing is almost always a synonym for tax increases," Mr. Gingrich said. "When you see someone described as willing to govern, it means they're willing to raise taxes."
Mr. Gingrich says he is on a quest for a governing conservatism, a way of adapting an opposition movement to the task of running the country. "In our 10th year as the party holding the White House, we still have not begun to replace the welfare state," Mr. Gingrich complained. Conservatives are also lobbying intensely for Mr. Bush to return to tax cuts and supply-side economics in his State of the Union message.
 
The Establishment Embodied
 Mr. Darman, on the other hand, is the embodiment of establishment Republicanism, a man of process as well as politics, a principal deal maker in this fall's budget making. This alone rubs some people the wrong way. It is hard to be a Republican in the House, after 36 years of Democratic rule. It is harder still to watch a Republican Administration, in the person of Mr. Darman, underscore your lack of power by striking deals with Congressional Democrats.
Mr. Darman, moreover, approached the budget talks with considerable pride of authorship. Some Darman-watchers theorize that he considered the eventual agreement a crowning achievement and was hurt at the scorn heaped upon it. "He had just pulled off this great budget deal and nobody liked it," said one senior Republican who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "This was supposed to make him Jim Baker Jr."
Indeed, in his celebrated speech, Mr. Darman declared that the budget agreement was "a giant step toward controlling the deficit," but added, "I realize I may be the first to suggest unequivocal support for the five-year deficit reduction program just enacted."
The budget director then proceeded to warn against a rush toward "new paradigms" for governing, and cast a skeptical eye on the general American affection for new ideas, including, he said at one point, "New-Newt-ism." Such approaches, he said, should be tempered with pragmatism, and reflect "the hard choices of detailed program design and resource allocation."
The game was on.
 
A Speech for a Speech
 Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Darman give big speeches with big ideas and big titles. So it was only natural that Mr. Gingrich would respond to Mr. Darman's "Neo-Neo-ism" speech with one of his own. It was called: "Beyond the Incrementalism, Hard Choices vs. Hard Thinking."
Mr. Gingrich told his audience: "I am not as smart as the director of the budget. I did not go to the Kennedy School." (He did, however, embark on a Gingrichian tour of ideology, values and American culture, raising questions like, "Are families simply randomized gatherings of humans who happen to cohabitate for a brief period?").
On the matter at hand, striking a blow for new paradigms against the onslaught of the managerialists, Mr. Gingrich raised the specter of another Kennedy School graduate, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.
Mr. Darman was wrong to dismiss the "isms" that sweep this country, Mr. Gingrich asserted: "Ideological battles matter. If they didn't matter, we would be talking about President Dukakis, he himself would be giving a large part of this speech, because he is a technocrat and he wanted us to believe that ideology didn't matter."
In the capital, this is strong stuff.
Some Republican strategists said it made perfect sense for Mr. Gingrich, given his conservative base, to rise to Mr. Darman's challenge. "Attacking Darman, Newt benefits," asserted one Republican strategist close to both men.
 
'Common Ground for Reform'
 It is less clear why the two men are doing all this quiet talking.
"We're trying to find a common ground of reform," said Mr. Gingrich. "What he thinks is sustainable within the budget agreement and other things that he is wedded to, and what I think meets the basic needs of the Republican Party and the constituencies we represent." But the Georgia Republican acknowleged that his fellow conservatives are wary of all this consorting.
"They're real glad I took him on and they're real worried that I'm talking to him," Mr. Gingrich said. "There's a sense that it's easier to drive him out of the Government than it is to work with him."
Mr. Pines of the Heritage Foundation agrees: "We see no purpose in trying to convince him. We know he's an enemy of empowerment. We know he makes fun of the new paradigm. We know that he's an old-line Wall Street Republican."
 
'Trash the Other Guy'
 A senior Administration official theorized, "I think they have these meetings and then they go home and trash the other guy to their friends."
The denouement is not far off. Once President Bush produces his budget and his State of the Union, Mr. Gingrich will either be within the White House fold, with Mr. Darman, or outside it. The fact that he is talking to Mr. Darman, Mr. Gingrich says, should not be overestimated. "There's a tendency to say, 'We've had these nice talks; doesn't that mean something?' " the Georgia Republican said. What matters is the result, he added.
Or, he said as he reflected, "In the land of pure process, the principled man is a heretic." Can this marriage be saved.

HEADLINE: Pink Slips for Law Firm Partners As Tradition Bows to Tough Times

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
At Hale & Dorr's annual meeting at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in early 1988, the law firm's managing partner singled out Blair L. Perry for his contributions over the previous 31 years.
Mr. Perry was not ready to retire, and continued to practice law. But last March, almost two years to the day after that festive dinner, the same managing partner approached Mr. Perry with a very different message: this time, he was letting him go. 
 For the 61-year old Mr. Perry and partners like him at large law firms throughout the country, pink slips are becoming increasingly common. A century-old tradition of job security, dating to the early days of America's great firms, is dying -- a casualty, oddly enough, of both the current recession and of the preceding prosperity.
 
The Importance of Partnership
 Once, a partnership at a large law firm like Hale & Dorr, perhaps Boston's most illustrious firm, was akin to tenure at a university. While the odds against becoming a partner were long indeed, and those rejected were expected to leave, the prize made the risk worthwhile. Barring egregious misconduct, partners were partners for life. A law firm took care of its own, through alcoholism, financial problems, depression, divorce and other calamities.
But as law firms mushroomed, their cohesiveness and collegiality eroded. Mr. Perry was the 35th lawyer at Hale & Dorr when he started in 1957; with his departure there will be 316.
 
Into the Upper Echelons
 Now, tough times have hit the legal profession. A recession that has already seen hundreds of junior lawyers lose their jobs is spreading into the upper echelons, affecting lawyers who do not produce or for whatever reason no longer fit in.
In the last few months, several large firms in New York, including Rogers & Wells, Webster & Sheffield, Shea & Gould and Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler have asked partners to leave. Previously, Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy of New York and Winston & Strawn of Chicago, did the same. And legal recruiters say the job situation is likely to get tighter.
"In the bell curve of how bad it's going to get, we're probably less than halfway up the slope," said K. C. Victor, a legal recruiter in New York. Another recruiter, Carol Kanarek, said, "It's just in its baby stages."
Lesley Friedman of Special Counsel Inc., which places lawyers in temporary positions, said she had begun to receive numerous resumes from discharged partners. "It's a first in the legal profession," she said. "One thing that astounds me is the quality of the partners. They're people from the best firms and the best law schools. It's really heart-breaking and scary."
 
Some Bleak Job Prospects
 A lawyer recently told to leave the large New York firm where he had worked for more than 30 years lamented that "partnership" now meant next to nothing. "We've had recessions before," he said, "but not a one of them entailed what's happening to law firms now, not a one. Ten years ago we hadn't been through this period of greed, when firms overexpanded."
He complained that discharged partners faced bleak job prospects unless they had "portables" -- that is, they could bring to their new firms as much as $1 million in business. "It's been rough," he said. "I'm not ready to retire, but the market's terrible. There's no maneuvering room unless you control major clients, and then they'd never have let you go."
In that sense, Mr. Perry is fortunate. Next month he will join Fish & Richardson, Boston's largest patent firm. "You wonder if you've slipped a notch and don't know it, but I'm satisfied that I'm as fine a lawyer as I've been in the past," he said. "It's very flattering to know you're wanted after being kicked in the teeth by your management."
Still, he has not told all his soon-to-be-former partners about his new job. "I tell them I'm going to stand out in front of the building with a tin cup and a sign that says 'Former Partner at Hale & Dorr' and see how much I can collect," he said. "If they have any sense of humor, they laugh."
 
'I'm Being Forced Out'
 The precise scope of the discharges, which are concentrated among lawyers specializing in real estate, corporate transactions and mergers and acquisitions, is hard to quantify. Many are being presented by the firm as "early retirements" rather than as discharges. That is the term that Hale & Dorr's John Fabiano used to describe Mr. Perry's departure.
But Mr. Perry said: "I don't regard this as a negotiated 'retirement.' I'm being forced out, against my wishes."
Bradford Hildebrandt, a consultant in Somerville, N.J., specializing in the economics of large law firms, said firms first talked of cutting unproductive partners five or six years ago. But only recently, he said, had they actually begun doing so.
"From time immemorial, partnership was really a lifetime commitment and problem partners were basically taken care of," Mr. Hildebrandt said. "Now, partnership is more a matter of 'what have you done for me lately?' "
In some instances, he continued, firms that had long disdained economics had become almost obsessed with them. "We've trained our present management to be so bottom-line oriented that some might have become a bit hard-hearted and short-sighted," he said. "They're underestimating the importance of human values."
 
McCarthy Incident Recalled
 Mr. Perry came to Hale & Dorr via Williams College and Harvard Law School. After having earned the highest score in the state on the Massachusetts bar exam, he arrived at the firm in 1957. That was three years after Joseph Welch, the firm's most famous partner, angrily accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy at the Army-McCarthy hearings ("Have you no sense of decency, sir, at long last?") of besmirching the reputation of Frederick Fisher, a young Hale & Dorr associate.
Such loyalty was typical of Hale & Dorr and firms of its type. Mr. Perry, who specialized in maritime and intellectual property cases, earned a reputation for brilliance, doggedness and independence. He also played a role in the firm's management, when he formally invited James St. Clair to return to the firm after he left to defend President Richard M. Nixon in the end game of Watergate.
For a time in the early 1980's Mr. Perry was derailed, professionally and personally, by divorce. Still, he helped the firm enter the lucrative field of high technology and intellectual property, a contribution that Hale & Dorr's managing partner, John D. Hamilton Jr., acknowledged at the firm's partnership meeting in February 1988.
"Blair, you had the foresight to lead Hale & Dorr into a new area of law," he said, as Mr. Perry stood by. "Without your continued support the ballgame would never have started and we could never have loaded the bases as well as we have to date."
 
Token of a Championship
 Mr. Perry, he said, symbolized the "many partners who make significant contributions which often go unheralded." In appreciation, he presented Mr. Perry with a baseball signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers team that won the 1955 World Series.
Scarcely two years after those words of praise, when Mr. Perry had recovered from an illness that had forced him to work at home for a time, he was called to meet with Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Fabiano, ostensibly on another matter. Mr. Hamilton told him the firm wanted him out, no later than the end of the year.
"I was quite taken aback," recalled Mr. Perry, who said never before had his work been criticized. "I said: 'What am I accused of doing? Am I not functioning well?' "
He said Mr. Hamilton told him that competency was not the issue, but listed several other grievances: that Mr. Perry worked at home too much, had a reputation as a "loner" and did not "leverage" -- that is, use enough paralegals and associates -- on his cases. The firm, Mr. Perry was told, had decided he would be "happier somewhere else."
Mr. Hamilton did not return repeated phone calls. Mr. Fabiano refused to comment on the meeting.
 
Weeks Filled With Lasts
 Mr. Perry said he considered insisting on a vote of the entire partnership, which was ostensibly required to remove anyone, but later rejected the idea. "A lot of people whose advice I respected told me, 'You can win the vote, but life here will be so uncomfortable for you that you'd wished you left."
On Oct. 25, after the firm had increased its initial settlement offer, Mr. Perry agreed to leave by Dec. 31.
The last few weeks have been filled with lasts: his last Christmas party, his last meeting with fellow litigators, his last partnership meeting, where he could hear what the firm describes as the "golden parachute" it is giving him being discussed and approved.
Looking out his window toward North Station and the Boston Garden, sitting among boxes containing 33 years of legal effects, Mr. Perry pondered that meeting for a moment. "It was sort of as if you died and you were attending your own wake," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
WPP Outlook Turns Worrisome

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
In a further sign of the pessimism with which advertising executives are looking ahead to next year, the WPP Group said Friday that it would not pay a previously announced interim dividend to shareholders because of weak cash flow.
The reaction of investors was sharp and negative. In London, WPP's shares -- which had traded earlier this year at well above 7 ($13) -- fell 18 percent, or 11 pence, to close at 50 pence (about 95 cents). In over-the-counter trading in the United States, the company's American depository receipts fell 35 percent, or $1.1875, to $2.1875. 
 WPP, based in London, is one of the three largest communications and advertising companies in the world and is the parent company of two large American agencies, J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather. Another big London-based advertising holding company, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., also stunned analysts earlier this month with an unusually grim forecast for 1991.
 
No January Dividend
 WPP had told shareholders in August that it intended to pay an interim dividend of 13.7 pence, or about 25 cents, a share in January.
Cancellation of the dividend was disclosed in a letter from David Ogilvy, the chairman of WPP, to shareholders. In explaining the company's actions, Mr. Ogilvy wrote, "We now consider that it would not be in the best interests of the company to pay the interim dividend."
While the company was confident of "achieving satisfactory profits," he said cash flow was "below our projections" because of the adverse economic climate.
The announcement surprised some analysts. Last month, Martin Sorrell, WPP's chief executive, told analysts that he expected WPP's 1990 pretax profits to be somewhat lower than brokers' estimates of 110 million.
That caused a precipitous drop in WPP's stock, which quickly lost more than half its value. But most analysts considered the company basically sound. They reacted by lowering their estimates of WPP's 1990 profits to about 85 million.
"I was surprised," said James Dougherty, an analyst with County Natwest Securities. "I don't know why there was any need to do this. It is the action of a company that is in desperate straits."
Mr. Dougherty said he had expected that WPP would have a couple of tough years but that the situation was "a long way from disastrous."
Contacted at his office in London, Mr. Sorrell declined to comment.
Even though the advertising industry is in a bad slump in the United States and Britian, Thompson, one of WPP's large networks, is performing well. Like other international agencies, Thompson has been helped by its extensive networks in Europe and Asia, which are expanding rapidly.
The picture is gloomier at Ogilvy. The agency has lost several high-profile accounts this year, most recently a major portion of the $50 million Nutrasweet account. In addition, its Scali, McCabe, Sloves unit has been racked by account losses and embarrassed by the publicity over a faked Volvo ad.
"Ogilvy has yet to prove that it was worth the trouble of an expensive acquisition," said Alan Gottesman, an analyst at Paine Webber.
Although Mr. Sorrell has declined to comment about WPP's prospects next year, Mr. Ogilvy hints in his letter at what the future holds. In discussing dismal forecasts for the industry in 1991, Mr. Ogilvy said, "It may therefore be some time before the group can resume the pattern of growth in profits and earnings experienced up until a few months ago."
Mr. Sorrell is considered a shrewd deal maker, building an empire through a succession of acquisitions, including the first hostile takeover of an agency, the acquisition of J. Walter Thompson in 1987. He succeeded in buying Ogilvy two years later.
Some analysts said WPP's falling fortunes might make it difficult for the company to pay its debts. WPP has debts of more than $600 million, primarily incurred in the acquisition of Ogilvy.
WPP has been talking with its creditor banks, trying to renegotiate its loan arrangements; J. P. Morgan & Company is the company's lead banker. Rupert Faure-Walker, a spokesman for Samuel Montagu & Company, WPP's financial adviser, said he was "confident that WPP would secure favorable arrangements with its banks."
WPP is trying to renegotiate some guarantees involved with its loans, including the amount of cash reserves it must maintain, Mr. Faure-Walker said.
Unlike financially troubled Saatchi & Saatchi, WPP is not expected to sell any of its units as a way of raising cash. But the company will probably cut costs in other ways like employee layoffs.

(Camera Press)

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Final Warning

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Not since Maksim Litvinov, Stalin's commissar for foreign affairs, vainly warned his own leader and the world against appeasing the dictator Hitler has a Soviet diplomat shown the vision of Eduard Shevardnadze in warning of the impending dictatorship of freedom's faithless friend, Mikhail Gorbachev.
 Consider how this historic admonition reverberates around the globe: 
 In the Soviet Union, people seeking religious toleration or fearful of ethnic persecution are in a panic to escape. Dissidents see the face of Stalin's secret police chief, Lavrenti Beria, in the bland features of Vladimir Kryuchkov of the K.G.B., who exhumes the politics of paranoia to rail at C.I.A. subversion even in the corn being delivered by the West. The Red Army's colonels of crackdown go unrebuffed.
 The occupied Baltic States brace for brutality from their quisling, the Latvian Boris Pugo, recently elevated by Mr. Gorbachev to head what is fast becoming a new version of the Ministry of Fear.
 In the United States, the Gorby-at-any-price claque derogates the Shevardnadze warning, grimly sticking with its man as the bulwark against Stalinism even as his inner circle reveals the truth: The dictator has chosen to label freedom "chaos," and prettify repression as "order," for the purpose of holding a tight union and preventing the development of a free confederation.
 America's doves are looking for a dividend in the resignation of the man who brought Soviet policy into the coalition against Saddam Hussein. They hope that K.G.B. and Red Army elements that opposed the Shevardnadze line may now press for a deal that leaves the Iraqi dictator, a longtime Soviet client, in peace and in power; U.S. accommodationists, eager for delay in the Persian Gulf, would prefer the Arabist Boris Primakov or the anti-American Valentin Falin as Kremlin Foreign Minister.
 Here in Britain, where the principled resignation of a key minister led to the toppling of Mrs. Thatcher, the resignation of Mr. Shevardnadze is seen as a harbinger of the downfall of Mr. Gorbachev, or at least the doom of the "good" Gorbachev.
 Recent Red Army cheating on conventional disarmament agreements, tacitly approved by the "bad" Gorbachev, humiliated Mr. Shevardnadze. What now troubles Francois Heisbourg, who heads the Institute for Strategic Studies here, is a possible setback for the Start treaty, scheduled for completion at a Moscow summit in February.
 Strategists are attracted to Start today for a reason that would have been considered bizarre a year ago: It may better enable both superpowers to count and control the Soviet Union's nuclear missiles in case of a union breakup; also, the missiles scheduled for retirement first are sited in the Ukraine, a fast-loosening republic.
 How does the departing Minister's cry for help in reform resonate in the minds of those who always believed Mr. Gorbachev to be a power-hungry opportunist, improvising glasnost as a means to jettison the burden of Eastern Europe and save the Soviet Union for Socialist central control?
 We find it hard to comprehend how his apologists in the West can still cling to the notion that he is saving us all from sinister forces of repression, and that we should help him as he applies a little discipline -- some unavoidable skull-cracking -- to those irresponsible types whose calls for self-government cause "chaos." Even our Secretary of State takes the moment of the Shevardnadze resignation, the first such political self-sacrifice in Kremlin history, to remind us of the dangers of "chaos."
 The people closest to the Great Juggler know better. After five years of talk about restructuring, he has built only a new edifice of power for himself, the K.G.B. and the Red Army generals, making the Soviet Union safe for dictatorship.
 Some of his early followers attributed a dream to him -- a vision of a less regimented, more productive land. They have now been shunted aside, subjected to harassment and humiliation that leads to self-purge, by men with harder eyes and more brutal ways.
 The Great Juggling Act is coming to an end. To an internal empire whose unity can be saved only by voluntary federalism, the juggler has dropped his pins on the side of inescapable union. To a command economy that can be rescued only by the profit motive, he comes down on the side of further control. To peoples who need the rule of law, he proclaims the law of the ruler -- "presidential rule," this millennium's final euphemism for tyranny.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Profitable Increase in Selling Stocks Short

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
A sign of the times is that it is the Wall Street bears who are now buying corporate jets. Feshbach Brothers, based in Palo Alto, Calif., the country's largest short-seller, recently paid nearly $11 million for a Challenger 601A jet, according to Grant's Interest Rate Observer.
The Feshbachs may need the jet to visit a lot more clients a lot faster these days, since they are racking up strong returns on their main short-selling partnership -- the $550 million Southgate Partners. They now have almost $1 billion in various funds, up several hundred million dollars this year. 
 A short-seller borrows shares and sells them at the prevailing price. These sellers expect the price of the shares to fall by a specified date, allowing them to repurchase the shares at a lower price later and return them to the borrower, making a profit on the difference. In this way, short-sellers can gain in a declining market.
But even during the bull market of 1985-89, according to a recent report by Cambridge Associates, returns for all dedicated short-sellers -- those whose portfolios are exclusively in short-selling -- ranged from 20 to 30 percent, far ahead of the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500. Not surprisingly now, since the broad market indexes have fallen sharply, short-sellers are realizing returns as high as 70 percent.
Their success has not gone unnoticed by money managers, who have recently turned from their bullish ways and started their own short-selling funds to cash in on the market's nearly unending stream of bad news. "There seems to be a proliferation of short-sellers," said one money manager who handles about $800 million for private clients and spoke on the condition of anonymity.
James S. Chanos of Kynikos Associates, which has about $400 million in its short-selling fund, said his firm had only about $1 billion committed to dedicated short-selling funds a year ago, but that now the amount was about $2.5 billion.
The professional shorts are not the only ones getting in on this game. Individual investors have lately taken a much more visible role, and several brokerages report that retail short-selling in October and November climbed sharply. On the New York Stock Exchange, the short interest climbed from about 706 million shares in September to nearly 856 million in December.
This short-selling boomlet among retail customers can be bad news for professional short-sellers. During extended bear markets, the effect of short-sellers concentrating on a small universe of stocks can cause quick, devastating turnarounds for the market. Beginning in October and continuing last month, some of the less-experienced shorts created such a snapback when, at the first sign of a rising market, they rushed to cover their positions in widely shorted stocks, buying shares to replace the borrowed ones they sold. The sudden burst of demand created a small rally that battered some of the professionals' portfolios.
The Feshbachs, for example, took a beating in November. For the first nine months of 1990, Southgate's net return was about 47.3 percent, according to the Cambridge Associates study. The Feshbachs had taken little of their profit out of the market when the small rally last month chopped off about 15 percent of their gain.
"Nobody likes to lose money in a short period of time, and we figured out a way to do it in October and November," Joseph Feshbach said. "But we've made up a lot of that in the past few weeks."
Some changes in the portfolios of the big short-sellers have come with the sharply higher amounts of capital that have begun to pursue many of the same stocks. The large amounts of capital dedicated to shorting small-capitalization stocks has eliminated some of the opportunities for short-sellers of these stocks. Because these thinly capitalized stocks have relatively few shares trading on the market, short-selling opportunities are limited because it is harder to borrow enough shares so an investor can make a worthwhile transaction or buy enough shares to cover a short position.
Partly as a result of this, the portfolios of some of the largest short funds now contain an unusually large proportion of the large-capitalization, widely traded issues that offer greater liquidity.
Of course, the lending and borrowing binge of the last decade has weakened many large companies. That has done a lot to turn large-capitalization issues -- of both financial institutions and the companies that borrowed heavily from them -- into bonanzas for short-sellers.
Shorting the financial-services sector, mainly banks and savings and loan institutions, has paid handsomely, and much of the short interest is concentrated in these stocks. The finance sector of the S.& P. 500 fell 28.4 percent through the end of September. Short interest in Citicorp, for example, increased 98.8 percent from October to November, rising to 16.9 million shares. Given the average daily volume of about 2.28 million Citicorp shares, it would take about 7.4 days to cover that position, according to Birinyi Associates Inc., a New York-based investment research firm.
Consumer-goods producers, airlines and retailers are among the other segments where short-sellers are placing bets. In November, the greatest rise in short interest was in Toys "R" Us stock, with short interest up 35 percent, according to Birinyi Associates.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 27, 1990, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day on Monday incorrectly paraphrased a comment by James S. Chanos of Kynikos Associates about the amount of money committed to funds that specialize in the short selling of stock. He said $2.5 billion was now committed to all such funds, not just to the Kynikos fund, compared with about $1 billion a year ago.

HEADLINE: Herbert Salzman Is Dead at 74; Economics Adviser to 4 Presidents

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Herbert Salzman, a business executive and merchant banker who served four Presidents in the field of international economics, died yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and had homes on the East Side of Manhattan and in Westport, Conn., and Klosters, Switzerland.
He died of leukemia, his family said. 
 Mr. Salzman, who had careers in business, government and banking, also served in 1983 as a New York City commissioner who advised on foreign business in New York City. After that he was a general partner in Bradford Ventures Ltd., a merchant bank that invests in promising companies.
Born to Russian immigrant parents in Brooklyn, Mr. Salzman attended public schools there and, in 1934, the Reali School of Haifa, Palestine. He graduated cum laude from Yale College in 1938 and also took an advanced management program at Columbia University in 1954.
 
Joined Father's Company
 Out of Yale, he joined the Standard Bag Corporation, founded by his father, William S. In World War II he enlisted in the Navy as an ensign. He was a lieutenant commander when he returned to civilian life in 1946.
A vice president of Standard Bag from 1938 until he became president in 1959, he was instrumental in the company's strong growth. When Mr. Salzman turned 50, he sold the company and went into Government service.
President Lyndon B. Johnson made him assistant administrator for the Agency for International Development in 1966, and the following spring he was put in charge of the agency's new private resources division. That office was created to channel private initiative and capital into projects in poor countries.
Mr. Salzman's division handled an investment guarantee program, forerunner of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. A quasi-public body underwritten by Congress, its purpose was to offer American money to third-world nations for economic development while insuring the investment against the risks of political upheaval and expropriation.
 
Worked With Javits
 One promoter of the program was Senator Jacob K. Javits, a member of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, and Mr. Salzman worked closely with him in shaping the corporation. The agency was created by legislation and was to have begun operations on July 1, 1970, but Senator Javits jousted with President Richard M. Nixon over who should run it.
Mr. Javits warned the Senate that unless Mr. Salzman was nominated, rather than President Nixon's favorite, the Senator would block funds for the corporation indefinitely. A compromise was reached at the end of the year when Mr. Nixon submitted a new list of 12 directors, with Mr. Salzman as executive vice president.
Mr. Salzman, who was reappointed by President Gerald R. Ford, remained with the corporation until 1976. The following year President Jimmy Carter sent him to Paris as the United States representative to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a post he held until 1981.
 
Held New York City Post
 Mayor Edward I. Koch, as part of an overhaul of his Office for Economic Development, named Mr. Salzman Commissioner of the Office of International Business Development in 1983. He began the job on March 15 but resigned in July.
At the time he informed the Mayor's office that he considered his mission accomplished by having gauged the extent to which foreigners were doing business in the city and setting forth the ways of keeping them and attracting more.
Over the years Mr. Salzman served on many governmental and private bodies, including trusteeships at the Studio Theater, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington and Harvard's Center for International Affairs.
He is survived by his wife, the former Rita Fredricks; two sons, Anthony David and Jeffrey Jonathan; a sister, Sally Pepper, and two grandchildren, all of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New President Named By Worlds of Wonder

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Worlds of Wonder Inc., the once successful maker of high-technology toys, last week named Keith E. Schaefer president of the company. Worlds of Wonder, which grew rapidly on the strength of Teddy Ruxpin, a talking stuffed bear, was bought by private investors in February 1989 after declaring bankruptcy in December 1987.
Mr. Schaefer, who is 41 years old, succeeds Joshua W. Denham, who has been appointed to a new position as executive vice president at Worlds' parent company, Sheridan Companies Inc., which has interests in toys and housewares, including Worlds of Wonder, Lewco and the Manhattan Toy Company. Mr. Schaefer will report to Franklyn S. Barry Jr., Worlds' chairman and the majority owner of Sheridan. 
 Most recently, Mr. Schaefer had been senior vice president of NEC Technologies Inc., in charge of the company's computer and home entertainment marketing in Chicago.
"To me, Worlds of Wonder is an absolute once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to take the company from where it is today to back on top of the mountain and this time do it with control, do it with a focus on the bottom line and at the same time keep the magic for children that it has always had," Mr. Schaefer said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Schaefer added that he was anxious to return to the San Francisco Bay area, where he has continued to own a home. Worlds of Wonder is based in Fremont, near San Jose. "I've been itching to get back to the Silicon Valley and the whole entrepreneurial spirit that's missing in Chicago," he said.
Before NEC, Mr. Schaefer worked for the Atari Corporation, which he joined in 1980 as national sales manager, rising ultimately to executive vice president for sales and distribution. He began his marketing career at Procter & Gamble, where he joined the company's brand management group in 1973. He was later a brand manager for the Clorox Company.
He received his M.B.A. from the University of California at Los Angeles, and his B.S. in economics and political science from the University of Pittsburgh. He is divorced and has one child.

HEADLINE: Health Problems of Inner City Poor Reaching Crisis Point

SERIES: Islands of Illness/Health Crisis in the Cities

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
While Americans elsewhere are living longer, healthier lives, residents of the inner cities inhabit islands of illness, epidemics and premature death. After decades of gradual improvement, the health of the urban poor took a turn for the worse in the late 1980's and has now reached critical condition.
 Experts blame new depths of urban poverty and inadequate medical services for the situation. Struggling for day-to-day survival, people have little time for niceties like doctor's visits. Poor nutrition and overcrowded housing create ideal conditions for the spread of disease. The arrival of AIDS and crack pushed chronic hardship into crisis, shattering families and monopolizing scarce health dollars. 
In the past three years, cities have reported skyrocketing rates of tuberculosis, hepatitis A, syphilis, gonorrhea, measles, mumps, whooping cough, complicated ear infections and, of course, AIDS. The number of cases is still often small, but most of these diseases were considered on the verge of eradication only five years ago after steadily declining since the beginning of the century. Many of them are virtually unknown in middle-class or wealthy neighborhoods.
 
'I've Seen Horrible Things'
 Dr. David Wood, a pediatrician at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, called 1990 a "gangbuster year" for inner city epidemics. "If you look at maps of measles outbreaks in Los Angeles and where the poverty is, they are the same."
 Studies also show that impoverished city dwellers with serious conditions like cancer and heart disease die far more quickly than their middle-class counterparts because treatment begins so late. "I never saw a woman die of cancer of the cervix until I came to the Bronx," said Dr. Carolyn Runowicz, a gynecologist at the Montefiore Medical Center. "On Park Avenue, women get pap smears, which prevent it."
 The death rate among the poor is also higher. In 1988, deaths from diabetes-related illnesses totaled five times as high in central Harlem as in the city's wealthier neighborhoods.
 But statistics, which at best count deaths and infectious diseases, capture only a glimpse of the big picture. They do not tally unnecessary suffering or the lifelong handicaps that result when treatable conditions like asthma and epilepsy go unrecognized or neglected.
 "I've seen horrible things," Dr. Wood said. "Kids who have such frequent seizures that they can't go to school. Kids with asthma who don't get medications and can't play outside because they get coughing fits. It's like years ago when people with unsalvageable conditions were hidden away."
 Dr. Harold P. Freeman, chief of surgery at Harlem Hospital in New York, caused a stir earlier this year when he reported in the New England Journal of Medicine that a black man in Harlem was less likely to reach 65 years of age than a man in Bangladesh. While violent crime is part of the problem, the paper said high rates of disease were the primary cause.
 "When 67 people die in an earthquake in San Francisco, we call it a disaster and the President visits," said Dr. Freeman. "But here everyone is ignoring a chronic consistent disaster area, with many more people dying. And there is no question that things are getting worse."
 In Newark, Dr. Beatriz Arpayaglou has learned to be a pessimist. "We're seeing scenes here straight out of underdeveloped countries, diseases that haven't been seen in the United States since the turn of the century," said Dr. Arpayaglou, a pediatrician with the University Hospital in Newark's Children's Health Project, which sends medical teams to low-income housing projects in vans fitted like medical offices. "It's really very frightening."
 In the next room of the medical van at the Stella Wright Apartments, a nurse, Anne Young, was seeing Kison Chauvers, a 2-year-old boy with anemia from nutritional deficiencies. The day before the team had rushed a 5-year-old girl to the hospital with a life-threatening kidney infection whose symptoms had been neglected for several days. Her grandmother, the stoic guardian to seven children of two daughters who died of AIDS, could not get the child to a doctor sooner.

 
Epidemics of Yesteryear

 To Poor, Vaccines Prove Elusive
 Different cities have fallen prey to different diseases:
 In New York City, 1,017 babies were born with congenital syphilis in 1988, the most recent year for which figures are available, up from only 16 in 1982. New York City accounts for about half the cases nationally.
 Newark has had a 35 percent yearly rise in the number of new tuberculosis cases between 1988 and '89, and the pediatric clinic at Newark's University Hospital reports a fourfold increase since 1987. There has been a 15 percent increase in tuberculosis cases in the country as a whole since 1988, largely in urban areas.
 In Los Angeles this year several hundred people have been hospitalized for measles, and 30 have died. The number of measles cases nationwide rose to 17,000 last year, from a low of 1,500 in 1983. The city had also played host to an outbreak of rubella, or German measles, which has left at least nine babies with serious birth defects. Rubella is a mild illness in adults but leads to blindness in the offspring of women who catch it while pregnant.
 Washington is just recovering from a three-year mumps outbreak. After seeing less than half a dozen cases a year for a decade, the city had about 200 reported cases in both 1988 and '89.
 "These epidemics are sentinel events for the crumbling of our public health services," Dr. Wood said. Measles, mumps, rubella and whooping cough are entirely preventable with vaccines, but many people do not get the shots.
 Nationally, asthma rates have undergone a dramatic and somewhat baffling rise, a rise doctors say is more pronounced among the urban poor. Dr. Michael Wietzman and colleagues at Boston City Hospital found that black children were twice as likely as white children to have asthma.
 In many studies, scientists compare black and white rather than rich and poor to eke out information about health care differences, since it is easier to figure out race than salary from medical records and far more blacks than whites live in the inner city. But most experts say it is primarily poverty, not race, that raises the risk.
 "It's mostly the social dimensions of being black," said Dr. Weitzman, now chief of Pediatrics at Rochester General Hospital in Rochester, N.Y. "Its being poor, living in overcrowded housing, having a low birth weight, being exposed to household toxins."

 
In Need of the Basics

 Hazardous Homes, Dangerous Diets
 Experts say the growing number of people who live in substandard housing with poor sanitation creates conditions favoring the rapid spread of infectious disease. "Diseases transmit more effectively and rapidly in crowded living conditions," said Dr. Shirley Fannin, associate deputy director of disease control programs for Los Angeles County. "A few years ago we went out to investigate a typhoid case and we found 27 people living in one house sharing a bathroom."
 As middle-class people worry about clean air and the ozone layer, many scientists blame indoor pollution for the high rates of asthma and other diseases among the poor. In the Boston study, the factor most tightly linked to a child's risk of developing asthma was smoking by the mother, Dr. Weitzman said. Poor young women from minority groups are the country's fastest growing group of cigarette smokers.
 Living in decaying housing, 68 percent of very poor black children and 36 percent of very poor white children in central cities have blood lead levels greater than 15 micrograms per deciliter. The Centers for Disease Control now defines toxic levels at above 25, but the agency said last week that it would advise local health officials to take action when children have lead levels higher than 10.
 Diets rich in fat and low in nutrients also take a toll. Many poor children have chronic anemia, a low red blood cell count caused by a lack of iron in their diet, leaving them perpetually tired.
 Once sick, poor people in the inner cities tend to suffer serious complications. Dr. Wood remembers examining a 9-year old girl with a facial tic and discovering 20/200 vision and profound hearing loss from damage done by untreated ear infections. "She was holding her face funny partly because she couldn't see," he said. "Her parents had seen a few doctors and used up their money. No wonder she's failing in school."

 
Quality of Care

 Prevention, And Much to Cure
 For poor people in the cities, access to care is part of the problem. To be treated in a public clinic for sexually transmitted disease in Washington, a patient has to be in the clinic by 9:30 A.M. and often must wait most of the day, said Dr. Reed Tuckson, former Commissioner of Health for Washington.
 The typical wait to schedule a pedriatric appointment in inner city clinics was several months, according to a survey done by the New York Children's Health Project, a medical outreach program affiliated with the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.
 But many experts say an even greater issue is the quality of care. The Community Service Society of New York polled 248 primary care doctors in poor neighborhoods in the Bronx as to whether they offered 24-hour coverage, had 20 or more regular office hours a week, accepted Medicare and had admitting privileges at a hospital -- what the society defined as minimum components of a decent medical practice. Only six met the criteria.
 The society's study also found that more than 60 percent of doctors providing prenatal care could not actually deliver babies because they had no hospital affiliation; the mothers were referred to an emergency room.
 "The family says yes we're seeing a doctor, but when you look the care is not well organized," said Dr. Karen Burke, medical director of the New York Children's Health Project. Experts say that clinics in poor neighborhoods focus on acute illnesses and ignore routine care like pap smears, anemia screening and vaccinations, which are generally less profitable.
 Pediatricians are particularly worried about how early lives plagued by health problems will affect children as they age. Babies born in Central Harlem are four times as likely to have very low birth weight than babies born in more prosperous New York neighborhoods, a statistic with lifelong consequences since babies under 3.5 pounds are more likely to have seizures, mental retardation, heart problems, asthma, blindness, deafness and learning disabilities. In today's inner cities, drug abuse and poor prenatal nutrition often converge to yield tiny babies.
 "A kid in a middle-class suburb who has an ear infection gets antibiotics and gets better," said Dr. Irwin Redlener, director of the New York Children's Health Project. "A poor kid with an ear infection doesn't and progresses to chronic infection, hearing loss and language delays."
 In both Newark and New York, most of the preschool children seen in the mobile vans are not fully vaccinated, leaving them vulnerable to serious diseases.
 Other inner city children have been wastefully, though not harmfully, vaccinated over and over again because of a lack of medical records. At a health van in Harlem, 15-year-old Jewel S. had no records because his life has been a flurry of different welfare homes and schools as he and his mother flee an abusive father.
 The surging number of poor children and the rising costs of medicines have stymied vaccination programs, Dr. Woods said. In the early '70s, the total cost of a child's vaccinations was under $5; now it is several hundred dollars.

 
Contrasts of the Crisis

 Determining Death By Money and Race
 In a study published in the International Journal of Epidemiology this year, scientists at the Washington, D.C., Commission on Public Health estimated that blacks in Washington were more than four times as likely as whites to die prematurely, before 65, of heart disease, asthma, pneumonia and some cancers. While the death rates for blacks in Washington have climbed steadily since 1982, the rates for whites have not changed.
 "We looked at conditions that people shouldn't be dying from in the prime of life," said Dr. Eugene Schwartz, the study's first author, and the chief of the Washington Bureau of Cancer Control. "And remember, death is a very crude measure. It's the tip of an iceberg, the end of a long chain of illness and disability that we don't have a handle on."
 Dr. Freeman tells of the shock of moving to Harlem Hospital from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, also in Manhattan, but four long miles downtown. "When I came to Harlem Hospital in the late '60s I suddenly found I was seeing extremely advanced cancer, and that hasn't changed," he said. Because they come so late to treatment, only 30 percent of women diagnosed with breast cancer at Harlem Hospital live 5 years, compared to 70 percent of white women and 60 percent of black women overall in the United States. Dr. Freeman has set up free cancer screening at Harlem Hospital two mornings a week.
 The fates of blacks and whites, rich and poor are diverging. The National Center for Health Statistic first started comparing black-white infant mortality in 1950, and the difference has never been greater than it is today, with black babies dying at twice the rate before their first birthday. While the life expectancy of whites rose to 75.6 years in 1987, that of blacks fell to 69.2.
 Doctors involved in outreach efforts hope they will save a few lives but know these are frail, jury-rigged solutions.
 "We're using Band-Aids, and things are getting worse rather than better," Dr. Freeman said. "You have to see disease in the context in which it occurs: poor education, unemployment, homelessness, hopelessness."
 Dr. Tuckson said: "It's hard to tell young black men in the inner city to practice safe sex or not to smoke. They'll laugh: 'You're telling me not to smoke so I won't get cancer when I'm 50? Hell, don't tell me about 50 'cause I'm not gonna make it out of my teens.' There are an extraordinarily large number of Americans who don't believe in any concept of a future and so don't believe in investing in it."

HEADLINE: Manila Journal;
A Land Where Tinsel Lies in Tatters

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, the Philippines, Dec. 20

 BODY:
There seems to be less Christmas spirit and simple pleasure in Roman Catholic Manila this year.
Most of the lights that used to adorn major streets like Roxas Boulevard have not been put up this year. The Mayor of Manila, Gemiliano C. Lopez Jr., has even been criticized for trying to brighten up the trees along Roxas with capiz shell lanterns, with some suggesting that energy is too expensive now for such fripperies, even at Christmas. 
 For businesses, sales are not good, though anything would be better than last Christmas, which followed a nearly successful coup attempt against President Corazon C. Aquino.
Filipinos are spending "much, much less," said a jeweler in Makati, Manila's main business district, which the coup plotters were occupying a year ago. "And whatever anyone tells you," he said, "tourism hasn't come back, either."
 
'Apathy and Fatalism'
 Nor have many foreign investors, perhaps overly concerned about the lack of stability here, as Mrs. Aquino loses more political leverage as the 1992 elections draw closer and the coup plotters, despite their lack of success, inevitably continue to plot. Senior Western diplomats say they expect further efforts at destablization, perhaps including assassination attempts, and another coup attempt, but expect it to fail.
"There's no real popular support for a coup any more," a diplomat said. "The problem now is apathy and fatalism: there's not much popular support for anything or anyone."
In addition, this has been a particularly miserable year for natural tragedies here, with a bad drought hurting agriculture, a devastating earthquake in July and a ferocious typhoon last month that pounded one of the country's few bright spots, Cebu, and destroyed up to 90 percent of the mango crop.
 
Who's Sorry Now
 "Many diehard Corystas," supporters of Mrs. Aquino, universally known as Cory, "are now sorrystas," said Blas F. Ople, a leader of the opposition Nationalist Party. While a debate rages between those who traditionally look to government to solve their problems and those who favor a more liberal, market orientation, he said: "The poor woman is stuck in dead center, where nothing moves. It's a balance of incompetence."
Others joke that while the Philippines may be giving the United States a hard time in negotiations over American military bases here, Manila has joined NATO -- No Action, Talk Only.
When there is action, it's often fumbling. After the highly confusing and unpopular round of energy price rises, some demonstrators, including a few from the middle class, were promoting, possibly with Christmas in mind, what they called the "four R's": Roll back, Reform, Resign, Repent.
Still, most Filipinos and diplomats here believe that Mrs. Aquino will be nursed along to the end of her six-year term in 1992, unless the economy really crashes and can be manipulated by her enemies.
"The economy is the main security threat just now," a senior military adviser said. "If the crunch really comes or oil goes up to $50 a barrel, all bets are off."
 
'Economic Wind Shear'
 A war in the Persian Gulf, a senior diplomat said, "would be like an economic wind shear for this decrepit DC-3 country, which is belching smoke but still in the air."
But a financial crunch is coming in the next quarter, perhaps as early as January, even without a gulf war. The fight is over fiscal discipline and the nature of the economy, and after a long period of patience with Manila, the International Monetary Fund is now fed up.
It is playing a serious game of "chicken" with Manila, holding back on a large amount of needed funds until fiscal reforms are made.
At stake is at least $700 million in loans from the fund itself. But hanging on the fund's seal of approval is at least $1.2 billion in new aid and loans, including the contributions of a multinational fund set up to help democracy here.
With tourism and investment off, the country has foreign exchange enough for only one and a half months of imports at current levels, and oil, which must be paid for in dollars, remains expensive in this period of phony war in the gulf. Growth next year is expected to decline sharply to about 2 percent, and inflation reach 16 percent.
So the fund wants a cut in the Government's deficit, an end to subsidies on staples like petroleum, import liberalization, better tax collection, and tax reform, to help make the Philippines a sounder, more competitive, more export-based economy.
 
Looking for Action
 And this time it wants action, not merely promises, from a weakening Government and a Congress that has its collective mind on the 1992 elections. Still, no one expects the fund to send the ship of state to the floor of Manila Bay, and most diplomats expect the country, as usual, to muddle through.
Senator Rene V. Saguisag remains one of Mrs. Aquino's firmest supporters, but like her, says he will not run again for office in 1992. Building democracy here is like building a medieval cathedral, brick by brick, he said, "and we will at least have put down our share of bricks."
But 1991 will be "a very, very tough year," he said. "For this Christmas, I suppose we can say, like the French priest at the end of the Terror, 'I survived.' We just have to hope the worst is behind us now."

Even Christmas buying has slowed in the predominantlyRoman Catholic country where businesses are reporting that sales are not good. Above, shoppers leaving a Manila department store. HEADLINE: Talking Business/with a former state insurance commissioner;
Need for Stronger Regulation Seen

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
With insurance company insolvencies apparently on the rise, attention is increasingly focusing on state regulation as one culprit. Critics charge that state insurance departments are starved for resources and are no match for industry lawyers and accountants. The critics say Federal insurance regulation may provide a solution.
James P. Corcoran, who was commissioner of New York State's Insurance Department from 1983 until last January, argues that Federal regulation is no solution to the problems of insurers, but acknowledges that state regulation needs strengthening. Under Mr. Corcoran, New York State's Insurance Department, considered one of the strongest in the nation, grew to 800 people from 600 while its budget doubled to $60 million. 
 Q. What specifically needs to be done to upgrade state insurance departments?
A. There has to be consistency of funding at insurance departments around the country. There are strong departments, and then there are underfunded departments. This has resulted in inconsistent treatment of insurers. The weaker departments need more computer technology, and they need to hire more actuaries.
Q. Is the issue purely money or is it a question of competence, too?
A. Money and competence are linked. You cannot expect top people to stay in these jobs and remain underpaid for too long. They deal with multitudes of lawyers and outside actuaries, many of whom are better paid than they.
Q. Do you agree with critics who argue that the National Association of Insurance Commissioners is a paper tiger that promulgates unenforceable rules because it has no enforcement power?
A. Not really. The association is undergoing a courageous self-analysis. I'm talking about its recent decision to begin certifying state insurance departments. Certification means that an insurance department has adopted various model laws passed by the association and has adequate funding and staff. There is one question that remains: What happens if an insurance department is not certified? Shouldn't there be more teeth?
Q. Do you favor Federal regulation of insurance as one solution to weak state regulation?
A. You need to tell me precisely what you mean by Federal regulation. No one has said what the Feds would do. One view is that Federal involvement with insurance should be in the form of a national guaranty fund. My idea on that is that if you have a national guaranty fund, impose a deductible so that policyholders have some incentive to investigate an insurer's financial condition.
Q. Do you object to the current characterization of insurers as facing a financial "crisis"?
A. There is no crisis. There is a manageable problem that needs to be addressed now. One problem relates to matching, whether the maturity of investment contracts that insurers sold was properly matched to the maturity of the assets the insurers invested in. That's what regulators are currently trying to determine.
Q. So does that mean that you do not expect the number of insurance company insolvencies to rise sharply?
A. I do not. The problem will be managed. There is tremendous sensitivity to the possibility of a major problem if nothing is done. The industry also understands the need to cooperate in the sense that policyholders have to believe that the industry is solvent. Yes, there will be mergers and acquisitions to lessen the number of companies -- there are too many companies writing too little business -- but there won't be a sharp rise in insolvencies.
Q. Does this mean that individual policyholders need not worry about insurers' health?
A. People are still covered by state guaranty funds. So even if the XYZ fly-by-night insurer goes broke, the individual does not get hurt. But there is a reason for insurance companies to worry because they will continue to pay for the cost of guaranty funds. As to the consumer, while the average person has insurance limits above his policy limits, that is not the ideal situation. You don't want people buying investment-type products from insurance companies and the salesman saying: "Don't worry. It's covered by insurance." Consumers should have some incentive to look at an insurer's financial condition.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James P. Corcoran (N.Y. State Insurance Dept.)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Long-Term U.S. Issues Fall

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds dropped and yields rose yesterday in a shortened pre-Christmas trading day, while most bills posted small gains.
Dealers attributed the sharp declines in the longer maturities to a relatively modest amount of selling by portfolio managers who wanted to add cash to their balance sheets, despite an extremely thin market. 
 The market in Government securities, which normally does not have fixed trading hours, closed at 2 P.M., Eastern standard time, or two hours after the Treasury and Federal Reserve closed their offices.
 
 Slightly Above Lows of Day
 As it was, the close found the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, being offered at 104 11/32, down 25/32, or slightly above its lows of the day. The decline raised the long bond's yield to 8.35 percent, from 8.27 percent on Friday.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8.5 percent issue due November 2000, dropped 18/32, to 102 4/32, as its yield rose to 8.18 percent, from 8.08 percent on Friday.
That portfolio managers would choose to take profits in a predictably thin market was not the only surprise of the day. The Federal Reserve added a further $1.5 billion of reserves to the banking system through customer repurchase agreements after it had injected a substantial amount of reserves on Friday to cover holiday credit demands by effecting six-day systemwide repos.
 
 Funds Rate at 6.5 Percent
 At the time of the Fed's latest infustion of reserves, the key funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans was trading at 7 1/8 percent, or an eighth above what is currently perceived as the Fed's target for this bedrock cost of credit. Perhaps as a result of the Fed's action, the funds rate closed at 6.5 percent.
But the Treasury bill market, which is the most sensitive to any action by the central bank, largely ignored the drop in the funds rate. The discount rate on the 90-day bills closed down a basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, at 6.54 percent; six-month bills rose two basis points, to 6.63 percent, and the one-year bills added four basis points, at 6.56 percent.
 
 Next Bill Sale on Jan. 2
 Because of the shortened holiday session, the Treasury held its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills last Friday, But the bills will still be dated Dec. 27. The Treasury's next auctions of bills are scheduled for Jan. 2, also because of holiday considerations.
After the market reopens tomorrow, the Treasury plans to auction $12.5 billion of two-year notes, which traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.29 percent, up five basis points from Friday. On Thursday, the Treasury will auction $8.5 billion of four-year notes, its last of this maturity. The four-year notes traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.74 percent, compared with 7.66 percent last Friday.
Starting in January, the Treasury will hold a monthly auction of five-year notes, instead of every three months, as has been the practice.

HEADLINE: Boston Globe to Trim Jobs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The Boston Globe said last week that it would reduce its work force by 100 full-time positions through attrition in the next five years.
The 100 positions represent about 5 percent of the full-time staff at The Globe, which employs 2,075 full-time and 500 part-time workers. 
 "We are experiencing the same economic forces affecting other companies," said William O. Taylor, the publisher of The Globe and chairman of its parent company, Affiliated Publications Inc. "Advertising is down significantly this year, and the outlook is cautious at best."
Mr. Taylor has said that he expects earnings to be down significantly at Affiliated Publications and that the company plans to raise the price of The Globe in April to 50 cents, from 35 cents, in areas more than 30 miles outside the city.

HEADLINE: Japan Offers Adults New Electronic Toys For Holiday Season

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Few countries celebrate the holidays as intensely as Japan does. As the end of the year nears, droves of blue-suited office workers take fellow employees, their best customers and their bosses on endless celebrations, often ending up in one of thousands of "snack bars" and "hostess clubs." As part of the ritual, a big-screen television set showing a music video with lyrics printed on the screen is flipped on, a microphone is passed around, and after sake and beer overwhelm traditional Japanese reticence, people begin to sing along. All night.
Now, with an enthusiasm born of long and noisy nights, Japan's industrial giants think the outside world is ready for large numbers of yet another export: those same "laser karaoke" systems that combine music, video images and lyrics in scrolling captions. 
 Japan's electronics makers are pushing a $1,000 karaoke kit for the home this holiday season. But karaoke systems are just one of the new gadgets Japan's electronics makers are selling this season. For those too shy or tone deaf to sing along, there is always the $400 Data Discman, a Walkman for those who would rather read a dictionary or encyclopedia than listen to Michael Jackson (it is Sony's hottest product of the year), or any number of car navigation systems, Japan's newest status symbol now that car phones are passe.
Not all of those products are yet available in the United States; with increasing frequency, the hottest electronics innovations are introduced first in Japan, where manufacturers feel they can gauge consumers' reactions firsthand. But even amid signs of recession, it is America that the Japanese makers ultimately have in mind, so the electronic ghost of Christmas present here is bound to be the ghost of Christmases yet to come in the United States.
Just ask Makoto Sakoh, an international marketing manager for sing-along systems at the Pioneer Electronic Corporation who has been visiting bars from New Orleans to Woodbridge, N.J., to study how karaoke systems need to be modified to suit American tastes. Pioneer says it has already installed 20,000 karaoke systems in American bars, restaurants and homes. (Pronounced kar-ah-okay, the word means "empty orchestra.")
"The basic concept is the same around the world," Mr. Sakoh said. All laser karaoke systems are centered on a videodisk player, hooked to a large television and a powerful set of speakers. The music "library" consists of disks, each containing about 28 songs and each matched with a different music video.
A laser beam "reads" the song and video much as it reads sound on a compact disk. But through a microphone, it also mixes in the voice of a person singing along. In bars or restaurants, patrons watch the video and sing along, cued by the on-screen lyrics. The system adds a lot of echoes, making even the off-pitch sound good, especially as the evening wears on.
 
The Shy American?
 "I am not trying to bring Japanese culture to other countries," Mr. Sakoh said the other day, when asked whether the United States was ready for the era of just-in-time sing-alongs. "American karaoke is quite different from Japanese style. In Japan, karaoke customers sing alone. In the U.S., they sing in groups. I don't know why. Maybe Americans are really very shy."
In his office at Pioneer's headquarters here, Mr. Sakoh keeps a video of a recent beach party for college students in Daytona Beach, Fla., who seem anything but shy. He shakes his head as he watches a group of swimsuit-clad students scream out the refrain of "Born to Be Wild" at a bar Pioneer hired to promote its system.
"These people are crazy," he says.
Half a million karaoke systems have been installed in Japan, or one for every 250 Japanese. The market is saturated, though Sony has found a hit this year with a poor man's karaoke system that consists of a bullhorn that alters one's voice and plays a limited repertoire of tunes stored in computer chips.
 
Popular in Asia
 While Pioneer, which did a $500 million business in karaoke systems last year, thinks America will eventually be ripe for karaoke, right now the big market is in Asia. (The exception is South Korea, where bitter memories of Japan's occupation have resulted in laws barring the sale of Japanese songs.)
In Taiwan and Hong Kong, restaurants often install several Chinese-language systems, at a cost of $4,000 to $8,000 each. "They have to put them in private rooms," Mr. Sakoh said, "because too many fights were breaking out about what to play."
If karaoke is Japan's export hit, the nation's at-home Christmas present is the Data Discman, Sony's latest entry in CD-ROM players. A CD-ROM is a compact disk jammed with digital data, usually encyclopedia entries or phone directories or transcripts of court decisions and newspaper articles. But until now, one usually needed a computer, hooked to a CD-ROM disk drive, to get at the reams of data packed onto a single disk. No longer.
The Discman is a one-pound, palm-sized keyboard with a pop-up liquid-crystal display. About four inches by seven inches, it "plays" eight-centimeter disks, about the size of "CD Singles" or small CD's that play one song. But they are big enough to pack a huge amount of computer data: Type in a key word and you can call up an encyclopedia entry.
 
A Hot Novelty
 When Sony brought out the Data Discman, at roughly $450, its product planners thought it would be a novelty, but not a big seller until many textbooks, dictionaries, instruction manuals, even product catalogues were available on the tiny disks. They were wrong. At the end of last month, Sony had already sold 90,000 units and told its factories to pump out 20,000 a month.
But so far, the only model is a Japanese-language one. Sony says English-language material has not yet been put in the right format for the miniature disk player. The problems are expected to be solved by next summer. Already, one feature of the players works in any language: Data Discman users who are tired of reading can pop in a CD single. The Discman plays music, through a set of headphones.
Another new category of electronic gadgetry in Japan this season also uses CD-ROM: car-navigation systems, which display a street map on a dashboard screen and indicate a car's exact location. As the car moves, so does a dot tracking its position on city streets and open road.
 
U.S. Technology
 American companies have been experimenting with such systems for years, and provide much of the key technology. But the first major commercial systems seem to be coming out in Japan, largely because an organization called the Digital Road Map Association -- financed by electronics makers and automobile companies -- has turned out a four-disk road atlas that covers all of the archipelago, from Hokkaido to Okinawa. A set of disks costs just shy of $300.
The disks are placed in a CD-ROM player installed in a car, and the maps appear on a color, flat-panel liquid crystal display screen.
But while many technologies are being marketed to track a driver's position, none yet work as well as their promoters contend.
The most advanced systems, like Pioneer's new $4,000 model and similar ones being marketed by Mazda and Toyota, fix a car's location by receiving signals from 16 global positioning satellites in orbit. The satellites have long been used by the military, and by ships.
The signals are received by a flat, box-like antenna mounted on a car's trunk. Fed into the navigation system's computer, the signals are matched with the maps, displaying the car's movements with an accuracy that can be measured in yards.
The problem is that not enough satellites are yet in orbit to give 24-hour coverage of the earth -- meaning that in midafternoon and after 9 P.M. in Japan, the system is useless. And on a recent test through the streets of Tokyo, the signal was frequently lost, especially in areas surrounded by high buildings. Nonetheless, Pioneer says it has sold 6,000 units since the system went on sale this summer.
 
Gyroscopes and Compasses
 Competing systems, promoted by Mitsubishi Motors and others, do not rely on satellites. Some use a gyroscope, which senses every turn of the car and adjusts the map display accordingly. Others use a compass in combination with a sensor that counts the rotation of a car's wheels and calculates the distance traveled. Both systems, however, require the driver to enter a precise position before setting out on a journey.
All three technologies suffer from a common problem: So far, the CD-ROM maps are not very detailed.

The system combines recorded music with video images and captioned lyrics flashed on the video screen. (Kaku Kurita for The New York Times) (pg. 46)
