HEADLINE: Anxious California Braces for Another Dry Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRO BAY, Calif., Dec. 20

 BODY:
The drought that has stricken California and the Southwest is entering its fifth year, and probably nowhere has water become more of a preoccupation of daily life than here on the central coast of California.
An ordinary puddle can be a source of wonder; people funnel waste water from their washing machines to their gardens, and Joy Elliott, the police chief's administrative assistant here, catches the three gallons of cold water that come up before the hot water starts in her morning shower and saves it for the lawn. 
 The drought has left gardeners and construction workers without jobs and has prompted the City Council here to consider importing water by barge from Canada. Neighbors snitch on one another for wasting water, and the town is riven by recriminations over getting more.
"People get angry," said Sandi Ford, Morro Bay's water conservation enforcer, or "water witch," as she calls herself. "Nobody ever thought the day would come when we didn't have water."
But that day has come for most of California, Nevada and Arizona. All signs point to a fifth consecutive dry year, forcing restrictions that could fundamentally alter living styles in a region for which cheap, plentiful water has long been the blood coursing through the veins of the economy. Water rationing will start Feb. 1 in Southern California, the land of swimming pools and car washes.
The drought could also affect other parts of the country, as California farmers, who produce half of all the fruits and vegetables in the United States, change crops and cut acreage.
And the drought has stirred growing complaints among urban residents that California farmers, who use more than 80 percent of the water, waste the cheap, federally subsidized water they get by inefficient irrigation and by growing crops like alfalfa and cotton, which require a lot of water.
Almost nothing has been untouched by the drought in California, whose population of nearly 30 million competes with forests, wildlife, agriculture and industry for increasingly scarce water. Wells are going brackish and electricty rates are up, partly because of lost hydroelectric power.
Despite a snowstorm in the Sierra Nevada this week it will take much more to reverse the cumulative effect of four years of drought. Since Oct. 1, when the wet season normally begins in arid California, precipitation has been only 25 percent of normal, and stream flows are ominously low.
 
Dropping Water Levels
 At a time when reservoirs are normally refilling after the summer the water levels in California's reservoirs have been dropping and now stand at 57 percent of the average for this time of year. They are down by four million acre feet of water, or about 10 percent below last year's level. An acre foot is 325,851 gallons, about enough to supply two families for one year.
"Right now we are partially using reservoir storage," said Maurice Roos, chief hydrologist at the California Department of Water Resources. "We just will not be able to supply the water we used to."
In Nevada, the nation's fastest-growing state, John W. James, a climatologist in Reno who is chairman of the Governor's Drought Review and Reporting Committee, said, "It's like being behind three months on your car payment and you can't make this month's payment, either."
Cities, water agencies and farmers throughout the region are taking costly emergency measures to find more water and conserve what they have. In Santa Barbara, 80 miles northwest of Los Angeles, the City Council voted Tuesday to build a plant to purify seawater, even as a debate continued over whether to also build a pipeline to tie the city into the State Water Project, a system of dams, reservoirs and aqueducts that channels water from the Sierra Nevada to farms and cities through much of California.
 
Rationing to Start Feb. 1
 On Dec. 11 the Metropolitan Water District, which supplies two-thirds of the water to Southern California, ordered a 10 percent cut in supplies starting on Feb. 1, the first such rationing since 1977. The order has forced cities from Los Angeles to San Diego to consider adding stiff penalities to the current rules against washing sidewalks and watering plants during the day.
Morro Bay, a fishing and tourist town of 10,000 people 12 miles northwest of San Luis Obispo, depends entirely on underground water, and four of its eight wells have gone dry or bad.
The City Council is considering a number of options, all very costly. These options, in addition to the proposal to import water from Canada, include desalination, diverting coastal streams, tying into the State Water Project and reclaiming waste water.
Drought is nothing new to California. In "East of Eden," a novel about Salinas Valley settlers in the first two decades of the 20th century, John Steinbeck wrote about cracked land and listless cattle nibbling at dry twigs.
"People would have to haul water in barrels to their farms just for drinking," he wrote. "And it never failed that during the dry years the people forgot about the rich years, and during the wet years they lost all memory of the dry years. It was always that way."
Since then the vast water systems have turned deserts into prosperous farms and sprawling industrialized cities that today are, in a way, even more dependent on water than Steinbeck's settlers.
Despite four dry years, California farmers have managed to keep production up, with $17.5 billion in sales last year. But this could be the break year for many, with water deliveries expected to be cut by 65 percent if heavy precipitation does not occur soon.
Those with permanent crops, like almonds or citrus, will have to buy water at any cost to preserve their plants for better years, said Mary-Ann Warmerdam, director of natural resources for the California Farm Bureau.
 
Some Terrible Choices
 Other farmers will have to switch to crops that use less water, like broccoli, garlic and onions. Those who can will switch to pumping water found underground, despite the heavy expense.
But there is so little good underground water on the west side of the vast Central Valley that farmers like Ted Sheely face some terrible choices. He raises cotton and tomatoes on 1,000 acres in Huron, in Kings County south of Fresno. His only choice may be to stop planting cotton. "If I don't have enough water I'll have to cut back and lay off people," he said.
The situation is no better across the Sierra in Nevada, where Gov. Bob Miller's 12-member drought committee is expected to send a drought plan to the Legislature next week.
For California cities, the effects vary enormously. San Francisco, which gets 80 percent of its water from just one reservoir, cut water use last year by 25 percent with rationing, but more cuts may be needed. Los Angeles, with more diverse sources, is expected to get by in 1991 with a relatively modest conservation rate of 10 percent, said Bruce Keubler, assistant chief engineer for the water system of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power.
But nowhere is the situation more critical than here on the central coast, and to some extent the problem is self-inflicted. About 20 years ago voters in Morro Bay refused to approve a bond measure to tie in to the Whale Rock Reservoir, forcing the town to remain on well water. Of the four remaining wells, two are so brackish that a portable desalination plant had to be rented to make the water potable.
Many people say the problem is that water has been too cheap -- only about $20 a month for a family of three. "People pay more for cable televison than water," said Mayor Rose Marie Sheetz.
Now the residents of Morro Bay are beginning to pay the price of past neglect.
Many are angry at the motels, where they believe tourists waste water. "They take longer showers than we do," one businessman complained. In Morro Bay, the problem is that tourism is not only the worst drain on water, but also the mainstay of the economy.
"We're hanging on by the skin our teeth right now," said G. H. Nichols, the director of public works.

HEADLINE: No Happy Season for Retailers

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The Christmas shopping season, which concluded last night with a soft thud, held a number of surprises, but none were very jolly.
In telephone interviews yesterday, merchants around the country generally expressed disappointment with the 32-day season, which began the day after Thanksgiving. Most said their business was flat, or about equal to their 1989 sales. Some said they had a small decline, and others reported a slight gain. 
 But when merchandise inflation of 2 to 4 percent is excluded from their results, almost everyone interviewed had a real decline from the figures a year earlier. "The poorest Christmas season in years" was a common expression.
Perhaps the biggest surprise, merchants said, was that retailers' predictions of a dismal season were not pessimistic enough. Many forecasts called for a 5 percent gain, but it is now expected that when all the numbers are in the industry will probably register a decline.
 
 No 'Cliffhanger'
 Another surprise was that the much-hoped-for "cliffhanger" never developed. Increasingly, in the last few years, heavy consumer buying has come later and later in the holiday season. Many merchants this year hoped that a late surge would reverse the season's earlier sluggishness. Although stores were busy over the final weekend and yesterday, the sales were lower than expected.
And a third surprise was that in some stores higher-priced goods outsold medium-priced items. "The customer has been clearly value-oriented," said Arthur Martinez, vice chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue, "but the irony is that the bigger-ticket, mostly designer goods sold well, while the real lag was in the more moderate-priced merchandise."
 
 Dominated by Price-Cutting
 Both direct and indirect consumer concerns hampered sales. "Consumers are so bombarded with bad news, the economy, the deficit, the Mideast and so on that it's no wonder they bought less than last year," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis. Price-cutting dominated the season's merchandising. Some of it was done by retailers trying to stimulate a season already in trouble.
But also, in the big cities and their suburbs, hundreds of stores, run by more than a half-dozen highly leveraged or financially troubled retail chains, slashed prices to raise cash. This brought in many customers, but also caused others to wait for still lower prices elsewhere.
"We'll show a gain over last year, but it's been a difficult season because we had to compete with the 'broke' competition," said William Dillard Sr., chairman of the Dillard Department Stores of Little Rock, Ark.
Holiday business was also hampered by unseasonally warm weather in the East and South. This created a huge inventory buildup in cold-weather apparel. Such clothes are both a seasonal item and a holiday gift. This prompted Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retailer, to advance its usual post-Christmas sale to two weeks or so before Christmas.
The 30-degree swing in the weather from a cold 1989 to a warm 1990 was also cited as a particular problem by Bloomingdale's in New York and Rich's in Atlanta.
 
 K Mart Stocks 'Under Control'
 "We'll be flat to 1 percent ahead, despite the extra shopping day this season, unfortunately," said Joseph Antonini, chairman and chief executive of the K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer after Sears. "I wish it were better," he added, "but we kept our stocks under control, so that we are $600 million less in inventory in our K Mart division."
Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson said: "The season was less than great. We think our same-stores will be flat. But our Target discount stores will be up 1 to 2 percent, our Mervyn's promotional apparel stores will be flat, and our Dayton Hudson department stores will be down by 1 to 2 percent. But all our inventories are surprisingly good."
Bloomingdale's 15 stores will wind up with "a very small decrease over all -- and a couple of percentage points down in our same stores," said Julian Taub, senior vice president for planning. But costume jewelry, Christmas decorations and men's furnishings had a strong season. Still, Mr. Taub said, speaking with a light touch, "December was our second-best month of the winter; October was a better month with less of a drop."
 
 Saks Margins Held Up
 Saks Fifth Avenue will be flat for the month, said Mr. Martinez, its vice chairman. But he added: "We operated with below-normal expenses so our margins held up. We should have a fine profit." He said that the markets in Boston and New York were the chain's hardest hit. Markets in Florida and Texas were strong while California's was satisfactory, he added.
Roger Farah, chairman of Rich's, said he expected the department store chain to register a slight decline in December because of warm weather and the regional economic slump. But Wilbur A. Fix, chairman of Bon Marche in Seattle, said that despite "a kick in the pants from a 12-inch snowfall last week," in a city that is unaccustomed to snow, "our business picked up, so we expect a 5 percent increase in our same stores this month."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Republicans Silent and Smiling

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
While Gov. Jim Florio and his fellow Democrats struggle with the prospect of yet another budget crisis, Republicans are offering few suggestions, hoping to keep the public's anger over Mr. Florio's 1990 tax increases boiling right up to the 1991 elections.
If the Republican strategy succeeds, the party would stand a chance of capturing both houses of the Legislature for the first time in nearly two decades. 
 "The question is: Will taxes be an issue in '91?" said Steven A. Salmore, a professor ofpolitical science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, who is also a Republican political consultant. "I certainly don't see it coming off the agenda."
 
Hiring and Building Freeze
 As Mr. Florio comes to the end of his first year in office, he is facing a possible budget shortfall of $600 million. He has put a freeze on hiring and major building projects while his administration drafts plans that are likely to include layoffs and the elimination of some state departments.
These budget problems come only months after Mr. Florio pushed $2.8 billion in tax increases through the Legislature to close another budget gap and raise more money for public education. Those tax increases heightened widespread anger that voters directed against the Governor's party in November, leading to the near defeat of New Jersey's most popular Democrat, Senator Bill Bradley.
Professor Salmore and other Republicans now project a series of events in the coming year that could make the issue of rising taxes even hotter by next November, when every seat in the Legislature will come up for election, something that occurs only once eery 10 years.
Those events begin in January, when employers start withholding larger amounts from paychecks because of Mr. Florio's income-tax increase enacted last June.
Though the Florio administration estimates that the $1.7 billion income-tax increase will affect only 17 percent of taxpayers, those at the top of the income scale, the new rates are certain to renew attention to the tax question.
 
Property-Tax Relief in Doubt
 One explosive issue is Mr. Florio's statements during the 1989 campaign that he saw no need for new taxes. Only months later, he raised not only the income tax but also the sales tax and other taxes.
The next potential hazard for the Democrats is the Governor's insistence that the new taxes will be offset by property-tax relief. Most voters interpret that to mean their property taxes will go down, or at least stabilize.
The likelihood of that in a battered economy, when tax revenue is falling locally as well as at the state level and nearly every community is struggling to balance its budget, is uncertain at best. If it does not happen, already skeptical taxpayers are likely to see tax relief as another broken promise.
"There are two issues at work here," Mr. Salmore said, "taxes and credibility, and the credibility problem is going to be more potent in the end."
Meanwhile, Republicans are doing well, in a sense, by doing nothing, at least as far as taking the legislative initiative on taxes and revenues.
"I think Jim Florio and the Democrats in the Legislature made dreadful mistakes," said Garabed Haytaian, the Assembly's minority leader and the chief legislative critic of the Florio tax increases. "The worst sin was not to bring the Republicans in to discuss this in the beginning. They have nobody to blame but themselves."
 
Democrats Told to Start Over
 Rather than offer an alternative tax plan, or try to repeal the Florio package piecemeal, the Republicans have urged Democrats to set their house in order by scrapping the whole tax package and starting over, a prospect that almost certainly would plunge the Legislature into partisan debate.
The Republicans have also called on the Democrats to take the lead in cutting costs. Mr. Haytaian, for example, has urged cutting state jobs by 5 percent, a move Governor Florio has said would probably violate existing labor contracts.
"Now they have a new potential deficit of $600 million," Mr. Haytaian said. "There is only one way to prevent that, you have to cut jobs."
But Mr. Haytaian emphasizes that the real goal is to start from scratch. "We have always said, let's put the whole package back on the table."
 
'I Told You So'
 At the same time, he also says that it is the Democrats who are in trouble, and that it is their responsibility to get out of it.
"I don't want somebody to say to me, what's your proposal?" he said. "I do want to say, I told you so.
"Now I want to sit down with the Assembly and the Governor and bring in the middle-level managers and get them to tell us how we can cut costs."
Mr. Haytaian is making it clear that the Republicans will do nothing that would take the heat off the Democrats.
This week, for example, the Speaker and Democratic leader in the Assembly, Joseph V. Doria Jr., declared he would not extend the life of the state's troubled trust fund for uninsured hospital patients, and asked for a bipartisan effort to come up with a new system, one that would very likely require another tax increase.
But Mr. Haytaian responded, "It's the Democrats' problem. They control the Legislature."
 
'The Voters Sent a Message'
 Jeff Michaels, the executive director of the state Republican Party, also maintains that the only solution to the pending new budget crisis, and the only balm to taxpayer anger, is to start over.
"The Republican position all along has been that the tax package was disastrous for New Jersey," Mr. Michaels said. "And we were proved right by the voters. The voters sent a message that they want the tax package scrapped and the school funding formula scrapped."
"The Republicans are willing to go back to the drawing board," he said. "Jim Florio is unwilling to do that."
In addition to requesting wide-open tax and budget renegotiations that would almost certainly keep the issue alive indefinitely, Republicans are also making it known that they support machinery to allow for the recall of legislators and the governor, for binding procedures for initiative and referendum to make or repeal laws by popular vote, and for limiting lawmakers' terms.
The first two, recall and initiative and referendum, are among proposals pushed by an anti-tax group, Hands Across New Jersey.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gov. Jim Florio, above (William E. Sauro/The New York Times), is facing a possible budget shortfall of $600 million at the end of his first year. "I think Jim Florio and the Democrats in the Legislature made dreadful mistakes," said Garabed Haytaian, the Assembly's minority leader. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Economy May Droop, but Gifts to Charities Are Climbing

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Even as thousands of New Yorkers are losing their jobs and economic forecasters are painting a bleak future for the region, New Yorkers are digging deep and coming up with increased donations for organizations that help the needy.
Many charities -- including the United Way of New York City, the United Jewish Appeal-Federation and Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York -- are reporting increases in giving, a result of aggressive fund-raising and, some say, of the generosity that people express in tough times. 
 "Charity comes out of hard times, not good ones," said Kermit Eady, president of the Black United Fund of New York. The fund helps 33 small organizations meet the growing needs of poor blacks. Mr. Eady said contributions to the fund, which raised $2.7 million last year, "are upward" this year.
The United Way of New York City, which has a goal of $84 million this year, has seen a9 percent increase so far in its campaigns for employee pledges at 200 local companies.
"We are elated because we're seeing New Yorkers somehow finding the money -- small dollars and some big gifts," said Ralph Dickerson, the president of United Way of New York City.
 
Salvation Army Trailing
 While some charities are reporting shortfalls, they are attributing that to factors other than a lack of generosity. For instance, the Salvation Army's Christmas appeal is running 11 percent behind lastyear's, but a spokesman said that was probably because the organization was having a hard time recruiting volunteers to mind the familiar kettles that dot shopping districts. The kettle campaign raises slightly more than $1 million a year.
Nationally the 2,300 separate United Way campaigns are expected to grow by 4.6 percent -- the first time in eight years a collection has been outpaced by the rate of inflation, which is running at 6 percent.
But in New York City the United Way is outdistancing both inflation and comparable fund drives in Boston, Washington, Cleveland and Detroit.
Still, the New York campaign is lagging behind San Francisco's, where there has been an 11 percent increase in giving over last year's showing. In Indianapolis and Seattle donations are up by about 10 percent.
In New York, social services historically have depended on a partnership between government and private contributors going back more than 100 years, according to AlanJ. Abramson, a political scientist who analyzed how services are delivered for the Urban Institute, a Washington research organization. Typically city, state and Federal sources provide 40 to 65 percent of the budgets for services by more than 4,000 private, nonprofit health or social-service organizations -- everything from prenatal care to shelter for people with AIDS. The balance comes from individual contributors, companies and foundations.
 
Government Support Weakening
 With both New York State and New York City grappling with huge budget deficits, charitable organizations are bracing for a drastic decline in government support.
"We know a great part of the $2 billion the city and the $1 billion the state usually provides for basic social services are in jeopardy," Mr. Dickerson said. "Still, we're glimpsing a spirit in people who have jobs to help keep money flowing until economic conditions can be turned around. People are saying, 'I'm staying here; I'm going to help on my block, and in my neighborhood.' And that is bringing in the money in New York, which is really a town of 500 neighborhoods."
The New York Archdiocese's annual Cardinal's Appeal surpassed its $7 million goal and raised $9 million, said Joseph Zwilling, director of communications. In addition 30 separate parish campaigns received $11.2 million in gifts or pledges. The 30 parishes retain at least 80 percent of the funds they raise for their own needs, like building repairs.
The Brooklyn Diocese, which runs a separate appeal for Brooklyn and Queens, also reports a rise in donations.
Lester M. Salamon, director of the Johns Hopkins Institute for Policy Studies and the author of several reports on nonprofit social-service organizations, said it was not unusual that charity appeared to be increasing as the economy foundered.
"An increase in private giving is consistent with historic patterns in which giving continues to grow in the early months of a recession but then levels off," he said."We know this happened in the mid-70's and early 80's."
 
Widespread Generous Giving
 Organizations ranging from the Gay Men's Health Crisis, which helps people with AIDS, to Fountain House, which helps former mental patients adjust to life on their own, have reported large increases in their donations.
But even that generosity is not enough, according to Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless, which expects its holiday mail campaign to bring in about $400,000. "Even if we received 10 times that total," she said, "it would not begin to meet the need."
Some campaigns began slowly but have recently begun to pick up.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which solicits on behalf of seven leading charities, recently moved ahead of collections at this time last year after a slow beginning last month. The total raised in the last campaign was $4,372,283.
"We are receiving many letters from contributors saying that in these uncertain economic times, it is more important than ever to help those in desperate need," said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Foundation, which administers the campaign.
 
Elderly Feel the Pinch
 The Children's Aid Society, the largest nonsectarian provider of help in the city for families and children, reported that its gifts were down about 10 percent from 1989. Many of its contributors are elderly New Yorkers on fixed incomes.
"Still, people who can afford it clearly are giving more, stirred by the open, brutal face of poverty all around us," said Philip Coltoff, the executive director. "My sense is we'll achieve our goal by year's end."
The annual drive of the U.J.A.-Federation, a major provider of services to 130 member agencies that assist 1.5 million New Yorkers of all faiths, is only slightly ahead of 1989. But then the orgnization simultaneously solicited for two other campaigns this year: More than $75 million was collected or pledged for Operation Exodus to help settle Soviet Jews in Israel and another $75 million for a multi-year $1.2 billion capital campaign for the benefit of members, said David G. Sacks, president of U.J.A.-Federation.
A number of organizations have assured increased donations by expanding their appeals.
United Way of New York, for instance, has solicited contributions from foreign-owned businesses, including banks and investment firms with large offices in the metropolitan area.
 
'Ambassadors' Solicit Funds
 It also has recruited a corps of "ambassadors" to carry its message to the public. One is Ed Glynn.
"When I go out to talk to business groups in Manhattan, I usually begin by telling them they may recognize me as someone they saw on the streets, living in a cardboard box, panhandling for change with a Styrofoam cup, usually outside the door at the post office or bank on Lexington Avenue," Mr. Glynn said in a recent interview. "My block was 45th Street."
That was three years ago. Now he works for an agency that helps New Yorkers with drug and alcohol addictions.
"I tell people, 'Because of the money you give, there is one less body you have to look at on the street and one less panhandler's cup put in your face.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Falling prices are making an impact on the American economy for the first time since the 1940's. Real estate prices are most notable, but deflation is also visible in steel, aluminum, plastics and other commodities used in manufacturing. Over all, the price drops are still outweighed by increases for many things, like medical care, college tuition and legal services. [Page 1.]
The Christmas shopping season held a number of surprises, but none was very jolly, merchants said. The biggest surprise of the season, which ended with a soft thud, was that retailers' predictions of a dismal season were not pessimistic enough. Most said business was flat, and after inflation, they had a real drop. They cited bad economic news, the Mideast crisis and warm weather. [43.]
 
International
European-owned air-cargo companies will get more freedom to operate in Europe's express-delivery business, thanks to new regulations taking effect next week. But the American and Australian companies that now dominate the fast-growing business complain that they will be left at a disadvantage. [43.]
Japan's industrial giants are ready to send the outside world yet another of their electronic exports: "laser karaoke" systems that combine music, video images and lyrics in scrolling captions. They are popular at Tokyo holiday celebrations. [1.]
Companies are providing the American troops streaming into Saudi Arabia with products as varied as soup, lip balm and hams. The Government is getting these goods at cut rates as companies bid for contracts so they can use idle capacity. [43.]
 
Companies
Warner Bros., producer of "Bonfire of the Vanities," is seeing its hopes dashed. The film, which cost about $40 million to produce and more to promote, took in a paltry $3.1 million in its opening weekend, a third of what might have been expected. Nor is Warner alone; the holiday season has been dismal for Hollywood. [43.]
Pan Am's cash position was strengthened by United Airlines, which paid in advance for assets it bought. The $20 million infusion, however, does not solve Pan Am's problem of how to survive a winter when traffic is low and fuel prices high. [43.]
Volkswagen will be running the Czechoslovakian plants that make the Favorit, a small family-style car made by Skoda, by March, it appears, as a result of a $6 billion agreement the West German company signed with Prague Government. [43.]
Halliburton said that the I.R.S. had accused it of having underpaid its Federal income taxes by about $247 million from 1980 through 1986. The oilfield services company said it believed most of the more than 200 points cited were without merit. [45.]
 
 Markets
Stocks fell slightly with the Dow average off 12.37 points, to 2,621.29, in the slowest trading of the year. Professionals attached little significance to the decline, attributing most of it to computerized program selling. [46.]
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds dropped and yields rose in a shortened pre-Christmas trading day, while most bills posted small gains. Federal funds traded as low a 6 1/2 percent. [52.]
The dollar strengthened, particularly against the German mark and the British pound, as traders sought a haven from volatility in the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union. [53.]
Wheat futures prices rose moderately in a rally linked to new export sales and fears of weather damage to the winter crop. [53.]
 
 Today's Columns
Insurance regulation should be strengthened, but there is no crisis, says James P. Corcoran, who was New York State insurance commissioner until last January. Talking Business. [44.]
Training programs for employees from entry level to top managers are likely to gain in importance in the 1990's. Careers. [47.]

HEADLINE: Bizarre New Class of Molecules Spawns Its Own Branch of Chemistry

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
AN explosion of research in what scientists are hailing as a new branch of chemistry has followed the recent discovery that bizarre ball-shaped molecules made entirely of carbon atoms can be easily produced in large quantities.
The ball molecules were tentatively identified five years ago, but laboratories succeeded in synthesizing only microscopic amounts of the new compounds -- too little for chemists to verify the molecules' structures or study their properties. The very existence of carbon-ball molecules was challenged by some scientists. 
 But two months ago, physicists at the University of Arizona in Tucson and the Max Planck Institute for Nuclear Physics in Heidelberg, Germany, announced that they had discovered a way to make large quantities of the ball-shaped molecules. In one of their first experiments, they discovered that the carbon-ball molecules, when purified, combine in a crystalline form that chemists had never suspected could exist.
And this month the Arizona-Heidelberg collaboration and the I.B.M. Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif., independently published photographs in the British journal Nature that verify the existence of carbon-ball molecules beyond reasonable doubt. The photographs, made with scanning electron microscopes, clearly show the spherical molecules, packed together like so many ball bearings, on sheets of gold foil.
The carbon-ball molecules are named "fullerenes" in memory of the architect Richard Buckminster Fuller, whose designs often exploited the geodesic dome -- a strong hemispherical structure made of interlocked beams. The new carbon molecules, which are also very strong, are held together by similar patterns of chemical bonds between neighboring carbon atoms.
Chemists regard the fullerenes as three-dimensional analogues of the two-dimensional benzene ring, a hexagonal array of six carbon atoms that is a component of more than six million chemical compounds. Compounds containing benzene rings include vanilla flavor, cleaning fluid, three of the amino acids essential to life, pharmaceuticals, dyes, explosives, plastics and countless other substances. In theory, the new family of fullerenes could become components of an even greater variety of chemical combinations than those based on the ubiquitous benzene ring.
Though practical uses remain to be found, researchers are confident that fullerenes will produce rich rewards. "This is a brand new field of chemistry," said Dr. Donald R. Huffman of the University of Arizona. "Up to now, chemists and physicists have lacked sufficient fullerene material. But now it's possible to make fullerenes by the pound, and a lot of laboratories are interested in the possibilities -- Exxon , A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories, U.C.L.A. and Berkeley and many others. Everyone's excited."
Representing the University of Arizona, Research Corporation Technologies, a nonprofit organization in Tucson, has filed for worldwide patent protection of the techniques for making fullerenes. Other research groups are expected to apply for related patents. A measure of the intense interest in fullerenes was evident at a late-night meeting of the Materials Research Society in Boston in November. The meeting was attended by more than 500 scientists, an exceptional number for such a symposium.
 
Sowing a Bucket of Seeds
 Even skeptics have been impressed by the discovery that fullerenes can be mass-produced. One of them, Dr. Donald J. Cram of the University of California at Los Angeles, said he was convinced that fullerenes had a bright future. Dr. Cram received a 1987 Nobel Prize for his development of cagelike carbon molecules.
"The discovery that these soccer-ball-like molecules can be made in large quantities will have an effect on chemistry like the sowing of a bucket of flower seeds -- the results will spring up everywhere from now on," he said. "I'd be surprised if we don't see thousands of new fullerene compounds in the next few years, some of which are almost certain to have important uses."
Some scientists speculate that fullerenes might provide a new class of lubricants, since the microscopic carbon balls can apparently roll as freely as ball bearings. Chemists see carbon balls as potential connecting molecules in millions of new compounds, many of which are expected to have very unusual properties. For example, some fullerene compounds may be capable of storing electric charges in novel ways, and this could lead to great improvements in storage batteries.
Fullerenes have also intrigued astrophysicists, who have speculated that carbon balls might exist in interstellar space. If so, the study of fullerenes could illuminate the behavior of certain types of stars.
The existence of fullerenes was postulated in 1985 by research groups led by Dr. Richard E. Smalley of Rice University in Houston and Dr. Harold W. Kroto of the University of Sussex in England. By irradiating graphite with powerful laser pulses, the Rice chemists produced carbon vapor that condensed into microscopic clusters. Spectrographic and X-ray analyses suggested that many of these clusters contained 60 carbon atoms each.
 
Molecules of 1,000 Atoms
 Applying the fundamental principle that every molecule tends to assume a shape corresponding to its lowest possible energy, the scientists deduced that each 60-atom cluster would probably assume a three-dimensional form corresponding to a truncated icosahedron -- a hollow, ball-like molecule with 60 vertices and 32 faces, of which 12 would be regular pentagons and 20 would be regular hexagons. Geometry implies that each pentagonal face should be bounded by five hexagons. Spectrographic and X-ray analyses tended to confirm these theories.
Dr. Smalley said the scientists also found egg-shaped configurations with 70 carbon atoms, and he added that depending on the conditions in which carbon vapor was condensed, clusters of 1,000 carbon atoms or more might form. In fact, the Rice group discovered, any even number of carbon atoms, from at least 1,000 atoms to as few as 32, can combine as a spheroidal molecule. (When chemists tried to reduce the fullerene molecules to fewer than 32 atoms, they broke up spontaneously.)
Fullerenes form when solid carbon condenses as soot from hot carbon vapor, and the vapor's rate of cooling determines the types and amounts of fullerene compounds created in the condensation, Dr. Smalley said. Chemists at Rice and Sussex theorize that under most conditions the condensation of the vapor results in the addition of carbon atoms to a molecular pattern resembling warped chicken wire. As atoms are added to the outer edges of this array, the chicken wire grows as a spiral suggesting the chambered nautilus, a primitive shellfish.
When conditions are favorable, the chicken wire closes on itself and joins at its edges to form spheroids -- most often, fullerene molecules of 60 carbon atoms.
 
Breakthrough in a Vacuum
 A major impetus in fullerene research came in September, when Dr. Huffman and fellow physicists at the University of Arizona and the Max Planck Institute hit upon a way to make large quantities of these bizarre substances. Dr. Smalley, a chemist, said he and his colleagues were stunned by the breakthrough achieved by Dr. Huffman and the other physicists.
"Their approach to the problem was very different from ours," Dr. Smalley said. "Their demonstration that fullerenes could be mass-produced as easily as metallic aluminum brought the study of fullerenes out of a backwater and into the mainstream of science."
In the method pioneered at the University of Arizona, an electric arc is passed between graphite electrodes in a vacuum chamber containing a small amount of helium. Carbon from the electrodes vaporizes and is then allowed to cool, condensing as soot on surfaces inside the chamber.
About 5 percent of this soot, the scientists found, is C60 fullerene molecules. Those molecules can be separated from the soot, purified and refined into crystals.
 
A New Form of Carbon
 "One of the reasons physicists and chemists are so excited by these fullerene crystals," said Dr. Donald S. Bethune of I.B.M.'s Almaden Research Center, "is that they have revealed the existence of a third elemental form of carbon -- a form of which we had been completely unaware." The two previously known forms are graphite and diamond.
But it is the potential chemical versatility of fullerenes that has put dozens of major laboratories to work. The unique qualities of the carbon atom -- nature's universal connecting joint -- underlie scientists' fascination with the new fullerenes.
When a carbon atom joins with other atoms to form a stable molecule, the internal structure of the carbon atom requires it to form four electronic links with neighboring atoms. In most cases, these links are in the form of single or double bonds. In fullerenes, Dr. Smalley said, single and double bonds are probably distributed around the molecule, and it does not easily react with other chemicals. But if some or all of its double bonds are converted to single bonds, the molecule becomes reactive and can form links with other atoms or molecules.
Some research groups are working in secret, developing patent applications for materials and techniques that could have great economic importance. Dr. Huffman said one research group was believed to have succeeded in bonding fluorine atoms to all 60 carbons in a fullerene molecule. Such a molecule might, like Teflon, be exceptionally slippery and resistant to chemical attack.
The Rice chemists themselves expect to synthesize salts in which a single electrically charged metal atom would be imprisoned within each carbon-ball molecule. Material made from such molecular cages could carry electric charges without having to react chemically, and might replace electrochemical components like lead and acid in conventional storage batteries.
"Whatever happens," Dr. Smalley said, "it seems to me that the extraordinary potential variety and the cheapness of these new fullerene compounds guarantee their importance as commercial materials. This is the dawn of a new era in materials science."

HEADLINE: Big Science Gets Smaller as Its Promise Loses Luster

SERIES: Big Science: Is It Worth the Price?/Last artical in a series appearing periodically on the largest new research projects.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
 EXPERTS say 1990 will probably be considered a turning point in the history of the Federal Government's support of big science, with decades of enthusiasm giving way to wariness as costs soared, budgets tightened and major endeavors turned out to have serious flaws.
At the heart of the shift was the 12-ton, 43-foot-long, $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, which, after 45 years as a dream and 13 years of planning, promised a new era in astronomy from its post hundreds of miles from Earth. Instead, it produced fuzzy images from a flawed mirror. 
 "There's a sense of disenchantment with the promise of big science," said Representative George E. Brown Jr., a California Democrat who has served on the House Science Committee for a quarter-century and is now its chairman.
Several Federal programs meant to build large instruments for advancing the frontiers of science had their budgets substantially cut in the 1991 budget. And the biggest project of them all, the proposed 500-foot-long, $37 billion space station, was ordered by Congress to undergo a complete redesign to cut costs and complexity.
Experts predict larger cuts in the future because of the tightening Federal budget squeeze and the agreement hammered out by White House and Congressional budget negotiators in October for no real growth in discretionary domestic spending over the next three years.
"It's a looming disaster" for the big projects, said Dr. Robert L. Park, a physicist at the University of Maryland who directs the Washington office of the American Physical Society, the nation's pre-eminent professional association of physicists.
Before the budget turmoil, large new projects planned for completion in the 1990's numbered nearly two dozen. They were to cost more than $60 billion to build and more than $100 billion to operate over their lifetimes, placing a heavy mortgage on the nation's research spending well into the future.
Representative Brown said a consensus was forming in Congress to scale big projects down or, for ones too far along to change, to stretch out their construction timetables.
He also noted that after several lean years, Government support was growing for small science, in which researchers work alone or in small groups rather than in vast teams. The budgets for the Government's two leading agencies that pay for small-scale science, the National Science Foundation and the National Institutes of Health, both rose in the 1991 fiscal year, the foundation by 11 percent and the institutes by 9 percent.
Experts have recently warned that big science projects were becoming so numerous and expensive that, in a time of budget austerity, they were starting to impinge upon small endeavors.
By definition, small science is relatively cheap. Its fruits -- antibiotics, transistors, lasers -- tend to have everyday applications. Big science uses huge instruments like giant telescopes, atom smashers and planetary probes to explore some of science's most fundamental questions or to open new realms of inquiry. Its scale is big because in some fields the easy things have already been done, and futher progress demands larger, more powerful scientific tools.
The most dramatic upset this year among the big science projects involved the space station Freedom, an orbiting outpost from which up to eight astronauts would fashion new materials, study the physics of fluids, grow crystals, perform medical experiments and scan the stars. Design work started in 1984, with completion set for the mid- to late 1990's, after about 30 shuttle flights. In designing Freedom, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration rejected the idea of putting up small self-contained units that could be linked and could achieve limited operation step by step. Instead it planned a single large unit that would function only when fully assembled.
But early this year, space agency investigators found that the giant structure was so delicate that it would need thousands of hours of external repairs and maintenance every year -- an unacceptably high number, the investigators said, since the maintenance would require space-suited astronauts to walk outside the craft, a risky operation.
The original maintenance goal had been 130 hours of space walks a year; in July, the NASA investigators estimated that 6,200 hours of maintenance would be needed even before the station was permanently manned, raising the knotty question of who would do the work.
 
A Simpler Space Station
 This and other setbacks prompted Congress to trim the $2.45 billion budget request for the station by $550 million in October and to demand that it be redesigned so it could be built in self-contained stages rather than as a single entity.
On Dec. 10, a White House panel echoed that message. "We believe the space station Freedom can be simplified and constructed on a more evolutionary, modular basis," said the 12-member panel, whose head is Norman R. Augustine, chairman of the Martin Marietta Corporation.
Representative Brown said the recommendations, which NASA has generally endorsed and begun to carry out, would delay the station's completion into the 21st century.
Another big science project fared somewhat better. The Earth Observing System, a $30 billion array of six large satellites that NASA wants to orbit starting in 1997 or 1998, saw Congress trim its 1991 budget request from $235 million to $191 million.
The costliest environmental research project ever, it aims at learning how the global environment works and is altered by human activity. Critics say NASA's bureaucratic ambitions have made the plan overly grandiose, delaying the system's completion and the gathering of vital data.
This criticism was buttressed in August when a panel of the National Research Council, a Washington-based group that advises the Federal Government, found that smaller, simpler satellites could begin monitoring the climate sooner and recommended that they take priority over the Earth Observing System.
Responding to the critics, Dr. Greg Wilson, an official in NASA's earth science program, said the agency had broadened its effort, taking a number of steps to loft small satellites sooner. "We're seriously working options," he said.
 
Cutting the Collider
 The largest budget cut for big science, measured as a percentage of the 1991 request, went to the Superconducting Supercollider, a huge particle accelerator planned for the plains of Texas. Its 54-mile race-track-shaped tunnel would be fitted with 10,000 superconducting magnets, each about 100 feet long. By speeding subatomic particles through the magnetic prison and smashing them together, the machine would give scientists a deeper understanding of the fundamental forces and particles that are the building blocks of all matter.
The proposed machine came under criticism this year over its sharply rising costs and over vexing problems in the design of its giant magnets. It started out in 1987 as a $4.4 billion venture, but the estimate rose to $8 billion this year, and one Federal panel said it could cost as much as $11.7 billion.
Amid growing debate over the machine's merit, Congress cut the $318 million budget request for the collider by $75 million, or 24 percent, in October. Russell L. Wilie, a spokesman for the project, said the situation was not as grim as it appeared, since Congress also allowed the use of $25 million in construction funds left over from 1990 and Texas will release $60 million of the $1 billion in promised state money for the project.
Congress put some big science projects on hold this year, including a $190 million observatory to study gravitational waves, and President Bush's proposal to establish Moon bases and explore Mars. Citing "severe budgetary constraints," Congress deleted virtually the entire amount requested for preliminary research on the exploration plan, whose lifetime cost is estimated at up to $500 billion.
 
A Cap That Will Pinch
 Federal and private experts say budget pressures on big science are about to get even worse, and sharply so, as the three-year cap on domestic discretionary spending limits growth to the rate of inflation. For science and technology, this means that any real increases will have to come at the expense of other parts of the discretionary budget, like education and housing.
"Many of the programs that will be competing with science and technology have very highly organized, vociferous constituencies," Dr. D. Allan Bromley, President Bush's science adviser, recently told a White House audience of scientists. If the nation's science program gets no better political support than in the past, he said, it will face "very real danger."
Some experts foresee a bloodbath. "It's going to be very, very messy," said John E. Pike, head of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, a private group based in Washington. "A lot of these projects are going to be asking for big bucks, and there's no place for it to come from."
Dr. Park of the American Physical Society said stretching out large projects was not necessarily a good thing. "Total costs go up," he said. "Plus, the problems the device was intended to solve might not be relevant anymore."
Representative Brown said the crisis would probably force the projects to find foreign partners with whom to cooperate and share costs, as some have already done.
 
A Time of Opportunity?
 Some experts see the looming changes as a time of opportunity to bring the Federal science effort into better balance by increasing the emphasis on small science projects, especially those that promise to aid industrial competitiveness. They say Federal policy makers generally failed to foresee how the most ambitious array of big science projects in the nation's history would squeeze little science and each other. A new balance is critical, they say, since small science, despite its name, is the largest and most important part of the American scientific enterprise, its health vital to that of the economy.
"This year could be a turning point," said Erich Bloch, who recently stepped down after six years as director of the National Science Foundation. "I think we have to make it a turning point. These things don't happen by themselves."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Erich Bloch, former head of National Science Foundation, sees a turning point for big projects. (Marty Katz for The New York Times) (pg. 40)
 
Table: "How Big Science Projects Fared" showing projects, 1991 budget request and percent cut from that request. (pg. 40)
 
 
THE SERIES SO FAR
 The series began on May 27 with an overview of several projects that supporters believe will herald a new age of discovery, but that critics fear will starve smaller, more practical projects of scarce Federal funds.
An article on May 29 discussed the Superconducting Supercollider, the $8 billion particle accelerator that may help explain the fundamental forces of the universe. On June 5 an article outlined the monumental project to map the three billion building blocks of the human genetic code. The proposed space station Freedom was the subject on June 10, and the elaborate satellites designed to study the global environment were scrutinized on June 19.
How small-scale, but important basic research is faring was the subject on Sept. 4, and the most recent article on Oct. 9 discussed a proposal to build a hot fusion machine intended to generate vast amounts of safe, cheap and clean energy.

HEADLINE: The Group and the Self: New Focus on a Cultural Rift

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
WHILE Americans say the squeaky wheel gets the grease, in Japan the maxim is "the nail that stands out gets pounded down." And while American children who won't finish their food are given stern warnings not to waste it, Japanese children are told, "Think how bad the farmer who raised this food for you will feel if you don't eat it."
Such contrasts have emerged from a rapidly growing body of scientific studies that show how deeply individualism runs in most Western cultures, and how shallow that vein is in most others. 
 The new cross-cultural studies are confirming what many observers have long noticed: that the cardinal American virtues of self-reliance and individualism are at odds with those of most non-Western cultures. They also suggest that the nature of American individualism has been changing toward a greater emphasis on raw self-interest, and that the rise of individualism in a society goes hand in hand with economic growth.
The work contrasts individualism with "collectivism," in which a person's loyalty to a group like a family or tribe overrides personal goals. Recent studies say this outlook predominates in most cultures of Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America.
The late Raoul Narrol, a professor of anthropology at the State University of New York at Buffalo, found in a 1983 study that such societies have among the lowest rates of homicide, suicide, juvenile delinquency, divorce, child abuse and alcoholism. They also tend to have lower economic productivity, though as countries like Japan become more affluent, they also tend to become more individualistic.
The collectivist cultures comprise about 70 percent of the world's population, according to the studies. But virtually all the data of modern psychology and most other social sciences come from the most individualistic cultures, like the United States. As a result, some social scientists say, many Western assumptions about the universals of human behavior actually apply to a minority of people, albeit those in the most advanced economies.
"There are many kinds of individualism," said Robert N. Bellah, a sociologist at the University of California at Berkeley who wrote "Habits of the Heart: Individualism and Commitment in American Culture" (University of California Press, 1985). "The individualism that's on the rise recently in the U.S. is one of 'What's in it for me?' with immediate gratification of one's own needs coming before all other loyalties. Commitments like marriage only hold while they pay off."
Leading the study of individualism or its absence, and the argument for its importance in understanding people around the world, is Harry C. Triandis, a psychologist at the University of Illinois who came to America as a college student from his native Greece.
Writing in the current issue of The Nebraska Symposium on Motivation, an influential journal, and reviewing over 100 scientific studies, Dr. Triandis argues that the distinction between individualism and collectivism holds the key to understanding a range of telling contrasts from culture to culture.
Though many seem minor, they bespeak vast differences in how people see the world and themselves:
*A lecturer in the West will be introduced as "distinguished," while speakers in Asia will always begin by saying how little they know about the topic at hand.
*A telephone operator in Greece will be rude and unhelpful until the caller establishes his identity, while American operators tend to be uniformly friendly to everyone.
*In countries like Pakistan, Peru and Singapore, people take it for granted that those at the top of the social hierarchy are very different from those at the bottom and that they should keep their distance. In countries like the United States, Australia and the Netherlands, such an attitude is seen as offensively anti-egalitarian.
<> <> Perhaps most critical for understanding contemporary events is the role of the collectivist outlook in generating friction between ethnic groups. "While collectivists are very nice to those who are members of their own groups, they can be very nasty, competitive and uncooperative toward those who belong to other groups," said Dr. Triandis. "There is an unquestioned obedience to one's own group and even a willingness to fight and die for it, and a distrust of those in other groups."
This attitude, he said, encourages the kind of ethnic fighting common in many parts of the world, including sub-Saharan Africa, India and the Middle East.
In an individualist culture, people's personal goals take priority over their allegiance to groups like the family or the employer. The loyalty of individualists to a given group is very weak; they feel they belong to many groups and are apt to change their membership as it suits them, switching churches, for example, or leaving one employer for another.
In such cultures, people subscribe to values like "winning is everything" and "to be superior, a man must stand alone," Dr. Triandis wrote in the November issue of The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. The article includes findings from studies of people in Illinois, Hawaii, Hong Kong, Peking, the Philippines, Japan and Europe.
 
Different Commandments
 Collectivist societies put high value on self-discipline, accepting one's position in life, honoring parents and elders, and preserving one's public image for the sake of the group, Dr. Triandis reported. Individualists stress equality, freedom, having an exciting and varied life, and personal enjoyment.
Child rearing in collectivist cultures is intrusive; children have virtually no privacy or autonomy. "A child's dependence on parents is considered good, as is breaking the will of the child to obtain complete obedience," Dr. Triandis said. When there is conflict between personal and group goals, the group takes precedence. People feel comfortable in hierarchies, and place a premium on harmony within their group.
People with a collective focus tend to think in terms of long-term goals, which benefit the whole group, Dr. Triandis said; their time frame is likely to include "a chain of generations." Individualists, by contrast, "look for immediate rewards for their efforts."
In collectivist cultures, Dr. Triandis found, family integrity is of the utmost importance. People strongly believe, for instance, that children should live at home with their parents until they get married, and that aging parents should live at home with their children.
"In short, the values that are most important in the West are least important worldwide," said Dr. Triandis.
 
Most Invididualistic: The U.S.
 The difference can be seen readily in literature, according to a 1983 analysis by Francis Hsu, an anthropologist recently retired from Northwestern University. Dr. Hsu found that novels in the West typically focus on a lone figure seeking private goals, while those of the East commonly celebrate duty to kin or other authorities, despite personal temptations. A Western prototype is Huckleberry Finn, striking out on his own; an Eastern one is Krishna in the Bhagavad-Gita, being persuaded to do his duty and plunge into battle.
In a worldwide study of 116,000 employees of I.B.M. in 1980, Geert Hofstede, a Dutch psychologist, was able to rank 40 cultures according to the strength of individualism or collectivism.
The five most strongly individualist cultures were the United States, Australia, Great Britain, Canada and the Netherlands, in that order. The other countries of Northern Europe also ranked high.
The five where collectivism was strongest were Venezuela, Colombia, Pakistan, Peru and Taiwan. It was also strong in Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong, Turkey and some countries of Southern Europe, including Greece and Portugal.
Growing affluence and geographic mobility contribute to the spread of individualism in a culture, Dr. Triandis finds. Likewise, within a given society, "individualism is higher among the affluent, socially and geographically mobile, more modern segments," he said. But as countries like Japan become more prosperous, people start to show more signs of individualism, especially the young and urban.
The most individualistic people in a collectivist society tend to be "rebels ready to migrate from the oppression of the culture," said Dr. Triandis. That may partly explain why societies like Canada, the United States and Australia, all settled by immigrants, are among the most individualistic.
"People in different cultures have very different premises about what defines a person, with different consequences for how they think, feel and act," said Shinobu Kitiyama, a psychologist at the University of Oregon, who, with Hazel Markus, a psychologist at the University of Michigan, will publish research on the subject next year in the journal Psychological Review.
"In white middle-class America people think of themselves as a bundle of traits, preferences and desires," Dr. Kitiyama said. "But in Asian culture people conceive themselves in terms of a dense web of social relations."
 
Traps for Social Scientists
 One telling difference between American and Asian cultures, Dr. Kitiyama found, emerged when people described their contribution to a collaboration. "When you ask Americans to give a percent figure that estimates how much each member of a team contributes to the overall effort, the total is almost always greater than 100 percent. People overestimate how much weight they pull."
But in Asia, the reverse was true. People underestimated their contribution, so the total for the group was usually less than 100 percent. Such self-effacement, Dr. Kitiyama said, is part of the way people in a collectivist culture preserve harmony within their group. Studies in China, for example, show that people who are modest about their successes are better-liked than those who take pride in them.
The difference in life goals between such cultures was evident in a 1978 survey of Pacific and Asian nations by Yasumata Tanaka, a psychologist at Gakushin University in Tokyo. He found that 64 percent of New Zealanders and 50 percent of Australians subscribed to the goal of "doing whatever I think worth doing," while only 32 percent of Japanese and 12 percent of Indians agreed with that strongly individualist goal.
Some social scientists say the American focus on individualism has gone overboard. Barry Schwartz, a psychologist at Swarthmore College, has written that failure to realize the limited appeal of individualism around the world leads to basic errors in social sciences like economics. The pitfall is in overgeneralizing how essential a part of human nature individualism is; a "greedy self-interest" cannot be assumed as "an eternal law of human nature," Dr. Schwartz wrote in "The Battle for Human Nature" (Norton, 1986).
Dr. Bellah, the Berkeley sociologist, sees a broader danger. "In earlier days," he said, "the individualism in America was one that also honored community values. Today we have an ideology of individualism that simply encourages people to maximize personal advantage. This leads to a consumer politics in which 'What's in it for me?' is all that matters, while considerations of the common good are increasingly irrelevant.
"There's perhaps a better model in the democracies of Europe," he went on. "There you find a strong sense of the dignity of the individual with an equally strong social responsibility."

HEADLINE: Capital Gains: Respite or Requiem?

 BODY:
President Bush has indicated he won't push for a capital gains tax cut next year. That would be a welcome advance for fiscal fairness, assuming he really means it. Better yet, he should drop the idea altogether.
Capital gains -- the income to investors when they sell investments that have increased in value -- are currently taxed at the same rate as ordinary income, mostly at 28 percent. Prior to the 1986 Tax Reform Act, the maximums were 20 percent for gains and 50 percent for ordinary income. The 30-point difference invited schemes to avoid the higher rate, and tax shelters flourished. 
 Elimination of this special treatment was the balance wheel of the reform package, and properly reflected the spirit of reform: tax equality for all forms of income.
Mr. Bush pledged in his 1988 election campaign that he would restore the preference. In backing off now, he appears to be yielding to the realities of politics and the budget, rather than economic sense.
The Democrats will have extraordinary strength in the newly elected House; only twice before has a President faced a larger opposition majority. Since his pledge was thwarted by the last Congress, he could hardly expect to do better in the new Congress that convenes in January. Moreover, under the rules of this year's budget agreement, he would have to propose an offset to the revenue that would be lost if the capital gains tax were cut.
The President's intentions won't finally be known until he presents his new budget in five weeks; the capital gains issue is still being pressed by some Administration diehards. But it's clear from Mr. Bush's own lips that he hasn't given up his "philosophical commitment" to the idea that a tax break for capital gains stimulates growth.
There is little evidence that it does what the President supposes. Rather, it channels investment into activities designated for the tax payoff, regardless of their economic merit, or it simply rewards cashing in old investments. Moreover, the biggest providers of investment capital for risky new ventures have been tax-free institutional investors, like pension funds and endowments.
There is abundant evidence, however, that a capital gains tax cut would favor the well-off. Of the 110 million individual income tax returns in 1988, fewer than 8 million reported capital gains, and three-quarters of the gains went to taxpayers whose income exceeded $100,000. Over a longer span of years, middle-income taxpayers can benefit, too, of course -- when they sell a house, or stock. But that's relatively infrequent for the average American, and little stimulus for the economy.
Even -- or especially -- in the face of a recession, a tax subsidy for the rich is without merit. This idea deserves a quiet burial.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Quieter Christmas

 BODY:
So there he was, a portly septuagenarian sunk deep in a leather chair. This was definitely not Santa Claus. His cheeks were sole-gray, his face wreathed in sorrow. What could the matter be? "Christmas is wearing a gloomy face this year," he said. "It's warm when it ought to be cold. It rains when it ought to snow. There are more floorwalkers than customers in the stores. Worst of all, my assistant asked me this morning -- get this -- whether it would be O.K. to fax his Christmas cards."
Now that was a stunner. For what the gentleman's assistant had raised was the idea -- gloomy indeed -- that we as a nation have become so tangled in technology, so beguiled by faxes, cellular phones, third-generation paging devices, voice mail and E-mail that the simple act of writing and mailing a note is now quite beyond our patience or power. Had Christmas, like just about everything else, become mechanized? 
 And slowly the answer formed. It was, resoundingly, no. The fax-mad assistant notwithstanding, evidence abounds that this is a back-to-the basics Christmas, less self-indulgent, showy, commercial, exhibitionist and, yes, more personal and intimate than Christmases immediately past.
The main reason is as depressingly plain as an article in Friday's Times. The New York metropolitan area lost 100,000 jobs in private industry in 1990, the article reported, half of them in New York City. The money that fueled the conspicuous consumption of the Reagan years, especially among those not-so-young-anymore and certainly not-so-upwardly-mobile-anymore professionals, simply isn't there.
According to The Wall Street Journal, among the more prominent casualties of the grim realities of the 90's have been the status symbols of the 90's: the Brooks Brothers suspenders, the Rolex President Watches, the $200 leather-bound Filofax personal organizers and, of course, that ever-popular stocking-stuffer, the two-door BMW 325i. Instead, people are buying things they need, including "sensible brown shoes," according to one woman quoted in The Times, and postponing discretionary pleasures for a later day.
This may not be wonderful for the economy, but it is a usefully sobering reminder of what Christmas is about. Christmas is a joyous, festive secular celebration, but that is secondary. It is a religious holiday. Thus there's much to be said for observing it quietly, simply and unpretentiously. Indeed, the great moment that it recalls, the birth of the Christian Saviour, was itself a remarkably unadorned event: a carpenter named Joseph, his young wife, a stable, the Child.
There were, of course, gifts: the Wise Men brought beautiful things, gold and myrrh and frankincense. But the lesson of that day was that no temporal gifts could match the greatest gifts of all: the gifts of sharing, and sacrifice.

HEADLINE: The Wizard of Oz Unmasked as the President

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The television network production of "The Dreamer of Oz" (review, Dec. 10), on the alleged origins of L. Frank Baum's "Wizard of Oz," is perhaps artistically sound. But it is as much a fantasy as what it purports Baum's description of that little Kansas farm girl and her trip to the magical kingdom to be. I watched in hope that it would make note of Baum's political thinking. The closest it came was to have his mother-in-law a women's suffrage activist, of sorts. 
 Articles going back to one by Henry Littlefield in American Quarterly in 1964 have exposed the politics of "The Wizard of Oz" and Baum as a political activist in his own right, a champion of what was called populism at the turn of the century. The movement was then headed by William Jennings Bryan during his two unsuccessful Presidential attempts in 1896 and 1900 against William McKinley.
It was in 1896 that Bryan made his famous "Cross of Gold" speech at the Democratic National Convention, in which he used the metaphor of the crucifixion of the farmers of America on a cross of gold by the Eastern industrial establishment by insisting on maintaining the gold standard, rather than a silver-backed currency. Silver, Bryan insisted, would have provided the oppressed farmers with easier financing.
Baum was a Bryan supporter, with reservations. His Kansas locale was a way of placing the fantasy trip in the midst of the farm belt, and little Dorothy's three traveling mates all held political significance. The Cowardly Lion was Bryan himself, and indicated that Baum thought his candidate was little more than a loudmouth speechmaker with little substance. The Tin Man was the unemployed industrial worker who was rusting with idleness, and his Scarecrow was the farmer who didn't have the leadership and sense to take up his own political fight.
The rest of the characters and locales also served Baum's populist thinking. The Wicked Witch of the East was, of course, the evil banker who exploited the little people, or his Munchkins. Dorothy was wearing silver slippers that symbolized Bryan's (and Baum's) quest for the silver standard, and her trip took her down the Yellow Brick Road, which was the gold standard.
Who else could the Wizard be but the President sitting in the White House in Washington, or the Emerald City. We all remember that the Wizard acted and spoke in a manner that made him appear just as the people wanted him to, Baum's cynical view of all politicians. In the end, the Wizard is shown up as an antipopulist scoundrel and is thus exposed by the Scarecrow, the Tin Man and the Lion. To complete the picture, "Oz" was not a tab on a filing cabinet, but the abbreviation for ounce, by which gold was measured.
Had Baum lived exactly one century later, his "Wizard of Oz," with just about all of the same characters in place, would be as timely. The beauty of his artistry is buried in the sadness of our times.
 
DON SLOAN
New York, Dec. 11, 1990
