HEADLINE: FALL IN U.S. PRICES, FIRST SINCE 1940'S, BEGINS TO SPREAD

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
For the first time since the 1940's, falling prices have returned to the American economy, and they are starting to spread.
This new deflation is most visible in real estate. But prices are also dropping for steel, aluminum, plastics and other commodities used in manufacturing. And while prices are still rising for many things, like medical care, college tuition and legal services, recent data show the beginnings of deflation in some consumer products, like cars, furniture and kitchen appliances. The lower prices are often masked as rebates, sales and steep discounts; these are becoming fixtures rather than just special events. 
 The decline of some prices is beginning to show up in the Consumer Price Index, which measures the costs of a cross section of services and products. Not since 1960 has the United States entered a recession with that index rising by as little as it is today -- averaging just 3.9 percent at an annual rate over the last three months, not counting energy prices.
 
Accustomed to Inflation
 Deflation, with its promise that the dollar will buy more each week than the week before, might seem a welcome experience for a nation accustomed to inflation -- if it were not for the worrisome consequences. Principally, deflation causes problems for a nation burdened with debt, and debt in the United States increased to record levels in the 1980's.
The problem is that falling prices mean lower revenues for businesses of all sorts with huge debts, including manufacturers and real estate developers. This makes it harder for them to pay off their loans. The result has been rising defaults that are squeezing hundreds of banks and pushing some to the brink of failure. The loan crisis in turn forces rushed sales of buildings and other assets, and this hurry to sell reduces prices even further.
 
Median Wages Inching Up
 Many wage earners might benefit from deflation as long as they do not lose their jobs in the recession that is helping to push down prices or do not suffer cuts in hours or pay. So far, by most measures, median wages are still inching up. But if deflation takes too much of a toll on revenues and profits, then layoffs and wage cuts might spread, as they did during the Depression. That in turn would make debt repayment harder for many individuals, who had counted on secure jobs and rapidly rising wages to make their debt seem less burdensome.
The high levels of debt are the biggest cause of deflation, many economists recognize. Irving Fisher, a prominent economist early in the century, pinpointed the syndrome in which deflation follows debt in a 1933 article, now a classic in economics, that reviewed the Depression's damage.
"This is different from the experience of the Great Depression," said Ben Bernanke, a Princeton University economist, "but something related to the 1930's is beginning to happen."
Deflation caused by debt differs from other episodes of falling prices in the United States since the Depression. The last such episodes occurred in the late 1940's and early 1950's, the most important coming in 1948-49, when a huge demand for goods after the war finally leveled off. There have also been isolated episodes of falling prices, including the sharp drop in oil prices and the steep decline in farmland prices in the mid-1980's.
The sharp drop in real estate prices today would also be passed off as another temporary episode, if not for the context. The heavy borrowing to finance the real estate boom and the numerous corporate takeovers could turn out to be the opening stage of Fisher's cycle in which deflation follows debt. It is a cycle that can make deflation spread throughout the economy rather than remain in isolated sectors.
 
 Economy Called Resilient
"There will be wide deflation this time," said John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist. "But the American economy is far more resilient than it was in the 1930's. And if things get bad enough, there is an inescapable obligation on the part of the Government that did not exist before to step in and reverse the trend."
In the Fisher scenario, all the borrowing and spending, instead of producing profits for business and new wealth for society, simply create too much capacity and too many products. For example, 30 percent of all the commercial office space in the nation today was built in the last 10 years, according to the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill, which gathers such data. "And 20 percent of all office space is vacant, generating no rental revenue at all," said George Christie, Dodge's chief economist. "That's also a record."
Something similar is happening in cars. New Japanese plants in the United States are supplementing the output of Ford Motor, General Motors and Chrysler and the industry as a whole is producing more cars than Americans can easily absorb. Wynn Van Bussman, a Chrysler economist, calculates that industrywide rebates and incentives averaged $952 a car last month, more than offsetting price increases on some new car models.
"The problem with lowering prices is that costs are rising, particularly labor costs," Mr. Van Bussman said. "Society is not organized for deflation. We have so seldom had it. We need price increases of at least 1 or 2 percent a year to lubricate the system."
 
 Furniture Prices Down
 The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which tracks prices, is also beginning to pick up early signs of deflation. Furniture prices, for instance, are down 3 percent since late 1989. Kitchen appliances, glassware, various textile products and numerous commodities are also lower in price than they were a few months ago.
And while the bureau's Consumer Price Index still shows sharp increases for health care, funeral expenses, legal fees and other services, price increases for many manufactured products are disappearing.
"We have simply not been able to raise prices before this recession began," said Walter Joelson, chief economist at the General Electric Company.
 
Real Estate Defaults Growing
 But if the car companies and other manufacturers are being squeezed for profits and cash, the real estate industry is furlongs ahead of any other in the debt-deflation cycle. Without sufficient rental income, developers fall behind on loan payments and eventually default. Today this is happening mainly in the Northeast, but the defaults are spreading to other regions.
To cover the loans, either the developers or their banks try to sell the properties. The effort drives down prices, so that even if properties are sold, they often do not bring enough to repay loans. Across the country, the best commercial properties are off in price by 5 percent to 10 percent, David Shulman, a real estate expert at Salomon Brothers, reports. And home prices are either dropping or no longer rising in nearly every state. The median price for houses has declined by 6 percent nationwide since July. Not in years has real estate deflation been so widespread.
In some cases, condominium developers, unable to sell a one- or two-bedroom apartment in the Northeast for their original offering price of $300,000 or $400,000, have been forced to auction them for prices $100,000 less.
 
Effort Increases Burden
 Describing the process of deflation caused by debt in 1933, Fisher wrote, "The very effort of individuals to lessen their burden of debts increases it." Rushing to sell an office building for, say, $1 million helps to drive down its price to $500,000. But the mortgage owed to the bank remains at $800,000. The banks had made the $800,000 mortgage loan mostly with depositors' money.
Now the bankers are, in effect, taking money from their pockets to reimburse depositors. That process has exhausted, or almost exhausted, the capital of hundreds of commercial banks that lent heavily in real estate. Fourteen percent of banking's total loans outstanding are in real estate. An additional 4 percent are in loans for corporate takeovers and leveraged buyouts. The sharp decline in "junk bond" prices in recent months means that the resale value of the indebted corporations is also deflating.
In lockstep with the Fisher scenario, the banks are responding to the crisis as they did in the early 1930's -- by not making new loans. The aim of a bank doing this is to reduce its loan portfolio to bring it back into line with the bank's capital, which has shrunk. The banks say that Federal regulators have forced them to act this way, by requiring them to increase their capital at the wrong moment.
 
Difficulties for Banks
 But others argue that in a recession the banks cannot find low-risk loans that would assure them of the profits from interest income to rebuild capital. "And if a solid company does walk in with a good loan proposal, the banks are so uneasy they don't make the loan anyway," said Robert Heilbroner, the economic historian.
Whatever the reasons, the reluctance to lend has spread to the insurance industry, another big source of credit. The upshot is that hundreds of companies, unable to refinance their debts, try to liquidate them through the sale of offices, factories, machinery and other properties. And the deflation in real estate spreads to other industries.
"If banks are not lending, and they aren't today, then if I want to sell an asset to you, and you cannot find a bank or other lender to finance part of the purchase, the asset will go to zero," said Albert Wojnilower, a senior adviser at the First Boston Corporation.
 
Not as Severe as in 1930's
 But few if any economists expect the deflation that developed in the early 1930's to recur as severely in the 1990's. Prices fell by as much as 11 percent a year in the 1930's, and wages also contracted so that thousands of workers received fewer dollars in their weekly paychecks at the end of the year than they had at the beginning. The wage declines played a major role in cutting production costs and thus giving companies the leeway to reduce prices during a period of very weak demand, economists say.
By most measures, wages for the average worker are rising today, although by smaller amounts than a year or two ago. And savings are safe. During the Depression, when a bank failed, a family's savings were instantly wiped out; now they are protected by Federal deposit insurance. "You can imagine the lines that would be forming at the banks today without deposit insurance," Mr. Galbraith said.
 
Rise for Services Continues
 Perhaps most important, the 1930's lacked the huge presence of a service sector and of Government spending on Social Security, welfare and other services. These outlays help to keep prices rising, despite the debt-deflation cycle now under way. Prices might be falling for real estate and even manufactured products, but they continue to rise for services like medical care.
But if the 1990's are not the 1930's, other factors are helping to bring down prices. For one thing, the baby-boom generation is mostly through its home-buying years. The new generation of young couples establishing homes is much smaller, reducing the demand. The downturn also coincides with a drop in grain prices. Big harvests and fewer Soviet purchases are helping to deflate prices.

HEADLINE: Herbert Salzman Is Dead at 74; Economics Adviser to 4 Presidents

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Herbert Salzman, a business executive and merchant banker who served four Presidents in the field of international economics, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and had homes on the East Side of Manhattan and in Westport, Conn., and Klosters, Switzerland. 
 He died of leukemia, his family said.
Mr. Salzman, who had careers in business, government and banking, also served in 1983 as a New York City commissioner who advised on foreign business in New York City. After that he was a general partner in Bradford Ventures Ltd., a merchant bank that invests in promising companies.
Born to Russian immigrant parents in Brooklyn, Mr. Salzman attended public schools there and, in 1934, the Reali School of Haifa, Palestine. He graduated cum laude from Yale College in 1938 and also took an advanced management program at Columbia University in 1954.
 
Joined Father's Company
 Out of Yale, he joined the Standard Bag Corporation, founded by his father, William S. In World War II he enlisted in the Navy as an ensign. He was a lieutenant commander when he returned to civilian life in 1946.
A vice president of Standard Bag from 1938 until he became president in 1959, he was instrumental in the company's strong growth. When Mr. Salzman turned 50, he sold the company and went into Government service.
President Lyndon B. Johnson made him assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development in 1966, and the following spring he was put in charge of the agency's new private resources division. That office was created to channel private initiative and capital into projects in poor countries.
Mr. Salzman's division handled an investment guarantee program, forerunner of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. A quasi-public body underwritten by Congress, its purpose was to offer American money to third-world nations for economic development while insuring the investment against the risks of political upheaval and expropriation.
 
Worked With Javits
 One promoter of the program was Senator Jacob K. Javits, a member of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, and Mr. Salzman worked closely with him in shaping the corporation. The agency was created by legislation and was to have begun operations on July 1, 1970, but Senator Javits jousted with President Richard M. Nixon over who should run it.
Mr. Javits warned the Senate that unless Mr. Salzman was nominated, rather than President Nixon's favorite, the Senator would block funds for the corporation indefinitely. A compromise was reached at the end of the year when Mr. Nixon submitted a new list of 12 directors, with Mr. Salzman as executive vice president.
Mr. Salzman, who was reappointed by President Gerald R. Ford, remained with the corporation until 1976. The following year President Jimmy Carter sent him to Paris as the United States representative to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a post he held until 1981.
 
Held New York City Post
 Mayor Edward I. Koch, as part of an overhaul of his Office for Economic Development, named Mr. Salzman Commissioner of the Office of International Business Development in 1983. He began the job on March 15 but resigned in July.
At the time he informed the Mayor's office that he considered his mission accomplished by having gauged the extent to which foreigners were doing business in the city and setting forth the ways of keeping them and attracting more.
Over the years Mr. Salzman served on many governmental and private bodies, including trusteeships at the Studio Theater, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington and Harvard's Center for International Affairs.
He is survived by his wife, the former Rita Fredricks; two sons, Anthony David and Jeffrey Jonathan; a sister, Sally Pepper, and two grandchildren, all of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Pope, in Christmas Message, Warns on a Gulf War

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Pope John Paul II delivered a blunt admonition to world leaders today that war in the Persian Gulf would be "an adventure with no return."
In his annual Christmas message, "Urbi et Orbi" -- "To the City and the World" -- the Pope called for talks to resolve the crisis. But at the same time, he seemed to suggest that Iraq had to withdraw from Kuwait, saying "the inalienable rights of people and nations" must be respected. 
 Moments after speaking about the gulf from the central balcony of St.Peter's Basilica, John Paul urged a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, one, he said, that would acknowledge "the legitimate expectations" of each side. This reflected a frequently expressed papal theme: that Israelis and Palestinians had equal rights to their homelands and to secure borders.
The gulf and Israel were lumped together in a prayer for "the tormented nations of the Middle East." It was not clear, however, if the Pope intended a direct political link between the two issues, as Iraq has demanded. Thus far, the United States and its Western allies have insisted that Iraq must first leave Kuwait, and only then could anoverall settlement of Middle Eastern problems be discussed.
International issues, including Eastern Europe's political rebirth and Africa's continuing ordeal of hunger and conflict, dominated the papal message, delivered before several thousand people gathered on a drizzly late morning in the vast square below the balcony. The Pope also offered brief season's greetings in 53 languages as part of remarks that were carried in live and delayed broadcasts to millions of television viewers in 60 countries.
It was not the first time since the gulf crisis began nearly five months ago that John Paul had pleaded for peace.But this was his sternest appeal, and, coming three weeks before the United Nations deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, it carried added urgency.
"For the area of the gulf, we await with trepidation for the threat of conflict to disappear," he said, speaking in Italian. "May leaders be convinced that war is an adventure with no return. By reasoning, patience and dialogue with respect for the inalienable rights of people and nations, it is possible to identify and travel the paths of understanding and peace."
The Pope spoke after celebrating a Mass inside the basilica. Earlier, he had presided at the traditional midnight Mass and at services soon after dawn in his private chapel. At the midnight celebration of Christmas, a speaker read a prayer in Arabic that asked God to "enlighten the minds ofthose responsible for nations so that they become builders of peace and make every effort to build it in justice and reciprocal respect."
As usual, St. Peter's Square contained the Roman Catholic faithful and the merely curious. Because of the dreary weather, it was a thinner crowd than usual, and as he spoke, some drifted away to a Nativity scene.
In the front ranks, a group of pilgrims unfurled a large banner identifying themselves as Ukrainians, and they cheered when John Paul included Ukrainian among the dozens of languages in his Christmas greetings.
The revival of the Catholic Church in the Soviet Ukraine, which until recently was forced to survive underground, has been a special concern for the Pope. It is believed that he wants to be sure that full religious liberty andchurch property rights are restored there and elsewhere in the Soviet Union before he accepts an invitation from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to pay a visit.
Turning to Africa, John Paul echoed a concern he has expressed for the last year -- that the West's desire to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe should not come at the expense of struggling third-world countries where "freedom is compromised because of underdevelopment."
Calling for a "more just world ethical and economic order," he said that "only effective and respectful cooperation between the rich countries and the emerging people can prevent the contrast between North and South from becoming a widening abyss that will increase the already vast and disturbing archipelago of poverty and death."

HEADLINE: Amid Gulf Crisis and Cold War End, Questions on U.S. and NATO Roles

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
The crisis in the Persian Gulf and the end of the cold war, despite political uncertainty in the Soviet Union, are adding fuel to a major debate about strengthening Western Europe's defenses and reducing its dependence on the United States.
Government officials in West Germany and Britain support the idea of building up the European defense pillar, something they hope would encourage the United States not to withdraw to the other side of the Atlantic. But others, even in Britain, argue that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization may no longer be the best way to insure that the United States keeps devoting resources to European defense. 
 "NATO should remain in being only as long as necessary to create the conditions that would allow it to be dissolved," Sir James Eberle, a retired admiral and a former NATO field commander, said this month in a speech when he stepped down as director of the Royal Institute for International Affairs.
The 16 NATO countries agreed at a meeting in London in July to transform their alliance into a political entity, and said they hoped for agreement on the outlines of a new post-cold-war strategy by early next summer. At the same time, nine of NATO's European members are showing increasing interest in a new role for an organization they belong to -- the Western European Union, a long-slumbering vestige from the early days of the alliance.
 
Nucleus of Future Defense
 Close cooperation among the nine members of the Western European Union could form the nucleus of a common military policy for the 12-nation European Community, a proposal by the French President, Francois Mitterrand, and the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, suggested this month.
Supporters of the proposal say it would lend influence to the economic and political power of the European Community and satisfy American demands that the countries of Europe do more for their own defense.
Even British officials, traditionally more inclined to rely on sovereign military power and close links with the United States than on European cooperation for their defense, have shown interest in the Western European Union.
The organization, which took shape and was trying to organize a multinational European army in the early 1950's, decided in August to coordinate and increase naval activities in the Persian Gulf in response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Before that, it was used in 1987 to coordinate the activities of countries that sent ships to the gulf to protect tankers threatened during the Iran-Iraq war.
 
Brushfires Outside Europe
 Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain, in a statement in Berlin on Dec. 10, said the Western European Union could be a bridge between the European Community and the United States. He said it might also provide the framework for a multinational reaction force that could be used to respond to security threats outside Europe, something NATO has not been able to do.
Alan Clark, the British Minister for Defense Procurement, also said recently that Europe needed "something slimmer, less set in its ways than NATO, something capable of faster response" to defend itself now that the threat of overwhelming nuclear and conventional attack from the Soviet Union has receded.
"The purpose of NATO is achieved," Mr. Clark said in remarks to a London audience that were reported by The Independent newspaper on Dec. 10. "It won. The W.E.U. probably is the nucleus" of the future European defense role, he said.
One difficulty is that the Western European Union involves only nine European countries. Another is that until recently, few people knew that it still existed. Its secretariat is in London, opposite the grounds of Buckingham Palace. A 108-member parliamentary assembly meets occasionally in Paris, where the union also has a small international staff and an institute for security studies.
 
Overstaffing Criticized
 Where Mr. Clark questioned what the 4,000 military and civilian employees at NATO headquarters in Brussels were doing anymore, the Western European Union has only 53 in London, including seven security guards, two drivers and two messengers.
"We have no secure communications with NATO or with the national capitals," said the Secretary General, Willem F. van Eekelen, a former Dutch Defense Minister.
He said he would not need a vast bureaucratic structure to support the kind of European military force he has proposed, to be started from a brigade of 4,000 or 5,000 soldiers from each participating country, with their own staffs, logistical support and artillery. A single European general would exercise divisional or corps command.
The Western European Union could have sent such a force, if it existed, to the Persian Gulf, he said.
 
French Are Not Impressed
 Mr. Hurd suggested moving the union to make it easier to coordinate with NATO and the United States. But so far, the suggestion has not been taken up with enthusiasm by France, which has kept its own forces out of NATO's military command structure.
Mr. van Eekelen suggested that the debate about the American role in Europe's defenses would become more acute after 1994, when all Soviet troops have been withdrawn from Germany.
Though the United States encouraged the Western European Union when it took shape in the early 1950's, American diplomats in London, Brussels and Rome are somewhat skittish about reviving the idea nowadays. Mr. van Eekelen said that Europeans would have to be just as ready as Washington to consult their allies, through NATO, before making final defense decisions in order to avoid raising suspicions.
Europeans who have often felt that Washington did not so much consult as inform them after the fact of what it had decided could now behave in much the same way toward the United States, some NATO diplomats fear.
 
What Will the Germans Do?
 One of them said the Administration was particularly concerned about how Germany, economically and militarily the most powerful European country, would act.
The Administration felt severely let down by the lack of German response to American appeals to do more in the Persian Gulf. Germany has sent no combat forces but has provided logistical support for the air and sealift of some of the American troops.
"The reality is that the decision as to whether or not Saddam Hussein has to be removed from Kuwait by force of arms rests entirely with the President of the United States," Sir James Eberle said, pointedly observing that the impression of an international military effort there was misleading.
"Whatever the outcome, the cost of the gulf operations will be seen by most Americans to have fallen largely on the United States," he said. "This will inevitably raise deep questioning of the future world leadership role that the United States wishes to play. Europe cannot stand aside from its own responsibilities."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Gulf Summit Talks End on a Mixed Note

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 25

 BODY:
The six nations of the Gulf Cooperation Council ended a four-day summit meeting today by warning Iraq that war was the only alternative to its peaceful withdrawal from all of Kuwait.
The council, the Persian Gulf's economic and military cooperation group, held its 11th annual summit meeting in Doha, the capital of Qatar. 
 In a closing statement read by Abdullah Bishara, a Kuwaiti who is the group's general secretary, the council demanded Iraq's total and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait before Jan. 15, "to spare the fraternal Iraqi people and the people of the region and the whole world the horrors of a destructive war." It also said that Iraq would be held responsible for compensating Kuwait and its people for the looting and plundering of the country.
The group, made up of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Oman, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Qatar, wanted to add its own voice to the growing chorus of threats to Saddam Hussein from the Bush Administration, European leaders and Egypt, among others.
But underlying its oratory was a realization that the council had failed, despite billions in arms purchases, to deter a threat to one of their member states and that the future would likely be determined not by these tiny sheikhdoms but by the superpowers of the region and the world.
 
Warning by Saudi King
 Saudi Arabia's dominance within this group and its status as a regional economic power were reflected in the weight attached to the sole public pronouncement by King Fahd, the Saudi ruler. In a tough speech on Monday, the King said his country and the rest of the gulf were prepared to go to war if this was the only way of forcing Iraq to leave Kuwait.
The Riyadh Government's role both within the council and in the conflict is critical. First, it was Riyadh's request for assistance in deterring what it viewed as an Iraqi threat to its territory that brought American ground forces to the region. Second, the overwhelming majority of American forces are now based there. In the event of war, Egyptian and other Arab forces stationed in the Saudi desert would be fighting under Saudi command. And politically, Saudi consent is indispensible to any peaceful or compromise resolution to the gulf crisis.
No important pronouncements had been expected from this gathering of sheiks and kings, and none were forthcoming. "They were just trying to get through this summit," a Western diplomat said. "They had to hold it because not to hold it would have been disastrous."
The statement said the council had approved "recommendations by their Defense Ministers for the consolidation of the member states' defense capabilities," but it did not elaborate. King Fahd and council officials emphasized the need to review existing security arrangements for the region, but most members believed that future defense arrangements could be meaningfully discussed only after the crisis is resolved.
 
Unanswered Questions
 "Will the crisis be resolved through peace or war?" an Arab diplomat asked. "Will Saddam Hussein be around or not? Will Iraq's military forces be intact or not? Will there be an Iraq as we know it today? We cannot decide on future structures for the gulf until these questions are answered."
Officials in Washington and Western diplomats here asserted that there were no serious disussions taking place at this time about future defense arrangements. But, they added, there was a consensus forming that prepositioning equipment and installations in this area made economic and strategic sense.
"A lot of what we have brought here will probably remain here," said Col. Jerry Nelson, commander of the 401st Tactical Fighter Wing, the 900-member United States Air Force unit that has been based here since the end of August. "It would be cheaper to haul the Arabian peninsula back to the United States than to go through this again."
John Duke Anthony, president of the National Council on U.S.-Arab Relations and an expert on the Persian Gulf who attended the session, argued that the council should not be judged too harshly for failing either to deter or to respond to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
 
Iraqi Regional Power
 "This organization had emphasized air and naval capabilities because until recently it had contemplated a threat from Iran," Mr. Anthony said. "But to evict Iraq from Kuwait, you need land forces, tanks and artillery." Besides, he said, the six members were dwarfed by Iraq. "Altogether, the military forces of the six equal one-eighth of Iraq's regular army. Iraq has 10 times as many tanks, 8 times as much artillery, and 4 times their combat aircraft."
There was little sense at the meeting that Iraq's aggression had induced a sense of humility among the gulf leaders. Meetings between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and George Bush have had less security than this assemblage did. Journalists were virtual prisoners in a hotel across town from where the leaders met, and most gulf state officials never ventured anywhere near the 400-member Arab press corps or the few Western journalists.
Though the council attempted to adopt a united front in its public declarations, longstanding differences came up repeatedly in the private meetings. Oman, for example, has vigorously pressed for a negotiated solution to the Iraq-Kuwait crisis. As the only member of the council to receive high-ranking Iraqi officials, it has championed the efforts of the Algerian President, Chadli Benjedid, to devise an Arab solution that would secure Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait without war.
But Saudi Arabia, in the statement by King Fahd and in his previous statements, has taken a far tougher approach, emphasizing that there can be no compromise with Baghdad, at least on the matter of Kuwaiti territory.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Iraqis' Christmas: Joy and a 'Weight'

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 25

 BODY:
With the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988, the Rev. Kamal Bidawid thought he had passed his last Christmas with death and destruction hanging over his 250-family congregation of Chaldean Catholics.
During the eight brutal years of that conflict, Father Bidawid said the requiem Mass for most of the 15 men who had died in combat and were buried in the congregation cemetery donated by the Iraqi Government 25 miles outside the city. He thought he had put the pain of those years behind him. 
 Today, sitting in his office among several young parishioners on holiday leave from the Iraqi Army's front lines in Kuwait, the 37-year-old priest was somber and as reflective as a religious leader can be in a country that tolerates religious expression so long as it does not become political expression.
 
'The People Need Peace'
 "This Christmas was different because this year the people need peace," Father Bidawid said in an interview. "When a man has no peace, he cannot do anything." He said the prospect that Iraq might go to war with the American-led forces amassed in Saudi Arabia had settled on Iraqis like a weight.
"People live their lives only seeing and hearing," he said. "They believe very strongly that our Lord will give them peace, and because they cannot do anything to change their fate, we pray -- like Christians, we pray."
War has done nothing but deplete Our Lady of Perpetual Health, one of two dozen Chaldean churches in Baghdad, Father Bidawid said.
Chaldean Catholics represent more than half of the one million Christians in predominantly Muslim Iraq, a country of more than 16 million people. Smaller groups of Christians belong to the Syrian, Latin and Armenian rites of the Roman Catholic Church and to the Armenian Orthodox Community.
A decade ago, the rolls of the Chaldean parish were flush with about 500 practicing families. But in 1980-82 and again in 1990, Iraqis who could obtain exit visas to immigrate to the United States, Europe, Canada or Australia did so, leaving behind a parish that is roughly half the size today, Father Bidawid said.
 
Encroaching Real Estate
 The small white masonry church with heavy Romanesque dome sits about a mile from the Tigris River, just east of the encroaching high-value real estate taken up by luxury hotels and the Ministry of Military Industry and Industrialization, which is run by the son-in-law of President Saddam Hussein.
On Monday night, Father Bidawid and a small cast of children re-enacted the Nativity scene before a packed congregation, including visitors from other churches. The men sat in the front pews and the women and children behind, because that is tradition, Father Bedawid said.
As the lights dimmed, the youthful costumed players acted out the story of Meriam and Yousef and their journey to comply with the Roman census decree, and their arrival at Bethlehem, where there was no room in the inn.
No detail was neglected in the pageantry. Even the star that guided shepherds and kings to the manger entered the upper nave of the church through a gimbaled portal from where it danced down a wire toward the birthplace of Jesus, snagging only briefly on the blade of a ceiling fan.
Narrated in Arabic and accompanied by lilting chants in Aramaic, the nearly extinct Levantine language spoken at the time of Jesus, the story reached its climax when the child playing Meriam held up a baby doll wrapped in a blanket and drew a standing ovation.
 
Pageantry Throughout Iraq
 Similiar scenes were repeated all over Iraq during Christmas Eve and Christmas Day services for the country's Christians, whose Christmas traditions seem to exert a disproportionate influence on the Muslim majority during the holiday season.
"In this country, the majority was Christian before Mohammed" and the sixth-century Muslim conquest, Father Bidawid said. "Even Tikrit," the hometown of Mr. Hussein, "was a Christian city, because we had a bishop at Tikrit."
"Christians are the salt of this land," the priest said. "We are faithful to this country, and we gave thousands of martyrs during the war because it is our country."
A few miles from the church, in a small Syrian Catholic enclave, a large Iraqi family invited a visiting American to a Christmas dinner of baked chicken, potatoes, sheep intestines stuffed with rice and meat, pickled turnips and stuffed grape leaves.
In this typical working-class house, over glasses of the local Farida beer, the talk was of war and politics, somewhat restrained because of the foreigner's presence, but also relatively frank as Iraqi political discourse goes. A picture of Mr. Hussein was on one wall in the adjoining television room next to a rendering of the Last Supper.
Red divans ran along the perimeter of the living room in Arab diwanniyya, or meeting-room, style, under needlepoint works of Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane and of a pair of kittens. An artificial Christmas tree stood in the corner, well trimmed with golden balls, angels and red bows.
 
Hope of Avoiding War
 The strongest view expressed in the house this Christmas was that Mr. Hussein would pull his forces out of Kuwait at the last minute to avoid war while pressing his economic grievances against Kuwait in an ensuing round of Arab diplomacy.
Baghdad is full of rumors this week that the Arab Baath Socialist Party workers throughout the country have received secret instructions from Mr. Hussein to begin public demonstrations on Jan. 10 to beg the leadership to avoid war and at all costs preserve the leadership of Mr. Hussein. This public display would presumably allow a face-saving "out" for Mr. Hussein if diplomacy has yielded nothing on the eve of the United Nations Security Council deadline for withdrawing his forces from Kuwait.
The family's oldest son, who spent more than nine years in the army, was called back to duty last week, along with several cousins and neighbors who were born between 1957 and 1960.
"I think we will only be in the army for one month this time, so I am very happy," the son said.
His father, a full-bellied man of 60 with tradesman's hands and whiskers trimmed in the Turkmen style of northern Iraq, leaned over to the visitor after dinner and said, "I tell you, people in Iraq like Saddam Hussein, because they know that if he goes there is no one better."
The man's wife, who spent most of the week cooking pastries for this gathering, said her Christmas wish was that the threat of war would recede so Iraqis could once again travel abroad, where she would like to go to visit her brother.
"God willing, we will be able to go, if Bush doesn't destroy everything," she said with a hearty laugh.

HEADLINE: Hard Times Challenge Goals Of Liberal Wave at City Hall

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
The Draconian budget cuts in City Hall have not only sent city agencies reeling to slash services and personnel, but radically changed the agenda for dozens of liberal advocates who joined the Dinkins administration, putting their reform programs on ice and often pitting them against the very groups they once championed.
"It is very discouraging," said Nancy Wackstein, the director of the new Office on Homelessness, who finds herself trying to salvage homeless policies she had condemned before the election. "In the 1980's we all thought about what we would do when we had power. Now we have it and there is nothing to play with. The social justice agenda will have to wait another decade."
Many of the former advocates are working in departments that may have to cut their operating budgets by as much as 10 percent in the fiscal year that starts next July 1 and have been ordered to cut 7.5 percent out of this year's budget. 
 Many realize that they may not even be able to do as much as their old nemesis, Edward I. Koch. Many of the groups they once worked for have labeled them ineffectual. And the social problems they have fought for years to resolve may actually get worse under their guidance.
Keith J. Summa, the advocacy director of the Coalition for the Homeless, said: "These former advocates represent different issues now. When you are a city official you have to answer to the Mayor, not the homeless."
 
Few Plan to Pull Out
 Despite the budget cuts, most of those who joined the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins with high hopes have no plans to pull out, especially as they battle for their programs in the current round of budget negotiations. While many admit to being frustrated, they also say they believe that the Mayor is sincere in his concern for the city's poorest residents.
But some critics worry that the Mayor, determined to make his administration fiscally solvent, is turning away from the very groups and people who helped elect him.
"It is very frustrating to see the same unremarkable proposals coming out of City Hall," said City Councilman Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Manhattan Democrat, "especially since the expectations were that this administration would be open to new ideas and actively seek the advice of people who have not had access previously and are experts in their fields."
The reversal of roles, from advocate to city official, has not always been easy for these new city officials, especially since they often must endure criticism from their former colleagues.
 
'My Beliefs Have Not Changed'
 Ms. Wackstein offers one of the starkest examples. She worked as an advocate for the homeless before joining the Dinkins staff when he was Manhattan Borough President. Before the election, she criticized the use of hotels and large shelters for the homeless.
"My beliefs have not changed," Ms. Wackstein said. "I still do not believe that hotels or congregate shelters are good for families and children, but I have a better understanding as to why the prior administration had been forced to use these facilities."
With the budget cuts, Ms. Wackstein and her staff will be fortunate to retain the homeless programs established by the Koch administration, and have little hope of expanding or significantly altering the old policy.
"Homelessness is a problem that has some known solutions, but very expensive solutions, and that is what will not happen," Ms. Wackstein said.
While Ms. Wackstein and other advocates see the root cause of homelessness and crime as socio-economic, they work for an administration that has decided to pump much of its scant resources into beefing up the police, although it has chosen a few social programs for support.
As the Mayor's term wears on, these sentiments hold less sway with advocacy groups.
"If they did not believe these changes were possible, why did they advocate for these changes?" asked Virginia G. Shubert, the director of the AIDS project for the Coalition for the Homeless. "I look at them and feel the loss of allies."

HEADLINE: New York State Cutting 600 Workers This Week

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 25

 BODY:
More than 600 New York State employees, virtually all of them prison workers, will put in their last day on Wednesday as part of a plan to eliminate an estimated $1 billion deficit in the state's $50 billion budget.
In all, 2,000 state workers are to be laid off by the end of the fiscal year on March 31. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has promised to eliminate another 4,000 jobs through attrition and early-retirement incentives. Next year, the Governor has said he may have to eliminate 12,000 more jobs. The state has more than 200,000 employees. 
 Included among the employees to be laid off on Wednesday are about 300 prison guards and 300 other prison workers.
Thomas Kennedy, the president of Council 82, the prison guards' union, said being laid off during the holiday season was especially tough.
"There's no good season to be laid off," Mr. Kennedy said. "But given these economic times, and the fact that it's holiday time, it's very difficult."
 
Cuomo's Intervention Sought
 On Monday, the leadership of Council 82 met with the Commissioner of the State Department of Correctional Services, Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, to discuss the layoffs amid rumors that the guards were considering a strike or some other protest.
"Council 82 has not called for a job action or a strike, as is rumored, on Dec. 26," Mr. Kennedy said after the meeting. But he warned that anxiety among guards was running high, and he said he would like Governor Cuomo to intervene.
"The last time we saw this type of dissatisfaction with the way we're being treated, there was a strike in 1979," Mr. Kennedy said.
In 1979, the Governor, Hugh L. Carey, called in the National Guard to run the prisons during a 16-day strike by prison guards upset over negotiations for a new contract.
 
No National Guard Alert
 "I call for the Governor's intervention into this issue -- into the reasons why our staff is so disgruntled -- before too long," Mr. Kennedy said, "because the levels of anxiety out there are growing with each passing day."
Mr. Kennedy said the rumors of a possible strike have been fueled by contacts between state prison officials and National Guard officers.
"The National Guard has been in to one of our facilities for a tour in the last week," Mr. Kennedy said. "It looks to our people like we're being provoked."
A National Guard spokesman, Chief Warrant Officer Allen Koblenzer, said on Monday that the Guard had not been placed on alert because of any possible action by the prison guards. Mr. Coughlin's spokesman, James Flateau, said the tour was "pure coincidence" and had nothing to do with any possible job action by the guards.
Other state workers who will put in their last day on Wednesday include 19 employees of the Division of Parole and the Commission of Correction.
Those who are leaving the state work force on Wednesday received their pink slips at least three weeks ago, said Mardi Massaroni, a spokeswoman for the Governor's Office of Employee Relations.
Twenty-three more layoffs will take effect on Jan. 2. Those workers will come from the Division of Criminal Justice Services, the Division of Military and Naval Affairs and the Department of State, Ms. Massaroni said.

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Says Many Retirees May Use a Simpler Tax Form

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
The Internal Revenue Service, an unlikely source of holiday cheer, has announced that millions of older Americans will now be able to switch to a simpler income tax form.
The I.R.S. said Monday that income earned from pensions, annuities, individual retirement accounts and taxable Social Security benefits may now be declared on the relatively short and simple 1040A tax form. Previously, such income had to be reported on the longer, more complex 1040 form. 
 Arthur Altman, director of the tax forms and publications division of the I.R.S., said that as many as 4.5 million Americans, most of them retired, would be able to file the shorter form. He noted that not only was the form simpler, but also that it was printed in larger type and, therefore, easier to read.
Patricia Hoath, a senior program specialist with Tax-Aide, a volunteer program that provides free tax advice to retirees, said it might take a while for people to learn that they could use the easier form. But, she said, "Once the transition period is over, this will be helpful to older people."
This year, packages containing the tax forms and instructions from the I.R.S. will begin to appear in mailboxes on Dec. 28. In recent years, the forms had arrived on the day after Christmas.
 Mr. Altman said that Fred T. Goldberg Jr., the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, had decided that it was not in keeping with the spirit of the season to have tax packages arrive in the mail the day after Christmas, and so directed that the mailing be delayed for two days.
About 97 million tax packages will be sent out this year. In addition, 11 million postcards, instead of the full package of tax forms and instructions, will be sent to people who filed farm or business returns last year. The presumption is that these businesses use professional preparers and do not need the package, although they can get one on request. Last year, the I.R.S. saved $1 million by sending out postcards in place of the full packages.
The service expects that about 113 million tax returns will be filed for 1990.
As for the new tax year, beginning on Jan. 1, employers must resume deductions for Social Security taxes for workers who had paid the maximum tax before the end of the year. The Social Security withholding in 1991 will be 6.2 percent on wages up to $53,400, an increase from the maximum taxable wage base of $51,300 in 1990. This withholding covers retirement, disability and survivor benefits.
In a change from last year, 1.45 percent of all wages up to $125,000 will be withheld in 1991 for Medicare insurance. In 1990, Medicare payments were included in the overall Social Security payments up to $51,300.
Employers are required to match the entire 7.65 percent payroll withholding for Social Security and Medicare benefits.
 
Personal Deduction Rises
 Mr. Altman of the I.R.S. noted that reporting requirements were virtually unchanged for 1990 from 1989. Most of the changes Congress made in the tax code in 1990 will take effect with 1991 earnings and will affect returns filed starting in 1992.
One of the few changes for 1990 filings is that the personal deductions for taxpayers and their dependents will rise to $2,050, from $2,000, as an adjustment for inflation.
Another change will reduce the amount that may be deducted for interest from personal loans, like car loans and credit card accounts. Last year 20 percent of such interest could be deducted from tax payments, but this year only 10 percent may be deducted.
Mr. Altman said he hoped taxpayers would use the prepared label sent along with the tax forms, which he says contains information that helps the I.R.S. tax processors complete their work on individual tax forms more quickly and accurately.
Based on experience, the I.R.S. expects to make refunds averaging $900 to more than 70 percent of taxpayers. Errors in filing tend to delay the refunds by several weeks, he said.
 Henry Holmes, a spokesman for the agency, said returns prepared by accountants or other professionals tended, not surprisingly, to have a lower error rate than those filled out by the taxpayers themselves. Of 54.5 million returns prepared by professionals last year, about three million were found to contain errors, while of 57.5 million returns prepared by taxpayers, 7.3 million had at least one error.
One of the most common mistakes, Mr. Holmes said, is to state incorrectly one's filing status -- whether or not the filer is the head of a household. Many single people fail to identify themselves as heads of households even though they may have children or other dependents.
Another frequent error is made by people who fail to claim deductions for which they are entitled or who incorrectly compute those deductions. For example, people do not claim deductions for all of their children or do not identify dependents like elderly parents. People who are blind or have some other disability that makes them eligible for a deduction, in addition to the standard deduction, often fail to claim it, Mr. Holmes said.
There are also problems with the returns of low-income taxpayers who file incorrectly for earned income credits on their taxes, Mr. Holmes said.
These errors are usually caught during the processing of tax forms, he added, but they slow the operation, costing the Government and the taxpayers money.

HEADLINE: HAWAII JOURNAL;
Rare Storm Over Race Ruffles a Mixed Society

BYLINE: By RICHARD HALLORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Dec. 23

 BODY:
In racial and ethnic relations, Hawaii is nor mally a gentle place, a mosaic of Hawaiian, Japanese, Chinese, Filipino, Caucasian and other Americans living in amity.
But under the surface are undeniable tensions rooted largely in economics. Caucasian and Asian Americans are on the top and middle of the economic ladder, while ethnic Hawaiians and Filipinos are on the bottom. 
 Like Hawaii's volcano, Kilauea, those tensions sometimes erupt. A woman of ethnic Hawaiian descent, Haunani-Kay Trask, recently set off one such explosion.
It started three months ago when a white student at the University of Hawaii, Joseph Carter, wrote a letter to the student newspaper lamenting what he called "Caucasian bashing" and asserting that "racism is not an exclusively white endeavor."
Ms. Trask, who teaches Hawaiian studies at the university, replied with a letter to the newspaper reciting what she saw as white oppression of ethnic Hawaiians and contending that "Mr. Carter does not understand racism at all" and should leave the state.
Mr. Carter did just that, flying home to Louisiana.
An uproar ensued, with critics of Ms. Trask calling her a racist who had abused her position by lashing out at a student. The faculty of the philosophy department, in which Mr. Carter had studied, condemned Ms. Trask in a unanimously approved resolution that gained wide publicity.
Ms. Trask's supporters shot back, contending that she was asserting her rights to free speech. In an interview, Ms. Trask denied picking on Mr. Carter, who has returned to the university and plans to re-enroll in January.
"I always raise this issue," said Ms. Trask, whose family name derives from a Caucasian great-grandfather. "This has been my position for 15 years. I am a nationalist. I am asserting my claim to my country."
The university's Center for Hawaiian Studies, of which she is director, accused the philosophy department of "plantation tactics of threat, reprisal and intimidation."
But members of several ethnic groups have argued that Ms. Trask has been "un-Hawaiian" in raising these issues with such vehemence. The Hawaiian way, they say, is to be gentle, patient and circumspect.
Ms. Trask responded: "I am not soft. I am not sweet, and I do not want any more tourists in Hawaii."
Newspapers have been filled with letters from all sides, radio and television stations have interviewed the main players, and the issue has been a staple of lunchtime conversations.
Some of the contention turns on the Hawaiian word "haole" (pronounced HOW-LEE), which originally meant foreigner, but is now widely used to mean a Caucasian. Mr. Carter asserted that ethnic Hawaiians use it pejoratively, but in her letter Ms. Trask said, "Only new arrivals resent it because they have not had experience in a numerical minority."
In everyday conversation, many Caucasians in Hawaii refer to themselves and other whites as haole. The word becomes pejorative, one Caucasian said, "only when certain adjectives are added in front of it."
The racial and ethic climate here is rarely this heated. On the contrary, those born here and many newcomers often marvel at the civility of this diverse society.
Floyd Takeuchi, a Japanese-American, said the state is "remarkably cohesive, remarkably free of strife." In the days before World War II, he said, people in various ethnic groups worked together but lived largely in separate neighborhoods and did not socialize much.
Since just before statehood in 1959, that has been slowly changing with the movement of Asians and others, especially Japanese-Americans.
Hawaii residents give several reasons for the relative racial harmony. The most important, they agree, is that everyone here is in a minority.
In a population of just over one million, Hawaii is 24 percent Caucasian, 23 percent Japanese-American and 20 percent ethnic Hawaiian and part-ethnic Hawaiian. Filipinos, at 11 percent, are the fastest-growing group. Other ethnic groups round out the population.
In addition, the good feelings conveyed by "aloha," a word that is hard to translate but alludes to human warmth, is still alive.
Then, too, said Ilima Piiamaia, an ethnic Hawaiian, "people get along here because everyone celebrates everyone else's holidays."

HEADLINE: S.& L. Debacle Hinders Change In Banking Law

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Despite the grave problems in the industry, an overhaul of the nation's banking laws next year faces such serious political obstacles that the chief proponents of change say their chances of success are no better than even.
With many of the country's prominent banks losing money and some threatened with failure, with the Federal deposit insurance fund hanging by a thread, and with companies unable to get the loans they need to prosper, President Bush has promised that his top domestic priority in 1991 will be to restructure a financial system that has been basically unchanged since the Great Depression. 
 He wants to break down the barriers that now keep commercial banks, investment houses and securities companies out of each other's businesses and that restrict banks from operating across state lines. Those steps, he maintains, are necessary to make American financial institutions efficient and competitive worldwide.
 
Problems Called Avoidable
 Some members of Congress especially fear that the authority of banks cannot be expanded without encountering the same calamity that the savings and loan industry met when it was allowed to enter new businesses. But the President's advisers insist that those problems can be avoided.
The President's strong support makes the prospects for change better than ever. But huge roadblocks lie in the way, just as they have in almost every Congress since Richard M. Nixon tried unsuccessfully to change the banking system 20 years ago.
"I don't deny for a minute that the chances are probably no better than 50-50," said Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the commanding officer of the Administration's troops who will be fighting the battle on Capitol Hill. Some other senior Administration officials put the odds even lower.
So many competing interests are involved that Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Federal Reserve governor, likens banking legislation to a Rubik's Cube. All the pieces must be fit together simultaneously to solve the puzzle, and moving one into place tends to upset the order of the others.
The Treasury Department has not finished preparing all the elements of the legislation the President will send to Congress next month, but the basic principles are well known.
The package will include measures to shore up the deposit insurance system, an effort that politicians, bankers and regulators agree is essential; the measures are expected to pass in one form or another. It will permit banks to open branches nationwide. And it will allow banks to merge with securities companies and investment firms. Banks could then sell stock, underwrite bonds and operate mutual funds, activities from which they are now proscribed.
 
A Fundamental Change
 That would mean a fundamental change from the Depression era, when fear of dominance by a few large banks and of bankers taking wild risks with depositors' money led politicians to divide financial authority into separate fiefdoms.
The issue, officials say, is an especially attractive one for President Bush, because unlike other potential domestic policy initiatives, it would not cost the Government money. The President is seen as having a better chance of getting his legislation through Congress than his predecessors did for several reasons.
The most significant one is that the White House and the Treasury are giving the matter top billing. In previous Administrations, other issues were deemed more important.
In addition, banks are now in such a weakened condition that no one can plausibly argue that they could end up dominating economic activity or that the businesses bankers want to enter are riskier than commercial banking itself.
 
Nonpartisan Issue
 These other circumstances are also in the President's favor: The issue is basically nonpartisan, important given the Republican minorities in Congress. Technological and regulatory changes in recent years have made many restrictions obsolete. The securities industry, which fought fiercely against previous attempts to enact such legislation, is on board this time. And key regulators, who objected in past years to measures that might have cost them some authority, are more or less united behind the Administration.
But other factors militate against success. What has generally killed banking legislation over the years has been the opposition of competing financial institutions that are often more influential than large banks. While the securities industry has joined with the big banks, powerful lobbies like community bankers, realtors and insurance brokers remain set against change.
And this year, the legislation faces a new and maybe even bigger hurdle -- the specter of what happened to the savings and loan associations when they were given authority to expand into unfamiliar areas of business.
Furthermore, the Senate and House banking committees are badly crippled nowadays, and their leaders may not have the stature or the capacity to push through monumental legislation.
Finally, authorities in and out of the Government question whether anyone in the Administration involved in the banking issue has the tactical political skills that will be needed.
"Our biggest problem is going to be to show that this isn't the savings and loan mess all over again," said Robert R. Glauber, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance.
 
Not Covered by Insurance
 In the Administration's view, the savings institutions collapsed, at a huge cost to taxpayers, because the industry was badly undercapitalized and poorly regulated. In the case of banks, Mr. Glauber and Mr. Brady say, stiff capital requirements and strong supervision would be imposed, and the losses banks incur in outside businesses would not be covered by Federal deposit insurance.
But politicians are so gun-shy after the savings and loan experience that those kinds of promises may be insufficient. Representative Charles E. Schumer, an influential Democrat on the House Banking Committee, believes this could be the legislation's Achilles' heel. A liberal from Brooklyn, Mr. Schumer is normally an Administration antagonist, but he expects to be a strong supporter of the banking legislation.
"Even if it's carefully structured," he said, "even if it avoids all the problems of the S.& L.'s, someone gets up on the floor and says this is the S.& L. crisis all over. You have shivers down the spine of Congress people, and they run for the doors."
 
Conflicting Interest Groups
 The Administration's other main obstacle is all the conflicting interest groups. Many bankers want the authority to sell insurance and real estate, but that would bring realtors and insurance agents, wary of the competition, out in force against the legislation. Many politicians say this would doom the legislation.
The problem from the Administration's perspective is that small community bankers do not care about underwriting bonds or becoming stockbrokers, but many would love to have desks in their branches where they could sell life insurance or run real estate agencies. That could induce them to accept legislation otherwise intended mostly to help large banks.
The large banks have been generous with campaign contributions. But in the aftermath of the savings and loan disaster, the money comes a bit tainted.
Every Congressional district has realtors and insurance agents. They "are the world's best lobbyists," said Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat on the banking committee. "That's what they do for a living," he added. "They make home calls. That's their culture. They will have to be accommodated."
The Administration hopes to mobilize manufacturing and service industries on the side of the banks with the argument that a strong banking system is necessary to a healthy business climate.
Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said his panel would begin work on the legislation as soon as it is submitted. He added that he was tempted to limit the bill to deposit insurance and not get into the broader issues.
 
Sapping of Strength Seen
 Mr. Riegle and the second-ranking Democrat on the banking committee, Alan Cranston of California, are two of the five Senators being investigated by the Ethics Committee because of their past relationship with Charles H. Keating Jr., who faces fraud charges in California and has become the symbol of the savings and loan debacle. The investigation has sapped their political strength, many Senators say.
On the House side, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas is a relatively weak and unpopular chairman of the banking committee. Chairmen are normally re-elected to their post routinely, but more than a third of the Democratic Representatives voted this month to unseat him.
Another problem is that unlike the Senate, where the banking committee will be the only one involved, jurisdiction in the House is divided between the banking commitee and the Energy and Commerce Committee.
The chairman of the second panel, Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat, is a powerhouse, and he has not committed himself on the banking bill. He has close ties to the securities industry and has been partly responsible for blocking an expansion of bank authority in the past.
 
Dingell Might Go Along
 The securities industry favors the legislation this time because the Administration has promised to permit securities firms to enter commercial banking as well as allow banks to get into securities. That being the case, Mr. Dingell might go along.
The prevailing view in political and banking circles is that the Administration may also have a personnel problem. Mr. Brady, who was briefly a Senator from New Jersey a decade ago, is well liked in Congress, but many question whether he has the temperament to handle messy politicking. His top assistant, Mr. Glauber, a professor on leave from the Harvard Business School, is personable and has few peers as an expert on banking laws, but he has little background in politics or lobbying.
The most experienced political figures in the Administration -- John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff; Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d -- give no indication of becoming involved.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Getting More Gas From Coalbeds

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 25

 BODY:
A decade after Congress granted the first tax incentives for drillers to gather natural gas from coal deposits, a small group of energy companies finds itself in a booming, subsidized and profitable business.
By some estimates, more than 500 billion cubic feet of natural gas recovered from coal deposits -- known as coalbed methane -- will flow into pipelines in 1990. That means coalbed methane will amount to 3 percent of the natural gas that analysts expect will be consumed across the continental United States this year. Five years ago, coalbed methane contributed only 10 billion cubic feet. 
 Further increases in production are widely expected. Many analysts say discoveries announced in the last five years are enough to meet all of the nation's natural gas consumption for more than four years. And analysts say rising production of coalbed methane should keep natural gas prices from rising substantially for several years.
Improvements in the drilling technique have played an important role in developing coalbed methane as a reliable and clean energy source. The new technique loosens the coal deposit freeing the methane in such a way that it flows more easily around the well bore.
But most analysts say these advances would not have been made without the financial aid from Congress.
"This is one of those examples of where a Government tax-incentive program worked extremely well," said John H. Wood, head of the proved reserves program for the United States Energy Information Administration. "Production is growing very rapidly."
Methane, like coal, is formed from decaying plant matter that has been tightly packed under extreme pressures for millions of years.
 
Global Warming
 Energy companies have known since the 1920's that coal layers contain methane, often in large concentrations. Indeed, exploding concentrations of underground methane have killed thousands of miners. The Federal Bureau of Mines estimates that 300 billion cubic feet of methane escapes from underground coal mines each year, contributing to global warming.
Until the more productive method was developed in recent years, high costs discouraged energy companies from trying to capture methane from the coalbeds.
Amoco Inc. drilled the first successful methane-recovery well in the San Juan Basin of New Mexico and Colorado in 1977.
Amoco used essentially the same drilling technology in its coalbed wells through most of the 1980's as it did in its oil and gas wells. Drill bits carved a well to the lowest depth of the coal seam. A pipe was lowered to the bottom of the well and concrete was forced out the bottom of the pipe until it rose up to the surface between the pipe and wall of the well. This formed an outer casing or shell to protect the pipe and prevent mud, gases and coal from seeping into groundwater supplies.
Small bullets were then shot through the steel pipe and concrete that lay within the coal seam to create holes through which the methane could flow into the well. Next, a mixture of sand and water was pumped under heavy pressure from the surface into the well to further loosen the coal and get the methane flowing more rapidly into the well.
 
Stress-Cavity Technique
 Since 1988, most drillers have used a newly developed method, called the stress-cavity technique, that dramatically accelerates the methane flow rate by exposing more coal to the well bore. The steel and concrete shaft stop short of the coalbed and do not go through it as is the case with the older method. Water and natural gas are pumped alternately from the surface directly onto the coal, carving a huge hole as chunks of coal are flushed back to the surface through the narrow drill pipe. Afterward, a liner pipe is placed at the base of the well to prevent more coal from being sucked in as methane is released from the coalbed. The methane flows through holes drilled in the liner pipe.
The Devon Energy Corporation, based in Oklahoma City, said it drilled 10 wells this year using the stress-cavity technique near the sites of wells drilled with the older method. J. Michael Lacey, vice president of operations and exploration at Devon, said the payoff was production of 92.8 million cubic feet a day for the new wells compared with five million cubic feet a day at the older ones.
Drilling costs for both types of methane wells, which average $400,000 a well in the San Juan Basin, are only a part of total development expenses. Additional wells must be drilled, often to depths of 8,000 feet or more, to flush salt-heavy water produced from the coalbed back underground.
Sources of drinking water no deeper than 400 feet have been badly polluted by water pumped from coalbeds and released at the surface. Local officials filed environmental lawsuits in Alabama this year over water handling procedures at several drilling sites in the Black Warrior basin, delaying drilling programs there. For this reason, ARCO, for one, halted its drilling program at 25 wells instead of completing the 100 wells it had planned.
Field stations are required to separate the water and methane that flow from the coal layer, as well as remove carbon dioxide from the methane. Pipeline companies limit carbon dioxide to 1 percent of a total natural-gas shipment because the molecule corrodes pipe. Before treatment, carbon dioxide levels in coalbed methane are as high as 15 percent. Pipelines for gathering the methane and connecting to lines operated by pipeline companies are another big expense.
 
$600 Million Tax Credit
 By all accounts, the drilling advances as well as the $3 billion invested in coalbed methane wells and related equipment would not have occurred without the special tax credit Congress approved in the 1980 Fuel Use Act. The credit amounts to a reduction in taxes on income from sales of coalbed methane. Congress recently estimated that the credit is worth $600 million for the years 1991 and 1992 combined.
Producers said the credit gave them the financial cushion to experiment and develop the technology for mining the coal gas. The credit was set to expire at the end of this year, but a two-year extension for all coalbed methane wells was included in the latest budget.
Before that extension, most analysts and producers anticipated a sharp decline in drilling in 1991 for coalbed methane. A resurgence is now expected in 1992.
"A lot of small companies now realize they have another two years" to organize and finance drilling programs, said G. Warfield Hobbs, a former Texaco geologist who specializes in the economics and financing of coalbed methane production. "It's going to grow exponentially."
Mr. Hobbs, managing partner of Ammonite Resources in New Canaan, Conn., estimated that 2,400 wells have been drilled for coalbed methane this year, or more than one-third of all natural gas wells drilled in the United States, at a cost of more than $1 billion. He said the amount of methane production should reach a trillion cubic feet a year, or double this year's rate, within a few years.
John E. Olsen, a natural gas analyst with the First Boston Corporation in Houston, said the effect of the tax credit for producers was that the break-even price of coalbed methane was 25 cents a thousand cubic feet, well below the approximately $2 a thousand cubic feet that buyers are paying at this time of year. (Coalbed methane sells for slightly less than other forms of natural gas.) And for the year, Mr. Olsen said, the tax incentive amounted to an after-tax benefit of $1.26 for every thousand cubic feet.
Among the major energy companies, Amoco, ARCO and Conoco had the most output from the two largest areas of coalbed methane production. All three were active in the San Juan Basin, and ARCO and Amoco had smaller drilling programs in the Black Warrior Basin.
Meridian Oil, a Houston-based unit of Burlington Resources, was one of the largest drillers in New Mexico. Smaller independents such as Devon Energy, Taurus Exploration, McKenzie Methane and Energen also were active in coalbed methane this year.
Many natural gas producers drilling in locations far removed from promising coalbed methane sites opposed the tax-credit extension. They blamed the subsidy for depressing market prices as more coalbed methane was produced, and fear the situation will worsen. Supporters of the subsidy countered that they shoulder the risk of huge losses if their coalbed projects yield little methane.
Mr. Hobbs said rising coalbed methane output, as well as new natural gas supplies coming on-line in the Arkoma Basin of Oklahoma and in the Mobile Bay field off Alabama, should keep natural gas prices from rising substantially for several years.
 
Cutting Prices
 Domestic producers have already lured some California customers away from Canadian producers by cutting prices on shipments that include large amounts of coalbed methane, Mr. Hobbs said. Canadian producers delivered 1.4 trillion cubic feet of natural gas to American customers last year, and many are concerned they will lose market share in California to marketers of coalbed methane from the San Juan Basin.
The American Gas Association, a trade group in Washington, estimates probable reserves of coalbed methane at 90 trillion cubic feet. The trade group estimates total probable reserves of all forms of natural gas in the United States at 796 trillion cubic feet. The United States consumed 17 trillion cubic feet of natural gas last year.
"Most people agree that this is a large resource," said Dr. Wood of the Energy Information Administration. "It's a matter of whether it's economical to get it out of the ground. That in large part is dependent right now on the tax credit."
