HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
The Justin Battle: A Waiting Game

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
A COUPLE of years ago, the battle for Justin Industries would not have seemed very odd. Now it seems extraordinary.
Justin, based in Fort Worth, is a small conglomerate with its biggest interests in boots and bricks. It is run by John Justin, a 73-year-old former mayor of Fort Worth who has no desire to sell. 
 Mr. Justin is busy fighting a tender offer to buy most of the company's shares at $18 each, well above any price at which Justin has traded. The offer came from a group led by two 32-year-old men, one of them a former aide to Asher B. Edelman, the corporate investor and chairman of the Datapoint Corporation. For much of the financing, they are relying on a commitment from Paine Webber Inc. to sell bonds.
Before the "junk bond" market collapsed, such deals were common. But the conventional wisdom now is that they cannot be done, a belief that Mr. Justin has emphasized in letters to shareholders.
Barry S. Rosenstein, the former aide to Mr. Edelman, conceded that the takeover market had changed and that he feels a bit lonely. "We're the only financial tender out there now," he said in an interview. "I feel like a dinosaur." But he said he was confident that financing could be completed.
In fact, the tender offer, which has been pending since September, is little more than a sideshow. The real battle is likely to come at a shareholders meeting. Perhaps that will be in March, when the 1991 meeting is scheduled to be held. But it could be earlier, since a court may yet order a repeat of the 1990 meeting.
Last week, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled that Justin had violated securities laws in failing to disclose before the 1990meeting that it had changed its bylaws to make it all but impossible for shareholders to throw out directors between annual meetings. That action, taken in November 1989 as the takeover effort was getting under way, was not disclosed until August. After a flurry of negative publicity, the board reversed its decision in September. Mr. Justin said that the failure to disclose was simply a "technical violation" of little importance.
But the judges did not order a new meeting; they only told a lower court judge to consider that issue. When the company announced that the court did not order the meeting, the shares promptly fell to as low as $12. But they recovered after the insurgents emphasized that the court was explicit in saying securities laws had been broken. On Monday, the shares closed unchanged, at $13.25 each, in over-the-counter trading.
Mr. Rosenstein's ally in the takeover attempt is Perry H. Sutherland, whose family controls the privately held Sutherland Lumber Southwest Inc., a Midwest retailer. The two men have acquired an 11.9 percent stake in Justin, just over one million shares, at an average price of more than $14. Mr. Rosenstein said they had spent another $2 million arranging financing and paying various fees, including legal fees.
While bank financing for most of the purchase seems secure, Paine Webber's "highly confident" letter for subordinated debt gives the firm the option to walk away for a variety of reasons, including "market conditions." But Mr. Rosenstein said that the deal would not be highly leveraged and emphasized that it did not rely on selling major assets of Justin. He said he was confident the money could be raised when needed.
Mr. Justin dismissed the $18 price as unreasonably low. "It is less than 1.5 times book value, and this company will sell for more than that," he forecast. He said that the Acme Brick business was doing well as the Texas economy started to revive, and that the boot business, based on the Justin, Nocona and Tony Lama brands, was "very good." In the first nine months of the year, Justin reported profits of $4.4 million, or 49 cents a share, on revenues of $208 million.
The Tony Lama business was bought by Justin after the first approach from Mr. Sutherland and Mr. Rosenstein, and was denounced by them as a "scorched earth" acquisition that had forced them to lower the price they could pay. But Mr. Justin said it was working out well, in part because Tony Lama no longer offers unreasonable credit terms that had "destabilized" the industry.
The tender offer is unlikely to go anywhere soon, if only because Mr. Justin, his board and his managers control 23 percent of the company, while an employee ownership plan holds 16 percent. That makes it almost impossible for the raiders to assemble the two-thirds of the shares they need to complete the deal.
But at an annual meeting, the group would only need a majority of the shares voting to replace the board, and Mr. Rosenstein said that goal is possible, although far from assured.
Anyway, he said, he and Mr. Sutherland are long-term investors who are prepared to wait and fight the battle with Mr. Justin over and over. "He can win 9 of 10 shareholder votes, and we win when we win that one," he said. "We've said to John, 'We've got 40 years on you. We can wait.' "
That wait, warned Mr. Justin, could be a long one. Although Mr. Rosenstein described Mr. Justin as being "in failing health," Mr. Justin said he was in "as good health as can be" and had no intention of retiring.

HEADLINE: Jump in Oil Profits Is Expected

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Many major oil companies will post sharply higher profits this quarter. Prices of crude oil and natural gas are far higher than they were last year, and fewer companies are likely to report big charges against earnings, as they did a year ago.
In fact, some companies may double their profits and touch off renewed charges of profiteering. But even with this strong fourth quarter, the industry will probably fall short of its expectations a year ago that it would increase earnings from operations by more than 10 percent in 1990. 
 "People will see in the fourth quarter what they had anticipated in the third quarter," said George F. Friesen, oil analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital Group in New York. "Earnings will be outstanding."
 
Crude Up by $10 a Barrel
 The big oil companies have sold crude at about $30 a barrel in the quarter, or $10 a barrel more than in the corresponding quarter a year ago. That is a 50 percent increase. Natural gas prices will average close to $2 per 1,000 cubic feet for the quarter, compared with $1.70 a year ago and $1.36 in the third quarter.
While gasoline has become slightly cheaper at the pump in the last two weeks, the wholesale price of gasoline has fallen faster, thanks to slowing demand from motorists and lower crude prices. Service stations, many of them owned by the oil companies, are restoring profit margins to what they were a year ago. After the Persian Gulf crisis began in August, these margins shrank as the retail price of gasoline rose more slowly than the price of crude.
 
Wholesale Prices Down
 According to Platt's Oilgram, gasoline retailers in the New York area paid an average of 68.9 cents a gallon for unleaded regular gasoline at wholesale last Wednesday, compared with a high of $1.002 on Oct. 17. In Los Angeles, the average wholesale price dropped to 65 cents a gallon last Wednesday; the high was $1.01 on Oct. 2. On average, motorists paid $1.37 a gallon for unleaded regular in the week ended Dec. 18, the American Automobile Association said.
Mr. Friesen said he expected a dozen international oil giants to report an average gain of 64 percent in overall profits this quarter. He completed his forecast last week. The same 12 companies posted a 17 percent decline in profits for the third quarter.
The results at some oil companies may be startling. Mr. Friesen estimated that profits at Chevron, British Petroleum, Phillips Petroleum, Texaco and Unocal will more than double in the current quarter from the 1989 quarter, excluding any special gains or write-offs.
That news could be so stunning, he warned, that some members of Congress might renew their attacks on the oil industry, accusing companies of profiting from the Persian Gulf crisis and high gasoline prices.
 
Some Earnings Declined
 Those complaints died down after the industry reported a wide range of financial results for the third quarter in October; earnings at some companies declined. An Energy Department investigation concluded early this month that the oil industry did not profit unfairly from the run-up in gasoline prices.
Percentage changes in quarterly net income can be complicated in the oil industry. Operating performance is often masked by gains or losses from sales of producing properties, by legal settlements and by charges against earnings for environmental expenses.
In the fourth quarter a year ago, for instance, ARCO reduced profits by adding $345 million to a reserve for future environmental expenses. Phillips Petroleum wrote off $280 million of its investment in the Point Arguello field off the Southern California coast, where an environmental dispute stalled production. Chevron wrote off $445 million for the same reason, plus $800 million in special charges.
Chevron said last week that it would take a special charge of approximately $220 million in the fourth quarter to reduce the recorded value of its fertilizer division. The company said in November it wanted to sell the unit. Thomas A. Petrie, chairman of Petrie, Parkman & Company, a Denver investment firm, said that while other write-downs were likely, the cumulative total would probably be far less than in the final quarter last year. "The integrated companies ought to do real well this quarter," he added.
Yet even such a strong finish to 1990 is not likely to fulfill the industry's widespread expectations last year that earnings from operations would increase by more than 10 percent this year. Production units suffered when oil prices fell below $15 a barrel in the spring, and chemical profits have been depressed because of slowing demand, flat prices and rising costs. Also, refining units now confront the same problems as chemicals after posting big gains in the third quarter.
 
Just a Few Percentage Points
 Charles T. Maxwell, senior energy strategist at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell in New York, said the industry would finish the year with a gain over 1989 of just a few percentage points in operations.
Dillard P. Spriggs, president of Petroleum Analysis Ltd., a research firm in New York, agreed. "Those who really took it on the chin in the third quarter, those heavily in chemicals, probably will do well to match last year," he said.
The higher crude costs after Iran's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 were accompanied by White House pressure to restrain gasoline price increases at the pump. The combination hurt profits in chemicals and refining and marketing operations.
 
Losses by Many Marketers
 Many gasoline marketers lost money in the third quarter. With President Bush and Congress warning against a surge in gasoline prices, big oil companies did not pass on the entire increase in crude and refining costs to motorists. They increased pump prices an average of 35 cents a gallon while crude costs rose by 60 cents at the refineries.
The result was third-quarter profits that surprised many analysts as well as industry critics. Many of the big integrated oil giants, like Mobil, Shell Oil and Exxon, reported no profit increases or declines for the period.
As the American economy slumps, these and other diversified oil companies still confront lower demand for gasoline and other refined products. Refiners have cut back output to below 84 percent of capacity, from 92 percent last summer. Companies that depend on that sector of the industry are showing strains. Ashland Oil, a large refiner, said last Friday that it expected a loss this quarter.
 
Drop in Premium-Grade Sales
 Since the Iraqi invasion, motorists are buying less premium-grade gasoline, a high-profit item for refiners. Premium-grade gasoline now accounts for only 17 percent of all retail gasoline sales. It was 24 percent a year ago.
Industry executives said last summer's surge in pump prices caused a sudden drop in overall demand. Gasoline sales amounted to 6.9 million barrels a day in the week ended Dec. 14, compared with 7.4 million barrels a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Warm weather in November and the first three weeks of December also has hurt refiners, and helped homeowners, cutting into deliveries of home-heating oil. Inventories, which soared on fears of shortages and higher prices after the invasion, were 16.5 percent higher than they were this time last December, when a record cold wave swept much of the nation. Stocks in the week ended Dec. 14 totaled 132.6 million barrels, according to the institute.
 
Slide for Chemicals
 Chemical divisions also are in a slide. With sales flat or declining in the weak economy, most producers have been unable to raise their prices in step with their higher operating costs. Crude oil is a major expense. Even though crude prices have fallen since the peak at $40 in early October, the current price is substantailly higher than a year ago.
The world's oil storage tanks, terminals and tanker vessels are well stocked. Crude supplies are abundant. In response, the shares of oil companies have tumbled in the last two months. Mr. Maxwell, for one, said earnings of oil companies would be unchanged in 1991 from this year.
Many oil analysts expect crude prices to plunge to $15 or lower by spring if the Persian Gulf crisis ends peacefully and Iraq and Kuwait add as much as four million barrels a day of production to world supplies. The February crude contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange finished last week at $25.92 a barrel.
 
OPEC Impact Called Small
 Analysts said oil companies would not suffer much damage if the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, especially Saudi Arabia, Iran and the United Arab Emirates, keep a pledge made earlier this month to curb output. OPEC's new price target is $21 a barrel.
Many analysts expect crude to fall from an average of $25 in the first quarter to $19 next summer, then recover to more than $21 by the year's end. For now, investors are looking no farther than prospects for Mideast peace.

HEADLINE: Chinese Trade Practices Raising Concern in U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
China's growing trade surplus with the United States, expected to be surpassed only by Japan's next year, is emerging as an important irritant in relations between the two countries.
Administration officials and some members of Congress say China's surplus, which is expected to overtake Germany's and Taiwan's, is in part a result of unfair trade practices. 
 The Americans complain that the Chinese are "dumping" products, or selling them at below cost, and are circumventing United States import quotas by shipping goods through other countries.
"The surpluses mean we're headed for trouble with our economic as well as political relations with China," said Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania.
"And when you engage in unfair trade practices, you lose friends fast," said Mr. Heinz, a member of the Senate Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over trade issues.
The growing trade gap is expected to figure prominently in the Congressional debate next year on trade with China. The issue before Congress is whether to strip China of commercial privileges and raise tariffs on billions of dollars of toys, apparel and other Chinese exports here. Chinese textiles represent one-fifth of its United States surplus, and China manufactures about half the toys imported by the United States.
Each June, China's "most favored nation" treatment, which keeps its tariffs as low as for most other countries, is subject to review by the President. President Bush decided this year to continue the special treatment.
On Oct. 18, the House, still mindful of the crushing of the democracy movement at Tiananmen Square in 1989, voted to punish Beijing by removing the trade privilege the Chinese have enjoyed since 1980. But , the House's 247-to-174 vote was short of the two-thirds that was needed to override the President's decision.
Next year, lawmakers say, the concern over trade surpluses and trade fairness could tilt the balance. Chinese surpluses have soared from $6 billion last year to an expected $11 billion this year, with Japan expected to come to more than $40 billion and Taiwan and Germany to around $12 billion each. Next year, a $15 billion surplus is forecast for China.
In an increasing number of cases, the Chinese are being accused of dumping, or selling exports below cost, in the United States in order to raise market share. Under American trade law, duties on dumped products can be raised to offset the unfair advantages.
A number of cases have been brought by the textile industry, which has taken the brunt of the Chinese export offensive. China shipped two billion square yards of textiles here last year -- everything from cotton nightwear to wool sweaters -- compared with 325 million square yards in 1980.
The textile industry has won dumping duties against products like cotton print cloth and industrial wiping cloths. Other dumping cases involved axes and sledgehammers and small electric fans.
 
Using Other Countries
 Textile industry and customs officials insist that the Chinese are circumventing American textile import quotas by moving goods to the United States through Macao, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines and other countries.
"In our opinion, the Chinese are engaged in massive quota fraud," said Carlos F. J. Moore, executive vice president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, an industry trade association.
What makes the issue potentially explosive is that China is one of the few remaining non-market economies. Far from reflecting a lack of American competitiveness or supply-and-demand forces of the marketplace, its trade surpluses result from targets, quotas, administrative guidance and other calculated decisions by Beijing authorities.
"This is somewhat alarming," noted Roger W. Sullivan, president of the United States-China Business Council, "because until recently, China was making the point that it was not a mercantilist nation and not seeking to pile up foreign exchange."
 
Restatement of Doctrine
 Mr. Sullivan, whose organization represents American companies doing business in China, said the change in Beijing's thinking could be seen in a recent statement by its Soviet-educated Prime Minister, Li Peng, that China's policy was not only to push exports but also to limit imports and bring in only necessary goods. In effect, it was a restatement of the old Communist doctrine of economic self-reliance.
Before the 1989 crackdown, more liberal policies had allowed for a rapid increase in imports and resulted in a large drain on hard currency reserves.
American officials say they have raised the issues of surpluses and trade unfairness in virtually all recent discussions with the Chinese.
The latest was a meeting in Washington on Dec. 10 and 11 of senior Chinese trade officials led by the Vice Minister for Trade, Gu Yongjiang, and Americans led by the Under Secretary of Commerce, J. Michael Farren.
 
Warning of Political Problem
 American officials say they warned the Chinese that the surpluses could become a significant political problem if not addressed.
"Our objective," said a senior Administration official, "is to get the Chinese to go back again to reforming their trading system toward more market-oriented operations."
American officials raised both the issues of creating trade surpluses -- through quotas, import substitution programs, export subsidies and other measures -- and of circumventing textile and apparel quotas through third countries.
Although the Chinese officials promised to investigate the accusations of irregularities, one American official said the Chinese were "not very sympathetic to our problem."
This official added, "They will pursue their interests and get away with anything they can."
Tien Mingwang, Minister Counselor at the Chinese Embassy here, denied that his Government was trying to create trade surpluses by closing its market to imports. He cited a special mission to the United States last October that bought $700 million of wheat, chemical fertilizers, timber, and other products.
"This was the first purchasing mission in our history," he said, adding that others may follow. "This is to show our desire for further expansion of imports from your country."
He said his Government would investigate all the trade accusations. "We would like to put the trade in textiles on a healthy basis," he stressed.

HEADLINE: Europeans Rate Japan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 25

 BODY:
A majority of people surveyed in several European countries have a favorable view of Japan but say it is not fulfilling its international responsibilities, the Foreign Ministry reported today.
Among the chief criticisms was that Japan needs to correct its trade imbalance. But many respondents in the poll, the sixth conducted by Japan since 1977, said the creation of a single European market at the end of 1992 would improve relations between Japan and the European Community, the ministry said in a news release. 
 The survey was conducted from September through October by private research organizations in each of the countries surveyed: Britain, France, Germany, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain.
In all seven countries, "the degree of trust in Japan is rather high," ranging from 71 to 91 percent, the ministry said.
In every country except Italy, however, a majority of respondents said they thought Japan was not fulfilling its international role. Japan, the world's No. 2 economic power after the United States, has come under criticism for not doing more to assist forces in the Persian Gulf and to reduce its chronic trade surpluses.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RAISE DUE, BUT NOT FOR BUSH

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Federal workers everywhere, from Vice President Dan Quayle to the troops in the Persian Gulf to the groundskeepers at the White House, will get a raise next year.
There is one exception: President Bush. 
 The Presidential salary stays frozen at $200,000, where it has been for the last 22 years and five Administrations.
For several million rank-and-file workers, both military and civilian, the pay increase is a flat 4.1 percent. But thousands of top Federal executives are getting big raises, generally on the scale of $20,000 to $30,000, because of a 1989 law that lifted the lid on salaries.
Mr. Quayle's pay will increase to $160,600 from $124,000. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley get the same 29 percent increase. Cabinet salaries rise to $138,900 from $107,300.
The Constitution precludes increasing, or lowering, the President's salary while he is in office, so Mr. Bush has no immediate prospects of a raise.
 
'No Complaints' From Bush
 Mr. Bush has "no complaints," said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, adding: "He thinks his pay is adequate. The Presidency's still a pretty good job."
No one disputes that, but an expert panel that reviewed Government salaries two years ago recommended increasing the President's salary in 1993 to $350,000 plus a cost-of-living adjustment. Congress ignored the recommendation.
The consumer advocate Ralph Nader takes another view. Mr. Nader, who lobbied strenuously to block the raises, said the President should revoke the 1991 raises and cut his own pay "as a gesture to the American people at a time of considerable sacrifice for them."
"At a time of deficit and recession, he should set an example," Mr. Nader said.
Whatever the salary, the Presidency is rich in perquisites, from a fully-staffed mansion to the limousines, helicopters and Boeing 747 jumbo jet.
"The President probably gets the equivalent of another $500,000 in perks," said Lloyd N. Cutler, who was chairman of the 1989 Quadrennial Pay Commission. "The perks make up for an awful lot of salary."
Still, Mr. Cutler said, the President's salary is "way below what it ought to be."
If Mr. Bush's salary were commensurate to that of corporate chiefs and top lawyers, "I suppose you'd be over $1 million," Mr. Cutler said. "With present budget constraints, this President would never ask for a raise if he were going to run again."
 
'A Darn Good Salary'
 Fred Hohlweg, a pay expert with the Office of Personnel Management, said $200,000 "was a darn good salary" when it went into effect in 1969.
The Consumer Price Index has increased nearly fourfold since 1969. If the President's pay had kept pace, Mr. Bush would be drawing $730,000 a year. Put another way, $200,000 today barely buys what $55,000 did in 1969.
Walton R. Winder, a vice president of the Towers Perrin Company in New York, said the chief executives of the nation's 100 largest corporations averaged $1.3 million in cash compensation last year, more than five times their 1969 level.
Even top jobs at universities and nonprofit organizations pay more than the Presidency, Mr. Winder said.
Vice Presidents, on the other hand, have never had it so good.
When the first Congress fixed George Washington's salary at the kingly sum of $25,000 in 1789, the lawmakers allotted $5,000 for Vice President John Adams -- 20 percent of the President's salary.
When Mr. Bush became Vice President, he was earning less than 40 percent of Ronald Reagan's salary as President.
But by the time Mr. Bush turned the job over to Mr. Quayle, it paid $115,000. Mr. Quayle got a $9,000 raise earlier this year and starting Jan. 1 he will be earning barely 20 percent less than Mr. Bush.
The first 17 Presidents got the same $25,000 salary that Washington received. Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th President, got a $25,000 raise that doubled the salary to $50,000 in 1873 for his second term.
 
Slugger and the President
 In 1909, Congress voted another $25,000, raising the salary to $75,000 when William Howard Taft took office as the 27th President. It remained there for the next 40 years.
In 1930, when Babe Ruth signed an $80,000-a-year contract with the New York Yankees, the slugger was asked if he thought he should be paid more than President Herbert Hoover.
"Why not?" Ruth replied. "I had a better year than he did."
Harry S. Truman, the 33d President, became the first $100,000-a-year President in 1949. Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson drew the same salary, but that doubled to $200,000 in 1969 when Richard M. Nixon took office.

HEADLINE: Getting Composers Into the Public Eye as Well as the Ear

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
John Duffy was composing incidental music for Shakespeare plays and television films 16 years ago when he came up with a way to help other composers make connections with potential audiences and collect fees at the same time. With a $54,000 grant from the New York State Council on the Arts, he made an offer to concert promoters around the state: If they programmed contemporary works, they could have the composers -- famous ones as well as fledglings -- on hand to explain their pieces.
Mr. Duffy called his project Meet the Composer, and it took him three months to give away that first bankroll. But two years later, he was helping to start Meet the Composer affiliates in other states. Since then, the organization, of which Mr. Duffy is president, has grown prodigiously. Besides its original Composers Performance Fund program, which sponsors about 8,000 performances a year, Meet the Composer has underwritten composer-in-residence posts at 32 American orchestras. 
 And in 1988 it began a $600,000-a-year consortium program under which several ensembles join to commission new works, thus guaranteeing them multiple performances.
"There was a tremendous gulf between concertgoers and composers," Mr. Duffy said of the early days of Meet the Composer. "So when an opportunity to help other composers came up, I knew very clearly what needed to be done. I also knew that our success had to be clear within the first few months, to show that there was a demand for the kind of organization I had in mind."
All told, the organization hands out about $2.5 million a year, of which 43 percent, by Mr. Duffy's calculations, goes to women and minorities, with around a third going to jazz composers. Among the recent products of the program are Hannibal Peterson's "African Portraits," an exploration of African and black American musical styles, which was given its premiere by the American Composers Orchestra last month, and Julius Hemphill's "Long Tongues: A Saxophone Opera," which had its New York premiere at the Apollo Theater three weeks ago.
 
Composing for Students
 In June, the organization awarded $400,000 in grants to 22 composers and 20 choreographers for new dance works. It has started an educational program, in which composers visit schools and compose works for the students to play. It also publishes two free handbooks, "Commissioning Music" and "Composers in the Marketplace: How to Earn a Living Writing Music." And it has recently started a jazz-commissioning program.
"One of our original tenets was that our grants would represent the whole gamut of music -- symphonic, jazz, chamber, theater and experimental," Mr. Duffy said. "Our first six grants, in fact, went to jazz composers. And we have always encouraged people to look out for women and minority composers.
"We don't beat people over the head with it. But there is a lot of stereotypical thinking out there, some of it in surprising places. For years, the Women's Hall of Fame, in Seneca Falls, would apply to Meet the Composer for grants, but always to commission a male composer. One year they called, and I said: 'Look, it's odd to have a women's organization always commissioning music from a man. What about a woman?' We sent them a list of women composers, with addresses, and they began looking at scores and listening to tape. From then on, they considered women composers.
"There have also been times we've suggested to community groups that present chamber music that they try a jazz composer. In most cases, people just haven't thought of it. They think that when you say Meet the Composer, it means 'serious' music, in quotes. They don't think about the fact that what Ornette Coleman does is composition. We like to enlighten people."
 
The Art of Finding Money
 Meet the Composer has had a way of finding the money to support its ambitions. Even now, when many arts organizations are feeling a financial pinch, Meet the Composer seems scarcely affected. In July, it received a $2 million grant from the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund to cover four years of consortium commissions.
The organization has also received grants from the Ford Foundation, the Pew Charitable Trusts, the Rockefeller Foundation and A.T. & T. in recent years. And it gets nearly $500,000 a year from the National Endowment for the Arts.
Its substantial budget notwithstanding, Mr. Duffy sees Meet the Composer as a grass-roots organization. In 1976, he encouraged regional groups to form Meet the Composer affiliates by giving them annual grants of $15,000. The first year, that amount was to represent 75 percent of their grant budgets. The second year, it was to represent 50 percent, and the third year 25 percent. Affiliates' budgets thereby grew from $20,000 to $60,000 in three years.
"Setting up the affiliates was like peopling the earth with composers," Mr. Duffy said. "We didn't want to seem like carpetbaggers. We just wanted to spread the good word. And we made sure that affiliates had grass-roots connections, were evangelical in their zeal, and stressed commissions, collaborations and giving young composers a chance. Our rule was that 60 percent of the affiliates' grants had to be for local composers, so that all the money didn't go to East Coast and West Coast composers.
"We've learned interesting things from the affiliates. We learned, for example, that in the Midwest, a lot of composers earn a living writing liturgical music. That's hardly the case in Manhattan."
 
Composers in Residence
 Mr. Duffy has dreamed up new programs for Meet the Composer every few years. One of the first, the Composer-in-Residence Program, started in 1982, has become one of the organization's most visible endeavors, partly because the works the composers write during their three-year residencies are recorded by Nonesuch Records. Besides writing for the orchestras with which they are associated, the composers in the program advise music directors on contemporary programming. But the program is by design to end in 1992.
"My thought -- and this may have been a misjudgment -- was that if in 10 years the orchestras had not taken on the program themselves, then we've missed the boat," Mr. Duffy said. "We have always thought of this as a self-destructing program. What we're aiming for now is to raise money and to help orchestras endow permanent chairs for resident composers."
The Jazz Program, which Meet the Composer started last year with $250,000 in grants from the Rockefeller Foundation and A.T. & T., was meant to address such a need. Jazz composers have also been elegible for grants from the organization's other programs, but Mr. Duffy felt that they needed special encouragement. The first set of jazz grants went to 18 musicians. Among the recipients are Geri Allen, Leroy Jenkins, Henry Threadgill, Butch Morris, Oliver Lake, Stanley Cowell and Benny Carter.
"Most jazz composers that I've spoken with and worked with want opportunities to work in larger forms," Mr. Duffy said. "They have seen Aaron Copland writing film scores, and Philip Glass writing symphonic works. Yet those opportunities are not open to jazz composers. Of course, writing for orchestra presents certain problems for jazz composers. What do you do about improvisation? What it takes for them to solve these problems is a residency with the group they're writing for. They get to know the players and the institution, and solutions emerge."
"When we started," Mr. Duffy added, "I would never have dreamed that we would make the progress we have. We've come through periods when funding has been cut and when there were economic disasters in the country, but we seem to have been blessed. We have built up tremendous loyalty in the field. And by bringing composers and audiences together, we have come a long way in banishing the idea that the composer is someone above the crowd, or someone who wore a wig and has been dead for a long time. We started in the 1970's with young composers who are now on their feet. Now we're starting with a new bunch, and we're hoping to open the same kinds of doors for them."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For Movie Theaters, a Bad Big Year

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25

 BODY:
When the movie industry tallies the final box-office gross for 1990, the total figure will be more than $4.7 billion, making this year the second best in Hollywood history, nearly as good as last year. So why are the owners of many of the country's 23,000 movie theaters singing the blues?
Their dissatisfaction, which reflects the figures now appearing on some annual profit-and-loss statements, has less to do with overall revenues than with how box-office receipts are split between the companies that make movies and those that exhibit them. Though nine movies have earned more than $100 million at the box office this year, a combination of too many theaters and too few films with staying power means that many exhibitors are experiencing a profit squeeze and, in some cases, even recording losses. 
 This month, prospects have improved somewhat with the release of a slew of films banking on prestige or star appeal, such as "The Godfather Part III," "Awakenings," "The Russia House," "Kindergarten Cop" and "The Sheltering Sky." But those movies appear to have come too late, too closely bunched together and at too high a price to reverse the slide.
 
Hoping for Longevity
 Typically, studios and other film distributors can expect a 70 percent share of what a movie grosses during its opening week, with the remainder going to the exhibitor. That scale then descends gradually, so that by the time a hit movie is in its 10th or 12th week at a theater, the exhibitor will be turning over only 25 or 30 percent to the distributor.
"The longer a picture plays, the higher the percentage the exhibitor keeps," said William F. Kartozian, the president of the National Association of Theater Owners. "If a picture turns over at a rapid rate, the exhibitor is always paying the highest rate, and that's pretty much what happened in the summer."
Even a much anticipated box-office hit like "The Godfather Part III," which opened at 1,800 theaters today, may not alleviate the situation, because of the stiff terms being negotiated. Exhibitors complain that Paramount Pictures is demanding that they make a 12-week commitment, with Paramount getting 70 percent of the box office the first 2 weeks, 60 percent for the next 2, and 50 percent for another 2.
Both theater owners and studio executives like nothing better than a movie that has "legs," or the ability to bring audiences into a theater week after week. This year, however, only a handful of movies, most notably such sleeper hits as "Ghost," "Pretty Woman," and, more recently, "Home Alone" and "Dances With Wolves" have demonstrated that kind of durability.
 
Blaster After Blaster
 In contrast, the expensive action-adventure pictures that had been expected to dominate the summer season and had been the object of spirited bidding by exhibitors, including "Days of Thunder," "Robocop 2," "Dick Tracy" and "Another 48 Hours," showed little staying power. Throughout June and July, one "body count" movie after another was released, making a big splash its opening weekend and then being overtaken a week later by the latest entry.
"This summer, one A picture after another performed the way that a horror or exploitation film typically would," said an executive at one major independent production company here. "They would do a ton of business the first week and then plummet 40 to 50 percent. It was two, three or four weeks, and out, which really hurt the exhibitors."
In addition, film exhibitors have found their bargaining power weakened by a decade-long expansion in the construction of theaters, which has pushed the total number of movie screens in the United States from 17,095 in 1979 to 23,129 by 1988, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. With big mortgages and other loans to pay back, those newcomers have sought to compete aggressively with existing outlets, paying top dollar for films they think will pull in moviegoers, whose numbers have not grown significantly.
The prosperous west side of Los Angeles offers a dramatic example of that tendency. In the last 3 years, 3 new complexes with 17 screens have opened just in Santa Monica, pushing the total there to 23 screens, all of them hungry to attract audiences with first-run feature hits.
 
Distributors Take Advantage
 Film distributors have been quick to take advantage of that situation. "This summer, I was getting over 50 percent of the aggregate gross on some of my pictures, which was something new for me," said one industry executive who specializes in distribution. "When that happens on picture after picture, it very rapidly goes to the exhibitors' bottom line."
The upper hand enjoyed by distributors stands in contrast to the recent past, when the balance of power often favored the film exhibitor, especially in smaller areas where there was little competition or cities where a single chain dominated the market.
"There are no more monopolies, and the distributor welcomes that," said John Krier of Exhibitor Relations Inc., which monitors and compiles box-office data. "All you have to do now is walk across the street and sell to the opposition."
Several of the country's largest theater chains have found themselves squeezed as a result. The General Cinema Corporation, which operates some 1,500 screens around the country, last week reported a $9.8 million operating loss for its theater operations during the third quarter of 1990 and a 42 percent overall decline in profits during its fiscal year ending Oct. 31.
Richard A. Smith, the chairman of the company, said the disappointing results reflected "somewhat weaker film product, particularly during the important summer season." At the same time, he noted in a statement to shareholders, "operating expenses were significantly higher, however, due to increased occupancy costs for newer theaters and higher film costs."
 
Event That Didn't Happen
 Movie industry executives here said General Cinema, in a decision typical of what has befallen exhibitors this year, had bet heavily that the Walt Disney Company 's "Dick Tracy," starring Warren Beatty, Madonna and Al Pacino, would be the "event" movie of 1990, as "Batman" had been the summer before. But after a strong opening weekend in which it earned $22.5 million at the box office, "Dick Tracy" quickly tailed off, grossing $104 million before moving into video this month.
Difficulties for exhibitors have also been deepened by an overall decline in moviegoing, which is masked by increases in ticket prices that account for growing movie revenues. Hollywood studio executives said they expected ticket sales for 1990 to drop about 5 percent from 1989's figure of 1.13 billion, which was virtually the same as the total 10 years earlier.
Any downturn in attendance is bothersome for another reason: it means less popcorn, soda and candy, sources of revenue that might compensate somewhat for stiffer film rental terms, are being bought. "When you don't have people coming through the turnstiles, your concession sales are not going to be as good," said Peter Farwell, vice president for corporate relations for General Cinema.
At this juncture, a Christmas season even busier than usual is not expected to provide much financial relief for exhibitors. Though an unusually large number of quality movies are being released this month, many are expected to fall victim to the same "churn" effect that crippled most big budget films this summer.
 
Too Much for Too Much
 "There's too much out there," Mr. Krier said. "People don't have enough time and money to see them all."
Several theater chains seem to think one partial solution to the problem is to suspend their ambitious construction programs and shut a few of their existing theaters in areas that have too many. Several major Hollywood studios have also announced plans to increase production, which would be another important step toward restoring a balance between supply and demand.
"There are certain rules of economics that pertain to theaters as much as to gasoline stations or supermarkets," Mr. Kartozian said. "In some years the distributor is favored, in others it is the exhibitor. The pendulum always swings in this business, and this situation is not necessarily going to be long lasting."

HEADLINE: A New Year's Fete Of Art, Not Alcohol

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
FROM Boston to Calgary to Honolulu, more than a million Americans and Canadians are expected on New Year's Eve to ring out the traditional celebration of booze, noisemakers and hangovers and ring in Mozart, ballet performances and a wide selection of popular entertainment from rock 'n' roll to reggae to hula dancing.
Fifty-five cities in the United States and Canada will serve up performing arts and family entertainment as nonalcoholic alternatives to the carousing and midnight countdowns and fleets of intoxicated drivers who make the night one of the deadliest on American roads. 
 In some respects it is an extension of a new militancy against public and private drinking, drunken driving and hazardous holiday risk-taking like fireworks on the Fourth of July and trick-or-treating on Halloween.
But more than that, the multicultural events seek to accomplish what is not supposed to be possible in many cities: a drawing together of diverse crowds after dark in downtown areas, reaffirming a community spirit through the celebration of the arts.
The idea started 15 years ago in Boston, where the streets have filled on recent New Year's Eves with as many as 500,000 people. Encouraged by that's city's experience with peaceful, festive crowds, the idea began to spread in the 1980's to other communities.
"New Year's Eve is the safest night of the year in Boston," said Zeren Earls, director of First Night Boston, the nonprofit organizing force behind Boston's celebration and others elsewhere that are based on the Boston model.
This year First Night Boston will feature more than 1,000 artists performing at 41 indoor and 18 outdoor sites along a wide corridor in the heart of the city.
"People are in the best mood, walking the city streets with their children, taking in everything from inner-city rap groups to Handel and Haydn," Ms. Earls said.
Others derive a benefit about as rare in some metropolitan areas as chamber music in a fast-food outlet: a revived sense of community.
"When we started First Night Montclair three years ago, I was amazed by the sight of people discovering it was all right to talk with strangers on the streets of their town," said Gerald Fierst of Montclair, N.J., a community of 36,500 about 15 miles west of New York City. "In modern America we've lost many of our rituals and on New Year's Eve we're attempting to create one of a community at peace as we go into the future together," said Mr. Fierst, a professional storyteller who spins fables for children on New Year's Eve.
A Montclair neighbor, Lucretia Robinson, sees a combination of trends behind the enthusiasm, the anti-drunken-driving movement being just one of them.
"In the past parents were forced to decide between having 'a good time' or staying at home with their children and watching the Times Square ball go down at midnight on television," she said. "And the economy is forcing a change in attitude that excesses like two Porsches in every garage is a terrible value, and that the conviviality and closeness of family-centered and community activities are more meaningful."
In a city like New York, where homelessness, crime and other intractible urban ills have enshrined a streetwise dictum -- "never make eye contact with a stranger" -- into a daily way of life, opportunities to cross the barriers of silent alienation often seem available only to dog-walkers and those in movie lines.
Midtown Manhattan, with its theater, nightlife and other cultural offerings, is not like other cities in which downtown life ceases after 7 P.M. But the annual Times Square crush, with its accompanying drinking and rowdyism, is the essence of what the First Night movement hopes to offer as an alternative elsewhere, said Ms. Earls of First Night Boston. So far, no one has sought to establish something like it in New York, she said, but First Night has taken root in the region in Montclair, Hartford, Stamford, Conn., Albany and Buffalo.
"There's a hunger everywhere for this kind of expression, but people are at a loss at how to go about creating it," said Philip Slater, a writer and social critic in Santa Cruz, Calif.
Michael Lears, director of the American Studies Department at Rutgers University, said: "Coming out into the streets to celebrate together sounds like a very European way of doing things. Americans have spent so much time escaping from their community by locking themselves up at night with television sets and VCR's that we've created a global village but lost a local one."
The First Night movement, which added 20 cities in the past year alone, has been set in motion chiefly by nonpolitical groups. In most communities the effort was spearheaded by local arts councils, newspapers, civic-minded individuals or merchant associations. In Dayton, Ohio, it came to life under the auspices of the Alzheimer's Association.
"I liked the focus of shifting away from alcohol to the arts," said Merry Lee Corwin, the force behind First Night Honolulu, which is holding its inaugural effort Dec. 31 and is expected to draw 100,000 celebrants.
Ms. Corwin got $150,000 in seed money from the Hawaiian Community Foundation, a cultural group, to set up an office, and another $100,000 from local businesses. In addition, $5 buttons that provide adult admission to all 30 performance sites on New Year's Eve from mid-afternoon to midnight are being sold and Ms. Corwin said she hopes that organizers will sell 30,000. All programs are free to children.
For that $5 a button holder can choose from a luau of concerts and acts ranging from Ballet Hawaii, the Maui Dance Company and a reworking of Shakespeare's "Merry Wives of Windsor" to a Hungarian dance troupe, circus performers, a Japanese ceremonial drummer, Samoan choirs and a master Chinese noodle maker. The evening ends at midnight with a fireworks display.
Many smaller cities do not have the backing of large companies. Consequently, most First Night celebrations in New England suffered deficits last year when bad weather descended on the region and button sales plunged.
The recession in New England has squeezed business contributions this year. In addition, state budget-slashing has sharply reduced public arts grants to the celebrations. In New Haven, the First Night celebration was canceled when only $12,000 in contributions was collected by October to meet a $130,000 budget.
While some communities like Princeton, N.J., hold arts-related New Year's Eve activities, they are outside the alliance started by First Night Boston. Now known as First Night International, the alliance charges a one-time fee, ranging from $500 to $1,500, for use of the copyrighted name First Night, and sets a number of rules.
A participating city agrees to stage a celebration that is focused on the arts and multicultural expressions of the community. Local artists are to outnumber those imported for the day; the event should be affordable to families, extra attention must be given to the needs of children and teen-agers and alcohol consumption is discouraged. Profanity and sexual references by the performers are banned.
Winning the participation of a wide range of racial and ethnic groups in a community requires aggressive marketing, Ms. Earls said.
Charles R. Stith, pastor of the black congregation at Union United Methodist Church of Boston, said New Year's Eve was one of the few opportunities outside of sporting events that offered community-wide participation in a racially divided city. On Dec. 31 his church will open its doors for a program of gospel music.
"I don't think the outreach or the participation has been as extensive as any of us would like, but First Night does cut across color lines," Mr. Stith said. "It represents an opportunity -- tragically one of the few opportunities -- to bring people together. It's a great way for any community in the country to begin a new year."

HEADLINE: Help Moscow's Reformers -- Soon

 BODY:
The West's leading financial institutions called last week for radical reform of the Soviet economy -- but without massive aid from the West. That's a cautious stance, endorsed by President Bush, and guaranteed to protect Western leaders from ridicule should perestroika fail.
But it's too cautious by half. The Soviets are engaged in a ferocious political battle between reformers and reactionaries, between those who seek decentralized markets and political democracy and those who seek to preserve centralized control. As Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze warned last week when he resigned, the reactionaries may be gaining the upper hand. 
 If that's so it becomes all the more important for the West to tip the scales in favor of the reformers with the promise of aid, conditioned upon further reforms. By pledging tens of billions to back up reform, the West risks only a pittance of its collective wealth. By withholding the aid, it risks immeasurably more.
In a major report, the International Monetary Fund and three other Western financial institutions made a shocking disclosure: living standards in the Soviet Union are only a tenth as high as in the United States, and closer to Costa Rica than Western Europe. Unless there's a radical turnabout, the economy will probably shrink an additional 10 percent this year and next.
The study calls on the Soviets to decontrol prices, liberalize trade, privatize enterprises, control wages and cut budget deficits. In the short run, each of these policies would prove painful, driving up inflation and unemployment. The study adocates technical assistance to help the Soviets construct, seemingly overnight, the institutions that developed over hundreds of years in the West: enforceable contracts, property rights, accounting standards, private banks and stock markets.
Technical assistance is important. But it's not nearly enough. The Soviet economy is collapsing, and economic reform threatens the livelihoods of millions of families. Unless displaced workers are offered assistance, radical reform will never begin. That's why Western money is essential, and why it can't wait until reforms become fact.
President Bush has offered the Soviets food and medical aid and "associate" status in the I.M.F. and World Bank. Food and medicine are crucial. But by denying the Soviets full membership, Mr. Bush cuts them off from large loans. Here again, caution is unnecessary, even shortsighted. Membership in the the I.M.F. and World Bank has drawn centralized economies closer to the West, notably in China during the 1980's before Tiananmen Square.
The power of this economic lever was confirmed by a surprising source when the chairman of the Soviet intelligence agency, K.G.B., warned last week that accepting Western economic aid threatened to impose an alien capitalist outlook.
The West does not need to choose between unconditional bailout and passivity. It can promise the Soviets assistance, withdrawing the offer if the Soviets renege on the reforms outlined in the I.M.F. study. But if the West waits, it will undermine reformers faced with a scary traverse from the certainty of centralized control to the seeming chaos of markets. A promise of substantial aid, conditioned upon steady progress, could remove the fear and make the traverse possible.

HEADLINE: Heading for a Deep Recession?

BYLINE: By Rudolph G. Penner; Rudolph G. Penner, director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1983 to 1987, is a senior fellow at the Urban Institute.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I fondly retain my WIN button. It symbolizes President Gerald Ford's 1974 campaign against inflation (Whip Inflation Now), which I played a bit part in organizing. It also represents the worst economic forecast of the 1970's.
At the inflation summits of September 1974, no economists warned of a serious recession ahead. Yet, within two months it became apparent that the economy was in free fall. Ultimately, the gross national product suffered what is still the largest peak-to-trough decline since the 30's. 
 There are eerie similarities between 1974 and 1990. Then as now, the economy had recently experienced an oil shock, although the shock of 1973-74 was far greater than that recently imposed by Saddam Hussein. Then as now, the Federal Reserve adamantly fought inflation until the eve of the recession. Then as now, economists claimed that inventories were not excessive.
Only later did it become apparent that the inventory data was of terrible quality, and that economists had been misled. Could it be that economists now -- a majority of whom are forecasting a mild recession -- are also being misled?
Inventory data were improved significantly after the 1974 fiasco. But data collecting agencies have been squeezed by the budget battles of the 1980's. In a recent survey conducted by the newsletter Blue Chip Economic Indicators, 76 percent of the economists responding felt that the Government's statistics had deteriorated over the last decade. Since the quality of data was pretty bad 10 years ago, that is truly frightening.
While the composition of the economy has changed significantly, our statistical techniques have not. Important data on payroll employment are particularly suspect. A month ago it was reported that employment in October fell by 68,000. This month, that October number was revised to a decline of 178,000. That is a large change, big enough to have altered the attitudes of the Federal Reserve and other policy makers.
The cost of improving the accuracy of such data is trivial compared with the economic losses that can ensue if we do not make the effort. To its credit, the Bush Administration has advocated greater spending for statistical agencies, but much more has to be done.
I do not mean to imply that economists armed with better data will suddenly become brilliant forecasters. No amount of good data will allow us to forecast a Persian Gulf crisis, which will have a crucial impact on the economy in 1991.
More important, the nuances of human behavior are never easily captured by the statistical equations used by economic forecasters, regardless of the quality of the data available. Therefore, good data will not insure good forecasts. But bad data can cause some bad ones.
Even with good data, there is an inherent tendency, as we enter a recession, for forecasts to understate the impending troubles. Paul Samuelson has quipped that economists can at best forecast minus one month. That may be optimistic, because of the problems we have figuring out what happened last month.
Recessions seldom look as serious at the beginning as they do at the end. It is the cumulative changes in human behavior as the recession unfolds that kill you, and they develop differently in each downturn. This recession has the shadow of war hanging over it, and we can't know how that will affect the decisions of consumers and investors.
In November and December of 1974, as it became obvious that the economy was collapsing, economists scrambled to ratchet down their forecasts. This year, with weekly announcements of new and more ominous data, a similar but less intense scramble seems under way. That implies to me that this recession will not be as severe as 1974's. But, then, who am I to know? I rely on the same data and techniques as everyone else.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Magnetic Trains Offer Environmental Benefits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the inventors of superconducting magnetically levitated trains and holders of the original 1968 patent, we wish to comment on "Doubts About Magnetic Train Mount" (letter, Dec. 3) by Marjorie and James Young. Our published designs have formed the basis for the levitation and propulsion systems in the Japanese superconducting maglev project the Youngs discuss, as acknowledged by its developers.
The Youngs state that maglev consumes at least three times as much energy per passenger mile as Japan's bullet high-speed rail train. However, their comparisons reflect totally different conditions. The Japanese maglev trains will travel at 300 miles per hour in tunnels where air drag effects are large, while the bullet trains travel at 140 m.p.h. in the open air. Sixty percent of the proposed Tokyo-Osaka maglev route is in tunnels because of the mountainous terrain. This new route represents a social decision by the Japanese to open previously undeveloped portions of their crowded country.
When traveling under similar conditions -- at the same speed and both in tunnels or both in open air -- maglev passengers use much less energy per passenger mile than high-speed rail passengers. This is because maglev vehicles are much lighter than high-speed rail trains, and there is no mechanical friction with the track.
The Youngs also do not compare maglev with auto and air travel. Maglev at 300 m.p.h. uses half the primary thermal energy per passenger mile that 60 m.p.h. autos do, and only a quarter of that used by airplanes. United States transport energy use would be considerably reduced by shifting to maglev. Moreover, maglev does not use oil fuel, but electricity from clean coal, hydro, solar or nuclear power.
The Youngs are wrong in stating that maglev cannot carry freight. Maglev could readily and economically transport most of the United States truck-type freight, in addition to passengers. Maglev forces are distributed over a large area on the guideway, and there is no mechanical contact; thus maintenance requirements are very low, even if freight is carried. In contrast, carrying freight on high-speed rail trains would quickly wear out and destroy the precisely positioned tracks from the constant heavy pounding. Even carrying passengers, high-speed rail tracks require a large maintenance force.
As for the health effects of magnetic fields, maglev can be designed so that passengers experience a constant magnetic field of the same strength -- about 1/2 gauss -- as all life forms evolved in and are exposed to on earth. Passengers in electrified rail trains typically experience strong magnetic fields that alternate at power-line frequencies. Such alternating fields are of potentially much greater concern.
Maglev, if it is implemented, will have enormous environmental, safety and economic benefits. It can greatly reduce pollution and carbon dioxide emissions, provide greater and safer mobility at lower cost, and reduce dependence on foreign oil. If we are to improve our environment and living standards, we must bring forward new technologies to solve our crisis problems.
 
JAMES R. POWELL
GORDON T. DANBY
Shoreham, L.I., Dec. 12, 1990
 
The writers are with Brookhaven National Laboratory as, respectively, head of the reaction systems division and a senior physicist.

HEADLINE: MAGNETIC TRAINS OFFER ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS;
Cannot Be Ignored

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The doubts about magnetic levitation train technology in Marjorie and James Young's Dec. 3 letter seem more like arguments for a maglev research program than against one. Possible hazards of electromagnetic radiation are one problem that must be thoroughly studied and addressed by shielding or some other method.
The comparison with the Japanese bullet train (shinkansen) by power per passenger is misleading. The bullet train achieves a high rating in this category because hefty employees shove 300 passengers into cars designed for 100.
True, passengers will not be allowed to stand in the aisles of a maglev vehicle going 300 miles per hour. But speed is a necessity, and becoming more so, because of the trend toward lighter-weight, more valuable cargoes and the increasing value of people's time. William B. Johnston of the Hudson Institute has observed that "In our future transportation needs, the rising importance of time stands out as the single most important and most overlooked issue."
The expense of maglev research and development is justified by its enormous potential. Intercity transport in the United States for trips of up to 400 miles consists of fuel-inefficient jet flights and even more inefficient auto trips. The short flights clog up the airspace at hub airports, which are on the verge of a congestion crisis; the autos jam highways and befoul the air. Maglev can replace many jet flights and car trips, relieving both air and highway congestion, while also eliminating a great deal of petroleum use.
Add to that the opportunity to develop and build an emerging technology that could revitalize our laboratories, universities and economy as the space race did in the 1960's, and it is evident that maglev simply cannot be ignored.
 
WILLIAM L. SCHLOSSER
Indianapolis, Dec. 10, 1990

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Year: Dreams Delayed By Fiscal Slump

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
One year ago on a crisp New Year's morning, David N. Dinkins took the oath of office as Mayor of New York City saying, "I recognize that we cannot do everything we should, that our finances may get worse before they get better, that for now our dreams are bigger than our budget."
Today the Dinkins administration is struggling with fiscal problems far deeper than the new Mayor imagined, and its daily challenge is to hold the line, to minimize the pain of layoffs of city workers and deep cuts in services. What dreams it has time for are of an eventual upturn in the city's economy. 
 If there is a thread that runs through Mr. Dinkins's first year in office, it may be deferred dreams, dashed expectations and daunting problems. His overwhelming challenge, he acknowledged in an interview last week, has been to deal with the city's worsening economy, with all that means for the quality of life in the city and for his own standing with his liberal coalition.
 
'It's Beyond Dreams'
 The candidate who campaigned on a platform "that government should be an agent for change, that government can't afford to stand on the sidelines," is doing his best to keep his city's government from changing too much -- for the worse. Mr. Dinkins's closest advisers acknowledge that improvements must be measured around the edges, and even some of those efforts may be delayed by budget constraints.
"It's beyond dreams," said Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "It's doing the things you never dreamed you'd have to do. It's not a question of all the good things you won't get to do; it's the bad things you do have to do."
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, a longtime Dinkins supporter, said: "It has been an extraordinarily difficult time for this administration to go through the usual difficult times that each new administration faces. When the ground under you is constantly in motion, when the doorway keeps getting shorter and narrower, it's quite likely that there will be lots of visible bumps, and I think we've seen most of them."
Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said, "It's sort of ironic that David Dinkins, considering his platform and commitment to so many things, is becoming most of all an expert on austerity."
The Mayor who won with broad union support granted the teachers' union a 5.5 percent raise but may now have to lay off 20,000 city workers to help close looming budget gaps. After vowing to be the toughest mayor on crime, he has struggled for an ambitious program to hire more police.
As Manhattan Borough President, he issued a report called "A Shelter Is Not a Home," but as Mayor, he has had to delay efforts to close big shelters because there is not enough permanent housing. He has dedicated his administration to children, and insisted on including some education and youth programs in his anti-crime plan. But he has also ordered cuts in the education budget that will affect classroom teaching.
And he has been the target of critics who have questioned everything from his competence to his clothing, from his willpower to his wisdom. Friends and opponents have suggested by turns that he was too slow, too soft, too stubborn, too sanguine, too snooty.
In some quarters, expectations for the city's first black mayor were so low that he was praised extravagantly for required acts, like balancing his first budget, while other expectations were so high that he was faulted for failing to resolve thorny disputes, like the black-led boycott of two Korean-American groceries in Brooklyn.
 
'A Mixed Report Card'
 "It's a mixed report card," said Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Health and Hospital Workers Union and a major backer who helped persuade Mr. Dinkins to run for mayor. "On the one hand, I believe that he has brought to the city a sense of calmness in the decision-making process, and we don't have what we used to have with Ed Koch, the instantaneous reaction to almost every single event that was taking place in the city, and that sometimes exacerbated the tensions."
"On the other hand," Mr. Rivera added, "he has seemed kind of indecisive. There is a growing perception among the people in labor that he's paying too much attention to the Wall Street community and the bond raters and not enough to the working people of New York."
Douglas H. Lasdon, executive director of the Legal Action Center for the Homeless, sees a lack of imagination.
"There's a sense of vision, or courage or bold and creative ideas that is missing," Mr. Lasdon said. "I think when presented with alternative ideas, he can pick the decent idea. But they haven't come up with anything bold, and there are plenty of ideas out there and not all of them cost money."
By the same token, Mr. Lasdon said, the Mayor "has taken progressive, smart and energetic people and hired them in key places, and that difference for us means that we can have civil and constructive negotiations with them." He added, however, "it doesn't translate into anything because the big ideas have to come from the top."
The Mayor's chief political aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, said he was as disappointed as anyone that so many of Mr. Dinkins's goals had had to be deferred. "We were hoping we could have the same level of resources that our predecessor had to work with and try to implement some of the Mayor's programs," he said.
Mr. Dinkins himself said, "There are many more things that I'd hoped to accomplish, especially in the area of human services, that just plain cost money."
But he and Mr. Lynch say that the administration is not trying to please the financial community at the expense of other constituents.
"It isn't like currying favor," Mr. Lynch said. "Their confidence in the administration has an impact on our ability to sell bonds, and if our rating is lowered, that can have a tremendous impact on revenues because we'll have to pay more to borrow, which means there's less for the city to do the things people want us to do."
 
'I Haven't Forgotten'
 The Mayor said: "I haven't forgotten who got me elected. But who got me elected isn't relevant to what one has the ability to do with the money that's available."
In a host of ways, Mr. Dinkins's ability to make a difference has been limited by the economic downturn that his own advisers call a crisis. For example, Barbara J. Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, said the administration would have adopted a more restrictive policy toward real-estate development than the Koch administration had, if it were operating in the same economic climate that fostered a decade-long building boom.
As it is, she said, the administration is eager to spur the economy, and there is so little development that possible differences in policy are irrelevant. The city's own plans for building long-term projects have also slowed.
"These are times when it would be good to have publicly funded projects to stimulate the economy," she said. "But because of our need to get our debt-service costs down, we're even cutting our capital budget," so the city will not need to borrow as much.
Perhaps the Mayor's most visible successes were luring the 1992 Democratic National Convention to the city, which he hopes will generate $100 million in revenue, and presiding over the visit of Nelson Mandela in June. He has also sought to expand affirmative-action programs for city employees, expand opportunities for small and minority-owned contractors, lure more foreign business, provide drug treatment on demand for pregnant women and make other changes.
"If all we were going to do was run a scaled-down version of the Koch government, I wouldn't be interested in staying," Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said. "The improvements will be smaller, but they'll be there."
David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society, a nonprofit social service organization, said: "I think everyone recognizes that we're all sort of riding this roller coaster downward. I think what we're hoping for out of the Dinkins administration is that it can lead an attack, on a Federal level, to get more support."
 
'You Can't Let People Despair'
 "To talk about further economies with disadvantaged populations is to make sure that you're going to set up a chain reaction of social pathologies that I think will have a hell of a lot more detrimental impact on New York than we can imagine."
"The next step has to be not only to inspire confidence in the financial markets, but also in the least among us," Mr. Jones said. "You can't let people despair, and that's going to be the critical issue for all of us."
Mr. Jones said other officials must join in the fight for more Federal aid. "I haven't seen anyone do anything but point the finger at David Dinkins, and that becomes unacceptable."
Mr. Dinkins said that much was expected of him, in part because his core supporters had felt largely alienated from the previous administration. But he rejected any suggestion that his term would not be worthwhile if there was no money to spend, and he set the challenge for himself.
"It takes a lot more skill and energy and hard work to move ahead in difficult times, so it is well worth it."

HEADLINE: Resales Of Homes Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes, helped by falling mortgage rates, edged up 3 percent in November for the first increase since August, a real estate trade group said today.
The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes climbed to a seasonally adjusted rate of 3.14 million units in November, following declines of 3.8 percent in October and 9.4 percent in September. 
 The sales rate in October was a weak 3.05 million units.
Analysts said the slight improvement was a result of declines in mortgage rates. Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages have fallen to 9.64 percent, the lowest in three years.
Rates had edged up after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But in recent weeks, mortgage rates declined as the Federal Reserve moved aggressively to fight a stagnant economy with lower interest rates.
The median price for a home in November was $91,300, down 1.7 percent from the level in October and down 1.9 percent from the median price a year ago.
The November sales increase was led by strength in the South and West. Sales in the South jumped 7.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.32 million units, while sales in the West were up 2 percent, to an annual rate of 500,000 units.
Sales continued to slump in the Northeast, however, falling 2 percent, to an annual rate of 490,000 units, down 17 percent from a year ago. Sales in the Midwest were unchanged in November from the October sales rate of 820,000 units.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Quiet Trading; Gold and Silver Prices Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower yesterday in quiet post-holiday trading.
Gold and silver prices rose, meanwhile, with gold for current delivery settling at $385.60 a troy ounce, up $3.10 from late Friday on the New York Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $384.20 an ounce, $2.95 higher than Friday. Silver settled at $4.095 a troy ounce on New York's Comex, up 7 cents from Friday. 
 New York precious metals markets were closed Monday and Tuesday in observance of the Christmas holiday.
Most financial markets in Europe, Hong Kong and Canada remained closed yesterday for an extended holiday.
Currency dealers said profit taking after Monday's rally was largely responsible for the dollar's decline. But they said market sentiment toward the dollar remained strong amid continued political and economic unrest overeas.
"Tensions in the Soviet Union and the Middle East continue to provide support for the dollar," said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president and trader for the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
Mr. Johnson said trading was sluggish, with most dollar brokers reluctant to do any major buying or selling since the overseas markets were closed.
In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar closed at 136.25 yen, up 0.30 yen from Tuesday's close. The dollar stood at 136.10 yen in New York, up from 136.00 yen Monday.
The dollar was down against the British pound, with sterling fetching $1.8815, vs. $1.8685 Monday.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.53475, from 1.5453 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.30825 Swiss francs, down from 1.3160; 5.2080 French francs, down from 5.2515; 1,155.00 Italian lire, down from 1,164.00, and 1.15945 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1600.
