HEADLINE: Suriname Coup Leaders Had Power Already

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
By seizing power in a bloodless coup on Monday, the Surinamese armed forces were merely formalizing their increasingly apparent control over the country, human rights advocates, Western diplomats and academics who follow the country's affairs say.
They say that after a civilian Government was elected in the former Dutch colony in 1987, ending the seven-year military Government of Comdr. Desi Bouterse, he used his military command, which he retained, to usurp civilian authority and regain dominance over the country's affairs. 
 In recent months, Commander Bouterse effectively vetoed Government initiatives in peace negotiations with leaders of a four-year old guerrilla insurgency, and publicly warned that his soldiers would do nothing to discourage looting if President Ramsewak Shankar carried out strong austerity measures to slow uncontrolled inflation and restore growth to an economy in steep decline.
Critics of the military have been mysteriously murdered or have simply disappeared, creating an atmosphere of fear in which few Surinamese have been willing to speak out about perceived army abuses.
"Our feeling is that he didn't have todo this because he has had power for some time now," a Western diplomat, reached by telephone in the Surinamese capital, Paramaribo, said of Commander Bouterse's seizure of power. "His ability to manipulate things was already near-complete. But by taking over formally, he has plunged the country into isolation."
The United States called for the immediate restoration of the civilian Government, while Suriname's former colonial master, the Netherlands, suspended all financial aid. Last year, the Netherlands provided about $50 million in aid.
Although he resigned his commandof the army on Sunday, saying he could no longer work for a Government that "exposes the dignity of the nation to ridicule," foreign diplomats and Surinamese observers said that Commander Bouterse remains firmly in charge of the military and was the clear mastermind of the coup.
Commander Bouterse, a 45-year-old former track star who led a coup by noncommissioned officers in 1980, resigned his command, but not his commission, shortly after returning to Suriname from a private trip to Ghana and Switzerland. His connecting flights passed through Amsterdam, and while he was on Dutch soil officials isolated him from the press and other visitors.
When he returned to Suriname, an indignant Commander Bouterse announced his resignation, castigating President Shankar, who coincidentallytraveled on the same flights to and from the Netherlands, as a "joker" for not having protested his treatment by Dutch authorities.
The next evening, with soldiers occupying radio and television stations, Comdr. Ivan Graanoogst, the leader of the military police and a close associate of Commander Bouterse, announced that the army had "taken over political power" and would hold new elections within 100 days.
A spokesman for the Surinamese Army, Borger Breefield, in an interview with Radio Netherlands denied that Commander Bouterse was now running the country, saying the former commander was "at home relaxing."
"It was not really a military coup," Mr. Breefield said of the army's seizure of power. "Within a week a caretaker government will be installed witha mission of organizing secret, free and fair elections."
But civic and human rights groups in Suriname have condemned the army's takeover and have urged Parliament not to cooperate with any militarily appointed Government.
"If they hold fair elections the results will be the same as in 1987, because the majority of the people are against the military," said Else Labadie, a banker who heads the Organization for Peace and Justice, a civic group that has called for the army to remove itself from politics. In the last elections, Commander Bouterse's party was badly defeated.
"When they took power in 1980 they promised elections right away and it took seven years," Mrs. Labadie said. "Now they have it back and nobody believes they will give it up soon."
